I have a public message for all.....

THANKYOU!!

I would like to make a special thank you to all of the people who speak =
out on this list.  You have given me something to think about in times =
where good conversation is hard to find.  I do thoroughly enjoy the =
conflicting view points often expressed on the list, especially because =
I do not necessarily agree with them all.  DIVERSITY OF OPINION IS =
GOOD!!  It is a right we all have that we must NOT down play!  We are =
all very lucky to live in a place where it is acceptable to display =
contrary thought.  I urge all of you silent ones out there(yes I know =
you are out there! :)) to speak thine mind and let us know what you =
think.  Life is so much more interesting if we have something to speak =
of, no?

p.s.  I do NOT encourage flame wars, merely free conversation.  Please =
take mine, and countless other people's advice and think before you =
post.  :)

Just be carfull because someone will flame you for that post.
Ridiculous isn't it? Flaming a positive post.
They will tear that terrific post apart and twist your words around so
it sounds like you are racist or sexist when you didn't even say
anythign like that at all. If people start to flame you, go ahead and
flame them right back. They will respond, it's just about getting the
last word in. So just simply reply with.
"WOW you're cool because you think differntly than me."
or
"I never knew that. You're smart"
Then it makes them feel stupid.
I personally don't enjoy getting picked on for a post that had nothing
to do with their accusations.
I wish that all the ravers on this list that enjoy flame wars would
un-subscribe or at least not post. Then their would be better vibes on
SFRaves. Hey, it could happen.
"Yeah, and ecstacy will fly out of my but"(<---JOKE do not flame)
So good luck with life and remember...
Rave On!
not
Flame On!

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id NAA06701; Sat, 1 Mar 1997 13:02:07 -0800 (PST)
Received: from holonet.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id NAA06696; Sat, 1 Mar 1997 13:02:03 -0800 (PST)

	id NAA02692; Sat, 1 Mar 1997 13:02:02 -0800

Received: by impactsf.com (Claris OfficeMail 1.0) with SMTP; Sat, 01 Mar 1997 11:54:23 -0800
From: "Andre Lucero" <Andre@impactsf.com>
Subject: Re: Keepin' it fresh
Date: Sat, 1 Mar 97 11:48:11 -0800
x-mailer: Claris Emailer 1.1
To: "David Minuk" <davidmin@wco.com>, <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>
>I have been a raver for 5 or 6 years now and have often had to face
>the possibility of burnout.  I am wondering how other people manage to
>stay enthused with raving while others move on to other things(not
>that that's necessarily bad).  One thing I like to do is have a unique
>"theme" to meditate on while dancing at each party. When my mind
>wanders I return to my "theme" in an attempt to gain insight into the
>subject.  Here are some of the things I have thought of:
>
>Helping out or putting on your own parties.  Very fun but it carries
>its own burnout/disillusionment factor.
>
>Traveling to other areas.  I have traveled around N. America and
>England but don't have the resources to do so right now.  The recent
>descriptions of LA sound enticing, however.
>
>Trying out new scenes.  Been to a jungle or goa party?
>
>Does anyone have any other suggestions?
>
Try being extremely selective when choosing a party.  This means you are 
not *required* to go out every weekend.  Find out what DJ's/live acts 
make you feel best when dancing.  Also, going to parties to hear DJ's you 
have never heard before can be an educating and enjoyable experience.  If 
you listen to the same six DJ's every time you go out, I can't think of a 
quicker way to get burned out.

Drugs can get boring too -- even psychedelics.  If you do drugs, save 
them for a particular time and place.  And if that party is not living up 
to your expectations, don't feel like you have to do them.  No one *has* 
to do drugs.  I find that I typically have a better time and remember the 
evening more if I stay sober.  I can fall into deeper trance states on 
the dancefloor when I am sober if the DJ/artist is creating a good vibe 
and telling a story that takes me to other worlds.

Eat light, take naps, feel the music.  Try not to be critical of the 
people around you.  Even if you have been going for years, you too were 
new to underground dance music and events at one point in time.  I'm not 
saying that this was any way implied by your post, but I see that in a 
lot of people who have been going to parties for quite some time.  If I 
remember how things were when I started going out, people were quite 
receptive to new people and influences and MUSIC.

One thing I do enjoy is travelling, but especially to cities with newer 
or fresher(literal) scenes.  People in smaller scenes remind me of how 
wonderful it can be just to escape to a world of kind people, DIFFERENT 
music and spiritual release through dance.  These scenes are not far.  
Almost all big cities have scenes.  Most of the smaller cities have them 
too.  If you can grab onto the excitement of these people, it is like 
being reborn (almost).  You do have to find this feeling yourself, but 
seeing it helps.
- Dre

Set Phaser to )))Vibrate(((


************************************************************
* Andre Lucero                           fax: 415-252-5958 *
* Impact Lighting                      phone: 415-252-1182 *
* 1550 Seventeenth Street                    extension #17 *
* San Francisco, CA 94107       web site: www.impactsf.com *
************************************************************

> ....  What I particuarly DON"T LIKE is the feeling of
>> forced sexuality I get when a promoter purposley puts girls in cages or
>> skimpily clad girls on stage to dance. 


The last couple of times that I've been to parties where I have seen cages,
the cages have just /been there/, and people have had the option to dance in
them or not dance in them.   But I guess sometimes the promoters hire people
to do it, huh?

I, too, feel a bit uncomfortable being nearby when it's going on, but I
guess it makes people feel sexy, and I guess there's nothing wrong about
that.   Kinda like the whole S&M thing.  I don't understand  it; and
probably won't ever ask anyone to give my bum a spankin', but some people
get a kick out of it.

Last weekend my band played at this party called the Burning P*ssy,   (they
were Burning Man folks throwing the party), and the highlight of the show
was a woman dancing around  and thrusting her crotch, which had a sparkler
mounted to it.  I didn't understand it, and I don't understand the whole
Burning Man desire to burn things, but then again, most people don't
understand why ravers dance till the sun comes up, so I need to give 'em
some slack.   I don't think there's anything wrong with being sexy or
show-offy, but I agree that raves are  probably not an appropiate place to
do it.

But then again, my Mum, living up in Puritan New England, would think that
woman who wear "belly button shirts", like some ravers do,  is "sl*tty".  So
I guess it's all personal opinion, you know?

A bientot, Alligator.

b))merang

i just thought maybe someone might be interested in this story brought to you
from the marvelous news service of America On Line ;-)

     14 Overdose at Teen Dance 

   Fourteen children aged 12 to 17 are in Boston-area hospitals today after
apparently overdosing on a muscle relaxant last night at a dance, police
said. Hospital officials say ten of the victims, mostly girls, are in serious
condition, many of them on life-support systems. Police found some of the
muscle relaxants, called baclosen, and an empty bottle at the ``Teen
Supreme'' dance at the Boys and Girls Club in Woburn, Mass., about 20 miles
north of Boston. Police were investigating how the children got the drug,
which one hospital official said is commonly used to treat multiple
sclerosis.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Mar  1 18:38:53 1997

Subject: Re: GHB Legal Status
Date: Sat, 1 Mar 97 20:54:11 -0600
x-sender: alexr@mail.bungie.com

From: Alex Rosenberg <alexr@bungie.com>

        "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>For those in California who happen to have an interest in 
>legal actions
>
>regarding drugs, there are bills pending to change the scheduling of GHB
>to schedule 1. There are lots of pro's and cons to the use of this
>substance but I for one don't believe that this drug has near the abuse
>potential of other schedule 1 (most dangerous) drugs. Schedule 1 drugs
>are specifically classified as such because of their abuse potential and
>total lack of medicinal use (oddly, Marijuana is still schedule 1).
>Although there is potential for abuse, there is a wealth of positive
>applications.

The other night on the news here in Chicago (they have a web page at 
<http://www.nbc5.com> but the HealthWatch area doesn't have this story 
yet) was the announcement of a new report from one of the local 
universities (U.I. Chicago perhaps?). The study was in the use of small 
amounts of GHB to aid in improving sleep for the elderly. They're trying 
to link the extended deep sleep time that GHB provides to improved cell 
regrowth. (Basically, they were saying that controlled use in this manner 
could help extend life expectency by encouraging the body to repair 
itself better as it does during youth.)

Anybody seriously interested in this issue should probably make sure that 
a copy of the report lands in the hands of the politicians involved. They 
would definately not be trying to schedule a "fountain of youth" drug.

|  Bungie Software          <http://www.bungie.com>  |
|  Nobody cares what I say.                          |

> SPEAK!

inexperienced poster with absolutly no idea on how to embrace 
diversity, will get you flamed really quickly. Especially as you have no 
right to try to censor people. Expressing your opinions are one thing, 
but telling anyone who disagrees with you to shut up is rude and 
immature. Again, grow up.

 Embracing diversity means (among other things) being humble enough to 
entertain the idea that you may be wrong and someone else may be right.

peas and hominy.

Well, I am home right now, just kickin it in my room....I hope everyone is
having the time of their life at Warmth/Analog/Basics or wherever you ended
up...I wanted to go to Analog, but after realizing that Choice...San
Francisco was throwing Basics, thats where I'd really want to be.....but oh
well, there'll be another party next weekend. There'll always be another
party, but the experience is always unique to each and every party I go to.
I keep a log of all the parties I have gone to, what substances I took, and
where the party was, and its a trip to look back and reminis. Places I have
gone and people I have seen. I keep a flyer collection as well, and I love
looking through the pages of all the parties I have gone to. "The rave that
never happened" or "The rave that I got hooked up at" or "my first rave or
UG". So much stuff goes down chasing parties. Its such an adventure. Right
now I am listening to my PHAT Jeno tape (Come-Unity 4-3-96), and it brings
back memories of The Gathering back in Sping '96. That night was definitly
an adventure. Take care everyone.

Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970302043831.3992A-100000@atari>

Precedence: bulk

Hey people -

Negativity follows.

I have very bad things to say about Space Children right now, but am going
to endeavour to be diplomatic.  Here is what my evening was like:

At 8pm, Sarah & I have tickets to Space Children's "Analog" and am excited
- I've not been to a large party in ages, and the lineup looks great, and
Space Children has a good reputation.

The voicemail is reassuring - to paraphrase, "people with presale tickets
will be guaranteed a place in our party", "advance ticket holders won't
have to wait in line", etc.

We decided to take a nap.  It had been a long day, and we wanted to have
lots of energy for the night.  So after a long nap, by the time we were
ready to go to the party it was about 1:30.  Just to be safe, I called the
voicemail - it contained a somewhat apologetic sounding message which
stated that they had closed the doors at 1am, and were no longer letting
anyone in.

Thinking surely they couldn't be referring to advance ticket holders, we
headed down there anyway.  Bad idea.  We were not only turned away, but we
were given NO apology, NO explanation, NO refund, NO chance to talk to 
a promoter or anyone otherwise affiliated with the organization of the 
event, and were treated rudely by the bouncers.  We witnessed the same
thing happening to several other presale ticket holders, as well, and were
FAR from impressed.

I understand that bad things happen from time to time - for all I know,
Space Children had a very good reason not to let anyone in after 1am.  But
"we were hoping everyone would get there before 1" (the current voicemail
apology) is not a good enough excuse for me.  For twenty dollars, I
deserve at least an explanation of why I was stranded downtown.

So space children:

 . If you oversold, own up to it.  If there's some other explanation, I
   want to hear it.
 . Don't hide behind rude, ignorant security guards.  If you're going to
   turn people away, do it face to face, and have explanations, apologies,
   and refunds on hand.
 . Don't expect to see me at any of your future events.
 . Feel free to call me, I'd love to talk about this.  (415) 552-4105,
   leave a message.
 . Update your stupid web page ;)  <-- ok, that wasn't so diplomatic :)

Nonetheless, I hope it was a good party.  Hope everyone had fun, who got
in.

On a more positive note, we stopped by Warmth while we were down there,
and it looked awesome.  Wish I'd chosen more wisely, but live & learn.

Take care all, thanks for listening, & see you around.

: : J. David Lowe : dlowe@saturn5.com : http://saturn5.com/~dlowe/ : :
:       "... that's what life is all about, finding a balloon        :
:            and loving it."             - Jay Parsons               :
 :: fingerprint: 1F E7 D3 24 04 18 72 67   CC E6 66 1B 79 79 CB 3A ::

Subject: Shine (review)

I'm feeling very shiny in the surprising morning sunshine, and want to give
props to Gateway for reminding us that they know how to do things right,
the NYE glitch being just that.

The VM didn't go on until after 10, but it was a good new map point for the
space and Susan, Paula & I crossed the Bay Bridge & got there just about
11.
Re Ach was doing some of his heavy jungle in the back/ambient room, and
after he was done, there was Joe Rice in the ambient & John Carel in the
main -- sweet!  It was the least hot dance floor I've been to at this
space, as the party wasn't too crowded and the fans seemed to work.  The
psychedelic art, lasers & lights were great as usual, and the beautiful
tarot space was a nice touch.  The vibe was thick, and the crowd was an
excellent mix.  Although I usually am a trooper to the end, we all left at
almost 5 with the party still raging for some rest and quiet reflection.

I'm now becoming satisfied by coffee and waiting for a World Cup soccer
qualifying morning, Canada at Mexico at 10 and U.S. at Jamaica (!) at noon,
only en Espanol on Channel 14.

leftjab

"Sun is Shining
the Weather is Sweet
Makes You Want to Move
Your Dancing Feet"

Precedence: bulk


Well, I'm back. That didn't last too long, eh? 

Wayne once said something that I agree with: Sfraves is not a 12 step
program don't treat it like one. However I must say that all the
compassion, caring and good advice that many of you offered my way is
*very* deeply appreciated, and it really my opened my eyes to something
that I was forgetting, that when you get past all the B.S. on the list(yes
guilty as charged myself) there are really some very warm, compassionate
people who give a damn about the well-being of others, even total
strangers. And that is the beauty of raving for me, a feeling of love and
support. Sometimes it can be hard to see, as one has a tendancy to get
jaded over the years and can't see certain things for what they really
are. I just wanted to say *THANK YOU* to everyone for reopening my eyes
to this simple truth.

Further, I am going to make a promise to try to be nicer here. How's that
for a shocker?(sorry the sarcasm stays as part of the deal.) Actually I
think about 5 other people on the list would do well to exchange this
simple promise between themselves and keep to it. Of course it is not my
place to say that you should or should not flame-the-hell-out-of-someone-for
-something-stupid-they-said, especially given some of the really stupid
things people say sometimes. But I guess the real question is "What good
does it do?" Occasionally something productive will come out of such
exchanges, but more often than not a series of "I'm right, you're wrong
and you are a (racist/bigot/homophobe) as well." So there goes an hour of
your life composing a message that the person on the other end is not so
much listening to as ready to strike-counterstrike or simply ignore. Net
result *0* unless you count the artificial ego inflation value. And again,
I am the first to admit that I have been very guilty of the above in the
past, but am going to try to work on it. One thing I would ask of folks is
that they think about they are saying before shoving a message on to
hyperreal. If you are going to offer "facts" on a given subject, make sure
you have those facts right? Consider going back into the archives and see
what others have said on that subject. A lot of the same, in my
experience. The list can be very repetitve at times with things like
Strychnine in LSD and Heroin in E, and many other things that have already
been said. Want to get into a race war on the list? Consider looking back
into the archives to get those warm tender feelings of animosity. It's all
there, it's all pretty much been said before. 

Well, thanks again for your compassion, love, and support. It's amazing
listening to others stories of people that they have lost(thanks for
sharing.) Many people have endured far worse things with relationships
breaking up, and they all seemed to have survived. 

I *will* see more of you out more, as I am going to be going out more...
Anyone want to give a no-rhythm white boy some stepping lessons? I have
been doing this for 5 years, and I still can't dance to techno.. :(
 
                                      Patrick(Black Adder is on holiday 
                                              right now)

This is the most awesome _rave_ i've been to this year.  This is how a
_rave_ should be thrown.  I feel much better now after that UnCool
World make-up gangsterfest which made me feel totally depressed for a
whole week after.  Now I'm back to my bouncy happy self.  Much props to
Spencer and Deepfog for throwing such an awesome _rave_ and I hope this
would be an example that the rest would follow.

The vibe was totally there, the DJ's were sooo rad, and everyone was nice 
and cuddly (just the way a raver should be!) and pretty much a lot of 
the people there know what raving is all about and guess what?  A lot of 
the people who attended were SFRavers and they all asked for SFR 
Laminates.  For those of you who got them please wear them proudly and 
for those who don't Orson will make some more and give it away to the 
next party he goes to and I will make sure that those who asked me for 
laminates and didn't get one will have one.  

Much love to EVERYONE who went to this awesome _rave_.  I've met soo many 
new faces and I'm sitting here trying to associate names with those 
faces.  Don't worry, I'll figure it out. =] For those of you who can't 
remember me (it happens), I'm the small filipino with the black visor 
and I was mostly hanging out with neat-o people by the tent in the chill 
room.  This is also the FIRST time i've met a raver who actually lives in 
the same city as i do (Vallejo) and is just about a few houses away from 
me and he happens to be one of the kewlest, the nicest, and the sweetest 
raver you'll ever meet.  Props to Pablo, he is the man!  


Love,
Anthony E

From: "Matt Davison" <mattd@cwnet.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Shine (quick review)
Date: Sun, 2 Mar 1997 15:37:30 -0600
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Priority: 3
X-Mailer: Microsoft Internet Mail 4.70.1155
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I had just an awsome saturday!!  I don't have time to talk to share it all
and talk about Shine too so i'll just fast foreward to about 9:00 pm last
night..... After a long afternoon of wandering S.F. compulsivly buying a
few things on borrowed cash ( i'll pay off my tab Anthony...soon ;) I ended
up at the beach (burrrr, it was cold!!) with my good friends Anthony and
Mac and our new friend Joe from Davis.  Just killing time talking, waiting
for the voice message to be updated.  We made it to the doors of Shine
sometime around 11:00, the dance studio was decked out like i've never seen
it before!!  Some really cool banners, trippy video projections and a funky
green laser shooting across the room.  Small crowd, just the right number
of people.  The chill room was just that with the airconditioning churning
out cold air at full blast.  I spent most most of my night in the chill
room (never actually chill'in, only sat down for a short while) groovin
from mad jungle to smooth breaks.  I made a few trips to the main room and
caught the beginning of Ehtan's set; got some snapshots of the man at work.
 
I was the stubborn guy who wouldn't take off his backpack, blinding
everyone with the camera flash.  It was a night worth adding to my rave
photo album.  The music and the vibe kept me awake and wired the entire
night but with my last group of friends cutting out (my last chance for a
ride home) I called it a night at 6:00... well 7:30, it's a long drive
home. 
To Summerize: great party!!  

Matt

Received: from localhost (blkadder@localhost) by value.net (8.8.4/8.7.3) with SMTP id QAA23313 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 2 Mar 1997 16:19:01 -0800 (PST)
Date: Sun, 2 Mar 1997 16:19:00 -0800 (PST)
Reply-To: blkadder@value.net
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Review: Warmth and Shine
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970302155544.21753A-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Anyone get the sense that there was some kind of sun theme this week from
the above named parties?

Warmth:

Fucking *fabulous* space. Well ventilated, the main system was downstairs
so they didn't run the risk of upsetting the po-po. The decorations were
wonderful, including Leslie Ayers beautiful(if somewhat minimalistic) 
altar. The crew(don't really know who) had their stuff together. The crowd
was definitely younger, and really nice. About an hour and a half into it
someone mentioned that there was a Gateway party going on which I hadn't
heard about. Being that I didn't really know anyone at Warmth(although
maybe I should have stayed and met more folks) I headed over to Gateway.

Gateway:

The dance studio. However it was *really* well ventilated this time,
almost to the point of being cold in the chill room(really was a chill
room.) Gateway of course has their killer sound system, so sound was
great. It was actually fairly lightly populated last night, but comfy none
the less. Decorations were good as usual. The music in the main room was a
little spotty, but I wasn't in the main room most of the night. Heard some
decent jungle from Rich and Joe Rice, a bit different than what I have
been hearing, which has been the same dull, repetative beat in every
single song. It was a pleasant departure. The people of course were
wonderful and I got to see a couple of new sfraves faces. All in all a
great night. It is a good sign to go to multiple parties, and feel safe
and really comfortable at both.

          by atari.saturn5.com (8.8.4/8.8.4)
	  id RAA06536; Sun, 2 Mar 1997 17:30:16 -0800 (PST)
Date: Sun, 2 Mar 1997 17:30:16 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <199703030130.RAA06536@atari.saturn5.com>
From: Steve Simitzis <steve@saturn5.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: space children & gateway
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


(negative review of Space Children followed by glowing review
of Gateway. film at 11)

Well, after hearing about so many people getting turned away at the
Space Children party, I can only say that aside from my deep regret
about losing your money ($20 is a lot of money to blow on a party),
feel happy you didn't get in, because this was not a great party. (I
even heard that Jonas Sharp was denied enterance at the door, and was
left standing outside with a big box of records. Not cool.)

Forturnately, Elise and I arrived as guests of Wayne (otherwise I
would have not gone, in accordance to my "pay no more than $15" rule),
only to find dance areas sparsely filled with random people looking
completely bored, hallways filled with people looking lost, wandering
from room to room, pushing and shoving in the sportswear room (oops, I
mean "house room") between two children who thought they were still in
their high school locker room (they weren't), and other kids standing
in the stairwells shouting out random letters of the alphabet all
night ("X!" "X!" "E!").

Of course, the total lack of vibe wasn't my biggest complaint. I was
more bothered by the *terrible* sound quality in the drum&bass room
(which was the reason that I, and many other people that I knew, had
come). If the promoters of this party are reading this, please follow
my advice:

make sure that whoever mixed the sound for the jungle room is REMOVED
from the sound engineering profession!

That was the WORST, most PAINFULLY excruciating attempt at sound
reproduction that I have ever experienced in my entire life. I have
been going to raves, punk rock clubs, played in a hardcore band, and
have been regularly blasting my ears with headphones for years and
years, and nothing could match the level of sonic pain from last
night. If that person's idea of EQ'ing is turning the volume as the
loud as it can go in a highly reflective room, then he/she has a *lot*
to learn. Muddy bass and sloppy snare rolls just doesn't sound like
music to me. Call me picky. ;)

Anyway, after realizing that we weren't having a good time, we left
and went straight to Gateway. Ah... 180 degree difference. Just as
soon as I was greeted at the door by the Gateway people, I remembered
why I love undergroud parties... No surly security people yelling at
me that I'm not using the right door to leave, no pushing, no shoving,
no degrading body searches, just good vibes.

We had no tickets, had missed the map point, and we were short $10 for
admission, but they still let us in, with a smile and a "have a good
time!". On the way upstairs (I love the dance studio!), I was greeted
by so many of my favorite raver friends everywhere, and even many
people that had also bailed from Space Children. I also saw the C-Lab
people again... Good thing they double-booked.

The main dance area was decorated beautifully. Probably the best use
of Gateway lasers, lights and projections that I have seen in a long
time. And there were just the right amount of people in the dance
area. Just enough people to get a good vibe going, but not too many so
as to remove all available oxygen from the room (a common problem in
the dance studio).

Most of my time was spent in the chill room (the red laser in the
crystal was really beautiful, btw) listening to C-Lab. I was really
impressed with their new stuff. Their IDM influences really
complemented the drum&bass sound they were after. Very nice! :)

Okay, I've ranted and raved enough for one post...

Steve

--

There is no doubt in my mind that this was a good party.
Beautiful (and I mean it) Chill room with excellent decorations. So
relaxing. Incredibly Chill. And bathrooms!! That's very essential.
Grrrrrrrrreat music. The most of it anyone. Micron blew me away with his
great selections and insane buildups. And although I really don't like
jugnle the jungle played there was good.

The one thing that I did find strange about it was the vibe. Although it
was a good one, there were two differnt vibes altogether, I thought.
It was like upsatirs was a vibe set by Spiritual Ravers and downstairs
was one set by Happy Ravers. They were both good, it's just that it
sorta felt like a very strange transition while walking up the stairs.
It seemed like the both of the good vibes were sorta debating it out to
control the rave. Then (as always with good raves) around the end, the
vibe turned into a family type vibe.

That's just how many and a many other ravers there percieved it.

Still...
Great job (whoever) for a super duper coolio fun party.
Good location too. I hear everyone's gonna be renting it out a lot.

Love.Luck.Lollipops,
P.S. Hello all you cool SFRavers that were at warmth. You guys are cool.
I FINALLY met Leslie. One terrrrrific lady. She is so nice. I love her.
Doesn't everybody?

The party rocked! The location was excellant! The music was excellant.
Everything was excellant! After reading all the posts by other people about
the various parties they went to, I have something to say about the party
that I went to! =) First off, I really don't know of any other promoter who
can put on a party better then Martin. He had FREE organic food, ( that
tasted excellant!!! THANKS DANA!!!) and there was plenty of water and drinks
and one could refill their bottle in the bathroom or drinking fountain. There
was plenty of spacee to relax. The dance area kinda got crowded but never
really got to crowded. As far as sound, the mkusic was excellant and the bass
was thumping! There was a mirror ball, and a few lights and some blacklight
banners and a few strobes. Seems like Martin always gets a kick out of
turning the dance area into a dark room then fireing up the strobes and
melting your head!!! I loved it. Nothing to complain about. Nobody turned
away. So many friendly people with smiles all night long. The choice crew
really has it togeather! Kenny Hawkes spun some sick house!! Seemed like he
had a few bumpy mixes but his music selection more then made up for it. Did I
hear some poonjabi?? Josh closeing things up!!! He p[layed some sick toons
also. Simon played some disco that really was dope. Tony had the palce
rocking as soon as people got there! Tracy seemed to be attracting all the
people zoocked out of there mind! This one kid was playing the mirror game
with Tracy. She would move left, he would move left. She would raise her
hand, he would raise here hand. He probably was having a really great time
but it was cool cause he backed up a little and gave tracy some breathing
room. her set was really good too. I have heard parts of her set before, but
i listened to most of it last night and she had the whole place moving!!!  10
stars!!!!!

Peace,
Jonathan

On the voicemail the said they were selling 2200 presales tix and that the
doors would probably close. 

I was dissapointed when they kicked us out at 5am.... pretending that the
police were the reason. The REAL reason was that the Maritime hall has a
5am curfew. A lot of bullshit was talked about the police and fire
department.

I loved the party! It was soooo fucking awesome. Caesar was bomb, Dutch
thew down, and I ran into a lot of friends. I must say that this was one
of the good ones. 

If there was a prized to be given, I received it. I got a t-shirt, and 2
tapes.... each time they threw something out my long ass arms grabbed one.
I bet people were beginning to hate me!... but I'm 6'2, what can I say!

If any of yous are planning on going to parities and need a ride from the
concord/martinez area e-mail me. Even if you're not from concord/martinez
we could arange something. I love going in groups!

On Sun, 2 Mar 1997, David Lowe wrote:

> Hey people -
> 
> Negativity follows.
> 
> I have very bad things to say about Space Children right now, but am going
> to endeavour to be diplomatic.  Here is what my evening was like:
> 
> At 8pm, Sarah & I have tickets to Space Children's "Analog" and am excited
> - I've not been to a large party in ages, and the lineup looks great, and
> Space Children has a good reputation.
> 
> The voicemail is reassuring - to paraphrase, "people with presale tickets
> will be guaranteed a place in our party", "advance ticket holders won't
> have to wait in line", etc.
> 
> We decided to take a nap.  It had been a long day, and we wanted to have
> lots of energy for the night.  So after a long nap, by the time we were
> ready to go to the party it was about 1:30.  Just to be safe, I called the
> voicemail - it contained a somewhat apologetic sounding message which
> stated that they had closed the doors at 1am, and were no longer letting
> anyone in.
> 
> Thinking surely they couldn't be referring to advance ticket holders, we
> headed down there anyway.  Bad idea.  We were not only turned away, but we
> were given NO apology, NO explanation, NO refund, NO chance to talk to 
> a promoter or anyone otherwise affiliated with the organization of the 
> event, and were treated rudely by the bouncers.  We witnessed the same
> thing happening to several other presale ticket holders, as well, and were
> FAR from impressed.
> 
> I understand that bad things happen from time to time - for all I know,
> Space Children had a very good reason not to let anyone in after 1am.  But
> "we were hoping everyone would get there before 1" (the current voicemail
> apology) is not a good enough excuse for me.  For twenty dollars, I
> deserve at least an explanation of why I was stranded downtown.
> 
> So space children:
> 
>  . If you oversold, own up to it.  If there's some other explanation, I
>    want to hear it.
>  . Don't hide behind rude, ignorant security guards.  If you're going to
>    turn people away, do it face to face, and have explanations, apologies,
>    and refunds on hand.
>  . Don't expect to see me at any of your future events.
>  . Feel free to call me, I'd love to talk about this.  (415) 552-4105,
>    leave a message.
>  . Update your stupid web page ;)  <-- ok, that wasn't so diplomatic :)
> 
> Nonetheless, I hope it was a good party.  Hope everyone had fun, who got
> in.
> 
> On a more positive note, we stopped by Warmth while we were down there,
> and it looked awesome.  Wish I'd chosen more wisely, but live & learn.
> 
> Take care all, thanks for listening, & see you around.
>

I would appreciate it if you two would not use my posts as weapons.  I =
was trying to get a message out to everyone, not provide you with =
ammunition for your own personal fights.  I don't enjoy the bitter =
sarcasm (don't deny it's existence) on this list.   A few months ago, =
when I first heard about the SFRaves list, I was really jazzed about it =
because I thought that it meant that I would have the opportunity to =
meet many cool people, discuss many interesting ideas, and generally =
keep in touch with the scene when I could not go out to play.  I have =
met many interesting people, have had lots of fun, and have heard many =
interesting discussions.  However, the people who told me about the list =
warned me as well.  They warned me about the vicious infighting that was =
going on almost constantly for a bit of time.  Before I started posting, =
I downloaded a section of the SFRaves archive and browsed through it for =
a while.  I bore witness to the numerous fights between various people(I =
will refrain from mentioning names because I wish to let old furies lay =
to rest).  These postings disturbed me because it was not what I had =
envisioned from the people in the scene whom I all know(and hope to =
meet) and love.  I was disillusioned to say the least.   I realize that =
it is easier to start a flame war via the nets because you are not face =
to face with your "adversary."   This is no excuse.
	PLEASE LISTEN TO ME!!!   This culture we  share with each other, the =
essence of raving, the oneness that we all strive towards is a fragile =
thing.  It does not take much to pollute it to the point where people no =
longer wish to partake of the waters.  When I first came to the list, I =
wanted to try to put out the fires and make the list a little less =
volatile.  I know now that I cannot do it alone.  In order to keep this =
list alive the way we all want it to be (at this point I take the =
liberty of assuming that a good portion of people who do not post very =
often agree with me, however I may be alone in this.  I hope not.)  we =
all must be respectful of each other's opinions and viewpoints. =20
	The vibe that we all share is a beautiful thing.  Cherish it, nurture =
it, but don't poison it.  I do not mean to lecture anyone, for that will =
accomplish nothing.  I do not require anyone to do want I say either.  I =
merely ask that you listen to me, and to the meaning of my first =
message.  I am sorry if I have offended anyone with my words, but this =
is how I feel. =20



<3   <3         <3            <3
<3     <3            <3
<3       to all....

Love, Hadrian
----------

the bathroom.

at myself

gets
  her PLUR points taken away.

Ninja Tunes, those guys got some talent .  The sound system and lighting at
that 
club was very top notch. Crazy mixing, scratching and musical choices made for
a very inspring evening

amazing
to see a different group of people, another comforting family. Man, Thad played
some amaxing songs in the basement. Drum and bass in your face loud, just like 
it should be (Audio Impact...this week, woohoo). I can't even begin to say
how incredible
Micron is, he played some of the most beautiful songs, just what I needed at
4 am in total
bliss, Micron rrrrrrrRRRRoOoOcCCCkkkkkkkSSSSSSSSS! 

Ofcourse if anyone has a chance, one must catch Protlab live, those guys can
play some
great tunes, pretty, breaky, dubby, fluffy, ah yaa. 

Great chillroom decorations, free Nub Chai doing wonders to my soul, free
bottled water
and fruit, wow. Warmth made me smile, tickly, fuzzy and kind of warm inside.

Sunday, to end the weekend, I did the drum gathering circle at Golden Gate
park for the
3rd weekend in a row, good spiritual cleansing and relaxation for a
wonderful sunny day,
ahh, the sisters and brothers come together.

I've had a really interesting weekend and it has involved wonderful
aspects of both of the scenes that have welcomed me and that I love :)

After spending a wonderful Saturday evening with a lot of my favorite
folks, I took time to test out my new mixer board by replaying some old
tracks out of my computer that me and my buddy Joe had written back in
1994/1995...  what a fun way to spend an afternoon :)

Anyway, this past weekend really made me think about how much I love all
parts of our scene and it also made me think how stupid it is to get all
upset over dumb shit.  There's just so much to be happy about all around
us every day.  :)  Anyway, try to start your week with a smile, okay?  To
all those I had the good fortune of visiting with, thank you very much!
And to those who were too far away to hug or at least smile at, know that
you are being sent the warmest wishes :) :) :)

Received: from localhost (krok@localhost) by uclink2.berkeley.edu (8.8.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id DAA13936 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 3 Mar 1997 03:38:57 -0800
Date: Mon, 3 Mar 1997 03:38:57 -0800 (PST)
From: Kyung Rok <krok@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Brand New Retro
Message-ID: <Pine.ULT.3.93.970303000113.26662A-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


If Star Wars, why not techno and house?  If "Jungle Boogie" and "Play
that Funky Music", why not "Charlie", "Pissed Apache", "Bombscare", 
"Atom Bomb", "Rez",  "Strings of Life", "Stella", and the Dust Brothers' 
remix of "Like a Motorway"? 

So there's this big buzz about seeing the Star Wars flicks in the
theaters "the way they were meant to be seen".  Someone should apply
this handsomely profitable logic to the cornucopia of headphone and 
livingroom classics that once upon a time, in a galaxy far, far away 
(i.e. '91, '92, '93, '94, '95, early '96) tore it up on dancefloors.
Currently, it's only safe for a DJ to wax retro if s/he confines it to a
single old-skool track, maybe two or three, within their set. If done
right, this monkey-business can pay big dividends, especially to those
hearing the track for the first time.  

I've heard about such retro events in LA.  Let's have some up here!  Let
us, for a moment, put aside the stifling burden of being terribly
current.  Let us, on one self-effacing night (or every once in a blue
moon) be overwhelmingly passe.  Let's unlock the music and let the good
times roll.

Rok.  

This message was prompted by a night of tragically mediocre new music.

Hey Hey,
  
First and foremost....THANK YOU! To everyone involved in throwin'
Warmth. This event will stay in my head as exactly what a raving is all
about. It was absolutely perfect. I wouldn't have changed one thing!!
What a fuckin' a fabulous nite! I'm still bouncing and smiling! (but
seeing as I'm at work and its 7am the bouncing and smiling is on the
inside :)) 
 As you all already have read.....the sets were super...all of you
deserve huge pats and hugs (as if I did't give em already) for throwin
down perfect sets. 
The space was so uh, WARM.....the vibe was as I remembered it being
years ago...it was so intense, and pure. Nothing but smiles and hugs
from everybody there. The decorations were awesome...the glowing tent
was the best...and the life sized stuffed bear in the chill room (out
front) was too much. 
Hey SFRavers...so glad to meet all of you! AnthonE...you made my entire
nite giving me your laminate...Thanks so much! Lara> you rock! so glad
to meet you. Macadio...phew..that first mix was a close call, eh....you
are amazing.... Claudia..uh, could you be any cooler? You are wonderful!
Wizard...what can I say? You are the man! I look forward to working with
you. Thank you! That record is phat..kewl sample..I got home and
listened to it first thing..it mixes perfectly with some other stuff I
have...I owe you.(plz hug and thank your s/o for me,
*thankx*)..Deepfog...didn't really get to talk to you...but it was kewl
to meet you in person after seeing your name everyday for the last year!
Vlad...your set was intense....it really took me off to a different
level. Amy! <hugz> Alekz! hey there..it was great to meet you! ..and to
everyone else who I met and shared this wonderful experience with but
can't remember your names.... I still want to say hi and give you all a
huge hug! 
Warmth was my girfriend's (Elena) first _real_ *E*xperience raving. She
had the time of her life...literally. In her words... as we were riding
home at 7am...."I've been waiting for that my entire life!"  We
definately have a new member among us now...she'll be online soon to
write her review..(could take a few days though) She wants to post and
say hi and tell everyone what a wonderful,unbelievable, enlightening
night she had! There couldn't have been a more perfect setting for her
first real event. The ppl, the STRONG energy, the perfect space, and the
love she felt from everyone who met her. I am so happy! Thank you to
everyone who met her and took the time to share with her. 
If you look up...rave...in the dictonary it says Ra've: see Warmth flier
for details. It was all that and then some! 
Micron, Spencer, Wizard, Macadio, Deep.....and those unbelievable guys
upstairs playing live ambient and jungle...WOW! you are all the Bomb! 
see you all very soon! 
PLUR,
Ari 
-----------
fubari@valuserve.com

Hello, Everyone :)

I had an excellent time at Warmth!!!  The music was teriffic, and I really
loved whichever chill-room dj it was who played all that old skool music
(Gawd, I love Orbital :) :)  There was only a slight bit of discomfort for
me in that I was supposed to be babysitting both my friend Laura (not to be
confused with Lara [HI, Sweetie!!!]) AND my gf, Melisa, and each had a
different agenda.  In the end, I think I made a good choice, but I don't
think my Melisa will want to rave again (it was her first time, and she
didn't feel really comfortable with people being sooo friendly [shame on
ALL of you ;) ;) hehehhe])

Anyway, I'm sooo looking forward to Warmth 2 in May :)

I loved the music, the decorations, the kewl-o visuals in the chill out
area, and, most of all, the people I met and chitchatted with (Hi, Lara,
Pablo, Anthony, Macadio, Tony, Todd, Perry, and those other people whose
names were lost with my brain cells!!!!)  Thank you to everyone who told me
Happy Birthday :) :)  Oh, and I'm happy to be the new owner of an SFRaves
laminate!!!  YaY!!! This was certainly one of my best birthdays, and I have
all of YOU to thank for it!!!

Take care, and I look forward to wherever next weekend will take me :) :)

Love and glitter,
Thomas =]

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar  3 09:33:03 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id JAA10471; Mon, 3 Mar 1997 09:33:03 -0800 (PST)
Received: from franc.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id JAA10441; Mon, 3 Mar 1997 09:32:56 -0800 (PST)
Received: from smtp.ucdavis.edu by franc.ucdavis.edu (8.8.5/UCD3.8.5)
	id JAA20982; Mon, 3 Mar 1997 09:32:53 -0800 (PST)
Date: Mon, 3 Mar 1997 09:32:53 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <199703031732.JAA20982@franc.ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: szriffle@peseta.ucdavis.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.1.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Rick Riffle <rdriffle@ucdavis.edu>
Subject: SpaceChildren / Shine
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

RE: and C-Lab had fun playing live at Space Children since we were playing
all new music.  There were definately problems, like the sound system wasn't
up yet in the room we were playing in, and our set got cut to 1 hour as a
result, and some of our friends were denied entry, and only got in with a
help from Jonah Sharp (thank you).  Andrew (Astral Matrix) spun some records
and played a few of his tracks from DAT right before we went on.  He rocked.
Then we played and had a blast jumpin around behind our keyboards spewing
out d&b.  It gets my energy up playin that stuff.  Optic went on right after
us, but I only got to hear a little of his set.  What I hear was really
cool.  he was all analogue, making everything up as he went along.  It was
way neato.  Sorry we had to rush out during your set, but we had to go to
Shine.  All the way up to Shine, there had been much chaotic energy flowing.
Space Children was crazy due to it's own inherent problems, plus our having
to break down the gear as fast as possible and head over to Shine.

So we get there and carry the stuff up those blasted stairs.  Bless those
who carry the speakers!  I step into the ambient area, and there is an
immediate conscious difference in my energy.  It is a warm loving atmosphere
of friends.  Claire (bless her) offers to switch sets with us to give us
plenty of time to set up and relax a bit before playing.  We do so.  I
danced a bit in the main room to the sounds of someone I didn't recoginize
by face, but I was really into his music.  My attention span for dance music
isn't usually very long, so soon I was gone to chill in the ambient space.
Chilled and talked to a few friends and was feeling sooooo good.  Good vibes
were very apparent.  I just kept telling everyone how happy I was to be
there.  I got stoked with free smoothy by the smoothy goddess (sorry forgot
your name), then a friend tells me it's time to make sound.  We had planned
to do more chill and down tempo stuff, but Claire gave me the ok to do some
d&b, and said some people were kind of expecting to hear it.  So we played
our new d&b sounds and had a blast bouncing around and bumping into each
other behind our set-up due to lack of space.  Totally fun.  I love the
Gateway sound.  They know what they are doing.  Sorry if any of you were
expecting "ambient sound research" and just got Consciouness Lab.  We have
all kinda branched our into other realms.  We still dig ambient, but are
just exploring other areas.

After leaving the party, we went to breakfast at this crepe place off of
Mission.  We moved a big table out onto the sidewalk and ate out side with
our 7 or 8 friends.  So fun.  Sun peeking through the clouds...as well as
the moon.  So nice.

Thanks Gateway for a wonderful night.

I'm happy,
Rick

will be scattered like ants across the world and the Dharma will come to the
land of the red man."
					--Padmasambava (8th Century)

Steve Simitzis wrote:
> 
> (negative review of Space Children followed by glowing review
> of Gateway. film at 11)

> 
> make sure that whoever mixed the sound for the jungle room is REMOVED
> from the sound engineering profession!
> 
> That was the WORST, most PAINFULLY excruciating attempt at sound
> reproduction that I have ever experienced in my entire life. I have
> been going to raves, punk rock clubs, played in a hardcore band, and
> have been regularly blasting my ears with headphones for years and
> years, and nothing could match the level of sonic pain from last
> night. If that person's idea of EQ'ing is turning the volume as the
> loud as it can go in a highly reflective room, then he/she has a *lot*
> to learn. Muddy bass and sloppy snare rolls just doesn't sound like
> music to me. Call me picky. ;)

I have gone to many raves/parties/concerts in which it did seem the
intent was to make me deaf by 40 instead of 50.  Probably the worst/best
example was a skinny puppy show is saw back in 92.

...but I actually found the pain enjoyable at Analog. If you could
accept the fact that damage was being done, then staying within 20 feet
of the speakers cancelled any echo effects.  Within this distance I
found the drum&bass overwhelming and well quite enjoyable.

double 'a' set at the end of the night was amazing...it was too bad i
only had enough energy to sit and bop.  

.....anyway there's three drum&bass events this week(audio impact,
jungle love, spring heel jack)....how does one choose?


j

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar  3 12:09:51 1997

Subject: & that's what I am... (Wknd RAViEw)
Date: Mon, 3 Mar 1997 12:16:22 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I am here, I am a raver....

It's funny, here, typing away, Mr. Spell Cheque highlights every other 
word, unfamillar with raver-speak (or I'm just a bad speller).

=)

Friday: _Ohmsonic_
I arrive with/a friend to 'the spot' @ 11:30. Nice lil venue.  A tad 
too bright for my tastes, Anon is mixin' them  psi-trance traks quite 
nicely... I start gruuving.  Looking around, I see the usual 
Goa-lites. Music intensity is building and I'm steppin' trying and 
keepin' up2beat...

Everybody seems to be having an alright time, some are floored by 
whichever substances they care to consume.  Me, I'm consumed in the 
frequencies that surround me.  Looking around I see our scene, our 
underground.  From teens to twenty-somethings,  visitors from afar, 
and locals at their millionth event. All creeds colors, races and 
religions.  Now, we are all of the same vein.  Children of techno.  We 
are all family.

There's a time when time doesn't matter, it's dark-thirty.  It's this 
time when I'm @ my happiest. I'm sitting in a small smoke-cloud, 
giving a backrub and smiling.  Talking to another oldschooler, she's 
telling me about her days in the eastcoast, Spring of 94 with some 
local hero by the name of Josh Winks.  I tell her about one the FMR's 
back in the early 90's with some DJ named Jeno... We laugh.  Watching 
the scene change.
I'm dancing, feeling the various cravings consuming me... To my left 
is a someone who caught my eye, my right is a speaker beating out a 
sound that my body is helplessly responding to, on the floor is a 
half-filled water bottle... My passion for all is equal. I can't help 
smiling.  Where is 20/20 when you need them?  But they wouldn't 
understand.  The other side...  They misunderstand us, and what people 
don't understand- they fear.

Saturday:  _Warmth_
Well, I don't feel it's right to post a review on a production that I 
was an acting force in assisting (doing setup, door ect..) but it's 
apparent that the party was a success. I really would like to thank 
each and everyone of you, dear ravers, for making this party a 
smashing success.  Without you, well we wouldn't exsist...
I would like to take time to say 'high' to everybody I chatted with:
Spencer, Branka, Matt, Anna, Rob R, Connie, Eric, Heidi, Pengo, Ariel 
(Pronounced R-E-L). As well as the plethora of others who's names slip 
me...

Also, Major props to the DJ's I conversed with (Micron, Wizard, Elmo, 
Deep, And Macgaines). Nice sets all...

I would like to whisk all of you into a small virtual rave.  Music is 
bleeding through the speakers.  People are gruvving, that guy/gal that 
catches your eye is smiling @ you...  Your waterbottle is still half 
full and yet someone offers you some more.  Someone taps you on the 
shoulder and says, "dosen't it all make sense now..".
Maybe you sit down and a friend gives you a massage (or you massage 
someone, if that's your cup of tea)...
Remember this feeling. Joy. Contentness. Vibe. Now keep it in you... 
but try to spread that to everybody everyday.  I'm glad that, someday, 
I can look @ my childrens' children and thell them:
-I was the generation when raves were a 'fad'.
-I was the generation when jungle could only be heard on college 
stations. (now becoming mainstream, thanks to Bowie and NIN)
-I was the generation that saw Leary die...
-I was the generation that tried to save this world with the power of 
music...

To me that is a raver...  And that's what I am...

P.S. To those that need to contact me in regards to the Saturday 
thingie, drop me an E-line and we'll talk.

---Adam
"stay connected"

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	I hit both Warmth & Shine this Saturday. They were both 
wonderful. Warmth had a very bright cheery vibe. It seemed to be
mostly the 20's & younger set, which tends to make me feel a little 
old. Shine had a slightly darker energy, but was truly an excellent 
party. This one was the 20's & older set, so I didn't feel so much 
like Dad. 

	Warmth - good things - candle altar by Leslie, 
	butterfly altar by ?, massage table, tent, *big*
	teddy bear, Protolab, DJs, free fruit & Chai,
	meeting Leslie, Branka, Raygun for the first time.

	Shine - good things - better age balance (for me,
	anyway), really effective use of lasers, dry ice
	piped into the chill room (both a visual & a coolant),
	laser/crystal thing, Buddha altar, body art. Live
	& DJ music, meeting Patrick (ne Black Adder), Joe, 
	Nancy for the first time. 

	I met so many people at these parties that my head 
	is kind of spinning. I'm only mentioning the ones 
	I had known previously from the mail list.

	If only they would play more trance...

Well it is Monday afternoon and im just sitting here in the office reflecting
on the AWESOME weekend I just had. Words can't really explaine the time that I
had at the party "warmth" this weekend, This event was well put together and
the space was great. I enjoyed playing with all the "guys"
adam,micron,thad,wizard,deepfog. I thought we all played very well together.
The vibe for those of you who did not go was just amazing I saw so many smiling
faces and happy vibes I was just extatic.I met and talked with so many kewl
people so im not going to mention any names cause I don't want to leave anyone
out. I would like to send thanks to orson for the SFR laminate. I would like to
personally thank all of you who made it out to the party YOU all made it great
it gave me a little insight as to why I spin and go to partys. I would like to
thank tony (deepfog) and spencer for giving me the chance to play at such a
beautiful party. I hope to see all your beautiful smilling faces at the next
warmth. The only two things of the Night that I did not like was 1.)the sound
was good but the guy that hooked it up did not do a good job so it made the
"sound", sound shitty it was real muddy and distorted at any rate the sound was
good just hooked up wrong. 2.)my second rekkid that I played the song ended
before I could mix it =( that is my own fault cause the night before I let my
buddy use my rekkids and he played the wrong side of the song that I playy so I
ended up playing a wrong edit so the rekkid ended and I did not have time to
mix it. But I made a "ok" recovery and the crowd was happy... Once again I
would like to thank all of you for making it a magical night..



*big hugz and love to all*
Macadio

From: Harmony <ascend@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: What's up with Harmony? (bsp)
Cc: ascend@ix.netcom.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello Sfraves,

	Well as some of you might have noticed, we have taken a much needed (but
short) break from throwing parties. Our last party was "Freaky People" in
Dec. '96, and our last schedualed party was "Family" Jan. '97 (it didn't
happen). During this "break," we have thought long and hard about where to
go with Harmony? What to do next? How to bring new life into the family?
And how to convay our thoughts, ideas, and dreams to everyone?

	The idea of throwing a "Massive" came into the picture. Although the Three
Year Anniversary (Sept. '96) was the largest party we have done yet
(14-1500 screaming ravers), and quite possibly could have been considered a
"Massive," in our eyes, it wasn't. Personally, I have always dreamed about
doing a party, where I wasn't limited in my financial decisions. I have
always wanted Harmony to build bigger and better props, bring in the best
djs and performers, the biggest- most colorfull light show, and the loudest
rockin sound system in California. For the Three Year Ann., most (over
half) of the budget went staight into the space and the buses we rented to
get to the space, so there was not a lot of $ to spend on the actual
production of the event. But usually, we have been confined to doing
smaller budgeted parties, which we feel are great, but still there is
little $ that can be used to increase the production of the party. 

	Another reason we want to throw a massive, is to bring our message of
peace, love, positivity and harmony to the masses. We have been doing
parties for almost 4 years now and we have maintained a good, positive,
family vibe through the good times and the bad times. We have seen our
family unite for a number of reasons. For example, our friend Omar. When he
was hit by a drunk, stoned and/or high driver at Burning Man, everyone came
together for him. People that he never even met before where sending him
prayers and sometimes even $ for his finacial help. Everything you guys did
helped him pull through. He is doing a lot better now, thanks to all of his
close friends and even the friends that he has not met yet! But it is love
and respect like this, that comes from you guys, that makes our family and
our scene so strong...

	But to make a long story short... That same love that you guys showed
Omar, is the same love that creates the energy which brings us all together
and closer at our parties. That love creates so much for our community. 
	
	Imagine what you feel like the day after a really good party, where you
dance, hear great music, and see most of your friends all night. You feel
great! And providing you are awake, you go out and have a great day. We
want more people to feel this way. We want more people to take the love and
togetherness from our scene, and apply it to everyday life.   

	Anyways, we took a vote at a metting and decided that it was a good idea
to pursue the thought of throwing a massive. We hope that the idea of this
being a massive, doesn't scare some of you away. There are some very valid
reasons why some people don't like massives. We are going to try our
hardest to make sure the we accomidate all of your concerns. And we hope
that all of you who have supported us in the past and present, also decide
to support us in the future. We are going to put in 100% of our energy to
try to make this the most colorful, high- energy, family-vibed massive that
the S.F. scene can handle! We are 100% positive that this is what we want
to do. And we are 100% positive that it will be a party that will change
your views about massives. We are going to put in all of our heart and soul
into this party to make sure that you have the time of your life! It is
going to insane!!! We are currently in the process of booking (some of the)
best Techno, Trance, Jungle, and Ambient djs and performers around. So stay
tuned, cause you're not gonna want to miss this party! 

	The date for this party is SATURDAY, MAY 17TH  1997. Start making plans!

	Also, look for the "Family" party on Saturday, April 5th '97. If you have
a presold ticket from the last "Family" party, you can use it for your
admission to this one. More details to follow. 

	Anyways, it feels good to have something in the works again. We can't wait
to see all of your smiling faces again! We love you!

Peace, love, and harmony to all,

Harmony =)

well...i guess i'm just gonna have to throw in my $.02

great party, space, people and music.

The party was well organized and went off with hardly a hitch.  

Hello to all the beautiful people i met and shared hugs with.  

Nice space; pretty clean and 2 bathrooms.  WOOOHOOO.  Downstairs got a
little warm ( i very nearly almost passed out after my set, dehydration
i guess ) but people kept dancing and kept the energy in the room up for
the entire night.  The speakers outside of the main room were also nice,
a lil cooler and u could still dance to the music. i was also happy to
see a live act in the chill room.

also, nice decorating guys, the place looked great.  

to all who came..THANK U....and for those that missed it...i'll see u
next time ;)

:)
micron

Greets all!
    I'm new to the list (first post anyway), so let me begin by introducing
myself.  My name is Steve Duell.  I enjoy foreign cuisine, antique refrigerator
restoration, and playing mah jhong with my grandparents!  Just kidding.  But I
truly am mad about hard techno and good, vibey parties.  Speaking of which,
Warmth certainly qualifies.  I suspect I'm heavily biased since I helped set up
and stuff, but no bias of mine can take away from the fact that there were
scores of awesome people in attendance.  I'm usually not one to get all
spiritual about vibes.  I beleive that a vibe is more a personal perception
than a definite energy among people, but this place WAS charged and I was so
happy to have been a part of it.    
     Deepfog did an awesome job getting DJ's together.  Many different styles
were represented, and represented WELL!  Protolab awed and humbled me, and
Thad's set tore me up.  Anyway thanks to all who had enough faith in Spencer's
first time production to give it a chance. I'll be seeing you.

                                       Shteeb

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello from the girlie with the glowing antennas!!!

Oh-My-GAWD!!! This was the best party I have ever been to!  I was a little
hesitant at first to go, since all my friends flaked on me, and I was
supposed to go to Space Children... All I have to say is THANK YOU SO MUCH to
Vertigo for changing my mind! 

Let's see, where to begin... I think that I will have to start with the
people... I met SO MANY people from the list that made me feel like family
right off the bat.  I am still rather new to the whole scene, so it started
my night off perfectly. A few people to mention:  
ROCKY - Get enough vitamin C??? Hope you had a blast with your satin sheets
and your waterbed... I know I would have... hehe!  
PABLO - Mirrors are happy! I don't care what anyone says! It was great
meeting you and chatting about all the crazy shit that I can't remember... :)
 
PAUL - Thanks for the bracelet! I always knew where to find you... Just
looked for those yellow gloves!  You rock!!!!
ANTHONY - My little filipino friend. You are the bomb!! And you've gotta make
sure that I get one of those laminates... Hope to see you at the next party.
ANDY - You little matchmaker you!  I hope you're happy with the outcome of it
all. You made my night too wonderful for words... Call me up for anything you
could possibly need! :)
ARIEL & JAMES - Thanks so much for talking Kermit out of his craziness. I had
fun (well, it was work, but still nice to chat with you) untangling the
christmas lights... See you at Cloud Factory.
MACADIO - You are the shit!!! I had so much fun dancing and watching you
spin.  And playing with your hair when Andy was talking to you! 
VERTIGO - Thank you so much for talking me into going to Warmth instead of
Space Children. I had the best time! You are great, and I am glad that you
found me at the party.  Make me a tape! From what I heard on the fone, it
sounded great! 
ANYONE WHO COMPLIMENTED ME ON MY OUTFIT - THANK U THANK U THANK U! I plan to
wear my little antenna's for a while... So look for me at the next party!! 

And,  of course, lastly.... 
MATT "KERMIT" or "that crazy loud Elmo guy"... I just remember walking into
the party and saying: I wanna meet that guy... He's too cool... And look how
things ended up... Happy happy...  I still feel bad for Shelly & Snoopy, cuz
of that wonderful Sunday afternoon... hehehe...  Good thing they were asleep.
But you better give me a call!! I know you will, so I'm not too worried. I
had the greatest time hanging out with you, and I'm sure therre'll be plenty
more times to come. :) We've gotta scare the people on Market Street again
next weekend! :) Love ya, babe! Can't wait to see you again!

Ok... PHEW.... anyone else I forgot, HELLO and thanks for making that the
best weekend I have ever had. The people were the best. The chill room(s)
were wonderful. Great decor, great music, great CHAI!!!  That was the first
time that I have had Chai, and I hope that I get to have more again really
soon! It was the best. Downstairs got a little wet and warm, but hey, it was
called WARMTH, right? (I had NOTHING to do with the wetness... I swear!)
 Well, I've taken up enough space... Hope everyone had as much fun as I did! 

Can't wait til the next Warmth... 

Oh, and from Shelly: 
To Pablo, Rocky, Heather, & (I think) Jeff: I LOVE YOU!! *BIG HUGS* And I
will call you when I get back from Dizzilyland. Take some "e" for me!!!

Peace out from the antenna girlie!
~^v^~ Stefani ~^v^~
"...and the last little piddy did e-e-e-e-e all night long!"

Subject: Your Horoscope and what it means..
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm beating the dead horse here, but it is pretty funny.....



  AQUARIUS (1/20-2/10) You have an inventive mind and are 
     inclined to be progressive.  You lie a great deal.  You make the same  
     mistakes repeatedly because you are stupid.  Everyone thinks you are a 
     fucking jerk.
     
            PISCES (2/19-3/20) You have a vivid imagination and often think 
     you are being followed by the FBI or CIA.  You have minor influence on 
     your friends and people resent you for flaunting your power. You lack 
     confidence and are generally a dipshit.
     
            ARIES (3/21-4/19) You are the pioneer type and think most 
     people are dickheads.  You are quick tempered, impatient and scornful 
     of advice.  You are a prick.
     
            TAURUS   (4/20-5/20) You are practical and persistent.  You 
     have a dogged determination and work like hell.  Most people think you 
     are stubborn and bullheaded.  You are nothing but a goddamn communist.
     
            GEMINI (5/21-6/20) You are a quick and intelligent thinker.    
     People like you because you are bisexual.  You are inclined to expect 
     too much for too little.  This means you are a cheap bastard.    
     Gemini's are notorious for thriving on incest.
     
            CANCER (6/21-7/22) You are sympathetic and understanding to 
     other people's problems which makes you a sucker.  You are always   
     putting things off.  That is why you will always be on welfare and 
     won't be worth a shit. Everyone in prison is a Cancer.
     
            LEO (7/23-8/22)  You consider yourself a born leader.  Others   
     think you are an idiot.  Most Leo's are bullies.  You are vain and   
     cannot tolerate honest criticism.  Your arrogance is disgusting.  Leo 
     people are thieving motherfuckers and spend most of their time kissing 
     mirrors.
     
            VIRGO (8/23-9/22) You are the logical type and hate disorder.   
     This shitpicking is sickening to  your friends.  You are cold and 
     unemotional and often fall asleep while fucking.  Virgo's make good 
     bus drivers and pimps.
     
            LIBRA   (9/23-10/22) You are the artistic type and have a   
     difficult time with reality.  If you're male, you are probably queer. 
     Chances for employment and monetary gain are nil. Most Libra women are 
     whores. All Libra's die of venereal disease.
     
            SCORPIO (10/23-11/21) The worst of the lot.  You are shrewd in 
     business and cannot be trusted.  You shall achieve the pinnacle of 
     success because of your total lack of ethics.  You are a 
     son-of-a-bitch.  Most Scorpio's are murdered.
     
            SAGITTARIUS (11/22-12/21)  You are optimistic and enthusiastic. 
     You have a reckless tendency to rely on luck since you have no talent. 
     The majority of Sagittarians are drunks.  Nixon was a Sagittarius. You 
     are not worth the time of day.
     
            CAPRICORN (12/22-1/19)  You are conservative and afraid of 
     taking risks.  You are basically a chickenshit.  There has never been 
     a Capricorn of any importance.  You should kill yourself.

>witness the magic of a desert gathering.

Yes, it is true, 'skimo is back on the list. If you don't remember
me, or maybe you just never met me (online or irl), this is who I am:

	Jonas Hanning, born in Sweden on May 22nd, 1976 (that would 
make me 20.75 years old I think...). I moved over to California in
August
of 1995 to attend Sonoma State University (yup, home of the world famous
Cossacks! *grin*). 
	What makes me tick? Well, music of course! As most of my 
friends know, I worship the ground that Josh Wink walks upon. Other 
than anything that JW lays his hands upon, I'm a sucker for hardbanging
acid and trance. Favorite labels would have to be Stay Up Forever, Noom,
and Loop Records. Today this guy at school asked me what the coolest
band
of all times was, and without hesitation I went for Kraftwerk. If you
don't believe me, try http://www.kraftwerk.com! =) And although I hate
to admit it, I'm starting to get back into the whole drum'n'bass thing.
(I can hear you laughing all the way up to Rohnert Park Lara! *smile*)
And oh, the new Depeche Mode album is going to kick fuckin' ass! :)
	Other things that float my boat are hanging with my wonderful 
friends, especially my raving friends (hi Lara, Ariana, Ryan, Perry, 
Fernando, Aaron, and everyone else!). 
	And oh, if you ever want to find me at a party, look for the tall,
skinny guy with a shaved head shaking his booty right by the speakers
all
night. If that ain't enough for ya, look for a GLOWING shaved head. Or
simply
ask around. :) Hope to see you all soon! =) (oh yeah, last two parties I
attended were Omnisonic and Warmth. At Omnisonic I was wearing black
silky
pants and an orange shirt, and at Warmth I had bellbottoms and a white
shirt. Did you see me? Cool! *smile*

	Now over to today's most important event -- Lara's b-day! Lara is
more than one of my best friends, she is also my promoter/manager. And I
wish her the best of luck! :)

hugs, jonas

At 9:56 PM -0800 3/2/97, Paul Hayden wrote:
>This is a list of cool people I know...
>
>Libby, Adam M, Philip, Eric(Blowpops), Lara, Pablo, AnthonE, Kermit,
>Leslie, April, Andy, Blake, and at least a million other people that i
>know that rave. Sorry if I forgot a name, but i am very tired now and am
>going to bed.  I love all you cool people. And especially one other
>person. John Lee. Leslie told me about you and it seems that you have
>done much that I should be very thankfull for. You are defintely a cool
>guy too.
>
>Love.Luck.Lollipops,
>Paul
>
>P.S. See I can post good vibes.

I am glad to see your positive post, but alas, I must take issue with you
dear sir.  Although I found your post a positive note for what has been a
week filled with flames, both perceived and real, it was from my view a bit
disingenuous.

You do not know me well enough to call me cool.  Getting information from
someone second hand does not qualify as really "knowing" someone.  You and
I have engaged in 2 or three e-mail back and forths, mostly acrimonious.
To single me out in an online forum given the, er, truth of our
realtionship (I wouldn't even call it that, more like a "Post-It"
association) as being ok/cool when YOU HAVE NEVER SEEN MY FACE, SHOOK MY
HAND, or at least BOUGHT ME A BEER is the height of hypocrisy in an world
filled with hypocrites and hypocrisy.

Now it's not like I don't want to get to know you or be your friend, that
is not the point.  I just don't like being singled out for your strange
form of , er, love and approval.  I would rather we at least know each
other before such declarations.

As for being thankful, I doubt I have done anything that you need be
thankful for.  I have done some gigs, and got to meet some really nice
people (here and as a result of many, many years of partying [man that
sounds tepid]).  I have contributed to all of this in my own way, but there
are others who have done more for the cause than I.  All I did was throw
good gigs, brought out some unheard DJ's, and helped others throw their
gigs when time permitted.  All of this happened years ago, proably before
you started going out, but once again, I don't know that since I don't
really know you, or your history.  Too many lollipops and platitudes such
that you have not shed light into who you are, and that's where we are.

I do not gladhandedly pour out platitudes for the sake of garnering
positivity.  Nor do I appreciate such banter.  I woulda preferred a minor
shout instead of being singled out.  After all Paul, we have never met.

Until such time, I guess a thank you is in order, although I would've
preferred it come from a place of reality instead of an attempt (as I see
it), to garner friends.  It takes time to make friends, and maybe in time,
we might both have the priviedge of calling each other friends.

Until such time, peace.

Out,
John

P.S.   The BEST way to get to know people is face to face.  Virtual is
rubbish if the contents make no attempt to communicate reality. Out.

"Those who profess to favor freedom and yet depreciate agitation, are people
who want crops without ploughing the ground; they want rain without thunder
and lightning; they want the ocean without the roar of its waters... Power
concedes nothing without a demand; it never has and it never will."

Frederick Douglass, 1857

At 2:38 PM -0800 2/27/97, Brian Denny wrote:
>When people talk about the risks and negative effects of drugs, they often
>forget to compare the risks and negative effects of everyday activities.
>
>Ever drive to work?  Better chance you'll get killed on the road than
>taking E.  And you're polluting while you're at it.
>
>Ever have sex?  I find it plenty psychologically addictive.  And god knows
>what could happen to you. :)
>
>I'm only half being tongue in cheek here.  My ability to expand my mind
>with psychedelics is at least as important to me as my ability to get to
>work at 60 mph.  AND i consider it less risky.
>
>Love,
>
>brian

Brian,

There is considerable evidence linking the use of psychedelic drugs and
psychoactive drugs in general to the spread of HIV.  There are soo many
studies out now that point to this:

psychoactive drug use + unsanitary conditions + sex = HIV infection.

too many to cite, if interested I can give details.

Anyway, drugs have BOTh + and -.  I think responsible and safe use are not
emphasized enough.  Drugs + Sex can be a very volatile combination.

Food for thought,
John

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: MaD *growl* *spit*
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Thanks to everyone who came to our wacky dinner party last
night. Sarah and David did a great job of organizing everything and
getting all the food and chai together (you guys kick ass!). Our last
two dinner parties have been a total success, so hopefully there'll be
more stuff happening at Natoma on the Lake. :)

After dinner, some of us (those that weren't too SLEEPY :P) walked
over to MaD. And for the second week in a row, I was lucky enough to
be treated to some pretty hard sounds... last week it was T-1000; this
week Aladdin Sane tore up the dance floor.

Definitely similar music between the adjacent week's guest DJ's. This
week, the music wasn't quite as hard (but still *much* harder than what
we usually get in SF), but more experimental and "noisy" sounding... 
It was really good "fuck with your brain" music; lots of bizarre vocal 
samples, big huge distorted kicks, sometimes augmented with moving 
atonal synth lines.

The crowd's reaction was sort of mixed; some of the people were sort
of scared or confused, but everyone else was *way* into it (including
myself) and just going off on the dance floor. I always get a chuckle
when that kind of thing happens...

Steve

Hey Deepfog and SFR!

I had the raddest time at Warmth (I'm sure you noticed). For those I didn't
talk with at the party, I was the bald headed dude with the brown "M&M's"
shirt on. Was this the first party you've thrown? You did great!! Just like
everybody said, this party was like the old school parties I remember...
the way a rave should be. I had tons-o-fun dancing like a lunatic in the
main room downstairs. The system down there was phatt and the music was
perfect. I know you already told me once (tony), but who was that jungle dj
that started up right when I saw you downstairs. I need copies of his
mixtapes and big ass speakers to play them over so that I can feel that
BOOOOOOOM.

I also wanted to tell you that everybody that I brought with me (my little
sis, her friend, a friend from work, and his friends) had a good time too.
It was my little sister's first UG, and she said she wants to go again.

It was cool to see so many people from the list there too. I feel like I
know most of you, and to actually see who was who was cool. Special shouts
out go to SmileGirl (thanx!), Adam Mednick, Pablo, and of course Deepfog!
Who was that Supergirl that I kept dancing with?

Still smiling,
Ivan

>while the historic Hale Bopp comet passes over us.
>

>an amazingly spiritual experience and DUNE provides an excellent opportunity to
>witness the magic of a desert gathering.  
>

>witnessed on the desert floor.

>part to help this scene grow and thrive.
>

part
