Subject: Stirring it up...
Date: Tue, 4 Mar 1997 15:05:43 -0800
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

	I have often wondered what the rave scene would be like without =
drugs..I am almost positive there wouldn't be nearly the number of =
people involved..The reason I like the scene at all, is pure and =
simple..I love the music..Whether it being techno, house, trance, =
jungle, it doesn't really matter, if it makes feel uplifted, energized, =
and hyped up to dance, that's all that really matters..All this PLUR =
business is a great concept, but when it comes down to it, would it =
really exist without the drugs..I would love to say yes, but that's hard =
for me to actually believe..I sometimes wonder why so many people are so =
into goa..If you really listen to the music, you can see how it can be =
funky or uplifting, but does it have any kind of musical appeal other =
than the fact that it sounds really good when you're high..I wonder how =
many trancers out there would still listen to goa if there weren't any =
drugs..Myself, I have recently decided not eat pills and things anymore, =
I'm trying to go back to where I began, and let the music be my drug of =
choice..I sometimes wonder if I am one of the only people out there who =
listens to jungle exclusively..I have an unconditional love for jungle =
that has been growing stronger and stronger since 1993..I listen to it =
in my car, at work, at home, and at parties..I am curious to know how =
many other people out there have this same love for our music..that =
being even if there weren't any drugs involved..



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar  4 15:44:27 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id PAA26615; Tue, 4 Mar 1997 15:44:27 -0800 (PST)

Received: from [128.32.110.56] (lsb78.Biol.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.110.56]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.8.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id PAA02150; Tue, 4 Mar 1997 15:44:05 -0800 (PST)

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 4 Mar 1997 16:53:06 -0800
To: Shawn Bryant <shawnb@softiron.com>
From: malyly@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Maly)
Subject: Re: Stirring it up...
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Shawn,
       For me, its mostly going to a rave with a bunch of people I adore
and meeting other  people and sharing in this sense of fun-ness. It is the
fun-ness of raves. I would be lying if I said Ecstasy didn't contribute at
all to the fun-ness but you can do  drugs anywhere and you can only rave at
a rave. If it's a GOOD party(like Warmth), then you don't need to get
inebriated on anything to enjoy yourself. The combination of good music,
good atmosphere, good people, and what we holistically call 'vibe' is why I
go to certain raves at all.  This combination constitutes a 'high' that no
drug could ever give me. Harmony, Lepidoptera, and Warmth all possess this
combo. Oh and the parties at Bravo Co.( if I'm allowed to be immodest).
Although I respect but don't buy into the PLUR platitudes and would fail on
a rave-culture/music test, I enjoy raves for very basic and very simple
reasons: I like the music and the people and the community: to be with
friends and to have a good time.

Maly

Subject: Re: Stirring it up...
In-Reply-To: <01BC28AD.88D75D40@shawnb.softiron.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970304152820.28961B-100000@epic15.Stanford.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I think you'd be surprised by the number of folks who have an
unconditional love for the music and a complete disregard for drugs...

On the other hand, I was surprised by the dawning realization that a
number of folks claim to have a similar love for the music, and yet make
drugs a central part of their raving experience.  This is not to say that
the two are mutually exclusive.  I just think that some folks should
seriously reconsider their priorities and change their internal dogma 
and external platitudes to reflect this.

Needless to say, lots of people love the music.  I was initially drawn to
the scene by the music, and it continues to hold me there.


	.02

			jon



On Tue, 4 Mar 1997, Shawn Bryant wrote:


> 	I have often wondered what the rave scene would be like without
> drugs..I am almost positive there wouldn't be nearly the number of
> people involved..The reason I like the scene at all, is pure and
> simple..I love the music..Whether it being techno, house, trance,
> jungle, it doesn't really matter, if it makes feel uplifted, energized,
> and hyped up to dance, that's all that really matters..All this PLUR
> business is a great concept, but when it comes down to it, would it
> really exist without the drugs..I would love to say yes, but that's hard
> for me to actually believe..I sometimes wonder why so many people are so
> into goa..If you really listen to the music, you can see how it can be
> funky or uplifting, but does it have any kind of musical appeal other
> than the fact that it sounds really good when you're high..I wonder how
> many trancers out there would still listen to goa if there weren't any
> drugs..Myself, I have recently decided not eat pills and things anymore,
> I'm trying to go back to where I began, and let the music be my drug of
> choice..I sometimes wonder if I am one of the only people out there who
> listens to jungle exclusively..I have an unconditional love for jungle
> that has been growing stronger and stronger since 1993..I listen to it
> in my car, at work, at home, and at parties..I am curious to know how
> many other people out there have this same love for our music..that
> being even if there weren't any drugs involved.. 
> 
> 
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar  4 15:48:43 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id PAA28813; Tue, 4 Mar 1997 15:48:43 -0800 (PST)
Received: from localhost by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id PAA28758; Tue, 4 Mar 1997 15:48:33 -0800 (PST)
Date: Tue, 4 Mar 1997 15:48:33 -0800 (PST)
From: Sami Khoury <khoury@hyperreal.com>
Reply-To: Sami Khoury <khoury@hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: NRR: Fw: MAJOR SECURITY HOLE IN INTERNET EXPLORER
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970304154315.26525A-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Another security warning for Internet Explorer users.

	Sami


> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> 
> Internet Explorer Bug 2/27/97 (Version 3.0 (4.70.1155))
> 
> Microsoft Internet Explorer v3.01 (and earlier?) has a serious bug which
> allows web page writers to use ".LNK" and ".URL" files to run programs on
> a remote computer.  This bug is particularly damaging because it uses NO
> ActiveX, and works even when Internet Explorer is set to its highest
> security level.  It was tested on Microsoft Internet Explorer Version 3.0
> (4.70.1155) running Windows 95.  This demo assumes that Windows is
> installed in "C:\WINDOWS".  Windows 95 DOES NOT PROMPT BEFORE EXECUTING
> THESE FILES. 
> 
> 
> .URL files are WORSE than .LNK files because .URLs work in both Windows
> 95 and Windows NT 4.0 (.LNK's only work in Windows 95).  .URL files
> present a possibly greater danger because they can be easily created by
> server side scripts to meet the specific settings of a user's system.  We
> will provide .URL files for execution in the next day or so. 
> 
> 
> The "shortcuts" can be set to be minimized during execution which means
> that users may not even be aware that a program has been started. 
> Microsoft's implementation of shortcuts becomes a serious concern if a
> webpage can tell Internet Explorer to refresh to an executable.  Or
> worse, client side scripts (Java, JavaScript, or VBScript) can use the
> Explorer object to transfer a BATCH file to the target machine and then
> META REFRESH to that BATCH file to execute the rogue command in that
> file. 
> 
> 
> The following table outlines which areas and users each shortcut type
> effects:
> 
> 	File Type 	Windows 95 	Windows NT 	Execute Apps 	Command Line Args
> Allowed 	Searches Path 	.LNK 	Yes 	No 	Yes 	Yes 	No 	.URL 	Yes 	Yes 	Yes
> 	No 	Yes <bigger>Security Comparision .URL vs .LNK</bigger> 
> 
> 
> Naturally, the files must exist on the remote machine to be properly
> executed.  But, Windows 95 comes with a variety of potentially damaging
> programs which can easily be executed.  The following link will start the
> standard calculator which comes with Windows 95. 
> 
> 
> <<calculator.lnk>Windows Calculator (.lnk).
> 
> <<calcnt.url>Windows Calculator (.url). 
> 
> 
> This bug can be used to wreak havoc on a remote user's machine.  The
> following links will create and delete some directories on a Windows 95
> machine. 
> 
> 
> <<mkdir.lnk>Create a directory "C:\HAHAHA".
> 
> <<explorer.lnk>Open "C:\HAHAHA"
> 
> <<rmdir.lnk>Remove the directory "C:\HAHAHA"
> 
> 
> The META REFRESH tag can be used to execute multiple commands in
> sequence. This demo copies a .BAT file into your Internet Explorer cache
> and then runs the .BAT file.  This .BAT will create a new key in your
> registry called "HKEY_CURRENT_USER/Software/Cybersnot".  It will then
> open your AUTOEXEC.BAT and CONFIG.SYS in notepad.  Finally, it will open
> REGEDIT so that you can view the key it creates.  This demo does not
> destroy anything and should not cause any problems on your system. 
> HOWEVER by clicking below, you are doing so at your own risk and agree
> not to hold us liable for any problems which may (but probably won't)
> arise. 
> 
> 
> <<http://asparagus.cybersnot.com/evildemo>.BAT Demo
> 
> 
> Well!  We've made it to the news!  Here is what people are saying: 
> 
> 
>
<<http://www.infoworld.com/cgi-bin/displayStory.pl?97033.wbug.htm>InfoWorld
> 
> <<http://www.news.com/News/Item/0,4,8447,00.html>CNetNews
> 
> <<http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/digest/tech2.htm>Washington Post
> 
> <<http://www.techweb.com/wire/news/mar/0303msbug.html>TechWeb
> 
> <<http://www.sjmercury.com/news/breaking/docs/013638.htm>San Jose Mercury
> News
> 
> <<http://www.cnn.com/TECH/9703/04/internet.explorer.bug/index.html>CNN
> 
> 
> And <<http://www.microsoft.com/>Microsoft says a bug-fix will be
> available within 48 hours (as of March 3, 1997) at:
> 
> 
>
<<http://www.microsoft.com/ie/default.asp>http://www.microsoft.com/ie/defaul
t.asp 
> 
> 
> And have provided a technical update at:
> 
> 
>
<<http://www.microsoft.com/ie/security/update.htm>http://www.microsoft.com/i
e/security/update.htm 
> 
> 
> ----------------
> 
> <<http://www.harvestweb.com><bigger>Internet Explorer Bug
> 
> </bigger>Discovered By <<mailto:shoggothe@cybersnot.com>Paul Greene
> 
> Page and Examples by <<mailto:geo@cybersnot.com>Geoffrey Elliott &
> <<mailto:bmorin@cybersnot.com>Brian Morin
> 
> 
> Hits today (as of 1:00pm EST): 68,853
> 
> 
> </excerpt>

          by atari.saturn5.com (8.8.4/8.8.4)

Date: Tue, 4 Mar 1997 16:08:14 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <199703050008.QAA18750@atari.saturn5.com>
From: Steve Simitzis <steve@saturn5.com>
To: shawnb@softiron.com
In-reply-to: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970304152820.28961B-100000@epic15.Stanford.EDU>
	(message from Jonathan Mark Logan on Tue, 4 Mar 1997 15:44:42 -0800
	(PST))
Subject: Re: Stirring it up...
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> On Tue, 4 Mar 1997, Shawn Bryant wrote:
> 
> > really exist without the drugs..I would love to say yes, but that's hard
> > for me to actually believe..I sometimes wonder why so many people are so
> > into goa..If you really listen to the music, you can see how it can be
> > funky or uplifting, but does it have any kind of musical appeal other
> > than the fact that it sounds really good when you're high..I wonder how
> > many trancers out there would still listen to goa if there weren't any
> > drugs..

I have loved electronic and experimental music since I was very young
and only had my parents' music to listen to. I later discovered techno-
industrial music (like Skinny Puppy, Front 242, etc.) back when I was
in high school, which eventually led me to be brave enough to listen
to hardcore and gabber. Of course, I wasn't doing speed or crack at
the time; I just loved the raw aggressive energy combined with the
hi-tech nature of the sound...

Now I also listen to trance, jungle, ambient, and if you catch me in
the right mood, maybe a little house. Though, I've never done acid, E,
pot, or whatever people think it takes to enjoy the music. No matter
what I'm doing; driving, eating, sleeping, or dancing, there's always
a beat pounding and some "beep-beep-bloops" either on my stereo or
running through my head.

I don't really see the connection between the music and the drugs. True, 
the drugs can enhance your experience while listening to techno, but it 
could just as easily enhance your experience while playing racket-ball
or scrubbing your toilet.

I hope this answers your question.

Steve

I wasn't going to get into this, but I show something about goa in here
soooo....

>	I have often wondered what the rave scene would be like without
>drugs..I am almost positive >there wouldn't be nearly the number of people
>involved.

I would agree, actually I think it would weed out those in the scene just
because of the drugs and keep those that are in it for the love of the
music, people and the vibe. Which IMHO would leave you with a better vibe
at a party. I can actually go either way. I love the music and the people
beyond anything else. I do have fun from time to time, but I don't need to
do it. I still get in that same tranced out state wither way.

>I sometimes wonder why so many people are so into goa..If you really
>listen to the music, you can see >how it can be funky or uplifting, but
>does it have any kind of musical appeal other than the fact that it
>>sounds really good when you're high..I wonder how many trancers out there
>would still listen to goa if >there weren't any drugs.

Wow, where to start.  The first time I heard Goa I was at my first F-8
party on a beach. I was sober all night. I first thought Damn there is alot
going on in this music. Then the next thing I felt was my eyes closing and
just going full force into a trance. It moved me so much, I finally found
the music I wanted to spin.

Listening to really good sounding and mixing of Goa is a drug in it's own.
I've sat and listen to Goa tapes and CD at times and when there over I feel
high as a kite. I would by lying if I said E or A doesn't heighten the
experence for ME. But I certainly don't need it to reach that trance state.
Goa I think is one of the most beautiful sounds out there. You just have to
get the right sound and have it mixed well. If it isn't, then no drugs will
help you. I for one started listening to Goa sober. I know there are alot
more trancers out there that would agree, Goa is a drug itself, a very
beautiful Natural High.


>Myself, I have recently decided not eat pills and things anymore, I'm
>trying to go back to where I began, >and let the music be my drug of
>choice..I sometimes wonder if I am one of the only people out there who
>>listens to jungle exclusively..I have an unconditional love for jungle
>that has been growing stronger and >stronger since 1993..I listen to it in
>my car, at work, at home, and at >parties..I am curious to know how >many
>other people out there have this same love for our music..that being even
>if there weren't any >drugs involved..

Well, I hate to admit this but, it took alittle EntErtainmEnt And Alittle
something with it for me to get into Jungle. I was candying when I just
trance out to a Jungle set. I couldn't stand it before. Now when sober, I
catch myself bouncing to the tunes sometimes. I'm VERY picky on it, but I
still catch alittle groove from it sober.

So sometimes it takes something to understand and grab hold of some types
of music. Then after that one time, it will eventually grow alittle on you
when your sober.

But as far as Goa goes, it's the only drug you need. It's a drug itself.
Speaking of which, I'm off work now and I'm going home to spin some Goa.

Later...and I hope this came out the way I wanted. I never am able to
really express myself the way I want in type. Typing about the love for Goa
will not do it justice IMHO. It's something that is better express in music
then in words.

(:  YOU ARE INVITED  :)


What: Cyborganic's illustrious TND (Thursday Night Dinner) - New Wave Night
When: Thursday, March 6th, 1997 - 8 PM
Where: 654 Mission Street between 3rd & New Montgomery, San Francisco, CA

With the midpoint of the 80's already a decade behind us, that era is
not only fair game for but heartily deserving of cruel and unusual
parody. From Valley Girls to Prince to Duran Duran to Madonna, pop
culture of the first MTV generation was embarrassingly melodramatic.
The 80's were characterized by a lot of hair and a lot of hair products.

Whether you were into Dead or Alive, Aha, Bananarama, Depeche Mode,
The Cure, Wham!, or you were just a moon-walkin', break-dancin' spaz
in terribly modern clothes, the likelihood of self-consciousness
regarding this genre is inevitable, but the time has come for the time
has come to reclaim big hair! Reclaim valspeak! Take back that
shredded, tattered, ripped-up fashion and make it your own again!

with a rebel yell for the very first time i ran, i ran so far away
in my little red corvette, cuz girls just wanna have fun. oh come
on eileen take on me and our house in the middle of the street.
one thing leads to another.  staring at the sea is the glamourous
life. lies lies lies yeah.  99 luft balloons wake me up before you go-go.
relax, don't do it, when you want to come...

**  the one and only Brian Behlendorf will dj the tunes  **

writes:

<< I am curious to know how many other people out there have this same love
for our music..that being even if there weren't any drugs involved.. >>

Hi, shawn and sfravers,
I don't do drugs anymore, I've only done e enough times to count on one hand
in about one and a half months time.  I love to party. I enjoy the music
sober just as well as I did high, actually more in sobriety.  I also love the
whole aspect of PLUR in sobriety because when I feel peace, love, unity and
respect for someone or something, I know it is not drug induced.  I love
people at parties when I am sober because I remember all  your smilin faces
with your names about 70% of the time, and I love all of you whether you are
sober or not.  
I still love goa, I love trance, I love jungle, I love ambient.
A whole lot of love.
And I've been partying sober more than I've been partying high.
So, yeah, I do love the music  when there are no drugs involved.
smiles:)
{{hugs}}
love<3
april(4) 
have you hugged your fourth month of the year today??


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar  4 17:48:51 1997

Date: Tue, 4 Mar 1997 17:44:46 -0800 (PST)
From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Reply-To: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Live 105 Rips Goa
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9703041722.A28653-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Just heard a pretty infuriating song on Live 105.  It's called "Ain't 
Going to GOA", and it's a smug debunking of the rave scene and its "false 
spirituality."  Taking a supposed "house music" side (which the song 
posits as "real" as opposed to bankrupt goa music), it rips trance 
dancing and smart drinks, and conjures an image of white people getting high 
on Third World beaches (i.e. the real Goa in India) thinking that means 
they're enlightened.  It ends by claiming that real spirituality is found 
in the Church!!

Kinda ironic that this anti-trance polemic is found on a commercial radio 
station that features bands jumping on the electronic bandwagon as fast 
as possible!  

If I had more time here, I would like to get into a discussion about the 
facile spirituality surrounding psychedelics ingested by privileged white 
youth.  But this particular song's attack seems pretty vicious, 
especially considering that it comes from a source identified as 
"house."  What happened to one house, one nation?  Is the first face that 
we as a dance subculture present to the mainstream going to have two 
sides, an irreconciliable split between house and trance?  I know this 
already is rampant in the scene...parties and subscenes ossifying around 
just one kind of music... 

I personally find house to be rather lightweight compared to the intense -
yes, spiritual - experience of goa, but that's a far cry from denouncing 
all househeads as mindless posers.  

And I bet Live 105 is playing this because to them it is "hip," using 
vernacular you have to be "in" to understand.  Live 105 gets to appear 
cutting-edge while promoting more prejudice against the very music they 
are profiting from.  A neat trick!




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar  4 18:04:57 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id SAA04863; Tue, 4 Mar 1997 18:04:57 -0800 (PST)

In-Reply-To: <01BC28AD.88D75D40@shawnb.softiron.com> from "Shawn Bryant" at Mar 4, 97 03:05:43 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> 
> 	I have often wondered what the rave scene would be like without =
> drugs..I am almost positive there wouldn't be nearly the number of =
> people involved..The reason I like the scene at all, is pure and =
> simple..I love the music..Whether it being techno, house, trance, =
> 
> (etc) 

Well, firstly let me say that I am a total goa-head and take no drugs
whatsoever (well, OK I drink coffee and the occasional beer). As people 
have said, goa/psi-trance is like a drug itself - you don't need anything 
more (although I can imagine that the experience can be heightened with 
the "right" additives).

I have also wondered, though, if the rave scene would be what it is today
if it wasn't for E, and I think it probably wouldn't be. E was probably 
what has made it the empathetic, PLURy movement it is, but I think that
once that movement has started, after a while the positive vibe starts 
to feed on itself. You get enough happy people in a room and EVERYONE 
starts to feel happy, whether they are on E or not. And after a while, 
it doesn't matter if NOBODY is on E - everyone is so keyed into the 
positive vibe and the openness and sharing that they come to expect
at raves that the vibe is there anyway and the drugs are unimportant. 
And maybe after a while people start carrying that vibe into their 
everyday lives and really starting to change their world outside raving.

I think that first and foremost it was the music that drew us all into
this scene, and it's the music that unites us as ravers rather than just
real nice happy people. There's a lot beyond the music though. The amount 
of love and creativity I see in putting together (say) a Harmony party 
or a Warmth (which I missed, damn!) constantly amazes me and brings joy to 
my heart. I just don't see this kind of thing anywhere else and it, as 
well as the music, keeps bringing me back. I can (and do) listen to the 
music constantly at home or in the car, but there's something INCREDIBLE 
about the vibe at some of these parties that is just really special, and
for me it has very little to do with drugs.

Well I'm rambling..... my 0.02.

Love you all, you cwazy wavers!

- Martin  =]

	id sma002097; Tue Mar  4 21:14:36 1997
Message-Id: <1.5.4.16.19970304191757.4caf949e@popd.ix.netcom.com>
X-Sender: shawna-@popd.ix.netcom.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.4 (16)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Stirring it up...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

><< I am curious to know how many other people out there have this same love
>for our music..that being even if there weren't any drugs involved.. >>



I could possibly be one of the few people who (for the most part) enjoy the
music more sober than I do on e.  I just can't dance while on e (which
really sucks), if I'm wanting to be on e I find dancing & music distracting,
if I want to listen to music and dance, I find being on e distracting.  Like
at Madness for example, I could never have danced the way I danced as hard
as I did on e, I would have missed all that amazing music!  And I find this
a bit ironic actually, because I did not like techno until I heard it one
time on e.  And when I did, I thought to myself "Oooohhhh! I get it now!"
and danced like a maniac.  It's so opposite now.  I love techno sober, I
love when it just grabs me by the scruff and drags me out on the dance floor
to dance whether I want it to or not, and that will never happen on e.  On
e, I become Just Another Chill Room Victim, and I miss out on a lot of the
party.  Not so bad if the dj's suck! ;)

Anyway, that's my backwards perspective. :)

Love
Shawna

p.s.  However, I cannot claim this is true for acid.  But that is just not a
drug I generally do at raves, the one exception being Tribal Future up in
the Mendocino mountains.  Full moon blazing, beautiful woods all around,
raver tents everywhere, and pounding techno in the center!  Ahhh! :)  And
really, viewing anything with a new perspective (i.e. listening to music on
drugs as well as sober) will always give you a new appreciation and better
understanding of it imo.  E definitely did for me with techno, and I
certainly dont need e to appreciate it now.  It merely showed me a different
way to hear it, and once I realized it was there I was off & running on my
own. :)


We are all gods in the chrysalis.
            
                   
         Do not go gentle into that good night.
       Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar  4 21:07:03 1997

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hmmm... You bring up many interesting ideas, ones that I have thought =
upon before.  The way I see it, The drugs represent a sort of =
"transitional" element in most people's rave experience.  This is of =
course my opinion.  It seems to me that many people find them selves to =
be more "responsive" ( I place quotes around this word because I am not =
sure if this is the right one) to the vibe with them.  I see it as part =
of a "maturation"( again with the quotes, I'm sorry, but I know not a =
better word for it.  I do not see it as being EXACTLY a maturation =
process; words are a poor construct with which to phrase ideas) process. =
 People come to the scene, find the people, find the music, find the =
drugs, and fall in love with all of them. Eventually, they may lose =
interest in the music(rare, but it does happen), but many people I have =
met do seem to lose interest in the drugs after a while.  I have never =
heard of anyone losing interest in the people, fortunately!  However, =
some people get too caught up in the drug facet of the scene.  This is =
when the accidents happen, and the bad press leaks out.  On one level, =
the "PLUR" vibe can be very much made up of the drug culture, but I =
believe that it soon gives way to a new understanding between people.  =
One might consider it to be a gateway into the "PLUR" so to speak.  When =
they said acid open's your mind,... well, they might not have been as =
far off as conventional wisdom claimed. =20
	I have to make an apology at this point for the horrid job that I have =
done in explaining myself.  I will think on this further, as it is an =
issue that concerns me sometimes.  Please, I would be honored if =
EVERYONE sent me (publicly or privately, I wish not to piss off those =
who want to free up the bandwith  :) ) their ideas, thought, and inputs =
about this.  Thankyou for hearing me out!


<3   <3         <3            <3
<3     <3            <3
<3       to all....

Love, Hadrian

----------
From:  Shawn Bryant[SMTP:shawnb@softiron.com]
Sent:  Tuesday, March 04, 1997 3:06 PM
To:  'sfraves@hyperreal.com'
Subject:  Stirring it up...

	I have often wondered what the rave scene would be like without =
drugs..I am almost positive there wouldn't be nearly the number of =
people involved..The reason I like the scene at all, is pure and =
simple..I love the music..Whether it being techno, house, trance, =
jungle, it doesn't really matter, if it makes feel uplifted, energized, =
and hyped up to dance, that's all that really matters..All this PLUR =
business is a great concept, but when it comes down to it, would it =
really exist without the drugs..I would love to say yes, but that's hard =
for me to actually believe..I sometimes wonder why so many people are so =
into goa..If you really listen to the music, you can see how it can be =
funky or uplifting, but does it have any kind of musical appeal other =
than the fact that it sounds really good when you're high..I wonder how =
many trancers out there would still listen to goa if there weren't any =
drugs..Myself, I have recently decided not eat pills and things anymore, =
I'm trying to go back to where I began, and let the music be my drug of =
choice..I sometimes wonder if I am one of the only people out there who =
listens to jungle exclusively..I have an unconditional love for jungle =
that has been growing stronger and stronger since 1993..I listen to it =
in my car, at work, at home, and at parties..I am curious to know how =
many other people out there have this same love for our music..that =
being even if there weren't any drugs involved..






From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar  4 21:27:25 1997

From: BRUCE ALVIN MCDONOUGH <glow@sfsu.edu>
Message-Id: <199703050527.VAA29749@orion.sfsu.edu>

Subject: drugs
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

In my opinion the rave scene likely would never have gotten started without
chemical influence.  Most of the musicians use them (if you don't think so,
drop 2 or 3 hits of 'cid and listen to about any of it), most of the best
experiences (unity, et al.) start with e or a (of course once someone gets 
there, it IS easier to go back without the drugs).  From what I've read,
the Summer of Love (in Britain (late 80s)) was largely fueled by e, not to
mention SF's own Summer of Love (1967) fueled by Psychedelics mostly.  

I would agree with Hadrian about the "transitional, responsive, and maturation"
bits, because that is largely the pattern I fall into, but it mostly started
with the drug based/rave experience of dance floor/chill room unity love (plur)
feelings.  One gets opened by the keys and tends to stay that way for a while.

bruce

Jonathan Mark Logan:

>I think you'd be surprised by the number of folks who have an
>unconditional love for the music and a complete disregard for drugs...

Exactly. In fact, in Scandinavia, people who do drugs at parties and
raves are looked down on by the "real" ravers. But at the same time,=20
I never get the same feeling of love and friendship at parties over
there as I get over here... =3D)

>On the other hand, I was surprised by the dawning realization that a
>number of folks claim to have a similar love for the music, and yet make
>drugs a central part of their raving experience.  This is not to say that
>the two are mutually exclusive.  I just think that some folks should
>seriously reconsider their priorities and change their internal dogma=20
>and external platitudes to reflect this.

To me, the need for drugs fluctuates. At 2o12 last year, I danced by
the speakers for 7 hours straight, and I was totally sober. The phat
goa and acid just blew me away. But at Ohmnisonic this past weekend,
I felt the need to just be with my friends and "e my balls off" (as
some of you may have heard me say that night...). But then again, that's
just how I feel and work. =3D)

>Needless to say, lots of people love the music.  I was initially drawn to
>the scene by the music, and it continues to hold me there.

Same here, my first raving experience came at age 14, and I will never
forget how the music kept me going all night. The repetitive beats. The
deep basslines. The tweaking sounds. That's what made me come back.=20
Nowadays, it's a combination of my love for the music and my love for
my friends, old as well as new. And oh, the drugs. =3D)

*hugs*
jonas

Personally, I think it's a rhetorical argument...

drugs have been found (if you're looking for them) in every musical movement
ever...prescription or otherwise...

there will alway be people who want to do drugs, and there will always be those
who don't...the music is kind of a constant (IM-mathematical-sort-of-HO)

GHB is no longer legal in the state of Ca, I think. It was legal because 
it was a steriod that body builders used. 

 I would say for all those people who are 
planning to take GHB go have a few beers and a toke  instead. Pretty much 
the same high.

The ironic thing about GHB is that if you don't take enough it feels like 
pot and alcohol, not worth the hassel of getting it. But if you take 
enough to get you fucked up, you usually end up being very ill. Oh, boy 
is that fun...... I love it when your friends are puking because they 
didn't know how much to take. HOWEVER on the the lighter note, you can't 
die, it just makes you sick and then after you sleep it off everything is 
fine and dandy. 

Nailvarnish

X-MSMail-Priority: Normal

Ok kids! Get out your No.2 pencils, eyes on your own paper, you have 30
min.

(If this sort of joke has been done before, someone let me know. And if I
offend anyone, which I don't *think* I will, I don't mean to and I
apologize ahead of time. Remember, this is all in good fun)


1) Alex wants to leave the Massive at Home Base and go to a party in S.J.
If the map point for the other party closes at 1AM, and it takes Alex 1 1/2
hours to drive to S.J., what time does he have to leave by in order to get
a ticket?

2) GhostTribe spent $1,000 for a city permit, $800 on DJ's, $200 on
decorations, $500 for security, and $1,000 on equipment. If they made
$25,000 in ticket sales and $10,000 in bunk E sales, how long can they wait
to throw another party to support their $1,000 a day crack habit?

3) If Eric has 100,000 Blow pops in January and goes to 2 parties a month
where he gives away 250 blowpops each night, how many Blow pops will he
have at the end of the year?

4) If a DJ has a 2 hour set to spin, and each of his records last aprox.
4min 30sec, how many records can he estimate he will play?

5) If an E dealer has 2 ounces of pure MDMA and wants to cut it how much
Mescaline does he need to make 30% more profit and how stupid would it be
for him to use heroin?

6) If a beginning DJ has $2,000 dollars and spends $850 on turntables & a
mixer, $100 on a record case, how many records can he buy at $6 and at $8
each?

7) If Roger took 3 hits of Acid at 1 o'clock and the cops bust the party at
4 o'clock, how long will he have to wait in his car before he can drive
home?


Times up!

-=Pengo=-
Blake "Pengo" Merriam

survey, out of the 450+ members of this group how many  are minority? 
Then do 
another survey. See of all the raves run in the bay area how many of them 
are not white male run? THen why don't we count how many DJs are there 
that are women? Then we can do lots of variations of that. How many 
non-white DJS? How many women of colour DJS? How many gay poor bisexual 
vegetarians with disabilities? 

We care not 100% culturally diverse at all.

happy. Life is not like that unfortunatly.

need to raise the issues here. I understand that it's a great concept but 
we need to keep improving on it. The four letters itself means little if 
we don't continue to refine the raver's ideal. Otherswise we become 
stagnant, and worse very boring.

The poison of any drug is the dose. The problem with GHB (and many other
drugs for that matter) is that it's one of the most difficult drugs to
ascertain an appropriate dose of. Hence, GHB can be a lot more dangerous
than people think it is. To say that you can't die from it is a little
presumptuous. There have been cases of seizures (READ: serious shit!)
related to overdosing on GHB. You CAN die from a seizure, and you can at
least get brain damage. I recommend sticking to Nailvarnish's suggestion of
having a few beers and taking a toke, two things known to be relatively
harmless in moderate doses, which are easily measurable. And at least you
don't have as high a probability of getting sick and ruining your night, as
well as that of your friends who have to clean your vomit out of their
cars. Anyone who's had severe motion sickness will know exactly what too
much GHB will feel like.

Adam

>
>         Friendship is a strange thing...we find ourselves telling each
>> other
>> the deepest details of our lives...things we don't even share with the
>> families who raised us...but what is a friend? a confidant?  a
>> shoulder to cry on? an ear to listen? a heart to feel? A friend is all of
>> these ...and more. No matter where we met, no matter how long we've been
>> together...I call you friend. A word so small, yet so large in feeling, a
>> word filled with emotion, a word overflowing with love. Truly great
>> things
>> come in small packages. Once the package of friendship has been opened,
>> it
>> can never be closed. It is a constant book always waiting...waiting to be
>> read...and enjoyed. We may have our disagreements...we may have our
>> disappointments...we may argue..we may concern one another...friendship
>> is a
>> unique bond that lasts through all tribulations. A part of each of us
>> goes
>> into our friendships...our humor...our experiences...our tears.
>> Friendships
>> are foundations...necessary for life...and love. Friends...you and
>> me...you
>> brought another friend and then there were three...we started our
>> group...our circle of friends...there is no begining....there is no end
>> 
>>         Keep this going...mail it to all you friends....mail it to those
>> you
>> never met....those you have and those you have lost along the way...
>> 
>> 
>> 
>> 
>>
>>-- 
>>Richardson, Patrick W
>>richarpw@jmu.edu
>>
>>
>>
>
>
>

if you love/like someone, tell them.
don't be afraid to express yourself.
reach out and tell someone what they mean to you, because when you decide
that it's the right time, it may be too late.
seize the day, never have regrets, and most importantly, stay close to
your friends and family, for they have helped make you the person you are
today.

makes them all the more special.

On 03/05/97 14:14:08 you wrote:
>
>>  Our house is 100% culturally diverse.   Few 
>
>What? YA. If you call diversity lots of white people and a few 
>minorities.  Sorry but the idea that raving is diverse is such a joke. 
>How many really poor people can afford a $40 night. This is a pretty 
>middle to upperclass activity.  How many women of 
>colour do you see actually running a rave or DJing? IN FACT lets do a 
>survey, out of the 450+ members of this group how many  are minority? 
>Then do 
>another survey. See of all the raves run in the bay area how many of them 
>are not white male run? THen why don't we count how many DJs are there 
>that are women? Then we can do lots of variations of that. How many 
>non-white DJS? How many women of colour DJS? How many gay poor bisexual 
>vegetarians with disabilities? 
>
>We care not 100% culturally diverse at all.  
>

I am not sure were you are going with your argumument??  All because the percentages are not 
strait across the board does not meen that the scene is not diverse.  I have never seen a sign 
in front of a party that says "No Minorities Allowed".  I believe that this comunity is open to 
everyone and gives everyoone a chance.  Thats the whole idea of an underground.  Mabee ther are 
no gay poor bisexual vegan diabetic female dj's in our scene, or mabee there are?  who knows?  
but the fact that there could be is enough to say that we are a compleatly diverse scene.  No 
one is stopping anyone from doing anything in this comunity for reasons of discrimination.  That 
wouldn't conform with the precepts of a rave.

>
>> other groupings of people can make such a claim, but here in our little rave 
>> world, we can say that, and mean it.  What this means is, that we will 
>> accept anyone for whatever their ideals as part of the greater whole.
>> 
>> 
>> Scott =)
>> 
>> DO we really accept everybody? Lets let in Neo Nazis, and the KKK? We 
>don't, we don't allow many other voices here. We want everyone to just be 
>happy. Life is not like that unfortunatly.  
>
>I am not flaming you at all. I just find PLUR problematic, and feel the 
>need to raise the issues here. I understand that it's a great concept but 
>we need to keep improving on it. The four letters itself means little if 
>we don't continue to refine the raver's ideal. Otherswise we become 
>stagnant, and worse very boring.  

What exactly do you propose.  Do you think that promoters should apply Equal Opertunity 
employment policies when puting together a DJ lineup?  I am not so sure I would agree with you 
that it is fair to book a dj just because they are Black or a Female.  It is much better to book 
them for their talent.  This is after-all an entertainmnet industry, not the DMV.  Lets keep it 
realistic.

The whole idealism of PLUR is the fact that is a vauge definition of very open ended concept 
that somewhat try to define the spirit of raving.  If we try to refine it or narow it down, we 
will end up creating bariers.  Lets let every individual decide for themselves what PLUR means 
to them.  The Idea is out there.  If you want to apply it to your own lifestyle, and set 
guidlines for your actions based on a refinement of plur, then that is wonderful.  But everybody 
has to decide to do that for themselves.  That is the foundation behind the diversity of our 
scene.

Peace, and keep it real.

Ray Vonie
bad spelling is my trademark

ps see you at community tonight

From: The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Where to get cheap glowsticks!  (sorta nrr)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey all!

As some of you may remember, I was once known as the glow stick queen, every
time I'd go to a party I'd get the question "Hey can I have one of your
glowsticks?"  And of course my response was always something along the lines
of "Well I dont' know, I've only got about 20 or so left!"  (you guys
remember me and my glowstickw dontcha?)  I'd always have an array of colors,
green, pink, yellow, red, orange etc.  But for the past year or more, I have
ever been in search of the elusive Blue Glow Stick.  And not one of those
stupid little ones either (altho the small blue ones were hard to come by
also).  These mythological creatures have been spotted from time to time at
certain party stores only at very specific times of the year, for example
Halloween.  But I, in spite of my great search, could find none!  They
eluded me every time, at every party supply store, every scuba diving store,
every Grand Auto Supply.  I was beginning to think they no longer existed,
possibly hunted to extinction by ravers and others.  I really did hunt for
over a year.  And then the other colors started vanishing too.  No longer
carried at my local scuba diving store, no longer at Grand Auto, and the
party stores really did only carry them at Halloween, and oft-times only the
little ones.  And then one day I ran in to KC at a party (hi kc!), she tells
me I can mail order them, big blue ones even.  Kinda cool, but who wants to
wait for the U.S. Mail?  And then today I find it!  A carefully hidden
little party supply store off on some side street in Lafayette, CA.  Big
'uns!  Little 'uns!  Long & skinny 'uns!  All colors!  Even my precious
long-lost blue ones!  All year round they say!  Tri-colored necklaces they
say!  Wow.  Needless to say I was jumping around in excitement.  I couldn't
believe that after a year of searching, I'd finally found my glow-stick
supplier again, and especially that they carry blue ones, year round.  And
hot pinks, which also rule and are hard to come by.  And not only that, they
are the cheapest I've ever run into (without mail ordering that is).  The
big ones I'd buy would usually range between $2 and $2.50.  These big ones
(and they were the better longer lasting 8 hour ones) were $1.35!  Yaaay!  

So any of you out there looking for glowsticks who happen to be in the
Contra Costa area, or who occasionally travel along highway 24, go visit
Boswell's party supplies in Lafayette!  (altho it was weird getting there.
I called and asked for directions, and when I followed the directions, I
found myself at the place they are going to be relocating to sometime in the
future rather than the store they're at now.  Very strange of them to give
me directions to their future location, eh?)


Love
Shawna

p.s.  Amy- tell Mel I now can find an unlimited supply of big blue ones! :)

To: rayvonie@ix.netcom.com
Date: Wed, 5 Mar 1997 20:36:29 -0800 (PST)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <19953520610141@ix.netcom.com> from "rayvonie@ix.netcom.com" at Mar 5, 97 10:16:21 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

ok, i'm going to step and be the "you better think twice" grinch on this
thread (with a nod to jslee!)

> I am not sure were you are going with your argumument??  All because the
> percentages are not  
> strait across the board does not meen that the scene is not diverse.  I
> have never seen a sign  
> in front of a party that says "No Minorities Allowed".

but segratation is very rarely overt.  if, to take a more neutral example,
no martians ever show up to my parties, then i don't need to put up a sign
that says "no damn martians allowed!"  or if only one or two ever show
up, and we make them feel uncomfortable till they bail, then still we
don't need an official rule.  the proof's in the pudding, ray, and the
fact is that by and large even when a party is held in the middle of a
almost completely minority neighborhood, it still looks lily white to me. 

NOTE: i'm not saying there is some covert racist cabal operating in the sf
party scene.  i'm just saying, look - the fact is that we aren't really
integrated, even if by policy we are, so we ought to ask why is that?

> What exactly do you propose?   Do you think that promoters should apply
> Equal Opertunity  
> employment policies when puting together a DJ lineup?  I am not so sure
> I would agree with you  
> that it is fair to book a dj just because they are Black or a Female.
> It is much better to book  
> them for their talent. 

again, almost right.  yes, of course it would be wrong to have quotas for
dj breakdowns, possibly increasing the bad spinning we hear.

BUT - on the other hand i've been to a bunch of parties where somebody
spun because they were a friend of the host, or the promoter, or of one of
the other dj's, and they had shitty records and no skills.  what's up with
that?

the #1 way to get jobs is contacts = friends, and if the pool of dj's,
promoters, and their circles of friends is lily white, then it makes it
damn hard for minority talent to get breaks when maybe they don't deserve
it, so later they'll have super-hard skills that make you say damn!

btw - i mean this all meant in a kind way - i find this sorta stuff really
easy to overlook in our day to day life.
matt.

On 03/05/97 20:36:29 you wrote:
>
>ok, i'm going to step and be the "you better think twice" grinch on this
>thread (with a nod to jslee!)
>
>> I am not sure were you are going with your argumument??  All because the
>> percentages are not  
>> strait across the board does not meen that the scene is not diverse.  I
>> have never seen a sign  
>> in front of a party that says "No Minorities Allowed".
>
>but segratation is very rarely overt.  if, to take a more neutral example,
>no martians ever show up to my parties, then i don't need to put up a sign
>that says "no damn martians allowed!"  or if only one or two ever show
>up, and we make them feel uncomfortable till they bail, then still we
>don't need an official rule.  the proof's in the pudding, ray, and the
>fact is that by and large even when a party is held in the middle of a
>almost completely minority neighborhood, it still looks lily white to me. 
>
>NOTE: i'm not saying there is some covert racist cabal operating in the sf
>party scene.  i'm just saying, look - the fact is that we aren't really
>integrated, even if by policy we are, so we ought to ask why is that?

HhMMM????  thats is a real good question.  I personaly always thought that the scene was 
intergrated, but you did bring up a good point.  I believe that htis perticular underground 
scene relyes heavily on word of mouth to spread the message.  If you are someone that is 
conected or asociated, then you may find out, if you are not, then you will never know.  

if you venture within the inner-circles of the hip-hip, or asian dance scenes you will notice 
reverse intergration.  these are also underground dance scenes and they probably consider 
themselves as open and accepting of all minorities (white being the minority this time), but it 
is obvious that they too work on word of mouth in there promotion and those not being in the 
loop, just do not find out.

The point being:  Since there is not an intergrated underground dance movement, Then no one 
underground dance scene can be compleatly intergrated.  The hip-hop scene is mostly black and 
hispanic, the asian dance scene is mostly oriental, the rusian dance scene is mostly europeans, 
the gay dance scene is mostly gays and bisexual - not heterosexuals......and so on...

I think that when it comes to intergration, the Rave scene is the closest that it gets, 
percentage wise at least, to a compleatly open and non discriminationg dance scene.  when you 
compare it to the other dance scenes, I think you will understand.
>
>> What exactly do you propose?   Do you think that promoters should apply
>> Equal Opertunity  
>> employment policies when puting together a DJ lineup?  I am not so sure
>> I would agree with you  
>> that it is fair to book a dj just because they are Black or a Female.
>> It is much better to book  
>> them for their talent. 
>
>again, almost right.  yes, of course it would be wrong to have quotas for
>dj breakdowns, possibly increasing the bad spinning we hear.
>
>BUT - on the other hand i've been to a bunch of parties where somebody
>spun because they were a friend of the host, or the promoter, or of one of
>the other dj's, and they had shitty records and no skills.  what's up with
>that?
>
>the #1 way to get jobs is contacts = friends, and if the pool of dj's,
>promoters, and their circles of friends is lily white, then it makes it
>damn hard for minority talent to get breaks when maybe they don't deserve
>it, so later they'll have super-hard skills that make you say damn!

of course its all about your friends.  if you were a promoter, would you rather have one of your 
friends spin at your party or some body you did not know?  thats what being a friend is all 
about =>  hooking up your friend, and them hooking it up for you.

Anyways, gotta get ready for community, gota run

Keep it real

Ray Vonie
bad spelling is my trademark.

>GHB is no longer legal in the state of Ca, I think. It was legal 
>because 
>it was a steriod that body builders used.

I was told that body builders used it because it helped them sleep and
repaired their muscles while they were sleeping.  Also, you don't feel as
burnt out, the next day, as you would after doing some other drugs.
 

> I would say for all those people who are 
>planning to take GHB go have a few beers and a toke  instead. Pretty 
>much 
>the same high.

I disagree.  I tried GHB for the first time a few days ago.  I was
expecting to feel drunk and stoned, like you said, but it was the
complete opposite.  Rather than feeling tired and clumsy, I felt
energetic and I felt like I could do anything!  It also made me so happy
that it was almost annoying!  I just bounced around my living room
telling all my friends how happy I was!


>The ironic thing about GHB is that if you don't take enough it feels 
>like 
>pot and alcohol, not worth the hassel of getting it. But if you take 
>enough to get you fucked up, you usually end up being very ill. Oh, 
>boy 
>is that fun...... I love it when your friends are puking because they 
>didn't know how much to take.

When I tried it, I was with a bunch of people.  A few of us were
first-timers.  None of us got sick.  We all had a great time, too!  One
girl fell asleep, but she had been sleepy all day, so I don't think it
was just because of the GHB.

I should point out that I was with a bunch of people who knew what they
were doing.  Anyone who uses drugs should know what they are doing, or be
with someone who knows what they're doing.  The people I was with made
sure I didn't take too much.

I really liked my first GHB experience.  In fact I'm totally looking
forward to doing it again...and again, and again, and again....

Love and kisses to all!!! :-)

----Libby Rose

The Top Ten Reasons You Know A Rave Is Bunk.

10. The flyer is harder to fold than a map.

9. The flyer saids RAVE on it.

8. You can win tickets for it on Live 105

7. The name has more words in it than DJs

6. It costs $25

5. It takes you one hour to get a free hug

4. They sent you the a flyer for it in the mail

3. The location on the flyer plus directions on how to get there.

2. You can purchase pre-sal tickets for it from BASS

And the number one reason....

1. The DJ is spinning James Brown Is Dead when you walk in.

Luvs&Hugs,
Paul

Re: Pengo wrote:
> 
> Ok kids! Get out your No.2 pencils, eyes on your own paper, you have 30
> min.
> 
> (If this sort of joke has been done before, someone let me know. And if I
> offend anyone, which I don't *think* I will, I don't mean to and I
> apologize ahead of time. Remember, this is all in good fun)
> 
> 1) Alex wants to leave the Massive at Home Base and go to a party in S.J.
> If the map point for the other party closes at 1AM, and it takes Alex 1 1/2
> hours to drive to S.J., what time does he have to leave by in order to get
> a ticket?
> 
> 2) GhostTribe spent $1,000 for a city permit, $800 on DJ's, $200 on
> decorations, $500 for security, and $1,000 on equipment. If they made
> $25,000 in ticket sales and $10,000 in bunk E sales, how long can they wait
> to throw another party to support their $1,000 a day crack habit?
> 
> 3) If Eric has 100,000 Blow pops in January and goes to 2 parties a month
> where he gives away 250 blowpops each night, how many Blow pops will he
> have at the end of the year?
> 
> 4) If a DJ has a 2 hour set to spin, and each of his records last aprox.
> 4min 30sec, how many records can he estimate he will play?
> 
> 5) If an E dealer has 2 ounces of pure MDMA and wants to cut it how much
> Mescaline does he need to make 30% more profit and how stupid would it be
> for him to use heroin?
> 
> 6) If a beginning DJ has $2,000 dollars and spends $850 on turntables & a
> mixer, $100 on a record case, how many records can he buy at $6 and at $8
> each?
> 
> 7) If Roger took 3 hits of Acid at 1 o'clock and the cops bust the party at
> 4 o'clock, how long will he have to wait in his car before he can drive
> home?
> 
> Times up!
> 
> -=Pengo=-
> Blake "Pengo" Merriam

Subject: GHB (was Re: Personal Experiences....
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

>I disagree.  I tried GHB for the first time a few days ago.  I was
>expecting to feel drunk and stoned, like you said, but it was the
>complete opposite.  Rather than feeling tired and clumsy, I felt
>energetic and I felt like I could do anything!  It also made me so happy
>that it was almost annoying!  I just bounced around my living room
>telling all my friends how happy I was!

indeed, drugs affect different people different ways.  most people find GHB
makes them feel a little drunk and generally relaxed, but i do know at
least a couple people who say it makes them feel bouncyhappy.

about dosage: BE CAREFUL!

the strength of GHB can vary GREATLY from batch to batch.  every time you
get a new batch, you should start with very little (no more than 1/2
tablespoon?) and see how it hits you before doing more.

overdoses of GHB have been linked to seizures, coma and even death.  if you
are careful and only take a little bit at a time, though, you'll fall
asleep before getting to that level of toxicity.

love,

brian

Hi!  ]=)

On Wed, 5 Mar 1997, Brian Denny wrote:


> indeed, drugs affect different people different ways.  most people find GHB
> makes them feel a little drunk and generally relaxed, but i do know at
> least a couple people who say it makes them feel bouncyhappy.

 I find that at proper dosage levels it always makes me feel fine and 
sociable.

> about dosage: BE CAREFUL!

 Yeah! You might fall asleep.  ;)  Probably the biggest scare is 
combining GHB with sedatives (like alcohol). You are asking for nasty 
situations then like respritory arrest.


> the strength of GHB can vary GREATLY from batch to batch.  every time you
> get a new batch, you should start with very little (no more than 1/2
> tablespoon?) and see how it hits you before doing more.

ummm, my experiences have not born this out. The dosage level has always 
been reliable. Whether crystal or liquid. Does not mean that it is always 
true though. It is always a good idea to start slow and easy with unknown 
batches. I would like to know where you are getting your info from Brian.


> overdoses of GHB have been linked to seizures, coma and even death.

 I've only heard of this when combined with other drugs like sedatives. 
I've seen people have _mild_ seizures. Very similar to people twitching as 
they fall asleep. I've also seen people take _way_ too much, pass out 
cold, and then wake three hours later and totally boogie.


>  if you
> are careful and only take a little bit at a time, though, you'll fall
> asleep before getting to that level of toxicity.

 Brian. Are you getting this info off Hyperreal or what. Thanks!  :)



Ran D.Dreams



                                      (Namaste)
                                         /
                                   -=*=-/
                                     ~

From: Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com>

Cc: kwood@cnet.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

	Not personal experience, but what I've been told about GBH 
	by weightlifter types I occasionally hang with is:

	Low dose = upper/stimulant effect (like Libby describes)

	Med dose = drunkenness/downer effect

	Hi dose = out cold for hours

	The thing that makes it so weird is that combining it with
	any other drug (like even one beer) can change where the 
	transition points between the different effects are by a lot.
	Anyway, if you like the "upper" effect, remember you can't
	get more of it by taking a higher dose.

Date: Thu, 6 Mar 1997 08:41:08 -0800
MIME-Version: 1.0

Upon arriving to the cozy little space known as the Cocodrie Club, I was =
pleasantly surprised to see Stareyes take the decks..And let me tell you =
man, I have never heard Vivian play better..Track after track of funked =
up, uplifting hardstep..Needless to say, I was dripping with sweat only =
a half an hour into her set..She played some absolute monster licks, =
which I learned later came courtesy of the man Aphrodite..As for the =
vibes, the place was rammed, and everyone seemed to be havin' it..Next =
up came Flux..(Evan) started out a little slow, but soon after had the =
massive bouncing around to some excellent jump up business..By this =
time, there was little room left to dance, but it didn't seem to matter, =
because of the wicked vibe of the entire place..A serious B.A.S.S. Kru =
mash up came next..Ed (UFO) dropped an absolutely BOOMIN' track by =
Mystical Influence, that had everybody in the place callin' for the =
REWIND!!!!!!..After Ed dropped his second track, it was time for the DJ =
Abstract to take the decks..Alex dug up a classic Elements of Noise =
track, and cut it to pieces with some surprisingly sick scratching =
skills..And that's where my night came to a close..Tired and dreading my =
6am alarm, I was really glad I had made it out to this incredible =
bi-monthly event..And although Bizzy B never made it, the night was =
probably the best night I have had out in months..Massive respect to the =
BASS Kru, and to everyone feeling the vibes..Jungle in SF is here to =
stay, nuff said...


~Ibis                              "all I want to do is bounce..."

PS, if anyone is interested, I was the tall, lenky fella who looked like =
he was warming up for a title fight...Always bouncin'

peace....

ok, it's time for me to (horror) admit i'm wrong!  or at least overcautious.

>> overdoses of GHB have been linked to seizures, coma and even death.
>
> I've only heard of this when combined with other drugs like sedatives.
>I've seen people have _mild_ seizures. Very similar to people twitching as
>they fall asleep. I've also seen people take _way_ too much, pass out
>cold, and then wake three hours later and totally boogie.

ok, you are correct.  a little research (which i should have done before)
reveals that all cases of severe negative effects from GHB have involved
either pre-existing health conditions or the use of alcohol or other
depressants.

it actually appears to be a very safe drug.

see http://www.lycaeum.org/drugs/synthetics/ghb/ghbfaq.txt

for a very informative faq.

sorry for the misinformation.

love,

brian

Thought I'd jump in on this...even though the thread is getting tired.
I have had many experiences with GHB...I have to agree with most of the
posts I've read and I think the idea here is the same that goes for most
substances. 
Dosage is the key factor. (I'm talking only physically)
I've had a great time on GHB and I've also regretted taking it like
nothing else. Different people definately have differ physical reactions
to it at the same dosage. I've witnessed my roomate passed out so cold
that we couldn't wake him up and thought he was in a coma, while his g/f
was jumping around and buzzing like a bee. They took exactly the same
dosage and he outweighed her by 40 pounds. 
I have not witnessed any permanent or life-threatening effects from
GHB;(although if one takes GHB, passes out, and vomits...definately a
serious situation) 
but I have noticed a particuar dosage window between 2-3 capfulls where
the effects fluctuate wildly and can be very disorienting. Taken in
conjunction with other substances...(alchohol & pot) can make the
effects intensify exponentially! I've seen all sorts of reactions;
intense horniness, anger and violence, intensified emotions, loss of
balance, disorientation, loss of memory, increased confidence, increased
insecurity....etc. I think GHB tends to intensify whatever you are
feeling emotionally and physically anyway. (somewhat similar to
psycho-active compounds) 
I've seen people finish taking a dosage and fall asleep on a couch 10
minutes later. Lots of people get sick, then really enjoy themselves on
it.  Personally, I did it a few times in college and embarassed myself
at a bar so bad I never took it again. My mouth was running with
insensitive and rude comments, I had no idea what I was doing, and all I
remember is not being able to see very well. Personally I couldn't
imagine raving on it....although at lower dosages it does give you
energy and a good feeling. But it is a VERY fine line between that level
and the above mentioned point being fubar. 
Sorry if I have repeated what has already been said...just my .02c. 
Peace,Love and homemade drugs....
fubari

Subject: Re: Come-Unity Review?
MIME-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Someone asked for a ComeUnity review.....  so...

I was really looking forward to the deep dependable house that I expect from Garth and Jeno, and from being in that special ComeUnity environment, where the ravers, the club kids, the cruisers and the just-wanna-have-fun folks come together.   But I couldn't stay out late (gotta work!) so I was hoping it would be goin' on early, as it often does.

My friend Sarah and I got there around 11:00, plenty of room to dance, which is great, and 1015 has remodeled and opened up the big room even more.

Unfortunately, the sound sucked, no treble, too much vibrating bass, and therefore a mushy sort of confusing sound.  (It looked like 1015 may have installed their own speakers and the Wicked sound system wasn't there?  I'm not a sound tech, but I know buzz when I hear it!) 

 And Simon was spinning the first set.  I don't usually respond to his music choices and his mixes, and this was not one of his better nights, I could hardly get myself to get into a groove.  All I wanted to do was dance, so it was frustrating.

The crowd was very clubby, there seemed to be few ComeUnity regulars there, and there was a drunk couple doing the dance floor version of the nasty in front of us for what seemed like eternity.  I was ready to go up and tell them I was with the club, and that the club rule was that couples dancingt was confined to the corners, thank you very much.  Fortunately, they eventually moved or left.

Saw only one person I knew (actually he recognized me! hi Andy) ... and left at 12:30 since the music never picked up.  I hope things got better when the next dj came on.   

I don't know if it's me, or if it's that the ComeUnity crew's heart just isn't quite in it any more, but it certainly is not anything like it used to be.  Ah well, such is life.  I guess I'm just spoiled, being able to hang out with so many wonderful ravers, that club life just can't cut it anymore!  I just WISH I could get my house music fix on a regular basis (other than my car!).

Leslie   ; ^)

OK,
	I have 680's now but prefer Ortofons Concordes, then Nightclubs.
Concordes supposedly get better Bass response than Nightclubs but both
perform well when backcuing, scratching, backspinning etc. I have no
experience with Trackmasters but I'have been told Ortofons are better.
					VERTIGO

Fulla Schitt and Giva Schitt, and a son, Chicken Schitt.

Schitt.

the arrival of Baby shit.

Now you know not only Jack Schitt, but also the entire Schitt Family.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Mar  6 13:12:05 1997

Received: from mail1.sirius.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id NAA14779; Thu, 6 Mar 1997 13:11:54 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [205.178.41.41] ([205.178.41.41]) by mail1.sirius.com (8.6.12/960710) with ESMTP id NAA22654 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 6 Mar 1997 13:09:33 -0800
Date: Thu, 6 Mar 1997 13:09:33 -0800
X-Sender: branka@pop.sirius.com
Message-Id: <v03007800af446bdf4147@[205.178.41.41]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: *B* <branka@sirius.com>
Subject: Wish review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I have been looking forward to this "Wish" for few weeks (although I go
almost every week, Mars and Mystr-E have a very special place in my heart
and I can't wait to see them, every single time).

I have to admit that the new set-up at "Wish" has been a little disturbing
lately.  It was great when you were able to have a beer and dance at the
same time, but I guess some people got in trouble due to underage drinking,
so now, the drinkers are divided from others with a big white cloth that
goes around the bar.  I wish the cloth could be a little smaller, so you
can see what's going on at the non-drinking tables, because having a beer
can get pretty lonely.

I went to "Wish" by myself knowing that dancing is what I want to get out
of the night.  Had few beers (yep, sitting by myself at the closest table
to the dance floor, so I can actually look at people), and then Mars came
on.  It took me a little bit to get into the dancing, but once I started I
had no time for anything else.  My roommate Ana showed up, so we were
crowding the dance floor next to Adam G.  What can I say?  Mars and Mystr-E
are definitely one of the best DJs I've ever heard.  Their music is so full
of energy, and it just makes you move harder, faster :).  I kept dancing
with a big smile on my face, my body getting more tired, my clothes getting
soked, but not wanting to stop.  The lights came on, the music stopped, and
it was time to go home.

This was definitely one of the best weeknights out :).  Too bad I had to
work in the morning....

If you haven't heard Mars and Mystr-E they should be on your list.  Can't
wait for their new tapes, because it seems to be that stuff they spun last
night was a touch 'harder' than on their tapes....

F-8 junkie,
*B*

From: Tony Rose <trose@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: hey neat!
Message-ID: <Pine.ULT.3.93.970306124932.26052A-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk

one of the TA's in my class just wrote the neatest thing to our class
newsgroup check it out...
<clip>
P.S. There may be some who think that raves have nothing to do with
neurochemistry...they would be misinformed. 

and then he added a link to sfraves homepage for the rest of our class to
check out...so i followed the link to said "sfraves homepage" to discover
a really neat thing called the raver white pages...but it is not very up
to date...so I'll start with my bio and maybe we can figure out how to add
them to the existing bio's ...(derek?)


My name is Tony Rose
I moved to Berkeley from Arlington Virginia on June 16th 1993, from the
first day I was here I knew that I had found my home. THE BAY RULES!!
I have also lived in Orlando, Salt Lake, And St. George(bleh).
	i have always loved electronic music, from my early days when my
first favorite song was mr. roboto =) by styx,   then in high school I
started getting into the whole new wave industrial thing =() ...I actually
still listen to the ol bauhaus, love & rockets, front 242 every now &
then. I-)
	techno started happening in orlando just when i moved to Virginia, 
club Oz was going off, but I wasnt old enough to get in!!!
When I moved to virginia the most active music scene was the dead, I got
really into that scene for a few years, probably while the rest of you
were here raving at kickin full moons and insane massives... I learned
alot from the dead scene about community and how to be open to new ideas
and ways of life. I even went on a summer tour in 92 which is definately
one of the funnest and craziest summers i have ever had! We took my little
peice of junk $200 toyota from pennsylvania to georgia...and not one flat!
	I went to my first rave at some crazy warehouse in some CRUMMY
neighborhood in washington DC, it was incredible, it reminded me alot of
the ol days at visagei in orlando dancing to nitzer ebb or 242, but it was
happier and more human friendly =) ... one thing that I thought that was
really neat at that party was a couple of times during the night they
would completely turn off the music for a second, then this huge BOOM!
like a stick of dynamite or something had just exploded ...AHHHHH!! then
the music would come back twice as intense the room just WENT OFFFFFFF!!!
	I joined sfraves when i first got my e-mail account about 2.5
years ago and lurked/deleted for a while before i posted, meanwhile I was
exploring the club scene, went to a few sunsets, but was basically too
bogged down with school to really get involved. The first time i really
FELT the vibe was at Friends and Family summer 1996, the one with the
rainbow and belfast playing singing happy birthday to some guy named
joe while we all had the biggest hug ever! It was incredible! This party
definately passed the cup test...
	After that, the next friends and family was momentous again! This
time i finally decided that i was going to get more involved and I made an
effort to start meeting people that I had been communicating with for so
long virtually, brendan99 introduced me to about 4 million sfravers...=-()
	Since then I have fallen more and more in love with the bay area
the music and the scene...I have much hope that we will all go far...i
love you guys
tony rose

ps. see you at FREAKY!!!

Hi-

Every once in a while we get in a big discussion over what should be on
SFRaves and what shouldn't. Regardless of all the bickering, people
always end up posting what they want to anyways...

However, the LEAST you can do is add (NRR) in front of your             
subject, i.e.:

                 (NRR) PEPSI VS. COKE.

There are hundreds of people on this list, and the little things you do
matter.

-peace-

alex

At 1:24 PM -0800 3/6/97, Nancy Shaw wrote:
>> I have to admit that the new set-up at "Wish" has been a little disturbing
>> lately.  It was great when you were able to have a beer and dance at the
>> same time, but I guess some people got in trouble due to underage drinking,
>> so now, the drinkers are divided from others with a big white cloth that
>> goes around the bar.  I wish the cloth could be a little smaller, so you
>> can see what's going on at the non-drinking tables, because having a beer
>> can get pretty lonely.
>
>Jeez, the drinkers are actually segregated off from everyone else by a
>big sheet?!  I knew the rave scene was anti-booze, but damn!  This is
>gettin' ridiculous!
>

This is, unfortunately, a condition of running an 18+ night at Bahia.
They've been hassled by police so much that a physical separation of the
bar area was the only option left open in order to keep events from being
21+ exclusively.

If anyone's aware of any other 18+ venues in the city I'd love to hear
about them... =)

Joe

     I saw an episode of "Captain Planet" (you know, the environmentally
conscious cartoon superhero show?)  Where somehow the planeteers had been
transported to the future.  Wheeler (I think that's his name--the anglo kid
with a sorta lazy attitude) was walking down the street when some dude in a
leather jacket and a mohawk gets thrown out of a window.  Wheeler bends down
and asks "are you OK? What's going on in there?"  The punker dude responds. 
"It's a rave...don't you know what a rave is?.......Man, what a jerk!"  And so
wheeler follows him into this "rave": a room full of people fighting and slam
dancing.  It was really funny.

ive been going to come-unity for a year..and for some reason..i didnt
quite enjoy myself as much this month!...well for one thing..it was too
packed!!!!..too many drunk people bumping others trying to groove in the
oven baked heat of the dancefloor..wasnt really fun
either...simon...wasnt his ususal self last night...probabaly was tired
after spinning at so many parties...although Garth once more played to
the crowd when he took over...I just love his funky bass lines!...Jeno
played a wicked set...he also envoked a  weird kind of music..nothing
ive heard in Come/unity at all..it was kind of slow..with a trance like
beat...he finally kicked it off with House Music never dies..which just
sent everyone screaming...the chill room downstairs..was a different
story..it was so beautiful in there..the music was so groovy too..total
funk!..anyone knows who  the DJ was  downstairs?...well overall I give
it a C..true.. not too many Come/Untiy regulars around..i guess
Come/unity is just becoming too commercialized these days!....i hope to
meet some of you SFRAVERS..at NEW HOPE!!!!..peace..christian

Special Note:
	As some of you may know, a friend of ours was smacked in the face
because he yelled at a person whos' car almost hit his (This all
happened right outside the party). We have to be very careful about how
we deal with people in the dangerous world we live in. There are alot of
crazy people who have guns and knives and don't give shit about any
thing (including themselves). I don't want my new friends taken away
by reasons we can avoid. Be careful!

OK?....now.. lets get to the nitty gritty....

Deepfog and Spencer: you guys and whomever helped put this production
together deserve big Props...Huge!

The space is magnificant. 20 ft. cieling as you enter to the chill
space. This will help those out who feel a bit cluttered and want to
relax with some vibey people. The ventilation upstairs is also primo.
Matt was playing as we walked in. A very good mix of up and down tempo
music. Then me and my brother Gaby (He says Hi.. and he truly loves
everyone he met) head downstairs to meet some kick ass techno. Macadio
is spinning and he is very serious. Then, all of the sudden, BAM! 
he's hopping up and down pointing to the next rekkid he layed down. 
You can see how Djs affect the crowd with their energy. I love it!
	I then cruise back to the smoking dungeons. The first person 
I see is Leslie and her Phat Hat. Yay!! We sit and talk and smoke for 
a while, then its off to the chill area. At this point I'm running into
everyone I know and it is a great feeling to know such beautiful people.
I don't want to name names (exept for Leslie and Boomarang) because
it would take all day. But you know whom you are 8^) 
	It seems I spent most of my time at the chill room. The 
ambiance is so good there. But I do head down to hear Thads set, and I
am very impressed. I will go to other gigs to hear him spin Jungle.
AT that time I run into Boomarang Fidget. Yayy!! I've been trying to
meet this guy for a while. He is a greater person in life than on the
list. You all should meet him. 
	Next, Micron is spinning some killer trance. I'm running around like
I'm at Disneyland. Yes.. DISNEYLAND! you know..that feeling with 
no worries, and excitement of what the future holds. 
	Thanks to the crew for $1 water and Nub Chai. Thanks for 
the restrooms (ther were 2 ?) Thanks for the chill room with a tent.
Thanks for the music. Good sound system downstairs. I love the
separation of the bottom system. Thanks for the decorations Spencer. 
Thank you for the alter Leslie.  And everyone else, thank you for
your friendship. As short as it may be, it seems I have known most
of you a life time.
				Much Love 
				Vertigo
ps. I cought the beginning of Deepfogs set and I love 
"20 minutes of Disco Glory" 
You are the Bomb!



----- End Included Message -----
