>>><<<LiFe>>>
>>>
>>>Life isn't about keeping score.
>>>It's not about how many friends you have
>>>Or how accepted you are.
>>>Not about if you have plans this weekend
>>>or if you're alone.
>>>It isn't about who you're dating, who you
>>>used to date, how many people you've dated,
>>>or if you haven't been with anyone at all.
>>>It isn't about who you have kissed,
>>>It's not about sex.
>>>It isn't about who your family is or how
>>>much money they have.
>>>Or what kind of car you drive.
>>>Or where you are sent to school.
>>>It's not about how beautiful or ugly you are.
>>>Or what clothes you wear, what shoes you have on,
>>>or what kind of music you listen to.
>>>It's not about if your hair is blonde, red,
>>>black, or brown.
>>>Or if your skin is too light or too dark.
>>>Not about what grades you get, how smart you are,
>>>how smart everybody else thinks you are,
>>>or how smart standardized tests say you are.
>>>It's not about what clubs you're in
>>>or how good you are at "your" sport.
>>>It's not about representing your whole being on
>>>a piece of paper and seeing
>>>who will "accept the written you."
>>>
>>>
>>>LIFE JUST ISN'T.
>>>
>>>But, life is about who you love and who you hurt.
>>>It's about who you make happy or unhappy purposefully.
>>>It's about keeping or betraying trust.
>>>It's about friendship, used as a sanctity or a weapon.
>>>It's about what you say and mean, maybe hurtful,
>>>maybe heartening.
>>>About starting rumors and contributing to petty gossip.
>>>It's about what judgments you pass and why.
>>>And who your judgments are spread to.
>>>It's about who you've ignored with full control
>>>and intention.
>>>It's about jealousy, fear, ignorance, and revenge.
>>>It's about carrying inner hate and love, letting it grow, and spreading
>>>it.
>>>But most of all, it's about using your life to touch
>>>or poison other people's hearts in such a way that
>>>could have never occurred alone.
>>>Only you choose the way those hearts are affected,
>>>and those choices are what life's all about.
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>>*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~   No one should
>>>drive a hard bargain with an artist
>>>                   ~~Ludwig van Beethoven
>>>
>>>*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~
>>>
>>>
>>>This is not your ordinary chain letter.  Depending on how many people
>>>you send this to, your life will change dramatically! If you send this
>>>to:
>>>
>>>0-people:  Something terrible will happen such as
>>>               losing a best friend.
>>>1-5 people:  You will have 1 good day.
>>>6-10 people:  You will have a good week, and the person
>>>                       you like will ask you out.
>>>11-15 people:  You will have a good month, and a great
>>>                       surprise every day.
>>>16 & up:  You will have a successful life and all of
>>>               your dreams will come true!
>>>
>>>        SEND THIS TO EVERYONE YOU KNOW!!
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>
>
>=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+
>+   Karisia Bitong     +
>+karisia@mnl.sequel.net+
>=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+
>
>
>

   a mellow laundromat pastime of lost radio frequencies and
   tabla-enchanced space ritual,
   on a bed of stress-free lounge soundtracking and occasional dub.
   8pm-10pm, All ages, Free. Brainwash, 1122 Folsom @ 7th, SF.

   w/DJs Darkhorse, Felix.

W E E K L I E S

   House/techno/acid jazz/ambient/etc reg'lar happenins Some of them may
   have ended - let me know when that happens...

   guests. 12mid-5:30am, 21+, $5. 55 Natoma, SF. 415.267.5984

   916.565.9588

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday afternoon 3pm-8pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of
       jungle, dub, breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight-3am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats,
       Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Friday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.

Amen, Tim!
I obviously don't need drugs to totally dig goa.  It is my favorite (can 
you tell by my sig file?  It is a line off one of my favorite goa tracks...)
Anyway, I listen to it morning noon an dnight (not 24-7, though!) and if 
I had to be on drugs to enjoy it, it just would not work! Anyway, that is 
my 2 cents worth.  Ya don't NEED drugs with goa.  It is the same concept 
as people who go into spiritual trances by chanting or meditating.  It is 
just a different level of consciousness and the music is the vehicle.

love and much shanti,

hey everybody.

i'm also spinning at a new hope tomorrow night. For your raving 
convenience, I'll make some comparisons to help you decide which event to 
support:

SPRING HEEL JACK			A NEW HOPE
==================			================
- you and 4 friends costs $50		- you and 50 friends costs nothing

- Bimbo's Nasty-Ass Bar			- somewhere near a large body of water

- homogeneous "spring-heel-jack-only"   - heterogeneous "dj-radon-may-play-
  set					  one-spring-heel-jack-cut" set	

- will probably close down by 2:30am	- will probably wind down at sunrise

- stuffy central heating		- bonfire and warm clothes

for coke drinkers:
- this is not it			- new hope is it

for pepsi drinkers:
- the choice of a doomed generation	- definitely the choice of a new
					  generation

see you all tomorrow night. :)

-dj radon

Hi again everyone, and sorry to crowd your inboxes.

My BSP was intended to be a joke, no disrespect intended at all... as my 
comment about my set was supposed to indicate, I think spring heel jack is 
amazing. On any other night, I'd definitely be going to see them.

Also, I should have put this on my first post, but I have no crew and am not 
associated with "rebel alliance productions", so please don't associate 
my comments with anyone but me. If anyone has gone too far, it is me and 
definitely not the dedicated people who are putting on this event for the 
love of the scene, and paying for it out of their own pocket.

-dj radon
freelance junglist

> > I am not sure were you are going with your argumument??  All because the
> > percentages are not  
> > strait across the board does not meen that the scene is not diverse.  I
> > have never seen a sign  
> > in front of a party that says "No Minorities Allowed".
> 

No I am not saying that because that is a ridiculous notion. I am a 
minority and I have never felt that I shouldn't be at a rave because I am 
not white, and that I have never encountered anyway turning me away 
because of my ethnicity (I have in other situations) But I am saying that 
there aren't that many people pf colour in the scene esp when in comes to 
people who organise it. It's not the people who runs the party that is at 
fault, but we have to look at the structure. I never said Scott put out 
racist parties, I am slightly insulted to have anyone say that about what 
I said. 


> but segratation is very rarely overt.  if, to take a more neutral example,
> no martians ever show up to my parties, then i don't need to put up a sign
> that says "no damn martians allowed!"  or if only one or two ever show
> up, and we make them feel uncomfortable till they bail, then still we
> don't need an official rule.  the proof's in the pudding, ray, and the
> fact is that by and large even when a party is held in the middle of a
> almost completely minority neighborhood, it still looks lily white to me. 

em like Love Affair in Oakland. Funny I put that in my essay.

> 
> NOTE: i'm not saying there is some covert racist cabal operating in the sf
> party scene.

ME neither,


  i'm just saying, look - the fact is that we aren't really
> integrated, even if by policy we are, so we ought to ask why is that?
> 
That is what I am trying to find out? Anyone?

> > What exactly do you propose?   Do you think that promoters should apply
> > Equal Opertunity  
> > employment policies when puting together a DJ lineup?  I am not so sure
> > I would agree with you  
> > that it is fair to book a dj just because they are Black or a Female.
> > It is much better to book  
> > them for their talent. 
> 
> again, almost right.  yes, of course it would be wrong to have quotas for
> dj breakdowns, possibly increasing the bad spinning we hear.
> 
No, one of the problems is that women and minorities, and any cobinations 
don't spin. I hate the fact you're taking me all wrong here. I said they 
don't exist, and I think it's perprosterous to say we are diverse when we 
are not. Damn, can't we even raise questions?????? I NEVER SAID PUT A 
WOMEN MINORITY DJ THAT CANT SPIN ON!!!!! ANYWAY WHY IS IT THAT YOU ASSUME 
THAT BEING A MINORITY DJ AUTOMATICALLY MEANS SHE CAN'T SPIN. NOw that is 
outright racist and sexist.


> 
> the #1 way to get jobs is contacts = friends, and if the pool of dj's,
> promoters, and their circles of friends is lily white, then it makes it
> damn hard for minority talent to get breaks when maybe they don't deserve
> it, so later they'll have super-hard skills that make you say damn!

AND DAMN IT THIS IS NOT A FUCKING FLAME. I AM MERELY DISAGREEING. WHY IS 
IT THAT WE CAN't DISAGREE? REspect my point of view. I do yours. I have a 
different opinion I WANT TO VOICE. (That's not to you Matt)

Ok, no more coke and pepsi stuff. If you guys want to tally, lets do 
something  RAVE related. SFRAVES? R A V E S 

Like house vs trance vs techno vs breakbeat vs jungle vs old skool vs 
ambient vs handbag vs electronica vs German Hard Trance vs English 
(focus: treble) trance VS American (focus: bass) progressive house vs 
Spanish  
Ibisa altenative  vs Hardcore vs gabba vs Happy Hardcore vs indian goa 
trance vs raves vs parties vs clubs vs which DJ you like best vs which 
record you like best vs which organisers you want to support vs which 
clubs on which night vs  estacy vs GHB vs Acid vs pot vs alcohol vs what 
you love about the scene vs where you think the scene has problems vs 
where we spot rave related articles vs reviews vs the MUSIC. (did I miss 
anything?)

GET IT? If your post doesn't have something to do with the above..maybe 
it's not about the scene. Look there are a million topics that can be 
spurned from that alone.

From: Hadrian <hadrian@uclink4.berkeley.edu>

Subject: RE: BSP: a new hope beats spring heel jack anyday...
Date: Thu, 6 Mar 1997 23:33:57 -0800

I have been partying down in LA for a while before I came up to the bay, =
and if there is anything it has taught me , it its that THERE ARE GOOD =
PEOPLE EVERYWHERE!!!  Perchance I am off the subject here, but I really =
resent the whole LA  vs. SF vibe that I see everywhere I look in the =
scene up here.  I think that this is an issue worth discussion (and I'm =
sure that fellow ex-LA ravers can back my up on this).  The scene down =
there is not better or worse, it is just different.  The people are =
different, the parties are different, the drugs are different.....  It's =
a different city!  People in SF rarely seem to realize that the majority =
of LA ravers are NOT out to make other people not have fun or be mean or =
whatever.  A reoccurring sentiment that is thrown at me quite often up =
here, is that SF is somehow superior to LA.  To all of you who have =
never partied down in LA, or met the fabulous people that I have,....... =


					Get off the high horse that you rode in on, and drop the =
superiority complex!!

I wish not to insult anyone, but I want to try to kill this one before =
it gets out of control.=20

As far as the diversity question goes, the only criteria that I feel =
must be met before one can throw parties or DJ, or do whatever, is that =
you must have the skills to pay the bills, or no one will want to come =
to your second event or buy your second mix tape.  It really is as =
simple as that.  There exists within our scene an amazing amount of =
talent as far as DJs are concerned.  Diversity will happen if we give it =
room to grow in.

<3   <3         <3            <3
<3     <3            <3
<3       to all....

Love, Hadrian


----------

> of someone else's?  This is the kind of crap that goes on down in =
L.A.,  and
> I wouldnt like to see this as a regular component of this list.=20

Regarding the Ortofon DJS's, I've owned a pair for a little under a year now,
and recently (past 3 months) they have been giving me many problems... one
cartridge has noticibly lower bass response, sometimes the left channel will
die on them, and I either have to wiggle the cartridge, or pull it off and
lick, yes, lick the contacts. I understand this is a somewhat common problem,
I learned the lick-trick from a couple of guys down at solid grooves.. I
don't know if this is still a problem with the new ones, but just thought I'd
let you know.. the styli (sp?) last forever, tho, provided you clean the dust
off regularly... 

dave

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I couldn't agree more with Monty about this.  If there was any indication
that the Spring Heel Jack show was being promoted by greedy corporagte
slime, then I could see some invidious dissin'.  

But I saw the SHJ show in Portland, which the promoters *dropped the
price for* because tickets were not selling at $8, to $2.00.  I don't
know if SHJ's fee went down, but the point is, in Portland the
promoters may have lost less money because they cut the price to a
can't-lose-let's-check-it-out level.  

They did a very good show that was livened up after they were done by
a short jump-up set by one of their crew.  There were at least 200
people there -- not too many to be crowded and not too few to make
it look empty.

My conclusion: this SHJ mini-tour is blessed with positive direction
and something, at least in Portland, we haven't seen for a while, which
is a serious U-turn on promoter ego and greed.  

I also think it's worth going to SHJ because Bimbo's is a seriously
wierd SF landmark that nonetheless has a bit of charm.  I saw Pele
Juju there years ago at a Usenix party, and then went to see Gato
Barbieri a while back.  

So, you can go get dinner at the Stinking Rose or just a bit of dessert
at one of the Italian cafes (which if overpriced are at least genuine),
or just stroll down Columbus and check out real drum&bass at a no-fooling
relic of SF from the 1950s.  

I think Spring Heel Jack deserve some attention.  I gather they've been
living somewhere around SF the last couple of months, or at least have
stopped over in town for long stretches.  Their recorded output shows
high quality production and innovation.  I don't think they have the
knack for reaching the heart that, say, Orbital do, but what they do is
good and does not follow the half-dozen conventional routes for jungle/d&b
as it now exists.  Their sense of adventure reminds me of what jungle
was like 18 months ago, when it was at its greatest level of ferment for
me anyway.  

Now then, let me also say how much I like and support, and how important
it is to have, outdoor/free/chilled-and-vibed-out events.  I lived for
them for a couple of years and miss it a lot.  The music is bound to
be as good and wellmixed as most any commercial event, and there is
a sense of adventure every time you go outside that is simply different
and more open-ended.  

So, consider what I would do if not for being in Portland this weekend:

GO TO BOTH!

phred

Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.970307014835.29381A-100000@capt.hooked.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk


***WARNING.  THIS POST CONTAINS INFORMATION THAT MAY ATTACK SOME OF YOUR 
EVERYDAY GIVEN LOGIC.  IF YOU ARE NOT OPEN MINDED AT ALL, YOU MAY NOT 
WANT TO READ THIS.***

hello everyone...

well sorry if this got through some people's filters...i am aware that 
some people have a rather rigid agenda that they expect everyone to 
already know and obey.  so 1,000 appoligies to those people in advance.  

i won't make this too long, i think.  but it seems there is a pattern and 
yanno i probably could run filters call one of my friends over and have 
that set up...but yanno i really don't mind pressing delete a bunch of 
times.  in fact, i deleted the entire pepsi/coke thing because i just 
didn't feel like contributing time to that.  by the time i send a post 
complaining about it and then get all the responses, because we all like 
to hear our own voices don't we?  by that time the thread is already over 
nstuff (hi jeff!)

but this is no longer any one person's list, and no one owns it.  ok, 
well someone started it...and let's all thank that person quietly or 
privately inside our minds.  

but just like a rave is no longer a promoters' party (sure, they create 
and set things up, but then the party is dominated by the people inside 
and enjoying it.  

and that's what sfraves is.  or any discussion group, really.  and there 
are hundreds of people on here.  most of them im sure got the ettiquette 
list and filed it away without reading it.  besides, it's been proven 
scientifically that we retain about 7-10% of the information we take in.  
im actually about 2% sometimes.  im not perfect.  and i don't expect 
anyone on this list to be, either.  so sometimes useless, non-rave 
related threads are going to start.  in fact, a lot, considering the 
number of people that logon, and logoff, and new people, etc.  

now try not to misunderstand things here.  i do think there is some kind 
of common sense ettiquette people ought to be abiding by.  i am not a 
proponent of cutting down ANYONE'S organization i don't care HOW bad they 
are, because that's what the masses do.  ever notice that?  how it's kind 
of cool to be neg?  we have all these stupid sayings on tshirts like bite 
me and just other negative just crap all over the place.  we are 
constantly bombarded by negativity and then we wonder why there is so 
much violence in our society.  i mean, duh?  =\  can we add?

now im certainly no expert on sfr ettiquette, i get out of line too, and 
sometimes i just feel like having fun.  why not once in a while?  it 
lightens up the list i think.  but heres' a little secret i found about 
dealing with some of the more negative and useless topic types of 
topics.  are you ready?  

sure?

the delete key is very useful.  you see, i often tell my sfr friends that 
i hang out with that sfr is often like watching tv.  there's good 
channels and bad ones.  can you all relate to that?  ok, the only 
difference, though is you can directly respond to those channels and 
create your own channel...or your own show.  

what channel are you on?  what show are you watching?  do you really want 
to be on that channel?  

some of you seem to read and nitpick every little thing that people write 
as if you're looking for something wrong to point out to everyone.  some 
of you people need to get out more...seriously.  lighten up.  i also 
hear a lot of read through your post and edit it and spellcheck...that's 
great too, but this is a freeflowing discussion group, not an english 
class.  and when was the last time you made a friend based upon how well 
they could structure a grammatcially correct sentence?   i see that going 
on all the time.  the nitpicking.  it creates these loooong ass threads 
that i just delete.  i could try to be a mediator and tell them to 
stop...but i've found by experience that some people aren't ready for 
that.  so i usually dont' feed their fire at all.  just let them rant for 
a while.  and let them be right.  watch how quickly they take it back and 
stop ranting.  ranting just creates more ranting.  

ok, i might have attacked some of your personal logic because i might 
have said something offensive.  in fact, i've been warned privately 
sometimes that im going to get "flamed" for stuff i've posted in the 
past.  go ahead, flame me.  i don't care...last time i checked this was a 
country where we still have the right to free speech.  i ask if you want 
to yell at me for something i said, if you're angry, and are going to 
express it...please.  do it privately.  give everyone a break.  you see, 
i say what i feel, and i think others should do the same, and you know 
what?  it doesn't always make peace.  some of you are trying to make 
everyone happy and not step on anyone's toes.  sorry.  life's not that 
easy. if it were, we'd all be happy and live in a perfectly clean world 
and raves wouldn't be underground.  in fact, life would be probably very 
boring.  more on that later.

now there are some of you that might totally agree with me.  fine.  i 
appreciate it if you do...and if you want to thank me go ahead, but 
before you do...just remember one thing.  the best way you could thank me 
is by going out and making a positive impact on someone else's life.  i 
don't need 45 "cool, i agree with you" posts.  be specific on what you 
agree with, if you would.  

most of you will lie somewhere in between, depending upon what type of 
programming lies in your brain and controls your mind.  just remember, 
the mind is like a parachute.  it's only operating at full capacity when 
it's totally open.

Good morning everyone...

Well, well, well... As I stated before, it's time to start paying the 
price of promoting.  RAS is a group of people that want to have a good 
time, plain and simple.  Some of us are 21+, some are under 18...  All 
we want to do is give back to the scene that has accepted us for who 
we are.  And that is a beautiful thing.
I've gone to FTT parties and the vibe is pretty good.  We have no 
disrespect towards Moshie nor any of the other promoters out there 
(Clare, Ethan, Mars, Mystr-E, Thomas, Ben & Dhrien,ect..).
Radon has apoligised for his statements, but he's excited, I am too... 
 It's not about competition, superiority, who has the biggest laser 
ect...  It's about the love, the vibe that comes across from us and 
the music we provide and you and the vibe you create.

I am looking forward to seeing the many of yous that's as crazy as us 
and will be on a chilly beach for a party (For the past 2 days we @ 
RAS have been doing wood runs to provide a decent bonfire).  Again, if 
anyone was offended by the SHJ RAS  thingie, our sencerest(sp) 
apologies.

(Taking spelling lessions from Vald)

----- Adam
"Stay Connected"

P.S.  If you do make it out tonite... Bring wood and dress WARM...

At 10:44 PM -0800 3/6/97, Nailvarnish wrote:
>On Fri, 7 Mar 1997 Tekno313@aol.com wrote:
>
>> I'm sorry, but where do you get off disrespecting people's events like this?
>> Why do you feel it's necessary to make your event look better at the expense
>> of someone else's?  This is the kind of crap that goes on down in L.A.,  and
>> I wouldnt like to see this as a regular component of this list.
>> --Monty
>
>
>
>Monty, I agree with your concern. But don't dis LA babes. I swear this
>stuff never happens on socal raves. Not to say they don't have problems.
>But this is not one of them. I don't understand the hatred of LA rave
>scene sometimes. It rocked when I was there. Sometimes I miss how NICE
>people were. REALLY
>
>Nailvarnish

Speaking as one who was involved in throwing several parties in LA, I can
vouch for the veracity of Monty's statement. From late '92 onwards promoter
greed, competition and backstabbing diminished the scene greatly in LA, to
the point that large undergrounds died out almost completely. Even among
the smaller undergrounds and weeklies, promoter infighting was rampant -
something I experienced firsthand. At one point in the planning of a large
event ironically meant to bring the LA scene together, a bullet was shot
through the front door of one of the planners and the event was called off.

Even now there are only a few groups I can think of who are doing heartfelt
underground events in LA - fewer than in SF, which is a bit odd considering
LA has at least 4 times the population of the bay area.

All of this has nothing to do with your average raver in LA - ravers are
ravers everywhere. =)

Joe

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Mar  7 10:16:47 1997

Mime-Version: 1.0

Message-ID: <MS-MAILG-3.0-Note-msatt-sgalloway-0857758264>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi all,

Just to clear this up...

I also think that it's weird having that division between the drinkers and 
non-drinkers, it breaks up the room, and it sucks if you want a drink and 
you're friends can't come in there.  But, it was either that, or stop 
throwing Wish...I chose to keep it going....

What happened was this...We were going fine with having a mixed crowd 
(drinkers & non-drinkers) and Bahia didn't seem to mind as long as it was 
monitored.  However, the city's authorities didn't see it that way. 
 According to drinking age restriction laws, the only way that we could 
remain open was to have a physical separation of the areas, so that those 
under 21 could not get alcoholic beverages..blah blah blah...

So, we did it...We put up that dumb sheet, and now have way too many 
security guys checking people's id's and such, and quite honestly it's 
annoying...but we had no other choice.  In fact, the Bahia is in danger of 
closing it's doors to 18 & over parties for good, and we are currently 
working on not letting that happen...if it does, we are already looking for 
alternate spaces..."Wish" us luck.  :-)

Thanks for listening...

Smiles,

Scott =)

______________

> so now, the drinkers are divided from others with a big white cloth that
> goes around the bar.  I wish the cloth could be a little smaller, so you

>Date: Wed, 05 Mar 1997 21:44:58 -0800
>Paul Hayden worte:

>The Top Ten Reasons You Know A Rave Is Bunk.
>
>10. The flyer is harder to fold than a map.
>
>9. The flyer saids RAVE on it.
>
>8. You can win tickets for it on Live 105
>
>7. The name has more words in it than DJs
>
>6. It costs $25
>
>5. It takes you one hour to get a free hug
>
>4. They sent you the a flyer for it in the mail
>
>3. The location on the flyer plus directions on how to get there.
>
>2. You can purchase pre-sal tickets for it from BASS
>
>And the number one reason....
>
>1. The DJ is spinning James Brown Is Dead when you walk in.
>
>Luvs&Hugs,
>Paul
>

I would like to add to the list, Paul if you don't mind me doing so.

11.  When PHAT DJs come and play a half-ass set :(!

12.  When the DJ set up is up on a stage. (I don't know about you, but 
 I like to interact with the DJ.  He is part of the vibe too =)!)

13.  Circle dancing. (Someday these people with figure out that people 
 dance alone but in unity as a whole.  Then again, maybe not.  
 Someday at a massive, I would like to start an energy circle =)!)

14.  No SmileS. (You can't have a party without those :D!)


Well, there are many other things I can say about bunk parties.  All I really
need to say is that you make the vibe.  When all seems so bunk, make good of
it, and have fun with all of your beautiful friends =7!

Love you all!  Lotsa huGGGGGGGGGGs!
Keep smilinG =D!

oxoxoxoxoxox,

PAULA >=^b!

Date: 07 Mar 1997 11:02:31 -0800
From: Leslie Ayres <Leslie.Ayres@ncal.kaiperm.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (Return requested)
Subject: Re: Top Ten Reasons...
MIME-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Paula added to Paul's list of reasons... 

-----------------------
13.  Circle dancing. (Someday these people with figure out that people 
 dance alone but in unity as a whole.  Then again, maybe not.  
 Someday at a massive, I would like to start an energy circle =)!)
-------------------------

I know lots of people hate circle dancing, but maybe if you take a 
different perspective for a minute... 

Circles are about performing for your friends, showing off your
moves while they can actually watch and you can give it your all,
dance full out 150% for a minute or two... 
then it's the next person's turn while you rest.

Circle dancing is different than trancing out solo, and the people
who like circle dancing are often into a different interaction and
dynamic.

Does that make it wrong???  NO NO NO!!!!!!  I love watching circle dancers
(when I can get close enough without being squooshed) because I love
watching people show off doing what they love.  Yowzah!

I think what people REALLY object to in circle dancing is that it
creates a bottleneck on the dance floor.  A circle gets bigger and
more immovable, and the individual dancers get crowded out.  

Remember my story of being kicked back by a young circle dancer 
at a party last year who somehow thought that MY space should 
have been HIS space?  (Silly boy. Don't mess with my dancing 
space!  He'll not likely do *that* again!)

At Love A-Fair, I saw a wonderous thing.  Outside, where there was
plenty of space, there was a huge circle of... ravers!  Lara and her
crew were circle dancing, and it was awesome to watch, because they
got to experience what it's like to perform for your friends.  Many
big smiles!  Happy ravers!  Dancing in a circle!  (you guys didn't
know I was watching from the railing, did you?)

In a way, circles ARE energy circles.  Different strokes and all.

So, if you like circles, please be considerate of the traffic flow
in the room and don't be a space hog.  And if you don't like them,
maybe stop and watch what it's all about for a while.  You don't have
to be a great dancer to enjoy watching!

Love, Leslie

Each rave I go to is a DifferentStory... 
in this Story, you get to be your Own character and do whatever you like
and
be whoever you want to be. and no one can take that away...

in this story, you get to meet other characters, some might share the same
vibes as you, and some might not...

Imagine being in a place, in which your fantasies, creativity and 
imagination are one of the most important things...with the goal being
to make yourself happy by making everyone else happy :o)

I dunno... I wish I could write a book, each chapter would be a different
party...all forming one BIG story.... a Never-ending story ;o)

On Fri, 7 Mar 1997, Deepfog wrote:





> 
> ***WARNING.  THIS POST CONTAINS INFORMATION THAT MAY ATTACK SOME OF YOUR 
> EVERYDAY GIVEN LOGIC.  IF YOU ARE NOT OPEN MINDED AT ALL, YOU MAY NOT 
> WANT TO READ THIS.***
> 
> hello everyone...
> 
> well sorry if this got through some people's filters...i am aware that 
> some people have a rather rigid agenda that they expect everyone to 
> already know and obey.  so 1,000 appoligies to those people in advance.  
> 
> i won't make this too long, i think.  but it seems there is a pattern and 
> yanno i probably could run filters call one of my friends over and have 
> that set up...but yanno i really don't mind pressing delete a bunch of 
> times.  in fact, i deleted the entire pepsi/coke thing because i just 
> didn't feel like contributing time to that.  by the time i send a post 
> complaining about it and then get all the responses, because we all like 
> to hear our own voices don't we?  by that time the thread is already over 
> nstuff (hi jeff!)
> 
> but this is no longer any one person's list, and no one owns it.  ok, 
> well someone started it...and let's all thank that person quietly or 
> privately inside our minds.  
> 
> but just like a rave is no longer a promoters' party (sure, they create 
> and set things up, but then the party is dominated by the people inside 
> and enjoying it.  
> 
> and that's what sfraves is.  or any discussion group, really.  and there 
> are hundreds of people on here.  most of them im sure got the ettiquette 
> list and filed it away without reading it.  besides, it's been proven 
> scientifically that we retain about 7-10% of the information we take in.  
> im actually about 2% sometimes.  im not perfect.  and i don't expect 
> anyone on this list to be, either.  so sometimes useless, non-rave 
> related threads are going to start.  in fact, a lot, considering the 
> number of people that logon, and logoff, and new people, etc.  
> 
> now try not to misunderstand things here.  i do think there is some kind 
> of common sense ettiquette people ought to be abiding by.  i am not a 
> proponent of cutting down ANYONE'S organization i don't care HOW bad they 
> are, because that's what the masses do.  ever notice that?  how it's kind 
> of cool to be neg?  we have all these stupid sayings on tshirts like bite 
> me and just other negative just crap all over the place.  we are 
> constantly bombarded by negativity and then we wonder why there is so 
> much violence in our society.  i mean, duh?  =\  can we add?
> 
> now im certainly no expert on sfr ettiquette, i get out of line too, and 
> sometimes i just feel like having fun.  why not once in a while?  it 
> lightens up the list i think.  but heres' a little secret i found about 
> dealing with some of the more negative and useless topic types of 
> topics.  are you ready?  
> 
> sure?
> 
> the delete key is very useful.  you see, i often tell my sfr friends that 
> i hang out with that sfr is often like watching tv.  there's good 
> channels and bad ones.  can you all relate to that?  ok, the only 
> difference, though is you can directly respond to those channels and 
> create your own channel...or your own show.  
> 
> what channel are you on?  what show are you watching?  do you really want 
> to be on that channel?  
> 
> some of you seem to read and nitpick every little thing that people write 
> as if you're looking for something wrong to point out to everyone.  some 
> of you people need to get out more...seriously.  lighten up.  i also 
> hear a lot of read through your post and edit it and spellcheck...that's 
> great too, but this is a freeflowing discussion group, not an english 
> class.  and when was the last time you made a friend based upon how well 
> they could structure a grammatcially correct sentence?   i see that going 
> on all the time.  the nitpicking.  it creates these loooong ass threads 
> that i just delete.  i could try to be a mediator and tell them to 
> stop...but i've found by experience that some people aren't ready for 
> that.  so i usually dont' feed their fire at all.  just let them rant for 
> a while.  and let them be right.  watch how quickly they take it back and 
> stop ranting.  ranting just creates more ranting.  
> 
> ok, i might have attacked some of your personal logic because i might 
> have said something offensive.  in fact, i've been warned privately 
> sometimes that im going to get "flamed" for stuff i've posted in the 
> past.  go ahead, flame me.  i don't care...last time i checked this was a 
> country where we still have the right to free speech.  i ask if you want 
> to yell at me for something i said, if you're angry, and are going to 
> express it...please.  do it privately.  give everyone a break.  you see, 
> i say what i feel, and i think others should do the same, and you know 
> what?  it doesn't always make peace.  some of you are trying to make 
> everyone happy and not step on anyone's toes.  sorry.  life's not that 
> easy. if it were, we'd all be happy and live in a perfectly clean world 
> and raves wouldn't be underground.  in fact, life would be probably very 
> boring.  more on that later.
> 
> now there are some of you that might totally agree with me.  fine.  i 
> appreciate it if you do...and if you want to thank me go ahead, but 
> before you do...just remember one thing.  the best way you could thank me 
> is by going out and making a positive impact on someone else's life.  i 
> don't need 45 "cool, i agree with you" posts.  be specific on what you 
> agree with, if you would.  
> 
> most of you will lie somewhere in between, depending upon what type of 
> programming lies in your brain and controls your mind.  just remember, 
> the mind is like a parachute.  it's only operating at full capacity when 
> it's totally open.  
>

Just to confirm what I was posting about a couple days ago, last night at
the Fillmore, Phil Lesh and Bob Weir of the Dead joined saxophonist David
Murray and his band for a bunch of Dead songs, including "Dark Star" and
"Shakedown Street."  (Sorry I was mistaken about Mickey Hart showing up as
well).  But all of us who were there know how out-there it was, and as the
karma gods had Susan and I next to the stage right at Bob & Phil's feet, I
can assure you they were loving it too!  We hung out for awhile with
deadhead raver Randy (or is it Andy?) with his red-lit crystal scepter and
perma-grin, and I saw an old tour-head friend who has settled with some
Santa Cruz spinners ... a great night.

leftjab

For now, I figure, since I'm on here, I'll talk...  (surprised? not!)

Tony/Deepfog said somthing that reminded me of something 
that happened to me once.


> ever notice that?  how it's kind 
> of cool to be neg?  we have all these stupid sayings on tshirts like bite 
> me and just other negative just crap all over the place.  

I was out one night, and through the crowded dance floor, I noticed
a big geeky kind of guy, nice face, but wearing a shirt that said... 
in big white block letters on a white shirt... FUCK YOU.

I brooded on that, thinking how negative to actually want to wear
something like that, and to walk around with such an obnoxious
message on your shirt...  

I was just about to go up to him and inquire why he wanted to wear a
shirt like that ....

then I got closer, and I saw that it said....

FUCK YEAH

And I said to myself... FUCK YEAH!!

See, things are not always what we think.  Right on.

L.

Back in junior high school..

  When Break Dancing was popular.
  Circle dancing was a sport. You go out, bust your moves, face someone,
and "Call them Out". This is what it is about at the ravEs (opinion) Just
like in the old days; it is a friendly game of dancing.
  Unfortunetly, I'm kind of selfconcious about break dancing these days.
Because I used to do it all the time in Junior high school. And when it
fell off of the face of the earth; people made it out to be "stupid" to
break dance afterwards, back in high school.
  I don't think it's uncool or stupid to break dance at the ravEs though..
Now it's just that, I like brain washed myself into thinking; I am to old
to spin around on the floor all night.  But who know.. I busted out with a
flawless flare @ Space Children. Maybe I will practice once agian, and
become the best. Once agian..
  God knows I could use the extra exercise..
   But for now.. It's all about trancin out in the least crowded corner /w
the best stereo input.

Jeff (purple adidass jacket / skinny white boy / best break dancer @
thornton junior high school in Fremont 1980 or so)

I don't think everyone would necessarily agree with that. Look at the
fact the Bay Area's hi-tech industry is the best in the country (yes,
it is well known that there is a shortage of technical people in
LA). We have significantly less violent crime and theft, far less
pollution (I became physically ill from the air on my last trip
through LA), we produce Odwalla, we create a mere fraction of the
commercialism and schlock that LA does, and so on...

I guess people like LA because you can make a lot of money...
Okay.

Steve

Thanks Leslie, for the reasonable perspective on circle dancing.  I used 
to love watching them ALOT until I found out the reasons why others 
detested them.  Then I was sort of a "closet circle watcher".  I 
appreciate people's dancing talents, partly because I lack it so 
much and I love self expression through dance as the art in itsself.  I 
still feel that circle dancing is inappropriate when there is not enough 
room for it and it infringes on those who do not wish to participate or 
watch.  I'm sure most of you would agree with that. ;)

love,
Amy

Subject: My cleansing at <<WARMTH>>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hola!  My name is ELENA,  <<WARMTH>> was my first true Rave experience.
The experience i had  at <<WARMTH>> has forever changed me.  I feel
cleansed and purified, rid of all that is negative.  My outlook on life is
much brighter and i am filled with peace.
A million thank yous to all who i made contact with at the event, never
have i met so many beautiful, and loving people.  Especially those of you
associated w/ SF RAVES ;)"
Since the beggining of last year i've felt lost.  Moving to San Francisco
in Sept. '96 began the healing process.  Exactly one year ago i thought i
might have full-blown cancer, and i had never been so terrified in my life,
i've always been a strong person, but that experience killed my soul.  I
have waited my whole life to be in a room where people are happy,
affectionate, respectful, and accepting of me.  <<WARMTH>> brought me back
to myself.
Never have i felt such an intense vibe, such a connection with other
people.  Someone wearing a SF RAVE card said the words
Peace.Love.Unity.Respect, i hadn't heard that before, and was floored!
What a unique expression, they are the most amazing words, perfectly
linked.  Everyone's eyes were large and had a little twinkle flickering in
them.  All night i thrived off the energy everyone and the music was
emmitting.
A special Hello to Claudia, Lara, Alicia (de Salamanca), and Omar (de
Andalusia).  It's almost impossible for me to meet other people from SPAiN,
i will treasure our talk, and i hope to see you both again ;)"
To my boyfriend ARI:  Thank you (muchisimas gracias) for taking me to
<<WARMTH>> i'm truely grateful, and i'm happy you and i were able to share
that :)
A big hug to everyone who was @ WARMTH. Until we meet again.....
LOVE, ELENA :)

for extra travel... I'll probably try spending an extra weekend in
Madras and Goa if I can swing the schedule that way, and I'm looking

a little late in the posting, but just wanna say that Warmth was
fantastic!  that's the best i've ever seen that space (654 mission)
look... it's very apparent that a lot of care and time went into setting
up for the event. extra-coolio was the tent + air mattress in the corner
of the upstairs room. (which makes me think that i should start bringing
my tent with me to parties...y'know, sorta like a portable, privy chill
room)  Dan/Micron's set was great! it was so good, i climbed back behind
the amps and cranked them up so that we could hear it in all it's glory.
:)  all in all, i had a wonderful time, even though a girl i had just
met barfed all over me. <hi stephanie!> :)

groove on, kiddoes
xoxox philip

Subject: things were going well at first

Date: Fri, 7 Mar 1997 23:15:04 -0800

Precedence: bulk

Dear Dan,

Things were going well at first.

Later in the moring I was feeling cocky, beatmatching the few records that
I know how to beatmatch, sweaty groovy beats in your chest, and then my
cocky, nervous, fidgeting fingers flicked of the sound switch on one of my
turntables, and it sounded awful.  

While the record was still spinning, I left the party and crossed the boulevarde
 to the Cafe Montarde.  Picasso was there, waiting for Ms. Stein, and he waved
me over to his table.  I was hungry but not in the usual way,  and I sat
down with 
Picasso and ordered a vermouth and it was quiet in the cafe and we waited
for Ms.
Stein, there in the quiet.

Pablo ordered us a second drink and we shared a bagette to make it
smoother.  He showed me some paintings he had been working on.  I agreed
that we were nice and finished my vermouth.

Then  I remembered that my record was still playing at the party across the
street, 
and I left the bill for poor Picasso, and ran back across the boulevarde,
through traffic 
and the rainwashed street, and my record was still playing, almost to the
end of the 
song but not quite,  and then I realized that although sometimes things are
awful and
I make awful mistakes, things are not always as bad as they seem.

Especially when you are living in San Francisco and it is raining at 4:30
in the morning, and most of your friends are asleep in their beds, and the
streets are wet and glittering from the streetlamps.  Sometimes knowing
that you have friends makes it seems as if everything is not so bad after
all.

yours,

boomerang

Man, I really wanted to stay out of this one, but it's just too juicy
right now!

Okay, being in the SoCal scene right now is very interesting.  There is
this inner-circle underground thing growing and then there are the
make-da-money-now folks and then there are the old skoolers and then there
are the kids who don't know a thing about the scene, PLUR, the music or
_anything_ besides getting out of their Dad's house for a night and taking
all sorts of drugs.

In other words, there is a lack of cohesive unity.  And I guess everyone
thinks they've got it right.  Stranger and stranger.  

Plus -- people in LA don't hug enough.  They just don't.  I don't know
why.  I try to hug everyone at some point and I just wind up feeling
weird.  The SF scene is a lot different than LA, but you can't get too
harsh.  It's just different.

On Sat, 8 Mar 1997 Simply756@aol.com wrote:

> In a message dated 97-03-06 11:55:46 EST, bri@value.net (Brian Denny) writes:
> 
> << it actually appears to be a very safe drug.

> Ummm,  hate to disagree with you, but I don't think there is really such a
> thing as a safe drug, a _very_ safe drug, at that.
> Just my two pennies from heaven.
> smiles:)
> {{hugs}}
> love<3
> april(4)
 
--
Hello all-
(Yikes! it's Sat. morning *already*?  Anyways...)

IMHO, it really does depend on how you define "safe."  From what I
understand, GHB is essentially a harmless derivative of the
neurotransmitter GABA.  (GABA is an essential chemical we all have and
need to regulate metabolism and a whole bunch of other bodily functions.)
GHB really has no major side-effects (except passing out, and that's only
if you take too large a dose), stimulates fat metabolism and muscle growth
(over long term use, and with exercise, of course), and breaks down into
just carbon dioxide and water as byproducts.  As a matter of fact,
apparently it was legal OTC in the 80's as a body-building supplement!
(But of course, that was until the FDA found out that it could be an 
*enjoyable* experience...  And they can't have something like _that_ being
sold legally, now can they?)  

Now as far as the _non-physiological_ issues of safety are concerned (such
as operating heavy machinery while under the influence), I agree, GHB
could be an *extremely* disasterous drug (especially since just a slight
overdose will simply knock you out cold for a while... = bad news if
you're cruising down the freeway at 60mph).  But this all depends on what
the user intends to do while on the stuff.  At a rave, well, as long as
you take a very reasonable dosage and don't drive home for a *long* while,
you should be fine.  Behind the wheel, you're risking the lives of who
knows how many innocent people.  In a sense, I guess it's like alcohol as
far as drinking and driving:  don't do it. 

BTW, if you want to read more on it, the Lycaeum article on GHB is
pretty good; I highly recommend taking a look (I can't remember the
address, but somebody posted it just a little while ago.  I know it
starts with http://www.lycaeum.org, and you could probably find it from
there.)  Happy exploring!
Peace and hugs 2U all-

 ____________________________________________________________________

Well well well. An interesting show. I had planned on going to New Hope, but 
like so many others on the list, I'm just getting over a cold, and being that 
my main form of transpo is a ten year old motorcycle, the chilly ride to SCruz 
put it a little out of reach. So, me and a buddy went to Spring Heel Jack which 
is conveniently near home. 

First off, I have to say Bimbo's as a venue rocks.   If you haven't been, don't 
be put off by the name. Cool decor, tables, and a big dance area.  The crowd 
was neato as well, a good mix of artsy schticksters, dyed-in-the-wool 
junglists, and funky hipsters. 
Alas, the show itself was rather dissapointing. The sound system sucked, with 
alot of distortion, especially at the lower frequencies- which I consider a 
veritable sin if you're trying to play d & b.  And the music...well, it just 
didn't cause me to have the spastic twitches and near-seizure movements that 
good jungle inspires.  In my opinion, the meer presence of 
puh-teet-puh-puh-puh-teet alone isn't enough to get it going; it's got to come 
up and kick you in the ass. 

How was New Hope? Looking forward to the reviews.  What about tonght? What 
looks good?  Also, what is your opinion of King Kong?  Is anyone familiar with 
the DJs? 

xxxooo

Nathan

Subject: New Hope!
Content-Type: text/plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greets All,
     I'll just get right to the point.  New Hope WENT OFF!  It wasn't crazy in
the normal, indoor party crazy kinda way, but TONS of people showed up, all
sporting good vibes.  (why am I not surprised?)  I saw many many friends, some
who I was expecting, some who completely surprised me.  Sound system was
perfect for an outdoor event, loud when close to the speakers, but low enough
at a distance to carry on a conversation.
     Something really funny happened on the way to the party.  Along highway 1,
we saw all these cars parked, so I told my friend Kei "STOP this has to be it!"
 So we parked and searched around for the party.  Soon we found a trail leading
to the beach, and sure enough, there were lots of people partying by a big
campfire.  I smelled A LOT of alcohol and thought 'uh oh'.  Apparently a bunch
of other people had been by looking for new hope asking "Where's the rave?"  So
all these drunk people were teasing us by offering us ecstasy.  This one girl
actually thought they were serious.  I hope she didn't get sold aspirin.
     Anyway, a quick recap: thick vibe, some sick acid tracks from micron, tons
of familiar and not so familiar faces, intensely warm fire, gorgeous location. 
What more can I say? I hope that these will be happening often this summer. 
Don't miss the next one!
                                         Steve.

             <Pine.OSF.3.95q.970308093945.28571A-100000@Bayou.UH.EDU> 
Date: Sat, 08 Mar 97 11:58:06 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> For god's sake, if you are *actually* going to be in India, skip the goa
> and go listen to some classical indian music (tablas, sitar and all). I'll
> wager it's time much better spent. Oh, yeah...if you're going to be
> hitting that curry, bring yer M.O.M. (unless of course you can handle
> stuff hotter than catsup mr.cheeseburger and fries ;)

Yeah, it seems to be the opinion of some that I should skip Goa, as
I've had enough party experiences w/ travelling EuroTrash to fill this
life time, and my next lifetime, reincarnated as a sheep-farmer's
favorite lil' lamb "Fluffy" (Bahahaaaaah!).  That, and I accidentally
stumbled into that song "Ain't Going to Goa" playing on my car radio
tuned to a "modern rock" station in SF. :-) :-) The confluence of these
events, plus my general boredom with "goa trance" music played at
raves, made me realize I'd just be wasting my time when I could be
checking out other things...

Of course I'll attempt to see some Indian classical music performances
if I can (it'll probably be the company-approved form of after-work
entertainment). Don't worry, I'm not as much of a gringo as you might
think -- I've been a long-time listener to Ravi Shankar, Ali Akhbar
Khan, Vishna Mohan Bhatt, Ashla Bhosle... as well as East/West
collaborations like Ravi && Yehudi Menuhin, John Handy && Dr. L
Subramanian && Ali Akhbar Khan, Monsoon, Sheila Chandra, and Najma
(check out Najma's recent "Forbidden Kiss"
co-produced/arranged/directed by my brother-in-law in NYC)... To say
nothing about participating at my best friend's multi-day Bengalese
wedding in Calcutta, much eating of Indian food (spicy==good), etc.

However, I've found that classical Indian music gigs I've seen (five
Ravi Shankar concerts, two Ali Akhbar Khan, numerous Zakir Hussain
concerts) all tend to be rather staid -- audience interaction being
respectful listening, counting tal (counting out the complex beats with
your hands), and hearty applause afterwards... Granted, things can get
pretty heady at these concerts when the musicianship transcends the
earthly plane, but it's not like people get up out of their chairs and
bust a move right in the middle of a sitar solo...

I wrote my initial note in the hopes that I'd get some pointers on 
what Indian youth culture is into. Are they into Bhangra,
indo-influenced Hip-Hop?? How does "rave" and modern dance culture
translate into Indian culture? Enquiring travellers want to know.

PS: as far as the uncecessary comments about  "stuff hotter than catsup
mr.cheeseburger and fries"... uhh, you can KEEP your WEAK SRI LANKAN
hot-sauces. I regularly grind up HABANERO PEPPERS, SNORT 'EM,  AND DUMP
THE SEEDS INTO MY CONTACT LENSES BEFORE PUTTING 'EM ON IN THE MORNING.
YEEEHAW.... THEN I BLAST HOUSE MUSIC SO LOUD, WITH WAILING DIVAS
SCREECHING SO SOULFULLY, THAT ALL THE NEIGHBORHOOD STRAY KITTIES COME
BY THE FRONT PORCH TO MOUNT MY LEG! So there!

==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

From: Jonathan_Dejano@Interactive.sony.com
Received: by mail1.fw-sj.sony.com id MAA26284; Sat, 8 Mar 1997 12:34:17 -0800 (PST)
Received: by mail1.sgo.in.sel.sony.com id MAA15594; Sat, 8 Mar 1997 12:34:11 -0800 (PST)
Received: by SESFCB02A.Interactive.sony.com(Lotus SMTP MTA v1.05 (274.9 11-27-1996))  id 88256454.0071D024 ; Sat, 8 Mar 1997 12:43:08 -0700

Date: Sat, 8 Mar 1997 12:12:23 -0700
Subject: ...(a) new hope: a review...(longish)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk





From: Jonathan Dejano@SEPL on 03/08/97 12:12 PM

well...good  morning kiddies...here's the lowdown on the phatty boombatty
party known as (a) new hope...


...couldn't make it to springheel jack last night, so me and my fellow jedi
knight (tony G) jump into our x-wing fighter (1986 toyota corolla class)
and head on down to the rendezvous point approximately 12.8 miles south
(from highway 84) on highway 1...

...with the force on our back and the adrenaline in our hearts, we arrive
at the secret rebel base around 10:30 and met up with general anakin and
his small rebel alliance crew, including deepfog and realit-E...we help set
up (sorta) the equipment...while this was going on, anakin asked if there
was a pyromaniac in our (as of yet) small enclave of rebels to help start
the bonfire...question:  how many ravers does it take to start a
bonfire?...answer:  one to light the kindling, and about seven or so to
start breaking down pallets (that we procured from a nearby location;)...)
and start saying "man...get that lighter fluid outta here...and go get me
the gallon o' gasoline and i'll show you how to make a fire..."

...anyway, as the fire was being lit to help keep our bodies warm, deepfog
started spinning some smooth trance to warm the embers in our
soul...deepfog's set got the night started as more of our fellow rebellion
brethren arrive in relatively modest numbers...

...surprise, surprise...immediately after deepfog's set, dj dan made a
surprise appearance (around 12:30 am) and got down on the decks...by this
time, the party was full on, with more people arriving in great
numbers...the humble collection of about 12 or so rebels about 2 hours
before was now growing into a multitude of hundreds by the
minute...however, the presence of our rebel base was felt by the dark side
and some storm troopers (CHP or park rangers i would imagine) were rumored
to be in the vicinity...so right in the middle of dj dan's set, all power
was cut off until the imperial forces left...with much force manipulation
and jedi mind tricks, the storm troopers soon left the vicinity and main
power was again restored...

...next up was general anakin himself and his second in command (on this
interactive set) realit-E...anakin started off with some pulsating hard
trance while realit-E layered some phatty analog synth accents courtesy of
some old skool korg keyboards...these are not your typical slim jim
keyboards mind you...these korgs are industrial strength looking like a
cross between a cash register and richard 23's calculator (for the front
242 fans out there)...anakin and realit-E's set blew the whole place up
when anakin dropped in the track "humanoid"...in the middle of this set,
anakin decided to throw a white label dub plate called "cool cuts 001" into
the throbbing throng and lo and behold, the vinyl landed near tony G's spot
(an erstwhile dj) who soon picked it up for his growing vinyl
collection...by then the force was indeed strong on this stretch of beach
on the leftcoast...

...next on deck was dj radon who (to my relief) threw down some wicked
earth shaking drum n bass...others soon followed into spastic convultions
as the phat bass frequencies were assaulting both our ears and our
bodies...

...unfortunately, master yoda called upon me and tony G to finish our jedi
training for the night (we had to go to work the following day @ 10 am
sharp)...so with our spirits satisfied (me w/drum n bass, and tony G
w/trance), we hopped back onto our x-wing and proceeded to head back to
dagobah (somewhere near san mateo/foster city/belmont area)...during our
trip home, tony G noticed the comet (sorry, but the name escapes me) that's
currently passing in our heavens and we discussed the
significance/insignificance of our existence in this universe..."we are
just specs of dust in this cosmic void, grains of sand in a large beach
somewhere, or drops of water in a large ocean much like that comet is in
this vast expanse of space" he says...i disagree...if we are just drops of
water in a large ocean, then look at those billions of drops working
together in a common goal to create a beautiful stretch of beach that we
were just on, giving us the chance to party our asses off into the
night...think what a multitude of voices can do in this "insignificant"
world of ours and in our rave culture for that matter...(a) new hope
indeed...

...well gotta go back to work (doing what you may ask, but testing
videogames...hah!)...

...so, thanx to anakin (tony G says thank you for the dub plate) and the
whole rebel alliance crew for the phatty boombatty vibe last night and may
the rebellion grow strong in the future...

...may the force be with you...always...

humbl-E,
jedi savant d0u8l3 J;)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Mar  8 16:12:15 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id QAA23979; Sat, 8 Mar 1997 16:12:15 -0800 (PST)
Received: from nak.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id QAA23965; Sat, 8 Mar 1997 16:12:11 -0800 (PST)
Received: from ucdata.Berkeley.EDU.ucdt (ucdata.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.165.25]) by nak.berkeley.edu (8.7.3/8.6.10) with SMTP id QAA11503 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 8 Mar 1997 16:12:09 -0800 (PST)
Received: by ucdata.Berkeley.EDU.ucdt (SMI-8.6/SMI-SVR4)
	id QAA05231; Sat, 8 Mar 1997 16:08:08 -0800
Date: Sat, 8 Mar 1997 16:08:08 -0800 (PST)
From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: The 181 Scene
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9703081522.A4971-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I haven't been to Club 181 in three years, since I left=CAthe world of club=
s=20
for raveland.  Maybe it was meant to be, because I had tentative plans to=
=20
go there tonight, and last night I found myself ferried there in the compan=
y=20
of a different set of people.  But all they had to tell were the magic=20
words "guest list", and I was up for it!

I remember dancing to disco three years ago, with a main dance room and a
small pool room, both basically empty on a couple of Friday nights.=20
Things have changed a bit at 181.  A larger back room has been opened, and
there was a good-sized crowd.  The crowd was interesting, so much more
diverse than the unfortunate homogeneity I've found at raves.  But (I
guess just like in larger society), there was a lot of self-segregation,
everyone sticking more-or-less to their own "group," and a lot of people
milling about checking everyone else out.  The night stayed like that,
restless and tentative; a club unsure of what it was trying to create, and
a crowd that never came together.  The sense of imbalance came also from
the totally different scenes in the three rooms - - a random band in the
front, pretty good band doing funk and 80's covers in the back, and
"classic rock" (!) in the pool room.=20

My group caught a bit of vibe dancing our butts off to the funk band.  Old
Parliament and Michael J covered with guitar and congas.  But the height
of the night came when freestyle rappers jumped into the mix.  They threw
in all kinds of rhymes, sampling old-school like PE and BDP.  They were
dizzying and the crowd danced and screamed.  Fun was had for a little
while.  After the live music ended at 2, a dj came on spinning very
incongruous (for this crowd) jungle and abstract techno.  The room emptied
(of course!).  I danced awhile, my group the only people on the
dancefloor!=20

The bummer of the night, no surprise, was the numerous times I was grabbed
as I wandered through the club or attempted to dance alone. I am a
"wanderer," I like to cruise around checking out the scene, usually on my
own.  In this environment that meant "AVAILABLE," and several times my
progress was stopped by strong hands grabbing my arms and pulling me
toward some drunk man or men stepping into my path, placing their
hands on me.  My body is my own.  The hands of anonymous men I've never
seen before are not allowed on it.  But of course, this simple right is
disregarded with impunity.=20

Actually, I think that's a major reason there is such a lack of women at
clubs and bars.  I notice when I go out that the ratio is often like
70-30.  Where are the women?  Maybe the environment is not quite as
hospitable for us, and we stay away.  And I see hordes of single guys
crowding the dancefloor and the bar - the vast majority of them, I'm sure,
sweet and decent people who just maybe want to meet someone -- and I think
it's sad that because of a few jerks, a lot of women aren't around.=20

Very surprised to run into a bonafide raver there!  What's up to Chris of
Solle Clothing...who was nice enough to offer some alternative parties for
me tonight if I wanted crazy trance, rather than hyping his own party
("Sugar Shack" - deep house), which I thought was a pretty refershing
quality in a promoter!  Good luck to Chris on his party tonite!!

love,
Nancy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Mar  8 19:17:16 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id TAA22148; Sat, 8 Mar 1997 19:17:16 -0800 (PST)

Hi!  ]=)

On Sat, 8 Mar 1997, -=Joe=- wrote:

> GHB is essentially a harmless derivative of the
> neurotransmitter GABA.

 Actually I believe it is a "percursor" of GABA. Like DMT, GHB is found 
in mammalian CNS's. It is in especially high concentrations in 
hibernating animals and unborn fetus's (sp?)(according to information I have 
read).

>  (GABA is an essential chemical we all have and
> need to regulate metabolism and a whole bunch of other bodily functions.)

 Also, (from I've read) it is a regulator of cellular respriation. In 
other words it slows down the intake of oxygen and nutrients for the cell 
while enabling the cell to survive these conditions (hence hibernating 
animals and unborn fetus's having high amounts).


peas,

Ran D.Dreams 							408.427.1666

                                   -=*=-/

An important message from the UBIQUITOUS family.

	As seen through all of the negative media, we have been labeled as a
drug infested communitya complete misinterpretation.  But as of right
now, the media, law enforcement officials, AND even parents have no
reason to think otherwise.  Our scene is much too beautiful to be
vandalized by such a destructive tag.  Because of this, cities are
imposing dance curfews and breaking up positive parties.  Places are
very few, where we as a people are welcome, and they continue to crack
down.  These are very delicate times.  And so it remains strongly, in
our opinion, that in order for our very special scene to grow and
prosper, we must begin to change our attitudes and ways.  Let them open
their eyes to see that the scene has so much more to offer than just a
$20 hit of "e."  
	In our community, there is diversity- at a "rave" all people of any
race or creed can gather together in perfect harmony; there is music- at
a "rave" there is beautiful house music, a universal language for dance;
there is freedom of expression- at a "rave" we are truly accepted as
individuals, ready to be ourselves; and there is LOVE- at a "rave" we
are family, all strong, united, and safe among friends.  No matter how
much positivity and self-fulfillment is generated by our scene, all
theyre led to believe is that "everyone does DRUGS."  We know thats
not what our scene is about at all.  So let the music be our high.  Let
them see that the feeling of dance far surpasses any artificial
euphoria, that we dont need drugs to have a good time.
	Weve been an active part of this scene for over 6 years now, and we
personally owe our survival to being sober.  At one time or another, we
may have all experienced altered states of existence.  This cant be
denied.  These experiences may have been the most euphoric times of our
lives.  But when introducing any artificial substance into our bodies,
we can never totally predict the resulting consequences.  We advise
people to take caution.  Love one another.  Be smart.  We are all one
family.  Location to location and party to party, we all have a
responsibility to watch over each other.  Spread the word and keep the
faith.
	We invite everyone to a wonderful UBIQUITOUS night on Saturday March
15th, 1997. Here, we are putting together a production with so much
energy and visual stimulation that artificial substances will not be
necessary to have an incredible time.  Extreme Beam will be introducing
an awesome multi-colored laser and intellibeam light show.  A fierce DJ
line-up, for two sound systems,  has been put together to create the
most beautiful music (Jeno, Phil Smart, Jon Williams, Carlos, Ghost,
Pete Avila, Simon, RkTech, Essence, Kimo, Kwashi, and Thomas Jenkins). 
Live congas should complement the music nicely.  Anyone who parties
till dawn will be treated to a fantastic morning fire performance. 
Organic fruit will be free for all.  Also, we are working on a special
after-party with STRAWBERRY SUNDAES- more info on this later.  We must
give special thanks to a very talented artist, to be named later, for
painting the divine UBIQUITOUS masterpiece.  Directions and other
important information will be provided on our web site: 
http://www.ccnet.com/~chance/   .  People of all ages can come on March
15th, but no children please (use your own discretion).  For anyone over
21, please call 408.881.0615 soon for info on our free UBIQUITOUS
weekly.  
	Why the self-promo? (We apologize for offending anyone on the SFRave
list.) Well, all of these lasers, lights, speakers, DJs, acts, and so on
are nice for a promoter to brag about, BUT without the people it doesnt
matter- without people we have no purpose without people we have no
party.  Thats what parties are all about arent they? 
PEOPLEHAPPYTOGETHER.

*** Most important, we encourage everyone to communicate.  Please dont
be afraid to meet someone new.  Its what keeps our scene alive. 
UBIQUITOUS yu/bi/kwe/tes adj: Existing or being everywhere at the same
time: omnipresent.

	Thank you so much for your time,
	Much Love,

	Chance, Randy, & Family

Jan 1, 2000 has been declared international peace day.

ppl and governments are making commitments to have a day of total peace
and nonviolence. No violence on tv, in the home, between individuals or
countries.
This will set the tone for the new millennium, so that we eventually
realize
a world where there is finally peace.

On april 5th 1997 ppl all around the planet will be celebrating because
this marks
the 1000 day countdown till Jan 1 2000. Coincidentally this is the day
for DUNE.

for more info on these events go to www.people4peace.com or
www.worldpeace2000.com

>13.  Circle dancing. (Someday these people with figure out that people 
> dance alone but in unity as a whole.  Then again, maybe not.  
> Someday at a massive, I would like to start an energy circle =)!)

My boyfriend is into break dancing.  He says the circle is there to
protect the other dancers around him.  He said, "If I'm breakin' and
there's no circle around me, I'm gonna kick someone in the head."

Besides, even if people are "competing", it's all for fun.  I've heard of
parties where people dance just to show off.  I have friends who have
been approached by people who wanted to "see their moves".  Still I think
if a party has the right vibe, there can be all kinds of dancing without
people actually being competitive.

Love and kisses,

                     Libby Rose

hello hello...
wow wow wow wow wow
what a wonderful fun filled wonderland of frolicking fancy free willobys.
sorry, I was trying to be creative.  so yeah, I had a lot of fun.
It was a nice party with good vibes.
my evening went like this... I pull up and see Eric and Rona and Hiroshi and
Annie May (we missed you smile Annie) and Mark and Melanie and Hope and Andy
and Victoria and Paul and my love Lara outside. Love you guys.  Pretty much
in that order too :).  Then I went inside and met some people who (sorry,
short term memory is gone) I don't really member all to clearly.  Then I saw
all you sit inside... Aaron, Fernie, Perry, Danny, Rick, Sam, (sorry if I
left someone out, but you know I love <3 you right?) And I hugged lots of
people.
Music was fun to dance too, I havent danced that hard in a long time.  Mark
Skinner was on the tables by about 11 or so, then the guy with the cool
 shirt (I'm sorry, I forgot yer name) and then Jeff.  
Everyboby was asleep though and I was whistling to wake them up.  I guess I
didn't think it was too loud, but the neibors did and they called the police.
 I'm sorry :(... My whistle is new and it needed to be broken in. But it was
the wrong time and place.  I feel bad :*(.
But yanno, It's okay because all you were there and I love you all.  And I
got to see you guys and I havent in a long time.
And the vibe was very happy :) everyone was all smiles :)
HAPPY BIRTHDAY TO KIP.... where ever he may be.
and to kate in a bubble, matt (kermit), shawn or sean who I took to 7-11,
james, john, clint, camela, andy, eric, wow, theere are so many more. I can't
remember right now... it was a fun fabulous little ditty put together by all.
Very good vibe.
I'll save my whistle for another party, this one a bigger one instead, cloud
factory maybe????
smiles:)

Hey guys,
I was looking through the AP wire at work and I found this article. It
concerns the security guard who was missing after jumping off the cruise
ship on Valentine's Day.
Take care,
Claudia

(San Francisco)-- A body found yesterday at Pier 42 is that of a
security guard who disappeared last month during a Valentine's dinner
cruise. That's according to coroner's
officials in San Francisco. The badly decomposed body of 28-year-old
Ricardo Ortega Junior was found at about 10 a-m, several miles from the
Oakland Estuary, where the
security guard was last seen on February 15th. Witnesses say Ortega had
jumped off
the Jack London Commodore to rescue a Georgia tourist during a private
party on the cruise ship. The body of 20-year-old Tavaris Willis of
Marietta, Georgia, is still
missing, officials said. Raised in San Francisco, Ortega graduated in
1986 from El Camino High School. He served several years in the US Army
after high school and was
trained as a sharpshooter, according to his wife, Willa Ortega. Ortega
had recently started his own business, Panther Private Security
Services, while waiting to land a job
as a firefighter so he could work with his wife, a San Francisco
firefighter.

those with Computers  get to see it ;o)

just my opinion...nothing more :-)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar  9 13:10:37 1997

From: Matthew Kodama <starchld@leland.Stanford.EDU>
Message-Id: <199703092110.NAA28206@elaine40.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: new hope!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 9 Mar 1997 13:10:22 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
