Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

in review (short and sweet):

didn't get to the party until real late (hey uncle owen, this artoo unit
has a bad motivator!).  when we rolled in around three, i was surprised to
see a _ton_ of people there, grooving down.  started dancing right away to
shake off the chill night air, and within a couple minutes we were nice
and toasty!

really enjoyed radon's set - all sorts of junglish beats with a strong
hiphop flavor - tasty!  too bad his monitor was broken, which made
beatmatching pretty tough.  really nice tunes, though.  next dj (mudfoot?)
played some good sounds too, but i found it not too danceable.  seized the
chance to nestle down for a disco nap while i listened. 

definite highlight was waking up to some spoken-word vibrations and hey!
andy's on the tables!  the sun was up, people were stretching out and
grooving down, and andy was pulling out some mix trix too wake up our
minds too.  big cheers for that crazee-ass guy with the cane, who was
still working his pimp-daddy trip nonstop.  what was with that?

finally, decided that it was time to head back for a hot shower and
breakfast, and end-of-term assignments (yuk).  i was thinking, it's too
bad not that many people are left to dance to andy's stuff - it's really
prime.  and then i walked out the crest of the hill, and everywhere you
looked here and there were groups of four or six or ten people,
prospecting and talking and dancing in the morning sun to the beats coming
over the hill.  yeah!

yippee for adam - one of the most fun parties i've been too in a long
while.  next time leave a contribution jar out where we can find it!  (to
put something in, of course.)
matt.



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar  9 13:42:06 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id NAA18624; Sun, 9 Mar 1997 13:42:06 -0800 (PST)
Received: from mail1.sirius.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with SMTP id NAA18618; Sun, 9 Mar 1997 13:42:03 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [205.134.228.26] (ppp026-sf2.sirius.com [205.134.228.26]) by mail1.sirius.com (8.6.12/960710) with SMTP id NAA05092 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 9 Mar 1997 13:39:36 -0800
Date: Sun, 9 Mar 1997 13:39:36 -0800
X-Sender: branka@pop.sirius.com
Message-Id: <v02130500630becf96eba@[205.134.228.19]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: branka@sirius.com (*B*)
Subject: New Hope review (long)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was excited all day Friday about this party - getting ready for it before
work (work is on the way) was way fun - make sure to take warm clothes,
sleeping bags, a tent, water, glow sticks etc.

We arrived to the beach around 12:30am, and I was pleasantly surprised
noticing that there were way more people than I expected.  I thought it was
going to 30-50 people crowd, but there were probably over 200 people there.


Micron was spinning when we came (I noticed that somebody said how DJ Dan
was there, but I guess they are mixing Micron whose real name is Dan, with
DJ Dan - oh, well - it happened before :P).  We put our stuff away, walked
around to see familiar faces (it was way to dark to actually notice some
people), and just get familiar with the space.  After turning a small space
into the dance floor with the carboard boxed we brought I started dancing.
Micron's set was fun, and before I knew it, it was time for Anakin vs.
RealitE.  They started of mellower, to get into some pretty hard trance
(which I absolutely love).  I ended up dancing through their entire set,
and by the time Radon came on, I was tired enough that sitting down looked
like a very good option.

I joined my friends in the grass, had a beer or two :), and hang out for a
while.  It started getting colder, so almost all warm clothes I brought
ended up on me at this time.  For some reason it seemed that jungle sets
lasted a long time...  Hmmm..  I used to like jungle a lot, but I think I
am realizing that too much jungle can get to you.  I like it when there are
2 sound systems, and one has jungle, and the other one trance or techno, or
if there is one system have jungle set, followed by something else.  I felt
pretty jungled out, cold, and I couldn't wait for the sun to come up.

It was fun watching Adam running around and looking for AndyW when his set
was about to start :).  Andy was somewhere taking a nap, but was rudely
awaken to spin for us.  By this time it was getting lighter, and possible
to actually see people who were there, and it was just great realizing that
I knew more people there than I thought.  Andy's set was fun :) - it was
great to hear some unusual house that turned into trace.  This was my
favorite part of the party - it was getting sunny, there were still people
dancing, walking on the beach, and everybody seemed really happy.  People
were hanging out, some drinking beer, some eating oranges and everything
seemed so beautiful (and I wasn't on E, although I am sure for some people
that's how it sounds).  I kept thinking "There should be more days (and
nights) like this".

Anakin switched with Andy, and his set was really nice.  I danced and
enjoyed every minute of it, till the music stopped and realizing that it
was time to go home.  We gathered out stuff, got help with clearing the
boxes we brought (thanks Todd and _____), and headed our way (SF).

Thanks to Rebel Alliance Sound for having this beautiful party, thanks to
all the DJs, and all the happy people who made it so much fun.  Can't wait
for the next one!

=) *B*

P.S.  Quote of the night I overheard at one point "Can you believe this
party is free!"

P.S.  sorry this got so long - I have to do some work, and writing about
beautiful things just seem way more fun :)

four of us went to "sugar shack" on saturday night,
mostly because the sfraves calendar said taj would be spinning.
after going to this joke of an event, i am seriously wondering
why this thing ever made the sfraves calendar. we spent 10 bucks
to go to what should have been advertised as a frat party for 
cheesy idiots. here are some of the things i witnessed:
1.  a drunken idiot squeezing the breasts of some girl who
was gladly letting it happen.
2. the cliche girls dancing together thinking they are being "crazy"
by acting like they are lesbians.
3. two guys sandwhiching two girls and giving each other high-fives.
4. at least five guys give my girlfriend the once over, and then ask her
to dance.
5. over 1 hour of crap music which should be played at the covered wagon.
6. one fight
7. at least five deep french kisses on the middle of the dance floor.

the night was a joke. i couldnt believe people were acting the way they were.
if someone has taj's email could you please send it to me. i want to know
why the hell his name was assocaited with this "party." ultimately,
we left at 2:00, following out the drunks who didn't know what to do when the
house music came back on. (you should have seen the dance floor thin out
when all the disco stuff ended.)

btw, dont get me wrong. im not uptight or adverse to disco music. i have
had fun at the covered wagn and the like. it's just that when i want to
go to something listed on the sfraves claendar, i expect to avoid the
things found on the above list. 

justin

On Sun, 9 Mar 1997, Paul Hayden wrote:

> NRR means Non-rave related
> What is BSP?

"blatant self promotion"  It's used when the person sending the email is
in some way involved with the event they talk about in their message.

	Sami

For some reason I have been infactuated with the idea of raving someplace
NEW. Some other scene. A new flavor. I have NEVER, despite partying for
almost 2 years here in SF, been to a party elsewhere. When I heard about
Dune III, I got exited and checked around, and found the SoCal raves
calendar. LA has some pretty good parties going on (it seems), and I noticed
that there will be a PHAT party in the desert called "Full Circle" by
"RaveOlympia". It is "to celebrate the coming, and passing of HALE-BOPP the
comet, which will be completely visable and will be passing the earth at its
closest point to the earth." It will be out in the desert, same as Dune III,
however, it seems to be on a much bigger scale. 2 dance areas, and a bunch
of DJ's. I dunno, I think I'm going to go. If anyone else is interested, let
me know. I can probably get my dads explorer for the weekend. PLUR.

Ryan

Subject: What a nice Saturday night! :)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello all!

Attended a very nice smallish party saturday night, maybe only a 100 people?
Had an upstairs chill area and a downstairs dance area.  Heard lots of
jungle (unheard of a year ago!), and lots of goa. :)  And I got to hear Rick
Riffle & Eric do their Re: thing!  Groovy live ambient music, which was
especially nice to run into, because I just emailed Rick earlier that
afternoon asking when the next time they were going to be playing was. And
coincidentally, I find them playing at the party that very night!  That was
extra cool.  

And it was so nice to find this party at the last minute!  I didn't even
find out about it until 4 pm Saturday afternoon!  Happened to find it while
digging thru 3 megs of email in my inbox, on accident.  Good thing I found
it!  Showed to the party around 11 or so, found tons of old friends I
haven't seen in a long time, and tons more friends I have seen in a long
time! :)  And I got to meet the Esteemed List Master himself, Mr. Brian
Behlendorf.  Very cool guy! :)  Got to see Vince too (yay! :), Amy &
Melanie, knucklehead, dj tom, jonas (I'd just wondered that day what had
become of you!), Andy W :), Black Adder (you disappeared without saying
goodbye!), Burger King Jon & friends, and lots of other folk I've been
raving with thru-out 96.  Very cool!  (and thank you Rick for the
*wonderful* hugs, I hope to run into you again sometime. :)

Well I'm done, and I'm off to go hang out on the deck and watch the sunset
over the City, and listen to the trees and smell the sky.

Thanks W+M for a lovely time! :)

Love to you all
Shawna

>Oh yeah, I remember now...
>whenever I think I want a cigarette, I imagine it as a cancer stick 
>going out
>and attackin my nice clean pink big healthy lungs and I wanta kick 
>it's bum
>and get it's evil thought outta my head.
>So, yeah, their ya go, canceer sticks'll kill ya, so  stopp puffin on 
>that
>bs. Oh, and for some off you "I only smoke a few a day" smokers, I 
>challenge
>you, buy a pack, sit for an hour and chain smoke. No pauses or breaks 
>just
>smoke till you puke in the gutter. trust me, tomorrow morning, the 
>thought of
>a cigarette will turn your stomack.   And who knows, maybe youll stop 
>too.
>That will be an excellent day.
>I tell myself that if I ever want a cigarette I have to buy a pack, 
>sit and
>smoke till I puke, and the thought of that is such a turnoff that I 
>don't
>smoke.
>So hey, try it, you might like it. or i mean, you might quit.
>Don't let them fool you into thinking that noone likes a quitter 
>either, I
>love quitter, they make my day.  And besides, don't you wanna be cool 
>and
>smoke free, like me???

It's really hard to quit.  I smoked a pack a day for about 4 years. 
Whenever I went for more than 3 hours without a cigarette, I 'd get cold
sweats, headaches, and I'd become really disoriented.  I had to use the
Nicorette Gum to quit.  Then I stopped smoking for 6 months.  When I was
no longer addicted, I said, "I'm not addicted anymore, so I can have a
cigarette every now and then."  I was so wrong!  I started getting the
psychological addiction again.  Luckily, I stopped myself before I became
physically addicted again!  Now it's been 3 weeks and 4 days since I've
had even a puff of a cigarette!

If anyone out there really wants to quit smoking, and they need some
help, please e-mail me.  I know how difficult quitting is, and I'd love
to help anyone through the struggle!

Love and kisses, 

                       Libby Rose

On Fri, 7 Mar 1997, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

> 
> My new job is sending me to Bangalore India for two weeks at the
> beginning of April. I was wondering if anybody has any sites to check
> out for interesting music and dance scenes near to Bangalore. Is "goa"
> still happening? Know of any internet lists or web sites to check out?
> 

Go to Goa and tell us all about it. I think it's still happenning, not as 
much as a few years ago, but I still hear they pull the three day parties 
on the beach. Two of my friends were there last year. I was going to go this 
Christmas but it fell through but here are the instructions I got. 

Get yourself to Goa, and that should be 4 hours (North?) I think out of 
Bombay. You will automatically be dissapointed by the lack of ravers and 
the huge ammounts of tourists your parents age. It's all very beautiful 
and resorty. What you then have to do is find all the English people that 
live there, and where they go to bars, (There is this area that's where 
you get the info.) and ask around. Or ask where the market  all the 
tourists sell their possessions and ask around. Lots of the people there 
are selling things so they can stay in Goa for longer. Then they will 
tell you to walk on the beach "that way" type thing, and you'll go 
forever in a deserted beach on a certain night, and you'll walk and walk 
and you become convinved that they were fucking with you, because you 
can't see anything nor hear anything... then suddenly there are boards on 
the floor, drugs that you can afford and a lot of people there dancing 
etc. If you're lucky theses things can go on for three days......
 Good luck.... I have to say, April won't be as happenning as the summer 
or new years.... but still... there are ravers there all year round, who 
live there. 

Nailvarnish

>Maybe you could explain it to me otherwise but I have plenty of 
>ex-friends/crank addicts who live and 2 who have died by this sad drug 
>called CRank.  
>    Parting sober is a great thing - I do it- but don't push that on us wit
>h 
>this hypocritical statement as a reason to come to your party.  People 
>will come if they like the dj's, the people who attend (vibe), and the 
>name/type of party you represent. 
>  Good luck..
>Austin
> 
>On Sat, 8 Mar 1997, UBIQUITOUS wrote:
>
>> 	We've been an active part of this scene for over 6 years now, and we
>> personally owe our survival to being sober.  At one time or another, we
>> may have all experienced altered states of existence.  This can't be
>> denied.  These experiences may have been the most euphoric times of our
>> lives.  But when introducing any artificial substance into our bodies,
>> we can never totally predict the resulting consequences.  We advise
>> people to take caution.  Love one another.  Be smart.  We are all one
>> family.  Location to location and party to party, we all have a
>> responsibility to watch over each other.  Spread the word and keep the
>> faith.
>
>> 	Chance, Randy, & Family
>>

Just my little opinion about leaving the underground 


> four of us went to "sugar shack" on saturday night,
> mostly because the sfraves calendar said taj would be spinning.
> after going to this joke of an event, i am seriously wondering
> why this thing ever made the sfraves calendar. we spent 10 bucks
> to go to what should have been advertised as a frat party for 
> cheesy idiots. here are some of the things i witnessed:
> 1.  a drunken idiot squeezing the breasts of some girl who
> was gladly letting it happen.
> 2. the cliche girls dancing together thinking they are being "crazy"
> by acting like they are lesbians.
> 3. two guys sandwhiching two girls and giving each other high-fives.
> 4. at least five guys give my girlfriend the once over, and then ask her
> to dance.
> 5. over 1 hour of crap music which should be played at the covered wagon.
> 6. one fight
> 7. at least five deep french kisses on the middle of the dance floor.
> 
> the night was a joke. i couldnt believe people were acting the way they were.
> if someone has taj's email could you please send it to me. i want to know
> why the hell his name was assocaited with this "party." ultimately,
> we left at 2:00, following out the drunks who didn't know what to do when the
> house music came back on. (you should have seen the dance floor thin out
> when all the disco stuff ended.)
> 
> btw, dont get me wrong. im not uptight or adverse to disco music. i have
> had fun at the covered wagn and the like. it's just that when i want to
> go to something listed on the sfraves claendar, i expect to avoid the
> things found on the above list.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar  9 20:07:03 1997

 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sun, 9 Mar 1997 20:06:52 PST
Date: Sun, 09 Mar 1997 20:04:56 -0800
From: Jonas Hanning <hanning@SONOMA.EDU>
Subject: One Track Mind presents 3000 [a review]
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-id: <33238868.5998@sonoma.edu>
Organization: n/a
MIME-version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.0 (Win95; I)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ok, this is last night's party in a nutshell...

+			-
dj's			people disrespecting the space
			vibe/crowd
			too many people!!!

And for those of you who're still with me, here's the rest of the
review...

I arrived at the party around 12:15. My friends and I were all excited
about the location, 654 Mission (where both Koinonea(?) and Warmth were
thrown.  We walked into a PITCH BLACK room. The walls and the floor were
"decorated" with black plastic bags. And the only light source was a
big screen showing different movies (my friends told me that there were
occasional snippets of a woman performing oral sex on a man...). 
When we got to the table where we were supposed to pay our $10, we were
informed that they were already over their capacity, and the only advice
they could give us was to wait for anyone to leave. (a few minutes
later,
the same "bouncer" got the question "what are we going to do about these
people?" [question was asked by someone who worked at the party], and
his
answer was "wait for them to get tired of waiting and leave") After
about
ten minutes, they decided to let the people who were waiting in (there
were about ten of us by then). When we got past the table and were able
to take a look at the crowd, I got a very bad feeling. At the risk of
sounding prejudice (which I am, as are most of you out there...), I have
never seen that many shirts and jackets from Tommy Hilfiger in one
place,
and the whole thing reminded me of the parties at HomeBase. But I
decided
not to care, and check out the dancing downstairs. On the way, I think I
had 3 or 4 guys offer me "X". And oh, if you wanted acid, you could get
3 for $5. 
I finally got downstairs, and it was just as dark as upstairs. And the
"main room" was packed to the brim. Lots of soul train dancers, which is
cool. As long as they don't tell you to get out of the way so they can
look cool! Which happened, oh ... about 3 times last night.
I reached the dj booth just in time to catch DJ Godfather from Detroit.
Now that's what I call mixing skills. He scratched, played two copies of
the same record with a beat's delay, played with everything. Not even a
broken crossfader could stop this. (the music kept playing as a new
mixer
was hooked up...)
But Godfather's skills weren't really enough to lift my spirits last
night.
What really bummed me out was the total disrespect for the space that
was
displayed. If you never get to go to another party at 654 Mission, last
night was probably the reason. I seriously don't think it's worth
putting
up signs about no smoking if you, as a promoter, are going to smoke in
the
rooms where smoking is allegedly prohibited.
What else? Oh yeah, the crowd. To me, this seemed a lot like the crowd
that
turned the Planet New Year's Make-up party into the gangbanger-night it
was.
I saw close to no love (lover-lover NOR friend-friend), which probably
derives
from the fact that some people were selling Advil for $20 a hit. The
only
people that weren't acting sober were the ones running around with vodka
and
tequila.

In closing, I have to say that although the party wasn't really what I
had 
expected, the promoters still did a fairly decent job. I mean, getting a
dj
with the talent of Godfather to come out to SF was rad. And the free
records
was a cool thing. Not that I got one, but hey... *smile* Too bad the
crowd
was looking for something else. The only times the vibe really rose in
the
main room was when the "MC" started yelling "Where the ho's at?" and
"East
Oakland in the house"...

If you didn't go, you didn't miss out. If you went, where were you? :)

But as always, this was just MY opinion. If you disagree, good for you.
=)

*hugs*
jonas

///////////////////////jonas_hanning\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\
//////////////////dj_eskimo///\\\dabalhed\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\
///////acid_techno_hard trance_goa_drum'n'bass_trance\\\\\\
///////////////////// sf rave family! \\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\

Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.970309230310.11568A-100000@am.UCSC.EDU>

*How to spot a _R A V E R_*

	*Ravers can perfectly understand and have amazing conversations with 
	anyone under the age of ten. 
        *Ravers know where all the best toy stores are. 
        *Ravers get the most mileage out of their shoes. The toes and 
	heels always curl up because they're so worn
        down. 
        *Ravers always wish the dj would spin that OC Transpo track that 
	they keep hearing on the bus ride home. 
        *Ravers are the only people who don't have their age calculated in 
	months, yet still wear and use pacifiers. 
        *Ravers always consider every new place they go to as a possible 
	location for a party. 
        *Ravers hug EVERYONE. 
        *Ravers can DANCE. 
        *Ravers can be found dancing everywhere EXCEPT the main dance 
	floor. 
        *Ravers understand the art of the bathroom conversation. 
        *Ravers choose their clothes by texture, colour, and size. 
        *Ravers love homemade clothes because they've seen the price tag 
	on a pair of Lithiums. 
        *Ravers get the most enjoyment out of gino/guito stories. 
        *Ravers always order water when they go out to clubs. 
        *Ravers realize that "Evian" spells "naivE" backwards. 
        *Ravers notice that the doors near the Mackenzie King Bridge have 
	an "e" on the handle. 
        *Ravers always know the most likely spot to find other ravers 
	within a one-hundred foot radius. 
        *Ravers don't bother planning to meet their friends ahead of time, 
	their friends are always already there. 
        *Ravers don't say "Nice shoes, wanna fu@k?" 
        *Ravers give the best hugs and massages. 
        *Ravers have a one track mind. It goes "thump thump tweet thump 
	tweet thump". 
        *Ravers constantly point out the trippy visuals in everyday life. 
        *Ravers helped Adidas through the "lean" years. 
        *Ravers never know the name of their favorite tracks. 
        *Ravers know how to SMILE. 
        *Ravers always choose "e" on multiple choice questions. 
        *Ravers are good at playing "guess what he's on". 
        *Ravers will say "hi" to those people they don't know, yet always 
	see on the bus. 
        *Ravers can't watch Electric Circus without it being muted. 
        *Ravers define the style of music they listen to as "good". 
        *Ravers know what to do with a dead glowstick. 

~LiQuiD






(This list was posted to the WNYSOR mailing list by Tom Robbs)

A flyer to me is a tangible reminder of a very special event.  It helps me
conjure memories of the party, and helps me keep a record of which parties
I've attended.  Someday I'll make my own rave scrapbook, and it will
feature the flyers prominently.  Might even make it to the WWW!
Love and peace,
Eric

Precedence: bulk

YES!!! My favorite question in the whole wide world!!! =3D)

>	* where did "techno" originate? ive heard chicago.. detroit... england

Ok, this how _I_ see things. Techno / electronic music originates in
Dusseldorf,
Germany. "Germany?" you ask. One word...KRAFTWERK. Inspired by their post-
modernistic surroundings (Dusseldorf is infamous for its industrialization),
they (Ralf Hutter and Florian Scheider) made a complete turnaround (they=
 were
both schooled in classical music), and started building their own=
 instruments
with which they recreated the sounds of the society along with a beat. Epics
of course include "Autobahn" (1974), "Radio Activity" (75) and the brilliant
"Computer World" (1980). And oh, "Tour de France" (83) was remixed by=
 Francois
Kevorkian and featured in the movie "Breakdance"...
Producers in Chicago, Detroit, and all over Europe heard what Kraftwerk were
doing, and they started working on what later turned into "techno", "house",
"electronic body music", "industrial", etc.

Any more questions? Feel free. =3D)

*hugs*
jonas

Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970310010154.804A-100000@epic9.Stanford.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: QUOTED-PRINTABLE
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk




What about the fact that disco music was being innovated concurrently in
America? I've heard that disco evolved into house, after the disco scene
was blown apart/went underground thanks to the Saturday Night Fever craze.=
=20
During that period, lots of ex-disco composers started tweaking their
cheezy synth units (i.e. 303, etc.) in unholy ways and discovered some
crazy new sounds.  This was the origin of the Detroit scene, as I
understand it.

Please correct me if my facts are screwy.




On Mon, 10 Mar 1997, Jonas Hanning wrote:

> YES!!! My favorite question in the whole wide world!!! =3D)
>=20
> >=09* where did "techno" originate? ive heard chicago.. detroit... englan=
d
>=20
> Ok, this how _I_ see things. Techno / electronic music originates in
> Dusseldorf,
> Germany. "Germany?" you ask. One word...KRAFTWERK. Inspired by their post=
-
> modernistic surroundings (Dusseldorf is infamous for its industrializatio=
n),
> they (Ralf Hutter and Florian Scheider) made a complete turnaround (they =
were
> both schooled in classical music), and started building their own instrum=
ents
> with which they recreated the sounds of the society along with a beat. Ep=
ics
> of course include "Autobahn" (1974), "Radio Activity" (75) and the brilli=
ant
> "Computer World" (1980). And oh, "Tour de France" (83) was remixed by Fra=
ncois
> Kevorkian and featured in the movie "Breakdance"...
> Producers in Chicago, Detroit, and all over Europe heard what Kraftwerk w=
ere
> doing, and they started working on what later turned into "techno", "hous=
e",
> "electronic body music", "industrial", etc.
>=20
> Any more questions? Feel free. =3D)
>=20
> *hugs*
> jonas
> =A7=A4*~`~*=A4=A7=93=A7=A4*~ -=3D=93=3D- jonas.hanning -=3D=93=3D- ~*=A4=

WARMTH
the perfect name for this party. cuz all of you, made me, and my friends, 
and everyone i have talked to from the party feel all WARM and LOVED 
inside. 
the decorations were incredible, the lasers on the cielings reminded us 
of fireflies.. the protolab made my evening perfect, hell, all the djs 
did, oh YAY anomaly and somewhere over the rainbow, somehow that was the 
perfect end to a set for me. props props prop micron for that one.
still need to sleep from after that party, i'm afterglowing like all hell 
and saying "throw another warmth soon!" 

i want to say thanks to all of you, for being beautiful people. not just 
by being nice to me cuz it was my b-day, but by being there for friends 
in need. here's a side story about warmth. i met a girl on the floor 
during the protolab's little phat session, and she was worried cuz she 
had showed upw ith her friends hella drunk and took E for the first time 
and she was worried some guy had made her snort some other drug (after 
further questioning she had sniffed that vicks vapo-inhaler stuff.. ahh 
vicks). i told her and her friends if they need ANYTHING (cuz i know E 
and alcohol don't mix well at all) to come find me or one of my friends 
in the corner with the tent. sure enough, about an hour or so later, one 
of the friends came and grabbed me, i went oer and a girl was sitting 
there i guess she had been convulsing. she was trying to talk but it all 
came out like "Bwaabaawwaawa!" and her hands were taught. i talked her 
down a little bit and 
massaged her hands, but then i felt a wave of incredible nausEa hit 
me.. and so I ran and got some of ym friends to help her out while i 
calmed myself down. point of the story is, everyone was more than happy 
to help out this girl, everyone at warmth was GIVING of themselves -- 
love, hugs, smiles, fruit, music.. it was a beautiful party, and it was, 
i felt, a true representation of our community and how it should be ALL 
the time. everyone was looking out for each other, and trying to have the 
best time as well as making others have the best time. i can't WAIT until 
the next warmth, hell the next PARTY (yay ~a new hope~) to see you all 
again, and share in your WARMTH and love :)
one quick question: what's up for saturday night? 
thanks again to all of you who make me smile on a daily basis just by 
being you!
love and hugs,
lara

is it just me, or is this cloning stuff 
thats come to reality as of late kinda creepy? 

If a human were to be cloned, would it have a soul?

If not, then is this a 'child of the machine?'

If it were to have a soul,  -say it were a clone of me- would i share my
soul with the clone?
or would it have it's own soul?

If i were a clone, am i manmade or a miracle like a real child?

i have like a billion whacked ass questions, but i dont think anyone on
this or any other mailng list could answer, but my brain has been going a
trillion miles an hour since ive heard this is reality.

-aieeeee
-much love
-the original justin

Um, I believe that a 'clone' according to the technique the british
scientists used would involve extracting DNA from an organism, and then
gestating a 'twin' in a lab, just like a test tube baby.

Thus, the 'clone' would grow from infancy into adulthood like a normal
organism.  Therefore, it would have as much of a soul as an identical
twin, but just be separated by a number of years from its brother/sister.


	jon

(p.s. I don't believe in souls.... we're all just a complicated mess of
chemical and electrical interactions.  I think the notion of souls is
another example of egocentric humanity trying to make our existence seem
more significant than it really is... aargh, this paper I'm writing is
turning me into an intellectual ass!  must... sleep.... now ;)

Subject: NRR, Re: clone this post

I don't think cloning is that strange at all.  Nature does it all the time
when twins, triplets, etc. are born.  How is it different if we do it in a
test tube?  Everyone has different experiences in life and twins naturally
"seperate" and become different.

Genes don't create people.

We could not recreate either Mahatma Gandhi or Adolf Hitler, because the
clones would not experience the same things as the originals.

I personally think that humanity is like an adolescent experimenting,
growing, exploring.  This stuff is inevitable.

I don't get scared about the future because I believe that humanity will grow
spiritually to keep pace with it's material growth.  We are just in a
temporary painful state.



The shocking technology is just around the corner.

Imagine biological recreating humans to be space-faring birds, underwater
fish, or huge earth-moving worms.  Maybe someday people will choose real or
imaginary animals to occupy.

Imagine harnessing energy that flows between vastly seperated time periods in
the history and future.

Imagine discovering hidden connections in the quantum fluctuations which fill
space that allow communication or travel between vastly seperated regions of
the universe.

Imagine scientists discovering that the universe is a holograph and that they
can look into the far reaches of space and see atoms within their bodies or
vice versa.

Imagine all of humanity uncovering vivid memories of infinite past lives or
becoming aware of every place their spiritual energy has been.

Imagine ceaseless communication between humans, aliens, angels, nature and
the universe.  Imagine no one dying until they felt they had completed what
they wished or needed to do.  Imagine even those who have died being easily
accessable to all who are living.

Imagine every spiritual being on the planet merging their energies so closely
that the planet becomes one indistinguishable being.

Closer in the future may just be a complete optimization of the human brain.
 There is no reason not to utilize it in the most practical and
psychologically/sprititually healthy manner possible.  Our drugs will look
like dinosaurs in the future.


Cloning is pretty boring.  

How would they get a clone of me to reach the same age as me anyway?  I'd
have to go in a spaceship near the speed of light for some time while my
clone on earth grew up.  And they'd have to do unbelievable things to raise
him in the same identical environment as I grew up in.  (mmmmm....maybe they
could extract my memories and put them into him.   That sounds exotic.)

The soul can probably be duplicated, although maybe that would wreck harm in
the balance of things.  I figure all my spiritual energy (soul) is pretty
much dependent on a source outside of me, larger and more transcendent.  So I
exist as a spiritual being only so long as I breathe in the air of that
larger, more encompassing reality.  I am organic and travel down a definite
path in life, but the "me" is really something I am borrowing.  I "own" me so
long as I love me, but then again I "own" all things which I love.  All
things which love me "own" me too.

I read a sci-fi book once where a computer dynamically recreated a planet and
all it's life as solutions to an advanced equation.  However there were only
certain solutions which were stable and self-consistent.  I think that things
like killing one's mother before one is born are impossible.  A reality like
that is not self-consistent.  Perhaps duplicating a soul is the same.  The
universe only requires one of each soul, because that soul was specificly
tailored for a place in the larger whole.

But then again....I think that souls repeat themselves, in a sense, all the
time.  For example, Moses, Buddha, Jesus, Mohammed.  Are they not the same
soul?  Do they not teach the same essential spiritual message?

Cloning humans is possible, although not that extraordinary or useful for a
well-balanced society.  Cloning souls is probably impossible or very
unlikely.  The likelihood of the exact same soul being required twice in the
solution of the universe as a whole is unlikely considering how complicated a
soul is.

I'm not sure where exactly the soul is.  I guess I imagine a soul as a
droplet of spiritual energy that condenses inside of living things.  If a
duplicate of a human being was created, I'm sure a soul would condense inside
of it too.  I doubt a duplicate soul would serve the world as well as one a
little different.


Lotsa thoughts churning in my head.  Ask me more questions.


Peace and love,


- Justin

(Isn't that freaky our names are the same??  Maybe we're the same person.
 I'm the original, though!)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 10 03:57:02 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id DAA13585; Mon, 10 Mar 1997 03:57:02 -0800 (PST)
Received: from emout05.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id DAA13568; Mon, 10 Mar 1997 03:56:59 -0800 (PST)
From: Epiglottal@aol.com
Received: (from root@localhost)
	  by emout05.mail.aol.com (8.7.6/8.7.3/AOL-2.0.0)
	  id GAA14869;
	  Mon, 10 Mar 1997 06:56:28 -0500 (EST)
Date: Mon, 10 Mar 1997 06:56:28 -0500 (EST)
Message-ID: <970310065627_2062896016@emout05.mail.aol.com>
To: gonzo@leland.stanford.edu, liquid7@cats.ucsc.edu
cc: iam@chosen.org, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: NRR: Re: clone this post
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

In a message dated 97-03-10 05:47:18 EST, gonzo@leland.Stanford.EDU (Jonathan
Mark Logan) writes:

<< (p.s. I don't believe in souls.... we're all just a complicated mess of
 chemical and electrical interactions.  I think the notion of souls is
 another example of egocentric humanity trying to make our existence seem
 more significant than it really is... aargh, this paper I'm writing is
 turning me into an intellectual ass!  must... sleep.... now ;) >>

Hmm, I don't really believe in complicated chemical and electrical
interactions.
I think that in reality these energies are complicated manifestations of a
more primal spiritual energy.  Have you ever heard of the God-particle?
 Lotsa quantum theorists like to imagine that there is some fundamental way
all the forces of the universe unite.  Unfortunately, since we can't
reproduce the Big Bang, we will never be able to study that particle, but I
believe that if we could, it would be very spiritual.

As far as I can tell, reality tends to become what we believe it to be
(especially true with acid), but also true in cases like wave-particle
duality.  What seem like simple questions: is the particle here or there; is
it moving at 99% of the speed of light or 99.5% are unanswerable until an
observer looks at it and creates a reality.  Nothing but abstract
probabilities and potentialities exist before that.  It flies in the face of
a tinker-toy, mechanistic view of the universe.

Now it could be that humanity is egocentric and looking for significance that
does not exist.  But I tend to think that reality is a little warmer and more
friendly.  How could a fundementally cruel and insignificant world be stable
enough to support itself?  How many times have you walked into a strange and
new place (like me, move to San Fran) and seen somebody you know?  The world
is small.  The universe is too.  There are connections between what happens
out there in space and down here on Earth that we can't pretend to
understand.  Chaos theory talks about how a small change like a butterfly's
wings flapping can eventually cause a change in weather.  The same things is
true for the connections of reality.

I don't claim to understand the soul.  All I can do is muse.  But I think
it's clear that there are dimensions of reality beyond and outside of time
and space and our everyday sense of logical connections.  This reality, for
lack of another way to understand it, is what I consider spiritual reality.
 It produces awe and transcendence, because it is larger than we are and
beyond our conception.  That same place that produces that sense of
transcendence is what I consider to be the soul.  It's the place where
spiritual energy resides.  It's the place where we perceive, love, and
comprehend.

(BTW: I don't think you're an intellectual ass for mentioning your beliefs.
 I respect you for it.)

Take care,

 - Justin

The existence of the soul.  Now there is an interesting question.  =
What/Who are we?  This is one of the oldest questions of humanity, as =
unanswerable now as it was when first thought about way back when.  We =
drift though life 99.99999% of the time oblivious of where our thoughts =
originate from, and relate to.  Try this experiment.    Sit on a chair =
and look at your hand.  It is incredibly complex in it's make up, from =
the cellular level up.  Each piece fits perfectly into this incredible =
articulate instrument for manipulating the world around you.  Now clench =
a fist, spread your fingers, flex a muscle.  How did you do that?  You =
think(?) and it happens.  Was that just an abstraction of the chemical =
and electrical impulses that you are made up of ,
 >(just a complicated mess of chemical and electrical interactions

or=20

[these] energies are complicated manifestations of a more primal =
spiritual energy.

Which is truth.  What is truth.  What creates that voice in your head =
when you form a thought?  What is a thought?

I do not believe that these questions can be answered easily, or at all. =
 Each person must come to grips with an explanation that makes them =
comfortable with *reality* as they see it.

"I think therefore I am"      - Ren=E9e Decartes
                =20
 Not just another catch phrase,  ponder that statement, and think about =
the paradox that arises if we are just chemical and electrical =
interactions.  Think of the paradox that arises if we are something =
more.  Is the very existence of your thought direct proof that you are a =
"spiritual being?"  Is it direct dis-proof that you are merely a bunch =
of chemicals?

I cannot argue for or against it until I decide for myself, but consider =
that a banquet for thought!



<3   <3         <3            <3
<3     <3            <3
<3       to all....

Love, Hadrian

beating out rhythms on the cali sticks with my friend Tom, and with a lot of
new friends who wanted to learn how to use them.  Playing with those martial
arts sticks is so much fun.  

There are a lot of ravers who hang out at the circle.  A beautiful vibe
under the warm, spring sun.

Subject: RE: Hey where did techno come from?
Content-Type: text/plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greets,
     Kraftwerk is definately one of the pioneers, but we also shouldn't forget
Tangerine Dream's music (from Germany also) from around 1974 to 1976. 
Actually, this stuff sounds more like today's trance than Kraftwerk sounds like
today's techno.  If you want to be truly amazed, listen to the album "Phaedra"
by TD, and keep in mind that it came out in 1974. It was one of the first
albums to sequenced synthesizers alone for all the rhythm parts.  They tweak
filters to create energy buildups and everything.  You would expect it to be
cheezy, but in fact (or maybe opinion), if it were released today, techno
freaks would still praise it.  Don't take this Tangerine Dream advertisement to
mean that all their albums are good.  After '76 they got heavily into making
film soundtracks, and started making some cheezy ass music.  Some may disagree,
but the only albums I would recommend are "Phaedra", "Ricochet", and "Rubycon".
 Anyway,
                                       Steve

Date: Mon, 10 Mar 1997 09:00:19 -0800

Good Morning everyones...

	Well I just don't believe it's right for me to post a review of our 
own party... but your words, dear raver, speak for themselves...
Thank yous:
I really would like to thank everyone involved for taking their time 
and effort to help set up, dance, trance, beat their feet to the funky 
beat, and tear down way later ('bout 10 AM)...
I also want to send the warmest thanks to the SFR family:  Branka, 
Matt, Pengo, Scoot C, Jonathan D (Hey, I think I promised something 
about helping out ;). And Everyone else in the SFR that made it out... 
 If I haven't met you yet pop up and say high!!!  SFR and all 
associated to it will always have a spot in my heart.
More thanks to the Rebels that help make the nights journies a 
memorable one:  Deepfog, Micron, Realit-E, Radon, Mudfoot, and AndyW 
 you guys all ROCK!!!
And also a thank you to the other promoters out there that showed 
support:  Euphonic Genesis in SJ, Warmth family, Ben and Dhrien's SC 
crew, Happy Kids bunch, was there even a few faces from Harmony out 
there??? And also to the promoters that contacted us and gave support 
even though they weren't there freezin',  their warmth was felt in 
spirit.
Thank you also for the non-Sfravers that we're out there showing that 
we all can co-exist w/o incident.  No fights. No bad vibes.  Just your 
general wackyness.  Much love to all of you...
One last thanks to the San Mateo Sheriff Dept. For not busting us @ 
1:30.  Usually the sight of two Imperial Cruisers is a sure shutdown, 
but, for whatever reason.  They kept going. (Sorry For the quick power 
outage Micron and all).

And one last word....
We are alive.  We are the new underground...  I remember the posts in 
regards to the scene being dead...  Well, I guess 200-300 ravers going 
OFF on a beach, in the middle of nowhere, with Jungle, House, Trance 
and other unclassifiable stuff bleeding thru the speakers,  during 
March, in the cold, for a free party shows that we are still very much 
alive...
Thanks for making our first outdoor party (and first outdoor of 97') a 
memorable one.  And it will happen again (once we pay off our credit 
card bills...)
				In April....

"Stay Connected"
---Adam  (Anakin)

And if you, dear raver wants to give us any input to make our events 
even better,  drop me a line... Any other kind of music style would 
you like to hear?  All questions, comments, praise, critisims are 
appreciated.  After all, these parties aren't for a profit (HAH), nor 
to perpetuate the 20/20 myths conveyed thru the media.  These parties 
are for you.  Look in a mirror and you'll see the same people who 
throw Rebel Alliance Sound.  Raves, for ravers by ravers.

Subject: Re: Hey where did techno come from?
To: thedamaja@hotmail.com (Steve  Duell)
Date: Mon, 10 Mar 1997 09:34:04 -0800 (PST)

In-Reply-To: <199703101632.IAA08798@f8.hotmail.com> from "Steve  Duell" at Mar 10, 97 08:32:13 am

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Precedence: bulk

> 
> Greets,
>      Kraftwerk is definately one of the pioneers, but we also shouldn't forget
> Tangerine Dream's music (from Germany also) from around 1974 to 1976. 
> Actually, this stuff sounds more like today's trance than Kraftwerk sounds like
> today's techno.  If you want to be truly amazed, listen to the album "Phaedra"
> by TD, and keep in mind that it came out in 1974. It was one of the first
> albums to sequenced synthesizers alone for all the rhythm parts.  They tweak
> filters to create energy buildups and everything.  You would expect it to be
> cheezy, but in fact (or maybe opinion), if it were released today, techno
> freaks would still praise it.  Don't take this Tangerine Dream advertisement to
> mean that all their albums are good.  After '76 they got heavily into making
> film soundtracks, and started making some cheezy ass music.  Some may disagree,
> but the only albums I would recommend are "Phaedra", "Ricochet", and "Rubycon".
>  Anyway,
>                                        Steve


And don't forget "Atem" (German for "breath") which predates "Phaedra"
by a few years - the title track lasts a whole side of the vinyl (maybe
20 minutes) and for the first half builds gradually to until it reaches
a total frenzy about half-way through, then suddenly drops out to this 
veerrryyy spacy, very quiet free-form ambience. It's supposed to be the 
breath - breath in, breath out.

Actually I remember when Phaedra came out and *we* thought it was 
pretty commercial compared with earlier TDream stuff! How things change
in the perspective of the years. I remember seeing TDream live at a
little university gig in England (I crewed for them!) around the time
of Phaedra and they were amazing - that huge wall of sequencers and 
knobs to twiddle is now condensed into a 303, basically. 

- Martin  =]

In-Reply-To: <970310062019_1283768410@emout17.mail.aol.com>

DISCLAIMER: This is REALLY long, cosmic and babbly; press delete now if
you don't want to read all the ranting...   :)
-----------------------------------
Okay, you've been warned...


On Mon, 10 Mar 1997 Epiglottal@aol.com wrote:
...
> We could not recreate either Mahatma Gandhi or Adolf Hitler, because the
> clones would not experience the same things as the originals.

Too true!... All the events in life play almost as big a role in defining
oneself (imho) as does genetic makeup.
(Genetic makeup?  Is that supposed to make you look sexy on the cellular
level?  Okay, okay, bad joke.)  :)

...
> 
> I don't get scared about the future because I believe that humanity will grow
> spiritually to keep pace with it's material growth.  We are just in a
> temporary painful state.

I do sometimes, after seeing what we've done with other fantastic 
discoveries, like nuclear fusion.  I agree, though, that this is just
another "first step" in our progress, and that the really amazing stuff,
even as far as genetic manipulation goes, is yet to come.  Progress is
always a bumpy road, for there will always be those who wish to prey upon
it for personal gain at the cost of others.  I believe this is simply
because our technological prowess surpassed our capacities for social
responsibility long ago (probably in the late Middle Ages), and we haven't
caught up since.  So progress will always be painful at first.  But
eventually, we learn to take responsibility for our actions, and our
social capacity rises...

Now as far as the soul goes...  I don't understand why people always place 
this gap between science and metaphysics.  I'm of the opinion that 
spirituality is the culmination of a lot of science that's so far beyond
us right now that we couldn't possibly understand it for many eons...
maybe even never.  (I consider myself both a scientist and a
spiritualist; in a sense, I find they are one and the same.)  Anyways, I
don't think that there's anything wrong with assuming a physical
explanation of the soul; it's just on such a totally HUGE scale that we
can't even hope to grasp it.  Imagine a circuit/pathway that involved
100,000,000,000 neurons!  I, for one, can't really even appreciate a
number that big, let alone try to figure out any of the pathways linking
these cells all together.  Now imagine that this system was dynamic, and
could switch all its connections around, modify or duplicate connections
anywhere else in the circuit, anytime.  Why couldn't something *that*
complicated be capable of *thought*?  The mass of cells in our heads is
_so_ amazingly complex, I don't see why they couldn't synergize and
generate all kinds of psychic energy (including whatever it is that we
call *thought*), pick up on others' energy, and maybe even use the energy
to manipulate matter (with training, perhaps...)!  And this isn't even
taking into account all the scientific quantum-stuff we haven't even
discovered yet, that might also be playing a part in our minds!  To me,
that qualifies each of us as having a "soul", though perhaps not in the
traditional religious sense.  Our minds are so immensely complex and so
beyond us that all we can do is give a name to the source of the beauty of
thought, and call it a soul.

It's kind of like how we look at the universe:  all we see looking through
our great big looking-glasses are a bunch of stars, galaxies, nebulae,
etc.  Nothing but beautiful bodies of rock, gas, ice, and plasma...  as
far as we can tell from here.  But even when our greatest physicists look
up to the heavens through humanity's most advanced technological "eyes,"
they haven't the foggiest idea how each of them are interacting, or what's
actually going on in any of the billions and trillions of star-systems
scattered across the sky.  The fact that an alien child just shot a
spitwad across the room in class yesterday on some seemingly insignificant
little dot of a planet somewhere in the middle of nowhere might be a
totally crucial event in cosmic history; but we may never know.  :)

Anyways, I am *totally* rambling at this point; thanx for bearing with me
through my little philosophical soapbox-speech...  Much love to you all-
-=Joe=-
 ____________________________________________________________________
 _)oe }{elgeson : jphelgeson@ucdavis.edu :  e  x  p  l  o  r  e  r

YES, YES, YES, I SAW IT friday night! It made me smile for hours, and
giggle, and annoy others in my presence! I love billboard
alteration. It is the finest of all arts in my view ( visual arts
anyway.)

> I looked to the left and right of these three letters thinking there may be
> burnt out letters that used to say something else, but there were none. The
> only other thing  i can remember is that below the letters LSD it said sale. 

It usually says HILLSDALE. Now it says hil LSD ale but the hil and the
ale have had the lights removed/broken out. Below it is usually a
picture of a some happy dweebs consuming useless yet expensive items
as they assume is their meaning in life. With the influence of the LSD
above, this common practice would be so very eliminated that of course
the light below was also taken out.

LSD in five foot red block letters floating in the evening sky! Life
is indeed beautiful sometimes.

Well, as many of you know, I, and many others, have been agressively adding
filters to manage the "content" of SF Raves. For the last month or so, my
filters have been sorting mail at the following ratio: SFR 66%, SFR/NRR 33%.

I just thought I would let you know.

I'll just throw my $0.02 in, by adding "E2-E4" by Manuel Gottsching...I
don't remember if he was involved in T-Dream or not, but he was originally
with Ash-Ra... Anyway, it's 33 minutes of gently pulsating synth with spanish
classical style guiter riffs laid over the top...pretty amazing considering
it's now 20 yrs old (or thereabouts).

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 10 10:30:46 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id KAA24921; Mon, 10 Mar 1997 10:30:46 -0800 (PST)
Received: from tapeheads.ednet.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id KAA24901; Mon, 10 Mar 1997 10:30:40 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [207.93.14.13] by tapeheads.ednet.net
 with ESMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.1.1); Mon, 10 Mar 1997 10:29:42 -0800
Message-Id: <v03101e02af49ff092014@[207.93.14.13]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 10 Mar 1997 10:34:05 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Joe Rice <ambient@netcom.com>
Subject: SHJ/OTM
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Checked out Springheel Jack at Bimbo's on Friday night after seeing Lost
Highway, which may have skewed the whole experience for me. =) I'd never
been to Bimbo's before - not the place I'd choose for a dance event, but
very elegant venue nonetheless. Sort of a 50's jazz supper club vibe.
Springheel Jack played some decent tracks - and I like their records quite
a bit - but it didn't seem very live and there was no interaction with the
audience. It didn't help that club's sound system wasn't really up to
reproducing jungle basslines and was overdriven for much of the show. I was
surprised at how crowded the show was, but it wasn't by any means an
underground contingent - more what I'd think of as the Guardian crowd. I
wonder if this was a preview of what's to come with weekly listings in the
SF Weekly...

Saturday night I went to hear the out of town jocks at One Track Mind. It
had a fairly dark and ominous feel to it due to the sheets of black plastic
and minimal lighting, but I suspect his was intentional - hearkening to
minimal midwest undergrounds. Chris O.S.T. was playing some nice ambient
electronica live upstairs at this point and DJ Dick was playing downstairs.
The two detroit DJ's, DJ Dick and DJ Godfather, stuck mainly to electro,
which was great - and it was cool to see everyone into it on the dance
floor. They went for the cut & scratch style of DJing, yet the tricks just
didn't do it for me. Too much ambitious scratching attempts with poorly
timed execution for me - the groove was interrupted every couple minutes.
After seeing Kid Koala last week at the Ninja Tunes show it's going to be
hard to impress me with scratching, though. He knew what to do. Heather
Hart played after Godfather and was pretty impressive - a flawless mixer
and a nice tracky techno selection.

Jonas commented on the crowd at OTM. There were some annoying dealers on
the stairs and quite a bit of sportwear, but there still seemed to be a
decent vibe, especially downstairs on the dancefloor. I suspect the crowd
consistency may have been somewhat due to the lack of events last Saturday.

Joe

past, and wall paper for your room!

last week, the weekly that happened three
years ago, or the flyer that had that one DJ that
you never heard, who moved your soul in a

with others in the scene.

At 10:27 AM -0800 3/10/97, Neil Palmer wrote:
>I'll just throw my $0.02 in, by adding "E2-E4" by Manuel Gottsching...I
>don't remember if he was involved in T-Dream or not, but he was originally
>with Ash-Ra... Anyway, it's 33 minutes of gently pulsating synth with spanish
>classical style guiter riffs laid over the top...pretty amazing considering
>it's now 20 yrs old (or thereabouts).

>Neil.
>neil@nit.airtouch.com

Also sampled by Sueno Latino for their track of the same name and by Carl
Craig for Remake. I'm always amazed at how much 70's ambient (ie Rainbow
Dome Music by Steve Hillage) sounds like the stuff the Orb and other new
school ambient pioneers did in the early nineties.

Joe

Liquid wrote:

>I just wanted to hear from everyone what excatly the "FLYER" for a party 
>is to them... what does it do to you? for you? give you? say to you?
>
>If youve ever chose to go to a party solely because of its flyer...
>what was it that made you go? as opposed to some other party?
>

I like to look at the pretty flyers.  For example, the Anolog flyer that Space
Children put out for their party.  Just because it is pretty does not mean it
is going to be good.  Let me just say that I heard Anolog wasn't the greatest
party.  The reason why I did not attend this party, was not because of their
flyer or whatever.  It was because of their previous mess ups.  Until they
prove to me that they can throw a decent party, maybe I will start showing up
there.

Somebody tried to teach me something about flyers so I may attend good parties
(stupid me didn't know that at the time).  I have noticed that the not so
pretty flyers were to ones to go to.  But I learned in time how to chose my
parties, through flyers and people.

Well as you know, you won't be seeing me at UBIQUITOUS.  To all of you that
know me, I will be seeing you this Saturday at a very HAPPY PARTY
=))))))))))))))).  It will be so nice to see all of your smiling faces again! 
Take care, be happy, Keep smilinG, lotsa huGGGGGGGGGS!

oxoxoxoxoxo,

PAULA >=^b!

Hi,
Mohan from FTT with another BSP....  We'd like to thank everyone who was at
Bimbo's on Friday for the Spring Heel Jack show. Apologies to those who
could not get in as the event sold out.  John and Ashley from SHJ send
their love and they'll be back in October for FTT's HALLOWEEN TRIBAL
MASSIVE... 
On the update tip, this month we'll be doing WINTER OASIS in Miami with
DAFT PUNK, and ORGANIC in SF on March 28th. Rockers Hi-Fi (formerly known
as Original Rockers) will be headlining and I'm sure their blend of sounds
will 'rock' the night! 
In April we'll be starting our National Summer Tour, and taking a breather
here in SF with the Porno for Pyros make up show.
May will kick off our brand new party, EPIC Live with a full-on hard
hitting rave with special guests, the CHEMICAL BROTHERS and the ORB, both
performing live!!!
We've also secured the LTJ Bukem LOGICAL PROGRESSION II tour for all dates
in the US, and we're planning a special kick-off here in SF late May, early
June.  Following that, the Goldie and Metalheadz US tour. And in the works,
our first International tour (Hawaii, Tokyo, Osaka, Seoul, Hong Kong,
Bangkok, Singapore, Jakarta and Bali) in August/October.
I apologize for this long message. We're constantly trying to improve on
our events and want to give our best at all shows, though we know this is
not always possible. 
If you have any suggestions, criticisms or grievances, please feel free to
email me personally at email : mohan@funkytekno.com

hi everyone,
                wow.. i'm actually glad that someone else noted 

                        <<people disrespecting the space
			<<vibe/crowd
			<<too many people!!!

because 654 mission street is my space. well i dont own the place, but robyn
and myself rent it out for cyborganic.

                i came kinda late to the party... and when i walked in i
immediately noticed a different feeling of the place. the last couple of
parties including Warmth and Madness had a very good aura about it.  the
place wasnt the same... 
              <<We walked into a PITCH BLACK room. The walls and the floor were
"decorated" with black plastic bags. And the only light source was a
big screen showing different movies>>

      <<What really bummed me out was the total disrespect for the space that
                        was displayed.If you never get to go to another
party at                 654 Mission, last night was probably the reason. I
seriously         don't think it's worth putting up signs about no smoking
if you, as a                         promoter, are going to smoke in the
rooms where smoking is     allegedly prohibited.>>


i have to definitely agree with you on that one. well the problem with the
smoking part is that you could smoke in our tiny smoking 'dungeon' in the
basement for the last parties. i guess if you've been to a party at
cyborganic before, you went down there to get your nicotine fix. but my co
workers decided to make this a non smoking party at the last minute. and
robyn and i had to be the bad guys. we went around w/ mag lites asking
people to please put their cigarettes out, or go outside and smoke. i got a
pretty good reception from that-- except for the people who put it out, then
went somewhere else and lit up again. or the ones who didnt believe me...and
blew smoke in my face. that _wasnt_ cool. we also asked one of the guys
putting it on to put up no smoking signs... he put up 5, right in a row on a
wall that was barely visible.  

        i also didnt really care for the people blatantly selling x and acid
in my hallway-- yelling <<3 for $5.>>  please, if youre going to sell-- i
_dont_ want to know about it. ok?


but enough of my banter. please, i ask all of you, take it to heart and
respect spaces. i think we are responsible enough to do so. tell your
friends as well. i'm not a babysitter, i'm not your mom. it totally sucks
going up to people, repeatedly, and asking them to not to smoke, tag, etc.
cyborganic is my second home. i hope all of you who come to cyborganic again
treat the place as you would treat _your_ home. this goes for all spaces.
thanks.

take care
-cassandra

I agree. This party was wiered. Not teribly good, nor bad. Just
really... funky. The decorations were close to nil, as I think the
plastic bag cover was more to protect the location. And yet they had
plenty of free fruit and water.  DJ Godfather did rip it up. But to
really enjoy that kind of performance you have to watch the DJ as well
as listen, it seems, to appreciate it. And I have never gotten the point
to MC's. Especially at a party like this. All the man does is say "Awwww
yea! Partys goin' on right here!" and I'm just thinking to myself "Dude,
shut UP!". Looking at others shake their heads in discust led me to
think the feeling was the same for most of the crowd. I also noticed
some tagging out front of the place (Cyborganic) that I didn't remember
seeing before. Vibe-wise it was nothing compared to Warmth from last
weekend. (Hi Tony!)

-=Pengo=-

At 10:18 PM -0800 3/6/97, Nailvarnish wrote:
>No I am not saying that because that is a ridiculous notion. I am a
>minority and I have never felt that I shouldn't be at a rave because I am
>not white, and that I have never encountered anyway turning me away
>because of my ethnicity (I have in other situations) But I am saying that
>there aren't that many people pf colour in the scene esp when in comes to
>people who organise it. It's not the people who runs the party that is at
>fault, but we have to look at the structure. I never said Scott put out
>racist parties, I am slightly insulted to have anyone say that about what
>I said.
>

I've been reading this thread and it seems there are plenty of good points
that you all have raised.  One of the most important points is that of
"who" is throwing these parties.  Right now, I beleive that there are 3,
count' 'em 3 people of color doing regular events (Martel (still?), Kevin
of FTT, Mac G. in SJ).

Also, I think that there is a serious gap as to the reasons we all party in
the first place.  I think those reasons are not shared in communities with
a lage number of minorities.  Let's face it, E, LSD, GHB, etc. are all
designer drugs.  They cost $$$ to purchase.  The drug culture, despite the
media's hype about drugs in communities of color, is not really embedded
there.  People of color are less prone to try designer drugs.  The drugs of
choice in neighborhoods of color are alcohol , cigarettes, and pot (CDC
'95, '96).

Speed is used less, and heroin is used much less.  Dance culture in sf is
closely tied to drug culture, asd a matter of fact thye are symbiotic.
This could also affect the number of people of color in attendance at
parties.

<cut, snip>

>> NOTE: i'm not saying there is some covert racist cabal operating in the sf
>> party scene.
>
>ME neither,
>
>
>  i'm just saying, look - the fact is that we aren't really

No, certainly it is not planned.  However, there are tinges of racism and
overt sexism in the scene.


>> integrated, even if by policy we are, so we ought to ask why is that?
>>
>That is what I am trying to find out? Anyone?
>
>> > What exactly do you propose?   Do you think that promoters should apply
>> > Equal Opertunity
>> > employment policies when puting together a DJ lineup?  I am not so sure
>> > I would agree with you
>> > that it is fair to book a dj just because they are Black or a Female.
>> > It is much better to book
>> > them for their talent.
>>
>> again, almost right.  yes, of course it would be wrong to have quotas for
>> dj breakdowns, possibly increasing the bad spinning we hear.

Very, very , very few people in SF are booked on talent alone.  Sorry to
burst any libertarian bubble, but it does not work that way.  It's all a
matter of contacts, and paying respects and being accepted into a certain
clique and having a good rep that matter.  Most importantly it is who you
know that is the most important, and if you have talent too?  That's a
plus, but once again, it is not required.

Bad spinning is caused by a number of things from shitty sound systems all
the way down to piss poor skills at the dex.  The bad spinning will cease
when people become alot more genuine as to what they really plan to do when
they throw a party.

>>
>No, one of the problems is that women and minorities, and any cobinations
>don't spin. I hate the fact you're taking me all wrong here. I said they
>don't exist, and I think it's perprosterous to say we are diverse when we
>are not. Damn, can't we even raise questions?????? I NEVER SAID PUT A
>WOMEN MINORITY DJ THAT CANT SPIN ON!!!!! ANYWAY WHY IS IT THAT YOU ASSUME
>THAT BEING A MINORITY DJ AUTOMATICALLY MEANS SHE CAN'T SPIN. NOw that is
>outright racist and sexist.

Here, here.  After all, I as wellas others know who started all this? ;)  I
take the opposite tack almost, if the person is a person of color or a
woman, and they hand me a tape, I can pretty much bet that it'll be a
slammin' piece of work.  There are a number of reasons, one of them being
the notion that if you're not a white male then you have to be 2-3x's as
good, and people internalize this.  The result, great effort is put into a
demo/mixtape and it shows that they are trying to impress (I have hundreds
of demos, so this is from my own experiences, YMMV).  Looking at the scene
I have found Charlotte (Baroness), Dani, Nikki Rivera, Tracy to have plenty
of skills, but still bookings are lighter than any of the various male
packs running around.  It goes to show you that:

RULE #1 IF YOU WANT TO GET BOOKED IN SF:
-START YOUR OWN PARTY AND PLAY THERE.

The formula for success.  Merit and the marketplace will decide your fate.
Good luck.

>
>
>>
>> the #1 way to get jobs is contacts = friends, and if the pool of dj's,
>> promoters, and their circles of friends is lily white, then it makes it
>> damn hard for minority talent to get breaks when maybe they don't deserve
>> it, so later they'll have super-hard skills that make you say damn!

The other problme I see with all of this is an effort being made by people
of color to form their own groups to help each other.  YSH was a perfect
example of some of the ladies of the scene taking charge and doing it their
way.  Now I certainly didn't agreee with their tactics or policies, but
thier hearts were in the right place.  Others would do well to mimick such
a plan for their own designs.  In other words, stop talking about it and do
something....IMO of course.

Also, here in this 49 sq. mi. city, it pays to talk to people, support your
friends, support your posse, pay proper respects, and, in time, get the
bookings you deserve.  But you could forego all that bullshit, start your
own party, and play at it.  That's much simpler.

>>
>> btw - i mean this all meant in a kind way - i find this sorta stuff really
>> easy to overlook in our day to day life.
>> matt.
>>
>> --
>
>AND DAMN IT THIS IS NOT A FUCKING FLAME. I AM MERELY DISAGREEING. WHY IS
>IT THAT WE CAN't DISAGREE? REspect my point of view. I do yours. I have a
>different opinion I WANT TO VOICE. (That's not to you Matt)
>
>Nailvarnish

Peace,
John

who want crops without ploughing the ground; they want rain without thunder
and lightning; they want the ocean without the roar of its waters... Power
concedes nothing without a demand; it never has and it never will."

Frederick Douglass, 1857

new hope was such a pleasant blast.

the spot was incredible, the sublime power of the ocean can make any party
and no crazy baldheads went for a swim either.

this was such a successful event, major props for andy and his crew. all
the dj's played great. I arrived at micron's set and he was laying some
fun tunes down. Anakon threw down some hard sounds that was pretty fun to
see from where I was standing. The lights and people grooving in the ocean
nite was so surreal and the sound was pretty good while competing with
mother nature0. Then alas the drum and bass, what a treat for the late
hours. The sound that filled the beach was very thick. Mudfoot played some
great tunes with a very trippy style, good stuff. 

Come the morning and the bright sun, wake up Andy your on next. His set
was so perfect for the gorgeuos morning. Uplifting stuff that I could not
stop dancing. What a joy the morning crowd was having. Played frisbee and
danced around till I could no more.


Funny point, two fisheram walked down the trail with pole and bucket in
hand. You should of seen there faces when they approached the speakers and
freaks dancing to boom boom boom.

Funny point two, the dude with the tick in his neck and his posse trying
to get it out. He wanted someone to burn it out with a cigarett, that was
funny.

thanks to adam

Precedence: bulk

Okay instead of trying to see the whole "forest" on the topic of cloning
(which I think is beyond our ability to comprehend). Let's just look at
one tree.

I have a disability called ADD (Attention Deficit Disorder), which is
genetically transferred. It's not a disability like being in a
wheelchair or being blind where one can see the disorder. For visually,
it's invisible to those around you. Your behavior is where the problem
is: Forgetfulness, constantly late, disorganized, unable to concentrate
on tedious tasks, ect. Yet there are many advantages to having ADD.
People with ADD are often more creative, have more energy, and are
better in high pressure situations. Example, many race car drivers have
ADD, so do many emergency room doctors. Many famous people throughout
history are believed to have had ADD like Mozart, Ben Franklin,
Leonardo, ect. And I'll bet many of the most creative Party Production
groups, DJs, and other contributors to our scence also owe their
creativeness to having ADD.

Now let's say that through discoveries made through cloning technology,
it were possible for someone like me to be able to ensure that my
son/daughter when born, did not have ADD. I tell you now that If I
could, I'd do it in a second. To live with ADD is hell. Yes I many be
more creative than the average Joe but I'd trade that in a second to not
be late for  every date, or to never again misplace important papers in
my house, or to never again become so frustrated on a test at school
that I must leave to room and go punch the bathroom wall over and over,
or to never again realize that I've been daydreaming and that I missed
my freeway exit about 20 miles back.

But I can also see reasons for not messing with this natural process. If
I were to be able to rid my kin of ADD, then many others would too.
Think for a second the implications of such a change in our genetic
pool. There would be fewer creative minds, fewer pioneers of new and
progressive thought, fewer new ideas would come about because of the
change in the populace. And while such an operation would probably be
available only to the wealthy, those unable to have the operation done
on their kin would be burdened with a world that becomes less and less
tolerable to people with the disorder.

Ok. Sorry this was so long. Any thoughts?

-=Pengo=-

>But I can also see reasons for not messing with this natural process. If I

treatment.  Ridlin does as good a job (if not better) of cutting down on 
creativity as it does of ridding users of the 'bad' effects of ADHD.

on 03/10/97 10:56 PM Dennis Toseland wrote...
>
>-Chill. I'm really not sure cloning is that big of a moral deal.  It just 
>might be a stupid thing if you have all the sheep in the world being 
>cloned from the same parent and then a simple cold wiped them all out.  
>Kinda like the Irish potato blight.

  two things...
one - just because an idea is stupid, doesn't mean people will avoid it.  
Especially with regard to ensuring genetic diversity.  Witness americas 
corn crops: 99+% are identical.  We're basically asking for trouble.

two - the sheep experiment was done *I believe* for cloning sheep that 
carry special recombinant DNA used for medicine.  This is the only way 
the process can be cost effective (those sheep are worth a fortune for 
their milk) and also the only way it can save any effort (inserting the 
DNA to code for the medicine is hard).

on 03/10/97 9:33 PM John S. Lee wrote...
>Let's face it, E, LSD, GHB, etc. are all designer drugs.  They cost $$$ to 
purchase.

  Lets face it, lsd is not a designer drug.  Stop and think what the term 
designer drug means.  (mdma is not one either).
  (BTW, although acid costs money, it seems to be pretty cheap)

>People of color are less prone to try designer drugs.  The drugs of
>choice in neighborhoods of color are alcohol , cigarettes, and pot (CDC
>'95, '96).

  The two characteristics of drugs found in innercity/poor neighborhoods 
seem to be they provide escape from the user's surroundings and/or they 
are addictive.  The former explains why psychedelics (think set/setting) 
aren't the hot drug of choice in poverty stricken areas.  The latter of 
course does not make something more appealing to a user, but since the 
70's, the drug pusher has had as much to say about which chemicals a 
person uses.  Alcohol and cigarettes, though legal, exemplify this as 
well as crack can.

At 3:33 PM +0000 3/10/97, presumed wrote:
>on 03/10/97 9:33 PM John S. Lee wrote...
>>Let's face it, E, LSD, GHB, etc. are all designer drugs.  They cost $$$ to
>purchase.
>
>  Lets face it, lsd is not a designer drug.  Stop and think what the term
>designer drug means.  (mdma is not one either).
>  (BTW, although acid costs money, it seems to be pretty cheap)
>
>>People of color are less prone to try designer drugs.  The drugs of
>>choice in neighborhoods of color are alcohol , cigarettes, and pot (CDC
>>'95, '96).
>
>  The two characteristics of drugs found in innercity/poor neighborhoods
>seem to be they provide escape from the user's surroundings and/or they
>are addictive.  The former explains why psychedelics (think set/setting)
>aren't the hot drug of choice in poverty stricken areas.  The latter of
>course does not make something more appealing to a user, but since the
>70's, the drug pusher has had as much to say about which chemicals a
>person uses.  Alcohol and cigarettes, though legal, exemplify this as
>well as crack can.

It offers just one explanation, the other is price.  Designer drugs are
expensive and thus out of reach for most people with limited amounts of
money (the reason why crack does well in poor hoods is due to it's
relatively cheap price $5/hit o rock).

As for the semantics,please tell me what you consider a designer drug to
be.  Better yet, let's all find a good definition and start from there.  To
me, if it does not occur naturally, it's designer.  So THC, Fungus,
Tobacco, and alcohol (a by prodcut of fermentation), are IMO non-designer,
IMO natural.  MDMA, Cocaine Hydrochloride, LSD, are all designer drugs.  If
we can;t agree on a term, why not synthetic?  There we go!

LSD can be cheap, but I think you might have something about certain drugs
do not provide the kind of escape people are looking for.  I also feel that
there is a distinct "danger" signal that is set off when such drugs are
intro'ed into a community.  LSD is seen as one drug that will mess you up
permanently, same with heroin, and all the other drugs that have initials.
Perception is everything when it comes to selling.

Pax,
John

Frederick Douglass, 1857
