----------
From:  Pengo[SMTP:Pengo@ten.net]
Sent:  Monday, March 10, 1997 1:23 PM
To:  Hadrian
Cc:  'Epiglottal@aol.com'; 'sfraves@hyperreal.com'
Subject:  Re: NRR: Re: clone this post

Okay instead of trying to see the whole "forest" on the topic of cloning
(which I think is beyond our ability to comprehend). Let's just look at
one tree.

I have a disability called ADD (Attention Deficit Disorder), which is
genetically transferred. It's not a disability like being in a
wheelchair or being blind where one can see the disorder. For visually,
it's invisible to those around you. Your behavior is where the problem
is: Forgetfulness, constantly late, disorganized, unable to concentrate
on tedious tasks, ect. Yet there are many advantages to having ADD.
People with ADD are often more creative, have more energy, and are
better in high pressure situations. Example, many race car drivers have
ADD, so do many emergency room doctors. Many famous people throughout
history are believed to have had ADD like Mozart, Ben Franklin,
Leonardo, ect. And I'll bet many of the most creative Party Production
groups, DJs, and other contributors to our scence also owe their
creativeness to having ADD.

Now let's say that through discoveries made through cloning technology,
it were possible for someone like me to be able to ensure that my
son/daughter when born, did not have ADD. I tell you now that If I
could, I'd do it in a second. To live with ADD is hell. Yes I many be
more creative than the average Joe but I'd trade that in a second to not
be late for  every date, or to never again misplace important papers in
my house, or to never again become so frustrated on a test at school
that I must leave to room and go punch the bathroom wall over and over,
or to never again realize that I've been daydreaming and that I missed
my freeway exit about 20 miles back.

But I can also see reasons for not messing with this natural process. If
I were to be able to rid my kin of ADD, then many others would too.
Think for a second the implications of such a change in our genetic
pool. There would be fewer creative minds, fewer pioneers of new and
progressive thought, fewer new ideas would come about because of the
change in the populace. And while such an operation would probably be
available only to the wealthy, those unable to have the operation done
on their kin would be burdened with a world that becomes less and less
tolerable to people with the disorder.

Ok. Sorry this was so long. Any thoughts?

-=3DPengo=3D-

From:  presumed[SMTP:presumed@uclink4.berkeley.edu]
Sent:  Monday, March 10, 1997 7:32 AM
To:  Dennis Toseland; soda...berkeley...edu
Subject:  Re:clone this message

on 03/10/97 10:56 PM Dennis Toseland wrote...
>
>-Chill. I'm really not sure cloning is that big of a moral deal.  It just 
>might be a stupid thing if you have all the sheep in the world being 
>cloned from the same parent and then a simple cold wiped them all out.  
>Kinda like the Irish potato blight.

  two things...
one - just because an idea is stupid, doesn't mean people will avoid it.  
Especially with regard to ensuring genetic diversity.  Witness americas 
corn crops: 99+% are identical.  We're basically asking for trouble.

two - the sheep experiment was done *I believe* for cloning sheep that 
carry special recombinant DNA used for medicine.  This is the only way 
the process can be cost effective (those sheep are worth a fortune for 
their milk) and also the only way it can save any effort (inserting the 
DNA to code for the medicine is hard).

so mr. fussbucket...

the budget for dewey cheatem and howe is shrinking rapidly this year, 
what do you suppose we do?

as the rising sun mixed in sync with the cars piling into downtown san 
francisco...perfectly beatmatched..., mrs. howe  waited expectationally, 
cherry donut in one hand, double mocha latte in the other, powdered sugar 
flaking off her mouth, for an answer.  

mr. fussbucket, who hadn't eaten all weekend, and was showing signs of 
scurvy from general malnutrition (and lack of fresh fruit)...took a gulp 
of tap water...and thought.  

"hmm...lemme look through my little phony book...say here we go?"

"who?"

"no, they had their final concert about 10 years ago.  no, there was this 
guy...he like played athat 420 song."

"Slider and Duke?"

"No, you fussbucket!  Everyone knows Slider and Duke are busy littering 
the universe with old beer bottles and empty party balls.  Im talking 
about Boomerang Fidget!  He's the next macgyver!  that boy can fix anything!"

"well give him a call, maybe he can help our delapidated organization 
from falling into the pits."


***TO BE CONTINUED***

On Sun, 9 Mar 1997 JHOVEY@SCUACC.SCU.EDU wrote:

> 2. the cliche girls dancing together thinking they are being "crazy"
> by acting like they are lesbians.

FYI-

I've been known to go out dancing with a group of some very good women
friends.  We go out solely to be with one another, dance, drink and have
fun.  Since they aren't the techno types, but still happen to be my
friends we usually end up dancing to hip/hop or funk.  Although I might
prefer dancing to something else, I like the company of my friends and I
like to try dancing to a wide variety of music.

We usually dance in one big group and ignore everyone else (club
atmosphere) because our purpose is to be with one another and have a good
time.  There is a different dynamic with an all-women group then in a
mixed group (not better, just different).  We aren't interested in being
picked up, we aren't interested in acting like lesbians.  We just ARE!
I've noticed men looking at us when we dance together, but we try and
ignore them.  I've often noticed it is one's own perception that clouds
one's view.  We would act the very same way, in fact do, in our own living
room.

As a group of women we find a bit more freedom to express sexuality via
dance than we would ever express in a mixed group because we aren't
worrying about what happens if we turn someone on (read: predator/prey).
It's hard to repress something that is a pivotal force of nature.
Besides, I don't find dance and sexuality mutually exclusive.  Even erotic
dancing can be an art form. And none of us are doing this to act crazy,
we basically want to dance unemcumbered with one another i.e. our
friends. I would like to point out that women don't worry so
much about being labeled as gay and often express more affection towards
one another than men.  So, you may be mis-representing what you see.

I just wanted to give you a perspective you may have missed.  I do
understand where you are coming from and don't find your comments way off
in a certain sense. But it sometimes seems to me that judging anyone for
anything is a double-edged sword.  

-kirsten

        A few years ago there was a bill board near my house
        that said "Annheiser-Busch Reminds You to Drink 
        Responsibly"  (this was at Xmas time).  Someone
        thereupon whited out the word "Responsibly".  That
        totally cracked me up!
 
        Right after I had moved to SF about 11 years ago, there
        was a billboard at Army and Mission that had a photo of
        a slender (emaciated) model holding a cup of Dannon 
        yogurt.  The large block letters above her said "Skinny
        Dip".  A few weeks later someone plastered a HUGE banner
        across the billboard reading "Fat Women are Powerful!".
        Again, I was in paroxysms of mirth!

Hey all,
remember back in November when I asked many of you for your insights
into why you rave for that research I was doing?? Didn't think so...and
that is why I am mentioning it again. The paper is finished...some
SFRavers got copies sent to em. I lost a few addresses and forgot to
send some of you a copy, too. Sorry...:(
The paper is now posted on 303. Its a cool website that was made by
ravers for ravers...its in its early stages and the peeps doing it are
looking for input, art, stories.....anything RR. So check it out at:
http://www.vibe.org
I am not affiliated with it..just a contributor. My paper...(which some
of you are quoted in!) is in the "articles" section. Enjoy. I'd love to
hear comments and impressions from you all but please don't burn me into
next year if you don't like it or find it misrepresenting of the scene
as you see it. You all know how multi-faceted and complex the
underground scene is. This paper was for a class I was in in college
"Drugs in U.S Society" (very cool class, I might add) My intent was to
shed some light on the connection between raving and Ecstacy. It was
only supposed to be a 10 page assignment. I had close to 30 written.
(Had to remove many pages of personal accounts and an entire section on
the spirituality of raving and the various interpretations of levels of
conciousness and of collective energy and so on....) 
Anyhoo....I sent this paper out to people last winter when there was
alot of negativity and bs floating about SFR. It can serve as a positive
reminder of why we rave and why each and every one of us loves being a
part of the scene in our individual way. (not meaning to put words into
your mouths, though)
PLUR...
Ari 
~~~~~~
fubari@valuserve.com

"sometimes...well, rather often actually... I just want to crawl inside
a giant wall of speakers and become the music itself"

Subject: NRR: Isn't it wierd. . . 
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

        Why don't people ever figure that every other person in the world is
basically equal to them.
        Do you think that that cop driving bye while you and your friends
are sitting in a parking lot in the middle of nowhere figures that you're
just a parked car? Or do you think that he has thought of the thought of
sitting in a parking lot with all of his friends and doing what you were
doing. . . 

        Or, do you think that you were the only sole living being on this
earth who had this great, super-special idea of whatever?

        Do you realize that the worlds lives are going on without you,
changing, making decisions, and basically doing everything that you could
do, while you were not present.

        Do you forget your friends after a long time without contact, and
never again think of them or what they may be doing. . . Or do you try to
re-attain your knowingness of that person and their lives.

        Do you sit at home, in your room, alone. . . and think of the rest
of the world, how it's changing around you? Or do you sit alone, in your
room, encompassed by your television, and that tv show, ignorant of the
world, your life, and your friends. . . 

        Are your friends the world to you? Are your family members your
life-blood? Can you live without them? Or is your live engorged in them,
waiting for any moment to spawn up and fulfill the needs and voids in the
people around you?

        Do you know who you are? Why you do what you do? Do you know the
reasons for your actions? Do you know the consequences? Are you more aware
of yourself, or others?


Just being thoughtfull. . . how silly of me. . . 


Love ya guys, even though most probably have no clue who I am.

Aryck

'you need four hugs a day for survival, eight for maintenance and twelve for
growth'        (found in the 'Online' section of The Guardian,  March 6, 1997)

hello from england to all sfravers.

we have been listening in on your conversations and enjoying your happy
vibes for the last week now ( i've been itching to contribute to your
diversity debate or the clone/soul debate) and  i think it is time  to
introduce ourselves.

my boyfriend (ben) and i (iris) live in the UK's infamous satellite town
Milton Keynes with (allegedly) one of the best rave venues in the country
and access to some great illegal raves (we would love to tell you about
EXODUS some time). we are mainly into happy hardcore (mainly four:four beat)
and techno, not so much into jungle, but open to anything where people are
happy and unconstipated (let me just look that word up...)

we are planning a trip to the states from the end of may to july or august
or until our money runs out. we want to concentrate on san francisco and
also visit the southwest. the problem is that trailing after a group of
tourist through chinatown or wandering around with a tourist guide book in
our hands is not our idea of fun. there is no point in visiting another
country if you don't get to meet interesting people and experience the
underground culture as opposed to mainstream culture which is what you
usually get as a tourist.

after searching the net for several nights for any non-touristy underground
culture stuff i came across sfrave and after reading your letters for a week
we  know now that san fransisco can be as exciting as we hoped.

so, ... here's our request (forgive us for being so straight forward right
away):
is anybody willing to help us explore the alternative san fransisco? can
anyone recommend cool places to go to, to see, to hang out at, to dance at,
the stuff that is not in the tourist guides. would someone like to take us
to their  favorite parties and...can someone point me to a public computer
terminal, so that i can check my mail and don't die of withdrawal?  :-)

since  we would like to hang out in sf for a little while and we haven't got
much money for hotels we were wondering if anybody would be willing to put
up some fellow ravers or recommend a cheap place to stay at or maybe we
could pitch our tent in someone's back garden.
we are no scroungers and we would not take advantage of anyone. in fact...we
are moving to manchester this fall and i have noticed an interest in the
manchester scene amongst some of you. so, if any of you ever happen to get
to manchester, england, you'd be very welcome to stay at our place. we'll be
there for at least three years.

sorry for this long posting. i would actually like to say much much more but
i don't want to stretch your patience. and i hope we haven't broken any
sfrave rules....you guys are sooo nice to each other! i feel like i have to
tread carefully. but i haven't been this excited in ages. sorry, _we_
haven't been this excited in ages.

iris
p.s. what does PLUR stand for? we've got an idea, but ...
...there's more...

hey, my name is ben.  i'm from milton keynes a small city  near london england  
we have a large warehouse here called the sanctury  it bangs out top notch
raves but has become pretty commercial in the past few years thou it still
has a wicked crowd  we also have undereground do's every couple of weeks
called  exodus. has any one had experience of the english rave scene and how
does it compare to yours 
we will be moving to manchester soon to go to university  glad to swap
addresses with people who would like to check out the english rave scene
think of it as a kind of cultural exchange
i've been reading the mail list for a week now and it sounds like the happy
vibe has spread around the planet. of couse i'm a firm believer it started
in england thou i am open persuasion from people who are amazed at this.
 the summer of love late 80s, acid house, 100k rigs on the M1 is my earliest
record of happy dance parties  or has the music developed simultaneously all
over the wolrd as the technology that helps create it appeared?
cheers
ben

From: ndurham@earthlink.net (n8)
Subject: Re: "where did techno"...   The TRUE story! 
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>        HEY you rave fanatics!
>
>        * where did "techno" originate? ive heard chicago.. detroit... england
>        * and wasn't it around '89 in LA & '91 in SF when the scene really
>          started growing?
>
>          just looking for rave history :)
>

Once upon a time there was a little elf (about 6.04 cm tall).  While
wandering through his town (a rock and roll store) one day he noticed a few
discarded pieces of equipment collecting dust.  He decided that they would
make a great place to turn into a party pad.  After lavishly decorating the
insides of his new home (known to humans as a 303) with trippy posters, elf
art, and Lucky Charms boxes  he called up his elf buddies to throw a party.
One elf brought butterfly snacks as party favours which made all the other
elves really happy (e.g. see elf on front of Lucky Charms box.)  However,
one elf had eaten too many butterflies and tripped over a circuit in the
floor and fell against a switch on the wall causing the 303-pad to jump
into action with crazy twisted sounds.  Frightened, he look up expecting to
be scolded for his carelessness but to his suprise the other elves were
grooving to the sound.  One of the really bright elves (T.K. Noah) had the
sudden inspiration to run outside to the next door and climb into what we
call a 909 (but of course to a 6.04cm elf it was big enough to get lost
in.)  After a few minutes he figured out how to turn it on as well and the
ears of the partygoing elves perked up in amazement.  Quickly running to
the next machine down the road he blew the dust off the cover of something
called an 808,  then sneezed, and crawled inside.  Not much later, he had
this one up and running too and to his suprise he had the grooves all in
synch.  By this time the party was full blown and elves from all over the
store were showing up and dancing to this new incredible sound.  The elves
continued to throw these parties...each time figuring out new and exciting
ways to make their party pad sound even better.  Years past and elves all
over the world had heard the secret and were throwing parties in their own
town while adding their own special touches.  Eventually, the elves decided
to share their secret with a few special humans whom they knew shared a
love for music and unity.  And thus the true story of how techno came to be
was passed down along with this wonderful music and everything we associate
with it.

The end.





Many Thanx to the crew at New Hope for a fantastic beach party...it seems
my brain has finally thawed.  :)

-n8

*****************************
Life is more than we can see
We are more than life can say.
We are lines of power,
circles of concern,
spirals of change.
Merry meet and merry part,
and merry meet again!
*****************************

On Mon, 10 Mar 1997, John S. Lee wrote:

> 
> As for the semantics,please tell me what you consider a designer drug to
> be.  Better yet, let's all find a good definition and start from there.  To
> me, if it does not occur naturally, it's designer.  So THC, Fungus,
> Tobacco, and alcohol (a by prodcut of fermentation), are IMO non-designer,
> IMO natural.  MDMA, Cocaine Hydrochloride, LSD, are all designer drugs.  If
> we can;t agree on a term, why not synthetic?  There we go!

Even though LSD was syntehsized by Albert Hoffman it does occur naturally 
in the ergot fungus, which grows on wheat.  So it is still naturally 
occuring even though it is usually synthesized, ust as psilocybin can 
be made in the lab but of course is found in mushrooms as well.  Cocaine 
is refined from the coca plant, so even though there is quite a bit of 
processing involved it is still a derivative of a natural substance, as 
is heroin from the opium poppy.

The only drugs I would call designer drugs are those whose chemical 
structures never occur naturally.  I don't think that making concentrates 
of a natural substance or simulations of one can be considered a designer 
drug.  At least that's my understanding of the general definition, that a 
designer drug is one whose molecular structure has, in a sense, been 
"designed" rather than copied.


brett

To: Brett Zane-Ulman <brettzu@cats.ucsc.edu>
From: bri@value.net (Brian Denny)
Subject: designer drugs
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


first of all, LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide-25) does _not_ occur in
nature.  ergot contains a related compound, named simply lysergic acid (i
don't remember whether it's also psychoactive), but it is not quite the
same stuff.


the term "designer drug" has been used in the medical community to denote
drugs that were created by making slight alterations to existing substances
-- MDMA from MDA, ALD from LSD, crack from cocaine-- usually with the
intent to avoid legal ramifications, though any such loopholes are
generally closed quickly. (1)

in common parlance i've come to understand it to mean drugs that are not
(and have generally not been) produced by mainstream pharmaceutical
companies and which are limited in their exposure, even within the drug
culture.

thus, MDMA is a designer drug by the first definition, but not by the second.

LSD has never to my knowledge been considered a designer drug, because it
was developed at a pharmaceutical company and used psychiatrically for
years.

this information is based on a limited number of sources so if you have a
reference which either clarifies or refutes what i've just said, please let
me know.

-brian


(1)     "Designer drugs, like designer clothes, are produced to sell.  They are
created and marketed to a clientele of growing size that is looking for an ever
more varied or specific experience in a recreational drug.  The designer
drug is usually a variation on a previously controlled substance."

-Journal of the American Medical Association (found at:

http://hyperreal.com/drugs/misc/review.designer.drugs

) -- a mainstream, anti-drug article.

At 01:45 AM 3/10/97 -0800, you wrote:
>is it just me, or is this cloning stuff 
>thats come to reality as of late kinda creepy? 

To me, not at all.  Depends on your viewpoint.

>If a human were to be cloned, would it have a soul?

It would have whatever every other human has.  I don't believe in "souls"
myself but that doesn't matter.

This, of course, assumes that human cloning works.  Unfortunately we'll
probably never know because given the firestorm of BS surrounding it, no
one will ever admit to success.

>If not, then is this a 'child of the machine?'

No.  Think of it as an identical twin born later in time.

>If it were to have a soul,  -say it were a clone of me- would i share my
>soul with the clone?
>or would it have it's own soul?

You would be two different people with the same genetic makeup.  Just like
identical twins.  See above.

>If i were a clone, am i manmade or a miracle like a real child?

Both.

>i have like a billion whacked ass questions, but i dont think anyone on
>this or any other mailng list could answer, but my brain has been going a
>trillion miles an hour since ive heard this is reality.

My advice: stop stressing about it.  Having known a set or two of twins,
they become very annoyed if you assume they are mentally identical.  I was
childhood friends with one but not his twin -- not like they were polar
opposites, they just had different lives.  And they both had the exact same
upbringing...imagine if it were inevitably different, as it would be with a
clone.

// grigsbeast

but also because of the extent of the differences.

closed automatically in most cases.

on 03/11/97 5:22 AM The Grigsbeast wrote...

>>is it just me, or is this cloning stuff 
>>thats come to reality as of late kinda creepy? 
>
>To me, not at all.  Depends on your viewpoint.

  To me, the idea of cloning is not disturbing.  I look at the paranoia 
of many and think of when people used to burn down the first telegraph 
stations out of fear.
  But the problem with western society possessing these tools is that it 
doesn not have an exceptional track record for utilizing technology to 
benefit the masses, and we, as a society, have not yet reached to simple 
goal of recognizing that everyone is equal.  As a result, if cloning of 
humans ever does take place, it will almost surely have something
 *other* than the best interests of mankind in mind (a rhyme, sorry).  If 
being cloned is desirable, who will be cloned?  The rich WASPS, I'd be 
willing to wager.  Is this just going to compound the division between 
classes?  How can technology cause problems for us?  Simply because our 
society is convinced that it knows what is best.  It makes value 
judgements it should not.

Dear Ravefriends,

        As I mentioned some time ago, I've been trying to set up a chance
for us to meet and talk about the issue of how the authorities suppress
raves through busts, permit requirements, police hassles, etc., and see
what action we can take.  Here it is:


        WHEN:   This Wednesday, March 12, 730pm
        WHERE:  Freedom's Forum Bookstore, 1800 Market Street @ Octavia
        WHY:    Because we have the right to dance and listen to music


        This topic is on the agenda as part of the monthly San Francisco
Libertarian Party meeting.  I'm hoping we'll produce a good turnout to show
the party that ravers have a just grievance and are serious about doing
something about it.

        It's easy for us to talk about this on our lists, a bit harder to
actually take the time and effort to do something political offline, but I
think we are up to it.

        Several people have told me they want to come, and I hope to see as
many of you there as possible.  If enough of us get mobilized on this, I
think we can succeed in getting the laws changed.  At the very least we can
make them aware that there is a public relations cost to pay for trampling
on our rights.

        I would especially encourage anyone who has legal or other
expertise, or hard data on things like cost and availability of permits,
how laws and enforcement vary from place to place, and so on, to show up
and share your knowledge for the good of the scene.

        If you know of anyone not on SFRAVES who might be interested,
please pass the info along to them.  If you or someone you know would like
to be there but need a ride, give me a call and I'll see what I can do.

May the bass be with us,
                                        <<< Starchild >>>

Phone: (415) 626-3036

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id VAA14487; Mon, 10 Mar 1997 21:58:25 -0800 (PST)

Received: from beast (d153.netgate.net [205.214.160.193]) by ng.netgate.net (8.8.5/8.6.9) with SMTP id WAA12575; Mon, 10 Mar 1997 22:03:18 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <3.0.1.32.19970310220004.005a9440@ng.netgate.net>
X-Sender: grigsby@ng.netgate.net
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 3.0.1 (32)
Date: Mon, 10 Mar 1997 22:00:04 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: The Grigsbeast <grigsby@netgate.net>
Subject: NRR: Re: Re: clone this post
Cc: grigsby@ng.netgate.net
In-Reply-To: <970310065627_2062896016@emout05.mail.aol.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 06:56 AM 3/10/97 -0500, you wrote:
>In a message dated 97-03-10 05:47:18 EST, gonzo@leland.Stanford.EDU (Jonathan
>Mark Logan) writes:
>
><< (p.s. I don't believe in souls.... we're all just a complicated mess of
> chemical and electrical interactions.  I think the notion of souls is
> another example of egocentric humanity trying to make our existence seem
> more significant than it really is... aargh, this paper I'm writing is
> turning me into an intellectual ass!  must... sleep.... now ;) >>
>
>Hmm, I don't really believe in complicated chemical and electrical
>interactions.
>I think that in reality these energies are complicated manifestations of a
>more primal spiritual energy.  Have you ever heard of the God-particle?
> Lotsa quantum theorists like to imagine that there is some fundamental way
>all the forces of the universe unite.  Unfortunately, since we can't
>reproduce the Big Bang, we will never be able to study that particle, but I
>believe that if we could, it would be very spiritual.

Does this belief of yours help to explain anything, or is it just a
convenient label to put on something you have no comprehension of whatsoever?

"God is just another word meaning 'I don't know.'"  -someone I forgot

>As far as I can tell, reality tends to become what we believe it to be
>(especially true with acid), but also true in cases like wave-particle
>duality.

This is a common mis-perception: the light does not become what we _want_
it to be, it acts like _one or the other_ based on our perception.  The
light beam won't turn into, say, a hippopotamus, just because we want it to
-- or for any other reason we have yet discovered.  We can affect the
outcome by our perception, but the array of possible outcomes is not
unlimited.

>What seem like simple questions: is the particle here or there; is
>it moving at 99% of the speed of light or 99.5% are unanswerable until an
>observer looks at it and creates a reality.  Nothing but abstract
>probabilities and potentialities exist before that.  It flies in the face of
>a tinker-toy, mechanistic view of the universe.

Who cares if it's 'mechanistic' or not?  What's interesting is how it
works, and if 'how' involves subjective perception (which I wholly
believe), why does that imply this vague realm of spirituality?

I think people tend to take the wrong view of all this.  Instead of
constantly trying to justify how humans are special, and then feeling
guilty because we don't measure up to God or some other platonic ideal of
ourselves ("souls", "energy beings", "privileged by reason", etc.), I
prefer to look at it the other way: isn't it amazing what animals can do
with opposable thumbs, linear thought, and hive mentality?  And instead of
feeling guilty about our shortcomings as humans, perhaps we should just get
down to the hard work of addressing them.

>Now it could be that humanity is egocentric and looking for significance that
>does not exist.  But I tend to think that reality is a little warmer and more
>friendly.  How could a fundementally cruel and insignificant world be stable
>enough to support itself?

"Cruel" and "insignificant" are value judgments you place upon the world,
as are "warmer" and "more friendly".  Reality is what it is; you can call
it what you like.

Personally, I find "Is it useful?" much more interesting than "Is it true?"

// grigsbeast

	U.C. Santa Cruz campus, College Eight Dinning Facility
	Take all freeways from the BayArea to Highway 17 South
	Go over the SantaCruz mountains and take Highway 1 North Exit
	Go straight at 1st light, make RIGHT at 2nd light (Mission St.)
	Go straight through 3 lights, make a RIGHT on the 4th (Bay St.)
	Go through 2 lights. You'll see a big barn on the left corner
	Park in the lot by the barn! Thats the base of the campus...

	Now cross the street to the shuttle/bus stop and catch the
	shuttle (preferably a "Night Perimeter" shuttle its free)
	And ride it all the way around campus to COLLEGE EIGHT!

	Get off, cross the street (going downhill) and go down a big
	flight of stairs and the party's on your immediate right!

	**--PS--**
	You gotta park off campus in the barn lot and take the shuttle 
	because without a parking permit you cant get on campus through
	the gaurd gates after 8pm, if you come before 8 you can come in
	park at College Eight and not worry about shuttle riding and
	getting to your car later! We'll be around to help people finding
	their way and getting to their cars, ill give ya a ride! ;)

	Looking Forward to seeing many of you, meeting many of you,

WARNING:
The following is long, rambling and has nothing to do with raves.
Don't read unless you're interested in mental disorders and cloning.


>I have a disability called ADD (Attention Deficit Disorder), which is
>genetically transferred. Your behavior is where the problem
>is: Forgetfulness, constantly late, disorganized....

....

>Yes I many be more creative than the average Joe but I'd trade that in a
second to >not be late for  every date, or to never again misplace important
papers in
>my house, or to never again become so frustrated on a test at school
>that I must leave to room and go punch the bathroom wall over and over,
>or to never again realize that I've been daydreaming and that I missed
>my freeway exit about 20 miles back.

I have something of the reverse problem.  It's called OCD,
obsessive-compulsive disorder.  It means that I will essentially get "stuck"
on everything I do.  I can't let go and am often focused on the last class,
previous sentence, or that last beautiful idea or pattern.  I go into long
"blank" states where my eyes glaze over and a minute or an hour passes.
 Often times I feel like my mind is moving through mud, or I'm in a
hypnotic/trance state.  I go through repetitive all night long cleaning
behaviors, get stuck with thoughts that repeat so forcefully and continually
that I feel like my mind is breaking.  (Acid can exacerbate this and put me
into panic-striken time and visual loops.  E and stimulants give me a
refreshing break from the tired obsessions)

Anyway, as with ADD, all things are not bad with this strange disorder.  My
ability to focus and my patience are often phenomenal.  Repetitive tasks and
music attract me and I can see patterns and beauty that many cannot for their
lack of focus.  I regularly go into beautiful hypnotic states that many take
drugs to achieve.  I can "surround" and exhaust ideas in amazing ways.  I can
accomplish things despite endless failures.  But like you, I would trade it
in a moment just to be normal.

I don't think we should genetically create people so there is no possibility
of "error," but I think we should have genetic relief for those who want it.
 Cloning sounds senseless to me, but sending a therapeutic virus in to change
the genes in the cells could be helpful.  I think the possibilities are
exciting.


Much love,

  - Justin

> Marshal

I remember my first earthquake. I was lying in bed, and then I felt
sort of weird; kind of like my bed had moved a little bit, but I
couldn't figure out why (nothing fun was happening at the time, I
promise). 

I kind of liked the feeling, actually. Since then, I've become
slightly addicted to it, to the point that I relish the thought of
something slightly larger... It just seems like that ultimate
amusement park ride. Except you don't have to leave your own home!

The thrill of life is gone without ever-looming thrill of being near
death... Earthquakes remind me of that. They also remind me of how
foolish we are to build huge structures and dwell in them. They remind
me of how much more powerful nature is that it can destroy us all in a
blink of an eye.

That, to me, is fascinating. We concern ourselves with the minute
details of the environmental impacts of plastic vs. paper, what brand
of gas is better, etc. We worry that we have conquered our
environment; we think we are slowly destroying the earth, and then...

*whammo!*

8.4 comes along; destroys cities; burns down houses; years of human
efforts, down the drain in the matter of 90 seconds. Nature comes
and puts us in our place.

Nature always wins. I like that.
Nature is cool. :)
I am rambling.

Steve

"did the earth move for you, too?"

I personally see flyers as invitations rather than as a promotional 
tool.  Yes it's gets the word out that you are having a party but it 
needs to be inviting and represent the ideals of the promoter.  When 
people pass out flyers as if they were just paper I take them as just 
that... another peice of paper.  (Side note on this:  I was at a sunset 
and talking with some cool people and a girl came up who knew the people 
I was conversing with.  After intros and basic conversation she asked if 
i was interseted in going to "Beautyful People" and here's a flyer.  The 
flyer was simple b/w and effective but the presentation caught my 
attention more than anything.)

      Now that I'm starting to throw parties with friends here we have 
discussed this over many times.  I don't believe that if the flyer is 
multy colored or bigger than your pocket size the party is going to be 
bad.  Just represent your self with the art work you put on it, the 
colors, the design, the presentation, and the affermation that you want 
to put on a quality event with a bunch of great people.

For MASS we had our flyers done at MONOCHROME in LA.  We happen to know a 
few of the people that work there and through our connextions we got 
glossy, full color flyers for a great price.  However they f@#ked up our 
order (I would not recomend these guys in the future unless you to are 
getting a great deal) and we got our flyers a week late and many were 
printed bad.  For our next party we still will get our flyers from them 
only because they agreed to "give" tem to us for next to nothing because 
they messed up the first order.  

    I like simplisity, creativity, and remember they are there to invite 
a partier to your party because you have something to offer them to have 
a good time.

Rave flyer history:  I got a book for x-mas from Tower Records that went 
over briefly the hisory of flyers in England and had many examples of 
good flyer art work.  I can't remember the name but it's silver/grey and 
says raveclubpartyflyers or something like it on the front.

Hope that helps...


PLUR,

       Austin

Ergot has tremendously potent hallucinogenic effects, in addition to
causing severe nausea and fevers.  The sickness is called Saint Anthony's
fire.  Ergot poisoning precipitated the visions experienced by victims of
so called witchcraft in Salem in the 18th century.

Many innocent people lost their lives at the gallows as a result of the
misguided suspicions caused by this disease. 

weird stuff.

	jon
 




On Mon, 10 Mar 1997, Brian Denny wrote:

> 
> first of all, LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide-25) does _not_ occur in
> nature.  ergot contains a related compound, named simply lysergic acid (i
> don't remember whether it's also psychoactive), but it is not quite the
> same stuff.
> 
> 
> the term "designer drug" has been used in the medical community to denote
> drugs that were created by making slight alterations to existing substances
> -- MDMA from MDA, ALD from LSD, crack from cocaine-- usually with the
> intent to avoid legal ramifications, though any such loopholes are
> generally closed quickly. (1)
> 
> in common parlance i've come to understand it to mean drugs that are not
> (and have generally not been) produced by mainstream pharmaceutical
> companies and which are limited in their exposure, even within the drug
> culture.
> 
> thus, MDMA is a designer drug by the first definition, but not by the second.
> 
> LSD has never to my knowledge been considered a designer drug, because it
> was developed at a pharmaceutical company and used psychiatrically for
> years.
> 
> this information is based on a limited number of sources so if you have a
> reference which either clarifies or refutes what i've just said, please let
> me know.
> 
> -brian
> 
> 
> (1)     "Designer drugs, like designer clothes, are produced to sell.  They are
> created and marketed to a clientele of growing size that is looking for an ever
> more varied or specific experience in a recreational drug.  The designer
> drug is usually a variation on a previously controlled substance."
> 
> -Journal of the American Medical Association (found at:
> 
> http://hyperreal.com/drugs/misc/review.designer.drugs
> 
> ) -- a mainstream, anti-drug article.
> 
> 
>

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

WARNING:
This is very long and metaphysical
--------------------------------------------------


>This is a common mis-perception: the light does not become what we _want_
>it to be, it acts like _one or the other_ based on our perception.  The
>light beam won't turn into, say, a hippopotamus, just because we want it to
>-- or for any other reason we have yet discovered.  We can affect the
>outcome by our perception, but the array of possible outcomes is not
>unlimited.

How the light acts is a part of what it is.  Our minds require the light to
have so much energy at some particular point in time.  Reality is larger,
yes, a probability equation.
Our perception reveals different facets of a fundementally unknowable
universe.
And yet reality is also undefined by those measures of reality which connect
with a human being, until a human being looks at reality.  Does the tree make
any noise if it falls and there is no one to hear it?  Part of the definition
of noise is "that which can be heard."

I agree that what is "useful" is more interesting than what is "true."  What
is true, I will never know.

Is it irrelevant debating whether people are essentially good at heart or
not?  Does it make sense to question whether humanity is spiritual or not?
 Do we ask if there is a soul or not?  Maybe the question is unimportant

The question is what reality is most useful?  Which reality is healthiest?
 What belief system will create the world that we most want to live in?

I hear about the man who cured himself of cancer by watching endless funny
videos.  I think about the open-heart surgeries performed in China with
nothing but accupuncture.  Belief is fully half of medicine.  Sugar pills
work wonders.  (I wonder how many kids have gotten very real E highs from
very fake stuff.)

The mind is powerful and can produce amazing realities both through
perception and through action.  What reality is most useful?  What world do I
want to wake up to tomorrow?  I want to wake up to a world where I can make a
difference, where people care, where there's a reason for all things.  I want
to look at things and smile.  Filling up with positive energy makes the human
psyche run smoother and more powerfully.  This is my comprehension of the
spiritual.

Conceptions of God, spirituality, etc. become irrelevant.  I believe in them
and I don't.  All things are true and untrue.  Reality will always be larger
than I am and so I will believe and I will not believe.

Hmm.  The universe is large.  We are small.  We look at the sky and imagine
the vastness.  I look at the city of San Francisco from the hills and I see
lights that go on forever.

But I don't feel small.  I am so much a part of myself and so content to be
where I am that I feel large.

I feel I am that city because I love that city.  Yet my conception of myself
is that I am nothing because all my substance comes from outside of me.  All
my inspiration comes from a thousand places that aren't mine.  Yet I am
everything because all those things outside of me enter me, the air, food,
the love and the art.  They reside in me.  I love them.  And they exit once
again in a thousand pieces.

I let go of my ego-attachment to my own inspirations and ideas.  I let them
go to live or to die.  I feel most content when everything is a part of me
and I am a part of all things.

I don't feel guilty, because I love myself.  I don't feel proud because I own
nothing, not even my soul.  And yet my soul is everywhere and I own all
things that I love and I do own my soul.

So do I need to justify my own significance in the face of the vast emptiness
of the universe.  Do I need to believe in something spiritual, such as God,
to conquer that fear of being alone in the universe?

No.  It's the tao of opposites.  It's a koan.  And I am content with things
being large and small, true and untrue, fearful and loving, right and wrong.
 I know that God does not exist because I do not know or love God.  (And I
know of a reality where he does not exist.)  And yet I know that God exists
because I do love and know God.  (And I know of a reality where he does
exist.)


Peace,

 - Justin

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 11 02:45:20 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id CAA17055; Tue, 11 Mar 1997 02:45:20 -0800 (PST)

Hey friends,

I am an avid David Lynch freak and vidied his newest flick last night in
Orinda. It was really good, but definately a David Lynch movie. The two
people I went with thought it was pretty shitty, but I think you have to
be in the correct mind set for one of his movies (Eraserhead, Blue Velvet,
Wild at Heart..). It stared Patricia Arguette, Bill Pullman and Baldazar
Getty... it was trippy and really funny if you have a twisted sense of
humor like myself.

Definately worth seeing if you're interested in experiencing something
new.

just a little info on David lynch. They wanted him to direct Star Wars but
he declined because he was working on his first film, Eraserhead.

Who's going to see any of the Space Children shows this weekend? I'm not
sure which night I'm going. I think I'm going on Friday to see Union Jack.
$15 aint bad.

Wow, these business degrees really help when it comes to expenses:

Quite simple:

Van rental_ Approx. 50$/day (150$)

Gas (@ 1.35$/gal with 20 gall tank) 27$.
Refuled @ least four times (out to LA, from LA to the desert, back 
from the desert to SF and around the bay dropping off people) so now 
its looking around 108$.

So, yep I guess your looking @ 260$ -300$  (I'm covering what costs 
incurred after the initial 260).   The 13 people thang is a bit too 
much so I'm looking to see if I can get a van for maybe 40$ or less 
(but even that would bring the people limit only to 11 or 12)...


--_Adam (Anakin)

I've been collecting flyers since early 1994 (even a few from 93) for the 
great artwork and memorbelia purposes. I think to myself how precious 
they will be to me 20 years down the road when I look back to my rave 
days in the 90s.  Hell, I hope to STILL be raving in some form 20 years 
from now!  On some flyers of the parties I actually attend, I attatch a 
note to it describing my evening, so it is like a rave diary of sorts. 

I don't use flyers for information like I used to.  I always use sfraves 
word of mouth to decide what rave I want to attend. 

love to all,
Amy

> From: Joe Rice
> Subject: SHJ/OTM
> 
> Checked out Springheel Jack at Bimbo's on Friday night after seeing Lost
> Highway, which may have skewed the whole experience for me. =) 

I just saw that move too, sure was a long movie, only liked the
ascending (assending?)  the stair case scene :) I do like the acting
style where you have to watch their lips for seemingly hours before
you get any sound.

> been to Bimbo's before - not the place I'd choose for a dance event, but
> very elegant venue nonetheless. Sort of a 50's jazz supper club vibe.
> Springheel Jack played some decent tracks - and I like their records quite
> a bit - but it didn't seem very live and there was no interaction with the
> audience. 

I hate it when they say "playing live" and they just stand around
bored with nothing to do but listen to themselves.

For you gear-heads out there, here's what equipment they used: 

Guy on left: ADAT,Yamaha 02R mixer. 
Guy on right: two turntables, DJ mixer, Roland DJ-70. 

The guy on the left ( sorry I don't know there names) just played
STEREO outputs of the ADAT through the 02R. He brought up effects on
the the tape output. THAT'S IT. You can't imagine how sick I felt
seeing an 02R used as soley an effects send! You'd think that with
such little to do he'd at least dance, smile, or at least scratch his
balls or something.

The guy on the right (stage right) spun records some and played some
ugly keyboard parts on the DJ-70 that didn't really seem to fit in.

I guess that's better then lip syncing, and more equipment would mean
more of those heavy voltage transformers, but people should know what
they're getting.

> It didn't help that club's sound system wasn't really up to
> reproducing jungle basslines and was overdriven for much of the show. 

I was trying to listen to that distortion carefully, and it seemed to
me that the group actually used alot of distored samples on their
tape. They had their own sub-woffers, and I thought the bass was
clean. I think this band is going for the crossover industrial/rock to
d&b market. They sound more like MeatBeatManifesto to me that
d&b. Most of their double speed beats were rock beats instead of funk
beats, which cramped my dancing style. By the way, the rec'd companies
are chopping at the bit at crossover bands like this.

> I was surprised at how crowded the show was, but it wasn't by any
> means an underground contingent - more what I'd think of as the
> Guardian crowd. I wonder if this was a preview of what's to come
> with weekly listings in the SF Weekly...

There was an acticle in Pulse, the Tower records advertisment as
well. The crowd at Bimbo's always looks like the FM radio free pass
crowd to me. I like the appearence of the club alot, the napkins are
great, reminds me of my yacht club days, but the light's up at 1:30
deal really gets my goat. I really liked DJ Noel's short set after the
show better then SHJ. Wished I could'a danced a few more hours :)

=Darrel.
darrele@netcom.com

> From: Jondabomb@aol.com
> Date: Mon, 10 Mar 1997 16:16:30 -0500 (EST)
> Subject: Re: marketing to ravers? :)
> 
> Did you see the new DOW commercial for their pots and pans... they play...
> get this... JUNGLE!!!! And its a funky track too!!! What is this world coming
> too! ;)
> Jonathan
> 
> Hope everyone is having a killer monday
> 

I don't think this is marketing to ravers. I think this is happening
because musicians who do sound for commercials and other mainstream
stuff are getting into electronic music. Instead of it being the
advertising agency selling techno/jungle with their campain package,
they hire a musician to do the sound, that person is doing
techno/jungle on other projects, and so more easily does techno/jungle
on this commercial as well. I'll bet the advertising agency doesn't
know what the hell kinda music it is. They just think it sounds new.

=Darrel
darrele@netcom.com

 i wasn't sure whether to mail this to the list or not since it started out
as a personal reply but turned into a message to everyone at the end. i
don't know how much of your conversations are conducted in private. if i
start getting on people's nerves let me know. 

>Hello Ben and Iris, so you're from M.K., the concrete city. My good friend
>Eddie Richards resides there. My name is Eric and I live in Oakland, across
>the bay from SF. I'm a DJ/promoter/producer and I'll be hosting "B E L I E V
>E" on May 31st, in SF. So far, we've confirmed Eddie Richards and Pascal
>(Vancouver, Canada - hard progressive trance). You're welcome to party with
>us if you're in town then. Give me you number in Milton Keynes and I'll call
>you! =) MODA
>
>

thanks for the quick reply
yes, i believe be will be in town by then
what do you mean you'll call us. telephone? from america? i thought the idea
of email was to cut down the phone bill. why would anybody want to use a
phone these days? hey but if you have that much money to spare, it would be
great to talk to you.
our number is 01908-227143
but from the states it's: 011-44-1908-227143  (i think)
and after the 15th of april we're more likely to be at this number: 313669

have you been to MK? i guess you know about the concrete cows...    MK had
its 30th birthday a few weeks ago. i hate it and i love it and i'm terribly
bored with it. i always liked the layout. very american (i spent the best
year of my life in minneapolis and feel quite nostalgic sometimes). it
failed terribly in regard to community builing, though. it had the highest
suicide rate in the country for a while. i have to get out of here.....aaaah!
i never made it out west during that whole year in mpls. and i always wanted
to see  snow in the desert in arizona (well, wrong season for that). and san
francisco is just one of the places you have to visit in your life. like
berlin when the wall was still up. evreybody who missed that...well...you
missed it! it was really cool.
 i've been really high on adrenalin for the last few days now (best drug of
all. like being in love. that's what the rave scene is all about.) and all
thanks to you sfravers.it all seems to be coming together now.  thanks to
everybody who's replied so far (have to check my mail again in a minute). it
would be great to meet some of you in person. we'll stay in contact. we'll
be reading the list.

iris

  I love them earth quakes to.. Sure they can be tragic. But I think it is
health for us little creatures to get shookin up once in awhile..

earth quake proof fasion..  Don't put a 50 pound speaker above your
computer for instance. Or like, don't sleep below a bed room that has a
water bed in it.

MMM Well I happen to be reading this for an essay in "dub mix- the mix 
eventually contained only the bare dance rythums and base line of the 
original recording.  "Sounds familliar?)

The Story so far I have (Which I will post more when I finish..) Is the 
advent of electronic equiptment like the sampler and multi track 
recording, and African drum beats influencing western music, starting 
from slavery time..... up to now.... and the dub 
mix, and hip hops "borrowing materials and remixing it" and all of that 
put together kind abecame what we see as techno.
 Nailvarnish

There actually was a drug (methylaminorex) going around under the name
Euphoria (often written, for no reason I can fathom, "U4eUH") for a while.
It had a brief vogue a couple of years ago, seems to have disappeared now.
Notorious for, supposedly, creating bad experiences in combination with
LSD.

On Mon, 10 Mar 1997, presumed wrote:

> on 03/10/97 9:33 PM John S. Lee wrote...

> purchase.
> 
>   Lets face it, lsd is not a designer drug.  Stop and think what the term 
> designer drug means.  (mdma is not one either).
>   (BTW, although acid costs money, it seems to be pretty cheap)
> 
> >People of color are less prone to try designer drugs.  The drugs of
> >choice in neighborhoods of color are alcohol , cigarettes, and pot (CDC
> >'95, '96).
> 
>   The two characteristics of drugs found in innercity/poor neighborhoods 
> seem to be they provide escape from the user's surroundings and/or they 
> are addictive.  The former explains why psychedelics (think set/setting) 
> aren't the hot drug of choice in poverty stricken areas.  The latter of 
> course does not make something more appealing to a user, but since the 
> 70's, the drug pusher has had as much to say about which chemicals a 
> person uses.  Alcohol and cigarettes, though legal, exemplify this as 
> well as crack can.
>

I just feel sorry for the non-Internet connected people in the rave
community that won't know better and may actually go.

For the entire diatribe, see the SFR 11/96 archive file at
http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/archives/sfr.9611

Here's a little tidbit to refresh your memory...

-w

Remember, the big Rave-Crash of 1997 is coming :-(

Date: Mon, 2 Dec 1996 09:48:31 -0800 (PST)
Mime-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: vontews@dnai.com (Peter Von Tews)
Subject: UBIQUITOUS too good to be true?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I've been reading all the postings on UBIQUITOUS and you know the good old
saying "if it's too good to be true, than it probably is" here is one
example where those one of those unwritten laws of life apply.

If you were a promoter, would you dish out $15,000 to throw a party for the
people? or would it be a scam to: 1/GET $$$ NOW or 2/GET $$$ LATER  , I
think it was both. You have to remember that money runs this world, and
even if you want to keep the "vibe" alive you will not give a crap about it
if you saw 2000 people in line with $20 bills in their hands. True there
are a lot of people in the scene who WILL keep the "vibe" going ,but
they're going to have to try very hard not to sell out, especially in the
next couple of years when MTV will be doing a live video shoot at Funky
Techno Tribe featuring DJ Dan/Bassbin twins.
It will happen eventually, If something is appealing to the young
generation,big companies will market,advertise,shrink-wrap and offer
mail-in rebates on it.

If you have been going to raves for a while, treasure the moments and  the
people you've met because you will be telling your kids about it, just like
our parents can tell us about the 60's. Any way or other, I think raves
have made our future generation better, more open-minded, understanding and
positive.

tell me what you think...I though about this
Pete

http://www.sharperview.com
smoke me@420

All,
	Sorry if this goes out twice. I've been having problems with my
mail.

Anywayz, I've this documentary about the history of music (I only recorded
the last and most important part). It showes an Afro-american male 
explaining how Electro started in the Black neighborhoods of Detroit.(I 
forget his name.) The people puchased cheap equipment but created anew 
style of music never heard before.(It was later explained that groups like Depeche heard this music and inquired this"Afro American"). I believe
this music later evolved with Disco to form what is now House (taken from
the famous club The Warehouse with resident DJ Frankie Knuckles. As the
documentary explaines, This is the basis for Techno as we know today.

				Vertigo

hi everybody, how are y'all doing? i'm writing to express many thanks for
all the birthday wishes!
i had a marvelous birthday yesterday.i got to play all day long. everyone
around me made it extra
special. my friends took me to the beach and we watched the sun set as we
sat on a huge rock covered with mussels while the tide splashed against
the rock. needless to say, it was delightful.
it was really windy and there were two women and a little girl sitting by
a fire and we asked them if we could stand by and get warmed up. they were
really nice.they had a dog and a pet rat (!)  it turns out that the little
girl will be 9 years old
tomorrow, so i decided to give her one of my bracelets as a gift. 
also a ladybug landed on me and when a ladybug lands on you, it's
considered good luck, so naturally, i was happy. also i saw two
butterflies that came to play with me. 
well, i've already written too much, so i will end. tank jou again.
spread your happiness and give a hug to at least ten people, if not more
today and everyday.
sugarkisses and hugs,
***stariana***

    S.F. Chronicle, Thursday, June 22, 1995, page A23.

On Tue, 11 Mar 1997, Darrel Etter wrote:
>
> > Did you see the new DOW commercial for their pots and pans... they play...
> > get this... JUNGLE!!!! And its a funky track too!!! What is this world coming
> > too! ;)
> > Jonathan
> 
> I don't think this is marketing to ravers. I think this is happening
> because musicians who do sound for commercials and other mainstream
> stuff are getting into electronic music. Instead of it being the
> advertising agency selling techno/jungle with their campain package,
> they hire a musician to do the sound, that person is doing
> techno/jungle on other projects, and so more easily does techno/jungle
> on this commercial as well. I'll bet the advertising agency doesn't
> know what the hell kinda music it is. They just think it sounds new.
> 
> =Darrel
> darrele@netcom.com

--
Hmm, never thought of it like that; interesting...  Although, I still bet
a lot of these techno-backgrounds in commercials are simply supposed to
sound slick and "futuristic" to a minimally-exposed "mainstream" public
(which I still do believe is ever slowly embracing the sounds of 
electronica).  Just from looking at trends in pop-styles (i.e. U2
exploring more synthesis and less "standard" band-styles, MTV's show
"Amp," etc.), I bet a lot of folks would naturally view the genres we
all know and love as "wave of the future" or something.  Look at the last
series of Micro$oft commercials; they're totally gunning for some kind of 
"cutting-edge" feel in their commercials, because they want their
customers to think that M$ is cutting-edge (ha ha!).  So they use
cutting-edge music.  Anyways, I do think that a lot of execs. do use
techno for just that reason...
(Constructive comments are welcomed, but please don't flame the hell
out of me, thanx) -plur-

Where does techno originate from?

This is almost a religious question. Translate: as many answers as there is
people.

First of all the word techno is already being used by Kraftwerk in one of
their songs way before techno (what we today see as techno was invented).

The usual story goes like this: Herbie Hancock and/or Grandmaster Flash
gave us RAP.
After RAP came House (here comes Detroit and Chicago). England got house
and turned it into ACID!!!
Acid evolved into what we know as techno in the UK ,Germany, the
Netherlands and Belgium.

So goes the standard story.
 
What do we forget? A lot. The EBM or Industrial as is/ was called
established itself already in the early 80s. The likes of Front242 etc.
certainly pushed towards techno as well as the usual Depeche Mode referral.
I always like to think that YMO had some influence as well. But then again
I could also say that bands like Trio let the way, at least in regards of
minimalism.

For me techno certainly is very European. And don't tell me different
before you have been to a Berlin Love Parade. 

Regards
Jan



----------

> Hmm, never thought of it like that; interesting...  Although, I still bet
> a lot of these techno-backgrounds in commercials are simply supposed to
> sound slick and "futuristic" to a minimally-exposed "mainstream" public
> (which I still do believe is ever slowly embracing the sounds of 
> electronica).  Just from looking at trends in pop-styles (i.e. U2
> exploring more synthesis and less "standard" band-styles, MTV's show
> "Amp," etc.), I bet a lot of folks would naturally view the genres we
> all know and love as "wave of the future" or something.  Look at the last
> series of Micro$oft commercials; they're totally gunning for some kind of 
> "cutting-edge" feel in their commercials, because they want their
> customers to think that M$ is cutting-edge (ha ha!).  So they use
> cutting-edge music.  Anyways, I do think that a lot of execs. do use
> techno for just that reason...

>Greets,
>     Kraftwerk is definately one of the pioneers, but we also shouldn't forget
>Tangerine Dream's music (from Germany also) from around 1974 to 1976.
>Actually, this stuff sounds more like today's trance than Kraftwerk sounds like
>today's techno.  If you want to be truly amazed, listen to the album "Phaedra"
>by TD, and keep in mind that it came out in 1974. It was one of the first
>albums to sequenced synthesizers alone for all the rhythm parts.  They tweak
>filters to create energy buildups and everything.  You would expect it to be
>cheezy, but in fact (or maybe opinion), if it were released today, techno
>freaks would still praise it.  Don't take this Tangerine Dream advertisement to
>mean that all their albums are good.  After '76 they got heavily into making
>film soundtracks, and started making some cheezy ass music.  Some may disagree,
>but the only albums I would recommend are "Phaedra", "Ricochet", and "Rubycon".
> Anyway,
>                                       Steve

TD is one of my all time favorites.....   I've got just about every album theye
ever released...

JD

I THOUGHT YOU ALL WOULD LIKE THIS!
> 
> 
> Life
> 
> Life isn't about keeping score.
> It's not about how many friends you have
> Or how accepted you are.
> Not about if you have plans this weekend or if you're alone.
> It isn't about who you're dating, who you used to date, how many people
> you've dated, or if you haven't been with anyone at all.
> It isn't about who you have kissed,
> It's not about sex.
> It isn't about who your family is or how much money they have
> Or what kind of car you drive.
> Or where you are sent to school.
> It's not about how beautiful or ugly you are.
> Or what clothes you wear, what shoes you have on, or what kind of music you
> listen to.
> It's not about if your hair is blonde, red, black, or brown
> Or if your skin is too light or too dark.
> Not about what grades you get, how smart you are, how smart everybody else
> thinks you are, or how smart standardized tests say you are.
> It's not about what clubs you're in or how good you are at "your" sport.
> It's not about representing your whole being on a piece of paper and seeing
> who will "accept the written you."
> 
> 
> LIFE JUST ISN'T.
> 
> But, life is about who you love and who you hurt.
> It's about who you make happy or unhappy purposefully.
> It's about keeping or betraying trust.
> It's about friendship, used as a sanctity or a weapon.
> It's about what you say and mean, maybe hurtful, maybe heartening.
> About starting rumors and contributing to petty gossip.
> It's about what judgments you pass and why.  And who your judgments are
> spread to.
> It's about who you've ignored with full control and intention.
> It's about jealousy, fear, ignorance, and revenge.
> It's about carrying inner hate and love, letting it grow, and spreading it.
> But most of all, it's about using your life to touch or poison other
> people's hearts in such a way that could have never occurred alone.
> Only you choose the way those hearts are affected, and those choices are
> what life's all about.
> 
> *~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*
>        No one should drive a hard bargin with an artist
>                        ~~Ludwig van Beethoven
> 
> 
> *~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*~~*
>       When life gives you lemons, make lemonade
>                        ~~Johnny Fitzgerald Le
> 
> 
> This is not your ordinary chain letter.  Depending on how many people you
> send this to, your life will change dramatically! If you send this to:
> 
>       0-people:  Something terrible will happen such as losing a best
> friend.
>       1-5 people:  You will have 1 good day.
>       6-10 people:  You will have a good week, and the person you like will
> ask you out.
>       11-15 people:  You will have a good month, and a great surprise
> every day.
>       16 & up:  You will have a successful life and all of your dreams will
> come true!

>       SEND THIS TO EVERYONE YOU KNOW!!

Take I-80 East.  Take University Avenue Exit and go East for approximately
2 miles.  

At Shattuck Avenue (there will be a McDonald's to your left) take a right.
Go approximately 4 blocks (maybe 2 blocks past Bart) and Pasand Lounge
will be on the West side of Shattuck right at the corner of Shattuck and
some other street.  I think it is Bancroft, but I can't quite remember.
If you reach Shattuck and Durant, you've gone TOO far, though.  I'm
sure it is right next to the United Artists theater, so you can't miss it.

DEBORAH WATSON-GRAFF wrote:
> 
>         well, I've finally decided to post to sfraves, after reading for a week or so, a question is burning in my gut that mus be answered: What is the precise difference between Jungle and Drum and Bass? and for that matter Hardstep and Techstep? I've seen them all used interchangeably at one time or another.
> 
>         BTW, my name's Kevin, I'm from Monterey, and have been doing that Cloud Factory thing for the past couple of years, I hope to meet some of you this weekend at "Condensation". It should GO OFF!


Hi Kevin...

The thing about these labels is that they're all kinda arbitrary. But
here it goes:

Jungle=Drum'n Bass -

Some people say drum'nbass b/c jungle
sounds 	                            		 	      	commercial...for most
dj's I know, there's no difference. Some people say drum'n bass is a
more cut-up sound...

Cut-up :

 Drums are never consistent. Always broken up. Characteristic of older
jungle and 'classic' raga jungle.

Hardstep:

Aggressive bass lines....bouncy...more minimal drums.

Techstep: 

Distorted bass lines and drums. more atmospheric and scary. Industrial
sounds.

----------------

Hope this helps!

-peace-

alex

Brian Denny wrote:
SNIP>>
> LSD has never to my knowledge been considered a designer drug, because it
> was developed at a pharmaceutical company and used psychiatrically for
> years.
> 
> this information is based on a limited number of sources so if you have a
> reference which either clarifies or refutes what i've just said, please let

Brian:
    Extacy, was first developed as an appitite suppresant. Later it   
was used by psychitrists and psycologists to administer to patients 
during treatment .  It enabled people to be more open, relaxed and
talkative. Also patients were more prone to being honest and 
unrestrained about what they felt. 

LSD on the other hand was tested on people, and as far as I know was 
originally developed by some renegade scientists. Beyond testing its 
psycological-effects ON people, I dont think it was used in any kind 
of treatment, although I think I vagley recall hearing something about 
doctors treating schzophrenia with it. 

Anyone know for sure??

                           Jen Susser


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 11 19:42:00 1997

Received: from [207.33.94.173] (oak4-173.value.net [207.33.94.173]) by value.net (8.8.4/8.7.3) with SMTP id TAA06468; Tue, 11 Mar 1997 19:41:41 -0800 (PST)

Mime-Version: 1.0

X-mailer: Eudora Pro 2.1.3
Date: Tue, 11 Mar 1997 19:45:09 -0800
To: sean murray <renegade@linex.com>
From: bri@value.net (Brian Denny)
Subject: the development of lsd
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>LSD on the other hand was tested on people, and as far as I know was
>originally developed by some renegade scientists. Beyond testing its
>psycological-effects ON people, I dont think it was used in any kind
>of treatment, although I think I vagley recall hearing something about
>doctors treating schzophrenia with it.

LSD was NOT developed by renegade scientists.  it was first created in 1938
by Albert Hoffman at Sandoz Pharmaceutical as part of a series of
experiments involving derivatives of Lysergic Acid... he was looking for
something physical, not psychological, and LSD-25 apparently didn't (in the
initial experiments on rats) fit the bill and was put aside.   some years
later he absorbed a tiny bit of it by accident, and got just the slightest
effect.  he guessed it was LSD-25 that had made him feel strangely, and
decided to do a self-experiment.  he took 1/4 of a milligram (250ug), a
dose which at the time was as low as the lowest active dose of any known
drug.  if i'm not mistaken that's about 2.5 hits of decent acid by today's
standards.  never having heard of or imagined psychedelic effects before,
he had a pretty scary trip.   but he was aware that the drug had
psychiatric potential, and soon the company he worked for was marketing
it---

from the data sheet accompanying product:
(see also Physician's Desk Reference from mid-60's)

                      Delysid (LSD 25)

           D-lysergic acid diethylamide tartrate

        Sugar-coated tablets containing 0.025 mg. (25 ug.)

        Ampoules of 1 ml. containing 0.1  mg.  (100  ug.)  for  oral
administration.

     The solution may also be injected  s.c.  or  i.v.   The
effect  is  identical  with  that of oral administration but
sets in more rapidly.

                         PROPERTIES

     The administration  of  very  small  doses  of  Delysid
(1/2-2  ug./kg.  body  weight) results in transitory distur-
bances of affect, hallucinations, depersonalization,  reliv-
ing  of  repressed memories, and mild neuro-vegetative symp-
toms.  The effect sets in after 30 to 90  minutes  and  gen-
erally  lasts  5 to 12 hours.  However, intermittent distur-
bances of affect may occasionally persist for several days.

                  METHOD OF ADMINISTRATION

     For oral administration the contents of  1  ampoule  of
Delysid  are  diluted with distilled water, a 1% solution of
tartaric acid or halogen-free tap water.

     The absorption of the solution is somewhat  more  rapid
and more constant that that of the tablets.

     Ampoules which have not been opened,  which  have  been
protected  against  light  and  stored  in  a cool place are
stable for an unlimited period.  Ampoules  which  have  been
opened or diluted solutions retain their effectiveness for 1
to 2 days, if stored in a refrigerator.

                   INDICATIONS AND DOSAGE

a)   Analytical  psychotherapy,   to   elicit   release   of
     repressed  material and provide mental relaxation, par-
     ticularly in anxiety states and obsessional neuroses.
     The initial dose is 25 ug. (1/4  of  an  ampoule  or  1
     tablet).   This  dose is increased at each treatment by
     25 ug. until the optimum dose (usually between 50  and
     200  ug.) is found.  The individual treatments are best
     given at intervals of one week.

b)   Experimental studies on the nature  of  psychoses:   By
     taking  Delysid  himself,  the  psychiatrist is able to
     gain an insight in the world of ideas and sensations of
     mental  patients.   Delysid can also be used to induced
     model psychoses of short duration in  normal  subjects,
     this facilitating studies on the pathogenesis of mental
     disease.

     In normal subjects, doses of 25 to 75 ug. are generally
     sufficient  to produce a hallucinatory psychosis (on an
     average 1 ug./kg. body weight).  In  certain  forms  of
     psychosis  and  in chronic alcoholism, higher doses are
     necessary (2 to 4 ug./kg. body weight).

                        PRECAUTIONS

     Pathological mental conditions may  be  intensified  by
Delysid.  Particular caution is necessary in subjects with a
suicidal tendency and  in  those  cases  where  a  psychotic
development appears imminent.  The psycho-affective lability
and the tendency to commit impulsive acts  may  occasionally
last for some days.

     Delysid should only be administered under strict  medi-
cal supervision.  The supervision should not be discontinued
until the effects of the drug have completely worn off.

                          ANTIDOTE

     The mental effects of Delysid can be  rapidly  reversed
by the i.m.  administration of 50 mg. chlorpromazine.

              Literature available on request.

              SANDOZ LTD., BASLE, SWITZERLAND

9792*-Z1540 e.-sp./d.-fr.
Printed in Switzerland.


sources:

1.      LSD FAQ:
        http://hyperreal.com/drugs/psychedelics/lsd/FAQ-LSD-New

2.      _LSD, My Problem Child_, by Albert Hofmann
        http://www.nepenthes.com/Drugs/LSD/ProbChild/


beware of the FAQ, though-- it does contain some misinformation.  "My
Problem Child" is an excellent look at the history, benefits, and problems
of LSD through the eyes of its creator (who viewed it as a wonderful
psychotherapeutic substance and was quite disheartened that widespread
(ab)use of the drug led to its being made illegal).


Love,

brian

> of treatment, although I think I vagley recall hearing something about 
> doctors treating schzophrenia with it. 
> 
> Anyone know for sure??
> 
>                       ~ Increase Your Serenity~
>                            Jen Susser

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 11 19:44:26 1997

Received: from linux.announce.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id TAA10708; Tue, 11 Mar 1997 19:44:23 -0800 (PST)
Received: from ala-ca32-09.ix.netcom.com (ala-ca32-09.ix.netcom.com [199.35.209.73]) by linux.announce.com (8.7.6/8.6.9) with SMTP id WAA02193 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 11 Mar 1997 22:46:18 -0500

Message-Id: <199703120346.WAA02193@linux.announce.com>
