Hey beloved family!!!! *HUGZ*

yep, more n more commercialization, i just ran across this article on
electronic music in *entertainment weekly* magazine. if u want the actual
article, its in issue # 370, dated march 14, 1997 with ralph fiennes and
kristin scott thomas on the cover. in the lower right hand corner, it says
"rave on , a consumer's guide to the new music revolution" 

following is the article bcuz i know many of ya would like to read it right
at this moment, so i'll satiate that want =) : here it is:


ROCK IS DEAD , long live ...?

With grunge on life support and sales flatlining, the music biz is looking
to spark a rebirth with electronica. But can you dance to it? by chris willman

In an editing studio in midtown manhattan, Todd Mueller is programming the
future, and its not a pretty sight. Mueller, the producer of MTV's weekly
electronic music show, Amp, is trying to edit down the video for the band
Juno Reactor's "Feel the Universe." The music is the common throbbing
computer pulse of techno, and, like many videos of the genre, this one
doesn't bother picturing the performers; instead, it's footage of Ku Klux
Klan rallies, flowers, sunsets, and some sort of Japanese royal coronation.
It all looks like it's meant to signify a sense of information overload, if
not somesort of systems crash.

Not that the frantic jumble of sound and vision in the Juno Reactor clip is
necessarily intended as ominous. Here, in this cultish pocket of the
pop-music world, future shock carries uniformly cheerful connotations.
"Techno embraces technology and encourages the fusion of man and machine,"
says Mueller, 28, whose boyish visage, glasses , and beanie make him look
like Jon Cryer after a particularly long rave. "It says 'Don't be a
Luddite!" That should be our bumper sticker. We're at the dawn of the 21st
century; it's logical that technology would be part of everyone's mindset."

Suddenly, it's an especially large part of the collective mind-set of the
music biz, which could stand a movement to be bullish about. The bloom is
certainly off the alternative-rock rose that Nirvana pollinated in 1991. "To
some extent, that revolution has become everything it set out to cure," says
Reprise Records president Howie Klein. "What we have now is alternative
corporate rock, practically." Points out Mercury president Danny Goldberg,
"The energy that emanated from Seattle in the late '80s, early '90s is
obviously a five-year-old-energy--and in rock & roll, five years is a
generation." Executives humbled by 1996's flat sales and youthful yawns are
eager to spot any popular uprising that might replace the increasingly outre
strains of guitar grunge and jangle angst. The ska,alt-country,lounge,and
Latin rock scenes all hold promise but have apparent ceilings on their appeal.

Will the industry [look to] techno for an answer?

The answer seems to be a very qualified yes. The movement's leading British
band, Prodigy, is widely expected to establish a commercial beachhead here
with the May 20 release of their first album since Madonna's Maverick label
signed them to a rumored $5 million contract. Big heat surrounds the
Chemical Brothers' April 8 release , Dig Your Own Hole, as well. And even if
techno in its purest form never does go mainstream, some of the remaining
superstars of alt-rock -- notably , U2 and the Smashing Pumpkins -- are
already busy co-opting the stylistic tenets of electronic pop and beating
their Stratocaster swords into digital plowshares. Roll over, Leo Fender,
and tell Yngwie Malmsteen the news: In one form or another, "electronica" is
coming.

Most of the major labels have either made distribution deals with
electronically oriented indie companies or started signing techno acts
directly. Geffen records, for one, has done both. "I was just in England,"
says label president Bill Bennett, "where they think we're nuts: ' Oh,
you're just discovering techno music?' I think its gonna be big here."
Geffen was one of several companies that got into a bidding war late last
year for Prodigy. But Bennett acknowledges that the payoff may not be as
quick in the U.S. as it has been in Europe: "I don't know is it's gonna be
defined by radio like most pop music is-certainly not in its early stages.
The commercial possibilities at some time will catch up to the talent, so
you're kind of investing in the future."

For David Bowie, it's all about the here and now. "There's a freneticism
that I find very pertinent to the way we live in the late 20th century. It
just seems to be the dialogue that is valuable,"says Bowie, who borrows
liberally from jungle's rhythmic vocabulary on his new Earthling. It's a
mutual admiration society, of course: "My ear has always been attuned to
that brand of chaos," he notes, and the daring electronic albums he and
Brian Eno made in the '70s indelibly influenced waves of young tech-heads.
"Everybody knew something was going to come out of Britain, but it's almost
like the Blur/Pulp/Oasis thing was kind of treading water. The real valuable
music is coming from dance bands.

Not everyone is  quite so eager to speed toward the millenium, if this is
the soundtrack For years mainstream rock fans have watched with some
suspicion as bin cards heralding exotic subgenres like "drum-and-bass" ,
"illbient", and "trance" popped up in more progressive record outlets. Any
threat seemed remote; these were typically import compilations spotlighting
no name British dance acts, relegated to lesser, scarier corners of the
store. But the years of containment are coming to an end.

Leading the charge into the mainstream, U2 jettisoned their old "three
chords and the truth" credo for half a dozen samples and a sense of cheek in
key tracks-like the hit "Discotheque"-on their just released Pop album. The
Pumpkins are at work on an electronically tempered album, a preview of which
might be found in the drum-machine-fueled ballad Billy Corgan contributed to
the new Lost Highway soundtrack. Even guitar god Eric Clapton has recorded
an electronic album (Retail Therapy) under the pseudonym x-sample, as a
member of the group T.D.F. Several upcoming film soundtracks are thick with
the stuff, starting with such mainstream Hollywood fare as The Saint.
Clearly, all this electro-juice isn't just for breakbeat anymore.

Backlash, anyone? Before these brave new sounds have even filtered down to
most Americans, "Techno sucks" is becoming a counter-mantra. Isn't ambient
really just elevator music for cybergeeks? Isn't rave-readier stuff disco
all over agin? Where are the songs? Faceless dance music, computer
sequencers,prog-rock flourishes, all-powerful production geniuses...aren't
these the elements God sent punk to save us from?

Aw, contraire, say the true believers: Techno is the new punk, if its
do-it-yourself ethos counts as a benchmark. The shrinking cost of
drum-machine and sampler technology is a prime factor in the appeal to the
DIY underground-along with the fact that today's pierced collegiates, unlike
their safety pinned predecessors, were weaned on PCs. "I'm in my 40s, and I
hated dance music growing up," says Bennett, "but I don't equate this with
dance music. You know what it is? Any 19-year-old can be a producer now, as
opposed to Giorgio Moroder, and that's what excites me."

It's every man a king on the dance floor as well as in the studio. "At a
rave , as opposed to a concert, it's very empowering. The energy is
dispersed over the whole crowd," says Jason Bentley, a movement maven who
DJs on L.A.'s top alternative and public radio stations as well as handling
A&R for Island's Quango label. "It's democratic; it isn't like you're
sitting watching a pop star. You are empowered to involve yourself with the
music, or walk around or talk-it isn't focused on the stage."

Richard James, the one man band who bills himself as the Aphex Twin, makes
an almost perverse point of shrouding himself in a nearly opaque DJ booth on
stage. "I think one of the advantages to electronic music is that it's
faceless-the personality doesn't get in the way," he says. "There've been
songs I liked for years; then I see who did them and say 'Look at that
prat', and its spoiled it for me."

The lack of celebrity focus represents a fundamental paradigm shift for pop
fans. But if you're looking to fix your sights on an electronic star, check
out Prodigy. After their last album, in 1995, the formerly faceless group
hired Keith Flint, a spiky haired frontman who is what you either love or
hate about the band's "Firestarter" video -eschewed by MTV's Amp programmers
as too "pop" for their hip late-night viewers, but already among the first
real techno videos in prime-time Buzz Bin rotation. Unlike most electronic
bands, they use live guitars and even -God forbid- tour.

"It's about time," says an unlikely fan, Beck, enthusing over Prodigy's
burgeoning Stateside presence. "I've been watching them in Europe for a
while and wondering when the kids here would figure that out, because once
they do it'll be all over. We played festivals with Prodigy in Europe and
saw 50,000 kids going insane. The spirit of their music isn't
self-glorifying, really-it's a release thing for people, catharsis without
the cliche. They're harnessing the same energy Jerry LEe Lewis harnessed in
the '50s-and there's a sense of humor with it. I think it's kool; I condone."

Beck himself hardly counts as a techno-cian. But one of the godfathers of
the genre,Moby,pointedly prefers Beck's revolutionary brand of
electronically enhanced hip-hop-rock over the massive wave of dance music he
helped inspire.

"All the journalists who are getting excited about this 'electronica'
revolution, I feel they missed the boat," sniffs Moby, who's done his small
part to buck the tide by going back to guitars on his latest album, Animal
Rights. "The stuff that's going on now is a real pale imitation of what was
happening five years ago. It would be like people declaring a punk rock
revolution in 1985." The future, Moby claims, is in hybrids:" There are
great electronic records and great rock records. The thing that interests me
is people combining the two-Beck being a good example, someone who basically
made an electronic record but sang on top of it."

Behind Beck's cut-and-paste pop are producers du jour the Dust Brothers, two
guys from Silverlake, Calif., who made computers in rock & roll cool with
the Beastie Boys' Paul's Boutique in 1989 and cooler still with last year's
most acclaimed album, Beck's Odelay. The key difference between techno and
what these new Mac daddies pull off is that their work is willfully
backward-looking.

"We try and stay away from drum machines," emphasizes Dust Brother Mike
Simpson, who says the approach he and his partner, John King, take to
computer sampling is closer to Trent Reznor's neo-industrial loops than to
the new dance acts. Their rubber-soul sonic collages typically rely on drums
sampled from '70s R&B records and early '80s rap singles, a funky,
repetitive bed for all sorts of live effects up top. "I kind of feel like
we've just been imitating the Beatles the whole time, " says Simpson.
"Everything we do sounds like it could have been on Sgt. Pepper."

No wonder that no less pre-electronica an act than the Rolling Stones have
enlisted the Dusties to produce several tracks for their next album. "The
first demo that Mick played us sounded like we had already produced it,"
Simpson says. "He did do his homework." In other words, yes, the Stones will
be using some computer-sampled rhythms. Be afraid, Charlie Watts, be very
afraid.

Those of us who aren't drummers have little to fear from the electronica
revolution- or so we're assured. The movement shouldn't divide rock
enthusiasts into hostile camps, insists the Chemical Brothers' Ed Simons.
"It's not pretty music we make; it's quite rough and abrasive," he says. "In
that way, it is kind of dance music for rock fans. If you buy one of our
records, it doesn't mean you have to go and burn all your Offspring CDs."
Maybe, in fact, that's where the premillenial party lies: moshers mixing it
up with the raving mad.

 Jen Susse said:
>LSD on the other hand was tested on people, and as far as I know was 
>originally developed by some renegade scientists. Beyond testing its 
>psycological-effects ON people, I dont think it was used in any kind 
>of treatment, 
************

In Baltimore in the 1970's (?) LSD was used successfully to treat
alcoholism, by some maverick docs.   Patients were administered heavy doses,
and were guided by their shrinks to examine their lives and locate the
sources of their unhappiness.   

When I was living in BaltiBore, I remember reading an article about one of
the recovered alcoholics, who described that after tapping into the source
of his addiction, he completely  lost the desire/need to drink. The
experiments were definitely kind of renegade, they weren't very widespread,
but I believe they had a lot of support, especially from the people who's
lives were changed by their experience on the drug.

~b))m

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: designer drugs
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

If your are interested in MDMA and its cousins just point your browser to
newsgroups. Have it search for MDMA and any other alphabet cocktail. There
are newsgroups and lists for alt.drugs.rec (etc.). Lots of interesting stuff!

> Jen Susse said:
>>LSD on the other hand was tested on people, and as far as I know was
>>originally developed by some renegade scientists. Beyond testing its
>>psycological-effects ON people, I dont think it was used in any kind
>>of treatment,


In December 1985, a group of psychotherapists in Switzerland obtained
permission to use psychoactive drugs in their work including MDMA, LSD,
Mescaline and psilocybin. They formed The Swiss Medical Society for
Psycholytic Therapy(95), and besides treating patients with these drugs,
members take one of the drugs together at twice yearly meetings.


[http://squishy.com/drugs/e4x/e4x.ch.09.html]


does anyone know what the _current_ state of legality of LSD and MDMA _for
clinical use_ is in switzerland and other european countries?

-brian

RAVE NEW WORLD

by David Browne

Like some DNA experiment gone wondrously wrong. pop in the 90s never stops
splitting an subdividing. Nowhere is that more evident-and perplexing- than
in the world of techno, electronica,electro, or whatever term you prefer. If
you think all techno sounds the same, you don't know Spring Heel Jack (more
on the later) - or any of the seemingly endless one-man -electro
bands,DJs,producers, and mixers that make up this polymorphous scene. The
differences between the styles like drum-and-bass and jungle are like the
differences between computer companies themselves: They're subtle, sometimes
extremely so, but apparent nonetheless.

The following guide is meant to help newcomers carve out their own path in
the electronica jungle (more on that style later). A year from now, the
genres below may have mutated into all-new ones, but techno wouldn't have it
any other way.

*TECHNO*
If techno could be personified, it would be Chuck Berry. Often used to
describe the entire spectrum of modern electronic music, techno is also the
name for the music's purest, most basic style. Along with the soulful, more
R&B-rooted house music, it took shape in the late '80s, tapping into the
'70s disco and new wave. Techno's air-duct-blast synthesizer snorts, smapled
voices, and shuffle-puck beats per minute remain the basic building blocks
of the electronic music scene of the '90s. For all its thumping, pulsating,
knob-twirling sonics, though, techno is the hookiest style of electronica.
You may not be able to hum the Chemical Brothers' "Setting Sun", Utah
Saint's "Something Good", Prodigy's "Firestarter," or Underworld's "Born
Slippy" - to name a few of the genre's greatest hits- but it's impossible to
deny their furious, techno-prisoners allure.
-Classic Rock Equivalent-:Kraftwerk trapped in a video game.
-Plugging In-:Techno has come so far that early compilations now feel dated
and one-dimensional. A few,however, are worth seeking out. *Only for the
Headstrong:The ultimate rave compilation (FFRR,1992) and *Futurhythms
(Medicine,1993) variously feature tracks by groundbreakers like Moby,
Prodigy, and Orbital. Beginners can start with the collections *Wipeout XL
*Astralwerks/Caroline,1996) and *Plastic Compilation Volume 1 (Nettwerk,
1997). (The latter features remixes of Garbage and Sarah McLachlan alongside
the Chemical Brothers and Underworld.) Another sampler for novices, *Special
Brew (Payday/FFRR,1996), includes brain-bending sonic overhauls of U2,
Bjork, and Paul Weller.

Now that you've planted one foot in the rave, proceed to individual artists'
records. *Utah Saints (London, 1992), the eponymous debut of that British
duo, is essential, as is Moby's *Everything is Wrong (Elektra, 1995), which
takes punk and dance under its electronica wing. Further proof of techno's
progress can be heard on the Chemical Brother's swirling debut *Exit Planet
Dust (Astralwerks/Caroline, 1995), and Underworld's art-rock-style *Second
Toughest in the Infants (Wax Trax!/TVT, 1996).
-Best Listening Environment-:Anywhere you're in motion-rave,dance club,or
health club. Despite techno mythology, mind-expanding substances not required.

*JUNGLE*
The breakneck pace of techno soon grew repetitive, so a new group of
artists, mixers, and entreprenuers decided to slip in reggae bass lines,
Jamaican patois, disco divas-anything to spice up what can be, at worst,
numbingly monotonous thumpings. Originally called breakbeat, jungle can be
brassier than hardcore, yet retains the spatial aloofness of electronic
music-call it spiritual disco.
-Classic Rock Equivalent-:Donna Summer goes shopping for crystals.
-Plugging In-:The compilations *The History of Our World Part One (Profile,
1994) , *Counterforce (FFRR, 1995) , and to a less interesting degree,
*Jungle: The Sound of the Underground (Sour/Colombia, 1996) showcase the
ways in which jungle brings out techno's human side. (History's Oaysis sound
nothing like that Oasis) Goldie, Britain's mixer about town, was one of
jungle's first stars, and the rapturous acid-disco title suite on his 1995
album, Timeless (FFRR) is a prime example of the form.
-Best Listening Environment-: At the office, while you're slaving away at
the computer- you'll work and tap your toes simultaneously.

*AMBIENT*
Everyone, even ravers, needs to chill. In the '70s, producer-musician-U2
cohort Brian Eno rocked the Muzak with *Music for Airports, but a new
generation of Brits took his disquieting sounds to new levels of lushness
and intricacy. Almost always instrumental, ambient is spacey and ethereal,
the only techno subgenre not for the dance floor. But there's nothing New
Age about it: Its boilings and sonic splats and burps show that computers
can be cranky too.
-Classic Rock Equivalent-:Pink Floyd circa Ummagumma-but double the bong hits.
-Plugging In-:Moby's *Ambient (Instinct, 1993) , Orbital's *In Sides
(FFRR,1996), and the Orb's *U.F.Orb (Big Life/Mercury, 1992) are musical hot
tubs, while ambient auteur Richard James, who records as the Aphex Twin,
tosses cheeky elements into the mix on *Selected Ambient Works 85-92
(R&S,1992) and *Richard D.James Album (Sire, 1997). Lying somewhere between
the two extremes, The Future Sound of London albums like *Dead Cities
(Astralwerks/Caroline, 1996) dot their aural landscapes with heavenly choirs
and spaghetti-Western guitars. 
-Best Listening Environment-: The bath is drawn, the candles are lit, and
you're alone.

*AMBIENT DUB*
Take ambient, add industrial-strength reggae bass lines, mix, and serve. 
-Classic Rock Equivalent-:Bob Marley, with no vocals and triple the bong hits. 
-Plugging In-: *Marco Dub Infection Volume One (Gyroscope/Caroline) features
sonic manipulators like Tricky, Spring Heel Jack , and the Golden Palominos.
Illbient, a fledging offshoot genre pioneered by DJ Spooky, is even more
heavy-lidded; check out the anthology *Incursions in Illbient (Asphodel, 1996).
-Best Listening Environment-:An opium den, with or without the opium.

*DRUM and BASS*
In simplest terms, drum-and-bass is ambient with a more sensual beat. A
close sister of jungle, it's been popularized in the U.K. by producer-mixers
like LTJ Bukem. As its names implies, drum-and-bass is stripped down and
occasionally features vocals. The beats are often hard shuffles, like
sandpaper scratches, but the synthesizers that cast a glaze over the
melodies create a warm bath of sound-music for looking to the heavens but
remaining physically grounded. (Well, most of the time: Chameleon's "Links"
samples Matthew Broderick in Ferris Beuller's Day Off.) Its soft, burbling
rhythms are also adaptable to pop melodies, as proved by recent records by
Everything but the Girl and David Bowie.
-Classic Rock Equivalent-:Brian Eno and Robert Fripp get a little funky.
-Plugging In-: Two compilations, *Logical Progression (FFRR,1996) and
*History Part 2 : The Rough and the Smooth (Sm;)e, 1996), collect sonic
explorers like Bukem (yes, nicknamed after the Hawaii Five-O catchphrase)
and Alex Reece. To hear the genre creep into the mainstream, try Everything
But the Girl's Walking Wounded and the EP Everything But the Girl vs.
Drum'n'Bass (both Atlantic, 1996).
-Best Listening Environment-:On the sofa, after a long day's work.

*TRIP HOP*
Even music rooted in technology can be emotive. Known early as the Bristol
sound in honor of the British city where it began, trip-hop isn't quite as
trippy or rap oriented as its name implies. The clip-clop beats sway, but un
a laid back way; the slinky, groggy singing is covered in a blanket of
numbed audio guaze. Cool, restrained, and cautious, it's soul for the
chill-out room.
-Classic Rock Equivalent-: Sly and the Family Stone's *There's a Riot Goin'
On, but in a better mood.
-Plugging In-:Start with the sound collective Massive Attack's *Blue Lines
(Virgin, 1991), one of the most influential records of the decade. Toss in
*Maxinquaye (Island, 1995) , the first and best album by the roguish Tricky,
and Portishead's *Dummy (Go!Discs/London, 1994). Next up: the trip-pop of
the Icelandic band Gus Gus and their debut, *Polydistortion (4AD/Warner
Bros. , out April 8), and a new Portishead album due this fall.
-Best Listening Environment-: Take it along during a casual stroll on a warm
spring or summer day.

*SLICE and DICE*
White men can't jump, but they can splice. Pioneered by the Beastie Boys on
their influential 1989 album *Paul's Boutique (the Sgt Pepper of its time),
this melding of rap,pop, and electronica doesn't officially have a name. But
its sensibility- the Cuisinart of hip-hop beats, strings, organs, white-boy
rapping, blaxploitation-movie homages, and everything but the kitsch sink-
captures the media-saturated brain overload of the '90s. The success of Beck
(and his coproducers, the Dust Brothers) proves the public may be ready for
cut-and-paste pop.
-Classic Rock Equivalent-:Turn on your local rock station, listen for 15
seconds, then start flipping back and forth between rap and dance stations.
-Plugging In-: Beck's *Odelay (and its predecessor, *Mellow Gold, both on
Geffen) stands as the definitive text, along with DJ Shadow's hip-hop
symphony *Entroducing... (Mo Wax/FFRR, 1996) and Money Mark's *Mark's
Keyboard Repair (Mo Wax/FFRR, 1996). *Headz 1 and 2 , two separate
compilations from the London-based Mo Wax label, feature the Beastie Boys
and the Dust Brothers alongside British genrebusters like MAssive Attack.
-Best Listening Environment-: In your living room - but for full
multi-media-age effect, turn on the tv and keep the sound off.

*DIGITAL HARDCORE*
One of the most appealing aspects of all these techno styles is their
utopianism; the blissed-out quality (and the one-world nature of techno
technology itself) feels several worlds removed from grunge frustration. Not
so much with digital hardcore, which is both a style and the name of the
German record company that's hping it. The basic idea: pent-up punk thrash
played on the synthesizers common to techno. Forget the relatively tuneful
Marilyn Manson- this is the musical apocalypse, the true premillenial tension.
-Classic Rock Equivalent-:The Sex Pistols log on, crash, and get truly angry.
-Plugging In-: Stick with the only one-say, Atari Teenage Riot's import-only
*Delete Yourself (Digital Hardcore, 1995) - so you don't risk eviction.
-Best Listening Environment-:Pick a work chore you find particularly
hateful, put on this music, and go at it. Gobbing optional.

--------from Entertainment Weekly Mag.---------------------------

Brian, 

Thank you so much for coming back after your research and correcting
yourself. The biggest problem with GHB is that most people and media haven't
done the research, make incorrect statements and then never come back with
the accurate correction.

Basically GHB has very low toxicity ON ITS OWN, but the minute you mix it
with anything, really anything (even over the counter) it becomes a little
like Russian roulette. And many people unwisely chose to do their
experimenting in public place like clubs and raves which has added to the
hysteria and media hype. All this has caused lawmakers to now want to add GHB
to schedule 1. This is an amino acid found naturally in every cell in our
bodies. It clearly does not belong on sched 1, but clearly people need to be
a little more responsible in their use of this substance. Respect your bodies
and never take anything without first doing a little research...
there is a book called "Better Sex Through Chemistry", and the same authors
are coming out with an entire book on GHB this summer.
 
See you on the dancefloor,

juliet   :)

Content-Type: text/plain

Precedence: bulk

Regarding the DJ kicks series, I feel obligated to warn you about the stacey
pullen CD.  I totally love Stacey Pullen's mixing (I have a tape of a party
called "Prometheus Unbound", a transmat records tour that he spun at that rocks
my world), but in this case, it is muddied by overproduction.  He adds a lot of
delay and reverb in certain portions.  A lot of times the delay isn't
synchronized w/ the record, making it sound like a train wreck.  I'm borrowing
the Claude Young edition of the series, and I DO recommend that.  It's got
amazing tracks (only one bad) and amazing mixing.
                             yup,
                                 Steve

  %^&#(&^$endoftransmission*^*$&#^**($&(

At 11:53 PM -0500 3/11/97, <a new SF Raver> wrote:
>>Well, as many of you know, I, and many others, have been agressively
>>adding
>>filters to manage the "content" of SF Raves. For the last month or so,
>
>
>Okay, I'll admit that I'm pretty ignorant when it comes to computers.  I
>understand what a filter is, but I don't understand your ratio thing.  Do
>you mean that 99% of your mail is being filtered out?  You're only
>getting 1% of the mail sent to you?
>
>If that's what it means why are you on San Francisco Raves?
>
>If that's not what it means, then, well...why am I so confused???
>

That means that of 100% of the messages that come to SF Raves, 66% of them
get put into my "first tier" SFR folder, and 33% of them go into my "second
tier" folder. My filters aren't perfect though -- most of what is on SF
Raves *has become* a bunch of off topic nonsense and not relavent to raving.

Why am I on SF Raves? The correct question is "Why am I still on SF Raves?"

When I subscribed to SF Raves two years ago, it had high ratio of people
and contributions that reflected a small, "everybody knows everybody"
virtual cul-de-asc type community. As far as content, there was relatively
small crap factor.

I am hoping for that to come again, but, as I write this, I realize that,
just like the rave scene itself, SF Raves is doomed to "mall rat culture"
dilution as the music (techno, house, etc.), community and prospective
"market" grows to a critical mass that can again, just like in the early
1990's, be market to.

It makes me sad that my old neighborhood is surrounded by freeways,
shopping malls, and McDonald's. I guess to find the neighborhood I used to
live in called "raving" I will have to move to a new "neighborhood." That
neighborhood will no longer be called "raving" but I will, hopefullly, find
the community that "raving" has lost.

My favorite recipe is as follows.

Ingredients:

4-5 medium sized spent glowsticks (per person)
2 tbs. butter
3 cloves of garlic, crushed
1/s tsp. salt
2 tbs. olive oil

Saut=E9 garlic in olive oil until slightly golden brown.  Add =
glowsticks.  Cover and let simmer for 10-12 minutes.  Remove from pan =
and arrange decoratively on a doily.  Salt and butter to taste.  Eat as =
you would asparagus.


Bon Appetite!=20

<3     <3            <3
<3       to all....

Precedence: bulk

hello all-

i find this attitude just a bit eliteist (is that spelled correctly?).  i
don't find that what is occurring to sfraves to be a "dilution", i find it
to be an evolution to something that it was never planned to be.  contrary
to popular belief, that is not bad, and can in fact be good.

this notion of what sfraves "should be", imho, is bordering on
hypocritical.  from my limited exposure (2 years, which is starting to make
me look like a middle-ager!) and a complete (yes, complete!) reading of the
archives, i have noted that there are always those who are griping about
"dilution", "pollution", "off topic posts", etc.  without those posts,
though, sfraves would not have grown to what it is, and would not have
grown to what people idealize that it was like in the past.

though i understand the need for control of the topics so that this doesn't
become alt.raves, i counsel disgression when using strong statements like
"dilution" and "mall rat culture".  

>I am hoping for that to come again, but, as I write this, I realize that,
>just like the rave scene itself, SF Raves is doomed to "mall rat culture"
>dilution as the music (techno, house, etc.), community and prospective
>"market" grows to a critical mass that can again, just like in the early
>1990's, be market to.


thanks for listening (those who don't yet filter me!)

love to you all-

matt
matthew d. p. k. lanier
professional hugger and empath
independent internet consultant

On Tue, 11 Mar 1997, Stephen Santos wrote:

> > Life

> > LIFE JUST ISN'T.
> > 
> > But, life is about who you love and who you hurt.
> > It's about who you make happy or unhappy purposefully.
> > It's about keeping or betraying trust.
> > It's about friendship, used as a sanctity or a weapon.
> > It's about what you say and mean, maybe hurtful, maybe heartening.
> > About starting rumors and contributing to petty gossip.
> > It's about what judgments you pass and why.  And who your judgments are
> > spread to.
> > It's about who you've ignored with full control and intention.
> > It's about jealousy, fear, ignorance, and revenge.
> > It's about carrying inner hate and love, letting it grow, and spreading it.
> > But most of all, it's about using your life to touch or poison other
> > people's hearts in such a way that could have never occurred alone.
> > Only you choose the way those hearts are affected, and those choices are
> > what life's all about.

Thanks! What a beautiful post.

                                            Black Adder

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 12 09:27:59 1997

Date: Wed, 12 Mar 1997 09:27:47 -0800 (PST)
From: TRISTAN BERNARD BLAUG <sandoz@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: sandoz@pluto
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Where did the term tchno come from?
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970312092108.2825H-100000@pluto>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hate to dissapoint all you kids but the term tchno is a word stemming from
a generic brand name.  You see in Europe we refere to activities by there
brand names.  Thus the term "doing the hoovering" means doing the
vacuuming (Hoover first invented the vacuum cleaner), "to tippex" means to
use whitner (tippex first invented whitner) and "to techno" means to
produce sounds from a technics 1200 (as they were the first people to make
a decent record player).  The only know refference that I know of in
reguards to term being used musically before this whole dance scene
thing took off was in 1986 on the Krafwerk record"Electronic Cafe" in the
track "Techno pop."
See yer!
Tristan.

>  What DO  you do with a dead glow stick?

Hi there,

This represents a very large portion of the negativity found in the bay area 
rave scene, and there is a definte separation of the tribes due to it.

I have always said that it is alright to surround yourself with the things 
that are familiar and comfortable to you.  But, we must also realize that 
without change, there is no growth.  To seperate oneself from sfraves 
because it is becoming "dilluted" with the "mall rat culture" is limiting 
that person to the possible growth that would be found there.  I joined 
sfraves because I have heard that this was happening.  That the more 
experienced sfravers were leaving for these reasons, leaving sfraves to the 
very "mall rat culture" that they don't agree with in the first place.  The 
only way for things to change is through education.  period.  All sfravers 
are on this list because we all share a common interest, raving.  Although 
some may believe that the list has changed for the worse, only through 
active participation on the part of people who disagree with the way the 
list is going will it change.

We are in the midst of a very critical time in the development of raving in 
America.  Soon, the masses will descend upon raving as if it were the buzz 
word for the 90's...it's already happening...read the magazines and 
newspapers...watch mtv...turn on hard copy...they are all reporting raving 
as some sort of new hip era of our culture.  Regardless of how we all feel 
individually, this influx of the masses is inevitable.  I welcome it 
however, because I know that it will invoke great change upon my ideals, and 
I will be forced to deal with my rave culture in a much different way.

It is not enough to surround yourself with the things that you believe in 
and are comfortable with.  We must educate those that we don't agree with as 
to what those ideals are.  For if you abandon these people, they will not 
see things the way that you do, thus continuing the only way they know 
how...use your voice...

Smiles,

Scott =)

 ----------

From: Wayne D. Correia
To: internet!hyperreal.com!sfraves; sgalloway
Subject: Re: FYI: SFRAVES: Filter Update
Date: Tue Mar 11 1997 11:12PM

At 11:53 PM -0500 3/11/97, <a new SF Raver> wrote:
>>Well, as many of you know, I, and many others, have been agressively
>>adding
>>filters to manage the "content" of SF Raves. For the last month or so,
>
>
>Okay, I'll admit that I'm pretty ignorant when it comes to computers.  I
>understand what a filter is, but I don't understand your ratio thing.  Do
>you mean that 99% of your mail is being filtered out?  You're only
>getting 1% of the mail sent to you?
>
>If that's what it means why are you on San Francisco Raves?
>
>If that's not what it means, then, well...why am I so confused???
>

That means that of 100% of the messages that come to SF Raves, 66% of them
get put into my "first tier" SFR folder, and 33% of them go into my "second
tier" folder. My filters aren't perfect though -- most of what is on SF
Raves *has become* a bunch of off topic nonsense and not relavent to raving.

Why am I on SF Raves? The correct question is "Why am I still on SF Raves?"

When I subscribed to SF Raves two years ago, it had high ratio of people
and contributions that reflected a small, "everybody knows everybody"
virtual cul-de-asc type community. As far as content, there was relatively
small crap factor.

I am hoping for that to come again, but, as I write this, I realize that,
just like the rave scene itself, SF Raves is doomed to "mall rat culture"
dilution as the music (techno, house, etc.), community and prospective
"market" grows to a critical mass that can again, just like in the early
1990's, be market to.

It makes me sad that my old neighborhood is surrounded by freeways,
shopping malls, and McDonald's. I guess to find the neighborhood I used to
live in called "raving" I will have to move to a new "neighborhood." That
neighborhood will no longer be called "raving" but I will, hopefullly, find
the community that "raving" has lost.

Preach on, Uncle Noah!  It *is* all scene, because everyone here is
what makes the scene!  I *love* the diversity of topics our community
jumps into, even if it does tend to stray a bit, although I do believe
that people should humour each other to a degree with the little things,
and put NRR on top of a post if it's NRR, so that those of us that *do*
want to use filters can.
I certainly wouldn't analogize this group to the development of "mallrat
culture," though.  Geez... that's kind of harsh.  After all the beautiful
NRR posts that pop up weekly (i.e. poems, inspirational words, etc.), I
think SFRaves is a *lot* less apathetic (and far more eloquent) than your
average utterly-bored mallrat crowd.  (...Speaking of which, as far as
_Mallrats_ goes, I thought it was a good flick.  Nothing on _Clerks_, mind
you (it should've been shot in B&W, too), but still pretty decent.
Okay, sorry, now I'm *really* stretching the NRR envelope!  I'll shut up
now.)   
Keep smiling!  :)

erm, isn't techno some derivative of 'technological'?  

that seems to make much more sense than any etymological reference to a
turntable brand name.  esp. since 'techno' music has to be composed and
produced before it could even *be* played on a turntable.

I heard that Joey Beltram canonized the term 'techno' as it applies to
electronic dance music, in the mid 80's.

	-jon

On Wed, 12 Mar 1997, TRISTAN BERNARD BLAUG wrote:

> Hate to dissapoint all you kids but the term tchno is a word stemming from
> a generic brand name.  You see in Europe we refere to activities by there
> brand names.  Thus the term "doing the hoovering" means doing the
> vacuuming (Hoover first invented the vacuum cleaner), "to tippex" means to
> use whitner (tippex first invented whitner) and "to techno" means to
> produce sounds from a technics 1200 (as they were the first people to make
> a decent record player).  The only know refference that I know of in
> reguards to term being used musically before this whole dance scene
> thing took off was in 1986 on the Krafwerk record"Electronic Cafe" in the
> track "Techno pop."
> See yer!
> Tristan.
> 
>

I believe Wayne is right on regarding the comments he made.  Note that he
did not claim that SFR is *currently* diluted with mall rat culture, but
only doomed to undergoing such a dilution.  Below is an excerpt from his
message:

<Wayne>
> I am hoping for that to come again, but, as I write this, I realize
> that, just like the rave scene itself, SF Raves is doomed to "mall rat
> culture"  dilution as the music (techno, house, etc.), community and
> prospective "market" grows to a critical mass that can again, just like
> in the early 1990's, be market to. 
</Wayne>

And as far as the arguments to the contrary go, is this so different than
when people often bemoan the disappearance of the underground?  As raves
become more mainstream, those who prefer "the way it was" (ie, more people
there for the music and less people there for the "scene" and "oh, is this
what cool people do now?") will go further underground.  Likewise, as the
internet becomes more popular and the rave lists become filled with ever
more sophomoric discussion (coke v. pepsi?  come *on*), those used to the
way it was (ie, more information, less fluff) will move on.

The comments about "diversity" miss the point completely.  If lewd,
disrespectful frat-types show up at Sunset and start making unwelcome
come-ons, is that diversity?  Of course not.  The coming of rave-culture
to the mainstream has nothing to do with diversity -- it has more to do
with scenesterism.

	Sami

> turntable brand name.  esp. since 'techno' music has to be composed and
> produced before it could even *be* played on a turntable.

> electronic dance music, in the mid 80's.

I heard that it was done by some British record collector who started the
whole thing in Europe by releasing a compilation of early Detroit tracks
under the name "the Techno Sound of Detroit." Which may have been Joey
Beltram, and may not.

From: Marc Fathauer <marcus@technologik.com>
Subject: NRR GHB legis. info
Cc: "socal-raves@UCSD.EDU" <socal-raves@UCSD.EDU>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/enriched; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Here's the latest:

                       AB 6    BILL ANALYSIS                                                                                                                                                                                                    

                                                          

Date of Hearing:  March 12, 1997


               ASSEMBLY COMMITTEE ON APPROPRIATIONS

                     Carole Migden, Chairwoman


               AB 6 (Bowler) - As Amended:  3/3/97 

 

Policy Committee:  Public Safety                Vote:  11 - 0


State Mandated Local Program:  YesReimbursable:  No    Urgency:   

Yes     


 SUMMARY


 This bill adds Gamma-hydroxybutyrate (GHB) to the list of Schedule  

II controlled depressant substances.


Possession of Schedule II depressants is an alternate  

felony/misdemeanor (wobbler), punishable by 16 months, two, or  

three years in state prison or up to one year in county jail.  

Possession for sale is a felony, punishable by 16 months, two or  

three years in state prison. Sale, furnishing or transportation is  

a felony, punishable by two, three, or four years in state prison.  



 FISCAL EFFECT


1. Suspense. Unknown annual state costs - likely in excess of  

   $150,000 - for state prison incarceration. If only eight people  

   receive a state prison sentence, the first year cost will  

   exceed $150,000, while annual out-year costs will increase.  

   There are more than 6,000 persons serving state prison terms  

   for possession and possession for sale of Schedule II  

   substances. 


   (Similar legislation, (AB 2226, Bowler) to place the so-called  

   date-rape drug Rohypnol on the Schedule, was placed on the  

   Appropriations Suspense File in both houses last year.)

  

2. Unknown nonreimbursable mandated local costs for county jail  

   incarceration.  

 

BACKGROUND 


1. GHB is not currently restricted under California law. 


2. GHB is usually distributed as a liquid. Users mix the drug with  

   alcohol and/or combine it with other drugs. GHB has become  

   popular at "rave" parties in L.A. and the Bay Area. The  

   intended effect is an intense high lasting about two hours.  

   Effects can include sedation, nausea, respiratory depression  

   and arrest, coma and seizures.


   In December 1996, the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration  

   reported at least three deaths related to GHB. 


3. If placed in the Schedule III or IV, the penalties would be  

   virtually the same as the penalties for Schedule II. The  

   schedule:

 

   I   High potential for abuse, no accepted medical use in  

       treatment in the U.S., and no accepted safety for use of  

       the drug or other substance under medical supervision.


   II  High potential for abuse with an accepted medical use in  

       the U.S. Abuse may lead to severe psychological or physical  

       dependence.


   III Less potential for abuse and an accepted medical use in the  

       U.S. Abuse may lead to moderate or low physical or high  

       psychological dependence.


   IV  Low potential for abuse relative to Schedule III, with an  

       accepted medical use in the U.S. Abuse may lead to limited  

       physical dependence or psychological dependence. 


   V   Low potential for abuse relative to Schedule IV with an  

       accepted medical use in the U.S. Abuse may lead to limited  

       physical dependence or psychological dependence. 



<color><param>ffff,0000,ffff</param>marcus@technologik.com

</color><color><param>8080,0000,8080</param>marcus@technologik.com

</color><color><param>0000,0000,ffff</param>marcus@technologik.com</color>

Thank-you Sami. That was *exactly* my point.

When more and more raves all feel like Friday night at 1015 Folsom (and
more and more of them *do* feel that way, as the "scenesters" find a new
"scene" to hang out in, en masse, you'll know the gig is up.

What do I mean? Women dressed to the hilt who beg to be looked at, but the
second they notice someone looking at them, the scowl at you. Add to that,
testosterone-pumped "mustang 5.0" types guys posturing for the attention of
formerly-described women. Now add a *lot* of alcohol and dilute with
hundreds and thousands of suburban clubbers looking for "the next cool
thing."

If you want a better idea of what's about to stampede toward the beautiful
rave scene you all know and love, I suggest you hit any of the bay area's
"modern dance" clubs like The Edge, Sound Factory, The X, Palladium, etc.
etc. Get to know these people -- they're headed *your* way!

It ain't pretty, there's a whole lot more of "them" than "us", and they
don't particularly care to find out about the fundamentals of rave culture,
including, but not limited to "kindness" "PLUR" or even necessarily about
the music. I hung out in the club scene for almost a decade. It's about
drinking and cruising, and that's on a *good* night!

Now, once all the cattle are excited about "RAVE" picture this:

-------------------------
"Super Stadium Rave 1997" at Shoreline Ampitheater

presented by Bill Graham Presents

STARRING: "The Prodigy, Chemical Brothers, Beck, Smashing Pumpkins and KEOKI"

Sponsored by: Live 105, Moonshine Records, Tanqueray, Camel and Budweiser"

Admission: $35 + BASS surcharge
-------------------------

It ain't pretty.

From: Joe Rice <ambient@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Where did the term tchno come from?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 12:22 PM -0800 3/12/97, Giles Bowkett wrote:
>[claim that techno comes from "technics"]
>> erm, isn't techno some derivative of 'technological'?
>
>it'd certainly seem that way, wouldn't it?
>
>> that seems to make much more sense than any etymological reference to a
>> turntable brand name.  esp. since 'techno' music has to be composed and
>> produced before it could even *be* played on a turntable.
>>
>> I heard that Joey Beltram canonized the term 'techno' as it applies to
>> electronic dance music, in the mid 80's.
>
>I heard that it was done by some British record collector who started the
>whole thing in Europe by releasing a compilation of early Detroit tracks
>under the name "the Techno Sound of Detroit." Which may have been Joey
>Beltram, and may not.
>
>* giles@bowkett.com                                       www.bowkett.com *
>* dashwood@flat-earth.org                                   (coming soon) *

The comp you're referring to was on 10 records and came out in '89 or '90,
I believe. I want to say Neil Rushton did the track selection, but he was
with the Network label so I can't be sure. I'll pull it out and take a
look. There was another compilation merely titled 'Techno 1' on KMS from
Detroit in '89.

I've been trying to dig up references, so I'm not going to make any
definitive statements here, but it's my understanding that techno was
coined as a term back in '85 or '86, back around when the first Metroplex
and Transmat records were being released.  While these records definitely
fit the genre, I don't know that they were referred to as such
comtemporarily. I can think of a couple of mid-80's vintage
electro/proto-techno tracks with "Techno" in the title - "Techno City" for
example. I'm also aware of an LA based hip-hop/electro label that was
active in the early to mid '80s called Techno Hop. I've heard this was Dr.
Dre's label, but I haven't verified that.I doubt Joey Beltram coined the
term, however - I can't think of any records by him prior to '89, although
I don't know when his first Nu Groove records were released. He's also from
New York, not England.

Joe

in regards to this post I have to say that I feel I myself am a hybrid of
the rave/mall rat/mod/alt/a bunch of other stuff and I feel that I am just
tring to take the best from all the environments and situations that are
around me. I feel that I am at least a semi-inteligent open minded
individual and I have learned through experince that everthing seem to
have it's good and bad points which are constantly evolving because things
change in both positive and negative ways. Those of you who are leaving SF
raves because it's not what it once was or there is too much "NRR crap"
etc. concider what you are doing and why, change is the only constant in
life(at least for me) don't be afraid, if this passes you threshhold of
acceptance so be it, just think before you act, you might find something
you didn't see in the first place, or you might learn something new. 

thanks for taking the time to read this I will try to prevent wasting any
more bandwidth(for now *B^))

><<LIFE>>
>
>>Life isn't about keeping score.
>>It's not about how many friends you have
>>Or how accepted you are.
>>Not about if you have plans this weekend or if you're alone.
>>It isn't about who you're dating, who you used to date, how many people
>>you've dated, or if you haven't been with anyone at all.
>>It isn't about who you have kissed,
>>It's not about sex.
>>It isn't about who your family is or how much money they have
>>Or what kind of car you drive.
>>Or where you are sent to school.
>>It's not about how beautiful or ugly you are.
>>Or what clothes you wear, what shoes you have on, or what kind of music 
>>  you listen to.
>>It's not about if your hair is blonde, red, black, or brown
>>Or if your skin is too light or too dark.
>>Not about what grades you get, how smart you are, how smart everybody
>>  else thinks you are, or how smart standardized tests say you are.
>>It's not about what clubs you're in or how good you are at "your" sport.
>>It's not about representing your whole being on a piece of paper and
>>  seeing who will "accept the written you."
>>
>>LIFE JUST ISN'T.
>>
>>But, life is about who you love and who you hurt.
>>It's about who you make happy or unhappy purposefully.
>>It's about keeping or betraying trust.
>>It's about friendship, used as a sanctity or a weapon.
>>It's about what you say and mean, maybe hurtful, maybe heartening.
>>About starting rumors and contributing to petty gossip.
>>It's about what judgments you pass and why.  And who your judgments
>>  are spread to.
>>It's about who you've ignored with full control and intention.
>>It's about jealousy, fear, ignorance, and revenge.
>>It's about carrying inner hate and love, letting it grow, and
>>  spreading it.
>>But most of all, it's about using your life to touch or poison other
>>  people's hearts in such a way that could have never occurred alone.
>>Only you choose the way those hearts are affected, and those choices
>>  are what life's all about.
>>
>>This is not your ordinary chain letter.  Depending on how many people
>>you send this to, your life will change dramatically! If you send this
>>to:
>>
>>         0-people:  Something terrible will happen such as losing
>>                    a best friend.
>>       1-5 people:  You will have 1 good day.
>>      6-10 people:  You will have a good week, and the person you
>>                    like will ask you out.
>>     11-15 people:  You will have a good month, and a great
>>                    surprise every day.
>>          16 & up:  You will have a successful life and all of your
>>                    dreams will come true!
>>
>>SEND THIS TO EVERYONE YOU KNOW!!
>>
>>
>>--------To everyone who got this, have a nice day----------
>>
>>

At 01:50 PM 3/12/97 -0000, you wrote:
>>> What DO  you do with a dead glow stick?
>


OKAY>>>
here's how to have an EVERLASTING GLOWSTICK!!!!
This includes a tad bit of villainous activity.
so don't do it. =o)

go to a dark place, such as a video arcade, movie theater, etc., etc. and
look for an EXIT sign. Evaluate the exit sign:

1. Is it black with glowing green letters?
2. Are there breaks between the lines in the letters?
3. Is the sign not plugged in?

If the answer to all three questions is yes... you are well on your way to
having EVERLASTING GLOWSTICKS. 

Chances are, the sign is planted in sheetrock, which will easily break away
after a bit of tugging and twisting. Find a discrete place to hold the sign
until you are away from the area.

Upon opening the casing of the sign, you will notice that there are
stickers stating that the signs are radioactive and you should not be
handling this without some sort of special license. Ignore this. The
radioactive chemicals are only exposed when the glass casing is broken,
which will also kill your everlasting glowstick. If broken open, the
chemical will make you smarter, effects may vary, so just in case, dont
break the glass.

The glass sticks are attatched to the sign with rubbery glue that peels
away, peel all that stuff off.

You now have not only 1 everlasting glowstick, but a set of 12 -count em'-
12 EVERLASTING GLOWSTICKS!!!

Now your youngen ravers in the year 12,048,384,543 AD will STILL be able to
use these glowsticks at their parties!!!

-much love
-justin
http://www.chosen.org

Thnak you all for your inquiries as to the equipment for sale.  Many of you
asked questions about the gear.  I don't have the time to reply to each
question so I've decided to report this message with a bit more detail for
those who still have ???'s:

Alesis 1622 Mixer
-16 Channels w/ EQ
-6 Aux Sends
-8 Aux Returns
-Solo on Input Channels
-2 Sub Masters
-Control Room Monitor Section
-Electronically Balanced Mic Inputs (Channels 1-8)
-Mixdown Tape Deck Return
-Inserts on all inputs and outputs
-8 Direct Outputs (channels 1-8)

Alesis Quadraverb
-16Hz to 20Hz Freq. Response
-Up to 4 excellent quality simultaneuous effects
-Touch sensitive multi-speed countoured programming buttons w/ led indicators
-32 character LCD Display
-Stores up to 100 programs
-Full Midi implementation
-Most parms adjustable real time via external MIDI controllers
-Easy editing of ALL parameters
-All funtions, parms, & volume levels fully programmable
-Stereo In/out
-Extremely flexible effects routing and mixing
-Several reverbs: Plate, Room, Chamber, Hall, Reverse
-Several Delays:Ping Pong, Mono, Stereo & more
-Several Choices of pitch shift incl.: Mono/Stereo Chorus, Mono/Stereo
Flange, Pitch Detune, Phase SHifter
-EQ up the butt: # band parametric, 5 Band parametric, and 11 band parametric
-All factory presets can be restored from ROM at any time.

E-Mu Proteus 1 Sound Module
Audio Channels: 32
       Presets: 128 (midi mappable)
       Data Encoding: 16-bit linear
       Sound Memory: 2MB (internally expandable to 4 MB)
       Signal to Noise: > 90dB
       Dynamic Range: > 90dB
       Frequency Responce: 20Hz-18Hz
       THD: < 0.05%

       Inputs
       Effects Return 1 In (stereo), Effects Return 2 In (stereo), MIDI In

       Outputs
       Six, polyphonic (configurable as three pairs of stereo outputs
       w/programmable panning), Mono mix, MIDI out, MIDI thru

       Rack Dimensions
       Height: 1.75" (4.5 cm.), Width: 19" (48.3cm.), Depth: 8.5"

Opcode Studio 3 Midi Router:
MIDI Interface with SMPTE Synchronization

The Studio 3 is a MIDI interface with SMPTE synchronization, two
independent MIDI Ins, and six independent MIDI Outs. Each MIDI Out is
assignable to either the printer or the modem port. The interface reads and
writes all formats of SMPTE and sends MIDI Time Code to the Mac for
synchronization.

Requirements: Macintosh 512K and up; MIDI instrument or MIDI compatible device.

The deal:  Serious inquiries only.  First come first served (if the offer
is good, you got it; there will be no bidding).  All of the equipment is in
MINT condition w/ manuals and sftw (I take good care of my stuff), has very
little studio time, and NO TIME AT ALL SPENT IN DIRTY CLUBS (I did mention
it was mint didn't I ? ;) ).  As of today all equipment is available.
Lemme know ASAP.

Later,
John

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 12 17:20:34 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id RAA26779; Wed, 12 Mar 1997 17:20:34 -0800 (PST)
Received: from value.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id RAA26754; Wed, 12 Mar 1997 17:20:30 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [207.33.94.97] (a104.value.net [207.33.94.104]) by value.net (8.8.4/8.7.3) with SMTP id RAA19008; Wed, 12 Mar 1997 17:20:11 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v02130502af4d013c8e92@[207.33.94.97]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-mailer: Eudora Pro 2.1.3
Date: Wed, 12 Mar 1997 17:23:39 -0800
To: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne2@club.net>
From: bri@value.net (Brian Denny)
Subject: commercialization of raving (was Re: FYI: SFRAVES: Filter Update
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>If you want a better idea of what's about to stampede toward the beautiful
>rave scene you all know and love, I suggest you hit any of the bay area's
>"modern dance" clubs like The Edge, Sound Factory, The X, Palladium, etc.
>etc. Get to know these people -- they're headed *your* way!

as far as raving itself:

let them have their $35 massives.  i'll be at the cheap undergrounds.  that
scene will only die if we let it. i mean, those who find the rave scene
getting stale can create something fresh.  those who find it too commercial
can take it further underground.  and they DO.

we can be co-opted by the mainstream, or we can move on to something new.

OR we can "be our own gods" and create the scene we want.

which is what we've been doing all along.  it's still happening and i see
no reason why it has to stop.

now as far as sfraves-- the list _isn't_ underground, and it really can't
be.  in that sense, those of us who want to stay underground may have to
choose other forms of communication.

so perhaps rather than complaining about the direction of sfraves, we
should be (assuming that we love and desire to maintain the community that
we may be losing) thinking about how to recreate it in another place or
form or medium.

or perhaps, while we take raving further underground, we should maintain a
presence on this list-- surely if the masses flock to the list, there will
be _some_ of them who were meant to be (underground) ravers all along and
were just never exposed to the scene.  our being on sfraves as it "goes
mainstream" would allow us to expose these people to our idea(l)s.  even if
only a tiny percentage of the people who come to the rave scene end up
"getting it", that's still better than nothing.

in other words:  can't we BOTH keep the underground alive AND take
advantage of the commercialization of raving to spread the vibe to as many
people as possible?


love,

brian

Sacramento media web pages...

called Chocolate and Vanilla.  The deceased is a former track star
named  Amy Sue Lofton.   Supposedly she had only been working for the
escort agency for 10 days when she died of an ecstacy overdose while
on a call.  More bizarre facts about this case can be found on the
KOVR and Sacramento Bee web pages.=20

on 03/12/97 11:22 PM berger@SONOMA.EDU wrote...

>> >> What DO  you do with a dead glow stick?
>> 
>>   I believe this item is on the list because of a text file that 
>> circulated from one of the rave mailing lists (socal?) that explained how 
>> to reactivate a lightstick.
>>   Whether it was a joke, or merely written by someone who had no clue 
>> what they were talking about is unknown, but it is bogus as written.
>> 
>can't you put glowsticks in the freezer and then when you take 'em out the
>next time they will be rejuvenated and work as they did before? that's
>something that i've always been told but never done. i don't know.

  Not really, this just slows down the reaction between chemicals.  
However, if you have a 12 hr stick and you get it home quick enough, 
there's often quite a bit of life left.
  This is the reason why the diving sticks are so bright I think, they're 
designed to be used in the water which is fairly cold and slows down the 
reaction.
  If you want to regulate, you can place your glowstick in a small bottle 
of water of hot water to make it brighter or cold water to make it last...

In a message dated 97-03-12 19:32:10 EST, wayne2@club.net (Wayne D. Correia)
writes:

<< It ain't pretty, there's a whole lot more of "them" than "us", and they
 don't particularly care to find out about the fundamentals of rave culture,
 including, but not limited to "kindness" "PLUR" or even necessarily about
 the music. I hung out in the club scene for almost a decade. It's about
 drinking and cruising, and that's on a *good* night!
 >>

And then what happened?

Did you drop "e" for the first time?
Did you suddenly stumble into an underground party?
Did someone drop a bomb on your head?
Did some kind of lightbulb go on?

With all respect, because I *do* share your exact same concerns, this "us"
and "them" polarity really reeeaaally gets under my skin.  What bugs me even
*more,* is the "run-for-the-hills-the-mainstream-is-coming" school of
histrionics that is so vocal on this list, and out there in the underground.
 It's such a defeatist attitude, and it's terribly pesimistic.  And it's
snobbery.  From what you just wrote, Wayne, you used to *be* one of "them!"
(Who wasn't?)  And who invited *you* to "our party?"

"WE" are not better than "THEM."  If we must act superior, can we just say
that we are "more enlightened" or "more mature."  I would find that a little
less grating.  But still patronizing.  "Different" would feel even better.
 Can "we" just be "different?"  Thank you.  =)

The best vibe on the dancefloor is a HUMBLE vibe.  IMHO.

To cop another kind of annoying phrase, "back in the day" things were
different because the scene was smaller.  Yes, *but*... in general, people
took more responsibility for it, too.  Newcomers were greeted with open arms,
no matter how clueless they seemed, and given an introduction, a sort of
"dis-orientation," by someone who was probably genuinely pleased to meet
them.  That kind of treatment works miracles.  Sometimes it actually changes
lives.  I bet there are many people on this list who will tell you it's
happened to "them."  

Maybe they don't care to "find out" about us.  Maybe we need to start telling
them.  There are a zillion ways to do this, even as we delve deeper
underground.   What happened to wanting to spread the news?

I know it's awfully optimistic.  But isn't optimism one of the hallmarks of
our scene?  I just can't stand all the whining.   We have a lot of unrealized
power and it would be nice if more people (myself included) toyed with that a
bit more before resorting to all this bitching and complaining.  It
accomplishes nothing, and I don't know about anyone else, but it's depressing
to "me."

Much love,
Claudia

PS - I love that Wayne is one of "us" now.  =)

hi everyone,

i'd like to share a case in point.  a few weeks ago i met a couple of
younger promoters (19 & 21, i'm 29 - soon to be 30 :) that were getting
ready to throw a big event with dj's from NYC, Raja from San Diego and a
bunch of other dj's.  they just happened to come over my house one night
and i had some taken some fungus so i was more open than usual and we all
partook together and had a great time.  well, i temporarily fell in love
with the 19 year old and got involved with the production.  about a week
later i got fired and these guys gave me so much love and support on all
levels it was amazing.  we went up to a party in seattle that some of my
frineds were throwing up there and we were handing out flyers.  my
boyfriend went to give one to someone and they said, "uh, that looks like
a rave, we don't go to raves we have spiritual gatherings."  so much for
his first introduction to the underground.

after he told me that i was just thinking if that person only knew the
intentions of my boyfriend, that he is one of the most loving, "spiritual"
persons i've ever met.  he has his own beliefs, primarily Christian and
completely lives his beliefs and doesn't talk too much about it.

i know the the comment that was made to him was a bit extreme, but it's
the same issue and i believe that "vibe" ( a term many of us have agreed
on) is found inside of us, everyone of us, and under the right
circumstances can be brought out in anyone.  (even my ex-husband, i'm sure
of it! :)

so, i'm simply sharing my thoughts with my friends as many of my friends
have shared their thoughts with me as i have delved into this scene, not
flaming anyone because i sincerley love you all.

be happy,

brenda :)

At 03:23 PM 3/12/97 -0800, berger@SONOMA.EDU wrote:
>can't you put glowsticks in the freezer and then when you take 'em out the
>next time they will be rejuvenated and work as they did before?

I've done it and it does slow down the reaction a lot, so if you take it
out and
warm it up in the next few days it will still have some glow left.

Not much you can do with a dead glowstick.  Due to that, and the fact that
one can't
always get glowsticks when one needs them, I have sought and found (or
built) alternatives.

You can get small battery-powered fluorescent lamps at any large hardware
store.
Most of the camping ones are too bulky, but there is a kind that seems to
be intended
for closets that takes AA batteries (lots of them) and is quite small and
takes a size bulb
which are also available in blacklights.   You end up with a
battery-powered blacklight
that is about a foot long and about 1 1/4" in diameter.   The downside is
that a set of
batteries will last a few hours at most.   I had a pair of these at Harmony 3.

For a more permanent light source, LEDs are hard to beat, and they are
available
in all colors now (though red is still cheapest and most efficient).   A
pair of AA
nicads can power a red LED for about 3 days continuously.

I have built these into wands, using the LEDs to illuminate a crystal on
the end.
They have long been my favorite dancetoys.

Everything necessary to make them (except the crystal) can be had from the
hardware store and Radio Shack.



The Tie-Dyed Side of the Force

On Wed, 12 Mar 1997, =?iso-8859-1?Q?=22=A4=5BOo=5D=A4=22?= wrote:

> At 01:50 PM 3/12/97 -0000, you wrote:
> >>> What DO  you do with a dead glow stick?
> >
> 
> 
> OKAY>>>
> here's how to have an EVERLASTING GLOWSTICK!!!!
> This includes a tad bit of villainous activity.
> so don't do it. =o)
> 
> go to a dark place, such as a video arcade, movie theater, etc., etc. and
> look for an EXIT sign. Evaluate the exit sign:
> 
> 1. Is it black with glowing green letters?
> 2. Are there breaks between the lines in the letters?
> 3. Is the sign not plugged in?
> 
> If the answer to all three questions is yes... you are well on your way to
> having EVERLASTING GLOWSTICKS. 
> 
> Chances are, the sign is planted in sheetrock, which will easily break away
> after a bit of tugging and twisting. Find a discrete place to hold the sign
> until you are away from the area.
> 
> Upon opening the casing of the sign, you will notice that there are
> stickers stating that the signs are radioactive and you should not be
> handling this without some sort of special license. Ignore this. The
> radioactive chemicals are only exposed when the glass casing is broken,
> which will also kill your everlasting glowstick. If broken open, the
> chemical will make you smarter, effects may vary, so just in case, dont
> break the glass.
> 
> The glass sticks are attatched to the sign with rubbery glue that peels
> away, peel all that stuff off.
> 
> You now have not only 1 everlasting glowstick, but a set of 12 -count em'-
> 12 EVERLASTING GLOWSTICKS!!!
> 
> Now your youngen ravers in the year 12,048,384,543 AD will STILL be able to
> use these glowsticks at their parties!!!
> 
> -much love
> -justin
> http://www.chosen.org
>

>To cop another kind of annoying phrase, "back in the day" things were
>different because the scene was smaller.  Yes, *but*... in general, people
>took more responsibility for it, too.  Newcomers were greeted with open arms,

Date: Wed, 12 Mar 1997 23:17:25 -0800

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Precedence: bulk

Hello,


At this point I feel that I must make a request.  Please define the word =
that everyone uses to describe this thing we have: by this I mean =
community.  I would look upon as a personal favor to me if everyone who =
cares about the scene and wants to keep it strong would post their =
thoughts on what they envision as the "scene".  Tell me what you want in =
terms of a community.  What does the rave scene mean to you?  What do =
you take from it and what do you give to it?  With that thought.....

I see the rave scene as a place where I can express some of the thoughts =
and feelings that I do not feel the freedom to express else where.  I =
see it as a place where I can meet new people who won't come at me with =
strange pre-dispositions or prejudices.  I see it as a group of people =
who, although they may not have met each other before, can express true =
friendship with everyone they meet.  People can show the love and =
affection that is sorely missing from our society today.  THIS IS GOOD!  =
What I get from raving, I give to it.  My favorite parts are the =
friendships I have made with all of the beautiful people I have met.  =
What pains me most, and what I see as being the "lack of community" that =
some speak of, is that fact that there are too many lurkers on this =
list; more simply, people need to get to know each other.  I wish that I =
could say that I know everyone on this list.  Unfortunately, this is not =
true.  If you want a real community, well then lets really form one.  We =
all share something special that most other people don't know yet.  That =
alone should bring us together. =20
	Some people have also been speaking of the gradual  commercialization =
of the scene and dilution of the general vibe.  I am definitely against =
the commercialization of the scene, however, I would wish that all =
people could see the scene as I do and understand what I get from it.  =
The Underground  is by definition a slightly elitist society, but the =
vibe is one for all people.  If people want to keep the Underground =
pure, that's fine with me, but let the vibe out in to the world.   It is =
for all.  The reality is that there are too many people for one to form =
close ties with EVERYONE.  We all cannot bring EVERYONE into the scene =
as we know it.  All we can do is let them know how we as a community =
feel about each other, in hopes that they will do the same with their =
friends and whomever that meet.  Repeat ad infinitum, and you have =
spread the vibe like a plague of friendship.

	I realize I'm being a tad idealistic, but tell me what you want?  I'll =
do my bit to help if I can.  :)

<3   <3         <3            <3
<3     <3            <3
<3       to all....

Love, Hadrian


  p.s. sorry that this was a bit long, I kinda went off!  :)



----------
From:  Brian Denny[SMTP:bri@value.net]
Sent:  Wednesday, March 12, 1997 5:24 PM
To:  Wayne D. Correia
Cc:  sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject:  commercialization of raving (was Re: FYI: SFRAVES: Filter =
Update

>If you want a better idea of what's about to stampede toward the =
beautiful
>rave scene you all know and love, I suggest you hit any of the bay =
area's
>"modern dance" clubs like The Edge, Sound Factory, The X, Palladium, =
etc.
>etc. Get to know these people -- they're headed *your* way!

as far as raving itself:

let them have their $35 massives.  i'll be at the cheap undergrounds.  =
that
scene will only die if we let it. i mean, those who find the rave scene
getting stale can create something fresh.  those who find it too =
commercial
can take it further underground.  and they DO.

we can be co-opted by the mainstream, or we can move on to something =
new.

OR we can "be our own gods" and create the scene we want.

which is what we've been doing all along.  it's still happening and i =
see
no reason why it has to stop.

now as far as sfraves-- the list _isn't_ underground, and it really =
can't
be.  in that sense, those of us who want to stay underground may have to
choose other forms of communication.

so perhaps rather than complaining about the direction of sfraves, we
should be (assuming that we love and desire to maintain the community =
that
we may be losing) thinking about how to recreate it in another place or
form or medium.

or perhaps, while we take raving further underground, we should maintain =
a
presence on this list-- surely if the masses flock to the list, there =
will
be _some_ of them who were meant to be (underground) ravers all along =
and
were just never exposed to the scene.  our being on sfraves as it "goes
mainstream" would allow us to expose these people to our idea(l)s.  even =
if
only a tiny percentage of the people who come to the rave scene end up
"getting it", that's still better than nothing.

in other words:  can't we BOTH keep the underground alive AND take
advantage of the commercialization of raving to spread the vibe to as =
many
people as possible?


love,

brian

On Wed, 12 Mar 1997, Here Are The Facts You Requested wrote:

> How do I find Wisconsin-area rave mailing lists?

In general, if you are looking for information on raves in places other
than San Francisco/Bay Area, try these URL's:

http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/grid/
"GRID" is the Global Rave Information Database and should contain info
about upcoming events from all over.

http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/
This page has links to all the regional rave archives/lists that reside on
hyperreal -- another good starting point if you want to know if anything
is going down where you're headed.

Hope this helps,

	Sami

Hmmm, interesting... now, how does this work? I think people like sending
out a nick name, or a 'tag' (i.e. PEN PAL) to see how quickly this spreads
across the world, and how long it stays in circulation.

The forwarding of these 'virus alerts' IS the virus, taking up space on
everybodies hard drive, and distressing users new to the internet.

Or... possibly someone had recieved this message, then accidentally deleted
c:\ tree rather than emptying their trash?

If this is a true virus, will somebody please send it to me, because i
would like to see just how a text message is capable of deleting my hard
drive.

-i need a massage

>Someone just forwarded:
>
>>ALERT
>
>Hmmm, interesting... now, how does this work? I think people like sending
>out a nick name, or a 'tag' (i.e. PEN PAL) to see how quickly this spreads
>across the world, and how long it stays in circulation.
>
>The forwarding of these 'virus alerts' IS the virus, taking up space on
>everybodies hard drive, and distressing users new to the internet.
>
>If this is a true virus, will somebody please send it to me, because i
>would like to see just how a text message is capable of deleting my hard
>drive.

believe, since attachments are automatically executed in their =
respective programs, including word (with a well know macro virus =
'problem').

sure.  It is definately on macafee (macaffee?) 's web page, and maybe =
other virus protection pages...

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

--------------5F7B7D82216D
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I can definitely identify with wayne feelings about the changes
in the scene and on the list.
It seems like the people on this list are getting younger, or
maybe its just that I'm getting older.  This isn't neccessaryly
a negative.  Its just that I find with an older group there are 
people who have taken more time in their lives to consciously 
develop and enhance their spirituality. 
I am thankful that there are people here and at partys that value
their spirituality at all.  For me that sence of spirituality has
been the essence of raves.
I enjoyed dancing before I found the rave scene, and I will continue
to enjoy it for whatever changes that may occur. 
 I love music and will continue to appreciate the joy of sharing  
that love of music and hopefully others will join in.  And if others
don't, I'll try my best not to get disappointed by it, and continue to
enjoy it for at least myself and hopefully more.
Hopefully I will continue to learn how to feel and find that sence of 
connectedness that we all share in other ways besides music.

Thank you to all of you who share your joy of the music no matter
what changes you experience at raves.

 
>  Reason #173 to fear technology...

I remember one of my first times at a party..I didn't know a thing and 
was a little bit lost.

I was wandering around- looking at the lasers...

when this girl comes out of nowhere, sits me down and gives me the best 
massage, a hug and a smile.

and suddenly, I wasn't lost anymore.

Subject: ...his name is KONG...the EIGHTH WONDER OF THE WORLD...

From: Jonathan Dejano@SEPL on 03/13/97 09:30 AM

...good morning hardsteppas (and to all you techsteppas out there)...

...as i was coming home from work last night, i thought i felt another
earthquake...possibly a 3.5...upon closer inspection, it's was just big ol'
KING KONG himself, shakin' his fat hairy butt at the CW Saloon and causing
all sorts of commotion...

...i got there around 10ish and saw about five people in the place groovin'
to some badass techstep...two of which were Jonathan aka "Mudfoot" and Foo
(sp?)...they told me that it was dj slider on the decks...slider continued
to warm up the crowd which was growing to about 15 or so crazzzy jungle
junkies on a wednesday night....during slider's set, mudfoot mentioned that
their special guests the 119 cru (that's eleven-nine cru to you baby) were
on their merry way and plan to go on around 12..."these guys are gonna fuck
shit up" he says...

...next up was none other than mudfoot himself who was throwin' down some
phattyboombatty hardstep cuts to get the small crowd goin'...and it worked
(for me anyways)...i danced and jerked and twitched throughout his whole
set...this guy was smooth like a mudslide on the tec 12's...

...finally, big ol' hairy ass KING KONG dropped the mother of bigass
bombs...the 119 cru straight outta the socal brotherhood and the LA
junglists...the frontmen were golgo 13 (one of my favorite manga
characters), heretic, and MC leroy brown...the set started more on a
hip-hop tip as golgo 13 and heretic tagteamed the tec 12's...for the next
two hours, these bombass cut re-creators spun some of the hardest jungle
tracks around while they flawlessly layered some scratches over the
tracks..in other words, they FUCKED SHIT UP...man i was in jungle
heaven...can anybody say hop n' bass?...if anybody hears that these guys
are coming down again, by all means, go and check em' out...

...unfortunately, i had to leave around 1:30am but i managed to score a
copy of the 119 cru california drumandbass CD out on Sub Base usa...all
good...

...til' next time, gotta get myself a big ol' cup of hot steamin cup o'
java to wake my sleepy asszzzzzzzselfzzzzzzz...

d0u8l3 J;)zzzzzzzzzzzzhuh?what?zzzzzzzzzzz...
