From: KC <scarab@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Freaky
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970313092801.23699A-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Just wanted to post a quick review about Freaky last night in Berkeley.
It was a total blast, especially for us locals.  Pasand Lounge is set up
really nice and they have a great sound system. It's defintely plush
left-overs from the disco years. My roommate loved the very
70ish columns around the dance floor.  They were so funky!

The music was great, although I didn't get to hear Freaky Chakra.  It was
such a relaxed vibe with people boogeying and looking terrifically pleased
to have this event happen.  A nice sized crowd showed up.  Enough to fill
the dance floor.

If this happens again, I highly recommend going.  It's a nice atmosphere
to meat people, and it sure would be nice to have a weekly in the East
Bay.  Plus, everyone there was so nice :)

Thanks to everyone who put this together :)

-kirsten

King Kong last night was great. I got there pretty early and stayed till
they turned on the lights. Slider and Mudfoot got everyone going to a high
pitch. There was a bit at the beginning of Mudfoot's set with some vocal
sample "dub plate" that was over the top. What is that track? Then the 119
Crew came on and did *way* more than just crossfade from one turntable to
the other. Excellent.

The crowd was a bit thin, which makes me think of all you who were either
missing a good time or having one at FREEkey. :) When there are too many
appealing things in one knight, I guess jungle will tip the scales for me.

Terrence.

 > >[From the 03/12 issue of "The Onion"]
 > >
 > >U.S. Techno-Industrial Base Eroding Due To Foreign Competition
 > >
 > >
 > >WASHINGTON, DC--With first-quarter Club Rotation Index figures the
 > >lowest in seven years, and imports outselling domestic 12-inches
 > >more than two-to-one, economic observers throughout the U.S. are
 > >sounding the alarm over the nation's rapidly declining
 > >techno-industrial base.
 > >
 > >"America faces a grave moment of crisis," said DJ Nathan Brackett,
 > >Secretary of Industrial and Hardcore, in a recent speech before
 > >Congress. "Vinyl imports from both Europe and Japan are threatening
 > >our nation's once-great techno-industrial power base. Our Gross
 > >National Beats Per Minute is at its lowest point since 1991. The
 > >message is clear: We must fuck up the mix, or all is lost."
 > >
 > >In its late-'80s/early-'90s heyday, America's techno-industrial complex
 > >seemed unstoppable. Led by such formidable powers as Nine Inch Nails and
 > >Ministry,  the U.S. achieved near-total dominance of the global
 > >dance-mix marketplace.  Even in the traditionally insular Eurodisco field,
 > >the loud, banging, clamorous sound of American-made techno strongly
 > >influenced such foreign industrial powers as Front 242 and KMFDM.
 > >
 > >Less than a decade later, however, the glory days of the American
 > >techno-industrial complex seem far away. With over 20,000 former
 > >clubgoing elite out of work in the warehouse district of Chicago, and
 > >the Detroit house scene over $7 billion in debt, bitterness over the
 > >nation's eroding techno-industrial base can be felt throughout its
 > >once-thriving industrial centers.
 > >
 > >And with the rise of such overseas dope on wax as drum 'n' bass, ambient
 > >and jungle, the problem, experts say, is not going to go away any time
 > >soon.
 > >
 > >In fact, many fear that foreign competition from such heavy-hitting
 > >imports as England's Prodigy and Chemical Brothers, Germany's Atari
 > Teenage Riot and Japan's DJ Krush--whose rare vinyl imports fetch up to
 > >$29.99 domestically, even for a remix track--will overtake America's
 > >floundering techno-industrial base by the year 2000.
 > >
 > >Many, including NYC illbient's DJ Spooky, contend that fault lies in
 > >American industrial's inability to adapt to the changing realities of
 > >modern times.
 >
 > >"We must retool America's angry, metallic, hard-edged industrial mix to
 > >better reflect the mellowtronic, groovadelic peace memes of the emergent
 > >global cyber-age," he said.
 > >
 > >California's DJ Shadow agreed. "We are being beaten at our own game.
 > >Trip-hop was invented here, but right now, the British are simply doing
 > >it better," he said. "America has got to seriously remix its priorities."
 > >
 > >In the face of the foreign dance-floor dominance, President Clinton is
 > >urging Congress to pump money into the revitalization of the nation's
 > >techno-industrial infrastructure.
 > >
 > >"It is not enough to say, 'We must drop bass.' It is not enough to say,
 > >'We must rock the crazy beats,'" President Clinton said Monday in a
 > >secret live appearance at D.C.'s famed underground The 930 Club. "If
 > >American techno is to become the world's leader once again, we must drop
 > >much bass; we must rock mad, phat-ass, crazy beats; and we must do so
 > >quick-fast in a hurry, 24-7,  365. And I am out."
 > >
 > >Many conservatives in Congress, however, oppose to such change "U.S.
 > >techno-industrial is hardcore, and it must stay hardcore," said Sen.
 > >Orrin Hatch (R-UT). "Would Al Jourgensen wear a T-shirt depicting smiley
 > >aliens telepathing 'Love' to their baggy-pantsed children? Techno should
 > >be about hate, not love. Techno is about wearing black and screaming, not
 > >standing in one place and swaying peacefully. I say, bring back the days of
 > >Skinny Puppy."
 > >
 > >"Techno? Industrial? I am not familiar with these strange terms," said
 > >Rolling Stone magazine's Jann Wenner, speaking from one of his boats. "I
 > >do understand, however, that something called 'electronica' is the Next Big
 > >Thing. It says so right on the cover of our latest issue."
 >
 > --------- End forwarded message ----------
>
>
>- Bob Wallace (just my opinion); bobw@promind.com
>
>MIND BOOKS offers publications about psychedelics;
>email books@promind.com, or browse www.promind.com
>

From: Geoff Herbst <geoff@xingtech.com>

Subject: My Intro and a ?
Date: Thu, 13 Mar 1997 11:26:31 -0800

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I'm new to the group, but I have to say the vibe is great here!  I'm
in SLO, and found this group off the hyperreal link....

I went to my fist party in November of last year (Seismic threw it
in Los Osos, near SLO) in some large tents outside-it went until 8am when
the cops shut it down) but I knew then I'd found a new home.  The
friendliness, hospitality, acceptance, and the bass.  It was one of the
greatest experiences of my life.  But anyway, I am posting because
I have a question:  Do any of you know if there has ever been a live
webcast / internet broadcast of a rave or party yet?  The software
company I work for sent some av guys to the last local party we had 
(aXess, thrown by eMOTION-Rico from SF spun) and we cybercasted it-at least
until the cops shut it down at 3.  We think it might have been the
first live webcast of a rave.  It was hot! 

It is available for viewing via our free plug in (www.xingtech.com, 
follow the streamworks now links) to download your player.   Then 
run the application (outside your browser) and under File, Open Stream
paste

xdma://206.126.224.10/axess/axess.mpx

If you are on a 28.8 modem be patient... its not a download and play
its a stream, but you won't get a lot of video frames per second.  But
anyone on an ISDN or at work can get near full motion video.  Some 
parts are hard to see (obvious lighting challenge) but let me know what
you think.  I am working on making the MPEG available...

keep upthe vibe,
And turn up the bass!

Geoff

Delivered-To: analogue@qmail.hyperreal.com
MBOX-Line: From analogue-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 12 22:55:53 1997

From: atombee@slip.net (Knox Bronson)
Subject: Wendy Carlos invented the 303
Date: Wed, 12 Mar 1997 22:55:46 -0800
Sender: analogue-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Actually, it was Walter Carlos who invented it, but after Wendy's "how to
make a vagina from a penis" interview in Playboy in the mid 70's,  she got
rid of everything that had belonged to Walter, including musical talent and
inspiration.

But now she regrets some of her actions of the past (hormonal imbalances
leading to rash decisions) and is going to do all of Beethoven's late
quartets, including the Grosse Fugue, on a 303, overdubbing each part on
tape  separately, using only the built in sequencer on the 303 and running
a click off an 808 for syncing purposes.

So the 303 is far from being "finished" as a sound source in modern music.

If you can't say what you need to say with a 909 and a 303, you are
probably a member of the ruling class with vested interests in the
oppression of all free spirits and, of course, the TRUTH ...

The great thing is that all we need is _one_ chord  now ...

I guess I'll wait for the meds to kick in before I post again .... :)

Knox

Visit Yoshi the Pot-Bellied Pig: http://www.slip.net/~atombee/yoshi2.html

On 03/12/97 13:26:46 you wrote:

>It ain't pretty, there's a whole lot more of "them" than "us", and they
>don't particularly care to find out about the fundamentals of rave culture,
>including, but not limited to "kindness" "PLUR" or even necessarily about
>the music. I hung out in the club scene for almost a decade. It's about
>drinking and cruising, and that's on a *good* night!


Why even trip on what "they" are doing or What "That thing" is all about.  Its not like you can, 
or are willing to, do anything to change it, so why even give it any thought, or estrablish a 
conection.  

apart from the music, what does raving have to do with clubing anyways??  All because "they" 
play tecno does not make it a rave, nor does it make it underground.

Don't forget that Music and dancing are afterall the most obvious componenets of 
"Entertainmnet".   That is what people want, weather it is 'us' or 'Them'  it does not matter, 
"WE" all just want to have a good time, meet interesting people, express ourselves, and have 
fun.  


>Now, once all the cattle are excited about "RAVE" picture this:
>
>-------------------------
>"Super Stadium Rave 1997" at Shoreline Ampitheater
>

>-------------------------

Whats so "not pretty" about this?  It sounds like a blast.  I would go in a heartbeat.  Were 
else can you see this type of soughtafter musical talent all on one stage.  It sounds beautiful.  
I would even pay $50 to go or more.  

And what does it matter who sponsers it?  As long as it is hapening, Who cares if it is a radio 
station, or an independent producer.  What diference is it going to make to any of us in the 
long run.  Music and Fun does not have to be as political as we make it out to be.

Lets not get so involved in the little thinks that we overlook the big picture.

Keep it real
Ray Vonie

> long run.  Music and Fun does not have to be as political as we make it out to be.

Subject: minireview: kingkong vs step2k
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I went to both events last night in SF, first to King Kong.  It was a bar
atmosphere, pretty well lit, with a small dancefloor and stage where the
dj's were tearing it up.  There were about a dozen people, all but two or
three were sitting on a ledge thing around that area.  A couple of guys had
a laptop on the stage and were doing something, but I didn't see a ricochet
modem so it couldn't have been 'too' fun :) <wink>  I seriously admired the
mixing skill of the unknown dj.. thin guy, long hair, happy - whoever he
was he was doing it right.  But something didn't feel right for me, and I
thought about noel, etc at step2k.. so I left and headed over.
At step2k the atmosphere was _very_ different.  It was a bar sort of place
too, but darker, and laid out differently, the bar (read: light) was up
front, and by moving back through the narrow long room you got to several
sets of speakers and the dj..  it was warmer, and carpeted.. with a few
blacklights in various spots..  almost all of the several dozen (perhaps as
many as 50) people where moving, and there were some people who could
DANCE, oh my ghod.. and I thought I was something :) :)  There were some
girls that simply blew my mind, unbelievable steppers, and these two guys
who must have been born dancing - maybe smooth ninja breakdancers?  How
else to describe.. but hey that's the kind of energy jungle inspires..
washing synth and smooth jazzy vocals over a deep in your face bass - wow
that bass was soooo nice !
uhm, hehe.. probably getting carried away.  Anyway I'm glad I went to both,
and _really_ glad I went to step2k.
love
Max

Hey all -

I just wanted to thank everyone who came out for King Kong last night -
thanks especially for the cool sfrave reviews!  The 119 Crew had a great
time, and my head kept exploding repeatedly from the crazy battle
techniques of Heretic and Golgo 13!  These guys are incredible, they
tag-teamed for 2 hours, they dropped VIP mixes on dubplate, they scratched
like mad Q-Bert style, and they even dropped their own original tune, which
samples Too Short!  When they come back, don't sleep - these guys are the
bomb.  Watch out for their CD, "California Drum and Bass" available this
Friday on Suburban Base Records - I'm listening to it now and it's tight.
All I can say is, we're going to see some serious growth in the jungle
scene in 97 - it's happening right now, right here in the Bay Area.

NEXT WEEK: King Kong Rides Again, Wednesday March 19th at 10pm, with
Slider, Mudfoot, and special guests TBA - call the hotline for info: (415)
276-8549

ALSO: Wendesday March 26th, King Kong is proud to bring you DJ E-SASSIN
(AKA EPSILON) from LA, spinning crazy dark techstep, including his own
original records and unreleased dubplates.

 Peace from the King Kong crew - Mudfoot and Slider



Jonathan Golub

 Filter Update)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Strongly disagree.  A strong component of the rave scene as long
as I have been in touch with it has been community values including
self-sufficiency, personal creative and intellectual expression, and
environmental consciousness.

It is a double edged sword, fame.  On the one hand, most of us are
happy to see artists whom we respect become more widely recognized.
On the other hand, the media spotlight and the machinery of fame
are decidedly at odds with the values mentioned above.

However, I am going to stop short of telling anyone what I think
they should do in light of this information, since that's what starts
flamewars.  I would suggest that anyone with a thought on this subject
should try to frame it in terms of what their community means to them
(in real terms, not just the PLUR mantra) and how the surging interest
in the scene is or is not compatible with their values.

Perhaps PLUR should be temporarily amended to "Patience Love Unity Respect"

Peace,
Scott

In-Reply-To: <970312220939_208782557@emout04.mail.aol.com>

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Brilliant post, Claudia.  I completely agree with you, and I also relate 
to how Wayne (a wonderful friend of mine) feels.   Evolution and change 
of ANYTHING is inevidable.  To try and go against what *IS* is 
impossible, stressful and depressing.  It is like trying to dam up a 
river by standing in the middle of it - it is just going to push against 
you and possibly knock you over. Isn't it easier to ride the current?  
You may not like the direction the river takes you, but there are little 
coves and tributaries in which to lurk off into (meaning underground 
parties).

The scene may not be exactly what you want it to be as more and more 
people become introduced, but you can be comforted to know that there are 
others out there who share your vision as to what the scene should be 
like and they throw the raves you attend.  So what if raving becomes the 
next trendiest thing?  I will still have parties like Warmth and 
Koinoneia to attend.  

I keep thinking of situations at raves where newcomers and 
"old-schoolers" alike exclaim how they wish the whole world could 
experience the positiveness of a rave - to feel the wonderfulness and 
love and spiritual energy that they do.  Hell, I wished that too!  And 
now that it looks like more and more of the general public *IS* being 
exposed to what we wanted them to be exposed to and WE ARE UNHAPPY ABOUT 
IT!!  Ever heard that phrase, "Be careful what you wish for, you just 
might get it?" 

I just say, as someone who has been in the scene since 1992 and has seen 
alot, to just go with it.  Nothing has happened yet and the same concerns 
were there 4 years ago that are here today.  Newcomers keep the scene 
fresh.  My new boyfriend just started raving 6 months ago and now he is 
planning on throwing his own party in September.  The newcomers keep 
things fresh, and re-open the eyes of people like me who need reminding 
every once in a while.

love,
Amy

I just wanted to add a little something to this that i learned in a class
at school. In this class we discuss a variety of issues, many of which are
highly inflammatory and emotionally charged. In the first class session we
layed down some ground rules to our discussion so as to promote honest,
positive and fruitful discussions, one of the ground rules that i think is
most important in a discussion is to focus on <what> is said and not <who>
said it, i hope that this makes sense to some of you in the context of
this discussion and maybe we can all sort of use this as a framework when
replying to and discussing emotional issues. towards a peaceful future =)
love tony

To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
From: "nathan.b.beckord" <nathan.b.beckord@ArthurAndersen.com>
Date: 13 Mar 97 16:17:01 
Subject: King Kong vs. Wish
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I think that now EVERY SINGLE PERSON who was at King Kong last night has now 
posted about it....all 5 of us.  j/k there were a few more people there, but 
the crowd was low density to be sure.

Started the evening out at Hamburger Mary's for some drinks pinball and dinner 
with several friends.  Afterwards, I took them to the Covered Wagon for King 
Kong around 10.  Super thin crowd, and they were tired, so they left right 
away.  I stayed on, and parked myself on top of one of the bass bins for 
awhile, grooved on the bass riffs hooks and snare patterns, then danced 
briefly, then left around 12:15.  

On the way home, around 12:30, I stopped by Wish to check it out.  IMO, the 
perfect sized crowd.  The music got me fired up to dance, which I had wanted to 
do all night but which wasn't really happening at KK.  And even though it's a 
little cubby, I gotta say I love the song Keep On Dancin', and the way the DJ 
mixed it up.  Also, I got a huge charge from the crowd that was there; many 
many happy faces and hi-energy dancing.  Finally left at 2, got to work today 
at 6:30, and boy does today suck!

The night definitely satiated the dance monster within, who rises up about 
every ten days and must be fed or he attacks and rots the core of the spirit

Bye folks 

Nathan


Cloud factory this wkend?   Ja/nein?

i turned on free radio berkeley a bit before 5:30 this evening and they
were playing some interesting music...  i heard some trip-hop, some Brian
Eno...

acoustic strings and a lite, fast unmistakably _jungle_ beat.

it was a wonderful piece of music.  any guesses as to the artist?  (they
said the name.  it sounded Indian but i couldn't really make it out.)

The calendar looks extra phat this week, with four events Friday and
*nine* events on Saturday (not even counting the weeklies).  A lot of them
look good too, so there's no excuse (except perhaps indecision from too many
choices!) not to go out this weekend.  I've been getting much info from
all directions this week, so thanks go out to all of you for keeping the 
list full!

    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Thursday, March 13rd - _Purifide_
   north bay monthly madness
   Mark E Quark, James, Ruben (SC).
   9pm-2am, 21+, $3. 107 4th St, Santa Rosa. 707.523.9545
   
   Friday, March 14th - Space Children presents an evening with Union Jack
   exclusive SF debut live performance by the UK's legendary Union Jack
   Daniel, Dutch, Graeme, Surge.
   10pm-???, $15. Cesar's Palace, 3140 Mission @ Cesar Chavez, SF.
   415.273.1622 510.461.SPACE
   
   Friday, March 14th - _Nikita 1 year anniversary_
   Derrick May, Supa DJ Dimitry, Henrik, Simon, DJ Micro (Caffeine NY),
   Taj, Baby Fox (ESP-Sun London), Felix the Dog.
   10pm-6am, 21+, $10. 1015 Folsom St, SF. 415.267.0568
   
   Friday, March 14th - _Believe_
   Siphon, MC^2 (Cloud Factory), Jonathan, Kamia (Ascendance).
   Visuals by Dionysus Dreams.
   more info email: LiQuiD7@cats.ucsc.edu.
   8pm-. UC Santa Cruz, College Eight, Santa Cruz. 408.460.1659
   
   Friday, March 14th - XLR8R release party
   Jon Williams, O.S.T.(live), Abstract vs. UFO, Disco Boy, Theta Blip,

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday afternoon 3pm-8pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of
       jungle, dub, breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight-3am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats,
       Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Friday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

heard... there's a few of those around, one is on Dropbeat Records (the
label is owned by the store), and it's very cool.  Only their 2nd or 3rd
release I think.  The other tune I heard that matchess the description is
by a group called "Sounds of Bengal" or something?  I've seen it at
Soundworks in the city.

The one thing that I do know about the parties in japan is that they don't even use flyers very 
much to promote.  They pass around 'flopy flyers' or do everything online through mailinglists 
and web sites.  I have seen some flopy flyers a few years ago, and wanted to do one but the 
costs were to high then, and now, with everyone having nett acces, it is no longer practicle to 
hand out diskc or cd's when you can just hand out your web address.  But back to the point, if 
you do get a chance to grab some of the lates Japaneese Rave Promo or anything like that, mabee 
you can bring it back and share it with us on the list.  I know I would certainly be interested.

Have a great time.

Keep it real
Ray Vonie

Subject: we have a difference of opinion
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Based on the knee-jerk flames I found in my mail box tonite, It seems many
of you see raving as entertainment.

I see it as community.

Entertainment is going to Shoreline Ampitheater to be "entertained."

Community is making something happen with your close friends in a living
room, warehouse, field or beach.

Too bad so many of you are unconsciously aligned with consumer culture --
it probably means you're missing the real magic of raving.

You don't "buy" it from BASS. You make it.

Received: from [207.33.94.145] (oak4-145.value.net [207.33.94.145]) by value.net (8.8.4/8.7.3) with SMTP id UAA28316; Thu, 13 Mar 1997 20:51:08 -0800 (PST)

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-mailer: Eudora Pro 2.1.3
Date: Thu, 13 Mar 1997 20:54:38 -0800
To: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne2@club.net>
From: bri@value.net (Brian Denny)
Subject: Re: we have a difference of opinion
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Wayne: exactly.

>You don't "buy" it from BASS. You make it.

so who is going to stop us from "making it?"  BASS?  the club kids?

they _can't_ stop us.  we create the vibe, we create the scene.

they can co-opt our music, they can co-opt anything they want.  that
doesn't mean we have to join them or disappear.

this community is not an inanimate object.  it is not even a being born
once and left to live and die.

it is _constantly_ being created and new life breathed into it.

Friends and Family, Koinonea, Rebel Alliance.  until people like these stop
deciding to create, the underground rave scene will live.

i'm not sure what your original post was trying to say:  was it a prophecy
of doom for the rave scene, or was it merely a warning that we must keep
creating?

the way i see it, a cynical, fatalistic "the scene is going to die"
attitude is to an extent a self-fulfilling prophecy.  on the other hand, if
we are aware that "You make it", meaning each and every one of us through
our attitudes and through our efforts, our community will live.

if anything, commercialized "raves" will simply draw those who don't wish
to contribute to our community out of it, while perhaps helping to bring
those who to wish to contribute into it.

i am not flaming you, i am merely trying to understand the apparent
contradiction between your cynicism and the positive, "You make it"
attitude that i have always considered you a proponent of.

please do clarify, rebutt, or respond as you see fit.

love,

brian

On Thu, 13 Mar 1997, Wayne D. Correia wrote:

> Based on the knee-jerk flames I found in my mail box tonite, It seems many
> of you see raving as entertainment.
> 
> I see it as community.

	There is a large degree of separation between the two as well.
There are a lot of free parties going on, put on by people who like to get
people together. One morning, I stuck around to help tear down speakers
and found that I kind of liked moving big speakers around and learning a
little about these things that make a lot of noise, but what I liked more
was talking with people and hanging out when I could hear what people were
saying or laughing about. And working with people gave me some type of
sense of who they were, what they were good at and so on and so forth.

> Entertainment is going to Shoreline Ampitheater to be "entertained."

	There is something weird in a world where one has to spend money
in order to "have fun". But then, I really cannot remember the last free
or under $10 underground (oops, no, sorry last I remember was Resolution). 
So maybe there is reason for this mass of people would want to be
"entertained".

> Community is making something happen with your close friends in a living
> room, warehouse, field or beach.

	I do not care if they are close friends, or people that I have
never met before - community is making something happen with the people
around you. Close friends come over a longer period of time as I get to
know people better, not just in a party setting, so I cannot say community
is about my close friends (but then, as I have moved into working full
time in the software world, my "close" friends get farther away, I guess
that's something I need to work on). And I do not feel right about saying
that community should be about my close friends because, it seems that
that closes out a lot of people that I have considered to be part of my
community, people I have worked with but have not spent much time with
outside of parties for one reason or another), maybe it's that commute I
which I would really like to shorten....

> Too bad so many of you are unconsciously aligned with consumer culture --
> it probably means you're missing the real magic of raving.

	One point here: its a magic of raving that some of attribute the
"expereince" of raving to. It's what I got out of raving (and for some
stupid reason, might be letting slip away because I cannot find a house
with enough room to store a sound system and be in a price range I can
afford, that isn't going to go surfing down a hill any closer than San
Jose. Ooops typical dave aside, sorry, back to the subject at hand). And
somehow some of us were swayed, like Wayne was. I was. Maybe those of us
who were swayed should ask ourselves why people are no longer swayed. What
is it that we are not doing?
	Maybe the "new" underground will shed some light on this, because
it seems the old underground has lost it...


> You don't "buy" it from BASS. You make it.

	And people made it. There was a beach party a couple weeks ago I
believe that people put together. Though I didn't really understand the
comment "I cannot believe this is free" - what else is a beach party?! 

dave

On Thu, 13 Mar 1997, Wayne D. Correia wrote:

> Based on the knee-jerk flames I found in my mail box tonite, It seems many
> of you see raving as entertainment.
> 
> I see it as community.

Then I think that we can agree...but im still gonna pay 30 bucks to see
the orb live! 

> 
> Entertainment is going to Shoreline Ampitheater to be "entertained."
> 
> Community is making something happen with your close friends in a living
> room, warehouse, field or beach.

and I also hope to go see the orb with some of my friends and see some of
my not so close friends, even smiling strangers there

> 
> Too bad so many of you are unconsciously aligned with consumer culture --
> it probably means you're missing the real magic of raving.
> 
> You don't "buy" it from BASS. You make it.
> 
> 
something related that I have been thinking about today, a friend was
going through my collection of .25 cent records and found an old woodstock
record, we got to talking about what happened to that scene and all the
ideals and momentum that movement had, why is it that that movement seems
dead to us? I realized that with woodstock2,  the whole thing
was officially dead and buried. the hippies sold out. But that is just
what I see on the surface. And that is what brings us to the main
question. What was the hippie movement all about? Why is SO much of a
movement defined by its music? Why is it that it is so hard to seperate
our community from the music we share together? Could it be that an
important step in our logic may be to make a distinction between the music
and the community. Honestly, I feel that even this is inadequate, Because
even in some big raves/parties/conceerts/<pick any (human social
event)=(any time you are not alone)> something called community can
happen. And I think that this is what is really important. We all see how
hard it gets to create a vibe the bigger and bigger a crowd gets. gee, why
is it that government and corporations usually suck so much? This is what
I feel is at the heart of so many of our social problems, no one really
knows how to get along. What I see as beautiful in the underground is
safe spaces created where we all can get along, with the hope that some
how we can learn to take some of this into the real world with us. I dont
see this hope dying out anytime soon, therefore I have no fear that the
underground will ever go away. But we need to know how to move beyond.
Learn how to constantly challenge ourselves to share what we find
while keeping it real. 
	What I am curious about is what has been
going on in the interim between the explosion in the sixties, and now
when we are experiencing something that feels similar. Or could it be just
living in the bay area makes one feel as if there were a renaissance in
motion. My experiencing with living most of my life on the east coast is
that there are ALOT, MANY, TREMENDOUS amount of unaware people...just
living a routine, desperate to keep their heads above water, or if not
always working, constantly being washed by the tv or some other device. 
but then again, this could just be my own cynicism coming out, maybe they
are just waiting for something real to come into their lives? Just asleep
until...???more questions than answers...tony

Bull Shit! 
The scene is completly alive! We are all living proof. The fact that
sfravers are so incredbily nice and lovable. SF is highly regarded on
the west coast as being the best. LA ravers would die for an SF Rave. I
went to OZ in LA. Everyone was saying how wonderful it was that an
actual SF raver wnated to rave in LA. They all wanted to come up here,
they kept telling us.

The scene is not dead. The scene may be falling, but that's as far as it
will ever go. True, it is falling, but it will NEVER hit bottom. We have
such a positive energey here in the underground portion of the rave
scene. A lot of massives may be lost to commercialization, but the
underground knows whats up!

I don't know about you, but I still have some faith in the scene. It may
be total crap now to some people. It may be falling. We can look at the
positive side of the scene falling!

What's so positive about the scene falling?

VIBE FILTERING!

Hopefully the scene will just blow up, and at the end we will see who
the people that are left standing are, and we can all start anew in a
better way. A more secret way. A even more underground way!
Once the scene goes overboard where (like in England) raves are illegal,
it will filter out all the bad vibes. Massives will be just as massive,
yet the flyers will be smaller or it may be word of mouth. COOL WORLD
will be forced to make smaller flyers (magazines) if they want to make
any money. Locations will get better and promoters will really really
really start to keep it underground.

I can't wait for that to happen. It will better our scene so much.
And I will be there in the new scene with everyone else.

Luvs&Hugs,
Paul

I went to Japan a few years ago. I think Japan is the one place where
I've never heard about raves happening there. Mostly I think cuz the
populace is pretty law abiding, ie not much in the way of underground or
illegal activities. And space is so valuable that there isn't many
places to be able to pull off a party. But the club scene is cool. And
the people are nice enough so it does have a vibe nontheless. I also
recomend SEGA owned arcades. They fucking rule there!!!!!!

Now SF Weekly is running excerpts of a new novel, "Ecstacy Club"

P.S.  ABC continues to run anti-drug shows, right now there's an
expose on pot growers.  Whenever they have an anti-drug "expert" on ,
it always seems to me that they're making the opposite point and not
realizing it.  Also, it appears that the
smoke-a-joint-and-lose-your-license law is about to end in Cal.  It
expired on Feb 28 and the only thing left to do is for the legislature
to pass a resolution repudiating the law in order to gain access to
federal highway funds (oh, the irony!).  The alternatives would be
renewing the provision, or losing the money (the federal government
requires states to pass smoke-a-joint laws or pass resolutions against
the provision in order to gain access to highway funds).

Well.. I must say that I seek to be entertained at raves.  These days,
I find watching the dj's pretty entertaining.  Either I'm getting old, 
or no- maybe its just...too many kids try to sell me shrooms.  
That shit just gets tiring.
I also look for kids that can breakdance.  That's pretty entertaining.
(no, I'm not trying to lead into another circle dance thread..)
A good speaker tweaker or two can also be pretty entertaining.

I'm starting to look at raving as artistry.  I see gesture in dance,
I see performance art in DJing, and I see a site installation in the
way the party is presented (space, lighting, etc.).

Okay.. I'll stop blabbing.
It's good to be back here.. although I see it's still up to 100msgs aday!

HEllo everyone!  I've missed you _all (if you _all are still here)

> dead to us? I realized that with woodstock2,  the whole thing
> was officially dead and buried. the hippies sold out. But that is just
> what I see on the surface. And that is what brings us to the main
> question. What was the hippie movement all about? Why is SO much of a

first of, an apology - i'm lifting this from your post almost totally
out-of-context.  just wanted to pass on something that i was told that
made sense to me.  i'm too young to know whether this is really the truth
or not, but it has that ring.

the 'hippies' (or other label-of-choice) who really changed their lives
and goals permanently in and after the sixties are _not_ the people you
hear spouting off about it today.  they are also not the people who pulled
woodstock out of the closet, tattooed a pepsi logo on it, and beat it like
a dead horse.  the 'hippies' dropped out of the cold war's military and
corporate power structure, either for good or for a long time.  

today's profitteers and self-appointed spokespeople for the '60s are by and
large the people who stayed in the mainstream of american society through
the sixties, watching but not participating in the counterculture.  they
got ahead while others got back to nature etc. and now they are the elite
class which gets to write the official history - CEO's, politicians,
university professors, and so forth.

which, i suppose, means that in twenty years i'll have the pleasure of
hearing today's business school students and student body presidents get
on 'nightline' and tell me why the pacifier and whistle were emblematic of
end-of-millenium generation-x discontent.  i can hardly wait.
matt.

>its workers a film aimed at encouraging the use of safety goggles on
>the job. According to Industrial Machinery News, the film's depiction
>of gory industrial accidents was so graphic that twenty-five workers
>suffered minor injuries in their rush to leave the screening room.
>Thirteen others fainted, and one man required seven stitches after he
>cut his head falling off a chair while watching the film.
>
>- ------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>The Chico, California, City Council enacted a ban on nuclear weapons,
>setting a $500 fine for anyone detonating one within city limits.
>
>- ------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>A bus carrying five passengers was hit by a car in St. Louis, but by the
>time police arrived on the scene, fourteen pedestrians had boarded the
>bus and had begun to complain of whiplash injuries and back pain.
>
>- ------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>Swedish business consultant Ulf af Trolle labored 13 years on a book
>about Swedish economic solutions.  He took the 250-page manuscript to
>be copied, only to have it reduced to 50,000 strips of paper in seconds
>when a worker confused the copier with the shredder.
>
>- ------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>A convict broke out of jail in Washington D.C., then a few days later
>accompanied his girlfriend to her trial for robbery.  At lunch, he went
>out for a sandwich.  She needed to see him, and thus had him paged.
>Police officers recognized his name and arrested him as he returned to
>the courthouse in a car he had stolen over the lunch hour.
>
>- ------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>When two service station attendants in Ionia, Michigan, refused to hand
>over the cash to an intoxicated robber, the man threatened to call the
>police. They still refused, so the robber called the police and was
>arrested.
>
>- ------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
>A Los Angeles man who later said he was "tired of walking," stole a
>steamroller and led police on a 5 mph chase until an officer stepped
>aboard and brought the vehicle to a stop.
>
>~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>
>(These are real examples from real resumes)
>
>--Here are some qualifications for you to overlook:
>
>REASONS FOR LEAVING THE LAST JOB:
>--Responsibility makes me nervous.
>--They insisted that all employees get to work by 8:45 every
>  morning. Couldn't work under those conditions.
>--Was met with a string of broken promises and lies, as well as
>  cockroaches.
>--I was working for my mom until she decided to move.
>--The company made me a scapegoat - just like my three previous
>employers.
>
>JOB RESPONSIBILITIES:
>--While I am open to the initial nature of an assignment, I am
>  decidedly disposed that it be so oriented as to at least partially
>  incorporate the experience enjoyed heretofore and that it be
>  configured so as to ultimately lead to the application of more
>  rarefied facets of financial management as the major sphere of
>  responsibility.
>--I was proud to win the Gregg Typting Award.
>
>SPECIAL REQUESTS & JOB OBJECTIVES:
>--Please call me after 5:30 because I am self-employed and my
>  employer does not know I am looking for another job.
>--My goal is to be a meteorologist.  But since I have no training
>  in meteorology, I suppose I should try stock brokerage.
>--I procrastinate - especially when the task is unpleasant.
>
>PHYSICAL DISABILITIES:
>--Minor allergies to house cats and Mongolian sheep.
>
>PERSONAL INTERESTS:
>--Donating blood.  14 gallons so far.

>SMALL TYPOS THAT CAN CHANGE THE MEANING:
>--Education:  College, August 1880-May 1984.
>--Work Experience:  Dealing with customers' conflicts that arouse.

>  operation.

>Ivory Coast mobs kill 3 alleged sorcerers in penis scare
> March 8, 1997
>Web posted at: 3:00 p.m. EST
>
> ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast (Reuter) -- Angry mobs have burned or  beaten to
>death at least three alleged sorcerers in Ivory  Coast's commercial capital
>of Abidjan, after a shrinking or  disappearing-penis scare spread from
>neighboring Ghana.
>
> Such reports are not uncommon in West or Central Africa.  Purported
>victims often blame handshakes with sorcerers. At  least 12 men were killed
>in Ghana in January by mobs accusing  them of making penises shrink or
>vanish.
>
> Police in Ghana and Ivory Coast dismiss the phenomenon as a  ploy by
>thieves to cause a crowd to form so they can rob  people. Some victims say
>sorcerers touch them and make their  penises shrink or vanish to extort
>cash in return for a cure.
>
>Copyright 1997 Reuters Limited. All rights reserved.

>Bull Shit! 
>The scene is completly alive! We are all living proof. The fact that
>sfravers are so incredbily nice and lovable. SF is highly regarded on
>the west coast as being the best. LA ravers would die for an SF Rave. I
>went to OZ in LA. Everyone was saying how wonderful it was that an
>actual SF raver wnated to rave in LA. They all wanted to come up here,
>they kept telling us.

Well..  For some people, the scene dies all the time.. Then it just
comes back alive again.  It's all relative.  Everybody goes through
the typical rave stages. 

1  Wow, everything is soo cool and positive.  I like the fancy lights 
and popsicles.

2.  I'm starting to meet everyone... I love you all.

3.  Now its time to make hats and sell them, become a dj, or start promoting.

4.  Now youre sick of it.. The scene is dead..everyone is shady..  You start
talking shit.

5.  It's been a year and a half and you've found new light in the scene

6. You're back.

And the cycle keeps repeating itself.  Its so easy to get burnt out.. Isnt it?

>The scene is not dead. The scene may be falling, but that's as far as it
>will ever go. True, it is falling, but it will NEVER hit bottom. We have
>such a positive energey here in the underground portion of the rave
>scene. A lot of massives may be lost to commercialization, but the
>underground knows whats up!

What are you talking about?  Massives.. Commercialization.. same thing.
But who ever said commercialism was bad?  Every raver takes part in
their own "commercial" economy.  If you've paid money to get into a rave, 
you've taken part in some form of commercialism.

I guess its just annoying to see my 'secret society' become the 11 oclock news, 
and a new marketing scheme for Virgin.. But whatever..IT's good to see hard
working artists finally get what they deserve.  God bless em... 

>I don't know about you, but I still have some faith in the scene. It may
>be total crap now to some people. It may be falling. We can look at the
>positive side of the scene falling!
>
>What's so positive about the scene falling?

Then we can just go bowling or to the movies on Saturday.

>VIBE FILTERING!
>
>Hopefully the scene will just blow up, and at the end we will see who
>the people that are left standing are, 

Promoters.. With fat cash falling out of their pockets.
Dj's.. With silver shiny coats and space age sunglasses

> and we can all start anew in a
>better way. A more secret way. A even more underground way!

I don't think there is such a thing as underground anymore.
Which reminds me.. SOme one remarked about Godfather at the last
one track mind and said he was playing shit that you hear on the radio.
I said...  Oh really.

>Once the scene goes overboard where (like in England) raves are illegal,
>it will filter out all the bad vibes. Massives will be just as massive,
>yet the flyers will be smaller or it may be word of mouth. COOL WORLD
>will be forced to make smaller flyers (magazines) if they want to make
>any money. Locations will get better and promoters will really really
>really start to keep it underground.

Oh.. Cool World.  Weren't they the ones that put a commercial on the radio?
And how can locations get better?  What we need to do is get the
government to subsidize raving..  You know.. It heals cancer and all that..

>I can't wait for that to happen. It will better our scene so much.
>And I will be there in the new scene with everyone else.

New scene.. Old scene.. It's all the same scene.
You know whats scary.. WHen you start singing a Smiths song
at a rave and the person next to you finishes the next verse.

Anyway, I hope I didn't offend anyone.  If you don't know me, I'm generally 
sarcastic- but not jaded.  I still love going out when I can...

-Jon

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id XAA21836; Thu, 13 Mar 1997 23:07:25 -0800 (PST)

Date: Thu, 13 Mar 1997 22:53:45 -0600
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Jason Heltne <jdheltne@dcn.davis.ca.us>
Subject: TXRAVES: Florida report
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Got this off the FLraves list.

>*********************************************
>
>From: Rebecca Moss <rmoss@ucet.ufl.edu>
>To: fl-raves@cat.net
>Subject: fl-raves: Transcript of Capitol Report story on anti-rave
>legislation 
>Sender: owner-fl-raves@cat.net
>Reply-To: fl-raves@cat.net
>
>
>Correction of my last post--Sorry, it's the House regulated services
>committee, not the regulatory committee.  duh!)
>
>
>The latest import from Britain has Florida teens dancing all night.  No,
>it's not the Beatles or any other musical group--it's called a rave and
>police say the all-night dance parties are a haven for drugs.  Now, state
>lawmakers are hoping to slow organizers down by restricting where raves
>can be held.  Buzz Conover reports.
>
>The phenomenon known as raves began in England with tens of thousands of
>party goers meeting in valleys across the English countryside to dance and
>get high.  Police were finally able to close the huge parties down by
>surrounding the valleys and moving in.  So far law enforcement has not
>come across any parties of that size in this country, but they say that
>parties with over one thousand teens are common. Florida is not the first
>state to experience raves, but they are popular in the Sunshine State,
>with Orlando and Tampa being considered the benchmark areas.  It's not the
>all-night partying that has people worried, though.  Rampant and open use
>of drugs such as XTC, LSD, and others has adults, including state
>representative John Moroni up in arms: "If you're not familiar with what a
>rave is, it is an underground movement which gathers large numbers of
>young people at secret locations for all-night dance parties. And raves
>have become a haven for drugs. And they are not sock hops, they are not
>dance clubs, they're nothing but drugs, there is nothing but drugs there."
>
>The raves usually do not start until midnight and often last many hours
>past dawn.  Because of their size, raves are often held in vacant
>warehouses, civic centers, and even fairgrounds.  But one of the most
>widely used locations in Florida at least are bars and other clubs after
>they close for the night.  Those locations are popular with organizers
>because they are equipped to handle crowds and have a sound system for the
>music already built in.  Captain Bruce Ashley is an agent with the State
>division of alcoholic beverages and tobacco.  He says the 13-18 year olds
>who attend raves are not going to drink--they are going to get high.  And
>information about the highs available at the raves is no more than the
>click of a button away: "It's very much a dollar-driven business at this
>point in time.  The advertising for these events, as found on the
>Internet, tells about every drug that's gonna be available at raves.  It
>tells you how to obtain it, it tells you how to use it, it tells you what
>are the side effects, what to mix it with to enhance the experience of the
>drugs, and every bit of this material is found on the Internet, under the
>title 'Rave.'"
>
>Authorities estimate there are 40,000 Internet Rave sites, but tracking
>the organizers is difficult.  Capt. Ashley says the lure of organizing a
>rave is a simple one: money, and there is plenty of it to be made,
>according to him: "the range of fees required of young people to enter
>these events has been between five and forty dollars.  To go in the door
>of a rave event in Florida.  So, if you took the very general, middle of
>the road type event, and you had a thousand attendees at a given rave, if
>they were charging twenty dollars at the door, that's twenty thousand
>dollars of cash put through the door into the promoters pocket."
>
>The House Regulated Services Committee is hoping to crack down on raves by
>prohibiting the after hours renting of a facility which holds a liquor
>license.  Capt. Ashley has said that the bill which has passed the
>committee is not a cure-all, but it is a start: "I don't think we are
>going to stop all the rave activity based upon a bill that prohibits them
>at a licensed premises.  Obviously we've already got some occurring in
>non-licensed premises. There's regulatory law, nuisance statutes,
>drug-related statutes that can address a non-licensed premises, probably a
>local city council or county commission's power to abate or revoke an
>occupational or some other type of license may better attack that problem.
>But obviously, the majority today are being held on licensed premises." 
>
>Law enforcement officials say stopping the rave phenomenon is further
>complicated by the fact that when one party is closed down, often the rave
>just moves to a predetermined alternative site.  The next stop for the
>anti-rave measure is the floor of the House for a debate and a final vote.
>
>For Florida Public Radio, I'm Buzz Connover.
>--
>Then, musical interlude that is a bit of Dee-lite's "Groove is in the
>Heart" before the next news segment!
>
>
>
>

I _hate_ Spin magazine.  Now, for those who know me, you know it takes a 
lot to get me to dislike an entity.  But Sin really did it.  And as if 
you want to hear the story, here's why:

One night I was watching that show Politically Incorrect and they had a 
panel of various folks talking about why LSD was so great.  This panel 
included the head editor of Spin.  Now this guy looked like your typical 
gen-x-er, but he had some attitude on him.  He was happy to tell everyone 
that he had never used any drugs (though he later admitted to quite a 
caffine addiction) and he went on about some BS.  Okay, then this other 
panelist says that LSD was made illegal by the government, just like 
everything else that is found to be fun, like pot, ecstacy..
AND AT THIS POINT that worm from Spin says, "Yeah, but Ecstacy makes you 
listen to really bad music!" and the crowd cracks up laughing.  

OKAY if this isn't bad enough

About a month ago, SPIN does this article.. THE COVER STORY about how 
techno and various electronic music is the new hip thing!

GET YOUR ATTITUDE STRAIGHT AND STOP TRYING TO CHASE DOLLARS, SPIN!

Either you like the stuff or you don't.  Stop insulting our scene.

To: rayvonie@ix.netcom.com
From: dreamer@ziplink.net (Starchild)
Subject: Rave Busts/Libertarian Party Meeting
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com, sfr-legal@saturn5.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear Ravefriends,

        In response to Ray Vonie and others who are probably wondering, the
Wednesday evening discussion of rave bust issues unfortunately didn't
happen.

        First, to my knowledge only about five people besides Chikako and I
showed up -- not even the few folks who said they'd be there showed, which
was kind of disappointing.  Complicating this was my mistake in not getting
a specific time slot for the rave topic.  A matter of internal Libertarian
Party politicking about the relationship between the local, state, and
national organizations ended up taking a HUGE amount of time, and the
ravers who showed up didn't want to sit around for hours, not that I blame
them!

        If there'd been a larger turnout, we could have requested and
gotten time for our topic, but I didn't feel right trying to cut short the
business of the party for which around 25 people showed up, to deal with an
issue primarily of interest to only a handful of us.

        I'm still intending to work on bringing people together on this
issue however.  Perhaps I was a little naive to expect a lot of ravers to
come out on a weeknight to a non-party event.  Next time I think I'll try
planning a potluck social at my place or some other location where we can
listen to music and have some fun besides talking politics and legal
strategy, and contact more people about the meeting on an individual basis.

        Another thing I'm thinking about is compiling a city-by-city
database of what the laws and requirements are pertaining to holding dance
events, what the practical steps are you must take, and who are the people
you have to go through.  Once we identify the pressure points, and spread
the information around, we can bring pressure to bear on them.

        If there are any volunteers for doing research on specific Bay Area
cities, I'll happily accept any knowledge gained and put it in some kind of
organized form to distribute back to everyone.

        I also know there's been plenty of discussion in this area on
SFRaves over the years, so that information would be in the archives.
Would doing a keyword search to retrieve useful and relevant posts from our
collective past be practical?

        Other ideas?  Steve S., Leftjab, Adder, Diane T., anyone?

May the bass be with us,
                                        <<< Starchild >>>

Subject: Re: The Scene Is Dead? (Ultra Vivid Scene)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SUN.3.91.970314020934.24400B-100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.96.970314044049.20867B-100000@capt.hooked.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

one night as me and a friend and another friend took these little square
pieces of paper which made us laugh horrendously (must have been the
content) for hours we were having fun poking fun at some of the
scenesters...no one here, don't worry.  but just sayin shit like

"oh, i've been in the scene longer than you have..."

"im from [such and such a town]..."

"oh, i know that song..."

i think what was really funny though was the fact that we ended up having
to sit up all night in my little tiny bedroom in a 1 bedroom apt...with my
roommate and his "friend" trying to sleep in the next room and my
neighbors in their bedroom, which was right next to my bedroom, on the
other side of us.  

and then it happened.  

i tried to stray away from rave music and pop in this cd called "Ultra
Vivid Scene"

anyone ever heard of it?  

well, one of my friends started pointing out how much of a joke this cd
was.  it had like all these jesus christ religiious symbols on it that i
never even noticed because i never went to church or sunday school or
anything like that, but at the same time it had like drills nstuff (hi
jeff!) on it...and we all just started busting up and then it goes back to
that 

"oh, i know that song"

because at the time we all were sort of burned out on the scene.  

so we switched to the ultra vivid scene.  

july 1994
santa cruz, ca

Bon Appetit!  :>

Is this some type of elaborate ploy to start up more underground 
events???

Following this thread, it's true that the scene stays and it's the 
people who change... A few friends and myself spent several hrs last 
night wandering the hills, 'staking' an east bay location for another 
renegade (on a state park, of all things).

As long as there is a drive for positve events. As long as priorities 
are in place ( I.e. why are you going / throwing this party?). As long 
as it's understood that this is a community and not just random faces 
in the crowd ( and only YOU can make a party a community event).
That's is what makes the vibe,  that's what keeps us alive...

it's in the middle of nowhere (And right on the outskirts of a major 
city).  Hope to see you there in April...

Wayne D. Correia wrote:
> That's why I specifically recommended people have parties in their homes,
> in fields, and random places with their friends: to create.
> 
Wayne is totally right....its known as DIY....Do It Yourself. And I see
this happening all over... we all know the scene is NOT dead or dying.
As any entity grows and evolves it becomes more complex by nature.
Accept it.
The DIY culture brings ravers back to their roots...or the core of why
we rave....the music, the people, the spiritual energy. (and so much
else :) 
 Please see Ecstasy.org for some relavent info:
http://www.ecstasy.org/party.html

More and more often these days as pessimistic peeps cry about how the
scene is being exploited (I won't argue with that, though) and how it is
dying or being ruined...I see others putting so much love, time, energy
and $$ back into the scene and generating new levels of energy and
throwing events that are as unfuckin'believably amazing as the last one
you thought couldn't be topped. Illustration: I have been raving for at
least 5 years now...and I still walk out of a space bleary eyed at 7am
saying to myself and others...holy shit..that was the best nite ever! 
  I don't mean to ramble off on a tangent....but this all comes down to
a key aspect of our society...too many people just take and take and
don't give back. (read: not giving a shit)
Don't get me wrong...I'm not saying every raver out there should throw
their own party to "give back" to the scene because they owe it...just
that we need to stop and remember that the world is made up of
people...and raving doesn't happen by itself. It takes a lot of hard
work by alot of people to put together an event...as all you SFRavers
know already. All I'm saying is that 5 people can't do the work for the
rest of the crowd. Everyone should contribute in their own personal
way...
anywaze...I'm done now. everyone have a super wknd...this one looks like
it will be amazing...(again!!)
PLUR,
ari

Tony,

  You said a lot of interesting things which makes me think about where
"we've"
been and where "we're" going.... Have you ever read Hess's Journey To
the East?
It is an appropriate statement on what always goes on in society -
particularly
large media fed ones like ours ( some would say lead by the nose ).
Namely
when the going is easy and the media ( or even or local leaders etc )
convince
us that we are making "progress" we all buy into it - pat ourselves on
the back
and believe we are making that progress.  But many people aren't really
on the
"journey" (at least in a conscious way ) or they lose their connection
to the
journey. Then they think the journey "stopped"....

  So it was with the 60's - we were ALL making "social progress" and
exploring
the limits of consciousness. That's the media bull shit... the actual
story was
that some were on a mainstream journey to consciousness expansion and
many of
these continued: Ram Dass, Leary, Wavey Gravey, Al Huang, Paul Horn,
Lilly,
and Santana. Also, local leaders like Rev. C. Williams etc. found values
there. 
They haven't "sold out"....  Others, unfortunately, were never on the
"journey" -
they never really "got it" so there was nothing to sell out.... but they
did
party a lot, listened to great music, got really high and got laid a lot
;-)

  Unfortunately, many in our scene are the same... they're in it to be
"entertained"
by the music or to get high or whatever... but they see no journey in it
all.
The good thing about the 60's was it caused many people to explore many
things
beyond the music - religion, art, philosophy etc. It was really these
mind/soul
expanding juorneys that worked. The music was not enough - although
music was an
important part especially for people like Santana or Paul Horn. Over and
over again 
I hear people within the scene saying " it's ONLY about the music - I'll
see you on
the dance floor"... if all we are doing is throwing big parties, getting
high,
and being entertained by music then it won't be enough. Others in the
scene, do
rituals, make art or alters, explore philosopy etc. These people are
begining a
lifelong journey that leads "to the "East" "... it's not really about a
place - it's
about a way of being. 

  So like all periods of expansion - we have "crowds" of people bubbling
about how
they have "found it"... THE JOURNEY... but if that journey isn't about
deep
connections with life and feeding the spirit within - it won't be enough
- it 
won't sustain itself. Thus, when many of the people I now see on the
dancefloor
are my age ( giving them a couple of decades ) they won't even remember
why they
liked techno and dancing so much.... just visions of lost youth - stupid
shit you
do when you're too young to know any better.  Others will smile about
how their
journey started - as I smile now about taking LSD and reading Be Here
Now 25 years
ago. Some get it - others don't... we all have freedom to do what we
want.... That's
how it is and how it's always been....

  BTW the concious expansion of the 60's was NOT unique other than TV/
media coverage
or hype. There was the "new thought" movement in the early 1900's ( read
S. Lewis
Elmer Gantry ) which was like the "new age" movement of the 60's. There
were the
gay 90's or the flapper era.... all of these had aspects like the
60's... it always
cycles. And I thank god for the "house movement" because it is the cycle
of
conciousness expansion ( just like the 60's ) that came after the "blah"
eighties.

Just my thoughts,

Mike


-- 
     Mike Clay      meclay@ix.netcom.com    (415) 572-8971
**** Alone and Ecstatic a young rainbow learns to levitate. ****

> RE: LA-303
> 
> For sale Sears Craftsman 'SKILL' saw Model LA-303.
> 
> Unlike the original which used an acid dipped SAWTOOTH
> blade and discrete components, this model uses telekinetics
> to cut through the toughest of minds.
> ...

Actually, a variable speed SKILL saw with a contact microphone
attached run through a 24db/octave filter is an excellant idea, and
certainly not a joke at all. I would also add a vice-like handled
screw to the bolt that tightens down the circular blade to add or
decrease non-linear harmonics. You could take a piece of steel and
touch it against the spinning blade for amazing sounds. Then take a
wheel/drum with knobs on it, like a music box drum, that would switch
on and off the trigger of the saw in rhythimic patterns to use as a
pattern sequencer and your complete. Just shift the drum up and down
for different patterns, and vary the saw speed for
transpositions. I'll bet it would sound better than Roland's new
"SuperSaw" wave on the JP-8000. Talk about real analog ...

I once played Ford mufflers in a band. I had five of them cut to
different sizes mounted and processed by micromoog (4-pole) and an
old analog delay. Ford mufflers sounded much better then Chevys. 

Are my black roots showing?

=Darrel
darrele@netcom.com

	**--LOCATION--**
	U.C. Santa Cruz campus, College Eight Dinning Facility
	Take all freeways from the BayArea to Highway 17 South
	Go over the SantaCruz mountains and take Highway 1 North Exit
	Go straight at 1st light, make RIGHT at 2nd light (Mission St.)
	Go straight through 3 lights, make a RIGHT on the 4th (Bay St.)
	Go through 2 lights. You'll see a big barn on the left corner
	Park in the lot by the barn! Thats the base of the campus...

	Now cross the street to the shuttle/bus stop and catch the
	shuttle (preferably a "Night Perimeter" shuttle its free)
	And ride it all the way around campus to COLLEGE EIGHT!

	Get off, cross the street (going downhill) and go down a big
	flight of stairs and the party's on your immediate right!

	**--PS--**
	You gotta park off campus in the barn lot and take the shuttle 
	because without a parking permit you cant get on campus through
	the gaurd gates after 8pm, if you come before 8 you can come in
	park at College Eight and not worry about shuttle riding and
	getting to your car later! We'll be around to help people finding
	their way and getting to their cars, ill give ya a ride! ;)

Inspired by the stages of the raver, on some other post I pressent you the 
raver personality guide. Edition 1

Come on admit it, you all old folks out there you were once a:

SEPTEMBER CHILD!

How to spot one; All their gear is new. Clean shoes, brand new addidas 
		back pack, perfect parting everytime (Female)

Where to find them: In every big underground, and clubs.

They always appear: Just after the summer, either they got introduced in 
		the holidays or at the beginning at the quarter of their
		 first year in university.

Internet characteristics: Their account has edu behind it.
			Their post consists of Lot of "I Love you all"
			"It was so fluffy and PLURry." "I have never had 
			friends like this.	

Pros: They are great to look at. They give you candy. They make you smile 
because you have lost that innocence.

Cons: THey're hella annoying when you're pissed off and recieve an email 
from them, eg. "It's all above love. peace" In other words what you say 
don't count."

They don't know the difference between trance and breakbeat 
if it hit them. SO they resort to posts on NNR things.

What they become: Usually they drop out of the mailing list and you never 
hear of them again because the e has worn off. 

They become cynical and complains like the rest of us, after being 
flamed one too many times, and been ripped off and given crap drugs, and 
gone to bum parties..

Don't feel bad this is YOU! Everyone gets thier turn.....

To be continued........

Coming raver personalities: The grouch, The DJ, The Drug dealer, The Old 
skooler, The 43 still-happy-and-raving old skooler, The about to burn out 
raver, the born again raver (Straight edge from now on) etc....

10 REASONS WHY SCOOBY DOO WAS A DRUG INFLUENCED CARTOON

1. SCOOBY AND SHAGGY were always being freaked out by ghost and ghouls,
but no one else saw them before Scoob and Shaggy.

2. Scooby and Shaggy always had the munchies.

3. Shaggy always thought Scooby was talking and was the only one who could
hear him and understand him.

4. Scooby and Shaggy always fell into the trap that was intended for the
monster because they were tripping over themslves and couldn't see where
they were going.


5. They were always deluded and warped by thinking they were dressed iup
up in some costumes and entertained the monster.

6. Shaggy always said :"like" to the extreme, i.e. "like ZOINKS, scoob,
let's get outta here!!" what's a ZOINK?

7. Scooby and Shaggy were alwas the ones in the back of the van (doing you
know what).

8. They drove arouynd in the MYSTERY MACHINE which had that weird trippy
design on it's side.

9. Shaggy and Scooby were always giddy and laughing.

10. Look at Shaggy. The way he dressed, him goatee, etc, 'nuff said.

although i'm a great believer in third party politics and grassroots
democracy as someone who has worked on ralph nader's campaign last year,
including organizing a rally for third party candidates and a variety of
other progressive grassroots projects over the years, i want to suggest
that this effort shouldn't tangle itself in the politics of any third
party. there is a lot that can be done to research permitting at the
planning commission (good place to start), form a grassroots coalition,
start a petition/initiative drive, put out letters to the editor and
press releases, organize volunteers, etc. later, once this basic work
has started and you're onto coalition building, you might then approach
a variety of organizations, political and apolitical, to get their
support, esp. neighborhood groups, and by approaching them all you won't
be alienating any potential base of support. i've got some stuff on the
web describing a coalition (coalition for sustainable neighborhoods) we
organized to oppose the burger king in the sunset. might be interesting
to look at. 
-- 
Andrew Nemec
            _

 / _ \ '_ \| |/ __|       Voice/Fax: 415-641-5857
|  __/ |_) | | (__        WWW: http://www.sirius.com/~anemec

E N T E R P R I S E S     mission-critical applications and systems

Hi all you wacky wavers!!!   =]

A friend of mine, a university professor with special interests in
ethnomusicology, has asked me if I can provide a short description
(10-20 words) of "What is a rave?" I thought this was such an
interesting question that I'd throw it out to you all to see what
kind of answers we'd get. (All she's heard so far from students
she's asked is "A drug-fest", which I think is a very unsatisfactory
answer).

So.....

                    What is a rave?


Love and hugs!!!

okay here are 10-15 words that explain a "rave" to me:

family, community, acceptance, music, dance, ritual, spirituality, a
release, CHANGE, expansion, positivity-negativity, me, my friends(now,
past and future)and grunge...well most of the time. :P

some additives:
waking up at 4 in the afternoon,
trying to find a (natural) way to stay up past 4 a.m.
expansion of my mind 
soooooo many different ideals and ideologies under one roof...in harmony
an introduction to sooo many new and different things
and lastly...
	......people

i'm not trying to be cheesy here...but it seems to be coming out that
way.

I mean it must mean SOMETHING (or a few things) to me...i've been doing
it for 6 years now. and YES i do get very jaded at times..but like
someone said..it's all a circle.

a RAVE or THE scene is by no means perfect but it has given me a lot and
really helped make me the person i am today.  Which, trust me, is a MUCH
better person than i was 6 years ago.

:)
dan

hello all,
just another little note sent out to you, to tell you all that i love you
it's friday friday friday, a beautiful friday at that, and i want to
spread my happiness to all y'all so i have composed a happy thought to
bring
smiles to your lips.

once upon a time, there was an enormous group of people and they all liked
to engage in many fun activities. listening to music, feeling, sharing and
spreading a groovelicious vibe, and surrounding people with unconditional
love and happiness was what they are all about. within each person grew an
extraordinary spirit. playing on the grass, basking in the sun, dancing,
hugging, kissing, smiling and laughing, people were carefree, not a worry
in their heads. flowers were blooming, butterflies playing tag, buzzing
bees and ladybugs, sun shining down on their heaven on earth, a cool
breeze blowing gently. they played on into the night when all the stars
began to show their brights and the adventures continued on. comets soared
throught the sky and were wished upon asking the gods to never let this
end, to continue to play and unite and come together with their community,
forgetting all the icky-poo stuff and concentrationg solely on good.
people wrapped themselves and their loved ones in warm yummy blankets,
crowding around a warm fire with enough room for everybody as the beats
keep pounding, pounding pounding.things that they didn't have to worry
about: money, drug overdoses, unhappiness, hate, stolen items, and not
having enough water. oh, and there were plenty of crayons and paper and
fingerpaint and bubbles and lots and lots of toys to play with and stuffed
animals and tents made out of blankets and branches, and trees to climb
and a pond to swim in and oh, all that other fun stuff. and this went on
forever and everyone was happy...
okay, so it's not realistic, but definitely ideal. as longs as i'm
surrounded by my friends, anything is good. 
everybody, go out and have a superb weekend, always play safe and take
care of the people you love. 
sugarkisses and all that other fun stuff,
***stariana***

Victoria-

I thought I might let you know about Hyperreal, if you're not already
aware.

> I want to show the world that ravers have talent.

The implication being that www.hyperreal.com does not indicate this?

Hyperreal is a very high-profile site.  Besides the recent messages to the
list about Hyperreal in the news, we have has been getting press for some
time now -- at one point, a Hyperreal staffer's homepage was the cover
photo of USA Today's Life section. 

Also, check out www.hyperreal.com/artists/.  There you'll find a listing
of Hyperreal staffers who do more than hack up webpages and listen to
techno :)

Please note that the intent of this message is to inform you that there
are others who share your goal and that massive numbers of people each day
are getting a really positive take on this whole rave thing.  My apologies
if it came off otherwise.

If there's one place that is giving ravers a good name, it has to be
Hyperreal.  With all the "cyber-ness" going on in the media, it's a little
odd that 20/20 didn't mention us.  I guess it also makes sense though
since they wanted to show a bunch of kids indiscriminantly popping pills
and not educating themselves about these substances -- the drug archives
is one of Hyperreal's most popular sections.

	Sami
