Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

As usual, folks, the hyperreal web-site (the FAQ) has some good info on
this subject (editing could make it less than 20 words):


What is a "rave"?

The term "rave" has been overused almost to the point of losing its
meaning. The word has always meant (according to
webster):

    1.rave \'ra-v\ vb [ME raven]
              1a: to talk irrationally in or as if in delirium
              1b: to declaim wildly
              1c: to talk with extreme enthusiasm
              2: to move or advance violently : STORM : to utter in madness
or frenzy
       rav.er
    2.rave n often attrib
              1: an act or instance or raving
              2: an extravagantly favorable criticism

In general practice, a "rave" usually refers to a party, usually all night
long, open to the general public, where loud "techno"
music is mostly played and many people partake in a number of different
chemicals, though the latter is far from necessary.
The number of people at the event is unimportant; it can range from 50
people to 25,000 people. The cost of attendance is
also unimportant - there have been good raves and bad raves at both ends of
the cost spectrum (though in practice, the higher
the price, the more commercial the event, and the lower the quality). At a
rave, the DJ is a shaman, a priest, a channeller of
energy - they control the psychic voyages of the dancers through his choice
in hard-to-find music and their skill in
manipulating that music, sometimes working with just a set of beats and
samples, into a tapestry of mindbending music. A
large part of the concept of raves is built upon sensory overload - a
barrage of audio and very often visual stimuli are brought
together to elevate people into an altered state of physical or
psychological existence.



The "Vibe"

The actual concept of raves is not new - it is as old as time itself. As
the base level, raves are very comparable to American
Indian religious ceremonies, i.e. pow-wows, and also to the concept of the
Shaman in Eskimo and Siberian society - where
music is the key towards pulling oneself into a unique emotional and
psychological state, a state in which one experiences
washes of sensations and visions, not delusions, but visions. Sounds very
hokey in print, but I'm sure MANY of you out
there know what I'm talking about. The hypnotizing effect of techno music
coupled with the seemless transitions and
thematic progressions of rave DJ's as the night progresses can be QUITE
intoxicating, resulting in what could be closely
compared to a religious experience. Music in general has always been able
to sweep people off their feet, but what
distinguishes raves are the concept of the _shared_ experience; a feeling
of unity often arises, and people are open and
friendly to one another. There is a loss of that "attitude" that is
omnipresent in normal clubs and even in life in general.
People are celebrated for who they are, not what they aren't. There are
many better ways to explain the above, and more than
a few can be found at the web site. For a better, blow-by-blow description
of what an actual rave is like, please check check
out the "The Ecstatic Cybernetic Amino Acid Test", an article that appeared
in the San Francisco Examiner in February 1992,
and is perhaps one of the most comprehensive surveys of the rave scene ever
to appear in print.

leftjab

Dear Dan,

It seems that a lot of people have been depressed recently.
I have noticed that a widespread darkness has increased since the night that
the planets ligned up, marking the age of Aquarius.

I am not kidding.

Some say that we are going through a period of darkness and uncertainty that
precedes the golden age of humanity.

Some say that this period has been predicted by different religious
scriptures and kooky foreseers, and is likewise suggested in the
pseudofictional work "The Celestine Prophecy".

We are becoming closer to our spiritual nature; yet we are confused about
the impending light; and thus we are more agitated, depressed & violent. It
is the reverse of "the calm before the storm."

I am feeling like one agitated, fidgety-finger mother these days.

I have a friend called Judy who is an Aquarius.  She told me last week that
she hasn't felt normal since right around the time that them damn planets
lined up over Earth.  I wonder if other Aquarians are more sensitive to it.

I dunno.  I hang out with some of these "rave" people and sometimes we get
funny ideas in our collective head.  There is a rave magazine called XLR8R,
which recently dedicated an entire issue to darkness.

If all this is true, I am going to have one remarkable hard-on when the
clouds clear up and we enter the golden age.  Hope it doesn't take too long;
I'm going to lose my mind if I don't stop fidgeting.

Just a thought.   Cheer up or I'm going to come to your house and stomp on
your head.

Yours,

boomerang

Subject: British Rave Scene Review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i decided to post this on the list because several people have expressed
interest in the british rave scene and we don't want to repeat ourselves too
much.

i wrote this in a private conversation:
:
> or do you not like jungle?

not that much actually. but that's just a matter of taste... and of skin
color, interestingly enough, regarding the recent diversity debate on the
list. it seems that here in england happy hardcore and techno crowds are
largely white and jungle crowds largely black. i figured it out a while ago,
thou, at exodus, an illegal rave, where the crowd is mixed and they play
jungle as well as techno sets. it's a matter of movement. white people and
black people move and dance differently. and once i understood that you have
to move differently to jungle, i actually got into it. i still like happy
hardcore best. i am white, nothing i can do about it. i move better to
hardcore. but i'd love to check out your favorite jungle do sometime in
june. i'll get ben to post something about the british rave scene on the
list some time. he's the real raver.=20

and  this is the reply plus Craig and Ben's reply to the reply (ah, you know
what i mean):

>
>I hope you don't mind me asking you all these questions, but I have been
into >jungle since >back in '93, and I have always wanted to travel to
England to check >out all the dj's...I know >they throw a lot of massives in
Milton Keynes, at the >Sanctuary right?

Damm right ! Hi there in SF,my name is Craig, i'm one of Bens and Iris's
friends and i have been raving for about 7 years. We are all off to "HELTER
SKHELER"  later today (15th) with load's of Friends, which is at the
Santurary and Rollers (a neighbering wharehouse). I don't know if you have
heard of it ? But they always have blinding line up's, for instence in the
sancturary they got SY, HYPE (the best jungle DJ in the world), DANCE, BILLY
BUNTER, VINYL GROOVER, UNKNOWN, NICKY BLACK  MARKET, GROOVE RIDER, ELLIS
DEE, SLIPMAT, DOUGAL, and RAMOS. And as eqally blinding DJ's in the other
including VIBES, SEDUCTION, RAY KEITH and RANDALL. They are always a wicked
party with a buzzing up for it crowd.

> Now are these just=20
>really big commercial parties, and is their a lot of segregation between
the "black" >junglists >and the "white" happy hardcore crowds..I guess what
I am trying to say >is..is the jungle scene >in England mainly a black
scene...kinda of like hip hop is >over here?
=20
I would'nt say it was a mainly black scene. The scene over here is quit
mixed both in commercial and underground events, but there are strictly
jungle events where a white person
might not be welcome if they where on there own. There's not that
"P..L..U..R.." that is so common in mixed music events where colour does not
matter. There is a big following by both white and black people, but most of
our events are mixed music, jungle, tecno, and happy hardcore, and most
people are in to it all. For example, they like to start the night with
Jungle to get things going, then biuld things up with some Hardcore, then in
to uplifitng Tecno  and Hard Trance .. Goa ... So generally there is some
thing for every one and if there's a style you dislike it eventualy grows on
you. I used to hate jungle, but i started to go EXODUS an illegal rave that
is curently fighting the criminal justice bill for the right to party (they
use other people's wharehouses and only charge =A31) and they play the above
order of music and i now love hard step like what is played by HYPE. I
seriously recomend you get some of HYPE'S set's from HELTERSKELTER, there
amazing, let's trade tapes! With anyone that wants to.
Stuf i'm into: Orignaly i was into Hardcore but that's a bit chezzy these
days, I love uplifting Tecno, Goa and some Jungle.
There's quit a big Goa scene in london's underground clubs and lot's of
travellers put on free partys with Goa playing all night. To be
continued............................

Craig + Ben


+ Iris
(sorry if this is a bit chaotic.  my cutting and pasting, i mean)

On Fri, 14 Mar 1997, Pablo Beck wrote:

> 
> 10 REASONS WHY SCOOBY DOO WAS A DRUG INFLUENCED CARTOON
> 
> 1. SCOOBY AND SHAGGY were always being freaked out by ghost and ghouls,
> but no one else saw them before Scoob and Shaggy.

> hear him and understand him.

> monster because they were tripping over themslves and couldn't see where
> they were going.

> up in some costumes and entertained the monster.

From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>

cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com, Sami Khoury <khoury@hyperreal.com>

In-Reply-To: <v0300783faf4ccc5604a8@[157.22.222.52]>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970314192103.14510C-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>

On Wed, 12 Mar 1997, Wayne D. Correia wrote:
> At 12:10 PM -0800 3/12/97, Sami Khoury wrote:
> >I believe Wayne is right on regarding the comments he made.  Note that he
> >did not claim that SFR is *currently* diluted with mall rat culture, but
> >only doomed to undergoing such a dilution.  Below is an excerpt from his
> >message:
> >
> ><Wayne>
> >> I am hoping for that to come again, but, as I write this, I realize
> >> that, just like the rave scene itself, SF Raves is doomed to "mall rat
> >> culture"  dilution as the music (techno, house, etc.), community and
> >> prospective "market" grows to a critical mass that can again, just like
> >> in the early 1990's, be market to.
> ></Wayne>

Uh, hello, SFRaves isn't "doomed" to anything.  I don't believe in fate.
History on this list has shown that, for better and for worse, individuals
can play a huge part in charting the course of discussion, and who those
individuals are can change dramatically from month to month.  Some of the
most caustic flamethrowers transmogrified into the most positive
contributors - the opposite has happened too.  SFRaves is only "doomed" if
no one cares to post to it.  That doesn't mean folks need to live their
life vicariously through the list - which has happened too much before -
all it means is folks need to get some value for the time they spend
reading or writing to the list.

Ask yourself these questions:  Are you interested in hearing about how the
scene is evolving?  How the parties last weekend were?  In hearing how
others feel about the music, the dancing, the lights, the drugs, the
experience?  In maybe striking up a friendship or two with folks with
similar interests?  If the answer is yes, then there's a reason to
contribute to the list.  I think for many people, this is still true.  

The Death of the Scene, and of the List, has been greatly exaggerated.
Raving has transcended trend status - this is the tenth year at least that
people have been dancing to acid house, and before that these types of
parties simply went by different names.  This is the fifth year of
SFRaves.  

> When more and more raves all feel like Friday night at 1015 Folsom (and
> more and more of them *do* feel that way, as the "scenesters" find a new
> "scene" to hang out in, en masse, you'll know the gig is up.
>
> What do I mean? Women dressed to the hilt who beg to be looked at, but the
> second they notice someone looking at them, the scowl at you. Add to that,
> testosterone-pumped "mustang 5.0" types guys posturing for the attention of
> formerly-described women. Now add a *lot* of alcohol and dilute with
> hundreds and thousands of suburban clubbers looking for "the next cool
> thing."

My god, heaven forbid the common folk catch on to this "gig"!

Some parties billed as raves have been frequented by folks like this since
I first started raving in 1989.  Sometimes they turn out to be the most
vibe-y folks at the party.  And if their Mustang doesn't garner a lot of
attention, they just leave.  Big deal.

> It ain't pretty, there's a whole lot more of "them" than "us", and they
> don't particularly care to find out about the fundamentals of rave culture,
> including, but not limited to "kindness" "PLUR" or even necessarily about
> the music. I hung out in the club scene for almost a decade. It's about
> drinking and cruising, and that's on a *good* night!

Whoa!  Wayne's a clubber, wayne's a clubber!  Look out!  Once a clubber,
always a... wait... 

Wayne, I *know* you didn't mean that to come out like that, but it did.
Why is it inconceivable that you can be "redeemed" but other clubbers
can't?  Is there really a possibility of a "ClubKidPolcalypse" taking over
underground parties?  How many folks out there were on the "them" side of
this us.v.them issue?  

> Now, once all the cattle are excited about "RAVE" picture this:
> 
> -------------------------
> "Super Stadium Rave 1997" at Shoreline Ampitheater
> 
> presented by Bill Graham Presents
> 
> STARRING: "The Prodigy, Chemical Brothers, Beck, Smashing Pumpkins and KEOKI"
> 
> Sponsored by: Live 105, Moonshine Records, Tanqueray, Camel and Budweiser"
> 
> Admission: $35 + BASS surcharge
> -------------------------
> 
> It ain't pretty.

Hey, it'll give all the lemmings a place to go to while the rest of us
enjoy the CloudFactory party held the same night.  Sounds like they'll get
to enjoy at least one honestly good band too (Chem Bros), and if it's not
worth $35 to them they won't go to another one.  What's wrong with these
folks having fun?  With BGP, Live105, ChemBros, and everyone else making
some money?  How is it preventing us from having our fun?  It's not.

The real danger to our culture is if it can be demonized to the
point where dancing all night or listening to techno music is seen as a
subversive act, and the Powers that Be (tm) somehow work to prevent us
from doing this.  I *don't* see widespread adoption of techno music or an
explosion of club attendees doing this, necessarily.  If anything I think
it *helps* foster adoption of this as an acceptible activity.

I guess in your "ClubKidPocalypse" I just fail to see a problem.  If
"unsavory" elements show up at your shindig, deal with them - that's never
been a new problem.  How we choose to deal with them will say a lot about 
what kind of culture we are really building.

"RAVE" broke "big" in 1991.  It's old news.  No catastrophe.  And there
won't be.  

	Brian

brian@hyperreal.com     http://www.apache.org     http://www.organic.com/jobs

Hello friends,

Since we're talking about Berlin...

The following is from Jan who I believe is in the Netherlands (.nl?).  He sent 
me this info regarding this year's Love Parade in Berlin, which is the largest 
techno party I've ever heard of. Last year's estimate was around 1,000,000 
happy groovers!  I studied in Berlin while in college, and LOVE the city.  The 
overall 'youth scene' in Berlin is amazing, esp. in the former east Berlin part 
of the city.  So, my roomie and I are shopping for the lowest airfares, 
discount tix, etc., which I'll post to the list when we find it if anyone is 
interested in going. I have a double cd set of many of the DJs that were there 
last year (yes, it's rather commercial), but the music is good! 

In the meantime, see you at Cloud Factory on Sat!

Love, Nathan

This years Love Parade is 12th of July. But be there at least a day or two
before and do not miss the day after (loads of pre- and after-parties).

Where does everyone stay? Everywhere! People are camping in the parks,
sleeping on the streets etc. But most don't sleep those days at all (when
should they?).
The VIP ravers and the odd 1000 journalists stay in hotels ranging from up
to Hilton etc. After all Techno is big business by now in Europe.


Have not been to Tachales, but know the other two (at least I think I can
still remember).

You have been at Humboldt - studying what?

Jan

In other news, in San Jose a medical marijuana group is not only setting
up shop, they are working with the SJ city council to define a zoning
category for medical marijuana sale and use (which would probably require
them to be far from schools, etc.), they're going to pay sales tax, and
forbidding indoor smoking, all in compliance with state law.  That's the
real deal, folks - Dennis Peron could take a few clues from their lead.

On Fri, 14 Mar 1997, Ari Newman wrote:
> Wayne D. Correia wrote:
> > That's why I specifically recommended people have parties in their homes,
> > in fields, and random places with their friends: to create.
> > 
> Wayne is totally right....

uh, he probably could have made his point with a little less
apocalypticism, but yeah..

> its known as DIY....Do It Yourself. And I see
> this happening all over... we all know the scene is NOT dead or dying.
> As any entity grows and evolves it becomes more complex by nature.
> Accept it.
> The DIY culture brings ravers back to their roots...or the core of why
> we rave....the music, the people, the spiritual energy. (and so much
> else :) 
>  Please see Ecstasy.org for some relavent info:
> http://www.ecstasy.org/party.html

Or a whole archive dedicated to this on Hyperreal:

  http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/holdyourown/

> It takes a lot of hard
> work by alot of people to put together an event...as all you SFRavers
> know already. All I'm saying is that 5 people can't do the work for the
> rest of the crowd. Everyone should contribute in their own personal
> way...

Absaloootely!

	Brian

Hi Kidz,

I have sure enjoyed the recent discussions around here.  Seems
people are showing a little more respect.

I've never really introduced myself to the list, so here goes:  I'm
24, and a software engineer at Fractal Design.  I first learned about
raving almost 6 years ago through some friends who promoted a
little-known event in the northern wilds called Penelope's Web.  I never
actually got to go to a party until this New Year's, because I was too
busy geeking out at UCSC (graduated with honors, but no social life :)
My recent partygoing experiences have been intsrumental in snapping me out
of a long blue streak.  I just love to get up and dance, although I am
a little self-conscious about it.

That about covers it I think...

I hope you all are having a great Friday night!  I'm at work, trying
to get enough done tonight to justify going to Condensation
tomorrow night.  CF seems to have a great rep, and I had a fab time
at their NYE party.

I'm listening to Astralwerks' "Detroit: Beyond The Third Wave" which
is quite a bit different than what I usually listen to.  I bought
it on a whim when I had to return a defective Joni Mitchell disc :)

Peace,
Scott

Subject: Re: The Scene Is Dead?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

laren.k@easynet.co.uk wrote:
>lighten up you guys.
 [...]
>when it comes to community, ben and i certainly can't complain. several
>people on the list have offered help and even places to stay to us  two
>complete strangers. it's a trust simply based on a common interest and a
>knowledge of the scene. we trust that ravers are good people! i call that
>community.

This just reminded me of one time at a party not too long ago... it was
late, 8 or 9 am, sun in the windows and all the fluorescence gone, but the
party still rocking.  I was chilling in a corner, got up and headed back to
the main room.  I came to the end of the hall and looked out on the
hard-core couple of dozen still jumping, everyone looking strange in the
natural light but dancing just the same, smiling and grooving and passing
the pipe while the music kept pounding...  And I couldn't help myself, the
hugest grin split across my face and I said out loud without even thinking,
"It's the TRIBE!"

Now, I didn't know any of those people I was looking at, I didn't meet
anyone or make any new friends that night, but I felt that tribe all the
same.  It was on another occasion, in the aftermath of another party, that
I thought back to that event and decided that I knew what I had meant.  YOU
ARE AMONG FRIENDS.  That's my slogan, that's what the tribe means to me.
It's not flowers and stuffed animals, it's not X, it's not techno.  It's
not even raving--I know the same thing from a lot of other scenes.  It's
trust in others, trust in their sympathy and understanding.  Along with the
responsibility to back it up.  When you know that you can count on others
to take you seriously and when you will do the same for them--that's the
rave.  You are among friends.

anarch@scruznet.com

Martin Randall <kk@sei.com> wrote:
>A friend of mine, a university professor with special interests in
>ethnomusicology, has asked me if I can provide a short description
>(10-20 words) of "What is a rave?"

A blend of ecstatic experience and the tribal spirit within the realm of
music and dance.

For more on what I mean by "tribal spirit," see my other recent message
under "The Scene Is Dead?".

anarch@scruznet.com

Subject: Re: we have an opinion of difference
References: <E0w5lP5-0007Tc-00@ferret>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It really upsets me when I hear people talk about how much better things
were "back in the days". Let me just cut to it and say this:

If you were fortunate enough to have been exposed to the scene 2, 3 or 4
years ago, bad glad! I *wish* I was in your shoes. I've only been going
to parties for about a year consistently so I'll never know what it was
like back in '92 (which I guess is suppoed to have been THE summer). Or
'94 even. I keep hearing about all these things that I missed, but I'm
not complaining about it. I'll never know what it was like! You do! Be
glad!

Whatever happend back in the early days of raves was great I'm shure.
But it's gone now and it's time to move on. Will it come back? Probably
not. Even if it did, how would you know? Do you have a list to check
off?

It's too bad that some people feel the need to seperate "entertainment"
and "community". Raves for me have always sort of been this phenomenon
that transneds the distinction between entertainment and community and
finds somthing better than either of the two by themselves. "Well gee
Blake thats a lot of long, complex words but what do you mean?"

I think groups like Prodigy or Orbital are great. Their music kicks ass.
But I'll never know these people. It's just a CD to me. On the other
hand, I can listen to mix tapes by people like Boomerang, Micron,
Deepfog, Minor Minor, Greg S., Mars & Mystr-E, Ethan and countless
others and I know these people! They'er my friends, aquaintenses,
amigos. They are with me in the car, in my room, at work. It's such a
great feeling. I can kick back and/or dance to their set and shoot the
bull with them later on! They are my entertainment and my community.
That dosen't mean I won't go to a concert or massive ever. If the music
kicks it kicks. And there's been a few times when I talked with DJs like
Jeno and you get a chance to sort of know them.

If I just wanted community I'd go spend time at the local YMCA.

-=Pengo=-

Subject: Escape from reality?
In-Reply-To: <332A2594.7CD7@linex.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970314230622.26122G-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


[regarding "what is a rave?", someone said:]

> A gathering of people trying to escape from reality thru dance & music & 
> assorted substances. 
				  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

I was at my first rave, and i went outside to talk with S, my rave mom...
it was my first E and i was amazed at all of the positive energy i was
seeing and feeling... i said:

"Real life should be like this."

She said:

"This _is_ real life."

Raving, to me, is not about escaping from reality. It is, rather, about
escaping from the societally-defined bullshit and actively
defining/creating the reality that i want to live, a reality full of joy
and love. 

And, while substances, dance, and music are all wonderful tools toward
that end, to me, the most powerful tool is the smile in the eyes of the
person you're smiling at.

Love,

brian

ps	oh, was there a 20-word limit on that essay?  ;)

Brian Denny wrote:
> 
> [regarding "what is a rave?", someone said:]
> 
> > A gathering of people trying to escape from reality thru dance & music &
> > assorted substances.
>                                   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
> 
> I was at my first rave, and i went outside to talk with S, my rave mom...
> it was my first E and i was amazed at all of the positive energy i was
> seeing and feeling... i said:
> 
> "Real life should be like this."
> 
> She said:
> 
> "This _is_ real life."
> 
> Raving, to me, is not about escaping from reality. It is, rather, about
> escaping from the societally-defined bullshit and actively
> defining/creating the reality that i want to live, a reality full of joy
> and love.

EXACTLY. ESCAPING reality. the shit of the "real world", and re-creating 
reality as I want it to be. But unfortunately, when the lights & the sun 
come up I'm always a little disappointed that my hiatus from every-day 
reality is over & I have to be ready to go back to my office, to earn a 
living wich is the REALITY of life.  These two counter-realities are how 
I live. But I ain't complaining. Some people are stuck in the "real 
world" exclusively. At leats I can ESCAPE or rather take a breather from 
it on occasion.

> 
> And, while substances, dance, and music are all wonderful tools toward
> that end, to me, the most powerful tool is the smile in the eyes of the
> person you're smiling at.
> 
> Love,
> 
> brian
 

 A grand observation. The smiles & energy can be alot more potent & 
enlightening and fufilling than any drug I've come across. 

   Much love, I'm going to bask in rays of the SUN. Outdoor free parties
have the most intoxicating energy. I think it has something to do with 
the sunlight mixing with the lovelight of all the peoples. Sees ya'll 
out at the BANDSHELL in GG PARK.

                                    ~Increase Your Serenity~
                                          Jen Susser

> > >EXACTLY. ESCAPING reality. the shit of the "real world", and re-creating
> > >reality as I want it to be. But unfortunately, when the lights & the sun
> > >come up I'm always a little disappointed that my hiatus from every-day
> > >reality is over & I have to be ready to go back to my office, to earn a
> > >living wich is the REALITY of life.  These two counter-realities are how
> > >I live. But I ain't complaining. Some people are stuck in the "real
> > >world" exclusively. At leats I can ESCAPE or rather take a breather from
> > >it on occasion.
> >
> >   Anyone can take a vacation...  from their stressful job at the office.
> > Escaping "everyday reality" (earning a living) is a partial solution.
> > Finding a job that you enjoy will make you happier than any number of
> > breaks could...
snip!!!!

On Sat, 15 Mar 1997, David Minuk wrote:
> The author is listed as Douglas Rushkoff, and it's on Harper Edge
> Books.   I couldn't find any info on it at Harper's web site.
> Rushkoff, you may remember, wrote the book "Cyberia" which was a
> nonfiction book that had some info about the local rave scene.  His
> bio is at http://www.levity.com/rushkoff/index5.html and he's in the
> "Cool" hall of fame at http://cool.infi.net/agent/rushkoff.html

A close friend of mine, who was involved in parts of the scene described
in "Cyberia", gave it a four-word review when handing it to me to read -
"it ruined my weekend".  I had to agree, from what I knew of the
techno-pagan-rave-cyber-mondo-protoWiReD scene in SF in 1991-1992 it was
pretty, uh, "fantastic".  And made everyone look like fools.  I guess I'm
not going out of my way to check out "Ecstasy Club" either.

	Brian

>>On Fri, 14 Mar 1997, David Minuk wrote:
>>> Now SF Weekly is running excerpts of a new novel, "Ecstacy Club"
>>> which takes places in the SF rave scene.  It's on page 36 for those of
>>> you in a hurry.
>>
>>This isn't the same book by Irvine Welsh, "Ecstasy", is it?  I thought
>>that took place in Scotland, just as Trainspotter did.
>>
>The author is listed as Douglas Rushkoff, and it's on Harper Edge
>Books.   I couldn't find any info on it at Harper's web site.
>Rushkoff, you may remember, wrote the book "Cyberia" which was a
>nonfiction book that had some info about the local rave scene.  His
>bio is at http://www.levity.com/rushkoff/index5.html and he's in the
>"Cool" hall of fame at http://cool.infi.net/agent/rushkoff.html
>

a few months ago the SF Chron ran a story on the front page of their
Datebook section on Rushkoff, and he described the fictional novel as being
about "an increasingly paranoid rave cooperative in Oakland."   Not too
encouraging a description ...

>After watching the program, it at least showed the inevitabilty of pot
>use.  My favorite part was when an anti-drug county sheriff in Georgia
>lost an election to a more laissez-faire challenger who was supported
>by local growers(his brother was a grower!)
>

I think ABC's "Pot of Gold" was a fair portrayal of the realities of the
marijuana economy.  It also pointed out how much the cops benefit from
illegal drugs, as seizure laws gave the Washington cops the Volvos (!) they
were using to bust people, and such laws only work when the drug dealers
get rich first because the drugs are illegal ...

This was Peter Jennings' closing statement -- you make the call:

We think the government is absolutely right that we must educate our
children not to do drugs, including alcohol & tobacco. But that's an
obvious policy. We've also learned that marijuana is no longer simply
associated with a so-called "drug culture," and like it or not, marijuana,
marijuana for profit, now has roots in mainstream America.  This leads
inevitably to a discussion about legalization or touger laws.  That debate
is intensifying.  What people need to understand is that the current effort
to eradicate growing here at home isn't changing things very much except to
ensure that the price stays high. Really getting at the people who grow
marijuana no longer means closing the borders, but an enormously expensive,
invasive door-to-door campaign.  Which brings us back to that former deputy
sheriff in Bacon County.  He reminded us that you can only police the
people as much as they are willing to be policed.  And how much is that?


I know how we'd answer on this list ....

leftjab

Pittsburg.   }:\

  Damn my head hurts..
  The fourth story of Club Release is almost finished..  Looks like a
lounge. And parts of the floor are glass windows, so you can see down into
the main dance floor.. Pretty cool..

 I talked like hell of people out of going to Ubiquitous tonight.. Funny
to. Cause I ain't even going out tonight. Hope all my friends have fun at
The Moon party. The location sounds more promissing than Pittsburg for
one..  =]:..

 So did nobody on the list hear of the car crashed that happened at the
last, free 5 dollar Ubiquidous? The fucked up thing about it too. The girl
describe to appear dead in the car. Well. I thought her discription was
familier. It's sad. The lady that witnesses discribed, I haven't seen her
at the ravEs since the last Obiquidous. I saw the cars, they were pretty
twisted looking. Fortunetly I did not see any victoms. But a friend of
mine, Mike saw it. And he was tripping out depressed for a long time.

 Why do I mention such a terrible tragidy? Well.. From the looks of the
last Ubiquitous. In my opinion, it was all a setup. "to me" it looked as if
crpower had the whole thing planned.. So "to me" it looked like crpower had
the party deliberatly broke up at 2AM. And if that is the case; I hold
crpower directly responcible for that girl having to leave early, and be in
a car with an intoxicated driver.. So "to me" it seems that if crpower
would of just been true to the scene, and just have thrown a party for the
love of it, instead of to take the money and run. This girl would still be
alive today..
 The girl that supposidly died, was the passanger in the car. The driver
lived. From the possition of the cars, it looked like one car was going,
way to fast through the flashing yellow light intersection, and the other
car ran through the flashing red light.. No one should ever run blindly
through thoughs yellow lights at night in the city.
 I don't know the facts man. Maybe crpower is for real. But "to
me"......Yanno... They suck.

Jeff

night I had decided to go to different ones.. finally I gave up and just
came home :)

go that probably would have been the most beautiful party...

hi from milton keynes to all you sfravers
 it's sunday morning 9 a.m. and we have just come back from a good night of
raving and brought back a bunch of ravers to chill out together. so while it
is still fresh in our minds here is a review of HELTER SKELTER.

 there were at least 8000 if not more ravers from all over england,
scottland and wales there, 2 huge arenas + 2 small ones, outside fairground
rides, takes an average of 3 hours to get in, tickets cost =A325 ($37?),=
 very
commercial rave. but MAN!, it was WICKED!

Craig is taking back what he said before (regarding diversity) that raves
here in england _are_ multiracial. well, this one wasn't. it was  a largely
white event.

this is going extremely slowly because we are all so monged out (no idea how
to spell that) i'm not sure we can actually get this together now.=20

anyway, we all had the best rave in ages. they were playing everything from
jungle to hardcore to techno (ah, the experts are waking up :  gabba,
drum&bass jungle, hardcore 4 beat,  uplifting techno, acid techno,  hard
trance....) and i made sure to check everything out. i'm still a happy
hardcore chic, though. i know it's cheesy, and getting boring, ...and
slower! but it's still what i dance to best. i like techno, but at one point
tonite it got just a bit to fast for me. ben loved it! as i said, he's the
real raver!
 i must say that i am amazed at how the rave scene has diversified over the
last few years. i've only been in it for 3 years and i have noticed huge
changes. the more the rave scene diversifies the more we have to make sure
that we don't develop this tribalism that humans are so prone to.

all the others have to say, is: oh man, it was a wicked night. and: the
athmosphere was_ really_ good.

ben, have you got anything to say?
"it was all over too quickly. suddenly it was 7 in the morning and it was
all over.

Dan says: "i can't believe how much i was sweating last night."

Jo says: "Nicky Black Market is a genius."

well, it seems that this is as much as i can get out of them at the moment.
all you sfravers who are still out right now, still enjoying their saturday
night : hope you have a good one!

iris + ben + craig + dan + will + jo + selina + barney + karla

That's pretty fucked up to blame someone for this women's death. Things
happen for reasons. I don't believe that it's anyones fault other
then the drunk driver who killed her.

Using the reasoning you've described we could go on for hours discovering
who the real person responsible is. We could blame the alcohol company
for creating the alcoholic beverage, we could blame the
person who sold the alcohol to the drunk driver, we could blame the
employer of the drunk driver for putting him through so much stress that
he feels the need to get drunk, we could blame the person who discovered
alcohol in the first place, etc.... alcohol doesn't kill people, people
kill people. 

And why shouldn't people go to Ubiquitous? The line up looked really
good me. I would have gone if I didn't have plans for the evening. I'm
curious why you talked people out of going. Pittsburg is not as bad a
place as people seem to think. All that you hear about it is the crap that
happens, just like all news. I know a lot of people from P-town and it's
not as bad as people imagine. I'm from Martinez which is really close to
Pitt.

I wonder how many people are going to be po-ed when they get kicked out of
maritime at 5am. Unless they someone increase the curfew for tonight. 1
Hour isn't much, but it's still an hour.

It's 3:35 and I'm off to bed.... I'm going to the 50-100k person St.
Patricks day parade today in the city. I've never looked forward to a
Sunday in as long as I can remember. :-) Lots of bewsky for meesky!

-Byroni

mushrooms (sp) tonite with a group of sisters after feeling i needed to
leave a production due to me being sick as hell recently...

went home, and went on a medicine journey with some sisters...

mother, than as a citizen, that i stand by my beliefs in legalization of
drugs and that's a whole 'nother discussion...

morning and walked  dwon to the space to see how things had gone and ran
into this dude...

Matthew and i arrived at the cloud factory mappoint too late and tix =
were already sold out. :(  but as determined ravers we decided to try =
and talk our way in...i had 2 big tupperwares of oranges to give away =
(which i found out later were prob. unnecessary for that particular =
party).  anyway, we found the location and asked the folks at the door =
if there was anyway they could help us out.  and so here's my point of =
telling you that we couldn't get in:  the folks at the door were so darn =
nice about saying no, that it was okay with us.  we understood their =
reasoning and hey we didn't want the location messed up either.  it's =
such an awesome place to go.  so, once again thanks to the cloud factory =
folks for bing VERY kind and awesome.  we even got a recommend of =
alternate parties.  very cool :)  i hope that we'll be able to attend =
the next one.  if you went post a review....i'd like to hear about it.
 much love and hugs -
  mac

*great* parties)

too long (since May) and so  far, i've been so welcomed, and am excited to
meet more ravers and maybe lure more of my Utah friends out for these

really good time if the SFRavers might be interested in a daytime picnic back

to the  bright future!

This is going to be a bit long.  My best time on X was during the
Cloudfactory New Years party in Monterey, to understand the context we
need to step back a week or so.  California had been expecting some
enormous storm previous to New Years. The news swore it would be on
Tuesday, which came and went as sunny as ever.  The media checked itself
and picked another day to swear by.  This went on for several days until
"The Great Big Storm" became a something of a local joke.  Then came New
Years and two tabs.  Just after the count down my friends and I were
standing outside doing the hugging thing when "it" came.  That's right
"The Big Fucking Storm" hit and I would have to say (given the drug
induced circumstances) it was a truly memorable moment.  When everyone
realized that God's wrath was upon them the only logical thing to do was
laugh and scream, not surprising.

and that's the short, short version

From: Kolin <kolin@verso.com>
Subject: Re: best time on X
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My best time on E actually came recently.  I was in New Orleans last
weekend, meeting with some of my old friends from college.  One of my best
female friends had never done it before (E has a bad rap as a "sex drug" in
the South).  I brought it as a present for her and I to do some bonding. I
had sat on the capsules on the plane by accident, so we had to mix it up in
some O.J. to avoid the bitter taste.  It hit us like a Mack Truck in the
local 24 hour drug store (where we were buying candy and toys).  The lights
were impossibly bright in there, and we went nuts buying E toys, racking up
a bill of $40.00 or so.

We travelled to all of our old haunts, stopping by to distribute all of the
presents we had just bought.  It was a warm, humid New Orleans night, and
as we passed by all of the mansions on St. Charles Avenue, we were reminded
that New Orleans is unlike anywhere else on Earth, where the masses of
humanity mix despair with delight to achieve an imperfect but beautifully
dangerous synergy.

We spent the rest of the evening in her old shotgun apartment, candles
reflecting against French doors and the mouldings of high ceilings,
catching up on the past two years, her in Scotland, me in San Francisco,
wondering where the time went and realizing that two years is nothing in
the grand scheme of things.  We fell blissfully asleep at 7AM, only to
arise at 10 to find ourselves with renewed faith in the immortality of
mankind.

D. Kolin Better
Studio Verso
Public Relations / Marketing
High Five Business Manager
mailto://kolin@verso.com

world wide web:
http://www.highfive.com
http://www.verso.com
http://www.killersites.com

"They're all mad cause they think I'm giving them hell.  I'm not giving
them hell, I'm just telling the truth on them."
        - Truman

Hey everyone!

Got this from the insert of one of the new CD's in last week. With all the
ranting lately, I thought we could all benefit.

Enjoy!

"The term Underground is not measurable by sales, nor by income, or
notoriety. Rather, it represents an approach to this music we call House and
Techno, a desire to push foreward, to constantly evolve an idea and take it
all the way, often for the sheer hell of it. To reject compromise, to
preserve the integrity of the music, to go beyond the base standards set by
the mainstream and commercial requirements of the music industry. To make
music simple because it *must* be made, and not because it will sell by the
bucketload or make the artist a household name for five fleeting minutes.
Some of the artists here may aim to rock the dancefloor, others to mess wit
your head, but all will do so on their own terms."

"Taken into this context, the concept of Underground becomes a self-imposed
quality control mechanism, a reason to create and a code of honour. And they
are not alone. Each artist here is part of a network, a system of links that
spreads for local focal points and core clubs across the UK to reach out to
a global electronic network of musicians and dj's, clubs and labels, via
magazines and internet sites, distributors and shops that ensure that this
music will never be owned by the grey men in suits. They represent a
generation who have grown up with House and Techno, this strange, rhythmic
and challenging music that originated in Detroit and Chicago and has gone on
to criss-cross the planet."

"A music that finds its roots in all previous music but is tied to no
established form, to which nobody owns the copyright, but to which everyone
may stake a claim. Whereoutdated concepts of verse-chorus-verse 'songs' and
so-called 'real instruments' have been left far, far behind. A music that
does not sit comfortably with the media's obsession with personality,
appearance, and the artificial preconceptions of pop. And to which, as a
result, too many people are denied ready access. This compilation is but a
snapshot of something far larger, one of hundreds released every month, part
of a mountain of music that constantly grows in size where evolution is
inevitably maintained pure because it must be. The future may seem to rush
towards us with ever increasing speed, but the Underground will always be
there to welcome it. Be in no doubt, across the UK and beyond, the
Underground is alive and kickin'."

Tom Robbins, Magic Feet, May 1996

So the question remains...Are you Underground?

:)

J-

Message-Id: <1.5.4.16.19970316223051.3787034a@popd.ix.netcom.com>
X-Sender: shawna-@popd.ix.netcom.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.4 (16)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (Frisco Freaks)
From: The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Entertainment Weekly Magazine's Guide to Raving!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ack!

I'm at the grocery store in the check-out line, when I look over at the
magazine rack and a small headline on a magazine catches my eye:  "Plus:
Rave On!  A Consumer's Guide to the New Music Revolution"  I'm like "oh my
god!  I cannot believe that!"  And of course I pick it up cuz I just *hafta*
know.  Inside there's a detailed "consumer's guide" to the different types
of techno, and (I confess to being stumped here) they mentioned some kind of
music called "illbient".  Now my original assumption is that there's no way
in hell a hollywood entertainment magazine would know of more genre types
than I would (not that I'm the queen of genre types, but a hollywood
entertainment magazine? come on!), and assumed they had meant "ambient", but
now I'm questioning myself.  Folks:  is there really a genre called
"illbient"?  And if so, what the hell is it?  Heaven knows that a consumer
such as myself wants to be up & in the know on these things!  Heaven forbid
that I, a supposed raver, should be getting my up-to-the-minute knowledge
about raving & techno genres from an entertainment magazine.  Something is
very very wrong with this.  I took a brief look at the article, they talk
about how "alternative" music is now dead (i.e. how alternative/grunge/etc
has become everything it was attempting to combat) and that the new music
form that's gonna hit the markets & become the big thing is Techno!  And of
course all our big time favorites have pictures in the article, Chemical
Brothers, Prodigy, Orbital etc.  And a couple of ones I hear in the
mainstream less often, like Goldie or Aphex Twin, who are both pictured in
there. (Boy is Goldie gold!  a huge mouthful of gold teeth, very strange
looking.)  And god what a hideous picture of Keith Flint from Prodigy, he
really looks like he's about to explode into a mass of blood, green hair,
sweat & piercings. Yuck!  

Anyway, it's all a little strange and disconcerting, & a little in line with
the recent debates of "what's happening to our underground", they list all
the genres, compare drum & bass to jungle, with explicit descriptions of the
different types (now I'll know how to tell them apart finally! ;), & talk
about how big name bands & groups are changing their sounds to incorporate
the electronic techno sound, like U2 & David Bowie & Smashing Pumpkins.
This is something I'd been noticing on the radio too, did just hear a
Smashing Pumpkins song (prior to reading the article) and I swear that I
heard a 303 in there!  And there's a definite 303 line going on in that Tori
Amos song Blue Sky, which is actually a pretty groovy song.

But anyway, I must admit, in spite of my belief that the underground will
maintain itself as deemed necessary, that I am a bit alarmed to find all the
secret magical things I first found 1 1/2 years ago to be described in
detail in a Hollywood entertainment magazine.  And I wonder too, now that
the "alternative/grunge" scene is "dying", what happens to our rave scene
after it becomes mainstream.  Of course, our underground will continue I
believe, but at the same time, if there's anything that can kill it, it will
be the mass commercialization of techno I believe, nothing saps & drains the
life out of anything, nothing will wring everything out of it that it can,
nothing will beat a dead horse till there's nothing left but pulp, but the
frantic "Scramble for Dollars Wringer" that America at large will put the
scene thru for its own end.  IMO.  I'm curious how long the grunge scene
existed prior to its becoming famous, and how threatened/protective/fearful
did they all feel (if at all) when it did start making it big.  And is there
any sort of an underground grunge type scene still?  Or has it all been
squashed by its own commercialization?  I wonder if the history of the
grunge scene will predict our future.  And on the other hand, maybe the
introduction of techno into the mainstream will help to improve quality and
the evolution of mainstream music.  I for one started liking commercial
music quite a bit better after the alternative stuff started really coming
thru, I felt that there was some good quality there that was entirely
lacking prior to its introduction (ie: Aha, Wham, etc!  Ya gotta admit,
Nirvana was definitely better than that earlier 80's crap that was being
played.)  I wonder I wonder...

Anybody who's interested in checking out the article, the magazine is called
"Entertainment Weekly", page 36.


Love
Shawna

Did you hear that Leanna Bobit got killed?

Yeah, she was driving in her car and got cut off by some dick.

That's a "Condor" bartendress' joke. 

Here's another one:

There's a women who is getting hooked up by her friend for a blind date.
She told her friend that she was tired of being pushed around and run out
on. So her friend found her someone and sent him over. 

The door bell rings and the women sees a man with no arms or legs. He says
his name is Bob. Then she says, "What can you do for me?". He says "Well,
I can't push you around because I have no arms. And I can run out on you
because I don't have any legs". And she says, "What can you do for me?".

"Well, I rang the doorbell didn't I?", says the guy.

hello, my merry kids, men women, girls and boys.
  I went to  a party this weekend. it was called con-den-sa-shun.  It was
fun.
I met a lot of you kids there. Hello, everyone {{<3 :) <3 :) ~~ (: <3 (: <3}}
smiles and love in a hug.
  Let's see, brett, i waited at the mappoint, but i found a ticket before you
got there, so i'm sorry i didn't get to meet you, but i will.  The mapoint
was fun though, I finally met micron... after hearing *so* many good things
about you :). and i saw a lot of you kids from home too, love you all.
  It was a mess getting to that point though.  andy andy andy... well, i got
up there at any rate.  surrounded by some *drama*.  see, someone forgot their
ticket so we went back to get it. A human error, we were only 15 minutes away
from  his house... no big deal.  but someone got mad. Sweety, your anger was
unnecessary.
  Upon stepping into the party, i saw so many *shiny happy people holding
hands*
Names and faces i remember... Li, i will figure out how I know you; Orson,
faboo seeing you again; vertigo, smile forever; boomerang, so nice to have a
smile to go along  with the name; Macadio, i met you but i don't think you'll
remember me. but that is okay, i understand the state of mind you were in...;
brian denny who came up to say high when i was nearly passed out from taking
so much ginseng; how many more of you are there??? bao, with the glowsticks;
orson's cute little asian friend who gave me his laminate because i forgot
mine (I don't remember yer name) the three guys I met downstairs by the water
table, but I don't remember yer names!!!!! Vlad who works at city e; smurfy,
i remember meeting ya, but I don't remember when or how :/; god,(<~~ yes i
met god j/k) and the millions of other souls i met that night... i'm  trying
to cover the sfravers i guess on this post.
  I stayed upstairs most of the night by the ambient, but i was concerned
about my friend lauren who was pear pressured into taking "e" she did not
have fun. I tried to take care of her, but I couldn't do it all night.  the
amount of time I watcher her zapped a lot of energy from me.  I wish she
haddent taken that evil (for her) e.  
  I loved yer set Micron... you played a song at the beginning of yer set, I
think, the one with the words that was really pretty.  They played the song
again upstairs later on...
  And I remember someone mixing some big band ambient upstairs, that was
cool, fun to dance too.
  But it was scary cuz I fell asleep and when I woke up someone was spinning
some dark ambient and it SCARED me. I thought i was in a night mare
looooooooooooowwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww bass  sound with a high
sssssskkkkkkkkkkkrrrrrrrrrrrrrreeeeeeeeeeeeeecccccccccccchhhhhhhhhhhhhh over
it. it was like someone singing a really high note, but not as bad as mariah
carey.  the heat downstairs was not bad at all, compared to another party I
was at when we devirginized the location. the ceiling wasn't leaking too bad,
just enough for a slightly slickery floor.
  I missed Lara.  I haven't seen my baby girl for days... 
  Nice to see all the kids I drove up with... plus all the kids from
sunnyvale and north san jose and santa clara and cupertino and saratoga.
  okay so, for those of you who didn't know, my number one reason for going
to parties is to meet people and see all those I *love*.  But you can bet yer
butt that if the music did'n't come in at #1 the music is about as close as
it can get...
   I guess since I am still considered a *newbie* (bout half a year) my ideas
will change... maybe. But the people vibe is strongest for me.  I like to
make ya  smile. And another little addon, I rave sober, so when I say I
*love* you, I mean it, it is not drug induced love. and I can honestly say
that all the beautiful people in the party that night were loved by me.  
  I hope to see all yer smiling faces again very soon!!!!!!!!.
smiles:)

my best time on e was my first time. 
I was in santa cruz at the subud house.
I hugged everyone i saw who looked happy.
and hand orgy was fun fun fun.
and met some people who i love and are forever bonded to.
I met charlotte (the baroness) on my first e and she was *such* a nice girl.
plus her roommate hayden (hey, Hayden if you are here, call me!!!)
One of my favorite things was taking a shower when i got home...
Laying in my bad and sleeping, then waking up and feeling the sheets on my
legs.
Then smoking a cigarette (I have since quite) and having that feeling come
back to me.  Also, smoking a green bowl and having it come back.

okay, but given my first awesome 'e'xperience, why do i not do it... I was
taken advantage of, but my friends were there in time and helped me.  Some
guy was asking to have sex with me and I said no.  Then he wanted me to go
sit in his car with him, i said no. then he wanted me to get more e with him
in town, i said no.  My friends saw this and said... she is staying here with
us. More, but I won't get into it.
 I remember peaking... I was smoking in my friends car (the one who saved me)
and I said... oh my god... then he gave me a hug.  I call it my peak hug...
and ever since then I have been a different person.  I need to take him and
my other merry crew of friends to meet you all. they are just in a serious
lack of funding.
 yeah, so my first was the best and i hugged everybody.  my line was "hi, i'm
april, this is my first time on 'e', can i have a hug??" and everyone was
more than willing.
No bad vibes. except the one.  I hid from him all night (he scared me)
so that's it.

forms.  And perhaps one day they'll pull your jaw bone out of the dust

From: joel457@ix.netcom.com (joel gordon)
Subject: Cloud Factory Review - sorta (long)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I had to ask a friend of mine if it was a fun party, even though I 
was there all night long.

Apparently it was.  

Something I know, but had to rediscover is that I should not do 
anEthing when I'm not in the right mood.  Recently I've been taking 
it with a purpose, other than just having fun.  The purpose being to 
help me find a girl. 
FYI, not a good idea.
It just makes the longing worse and me seem pitifull.  
                                           
The whole reason I kept going to raves after my first one was that I 
was having fun in a way I never had before.  I was meeting awsome 
people, hearing out of this world music, and having positve trips. I 
could have gone to that rave (Rave to Save the Redwoods) and had an 
okay or bad time, and said that was fine but I'm not going back.  But 
I had an awsome time.  I enjoy people, music, and drugs; generally in 
that order. 
I found a home and a family in the Rave Scene.

I'm not having fun right now.  I'm just going through the paces.  
Find party, do somEthing, get high, get nothing, get depressed, go 
home. It was a really good party and I was unable to enjoy it. Shite. 
I feel bad for the Cloud Factory crew because I did not contribute to 
the vibe. I was kind of a downer.  

I felt disconected all night.  I haven't really felt a group vibe in 
a while.  I remember inhaling the vibe out of the air a the 3 year 
Harmony party, and physically feeling it in the air at the Gathering. 
The vibe is obviously out there. I just don't feel it these days.

Back to the party.  This was the first party I've actually looked 
forward to in a while. I went to Cloud Factory's new years party and 
Cloud House.  Both were awsome.  I knew alot of my good friends were 
going to Condensation and I was looking forward to spending time w/ 
them.  The space was well decorated and the lights were cool. Music 
was really good. 

Ack.  
It is hard for me to be postive when I don't feel it in my gut.
The party was good and I will not miss the next Cloud Factory party.  
I will buy my ticket in advance.
I will post a positve review when I am able.


-Joel

My friends will always be in my heart.

Subject: 2: It this you? Raver Personality Guide:TWO! (fwd)

After the September Child stage there are many other variations!!

Opposed to the Spetember child there's always the:

The Old Sckooler: circa 89-92.

How to spot them: Their clothes have a washout look, the prints of the
T-shirt are                     faded and have dates that say: 1991. 

Where to find them: In the background, in the dark, at the ticket booth and
All the                         anversary  celebrations.

Internet characteristic: They hardly posts (because every thread they have
seen                            already) but when they do it's to correct
someone's                               misinfomation.

Pros: They answer all your rave related questions. They know the cultural  
significance of the fifteen minutes solos. They remember 15 minutes solos!
        THey have cool stories to tell, esp ones like, "It used to be $5 to
get in  and you get free water. 

Cons: The complain ALL the time. About how the scene was better, (See quote
above).
        How the ravers now don't have the have the same attitude. Sometimes
when    they    post you realise your smallness. They remind you all the
time            they've been around.

Sometimes they also are......

The happy-43-year-old OLD skooler.

How to spot them: Their age, pretty obvious really. They dance the way THEY
want,           usually having to give them lots of space.

How you find them: Usually with their spouces, or they're telling you their
spouce          tells them to grow up!. In the misdt of all these          
        young people that worship him or her for his/her longevity. Still  
                dancing when all the 20 year old have had it.

Pros: You can't believe they are still at it! You want to be like them.

Cons: If you're not paying attention and get a glance of them, they make
you think               of your parents at home, wondering what you're up
to.

___________________________________________________________________________
_________


The DJ

How to spot them: One shoulder is lower than the other. They always have an
enterage                surrounding them. Managers, friends that needed to
get in free,            groupies of the male  or female perswuasion. With
their gear.



Where to find them: Behind the decks, or hanging out with other DJs. They
NEVER              dance. Behind their decks at home.

Characteristics: They are either ultra arrogrant, or they are really cool.
There is                never an inbetween.

Pros: We NEED them. If they're good, they make you estactic. You life
depends on                      them.When they are starting out, they give
you tapes, they                         play at your parties all for FREE.

Cons: When they suck, your life feels like it's over. If they're your
friends you     never see them, because they are either playing, or
practiing.                      They don't go to the raves unless they're
playing at it. you don't go out         with them and when you go to the
one they're playing at they are surrounded.

___________________

Subject: #3" Raver pesonality traits three.
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.970317095348.27894H-100000@ese.UCSC.EDU>

Edition 3: This is no neccesarrily evolutionary, but you have to reach the
first to get to 2 and 3. Here we have the ultimate raver, the
about-burnout-raver, the born again raver.

THE ULTIMATE RAVER:

How you spot them: The have all the clothes that you want. They have more  
                glowsticks, and bike lights on their bodies then even the  
        average raver. In the day, they look the same sans                 
glowsticks and bike lights.

Where you find them: EVERY rave. Seen dancing anywhere there are strains of
techno,                         in malls down the street, anywhere.

Characteristic: They are always there. When they wake up the first thing
they do is              put hard trance on and play it real loud. THey know
everybody.

Pros: Best person to call when you want to go out. THey'll aways go with
you,and they know where it is.They give you warning and directions to
secret          parties. You can count on them being there. They lend you
lots os tapes.

Cons: The can become About-burnout-raver (see below). They don't understand
when    you're tierd, or don't want to go out.

Pray they don't live in the apt above you.

___________________________________________________________________________
__________

THE ABOUT-BURN-OUT-RAVER.

How you spot them: They look more ragged than thier 12 year old teddy bear.
Their                   shoes are a non-descript colour of blah. They
haven't washed                  their hair for a month, in fact they
haven't done that to                    thier bodies or clothes for a while
either.

Where to find them: Again at every rave. BUt this time, really really at
every rave.
                 Including clubs on the weekdays, and cafes that play
techno in the                   afternoon.
        
Characteristics: They are always high, of coming down or about to come up.
When they               laugh it's a full body laugh where their heads flip
backwards, and          jaws lock. 

How you find them: In the day, SLEEPing, admist a pile of water bottles,
and fliers                      and  miscellaneous MESS. In fact they can
trace each bottle                       to the specific rave. They are
tierd all the time until they                   get to one.

Pros: The are great fun. THey always can find you the drugs you want, and
it would        be great. Sometimes they give you some free. 

Cons: They never have any money except to go to raves   and for drugs and
keeps   borrowing of you, for food and cigarettes. 


What happens to them: Usually a hiatus where they sit in front of the
computer and                    lives in the rave mailing  lists, and seems
quite bitter                    about not going out, but not having the
energy or money.                        Become a born again raver (see
below). 

Worst case senario: Rehab, or parents.


________________________________________________________________


THE BORN AGAIN RAVER. (Straight edge)

How to spot them: They are walking in a straight line. They TELL you.

Internet characteristics: Their posts usually contains some promotion of
raving sober

Characteristics: They are clean. They leave at 5am. They always have a     
        bemused look when you see you fall over, or curled up in
                 the corner, or bowing to the speaker.


Pros: No more fights about who's driving home. He or she always does. 

Cons: You are aware that they will remember things that you don't or
pretend not to.         The can laugh at you and there is nothing you can
use as amunition.


To be continued...

Next up the drug dealer, the grouch, anymore? Email me! Feel free to ADD!! 

Nailvarnish.

A rave is...the music, thumping bass, it's a post modern 
trajectory in music, a postmodern carnival, where the participants can 
find group cartarsis. At once part  of Attali's repetition model yet at 
the same time defies it, and 
opps forgot i'll look the two other post modern music people's name sup.
This is that damn essay I have been writing for my ethnomusicologist 
prof. 


On Fri, 14 Mar 1997, Martin Randall wrote:

> Hi all you wacky wavers!!!   =]
> 
> A friend of mine, a university professor with special interests in
> ethnomusicology, has asked me if I can provide a short description
> (10-20 words) of "What is a rave?" I thought this was such an
> interesting question that I'd throw it out to you all to see what
> kind of answers we'd get. (All she's heard so far from students
> she's asked is "A drug-fest", which I think is a very unsatisfactory
> answer).
> 
> So.....
> 
>                     What is a rave?
> 
> 
> Love and hugs!!!
> 
> - Martin  =]

First off  I would like to say out of the 165 messages that I just scanned
through this morning I would have to say that only about 3 were of any
relavence to me. They were all threads and stupid things except for the scooby
doo joke that was good. I would have to agree with Wayne on that only about 30%
of the posts are of any substance, but anyways I will not bog down the list
with my irration of NRR posts. The CF party went off!! BTW I remember you April
you little cutie pie! and the fight took place out side the party it did not
involve two ravers from the party it was a group of ravers out side smoking and
some Mission street thugs. But NW wayz scott and his crew did the place up
grand, the parrashoots and lasers were excellent. The alter was very good lots
of intellegent lighting and black lights some many good happy SFR's and people
"not on the list" but that still had the vibe this party was like home for me.
It was the true essence of "family" I had such a good time, now on to the DJ's
Maya rocked the house with some smooth melodic type teKno, joy from New mexico
rocked with hard acid trance, Ed colmar played similiar and we was real good.
My boy Micron (dan) rocked the house with some electro trancy break beaty natty
boom batty sounds!! but one thing I did hear a lot of people asking me was
"what time are you playing?" and I responded with "im just here to party and
shake my stuff" so that made me think Hmmmm... Maybe I should be on the CF's
next lineup? so scott if you reading (hint,hint) J/K I don't want you to fell
*pressured* or anything =)  But this was by far a good party, vibe, space, DJ's
and all in my book 5 stars. Sorry for not mentioning any one one the list but
there were to many of you to name so instead of missing a name I would rather
not say any. But you all know who you are and I love you all my SFR Family.
Sorry so long and for the BSP.


*Hugz4all*

Macadio

I have a few corrections here...

-----Original Message-----
From:	Nailvarnish [SMTP:playdoh@cats.ucsc.edu]
_________


The DJ

How to spot them: One shoulder is lower than the other. They always 
have an
Enterage surrounding them. Managers, friends that needed to get in 
free,            groupies of the male  or female perswuasion. With 
their gear.
*** Ok, funny and Frightenly true (esp the lower shoulder bit. And 
don't forget the DJ 'hunch' from leaning over the turntables for hrs 
on end...).

Where to find them: Behind the decks, or hanging out with other DJs. 
They
NEVER dance. Behind their decks at home.
*** Ah, strike ONE.  I know many MANY dancing DJ's.  One of the main 
reasons Dj's are 'born' is because they are dissatisfied with other DJ 
mixes ('I could better.  If they mixed in track blah blah, instead of 
blah blah it woulda sounded cool...)  DJ's actually dance pretty funny 
since they spend most the time 'bouncing' to their mixes and are 
usually bouncing on the dance floor after their mixes.***

Characteristics: They are either ultra arrogrant, or they are really 
cool.
There is never an inbetween.
***There's always a middle ground., It just depends where You are on 
that Meter of Life...***

Pros: We NEED them. If they're good, they make you estactic. You life
depends on them. When they are starting out, they give you tapes, they 
play at your parties all for FREE.
*** Strike TWO.  Many DJ's exhibit the same characteristics even after 
they've been around for a while...***

Cons: When they suck, your life feels like it's over. If they're your
friends you     never see them, because they are either playing, or
practiing.
They don't go to the raves unless they're playing at it. you don't go 
out with them and when you go to the one they're playing at they are 
surrounded.
*** Strike THREE.  A lot of DJ's are usually out @ parties to see what 
music/ style/ vibe that other DJ's are creating.  They also 'learn' 
from each other, usually incorperating mixing styles into their own 
sets...  Every DJ want's to keep fresh in the scene and not sound 
'burned' (i.e. dated) so, yeah, you can see quite a few DJ's if you 
know who's who out there... ***

Paz Y amour,

--_Adam
"Stay Connected"

At 2:44 AM 3/17/97, Ryan nEwEll wrote:
>>after a long time. All and all it was a great party, to bad about that
>>fight that happened out front, I was outside when I first started, kinda
>>scary, but still a great party! :)
>
>Wow, I'm surprised that there could be a fight at a party like this...what
>was it all about?

As far as I know (I was downstairs when it happened) a van with six people
in it stopped in front of our space.  A couple of them jumped out and
walked up to someone on the street wearing an A*didas shirt.  They tried to
jump him and one of our door people managed to help kind of get in the way
(he got hit in the face but not very hard).  The people left.  They came
back again a few minutes later and tried the same shit.

I'm not exactly sure that is how the whole story goes, (anyone from cf who
was at the door can fill in here ?) but what we got out of it was that
these guys didn't like the fact that this attendee of condensation had an
A*didas shirt on.

We proceeded to stock the front entry way with three or four big, tall
people and although the idiots drove by six or seven more times, they never
got out of the car again.

love scott

X400-Recipients: non-disclosure;
Message-Id: 
  <"0097D332DB15C160*/c=us/admd= /prmd=kaiperm/o=ncal/ou=notes/s=Ayres/g=Leslie/"@MHS>
Date: 17 Mar 1997 13:02:20 -0800
From: Leslie Ayres <Leslie.Ayres@ncal.kaiperm.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (Return requested)
Subject: Phunky Phoenix Review
MIME-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Just wanted to let you all know that there's a lively scene in Phoenix.  I go down for baseball annually, but since I travel with my 88-year-old surrogate grandmother (oh boy, that's another story), I can't do my usual all-night stuff.  However, I was able to get out twice to sample what's going on down there.

Friday night was Utopia, which is a club that's moved to Scottsdale from Las Vegas.  Not bad for a club... interesting since it's 21 and over until 1 a.m. (when the bar closes) ... and then they let in the 18-21 crowd, so things became more raver-like after 1.  Lots of miniskirts and giggly girls fixing makeup in the bathroom, and lots of cruisy vibes ... but also many friendly faces and great dancers too.  Could have lived without the security goon standing on a ledge between the bar and dance floor like Robocop.

The highlight for me was a live drummer -- his name is something like Shaireen (I have it written down at home w/his phone #s) and he was INCREDIBLE.... has a setup of six or seven drums including conga, plus misc. cymbals, set up right in front of the speakers, and he plays intermittently with the djs ... and he doesn't miss a beat, goes into a trance-like state and ROCKS!!!!  He dances and drums, and dances and collapses, and drums and kneels down in front of the speakrs.  Absolutely amazing, the first time I've  ever seen a live drummer work so closely with a dj ... it took the music to another level. He's from Orange County,  works/records with the Hardkiss brothers a lot up here, says he's played at Spundae.  I'd sure love to see him bring his amazing stuff to one of our parties sometime.

Saturday night,I was invited to a small underground called Phunky Town.  Arrived around midnight, a small warehouse near downtown Phoenix, saw a cop cruising slowly by, turn around, cruise by again.  When I asked at the door if they get busted, they said never had, that the cops are really cool with them.  A last-minute party (planned Thursday), decorations were as minimal as they come (half-inflated balloons hanging from the ceiling and a light ball)... but the music was good and the crowd felt like home.   Stayed a couple of hours and had to go home.  Would have had more fun if I knew more people down there, of course.

Musically, it's hard to generalize based on two parties, but I did notice that all the djs seemed to use long transitions in the music rather than tight beat-matching ... it kept me from really getting into a steady dance groove, and the crowd Saturday didn't dance nearly as much as I would have thought ....  but all-in-all, it was comforting to know that there's a healthy scene there.  Bought a couple of tapes from local djs at Swell... who are planning their 4th anniversary party coming up in a week or so... if anyone's going down that way, it sounds like it will be a great outdoor massive. 

Hope you all had a great weekend here, too!

Love, Leslie

you wrote:
> I rave sober, so when I say I
>*love* you, I mean it, it is not drug induced love.


i hope you are not serious. 
i hope i misunderstood something here. 
are you saying that the love i feel on e is not real? 
e doesn't induce love. it induces openness and trust, it makes us forget
that we should be aware of strangers and that's why we can love. anybody.
unconditionally. no fear! in an otherwise scary world. and i am soooo happy
that there is one place where i can be where i don't have to be afraid
because ravers take care of each other.

 so,  when i am on E and i say i love you, i mean it. and when i am sober
and i say i love you, i mean it.

 i believe that E opens the door to trust and unconditional love but that
doesn't mean that this love and happiness is worth any less or that it
disappears the moment you step out into the morning light (as some non-raver
i talked to last night suggested). 

sorry if i'm a bit touchy at the moment. i'm still a bit emotional from the
rave on saturday (and i still haven't slept much since then. tell me if i am
overreacting). it was such a good night and my boyfriend was so wonderful to
me. but if what you are saying is right, then he was only so nice to me
because he was on e????
i don't think so! i'll ask him when he get's home.

please don't look down on people who use drugs. please don't say their
feelings aren't real. drugs just amplify what you have inside of you. 

love you all and i can't wait to meet you soon.

iris

Precedence: bulk


you know, in general, i agree that E doesn't create feelings that aren't
there, it only amplifies ones that are.

but unfortunately, i have known people to say "i love you" and other very
nice things to people on E only to ignore them (or even forget who they
are) when sober.

it takes a bit of _conscientiousness_ in order to be sincere on E.  i find
that as long as i am aware of what i am saying, i don't say anything i
wouldn't agree to when sober.  but when you're high -- especially when
you're _really_ high =) -- it's all too easy to forget that you don't
always feel the way you do at that moment, and you shouldn't say anything
that might be taken as a promise of how you'll feel the next day unless
you are certain you will still feel that way.

love,

brian

!!!!!!!!---Hello again---!!!!!!!
I just woke up this wonderful Monday morning with such a tale and i didn't 
know who to share it with!
And while reading every post with loving care, it came to me! who better to 
appreciate it!?!
!!!!!!!!!!!!...I had a lucid *flying* dream...!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
this has *never* happened before in my whole life!
(if you don't know, lucid means that while your dreaming, you know your 
dreaming, and you can plot and manipulate what happens...)
I also had happened to master the art of flight... 
So those of you who might want to attempt to do the same...
i had a green veggie salad for dinner, and munched on some licorice sticks
went to bed round 4AM and had talked to my mommy, who even while she's
thousands of miles away, can still give me happy snuggly feelings... :)
so i feel asleep happy, and woke up *EXTATIC*
the biggest problem was, i got verry dizzy, up there so high...
i might need to re-master the art of avoiding vertigo?
Okay, so i also wanted to say i love you.. :)
(give me any excuse! haha)
AND i'd like to hear some more stories about dreams!!! does anyone 
elce have lucid dreams?  usually when?
and flying dreams?
re-occuring dreams??
what is your best dream?
Thanks! and !hugs!
