hey! 

i have been trying to induce lucid dreams for such a long time now, but to
no avail! i have tried so many techniques and such, but to no avail. i even
recently turned to melatonin but that doesn't seem to work for me either.
hmm.. maybe it's just me.

but normally i usually have very intricate, detailed, LONG LONG dreams.
maybe it's because i sleep about 10 hours a day, i dont know. 

like last nite, i had a dream i was at a concert, i got there, and went
inside, and it was a MADONNA concert, and it was all good, i worked my way
to the front and i was dancing around having a great time, and then the
concert ended and most people cleared out and there was a lineup up over the
stage of people who were meeting her and shaking her hand as she sat in this
big red upholstered chair. so after the cue had dissipated i asked one of
the security if i could go up and i did, and i went up to madonna and low
and behold she was not WHITE but BROWN, and she had black hair but she
looked like madonna (maybe it has somehting to do with the fact that i am
brown but who knows) so anyway i talked to her and blah blah blha.. and then
she thanked me and showed me the door to the parking lot where i had to
catch my ride.

the weirdest experience with dreams i ever had was once when i came home
from a party, i was all messed on crystal, so i took a few melatonin pills
to calm me down and put me to sleep. but before i fell asleep i called my
friend steve to say hi and catch up...but he had to go and told me he would
call me later. so i waited a bit and then fell asleep.. and i dreamt of
picking up the fone and talking to him a bit and then telling him that i was
too tired to talk. (i thought i was asleep and dreaming)... and later when i
woke up i remembered it and i thought it was so odd, and then i started
wondering if i had dreamt it or if it had been real, and i sat there for 20
minutes trying to figure it out until i decided to call him back. and HE
said that he indeed had called me back, and i had been talking normally and
everything and i told him that i had been ASLEEP at the time and we both
thought it was very weird.

so that was my weirdest experience...talking in my sleep and then dreaming
about it (:


naeema

something to do with the story line. it was such a lovely dream filled
with all this love and everyone was being so nice to me... so much
different than the horrible nightmares i have been experiencing for oh,
say the past two months. wow, cool, just one of those things. 
***stariana***

Sorry it's late but I'm only just beggaring to feel normal again! I just
HAD to say how much I Loved this Experience. Nothing I have ever been to
in England compares the  total friendship I received from all  new ppl I
met. Thank you to those that were there and organized it. I must say
personal thankyous to a few special people firstly Brett who gave me ride
to and from the event He even took me to a hotel with a glass lift just
after we left and the view, WOW what a beautiful city you have from 32
stories up! I will always be his friend even tho I met him 1hr before the
event. Secondly Scott who sent me a ticket - thanks and I'm glad I met
you albeit briefly. Thirdly a guy named Greg who sortEd mE Out With two
of my favorite things to swallow. Being from England and not too familiar
with capsules rather than pressed tablets I was expecting to feel happy
after an hour or so and wasn't at all. I was ( unfortunately ) thinking
that I'd been had and thus took the other one I had intended for an Event
in the future. I was  wrong.  Some time later ( time lost relevance for a
while) I remember weeping with joy and feeling that  I was going to
explode due to the sensory overload caused by the most  moving music
(upstairs) - Wish I knew who was playing. Anyway I met Mat and Smilegirl
and some of thier friends who graciously let me use their vibrating hair
brush.  I spent a LONG time brushing my hair with it!  I met a lot of
other people who must forgive me as I've forgotten their names but they
all added to the Experience and made Condensation ( my first ever SF
rave) THE Best  time of my life to date. One last person to mention Is
Dana  ( Robins room mate) who doesn't have E-mail but maybe it will
filter through to her. THANK YOU  The time I spent with her was the best
bit of the evening. 
I wish I could say things about the music and the Dj's but I Don't know
any of their names. It was all GREAT - it made me dance anyway! 
These are just some of the things that happened to me that I thought you
might like to share. sorry if I've trodden on any ones toes.
If All the raves I go to in the bay area are Like this You'll make it
very hard for me to go back to England When the time comes!
Thanks again
Love Ed xxx

i would have to say that it isn't the drug that produces these feelings,
but rather, it melts a barrier between expressing feelings which, under
normal circumstances, would be embarrasingly difficult to express. i tell
people my feelings both sober and drugged, only i don't feel quite as shy.
same with anything. ever notice how open people are when they're liquored?
in fact quite some time ago, one of my friends and i were not as close as
we were previously and one night everyone was drinking and we started
talking about our relationship and how it had deteriorated and how much we
had missed the closeness we had once shared. now everything is cool
between us, almost as if nothing had ever happened and we talked about it
the next day and agreed on how we were glad that we were faded enough to
talk about it. of cousre, some people don't always mean what they say when
they are on drugs, whether it is nice or mean, but i am only sharing with
you where i stand on this issue. if i tell  you i love you when i'm on E
i'll tell you i love you when i'm not, too.
hugs, sugarkisses, and all that other fun stuff,
***stariana***
i love y'all!
have a starry day!

>But anyway, I must admit, in spite of my belief that the underground will
>maintain itself as deemed necessary, that I am a bit alarmed to find all the
>secret magical things I first found 1 1/2 years ago to be described in
>detail in a Hollywood entertainment magazine.  And I wonder too, now that
>the "alternative/grunge" scene is "dying", what happens to our rave scene
>after it becomes mainstream.  Of course, our underground will continue I
>believe, but at the same time, if there's anything that can kill it, it will
>be the mass commercialization of techno I believe, nothing saps & drains the
>life out of anything, nothing will wring everything out of it that it can,
>nothing will beat a dead horse till there's nothing left but pulp, but the
>frantic "Scramble for Dollars Wringer" that America at large will put the
>scene thru for its own end.  IMO.

Capitalism is triumphant. And don't you forget it baby.

>I'm curious how long the grunge scene
>existed prior to its becoming famous, and how threatened/protective/fearful
>did they all feel (if at all) when it did start making it big.  And is there
>any sort of an underground grunge type scene still?  

Well, I used to go to those kind of clubs back in the mid eighties,
except we didn't call it grunge, we called it punk. I remember seeing
Nirvana in San Diego in 1987: I thought they were a punk band from
Seattle. I think grunge was just a marketroids (successful) repakaging
effort. Sort of like the word "technicia." Though to be perfectly honest,
grunge is a softer, gentler punk. Sort of a pop-punk.

A lot of punkers were bitter and pissed off when "frat boys" started coming
to "their" clubs and listening to "their" music. Most of the ones I know
from those days don't care too much about music anymore.

>Or has it all been
>squashed by its own commercialization?  I wonder if the history of the
>grunge scene will predict our future.  

There are still punk clubs. There are still bands that play that music.
Probably about the same number as before it became popular.

>And on the other hand, maybe the
>introduction of techno into the mainstream will help to improve quality and
>the evolution of mainstream music.  I for one started liking commercial
>music quite a bit better after the alternative stuff started really coming
>thru, I felt that there was some good quality there that was entirely
>lacking prior to its introduction (ie: Aha, Wham, etc!  Ya gotta admit,
>Nirvana was definitely better than that earlier 80's crap that was being
>played.)  I wonder I wonder...

Yeah, I noticed that the stuff being played on stations like live 105 got
a lot better when grunge became popular. It seems to be happnening again
(I am liking the music on the radio more), even though I don't listen to
that much techno outside of raves. It's just not "listening to" music to
me, but the pop-techno on live 105 is pleasant.

I expect the techno/rave underground will do a bit better at dealing
with commercial success than the punk/grunge crowd did, mostly because
punk is so anti-mainstream that being popular is an internal contradiction.

"He's the one
 Who likes all the pretty songs
 And he likes to sing along
 And he likes to shoot his gun
 But he don't know what it means"

PLUR won't be messed up if more people practice it. It might even all turn out
to be a good thing, sort of the rallying cry for the up and coming generation.
I ain't holding my breath, but I have hope.

Peace,
Jim
------------------------------
Ser y no ser resultan ser la vida. -Neruda

Hi there,

(Please excuse the length of this post...But, I strongly believe these 
things...)

We are finally now realizing the inevitable - the mass acceptance of 
"electronica" (techno) and mainstream america's commercialization of it. 
 There are big changes coming to us all in this regard, and what is 
important, is how we all deal with these changes.  I can only hope that good 
will come out of this change.  Granted, the corporate sponsored rave is 
going to become mainstream, and soon.  The jokes about Prodigy, Chemical 
Brothers, Underworld, Beck etc...on stage at some big stadium rave is actual 
reality in the UK.  Festivals such as Glastonberry that pull 100's of 
thousands of party goers have been going on for years...Love Parade in 
Berlin this year expects upwards of 1million partiers!!!  Now that dance 
music is entering into the main stream culture of the United States, we all 
need to seriously look at how we plan to cope.

IMO, I see that there may be a huge separation from the UG and Massive 
cultures.  (even more than exists now)  If anything, the underground will 
move even further underground...like people will band together in more and 
more exclusive rave events.  I would argue however, that this may not be the 
best way to deal with things...

The parties that we all love so much, Harmony, F&F, Gateway, Sunset, Cloud 
Factory, Warmth etc...will all be innundated with increasing numbers of new 
people to the rave scene.  Not entirely unlike the trend that bay area 
massives have taken in the last few years.  The most important thing that we 
can do with these people, is accept them for their differences (like we all 
are accepted) and show them the ways that we know.

We love raving so much because of the energy we get out of it.  The biggest 
reason that massives do not hold this same energy is because of the people 
who are there.  These people want the same things that we cherish - love and 
acceptance, they just haven't learned how to acheive these things.  We must 
show these people why we love raving so much.  We must teach them how to 
open up to others, hug them and send them love, unconditionally.

We all do these things at the smaller underground parties because we feel 
comfortable enough to do it.  We are usually surrounded by others like us, 
people on different spiritual paths, but with open mindedness enough to love 
each other, in all of our individual forms.  But, most of us fall trap to 
the fears that are within us when we choose not to send someone love when 
they are different.  It's important for all of us to apply the same rules 
that we use while with fellow ravers, to _everyone_ else that we may 
encounter, regardless of how we perceive them.

I'm not saying that if you happen to run into an angry mob that you need to 
jump in and start hugging people...use your best judgement as to what 
situations present the best opportunity to give love in that manner.  But, 
what you can do in these situations, is allow them their anger, and think 
good thoughts about their inner selves.

Change brings growth.  That growth will run in the direction of the people 
who are most closely related to it.  Tremendous changes are upon us, big 
things are going to happen in our community, it is essential that we all are 
a part of these changes and the resulting growth.  The more people that 
become open minded and full of love, the better, no matter what changes 
might occur.

Thanks for listening,

Smiles,

Scott =)

Hi there,

There are definately big changes to both the earth and the global 
consciousness.  I think a lot of people are just afraid of what might 
happen, and are busy trying to calculate our inevitable doom and when it's 
going to happen.  If that's what those people need to do, fine.  But, I 
choose to live each day the best I can, and look forward to the next.  Fill 
my life with love and positivity at every moment.  If something like the 
shifting of the poles, or a giant meteor strike on the earth happens, there 
is really nothing I can do about it is there?  Until that problem presents 
itself, I will continue on the same path I am on now, trusting that if 
something does happen, I will be the best prepared for it that I can 
possibly be.

As far as Boomerang's words go, I am with you.  I feel the same uncertainty 
about our future.  I am both scared and excited.  It's important to try and 
find light in all the darkness however, if we cannot, then we will exist in 
the reality of darkness and fear.  If we choose to find positivity and love, 
then we will exist in the reality of positivity and love.  We are all in 
this together, everything that anyone feels effects all of us, both negative 
and positive.  With luck, and persistence, our feelings of love will 
permeate those around us, and the effect will snowball creating a global 
community of love and positivity.  If this happens, then we may together 
have the strength to prevent the massive destruction that everyone seems so 
terrified about.

Just my thoughts...thanks for listening.

Smiles, (and hugs, and love, and laughter...etc...)

Scott =)

 ----------

>
>you know, in general, i agree that E doesn't create feelings that aren't
>there, it only amplifies ones that are.
>
>but unfortunately, i have known people to say "i love you" and other very
>nice things to people on E only to ignore them (or even forget who they
>are) when sober.
>
>it takes a bit of _conscientiousness_ in order to be sincere on E. 

yes, you are right. but as i said to that guy who said that the love and
happiness disappears once you leave the rave: only if you don't carry it out
into the rest of your life. 

i have longed for this feeling of unity and safety for such a long time.
i've been involved in many community and co-operative projects, always
looking for a way of living and working without hierarchical structures or
-isms, with equality and respect. and the rave scene has come closest to
this ideal.

of course this doesn't work for everyone. there will always be some bad
vibes or weird things happening at raves. and there will always be people
who can live two lives. but in general ravers still love eachother when they
are sober. didn't you ever pass someone in the street who was wearing a
jacket from your favorite rave? and didn't you smile at him/her?

love,
iris

not lucid, almost flying, but really falling: 
i spend a year in the U.S. (minneapolis) as an exchange student and it was
the biggest most important thing in my life. first time completely on my
own, i had to learn to live my life myself (instead of letting my family do
it). in the first three months i had several, what i later called,
initiation dreams. 
two of them involved falling, which is my scariest nightmare. you know, the
ones where you fall down a cliff, high building, whatever, you fall forever,
your stomach in your throat, trying to hold on to something, completely
helpless. and before you hit the ground you wake up. 
well, i went over the cliff in a bus and on a motorbike and  in both dreams
i did hit the ground - and i survived! and my family was standing at the top
of the cliff, waving to me.

love,
iris

Hi all,

Want to hear some reeeaalllllly good Irish music?  Stuff that's modern,
heavily-influenced by the techno movement, and yet still wedded to
traditional Celtic harmony?  With some of the best-written lyrics you'll
find in the post-James Joyce era ;)?  By the most-loved musical troupe on
earth today?  With accompanying decks-wizardry from Scottish DJ Howie B?

Then go get the new U2!  It's called POP and is sooooooo good... I think
anyone who's interested in seeing how techno music can overlap with
traditional 4-minute pop songs will think it's fantastic.

(sorry for the gushiness here, I'm just such a shameless fan and my
Irishness is running a bit rampant today!!!)

cheers to all,
Tim

hi scott
ben and iris here with the british rave scene review, part 3

i wrote and you sent back:
>> takes an average of 3 hours to get in, tickets cost =9C25 ($37?),

i see the pound sign came out funny on your side. maybe i should switch to
american keyboard.

you wrote:
>I had thought that raving in the UK was banned/illegal...Have things=20
>changed?=20

they had to give up a lot of freedom to be able to hold legal rave. on
saturday there was police in the compound all night. and at 7 a.m. when the
music stops you HAVE to leave. they have in the past made people line up
outside for their coats, in the middle of winter. it was -2 C. they have to
get a licence and the organization that are putting the raves on have to
register as a proper business. it may suddenly sound very commercial, but
the people are real ravers.=20
there is still a lot of illegal underground raves, travellers parties,
parties out in the sticks, and the police is still trying to make it
difficult for them. but they just can't keep up with the masses. EXODUS, a
two-weekly illegal rave has actually reduced the crime rate in the vicinity
of Luton on saturday nights (every other week, that is). there is just no
point in and no good reason for prohibiting something that people really
want - and do anyway, whether it's legal or not.

>8000 person rave?  Wow.  I know of only the biggest commercial events there=
=20
>like Glastonbury and Universe Tribal Gathering,

glastonbury is the same thing. something like 60 % of the 65 pounds it costs
to get in these days, go to the police, that patrols the site and the
perimeter, and the corragated iron fence they erect around the whole huge
site. glastonbury festival was only allowed to continue under these=
 conditions.=20

>Any news you have on all of this would be greatly appreciated.  Especially=
=20
>because a friend of mine and I are going to be visiting London for a few=20
>days at the end of next month, and with luck I will be djing at a couple=20
>clubs there, although I would prefer spinning at a rave.

contact us again and we'll give you the contact number for EXODUS. Luton is
only 30 miles north of london. might see you there!

ben + iris

Illbient: music critics and/or artists in a race to either create or
propogate unnecessary and pretentious neologisms.  Let it pass like wind.    

DJ Spooky: though I haven't really heard much of his work, I know that I
don't like the fact that he tries to overintellectualize electronic music.
The fact that he's been given an honorary PhD in electronic music
by the alternative rock press makes me cringe.  

A couple other overrated, criticially lionized artists/acts of 1996: DJ
Shadow, Dr.Octogan (original full-length).

Rok.

Subject: Lucid Dream
X-Mailer: ScoMail 3.0.Bd
MIME-Version: 1.0
Date: Mon, 17 Mar 1997 16:48:12 -0800 (PST)

Precedence: bulk

> AND i'd like to hear some more stories about dreams!!! does anyone 
> elce have lucid dreams?  usually when?
> and flying dreams?
> re-occuring dreams??
> what is your best dream?

	Interesting topic...

	I can get into lucid dreaming pretty reliably, when conditions are 
right... I do it in the morning, when I wake up before I have to get up.  I lie 
on my back, and do controlled breathing and try to get into a meditation state.  
I find that concentrating on the "phosphenes", the stuff you see when your eyes 
are closed, helps. So does counting breaths, to keep stray thoughts down. Once I 
trance out, I often fall back asleep, and then almost always dream lucidly.

	It seems to work better the cleaner I am, drug-wise.  Its hard to get 
into a good trance when I'm dopey or jittery.  Music might help (I'm too lazy at 
that hour to put any on), but once I get past the threshold of meditation my 
senses (both internal and external) become so acute that I think it would be 
distracting.  If I'm with anyone she has to be asleep (I don't recall having 
seriously tried it two-at-a-time).

	I use flying as a basic test to see if I'm dreaming.  Often, I'll 
notice I can fly before I know I'm dreaming (like, I'll be running, and I'll 
notice I don't need to put my feet down).  Sort of, "Damn, why don't I do this 
more often?  Oh, I'm dreaming, right".  Then I really go for it.  Or, 
maybe I'll just look out a window, realize I'm dreaming, and take off through 
the roof. Sometimes there are obstacles to get through, usually trees or 
telephone wires.

	My favorite thing is exploring.  I seem to have a bunch of places in my 
head -- houses, neighborhoods, towns, cities, lakes, valleys -- which don't seem 
to correspond to anything in the real world (or very roughly at best), but which 
I can visit again and again. Some great restaurants and hotels too (sometimes 
there's a party going on)...  I think that the more I learn about these places, 
the more I'll know about myself.  Creating things out of nothing is also fun, 
but they go away when I wake up.

	I've found that there seems a limit to how high I can fly.  Sometimes I 
try to get away from the planet, but it gets very difficult when the sky 
starts to go purple.  I don't think its the lack of air because breathing 
underwater isn't a problem. Maybe this is like the thing in astral projection 
where you're not able to go too far from your body.  Or maybe I just have to 
visualize my destination...   but I want a surprise.

	Of course when I first started doing it, I liked the sex best (I was 
about 15).  But it gets boring after a few years...  when I'm lucid dreaming, I 
know the other people aren't real.

Andrew
-----------------------------------------
Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

Yeah... I have to agree...Last month's Details magazine had a very humorous
"Guide to Techno & Jungle" and it described "Illbient" as the sound of
"self promotion"... its just a word that DJSpooky (and his publicist?)
made-up. Gosh I feel disillusioned today... apologies to any DJSpooky fans
please don't flame me as I have a headache...

peace, Meri

>Illbient: music critics and/or artists in a race to either create or
>propogate unnecessary and pretentious neologisms.  Let it pass like wind.
>
>DJ Spooky: though I haven't really heard much of his work, I know that I
>don't like the fact that he tries to overintellectualize electronic music.
>The fact that he's been given an honorary PhD in electronic music
>by the alternative rock press makes me cringe.

>Shadow, Dr.Octogan (original full-length).

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 17 17:02:03 1997

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

just thought I'd comment a bit about the "commercialization" of techno.

someone used Europe as an example of rave style concerts and what happens.

My opinion is that techno will never be as big in the U.S. as it is in
Europe for one reason: the U.S. has too many Puritan roots and is *not* a
dance culture as a whole.  Many countries in Europe and Latin America for
example have always been more "celebratory" so to speak.  Mainstream
american culture does not have such roots.  Dancing and hedonism are
frowned upon in a Puritan model, which we as an entire culture still
exhibit.

As we all have noticed it is "bigger", but I just can't imagine techno
itself reaching the proportions it has in Europe.  The average american
tastes are not the same as the average European's in this way.  If you
notice the techno "bands" that are making it big here have a certain
"rock" sound and also vocals.  This is a bit more acceptable than music
you'd hear at a rave.


Time will tell, I suppose.   I personally am happy that more people are
dancing these days and that I am included among them!!

Anyways, just thought I'd toss that out there.  It is only my meager
opinion!!

-kc

I'm still on Cloud Ten following this weekend's condensation!!  This was 
my first fantastic rave in quite a while... I used to rave all the time 
back in 93-94, and even though then I was going out a lot, raves on a par 
with Cloud Factory were still rare.  It's so wonderful to see that the 
scene is alive and thriving still!  It brought back so much... and I'm 
hooked once again!
  Hello to Ed, who I met through the list and had a great time with at 
the party and afterwards...  april, sorry I didn't get to meet you this 
time, but I'm sure there'll be others!  What's up to matt from fairfield!
  Some comments on the party:  Fabulous space, phenomenal music, high 
energy, a vibe that was truly palpable, friendly smiles everywhere!!  
And, being a non-tobacco smoker I really appreciated the non-smoking 
policy, which I've never seen at a rave before.  Free fruit and water was 
obviously great, and Travis and I had fun cutting it up for a while!
  Thanks to Cloud Factory for putting on such a plurfect event, and to 
all who attended for adding to it!  I felt incredibly welcome and at home 
even though I've been away for a long time!

love,

brett

P.S.  I'd love to meet any sfravers who live in the Santa Cruz area and 
possibly connect for future sf raves...  I have a car and would gladly 
give rides to anyone down here or on my way.  :-)

My best has yet to come.
        There is this amazing girl, she's full of thought and her life is
locked inside her unable to be released. A week in a half ago, she was raped
by a man who was trusted.
I've known her for a while, yet our first real conversation took place this
weekend. It's obvious that she is a very mis-understood person. I seem to be
the only one who understands. I felt a bond with this girl and our
conversations have changed me. I felt her pain, built up inside her, and I
heard how people thought of her. Both her and I know that we have something
the other needs. . . I feel that I can help her out greatly. The words we
spoke, and the words we didn't were completely understood by only us. I feel
that something will happen if she isn't released, and I feel that I can be
the one to save her soul.
        She is an extremely spiritual and psychic person. I've never had a
person understand me so well in my life. . . and most of our communication
was without word.

        I have to speak to her. . . 

        We can help each other more than we know, I actually feel as if
she's with me right now. . .

Strange world of ours. . . but two of us have it figured out. . . almost. . . 


SMILE:)

Aryck

> Then go get the new U2!  It's called POP and is sooooooo good... I think
> anyone who's interested in seeing how techno music can overlap with
> traditional 4-minute pop songs will think it's fantastic.

I think not. Remember in the late '70s at the height of disco, every artist,
no matter what genre, felt it was necessary to release a disco record or be
left in the dust? And remember the crap that was released as a result? Then
remember the crass commercialization that was found at the end of disco (think
Disco Duck)?

Well, U2's POP is a repeat of that situation. Except it's not disco this time,
it's techno.

got to GGate park around 4 in the afternoon..just in time to catch Jeno
do some magic on the turntables...it was so nice to see everyone have a
good time!..lots of smiles...and positiveness floating around...everyone
on the dancefloor were just grooving to the beat(cmon get up everybody!
:))..too bad it was a bit overcast..which was quite contradicting to the
SUN(name of the party)..much love to that hippy old man who looked like
he was having the time of his life..Much thanks to Space children for
this free party..it was great!...the moon..was a blast..although i
sensed a lot of negativity..when i got there...people pushing...giving
hard looks.. lots of people taking advantage of E'ers..ahhhh..that
hurts!..but around three..evrything started looking alright.....the true
ravers came out and totally vibed the whole party!! :)...saw so many
people I havent seen in ages..it was  a blast to just run up to them and
give them a hug...party ran out of water for four hours..so that
sucked...but a friend  and i found a bucket of water by the water
stand..which was eventually flocked  by water thirsty people!...thanks
again to all the wonderful people who made this night so amazing!...what
made my night was seeing my friend enjoy her first party..it just gave
me goosebumps to see her hug,,,and smile at everyone!...well..overall i
had a great SAT!...hope to meet  u all at SUNSET!...peace..christian

"Incursions in Illbient" put out by on the Asphodel label
is a mix of Spooky, Sub Dub, Bezar, DJ Olive and many others.
Closest thing to being at Recombinent '96.. which was 
illbient-heaven..



On Mon, 17 Mar 1997, Max Vision wrote:

> Illbient is truly a kick-ass genre of music.  I have but two Spooky CD's,
> and I am very impressed with his work!
> Max
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 18 00:07:09 1997

Subject: (NRR) Re: e s b techno music?
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello,

This being my first post to the list, please allow me to introduce myself!
My name is Gus, and I've been involved with the scene here in SF since
about '90... My first parties were Toon Town and Sunny Side Up, way back
when... I was so inspired by the scene that I started IF clothing in '91,
Realtime Clothing in '93, designed most of Journees stuff for the wonderful
Eric Lee, designed way too many flyers as Mindmeld, and played ambient
rooms as Team 2000 until '94...

Whew!

Since '94, I have been putting together a record label (Proto Records), a
studio (the Protolab), producing several artists, and writing music... and
now, we are very close to releasing a compilation CD of exceptional music
by the SF Bay Area's best undiscovered talent.

Some of you may have seen me and some of my cohorts play as Protolab at
Warmth.  We were totally amazed by the possitive response! Thanks to all of
you that wrote us with your support!  It meant a lot to all of us to be
received so well, inspite of all the technical difficulties we had...
We're working hard to make our next show better, and more enjoyable... if
you like our particular flavor of d&b! ;)

(BSP) Protolab is playing at the Harmony party on April 5th.

Sometime, foolish_fish2@juno.com wrote:

>both of these comments make me wonder about our music being so
>mechanistic that we are now resonating with the artificial sounds of
>machines and
>this concrete jungle that we have created. So much that we are becoming
>part of the machine. It is important to remember to also listen to
>the beat of nature...the pulse of the earth and the whisper of the
>wind and stars...so that we dont forget who we truely are.

Bleep! Blonk! Bloop!

Forget natural sounds... Who we are is who we make ourselves! Technology is
now and will always be an integral part of the human race... there is no
going back.  The challenge as an electronic musician is to create sounds
that are as organic and emotive as what exists in nature, but completely
artificial!  Unfortunately, not everyone who writes electronic music
realizes this. Listen to nature for inspiration, but keep in mind the best
music comes purely from the human mind, is given meaning by the human soul,
gives rhythm to the human body, and recorded with 18-bit digital hard-disk
systems... ;)

Take care!

- Gus

--
ProtoLab
Motion Graphics | 3D | Audio | Video | Design | Live Performance

mailto:audio@protolab.com

http://www.protolab.com/

Hi again!  ]=)

 "Believe" was a UCSC student club production. The club name is 
raV-O-Lution (I think that's right). In any case we could only go to 1:00 
AM or so because of school policies.  :(

 The party was fun though. It was especially nice to see so many SFravers 
there (hi Mike, Terry, Jen, etc.) and it was really nice to see some of 
the Harmony posse out there (hi Matt, Alex, etc.).

 We managed to get a decent sound system which was nice, but decorations 
were minimal due to a two hour set up time (dictated by UCSC).
 
 Siphon was pumping out some wicked jungle! His mixing was clean and 
smooth. :)

 MC 2 (Matt) was playing more trance/techno stuff which I found easier to 
dance to (too tired for jungle!).

 I napped for most of the rest (Sorry Joe!).

 As some artists have mentioned the process of producing art is sometimes 
more interesting than the art itself. In this case dealing with the UC 
system has been very, uhhhh, enlightening.

 Major hugz and thanks to those who helped out!! Big hugz also to the 
Madame and Liquid 7 for the love and support.

smiles,


Ran D.Dreams 							408.427.1666

In a message dated 97-03-17 16:38:47 EST, laren.k@easynet.co.uk writes:

<< 
 you wrote:
 > I rave sober, so when I say I
 >*love* you, I mean it, it is not drug induced love.
 
 
 i hope you are not serious. 
 i hope i misunderstood something here. 
 are you saying that the love i feel on e is not real? 
 e doesn't induce love. it induces openness and trust, it makes us forget
 that we should be aware of strangers and that's why we can love. anybody.
 unconditionally. no fear! in an otherwise scary world. and i am soooo happy
 that there is one place where i can be where i don't have to be afraid
 because ravers take care of each other.
 
  so,  when i am on E and i say i love you, i mean it. and when i am sober
 and i say i love you, i mean it.
 
  i believe that E opens the door to trust and unconditional love but that
 doesn't mean that this love and happiness is worth any less or that it
 disappears the moment you step out into the morning light (as some non-raver
 i talked to last night suggested). 
 
 sorry if i'm a bit touchy at the moment. i'm still a bit emotional from the
 rave on saturday (and i still haven't slept much since then. tell me if i am
 overreacting). it was such a good night and my boyfriend was so wonderful to
 me. but if what you are saying is right, then he was only so nice to me
 because he was on e????
 i don't think so! i'll ask him when he get's home.
 
 please don't look down on people who use drugs. please don't say their
 feelings aren't real. drugs just amplify what you have inside of you. 
 
 love you all and i can't wait to meet you soon.
 
 iris
  >>

Okay...
A) i am NOT looking down on you
B) when i did e, half of the people i met i do not remember to this day...
they say, "i met you here and you hugged me and said you loved me." sorry,
but i don't remember.
C) when you are on e, your feelings for those you already know and love
INTENSIFY and that is a very positive thing.
D) I have met people on e who say they love me, but then in an hour do not
remember me until i remind them for about 10 minutes.
E) drugs can be used as a doorway, but do not let them be a pathway. The path
leads you nowhere.  a very wise man said "choose you own idols, but blaze
your own path" (jake phelps, thrasher magazine) 
F) the BOND you form with someone on e lasts forever. and if you honesly LOVE
that person, the love does lasts forever.
G) I do not do e because the door was swung wide open for me.  I am following
MY OWN PATH to exstacy, nirvana, heightened sense of love and beauty combined
to one. without the aid of drugs (does pot count?) My experience with e has
changed me and helped me become more OPEN and FREE to LOVE. But it is a path
I now choose to blaze without the help of chemical induced behavior. 
H) E has HELPED me LEARN to love. 

Simply~~~> I do not need e to feel that euphoric feeling of *love* and
*beauty* that all comes to me naturally now.  When I say "drug induced" i
mean chemically euphoric.  what ever path you take is your own.  when the
door opens, step through and discover that other person in there.  you might
have more fun with him/her than you realize:)

hope this clears up any confusion.
it wasn't softend with <3's cuz I'm tired, just to the point.
please do not flame me.
it is mearly my feelings.
if you want to comment privatly, i would appreciate it more than have the
list have to bear through everything.

and i do NOT look down on those of you who do e. You know I love you when i
rub yer back for half an hour cuz i want you out of your e hole, or i get yer
arms with my crazy magic, or i give you candy cnady candy.
I care, and that is why I am here

smiles:)
{{hugs}}
love<3
april(4)
have you hugged yer fourth month of the year today??

hi april. hi sfravers.

april wrote:
>E) drugs can be used as a doorway, but do not let them be a pathway. The path
>leads you nowhere.  a very wise man said "choose you own idols, but blaze
>your own path" (jake phelps, thrasher magazine) 

i completely agree. drugs have been used as a doorway throughout human
history in spiritual rituals and in social contexts to create bonds and
trust and as a means to understanding and enlightenment. but too much is bad
for your body and your head. nobody likes addicts and they have usually
fucked up lives. it's a vicious circle. i generally don't do drugs when i'm
in a depressed state or dealing with some shit at the time (like jelousy or
lack of self-confidence) because, as i said, it would just amplify these
feelings. and the thought of a bad trip really scares me. i think that's why
raves are relatively violence free. people on e just can't cope with
weirdness or violence. i only take e very occassionally but i do enjoy it. i
love bonding with people at any time, but i also love it when i'm on e.

>F) the BOND you form with someone on e lasts forever. and if you honesly LOVE
>that person, the love does lasts forever.
>G) I do not do e because the door was swung wide open for me.  I am following
>MY OWN PATH to exstacy, nirvana, heightened sense of love and beauty combined
>to one. without the aid of drugs (does pot count?) My experience with e has
>changed me and helped me become more OPEN and FREE to LOVE. But it is a path
>I now choose to blaze without the help of chemical induced behavior. 
>H) E has HELPED me LEARN to love. 
>

again, i agree. i'm just worried that people within the scene who have
stopped using drugs for whatever reason will develop this patronizing
attitude toward people who still do. i'm not saying that's what you're
doing, i just always worry about something good like the unity of the rave
scene falling apart again because there's two groups developing (drugged and
sober, SF and LA, techno and jungle, black and white, old ravers and joung
ravers,...) let's just all stay one family, please.

>please do not flame me.
>it is mearly my feelings.
>if you want to comment privatly, i would appreciate it more than have the
>list have to bear through everything.

sorry, it was not my intension to be horrid to anyone. in fact, i agree with
everything all of you said. i guess i was overreacting after all and i was a
bit emotional last night. but now i finally had a good night's sleep and i
didn't have to go to work today.

this time difference is annoying me a bit. by the time you get going over
there at night, it's approaching morning here in the UK. no wonder i'm not
getting enough sleep. i'll shut up now. love you all.

iris

have a wonderful day

No way man--U2's been releasing remixes of their songs since 1981; they've
always been fans of dance music.  It's just always been more of a
house/gospel vibe with them, now they're getting into trance/trip-hop
rhythms.  
I agree that a lot of bands are bandwagon bands, but these guys deserve
some respect--they're the only ones who seem to be interested in
understanding just how much a part of rock n' roll techno really is.

Yes!  This was a cool party for only going till 1am.  I had to leave around
12:30, but the music was good and the space was cool.  Thanks Merc and
liquid for having me spin my junglism and sharing my style with so many
people that didn't really know what I was playing. =)

your events.  I promise to bring breaks this time! ;)

>Hi again!  ]=)
>
> "Believe" was a UCSC student club production. The club name is
>raV-O-Lution (I think that's right). In any case we could only go to 1:00
>AM or so because of school policies.  :(
>
> The party was fun though. It was especially nice to see so many SFravers
>there (hi Mike, Terry, Jen, etc.) and it was really nice to see some of
>the Harmony posse out there (hi Matt, Alex, etc.).
>
> We managed to get a decent sound system which was nice, but decorations
>were minimal due to a two hour set up time (dictated by UCSC).
>
> Siphon was pumping out some wicked jungle! His mixing was clean and
>smooth. :)
>
> MC 2 (Matt) was playing more trance/techno stuff which I found easier to
>dance to (too tired for jungle!).
>
> I napped for most of the rest (Sorry Joe!).
>
> As some artists have mentioned the process of producing art is sometimes
>more interesting than the art itself. In this case dealing with the UC
>system has been very, uhhhh, enlightening.
>
> Major hugz and thanks to those who helped out!! Big hugz also to the
>Madame and Liquid 7 for the love and support.
>
>smiles,
>

Hey Goolz...

I think this is going to be great. They are the same people who put on
Samhain and the visuals sound great. I think they are the Irish
folks...Also the venue - Mission Rock is funky with its wierdo-but-fun
atmosphere and location (right in the heart of the docks and wharves
surrounded by big ships) - I went to a party here once where they projected
the visuals onto the hulls of the ships - pretty cool. ALSO the Moontribe
folks will be there and they are something to behold (or to be-hear?)....

On Tue, 18 Mar 1997, ina v grubb wrote:

> both of these comments make me wonder about our music being so
> mechanistic
> that we are now resonating with the artificial sounds of machines and
> this
> concrete jungle that we have created. So much that we are becoming
> part of the machine. 

I think of it as remaking faceless, frightening technology into something 
tribal, passionate, real.  Redefining inhuman sounds to resonate with the 
deepest parts of our human souls.  Mechanistic bleeps are no longer the 
sound of alienation; they bring us to communalism and return us to a 
distant memory - the ecstatic dance to repetitive rhythm that humans have 
done since the beginning of time.


It is important to remember to also listen to
> the beat of nature...the pulse of the earth and the whisper of the 
> wind and stars...so that we dont forget who we truely are.
> 
Exactly!

> 
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 18 16:09:08 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id QAA26041; Tue, 18 Mar 1997 16:09:08 -0800 (PST)
Received: from inet-smtp-gw-1.us.oracle.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id QAA26023; Tue, 18 Mar 1997 16:09:02 -0800 (PST)
Received: from mailsun3-fddi.us.oracle.com (mailsun3-fddi.us.oracle.com [144.25.88.135])
	by inet-smtp-gw-1.us.oracle.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) with ESMTP id QAA32531
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 18 Mar 1997 16:09:01 -0800 (PST)
Received:  by mailsun3-fddi.us.oracle.com (8.7.5/37.9)
	id QAA21611; Tue, 18 Mar 1997 16:08:12 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <199703190008.QAA21611@mailsun3-fddi.us.oracle.com>
Date: 18 Mar 97 15:55:41 -0800
From: "LRITTING.US.ORACLE.COM" <LRITTING@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: NRR: Opinionated griping!
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Oracle InterOffice (version 4.0.4.0.25)
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Sorry people, but I have a small bone to pick.  Please hear me out.  This is 
my $.02 worth, and I want each of you to read the entire message before 
flaming. 
 
I'm truly tired of hearing the complaints about the 'pop' musicians, and 
'commercial' groups 'stealing' 'our' music. (I apologize for the quotes.  
There was a lot to emphasize.)  It seems that some of us don't appreciate 
vocals being put to dance tracks.  I, for one, am happy to see groups like U2 
finding a new sound.  I am happy to hear David Bowie putting his classic-style 
vocals over a heavy beat.  As their music becomes accepted by society as a 
whole (due to their standing as famous musicians), then 'our' music becomes 
more acceptable.  Our events become more acceptable.   
 
People say that we will lose our family.  Our family is here because we choose 
to create it.  Our scene is what it is because we make it that way.  As long 
as there are people who love this music, and love the people who love this 
music, then SFRaves will never die.  If you want small parties with a warm 
vibe and friendly people, then throw a small party with a friendly atmosphere, 
and the right people will arrive.  As our music becomes more mainstream, so 
does our attitude.  We have by no means found all of our friends who would be 
ready and willing to rave.  We have newcomers every day.  And one thing that 
we know is, you're never too old to rave.  Don't get angry with the younger 
ones who have yet to experience much of the world.  There is a lot for them to 
learn that many of us have seen, but they must still see it for themselves.  
Each and every one of us has a responsibility, if we care about our culture as 
much as we appear, to put a little time and effort into making this scene what 
we would like it to be... 
 
Thank you. 
 
Regards, 
 
Lucas Ritting 
 
"Whether outwardly or inwardly, whether in space or time, the farther we 
penetrate the unknown, the vaster and more marvelous it becomes." 
 
			-Charles A. Lindbergh

on 03/18/97 11:54 PM LRITTING.US.ORACLE.COM wrote...

>I'm truly tired of hearing the complaints about the 'pop' musicians, and 
>'commercial' groups 'stealing' 'our' music. (I apologize for the quotes.  
>There was a lot to emphasize.)  It seems that some of us don't appreciate 
>vocals being put to dance tracks.  I, for one, am happy to see groups like 
>U2 finding a new sound.  I am happy to hear David Bowie putting his 
>classic-style vocals over a heavy beat.  As their music becomes accepted
>by society as a whole (due to their standing as famous musicians), then
>'our' music becomes more acceptable.  Our events become more acceptable.   

  I think that the problem that results from the genre becoming 
mainstream is stagnation.  I seriously doubt that the radical evolution 
of electronic music that has occured will continue once it is completely 
mainstream.
  Why?  Look at evolution in general, it doesn't happen with massive 
groups, it happens in small isolated groups primarily.  Secondly, look at 
alternative and punk.  It wasn't that long ago, they were fucked up by 
over commercialization.
  When you have labels coming in, offering big contracts (ie, Virgin) 
this should be setting off some metal alarms.  Why are labels giving up 
on rap and alternative?  because of what they did to them.  U2, is a 
slave to its label, as indicated by the Negativland lawsuit.  Are these 
the labels that you want owning electronic music rights?  For instance, 
will you still be able to buy mix tapes?
  There are clearly some problems that are in store for electronic music 
in the coming years.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 18 17:04:07 1997

	id RAA09956; Tue, 18 Mar 1997 17:07:30 -0800

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello

Sometime, Lucas wrote:

>I'm truly tired of hearing the complaints about the 'pop' musicians, and
>'commercial' groups 'stealing' 'our' music.

There is no theft at all... but, when you take the inspiration out of
music, and replace it with what the latest
opinion polls say will sell the most... well, the result may be competent,
well-produced, and melodic - but they'll still be crap.

Good, timeless music comes from honest expression of an artist's vision...
The more dilute with marketing it becomes, the less likely
it is to be good...

>It seems that some of us don't appreciate vocals being put to dance tracks.

Vocals force a certain interpretation of the music upon you... I'd much
rather take the energy of the music and apply it
within my own mental framework.  The human voice is a beautiful instrument,
and it does have a place in dance music,
but when you change the focus from the music to the lyrics, something is
deffinitely lost...

The reason large record companies have been unable to exploit electronic
music is that there are no singers to package and sell!
When you have a singer, you can build an entire marketing angle around
them... you can exploit their drug-addictions, you can sell their
sweaty underwear, you make money on what they look like... the music
becomes secondary.  There are some fantastic studio
musicians who will never be recognized, even though you listen to their
music every day... some skinny, strung-out idiot who can't
sing in key gets all the recognition (and money) because he looks good on
stage... I won't give any examples 'cuz I'm nice... :)

>I, for one, am happy to see groups like U2  finding a new sound.  I am
>happy to hear
>David Bowie putting his classic-style vocals over a heavy beat.  As their music
>becomes accepted by society as a whole (due to their standing as famous
>musicians),
>then 'our' music becomes more acceptable.  Our events become more
>acceptable.

It was a new sound in 1988.  Picture Mr. Bigshot, head of marketing at Big
Records in a meeting...

"oh shit, band X's music isn't selling anymore... I guess this grunge thing
is dying out! What other genres are left unexploited?
Hmmm... there's Heavy Metal... whoops, no we did that in the late 80's...
hmmm, how about this Techno stuff?"

>People say that we will lose our family.  Our family is here because we choose
>to create it.  Our scene is what it is because we make it that way.

>Each and every one of us has a responsibility, if we care about our culture as
>much as we appear, to put a little time and effort into making this scene what
>we would like it to be...

Don't settle for mediocrity!  Fight while you can to keep the music and the
scene true to its roots!
Just because a big-name mainstream artist lends his/her name to a new
marketing campaign doesn't mean that it's cool...

I still listen to 'War' and enjoy it... But Zooropa bugs the f*ck out of me...

'Scary Monsters' is a good album, but can you honestly listen to
'Earthling' and say "hey, that is really original!".

I couldn't.

Blah blah... I'll get off this here soapbox...

Regards,

- G

--
ProtoLab
Motion Graphics | 3D | Audio | Video | Design | Live Performance

mailto:audio@protolab.com

http://www.protolab.com/

Hi all!  ]=)

On Fri, 14 Mar 1997, Martin Randall wrote:



>                     What is a rave?


 A rave, for me, has always been an enviroment where artists can get 
together and create a new social enviroment. Not just the DJ's, or the 
visuals people or the props people or even the live acts. But, ideally, 
everyone is applying their creative powers to make the event unique, 
special, meaningful and inspiring.

 Exploring the edge of social gatherings has always been what raving is 
about for me.




Ran D.Dreams 							408.427.1666



                                      (Namaste)
                                         /
                                   -=*=-/
                                     ~

--=_ORCL_33146679_0_11919703181810490
Content-Transfer-Encoding:7bit
Content-Type:text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"

 
>  I think that the problem that results from the genre becoming  
>mainstream is stagnation.  I seriously doubt that the radical evolution  
>of electronic music that has occured will continue once it is completely  
>mainstream. 
 
I feel that regardless of the 'mainstreamness' (to coin a term) of any music, 
the evolution continues underneath the surface in a counter-current to the 
popular styles.  Look at rock n' roll.  It began as a not-so-humble cousin of 
the blues.  We trace the roots of most of our current styles of music back to 
the blues.  Where do we trace the blues to?  The blues comes from an 
amalgamation of European classical scales and African styles and rythms.  Punk 
evolved from rock, and alternative evolved from punk.  Does this mean that I 
can't hear blues when I want to?  Blues is played constantly.  Jazz styles 
have evolved for many years, and continue to evolve at an incredible pace.  
And why?  Because there are people who love the music, and love the people who 
love the music.  We can be just the same.  The punk scene, although 
commercialized, never gained the support of the populace as acceptable.  The 
image of violence and outrageous behavior saw to that.  Whether our scene 
follows the same fate depends entirely upon us.  Our image of drugs and 
outrageous behavior (recognize the public's perspective here) could cause 
this.  The image that the mainstreaming of our culture portrays will determine 
this.  Our scene is still young regardless of how we see it.  The media sees 
it as this 'new craze'  and so it will be considered by the populace.  The 
important thing here is to recognize that we control our fate here.  If we 
decide that the scene will remain, we can make it so. 
 
 
Regards, 
 
Lucas Ritting 
 
"Whether outwardly or inwardly, whether in space or time, the farther we 
penetrate the unknown, the vaster and more marvelous it becomes." 
 
			-Charles A. Lindbergh

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: part 2
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

How much do you love raving?
A handbook for responsible raving


The Goodvibe Starts from Within

Stop complaining
about everyone else. What about yourself?
Are you treating others
the way you want to be treated?
That is the only route toward the
positivity that will unite us all.
Don't be afraid!
Fear is the source of all our conflicts and
aggressions.
The next time someone gives you a hard look,
understand that they are still captive
to their fears like you once were.
Don't resort to a negative response because that
will only create more negativity.
Smile! Let the goodwill within you flow!
Maybe your strength and love will give them
the courage to open themselves,
and they will follow the new direction.
It is all up to you...
-tito

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 18 19:25:58 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id TAA25734; Tue, 18 Mar 1997 19:25:58 -0800 (PST)
Received: from emout11.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id TAA25725; Tue, 18 Mar 1997 19:25:54 -0800 (PST)
From: Too4Short@aol.com
Received: (from root@localhost)
	  by emout11.mail.aol.com (8.7.6/8.7.3/AOL-2.0.0)
	  id WAA22937 for sfraves@hyperreal.com;
	  Tue, 18 Mar 1997 22:25:22 -0500 (EST)
Date: Tue, 18 Mar 1997 22:25:22 -0500 (EST)
Message-ID: <970318222351_-1471891402@emout11.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: part 5
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

*IGNORANCE IS OVERCOME THROUGH COMMUNICATION AND EDUCATION*

Ignorance is the easiest problem to overcome but it also depends on
individual efforts.. All we need to do is educate ourselves. But two
things must happen before we can educate each other.

First, we must be willing to be educated... we must recognized that we are
being stupid and want to change.

And secondly, we must communicate with each other.

Since we have no organized arena for ravers to come together and
communicate we are held in the dark. We must find a centralized forum
where together we can learn from our past mistakes and innovate our future.
Until we find that forum, it is up to you to discuss these problems and
re-shape our future.

The existence of rave culture depends entirely on you to simply talk with
one another... to share all of these important issues with others... with
people you meet for the first time.

Know what you're talking about-
Rumors and misinformation are splitting us apart. Know the facts about the
realreasons for "busts"... or the dangers of certain substances. Don't let
yourself be used as a tool for a promoters personal gain... or mouthpiece
for fabricated drug hysteria.

Know what you're taking-
We've already discussed unscrupulous drug dealers. Don't combine lots of
different drugs! There are combinations of substances that can quickly
become lethal. In fact, more drug related casualties are due to lethal
combinations of drugs and alcohol than overdosing!

Let the DJ do the mixing!

Know your limit-
Your accountability group can help you with this. Be careful trying to
"bump" your dosage. Always let someone know exactly how much of what your
taking BEFORE you take it.

Know the law-
Get to know the specific legalities of possessing controlled substances.
Know the consequences if you're busted and ask yourself if it is worth the
risk.

Know how to handle yourself with the police-
Be cooperative but also know your rights regarding search and seizure laws
(especially in searching a vehicle). Avoid dragging down the rave scene
with you. Don't even mention
raves if you have a run in with officers. Be afraid of the seriousness of
the consequences but don't let yourself be intimidated to the point that
you incriminate yourself.

Know what to do in case of an emergency-
This is a very important area if we wish to police ourselves at raves.

In case of an overdose or other drug related medical trauma
follow these steps before calling an ambulance.

1)Move the victim to a safe, private and discrete area away
from the noise and everyone else.

2)Find out EVERYTHING that they took... including
dosage, combinations and alcohol.

3)Find the victims friends.

4)Don't panic. Some drug related trauma can be relieved
simply through sleeping it off.

5)Find someone trustworthy and knowledgeable about those
substances and get their advice. (Like Medi-Rave!)

6)Do NOT administer CPR, induce vomiting, or other
first aid proceedures unless fully capable and qualified.

7)In the desert or in a hot venue, dehydration
could be the problem, so try drinking some water.

8)If necessary ask security to call for help or ambulance.

Know your promoters-
It's time that ravers determine how much an event is worth.
If you think you're getting ripped off or if a promoter is
constantly being busted... STOP SUPPORTING THOSE EVENTS!!! Try to remember
that promoter's other events. Think about what the promoter promised for
those raves...

Bust-free? (which might not really possible anymore)
Carnival rides/visuals/multiple areas?
Free water/gifts/etc.?
Big name Djs/bands?

So what do you and your accountability group do if you're
not getting your money's worth? All of you should:

-find and tell the promoter that you're not satisfied
-leave a message(s) on the voice mail
-don't go to that promoter''s events again
-write letters to local music magazines
-post to the internet rave related mail groups
-throw your own event... large or small!!!

Remember that many promoters throw raves for a living and
that they must make money. We're not asking promoters to
lose money! We're thankful that they go through all the
hassle to even HAVE an event to go to. However, we ARE
asking promoters to re-invest into the scene.... after all... if
the scene doesn't survive, the promoters don't survive either.

Support promoters that are helping our movement flourish...
that are innovating with creative ideas...that deliver what they
promise... that re-invest in the scene... that respect ravers,
DJs, venues, officers, public opinion and Mother Earth!




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 18 19:26:20 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id TAA25996; Tue, 18 Mar 1997 19:26:20 -0800 (PST)
Received: from emout12.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id TAA25952; Tue, 18 Mar 1997 19:26:14 -0800 (PST)
From: Too4Short@aol.com
Received: (from root@localhost)
	  by emout12.mail.aol.com (8.7.6/8.7.3/AOL-2.0.0)
	  id WAA10563 for sfraves@hyperreal.com;
	  Tue, 18 Mar 1997 22:25:42 -0500 (EST)
Date: Tue, 18 Mar 1997 22:25:42 -0500 (EST)
Message-ID: <970318222305_1409806132@emout12.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: part 4
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

*CARELESSNESS IS OVERCOME THROUGH ACCOUNTABILITY*

Carelessness, which sometimes is accidental, can easily be
overcome through a system of accountability. It only takes
two friends to commit to be accountable to each other in
reminding the other if they are being careless. The more
people you have in your accountability group (also called
"true friends"), the less likely you are to do something
careless. Create an acountability group with the
friends you rave with the most. Ask
someone to be accountable for you RIGHT
NOW!!!!

All you have to do is give a simple reminder.... speak up and
say, "I don't think it's such a good idea for you to do that."
Here are some places where carelessness becomes a problem
for each of us in the rave movement:

Forgetting about any of the above selfishness issues-
Go ahead... re-read them!

Driving safely-
There is nothing wrong with being too messed up or too tired
to drive home... unless of course you try to drive anyway.
Ask a more sober friend from your accountability group to
drive or wait until someone is able to drive. Coffee and other
stimulants won''t do the trick.. Take your time so you
and your friends can rave again another day!

Dealing with the wrong people-
Who are the wrong people? Unscrupulous drug dealers are just as problematic
as
undercover drug enforcement agents. If you think getting something "bunk"
is a problem.... think about how bad it would be if you bought something
poisonous or lethal! This is becoming a bigger and bigger problem as drug
manufacturers are finding cheaper ways to make money. Most of them aren't
chemists and don't bother testing their new batch... you may become a "test
subject" for an unknown substance. The media and law enforcement agencies
are infiltrating our masses to collect information to use against us at a
later time. You can never know who is who... so be careful. Know who
you're dealing with.

Loitering outside of the venue-
This only draws attention to the event and makes police curious enough to
"investigate." Loitering also makes it more difficult to patrol a parking
area to look for people breaking into cars or doing other selfish
activities that hurt individual ravers and hurt the scene overall. When
you're walking through a parking lot and you see people standing around ask
them to please go inside... but explain to them why it is important for
them to help in this regard.

Acting safely/Acting responsibly-
This is a broad area that has too many specific "infractions." Every once
in a while just ask yourself (and the people you''re accountable for) these
questions...

What am I doing?
Am I directly/indirectly harming myself or other ravers?
Am I keeping someone else from having a great time?
Am I helping build a positive public image about the rave scene?

Today Lucas posted some words of truth (copied below for those who
filter out "NRR" stuff... because it's totally rave related to me)...

Nail on the head.  I know it's frustrating when you think that your
secret world is being revealed to the rest of the world... we hear the
complaints because "they" are stealing our music, popularizing it,
using it on their ... TV shows!   ...   I accidentally saw "Amp" on MTV
last week, and was so happy that there was actually music on TV
that I wanted to hear... but a friend said "oh no, that's awful... MTV??"

I don't get this kind of paranoia.  

How does popularity diminish your love of the music? Don't you love
it because it makes you happy, makes you dance?  How does it 
affect you if someone else loves it too?  Even if it's in a McDonald's 
ad (which, of course, isn't really gonna play the weirder stuff that
we start craving the deeper we get into anything). 

Is Mozart's music any less because people around the world from
all walks of life love Mozart?  Of course not.  And, when the Mozart
imitators try to follow that lead, doesn't that still bring up the general
level of music by setting such a strong example?

The happiness that our music and our scene bring is worth spreading around.
Being one of the first in any scene only gives you tenure, not ownership. 

If part of your identification with the rave scene is because of some 
feelings of a "secret club" that "we've" got better taste, "we're" more 
"cool" than the rest of the world, think about your real motivations
and if there might be a little bit of ego talking there.

Sure, things get diluted when they get mainstream... but that's the way
the world is.  Things change, they evolve, and they get modified again.

Change is good.  Like us, our music is changing all the time, and will continue
to change.  There will always be new territory, and as it gets discovered by
the pioneers, others will follow in their footsteps.  And when it starts
to feel a little crowded, then the pioneers find new territory again.  That's
just how life works.  There are pioneers, there are leaders, and there are
followers.  Pioneers never about the followers, they're too busy forging
ahead.

Our underground is about more than just the music ... it's about personal 
relationships ... it's about a place where people of like minds and spirits
(and musical tastes) come together.  We can keep our underground and still
share our music. Lucas is right... we can still be our little family dancing
on the beach, and experience all the we love about the scene ....  even when
they're playing jungle at Taco Bell.   

The music doesn't define us, we define the music.  I'd like to think we could 
even be a family without the music if we have to.

Much love, Leslie
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Here's what Lucas Ritting wrote...

Sorry people, but I have a small bone to pick.  Please hear me out.  This is 
my $.02 worth, and I want each of you to read the entire message before 
flaming. 
 
I'm truly tired of hearing the complaints about the 'pop' musicians, and 
'commercial' groups 'stealing' 'our' music. (I apologize for the quotes.  
There was a lot to emphasize.)  It seems that some of us don't appreciate 
vocals being put to dance tracks.  I, for one, am happy to see groups like U2 
finding a new sound.  I am happy to hear David Bowie putting his classic-style 
vocals over a heavy beat.  As their music becomes accepted by society as a 
whole (due to their standing as famous musicians), then 'our' music becomes 
more acceptable.  Our events become more acceptable.   
 
People say that we will lose our family.  Our family is here because we choose 
to create it.  Our scene is what it is because we make it that way.  As long 
as there are people who love this music, and love the people who love this 
music, then SFRaves will never die.  If you want small parties with a warm 
vibe and friendly people, then throw a small party with a friendly atmosphere, 
and the right people will arrive.  As our music becomes more mainstream, so 
does our attitude.  We have by no means found all of our friends who would be 
ready and willing to rave.  We have newcomers every day.  And one thing that 
we know is, you're never too old to rave.  Don't get angry with the younger 
ones who have yet to experience much of the world.  There is a lot for them to 
learn that many of us have seen, but they must still see it for themselves.  
Each and every one of us has a responsibility, if we care about our culture as 
much as we appear, to put a little time and effort into making this scene what 
we would like it to be...

On Mon, 17 Mar 1997, Nailvarnish wrote:

> Edition 3: This is no neccesarrily evolutionary, but you have to reach the

> 
> THE ULTIMATE RAVER:
> 
> How you spot them: The have all the clothes that you want. They have more  
>                 glowsticks, and bike lights on their bodies then even the  
>         average raver. In the day, they look the same sans                 
> glowsticks and bike lights.
> 
> Where you find them: EVERY rave. Seen dancing anywhere there are strains of
> techno,                         in malls down the street, anywhere.
> 
> Characteristic: They are always there. When they wake up the first thing
> they do is              put hard trance on and play it real loud. THey know
> everybody.
> 
> Pros: Best person to call when you want to go out. THey'll aways go with
> you,and they know where it is.They give you warning and directions to
> secret          parties. You can count on them being there. They lend you
> lots os tapes.
> 
> Cons: The can become About-burnout-raver (see below). They don't understand
> when    you're tierd, or don't want to go out.
> 
> Pray they don't live in the apt above you.
>

>

> 
> Cons: They never have any money except to go to raves   and for drugs and
> keeps   borrowing of you, for food and cigarettes.

This is the best definition (academic) I can come up with, hope it's o.k.
Through the use of drugs and music a rave creates an atmosphere which is
simultaneously trible and futuristic.  This thriving mass of humans seem
to function as a single metaorganism bent on transgressing societal norms
simply by not participating in the mainstream.  i.e. temporary utopia
followed by the expectation of a utopia (the next rave).
