Hey all i think  something messed up the first time i sent it...so i'll try
again. I got this off the LA Raves mail list...enjoy


How much do you love raving?
A handbook for responsible raving


The Goodvibe Starts from Within

Stop complaining
about everyone else. What about yourself?
Are you treating others
the way you want to be treated?
That is the only route toward the
positivity that will unite us all.
Don't be afraid!
Fear is the source of all our conflicts and
aggressions.
The next time someone gives you a hard look,
understand that they are still captive
to their fears like you once were.
Don't resort to a negative response because that
will only create more negativity.
Smile! Let the goodwill within you flow!
Maybe your strength and love will give them
the courage to open themselves,
and they will follow the new direction.
It is all up to you...
-tito


part 2

This booklet is not intended to be definitive in its' approach...
it is a starting point for communication about very important
issues that directly affect each of us.

Our hope is that it will encourage you to step away
from the music with some friends for a moment so
that you can discuss the importance of individual
efforts in responsible raving.

Yeah? So what's the problem?

It is becoming more and more difficult to continue our cultural
phenomenon known as the "Rave Movement." The reason
that raving is more difficult is because raves and even smaller
parties are being shut down by the police and other authorities
at an alarming rate. Apart from DJs, sound and lights, in
order to throw a successful event you need secure locations,
permits/permission and insurance. With any of these
ingredients missing there is a strong chance that the event will
not get off the ground.

In order to get these ingredients we must go to people outside
of the rave community... the public.

It is the public that formulates opinions about us as ravers.
Most times it is public opinion that keeps a landowner from
granting us on his property... that keeps an insurance
company from providing a necessary policy... that keeps civil
agencies from issuing a permit that makes an event legal and
"unbustable."

The police are not shutting us down because of a giant
conspiracy against ravers, raving and living life to its'
fullest...

They are shutting us down because of our own...

selfishness
carelessness
&
ignorance

If we rid ourselves of these anchors, our public image will
greatly improve and our fragile movement will surely
flourish.

How? What can you do? A lot!

YOU can make or break our movement!


part 3



It is incredibly easy to combat selfishness,
carelessness and ignorance and still have the time
of your life... maybe even have a better time than you've
ever experienced. Imagine having the best time you've ever
had at a rave... now couple that with the feeling of
satisfaction and accomplishment that you would get from
helping build up and progress our scene... knowing that you
 did your part.

*SELFISHNESS IS OVERCOME BY RESPECT*

Each rave event is not yours alone... it is a communal
experience made for everyone. It is the togetherness of
everyone that makes raves fun and fulfilling. To completely
kill a group experience it only takes a few individuals who
don't understand the concept of community. Here are some
examples of selfish acts. Each is followed by a way to
overcome the selfishness.

-RESPECTING THE PUBLICS'' OPINION OF RAVERS-
Visibility of drugs and alcohol-
Drugs are taboo to most of the public that forms an opinion about us... the
same public that gives us permission to
gather and rave. If you feel that you need to have your mood
elevated, please be discrete. Don't let anyone see the presence of drugs.
Don't give them a reason to accuse us. Nitrous
balloons are the biggest problem in this area. Balloons can easily be seen
from a great distance and the hiss of the valves
makes it very easy to find the tanks. PLEASE DON'T BRING BALLOONS OR
NITROUS TANKS INTO RAVES! Similarly marijuana can easily be smelled. It
is more difficult to find but don't make it obvious.

Being rude or obnoxious to non-ravers-
Rude and obnoxious behavior does nothing but upset people,
sometimes to the point of having them call the police. Please
be polite to any "outsider" that you encounter while on the
way to or away from a rave. Be polite to everyone for that
matter!

Noise-
Noise is a very big problem in most residential areas and is
often the reason for shut-downs. Please be as quiet as
possible going to site. Playing car radios loud, horn
honking, screeching tires and yelling can be louder than the
sound system enclosed in the venue. Loitering around in the
parking area is illegal and only draws unwanted attention to
the party. As you're walking to the door remember that you
are only moments away from being able to make as much
noise as you want!!

Fireworks-
Although cool to see, fireworks are a reason for instant shut-
downs. We all know about the danger of fires. Enough said.
Additionally, the loud explosions can be misconstrued as
gun-shots which will get the police to the location faster than
anything.

Guns and Violence-
Neither of these belong at a rave. It is our non-violent nature
that sets us apart... makes us better than than the rock and rap
scenes. Hopefully, a positive rave experience will change the
life of a violent natured person.

-RESPECTING EVENT FACILITIES AND THE DESERT-

Parking-
Park only where it is permitted and, once again, don't hang
out in the parking lot or on the streets. Don't throw trash and
flyers on the ground. Keep as low a profile as possible.

Tagging-
We lose locations because of tagging more than anything else.
Tagging simply tells the landlord that we don't have any
respect for him or his property even though it is the landlord
that has been so kind to share his property with us. Tagging
makes insurance rates climb. If you see someone tagging,
explain to them that they are keeping you from being able to
rave in L.A. Ask them if they want to continue to rave...
then ask them to please stop. Make sure everyone in the
area hears you so that they also become involved in making
the tagger stop.

Trash-
Many times the property owner is shocked by the trash left in
the facility, especially bathrooms. It only takes a few seconds
to find a trash can... a very worthwhile investment of your
time. Trash and especially flyers should NEVER be dropped
outdoors. The wind can blow them away and where they will
never be found... except perhaps by a park ranger or other
authority figure. It is very difficult to say "that trash
was already there when we got here" when the trash is a
bunch of rave flyers. Gum, candy and cig butts can be just as
incriminating.

-RESECT FOR OTHER RAVERS-

Aggression/Violence-
Part of the attraction of a rave is that it can be a place to escape the
craziness of the rest of the world. Leave your personal problems at the
door... don't bring them into the celebration. Alcohol often brings
about aggressive behavior as well.

The rave scene prides itself on its' peaceful nature so there is absolutely
no tolerance for violence or aggression. This even includes any
frustration that you may have with security, entry lines, etc.

A peaceful but enthusiastic attitude can quickly spread to others creating
a pocket of "vibe" that everyone will want to be a part of. Acceptance of
others, even those different from
you, catches on quickly and creates a bond among all of us. When outsiders
look in at our scene and see this bond, they cannot discredit it... they
can only see something positive...
perhaps it will be something that they will discuss with others. This is
the easieast way that we can create a more positive public image!

Blatant Selfishness-
This not only kills "the vibe" but it breaks us apart, making it difficult
to band together to help our movement as a whole. A prime example of this
is blatant nitrous usage. People sucking on balloons must know that they
are jeopardizing EVERYONE'S right to rave and yet they continue to do it.
Their short-term high becomes more important than the future of raving
itself. This kind of selfishness will certainly kill our future. PLEASE
DON'T BRING NITROUS TO RAVES... leave it at home where it won't be a
selfish act that discredits all of us.


part 4

*CARELESSNESS IS OVERCOME THROUGH ACCOUNTABILITY*

Carelessness, which sometimes is accidental, can easily be
overcome through a system of accountability. It only takes
two friends to commit to be accountable to each other in
reminding the other if they are being careless. The more
people you have in your accountability group (also called
"true friends"), the less likely you are to do something
careless. Create an acountability group with the
friends you rave with the most. Ask
someone to be accountable for you RIGHT
NOW!!!!

All you have to do is give a simple reminder.... speak up and
say, "I don't think it's such a good idea for you to do that."
Here are some places where carelessness becomes a problem
for each of us in the rave movement:

Forgetting about any of the above selfishness issues-
Go ahead... re-read them!

Driving safely-
There is nothing wrong with being too messed up or too tired
to drive home... unless of course you try to drive anyway.
Ask a more sober friend from your accountability group to
drive or wait until someone is able to drive. Coffee and other
stimulants won''t do the trick.. Take your time so you
and your friends can rave again another day!

Dealing with the wrong people-
Who are the wrong people? Unscrupulous drug dealers are just as problematic
as
undercover drug enforcement agents. If you think getting something "bunk"
is a problem.... think about how bad it would be if you bought something
poisonous or lethal! This is becoming a bigger and bigger problem as drug
manufacturers are finding cheaper ways to make money. Most of them aren't
chemists and don't bother testing their new batch... you may become a "test
subject" for an unknown substance. The media and law enforcement agencies
are infiltrating our masses to collect information to use against us at a
later time. You can never know who is who... so be careful. Know who
you're dealing with.

Loitering outside of the venue-
This only draws attention to the event and makes police curious enough to
"investigate." Loitering also makes it more difficult to patrol a parking
area to look for people breaking into cars or doing other selfish
activities that hurt individual ravers and hurt the scene overall. When
you're walking through a parking lot and you see people standing around ask
them to please go inside... but explain to them why it is important for
them to help in this regard.

Acting safely/Acting responsibly-
This is a broad area that has too many specific "infractions." Every once
in a while just ask yourself (and the people you''re accountable for) these
questions...

What am I doing?
Am I directly/indirectly harming myself or other ravers?
Am I keeping someone else from having a great time?
Am I helping build a positive public image about the rave scene?


part 5

*IGNORANCE IS OVERCOME THROUGH COMMUNICATION AND EDUCATION*

Ignorance is the easiest problem to overcome but it also depends on
individual efforts.. All we need to do is educate ourselves. But two
things must happen before we can educate each other.

First, we must be willing to be educated... we must recognized that we are
being stupid and want to change.

And secondly, we must communicate with each other.

Since we have no organized arena for ravers to come together and
communicate we are held in the dark. We must find a centralized forum
where together we can learn from our past mistakes and innovate our future.
Until we find that forum, it is up to you to discuss these problems and
re-shape our future.

The existence of rave culture depends entirely on you to simply talk with
one another... to share all of these important issues with others... with
people you meet for the first time.

Know what you're talking about-
Rumors and misinformation are splitting us apart. Know the facts about the
realreasons for "busts"... or the dangers of certain substances. Don't let
yourself be used as a tool for a promoters personal gain... or mouthpiece
for fabricated drug hysteria.

Know what you're taking-
We've already discussed unscrupulous drug dealers. Don't combine lots of
different drugs! There are combinations of substances that can quickly
become lethal. In fact, more drug related casualties are due to lethal
combinations of drugs and alcohol than overdosing!

Let the DJ do the mixing!

Know your limit-
Your accountability group can help you with this. Be careful trying to
"bump" your dosage. Always let someone know exactly how much of what your
taking BEFORE you take it.

Know the law-
Get to know the specific legalities of possessing controlled substances.
Know the consequences if you're busted and ask yourself if it is worth the
risk.

Know how to handle yourself with the police-
Be cooperative but also know your rights regarding search and seizure laws
(especially in searching a vehicle). Avoid dragging down the rave scene
with you. Don't even mention
raves if you have a run in with officers. Be afraid of the seriousness of
the consequences but don't let yourself be intimidated to the point that
you incriminate yourself.

Know what to do in case of an emergency-
This is a very important area if we wish to police ourselves at raves.

In case of an overdose or other drug related medical trauma
follow these steps before calling an ambulance.

1)Move the victim to a safe, private and discrete area away
from the noise and everyone else.

2)Find out EVERYTHING that they took... including
dosage, combinations and alcohol.

3)Find the victims friends.

4)Don't panic. Some drug related trauma can be relieved
simply through sleeping it off.

5)Find someone trustworthy and knowledgeable about those
substances and get their advice. (Like Medi-Rave!)

6)Do NOT administer CPR, induce vomiting, or other
first aid proceedures unless fully capable and qualified.

7)In the desert or in a hot venue, dehydration
could be the problem, so try drinking some water.

8)If necessary ask security to call for help or ambulance.

Know your promoters-
It's time that ravers determine how much an event is worth.
If you think you're getting ripped off or if a promoter is
constantly being busted... STOP SUPPORTING THOSE EVENTS!!! Try to remember
that promoter's other events. Think about what the promoter promised for
those raves...

Bust-free? (which might not really possible anymore)
Carnival rides/visuals/multiple areas?
Free water/gifts/etc.?
Big name Djs/bands?

So what do you and your accountability group do if you're
not getting your money's worth? All of you should:

-find and tell the promoter that you're not satisfied
-leave a message(s) on the voice mail
-don't go to that promoter''s events again
-write letters to local music magazines
-post to the internet rave related mail groups
-throw your own event... large or small!!!

Remember that many promoters throw raves for a living and
that they must make money. We're not asking promoters to
lose money! We're thankful that they go through all the
hassle to even HAVE an event to go to. However, we ARE
asking promoters to re-invest into the scene.... after all... if
the scene doesn't survive, the promoters don't survive either.

Support promoters that are helping our movement flourish...
that are innovating with creative ideas...that deliver what they
promise... that re-invest in the scene... that respect ravers,
DJs, venues, officers, public opinion and Mother Earth!


part 6

The best way to combat ignorance is to get and stay informed.
All that is required of this is communication! Call unbiased
info lines to get the "scoop" on upcoming events. Read the
local magazines that report on rave culture.

Perhaps the BEST way to get informed is... if you know
someone with an internet connection... get online! Subscribe
to So-Cal Raves or visit web sites like Dr. Freeclouds and
Hyperreal (see next page).

The information and feedback offered by online
communication can really benefit you as an individual raver
and will help the rave movement flourish overall. Here's
what you can get from being informed through the net:

-A calendar of upcoming raves, clubs, after-hours and rave-related radio/TV
shows
-Help determine which promoters and events are worthwhile
-Find out about events that you may have missed
-Read other ravers'' opinions of events, DJs, music, and mix tapes
-Find out more about DJs or bands you like
-Voice your frustrations about specific rave related issues
-Get advanced info on location, line-up, changes, and mergers
-Get info on specific drug-related warnings or scams
-Learn more about rave/DJ culture
-Find out about unpromoted events and micro-raves
-MOST IMPORTANTLY...
Find new raver friends that share similar tastes and views with you.

Getting Online-

To learn more about So-Cal Raves visit the So-Cal Raves
WWW homepage. You''ll find info about the list, the people
on it, the calendar of events and how to subscribe.

Just point your browser to:

http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/socal/

For more info on responsible recreational drug use, raving,
music and more go to:

http://www.hyperreal.com/

To get rave info on specific LA events and issues go to
Dr. Freeclouds at:

http://www.drfreeclouds.com

Thanks for your time! Hope to see you online and
at many fabulous future raves! 
-Kc

Thanks to those who care enough to help:
My So-Cal Raves Family, Hyperreal, Mason Lyte,
Medi-Rave,Tito, tom-of-stimuli, John 'n' Veronica, Dallas,
Garrett, Moontribe, Moonchild, DUNE...
...and YOU !

Recreational drug use is an evolving issue of individual
freedom. This manual does not promote the use of illegal
drugs or encourage illegal activity. The practical
references listed here are in no way to be construed as
favoring the use of controlled substances or illegal
activity but, is solely intended to promote
greater awareness of the issues of safety and
responsibilty in raving.

RESPECT+
ACCOUNTABILITY+
COMMUNICATION & EDUCATION=
RAVE ELATION FOREVER !

For more information or to find out how you can help in our
fight to generate greater responsibility in the rave community
please write to:

Responsibility in Raving
2014 N. Sycamore 1st floor
Los Angeles, CA 90068

or e-mail to
sarahtonen@earthlink.net

>the top three reasons the underground will not become inundated with
>clubbers, frat boys,


I used to live in a frat house in Berkeley.   They were renting out extra rooms.
This one kid, he always wanted to know why I was strolling in with a smile
on my face at 7 in morning.

So one night, I decided I was going to show him what it was all about.

He hasn't been the same since.

A couple of things he said to me on the way home the next morning, with a
dazed beautiful sad happy look in his eyes:

  o  "All those ravers.   They just keep...raving."

  o  "Everything's different.  Nothing looks like it did yesterday."

  o  "Some guy kept touching me and I was scared people would think I was
gay, but then I realized that it was okay."

  o  "I can't figure out what those kids are doing, but I know it's
something good."


later,

boomerang

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 19 01:45:24 1997

I just got the latest XLR8R yesterday and I was thinking about this the 
other day.  The mag has changed from paper back to glossy magazine print 
and in comes the more sponsers, the latest equipment adds.  There are 
mass expansions of music avaliable now - record stores opening every 
where(one is in the works for here in San Luis).  Dj's are getting 
bigger, parties too, BUT there is still a thriving underground.  I hope 
it can all coexist in positivity.  Will it survive strong, for as many 
years as we can put positive energy into it. ( and not get diluted into 
just a fad).

I hope so.

In a message dated 97-03-19 00:13:52 EST

<< If part of your identification with the rave scene is because of some 
 feelings of a "secret club" that "we've" got better taste, "we're" more 
 "cool" than the rest of the world, think about your real motivations
 and if there might be a little bit of ego talking there. >>

 I just have to say..... this is why i  was *SO SO SO* GLAD to be out of High
School!!!
In high school, everyone was in a secret club but me, and everyone had better
taste, and eeryone was more "cool" then me!   One of the reasons i love to
rave with all of my heart, soul and mind is because i am accepted by all, and
rejected by none, i can be a part of a community, that loves me, and
embrasses me for all that i am, and i am not afraid of being "uncool".  So
even if like, eating at Taco Bell isn't my thing, or frat parties, or
whatever, i know that i will share the love, when ever i feel the urge to,
and i *heartily* thank my raver brothers and sisters for helping me with the
confidence to do so!
Yeah Whooo for acceptance!!!!


------==00==-------LunaTune------==00==-----

--you can skip these paranoid rantings and ravings *wink* i advise you do--

** ** ** on a side note.. there is one thing that does kind of sit odd with
me.. You see, i know a bit about how and why things are made... like why
certian commercials use certian diddys.. and how the commercials are set in
rotation, and just rightly positioned to get to the most number of viewers,
at the right times... and not just commercials, but *anything* that has been
run through a company designed to sell to the mass public.  Now, at a rave,
we know the DJ's.. we can talk with them, and kick it with them.. but what
about these people making the music for these commercials?  I mean.. i read
reports on how sales are increased by the pace of music in a grocery store..
hence, the birth of muzak.. they will rotate the songs, so that, well, for
example: first, play a slow song, and gradually the songs get faster, and
this is encoragement for shoppers to think about buying.. (the slow muzak)
and gradually work their way up to decision (muzak getting faster) and at the
peak, buy the items and get out! and the cycle repeats... Well, if this
works.. wow, scary, and if it dosn't, wow, scary!  It dosn't seem *right*.
I just don't know.... i mean, sharing is one thing. but sucking people in and
molding them to be better consumers.. yikes! ;)  We all know the hypnotic
effect of techo music, we know how cool it is, and we know how addicting it
is.. i would just hate to see it exploited for the wrong reason... i mean,
untill recently, techo music was kept underground, but my fear is that these
companies, that are just set up to find what *SELLS* will use this for making
us better consumers... 
boy oh boy am i paranoid...  i think it is mostly because, being raised in
this generation, i was really taught to fear any "authority" and anything
that isn't on my own level of understanding... so maybe in my heart of
hearts, i'd feel much safer if my beautiful world of raving, music, people,
 and attitude, stays right where it is, underground...
on the other hand...... HAY, we're ready for change ;) let the world in on
our love!!
-------when it's love your dealing with, what can go wrong??--------
Love and *huggerz*
--Lunatune--

in 1992, so I'm close to the description!
>

>                 THEY  want, usually having to give them lots of space.

 I would LIKE to have lots of space to dance - and whatever the dance
floor crowd density, I try to dance the way I want to ( no point going
to a party if I can't be "uncool" on the dance floor! ).
 
> How you find them: Usually with their spouces, or they're telling you 
>                    their spouse tells them to grow up!. 

 I try to bring my wife whenever possible - she likes the music, but
doesn't have my endurance or limberness. I've been depressed lately,
and haven't gone to a rave in over a month. She's the one who 
suggested I go to something this weekend! Gotta love her ...

>         In the misdt of all these young people that worship him or 
>         her for his/her longevity.

for sacrifices, or maybe just monetary donations...

>         Still dancing when all the 20 year old have had it.

 Ha! I just pace myself - sneaking off where someone can't see you and 
taking naps helps to maintian that "superman" image.
 
> Pros: You can't believe they are still at it! You want to be like them.

 Nobody's told me I'm a role model - scary thought, actually.
 
> Cons: If you're not paying attention and get a glance of them, they make
>       you think of your parents at home, wondering what you're up
>       to.
 
 Actually, that's how I finance going to $20 massives - I contact 
everyone's parents, and mom and pop pay me to spy on their kiddies.

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

X-Mailer: ScoMail 3.0.Bd

	This has come up here before, so I thought I'd post an update...

Andrew
---------
Supreme Court Hears Internet Indecency Case

WASHINGTON (Reuter) - A Clinton administration attorney attempted
Wednesday to convince the U.S.  Supreme Court to uphold a law regulating
indecent words and pictures on the Internet to shield children from
sexually explicit material.

"The Internet threatens to give every child with access to an
interactive computer a free pass into the equivalent of every adult
bookstore and video outlet in the country," government attorney Seth
Waxman said during arguments in the historic case about free-speech
rights in cyberspace.

But Bruce Ennis, an attorney representing a diverse coalition that
challenged the law, replied that the measure amounted to
unconstitutional government censorship that violates free-speech rights
of adult Internet users.

"This law is a ban on indecent speech in cyberspace," he said of the
year-old measure approved by Congress and signed by President Clinton
that imposes government regulation on the worldwide computer network
used by about 40 million people.

The law makes it a crime punishable by as much as two years in prison to
transmit sexually explicit material to anyone younger than 18.  But the
law bars prosecution of Internet transmitters who take "reasonable,
effective and appropriate actions" to restrict access to minors.

"One of the real democratizing aspects of the Internet is that average
citizens can speak to the world for free," Ennis said, warning that the
law inhibits speakers in chat-rooms and affects what individuals put on
the World Wide Web.

He argued that the law will not be effective as children still will be
able to get access to indecent material posted on the Internet from
foreign nations and said less-restrictive measures, including parental
control, were available.

During 70 minutes of arguments, the high court justices vigorously
questioned both sides about the rapidly changing Internet technology and
whether minors could be prevented from accessing sexually explicit
material.

The justices appearing skeptical of the government's defense of the law,
but gave no clear sign of how they would rule.  A decision in the
landmark case, which could affect future regulation of the Internet, is
due by July.

Waxman, the Justice Department's deputy solicitor general, told the
court an estimated 8,000 sexually explicit sites already existed on the
World Wide Web, and that the number would double every nine months.

"The problem is very, very serious," he said, adding that minors could
be stopped from accessing indecent material through the use of credit
cards and adult identification numbers, which cost as little as $5 a
year.

But Justice Stephen Breyer questioned whether the government might
prosecute a group of high school students who discuss in a chat-room
their sexual experiences.

"That's been known to happen in high school," Breyer said.  The law
would make "a large number of high school students guilty of a federal
crime."

Justice Antonin Scalia interjected, asking, "There's no high school
exemption?" as the courtroom erupted in laughter.

Waxman sought to salvage his argument by saying the law sought to
prevent a high school student from using a computer in a bedroom to get
access to Penthouse, Hustler or other sexually explicit material that
normally would not be sold to a minor.

Justice Sandra Day O'Connor seemed concerned about the restrictions,
describing the Internet as "a public place because anyone can get online
and have a conversation.  It is much like a street corner or a park."

On software programs that keep minors out of sexually explicit sites,
Waxman said it was not feasible.  "There simply is no way (parents and
software companies) can keep up with what can or cannot be screened
out," he said.

Ennis emphasized he had challenged only the law's restrictions on
"indecent" or "patently offensive" material, not already illegal child
pornography and obscene material.

He said the law goes too far and would make it a crime for parents to
send an indecent e-mail message to their college freshman child.

-----------------------------------------
Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

i've pretty much said all i have to say during the preceeding discussion.
there is however one thing i'd like to add.

i believe that the heavy ab-use of happiness drugs like crack and ecstacy is
a sympton of a social problem rather than the cause of the problem. drugs
have always been used by humans and animals. they have been scapegoated to
distract from the real problem (disastrous social and economic
circumstances) by a society hostile to hedonism. drugs have a bad name. it
is poverty, desperation, a shit job, unhappiness that drives us to overdo it
with drugs and misuse them ( i have a personal problem with people who drink
too much alcohol. too much!). happy people don't need that much drugs. i for
example smoke less dope when i am not working than when i am.

we shouldn't really have this discussion. people should just accept that at
least for some of us drugs are a part of life and of our experiences in
growing up, learning (especially about ourselves), and socialising, forming
bonds (smoking the peace pipe).

it's all real! drugs are real! drug induced experiences are real!
change society and the drug problem won't be one anymore.

and with that i wish you all a good life experience with or without the
drugs of your choice.
iris

p.s. i like to refer to drugs as mind-expanding.

> Where to find them: Behind the decks, or hanging out with other DJs. 
> They
> NEVER dance. Behind their decks at home.
> *** Ah, strike ONE.  I know many MANY dancing DJ's.  One of the main 
> reasons Dj's are 'born' is because they are dissatisfied with other DJ 
> mixes ('I could better.  If they mixed in track blah blah, instead of 
> blah blah it woulda sounded cool...)  DJ's actually dance pretty funny 
> since they spend most the time 'bouncing' to their mixes and are 
> usually bouncing on the dance floor after their mixes.***
> 
> Characteristics: They are either ultra arrogrant, or they are really 
> cool.
> There is never an inbetween.
> ***There's always a middle ground., It just depends where You are on 
> that Meter of Life...***
> 
> Pros: We NEED them. If they're good, they make you estactic. You life
> depends on them. When they are starting out, they give you tapes, they 
> play at your parties all for FREE.
> *** Strike TWO.  Many DJ's exhibit the same characteristics even after 
> they've been around for a while...***
> 
> Cons: When they suck, your life feels like it's over. If they're your
> friends you     never see them, because they are either playing, or
> practiing.
> They don't go to the raves unless they're playing at it. you don't go 
> out with them and when you go to the one they're playing at they are 
> surrounded.
> *** Strike THREE.  A lot of DJ's are usually out @ parties to see what 
> music/ style/ vibe that other DJ's are creating.  They also 'learn' 
> from each other, usually incorperating mixing styles into their own 
> sets...  Every DJ want's to keep fresh in the scene and not sound 
> 'burned' (i.e. dated) so, yeah, you can see quite a few DJ's if you 
> know who's who out there... ***
> 
> Paz Y amour,
> 
> --_Adam
> "Stay Connected"
> 
> 
> 
>

It's a real trip when you go around handing them out, because people think 
you're handing of Jesus stuff at first. But When I did it down in LA, it 
was really really nice that people didn't throw them on the floor and 
took it home with them. We handed out quite a lot (over 200), and we only 
saw one on the floor.  But it 
took me 3 hours to make 50. Do it 1while  on the phone, so I encourage 
everyone to do some!!! AND the best part is, you feel all pleased with 
yourself. 


Nailvarnish

I have been looking for a new place to live in San 
Francisco for well over 2 months and I am getting fed 
up.  Becuase of this, I want to try a new stragety.  
What I want to do is get 2-3 compatible roommates 
together before we have  actually found a flat.  Finding 3-4 
bedroom flats is  not that difficult, but with landlords 
demanding first, last and deposit, total costs to grab a flat 
run upwards of 4500-5500 dollars.

I would like to find 2-3 other people who would be 
compatible roommates and search for a flat with them.  
If we find a place, we can all chip in aproximately 
1600 dollars to cover total move-in costs.  All of our 
names would also be on the lease.  My target date to 
find a place is april 1.

Here are some general guidelines for the type of 
people I am looking to live with.  These are just 
general guidelines:

-Under 30 years old
-Steady job with good income.
-Ravers, Junglists, Househeads, Trip-Hoppers, Trancers, 
ect. into electronic dance music. (dj, or producer?  yeah!)
-Male or female.
-*very* clean, *very* respectful of other roommates.
-Watches very little or no television.
-Creative.
-Into computers/technology.
-Into enjoying all the cool and unique things SF has to 
offer.

I'm a 24 year old electrical engineer who is best 
described by the qualities above.  I am interested in 
finding a flat in Potrero Hill, SOMA, Lower Haight, 
Mission or Delores Park. I'd consider other areas depending 
on the flat, but I would really like to stay on the east side 
of the city.

If you are interested, email me at tsheets@saturn5.com

-troy (http://www.saturn5.com/tsheets)

The Raver Handbook is available on socalraves website, which I think
is accessible by link from SFRaves website.. I've downloaded 
it myself in the past, because I think it's such a good resource.

Last year, someone printed out a copy in the booklet form it was designed
to go into, and brought them to a couple of parties ... I know I grabbed one and
held on until someone borrowed it and didn't return it.

I'd love to see it refined and polished and printed up in greater quantities 
to hand out!  I've had it in mind to contact the person (people?) who put it
together and see if they'd mind us building on it.

Leslie Ayres wrote:

> 
> I'd love to see it refined and polished and printed up in greater quantities
> to hand out!  I've had it in mind to contact the person (people?) who put it
> together and see if they'd mind us building on it.


	I personaly agree with Leslie.  This is a wonderful 'Idea' but it needs
a seriouse makeover if it is to be circulated.  In my opinion, it needs
a lot of refinement and polishing.  I talked to Sara Tonen (great name)
and the other people that made this booklet when I first saw it about a
two years ago.  This thing was writen by LA promoters, for the LA ravers
during a perio of negativity in the LA scene.  

	This "educational" pamplet could seriously backfire due to its
content.  It makes a lot of negative implications that ravers are
'disrespectful drug ingesting thoughtless troublemakers'  Now we know
that this is not the case, but the way this thing is writen, it is very
easy for an outsider to interit this pamplet as such.  If this thing got
into the wrong hands (parants, media, police, city oficials...etc.) then
it would look very bad for the rave scene.

	This is pamplet was desighned as a "REACTIVE" tactic by the LA
promoters to inform people in the LA scene that they are acting like a
bunch of ignorant and disrespectfull junkies and are destroying the
scene.

	Thank goodnes we are not to this point yet, but we are close.
	
	That we could use is a "PROACTIVE" information pamplet that does not
imply negative conotations, and does not sound like a lecture.  I have
actualy been working on one myself, but could definently use some more
input.  If anybody would like to contribut to it please e-mail me.


hope to see you all at Pigen point lighthouse beach tonight for the
equinox party.

Keep it real
Ray Vonie
Feel Good Entertainmnet
Bad spelling is my trademark.

          by smtp.well.com (8.8.5/8.8.4) with SMTP
	  id UAA23927; Wed, 19 Mar 1997 20:52:10 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: leftjab@mail.well.com
Message-Id: <v01510102af5682b7195f@[206.15.69.102]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 19 Mar 1997 22:08:08 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, Troy Sheets <tsheets@saturn5.com>
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: Re: don't miss the Ward Valley Protest...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>This weekend, on Saterday, in front of the San Francsico Fedral Building is
>the Ward Valley Toxic Waste Dump Protest.
>

>You should come to this becuase (1) is a very good cause.  After having
>some truly spiritual experiences in the magical Southern California desert,
>I feel really shocked that they want to start putting massive toxic waste
>dumps out there.

It isn't just a "toxic waste dump" proposed -- it's a repository for the
entire nation's nuclear waste, from both power plants and weapons
processing.  And the issue isn't the "desert," per se, it's whether there
is a possibility that the site will leak into the Colorado River aquifer --
the river is less than 20 miles from the site, and the aquifer is much
larger.  Earthquake risk is being seriously overlooked as well -- the
desert earthquakes of two years ago show that inland southern California
will be the site of large-scale quakes in the future.

Simply put, nuclear waste is unsafe, but the government and nuclear
industry is convinced that there is a feasible way to put the waste
somewhere and the problem will go away.  In order to find Ward Valley
"safe" -- or any nuclear waste storage site relying on underground storage
-- the courts have basically said they agree with the assumptions of
scientists who believe it will be safe, despite the utter impossiblity of
any assurances over any time period.

Whether you agree or not with the issue that nuclear waste needs some
remote depository, the particular site chosen has not been nearly
established as the "best" even under the scientists' assumptions -- just
the one the government wants.

ravers should glow by black light, not radiation ...

leftjab

Precedence: bulk


Sunset is happening again? What's the number?? where's it at?? Is it at
the usual Sunday afternoon east bay location (Berkeley Marina or Point
Molotte??) Yay -- spring is here...

--------------------

Also, FYI, I was listening to David Ganz' excellent "Dead to the World"
show on KPFA (94.1 8PMish Wed) and he had an interview w/ Mountain Girl
(Jerry Garcia's ex-partner) who mentioned at great length that she
found the rave scene to be a good follow-on to the Dead show vibe.
Unfortunately, she made some unecessary comment about how you don't
always need real musicians up on the stage performing -- "everybody can
dance to a tape" -- but she totally missed the point w/ the
musicianship of the DJ and the never-heard-from underground network
that produces the records and white-labels played by DJ's at raves. To
say nothing about the DJ's job of sorting through amazing piles of
mediocre generic crap dance music to find a few uplifting booty-shaking
tunes and stringing  a bunch of them together into a seamless
the-whole-is-greater-than-the-sum-of-it's-parts experience.

It's true that many a raver thinks their vibe (and their L and X, if so
inclined) is something completely new under the sun, but let me tell
you that vibe (and vibe accessories) were also present at those
delicious outdoor Dead shows of the mid-80's, e.g. Frost Amphitheater,
Greek Theater, Cal Expo, etc. And I'm sure that spirit was probably
there in the late 60's too. I've been doing it since '82 (first dead
show -- Frost Ampitheater) and '88 (first raves -- Ibiza's Amnesia and
London's Shoom/Spectrum). I'm glad there's still a festival scene today
with different players and different music and a new generation of
fledglings itching to burn their wings against the sun. And this is
going to keep on happening forever and ever -- it's what makes life
interesting, even as one becomes old enough to have seen it all before.

Anyways, between the transition of deadheads into ravers and the
frequent mentions of "electronica" on MTV and in the press, the less
evolved might be inclined to say stuff like  "it sounds like we'll all
soon need to find something new and different to groove to if we're to
remain hip cutting edge underground frisco types." :-). 

That's your fear talking -- what's wrong if everybody starts listening
to music that sucks less, and sounds more interesting? And if you don't
like the way things are, then find power in rebellion.  Perhaps rave
needs a punk movement, or a new wave movement? Perhaps it's time for
acid big band backwards lounge music? Can I stuff some Xavier Cugat or
Martin Denny into my sampler and have it come out funky? Or is that
already oh-so-five-minutes-ago??

Also, those of you who have previously discussed how Bowie's latest
album is mainstreaming techno -- that's old hat for him. Check out his
old song "Fame" whose funk is 100% lifted riff-for-riff and
beat-for-beat from an old James Brown tune called "Hot (I need to be
Loved, Loved, Loved)"... And then there's the Beatles and the Stones
and Led Zeppelin with the Blues... to say nothing about the Dead who
probably played more covers American traditional tunes than original
songs (and to those who paid enough attention to realize that the Dead
were doing electric remakes of old songs, you find joy in hearing
something old and cobweb-strewn coming back all shiny, radiating a  new
light, reinterpreted for your time and generation...)...

Music is synthesis. If it werent' synthesis, it would sound like noise
and we wouldn't recognize it as music. Music is a form of social and
cultural memory for humans -- if it weren't for people stealing styles
and riffs, then a whole lot of people would end up being exposed to
very few sounds, few ethnic concepts & traditions, few diverging ideas.
A lot of sounds & ideas would be forgotten, a lot of wheels would be
reinvented, and life would be very very boring. Music is the reading
and writing and arithmetic of emotion and the soul.

<End of rant>

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

I wrote this last year:

SUNSET '96

The glow of our energy melting with the 
sun in the ocean.
brewing the storm of love burning throughout the
souls that gather around the shawman.
The master passively allowing the ritual to
develop through the music which controls the ceremony.
Gathering, not quite knowing the purpose
Sharing our separate views of life
Allowing one another a glimpse into another
being's reality
Experiences which are shared for the
purpose of growing.
As we look to see the sun ....... set

Student #: 2424
Major: Computer Science
E-mail Address: iweiss02@ccsf.cc.ca.us
Quote of the week: "My works idea of a medical and dental plan is a
                    bandaid and a toothpick"

Once upon a time, In a land not so far away..........There were two Djs.
One would spin funky breaks and hip hop @45 and techno 45s@33 and the other
played furiously as fast as he could. They were a great team and loved by
all.Then terrible things started happening to thier once glorious scene and
the team split. One would  come north, where he became legendary.........the
other stayed in the south where he kept on going faster and more furious...
	I miss DX2!!!!! Iwish dan (aka mr.bring the noise@45) and Ron D Core were @
the same party! 
 	Even tho they have gone their own way........oh well both djs are dope!!I
am going to m6 cause I've waited way too damn long to see ron spin in the bay
area!The last time I remember he was up here was for Speed Raver(back in 92
or 93  ) when he was still with Dan as DX2. Welcome back Ron D Core! Don't be
a Stranger now, Ya Hear?!


And Frankie Bones @ Nikita!!!!DAMN!-BTW/ the anniversary wasn't all that,
Demitry was sick so Keoki showed up and played a surprisingly decent set,then
Derrik May ROCKED!!!!...then I(we) left-went sober(I'm proud of meself)
Oh well,See ya's @ Method 6

Nailvarnish wrote:
> 
>   I talked to Sara Tonen (great name)
> 
> His name is KC, everyone gets confused.
> 
> >       This is pamplet was desighned as a "REACTIVE" tactic by the LA
> > promoters to inform people in the LA scene that they are acting like a
> > bunch of ignorant and disrespectfull junkies and are destroying the
> > scene.
> 
> Oh, YAY MORE LA BASHING! Here we are talking about what a great thing
> people in socal-raves did, but we can't leave it alone can we? WE have to
> say something bad about LA. What's new on this list! YEAH, I am a
> ignorant, derespectful, junkie.... thanks a lot. Please let's be honest
> it was a few people who did stupid things, but to generalise about LA is
> ridiculous. Anyway, many of us were part of the process of the booklet, and
> we were part of the scene.


Woooo, settle down buddy.  I never neant to 'bash' LA at all, or the
scene down there, and I am very sorry that that is what you think my
intenetions were.   All I was trying to say was that the booklet is not
a good thing to circulate the way it is writen because it was not writen
for the sf area, but for the LA area.  I don't know how you concluded
that I am Bashing LA with my post, but I think that you are 'too close
to the trees and can't see the forest' kinda thing.  I think that this
booklet was a wonderful thing for LA promoters to do, and it is a very
inspirational "MODEL" for other promoters to follow with, but IMO it is
compleatly inapropriate to be circulated as is without refinement.

> Can you READ The booklet again. I think there was something about
> respect.

Just for you I did read the booklet again and I am even more convinced
that this thing is more of a liability than a resource.  I read all the
wonderful things about respect.....BUT I also read the things on Nitrus
tanks,  Guns, Alcahole, Disturbing the poeace, DRUGS,DRUGS,and More
DRUGS, Loitering, Vandalism, and a bunch of DownTalking that is
obviously targeted towards one spacific crowd, not the entire scene.

Thsi booklet is a good start, but it is outdated and locational.  If it
is going to be passed out in this area, it should be revised, and
configured to identify and adress our isues, not LA's two years ago.  I
said that I was already working on one, so don't fight me, help me out
and contribute your positive input. 


> Question: Why do you think that's OKAY to generalise about 8 million
> people? Why is it okay to bash LA and not anything else? It's some of ours
> home. Geez.
> 
> Sorry for those who hate LA, I am going to keep bring this up, until
> people are aware what they are saying.


I don't think it is OKAY to bash anybody, and I'm not sure how you came
to the conclusion that when I was talking about the troublemakers in the
LA rave scene, That I was implying that all 8 million residence were
like that.  Settle down man, we're all ravers here.

Just in case you would like to give it another shot, attatched is my
original post.  Thanks.

Leslie Ayres wrote:

> 
> I'd love to see it refined and polished and printed up in greater quantities
> to hand out!  I've had it in mind to contact the person (people?) who put it
> together and see if they'd mind us building on it.

        I personaly agree with Leslie.  This is a wonderful 'Idea' but
it needs
a seriouse makeover if it is to be circulated.  In my opinion, it needs
a lot of refinement and polishing.  I talked to Sara Tonen (great name)
and the other people that made this booklet when I first saw it about a
two years ago.  This thing was writen by LA promoters, for the LA ravers
during a period of negativity in the LA scene.  

        This "educational" pamplet could seriously backfire due to its
content.  It makes a lot of negative implications that ravers are
'disrespectful drug ingesting thoughtless troublemakers'  Now we know
that this is not the case, but the way this thing is writen, it is very
easy for an outsider to interprit this pamplet as such.  If this thing
got
into the wrong hands (parants, media, police, city oficials...etc.) then
it would look very bad for the rave scene.

        This is pamplet was desighned as a "REACTIVE" tactic by the LA
promoters to inform people in the LA scene that they are acting like a
bunch of ignorant and disrespectfull junkies and are destroying the
scene.

        Thank goodnes we are not to this point yet, but we are close.
        
        That we could use is a "PROACTIVE" information pamplet that does
not
imply negative conotations, and does not sound like a lecture.  I have
actualy been working on one myself, but could definently use some more
input.  If anybody would like to contribut to it please e-mail me.


hope to see you all at Pigen point lighthouse beach tonight for the
equinox party.

Keep it real
Ray Vonie
Feel Good Entertainmnet
Bad spelling is my trademark.

I completely agree with Ray's sentiment that the handbook could use some 
refinement.  While the message is great I think it would be a lot more 
inspirational to focus more on a positive philosophical message than to 
dwell on not being negative.  Something of this type should point out 
where we're going, not where we've been, or where we shouldn't go.  

How can we as a collective compile an asortment of ideologies which we 
all (for the most part) agree with?  Suggestions?  I personally would 
suggest such things as a variety of classical philosophical and/or 
religious texts as a good starting point.  Not necessarily exact 
quotations, but just to get a flavor for how all things, on some abstract 
level, are really describing the same deeper reality (because there is 
nothing else to describe!).  Hyperreal has some great links to such 
material, such as the Tao te Ching.

Anyway, just thought i'd give a little input on the subject...  :-)

Happy spring break!

love,
brett

On Thu, 20 Mar 1997, Ray Vonie wrote:

> > 
> > I'd love to see it refined and polished and printed up in greater quantities
> > to hand out!  I've had it in mind to contact the person (people?) who put it
> > together and see if they'd mind us building on it.
> 
>         I personaly agree with Leslie.  This is a wonderful 'Idea' but
> it needs
> a seriouse makeover if it is to be circulated.  In my opinion, it needs
> a lot of refinement and polishing.  I talked to Sara Tonen (great name)
> and the other people that made this booklet when I first saw it about a
> two years ago.  This thing was writen by LA promoters, for the LA ravers
> during a period of negativity in the LA scene.  
> 
>         This "educational" pamplet could seriously backfire due to its
> content.  It makes a lot of negative implications that ravers are
> 'disrespectful drug ingesting thoughtless troublemakers'  Now we know
> that this is not the case, but the way this thing is writen, it is very
> easy for an outsider to interprit this pamplet as such.  If this thing
> got
> into the wrong hands (parants, media, police, city oficials...etc.) then
> it would look very bad for the rave scene.
> 
>         This is pamplet was desighned as a "REACTIVE" tactic by the LA
> promoters to inform people in the LA scene that they are acting like a
> bunch of ignorant and disrespectfull junkies and are destroying the
> scene.
> 
>         Thank goodnes we are not to this point yet, but we are close.
>         
>         That we could use is a "PROACTIVE" information pamplet that does
> not
> imply negative conotations, and does not sound like a lecture.  I have
> actualy been working on one myself, but could definently use some more
> input.  If anybody would like to contribut to it please e-mail me.
> 
> 
> hope to see you all at Pigen point lighthouse beach tonight for the
> equinox party.
> 
> Keep it real
> Ray Vonie
> Feel Good Entertainmnet
> Bad spelling is my trademark.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Audio Impact last night!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Just a quick note to say.... yeah!

I had a blast last night. It was so great to be back at the 115 Minna
space; I had missed that location, both for its vibe and for those
really great hardwood floors (a treat to dance on). Audio Impact
always goes off when it's there (with no problem from the local
authorities)... I hope we're invited back. :)

The decorations / visuals were comfortably minimal: the signature
cloth netting on the ceiling, the single flashing strobe hidden behind
the speakers, and just one black light.

The music last night was extremely varied, probably due to the tag
teaming that took place all night; everytime I looked up, there was
yet another DJ behind the decks. I could have gone for more techstep,
but there was still enough hard stuff to keep me moving.

The sound was especially powerful! It looked like Gateway had an extra
bass cabinet for each side, and there was another sound system in the
back (I'm assuming that was Dave Bayer's?) to complete all four
corners.

The night ended at 2am for me, so who knows how long it went on. But,
as always, I had the _best_ time, and I wish I could have stayed longer.

Steve

With incredible excitement, and (gulp) the liquidation of all my assets, I
am planning a summer-long trip all over Europe!  YEA!!  I am traveling
with a dear and wonderful person, whose only fault is that she is a
non-raver.  Even so, I intend to submit our itinerary to any machination
necessary to end up in Berlin July 12.  <evil laugh>

The questions are: Did anyone go to this last year?  Is it only a techno
festival, or is it more of a huge mass carnival/party?  I can't tell
whether it's a contained "mega-rave", or an excuse for all of Europe's
young people to descend on Berlin for a few days and party their asses
off, ala Brazil's Carnival.  And is anyone planning on going? 

Replies appreciated,

Nancy
soon-to-be
world-traveling raver!

submissive to the restrictions of nineteenth-century music.  Today we are
fighting for their emancipation.  Tomorrow, with electronic music in our
ears, we will hear freedom."
 							-- John Cage, 1939

On May 24th 1997, FGE will be puting on our next event.

It is called "A Feel Good Experience"

With every event, we put out a newsletter that gets sent to everyone on
oour mailing list and to all the Members of the Global Party Network. 
We are always asking for ravers to contribute by submiting articles and
stories or any positive contributing material that they would like to
share with us.

If any one has any input that they would like to submit for
consideration to be published in our newsletter, then please forward it
to me via e-mail.

the event is called "a Feel Good Experience" so if anybody has any
special or personal rave experiences that they want to share, peotry,
deep thougths, or any form of insightful, or positive contribution
please send it soon.  

Experiences make up our lives.  they determin and shape the individual
that we become.

Our rave scene is built like a chain of experieces by comon people with
a comon goal.

Sharing these experiences is a contribution in and of itself.

I am looking forward to reading some of your inspirational rightings and
poems.

space permiting, we will be able to publish a few of them in the
newsletter, but I do promis that I will consider each and every
submision.

Thanks for your support.

Keep it real
Ray Vonie
bad spelling is my trademark

Re: drug induced love? Deep thoughts.

><< it's all real! drugs are real! drug induced experiences are real!
> change society and the drug problem won't be one anymore. >>
>
>yes, I agree, but the experience is not who you are.
>(not a response :), just a thought.)
>love,
>april

Hey April,

I hate to disagree, because your such a neato person.  But in my opinion the
thing that is so wonderful about psychedelics  (E & L) is that they tap into
a part of our minds that it is buried so deep inside of us that it is nearly
forgotten. 

 It is unfortunate that our minds are programmed in such a way that this
these feelings of love & tranquility are not immediately accessible.  It's
also unfortunate that the tools that we use to access the buried conscience
can also be very unpredictable.  But the feelings of universal connection &
prenatal consciousness that we feel when we ingest these chemies is
something that it often takes buddhist monks a lifetime to achieve!   This
quick access to the human spirit is what makes these chemies so darned
appealing.

But I have to tell you, the first time I ever took psychedelics, I had an
overwhelming sensation that the feelings I was having were familiar...that I
had been "there" before.  Maybe before I was born...I dunno.  I'm normally
not a kooky type of person and prefer to think that I'm not delusional.  But
I still have a very committed belief that there are things inside my mind
that I would never have contacted in this lifetime without the aid of these
tools.  

I dunno...maybe I'm not giving myself enough credit.  I know that sometimes,
especially with vitamin E, I become discouraged with the falseness of the
experience.  Like, why do I suddenly feel love for someone who I barely know?

I think the answer to this is that we all have a hidden love & connection to
everything in the universe; and in particular, to other human beings, who
are capable of thought and emotion.    We all /want/ to be in contact with
that unconditional love, but the world we live in doesn't allow for it,
because it's complicated by so many other issues.

I dunno.  chemicals are a tricky thing.  But I don't think that psychedlics
"create" feelings.  I think they just allow us to access them quickly.  You
know the old addage..."cleansing the doors of perception" and all that
Huxley crap.

bye!
~b))merang

Hope everyone had a good weekend last week.  This weekend should be 
pretty good too with several choices each night.  I never did get more
info on Bass Heaven so I don't know if it's real.  The Union Jack show
got rescheduled from last week.

The Ward Valley protest (Atomic Butterfly) is something you should know 
about even if you don't go to the event...  As I understand it, the 
federal government and the state of California are pushing to build a 
nuclear waste disposal site at Ward Valley in Southern California.  
There's more info at http://www.moontribe.org/kissbig/Index.html.

W E E K L I E S

   House/techno/acid jazz/ambient/etc reg'lar happenins Some of them may
   have ended - let me know when that happens...

   guests. 12mid-5:30am, 21+, $5. 55 Natoma, SF. 415.267.5984

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday afternoon 3pm-8pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of
       jungle, dub, breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight-3am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats,
       Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Friday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

guests. 12mid-5:30am, 21+, $5. 55 Natoma, SF. 415.267.5984

Tomas. 9pm-2am, 21+, $3. Nickies BBQ, 460 Haight, SF.  415.621.6508

10pm-2am, 21+. elbo room, 647 Valencia, SF. 415.522.2946

Sexy T.K.O. - abstract drum and bass w/DJs Sonic Pioneer, Starsky,
eclectic guests.  9pm-2am, 21+, $4. 111 Minna St, SF. 

Apollo - house w/DJs Pete Avila, Jay-R, guests. free
before 10:30 w/flyer 9:30p-, 21+, $3. 1015 Folsom, SF. 415.905.4209 

Phonixs - "sounds never seen" w/DJs Marcus, Chris OST.
every other Thursday  21+, $2. the Top, 424 Haight, SF. 

f'tumsh! - ambient, techno w/DJs Chuck-roc (Denver 409), Erin. 21+, $2.
the Top, 424 Haight,  SF. 415.864.4528 

Royal Jelly - explorations in creative and social behaviour. Sound
experiments in digital rhythm and note fantasies w/DJs guest DJs and live
acts weekly. 7pm-, 21+, Free. Liquid, 2925 16th St @ So.Van Ness, SF.

Subject: Re: what makes us feel this way?
References: <E0w7u3h-0003IA-00@ferret>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ok, try these on for size:

We associate certain behaviors and emotions with what we see, hear,
feel, ect.  If for example, I feel extremely loved or happy and I touch
or am touched by something and in a certain way (or hear or see), and
this happens repeatedly, then I will associate those feelings with that
scence. When taken into the context of a rave, this becomes very
interesting. When you are at a rave (drugs or no) and your feeling good
or whatever, and you see these people that you see almost exclusively at
a rave, then you associate those good feelings with those people. Think
about the last time you bumped into someone that you 1st met at a rave.
Didn't seeing that person feel especially good? Something like ecstasy
magnifies this. If you feel REALLY good, then you associate feeling
really good with things you see, hear, or feel. Think back to the 1st
time you went to a rave sober after you had tried ecstasy a couple of
times at a rave. Did you feel especially good from the sensory input
that you associated with feelings of ecstasy? The sights, sounds, ect? 

Likewise there is the factor of rapport between two people and what
causes it. Rapport basically means that you and another person somehow
"click" or "connect" in some way. People often refer this to being "on
the same wavelength" with another person. All rapport comes from
communication between people. Yet what we say to a person is only 07% of
our total communication. The rest is through our breathing, our body
posture, our tone of voice, ect. Well, when you think back to what kind
of state and feeling E put you in (your breathing is usually increased,
your pulse is up, your "awake", feeling is enhanced) and think about the
people you are interacting with you who are having the same chemical
infulence as you, it makes scence that you and that other person or
group of people will feel very much "connected" with you and vice versa.

Combine both of these together now. When you think about the FEELING of
ecstasy and how you ASSOCIATE those feelings with whats around you, and
other people around you are FEELING the same way which causes you to
feel CONNECTED with those people; And if youre talking about 100's or
1000's of people potentially, you can see what a truly exceptional
experience one can have at a rave.

Word Up.

-=Pengo=-

just a thought - last time anyone was talking about techno becoming a next
big thing for mainstream music was around 92 or so; Nirvana showed up and
the whole concept was forgotten. I think the same exact thing is going to
happen; some more easily marketed, more rock-like "phenomenon" will show
up somewhere and in six months Spin magazine will be talking about the
amazing newness and hipness of lounge music or noise pop or something.

Subject: Re: drug induced love? Deep thoughts.
In-Reply-To: <970320203455_-670821645@emout03.mail.aol.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970320235430.19876A-100000@value.net>

On Thu, 20 Mar 1997 Epiglottal@aol.com wrote:

> >But don't you think that it reflects a facet of your personality? Sober or
> >altered, any action you take reflects something inside you, rather it is
> >one of your more prominent or one of your more subdued traits, it is all
> >part of who you are.
> 
> No, I don't think so.  I think drugs reflect your perceptions of things, not
> who you are inside.
> 
> Drugs reflect perceptions a person has on life rather than his or her
> personality.
> 
> Personalities are maleable and instantly changeable.  A quiet and peaceful
> person can become loud and obnoxious.  A loud and obnoxious person can become
> serene and tender.  Anxieties can soften or heighten on drugs.  Beliefs can
> be enhanced or warped.

I disagree. Personalities are not instantly changeable. Whatever your
actions, whatever you do, no matter how "right" or how "wrong," they are
all reflective of what is contained inside you, what is possible within
you as a person. They may be subdued traits, but they are all part of who
you are as a person. Drugs don't change that. They may highlight or subdue
facets of your personality, but who you are is not something that is
somehow warped while you are not sober. Barring any unusual circumstance,
you are responsible for your state, altered or sober, you choose that, and
you choose how you express that whether it is a concious decision or not.

> Drugs say a lot more about how we percieve the world than who we are.  I've
> believed I was other people or things on acid.  

And that is the whole point: *YOU* believed you were other people or
things while under the influence. Again, it is all within you as a person.

> I became them in every way I knew how.  Did that mean I was them all
> along inside?  No.  It meant I had a perception of them all along.  

Of course it didn't mean that you were them. But there was empathy, the
understanding of who they were, and what they were going through.

> I became that perception.  It was a dream let out.  Ecstasy does similar
> things.  It softens all those neurotic anxieties. Yet those neurotic
> anxieties are a part of us.  Without them we are no longer us.  

You did not become that perception. If you had become that perception, you
would not have recognized it, because it would have become part of who
you are. You are disproving your own argument by making it.

> I think an essential fact of drugs is that when we take them we lose a 
> portion of ourselves.  Perhaps it is a portion we need, perhaps not.

How? How do we lose ourselves when we take a drug? And don't you think it
is important to define what drug we are taking, that we lose part of
ourselves as a result of? 

> But what we were born with is no longer there.  The chemical balance has
> destabilized.  Our defining features may be lost.   

But don't you think your actions define who you are? What drugs you take,
it is all a means of defining yourself(barring addictive personalities.)
Drugs are tools, like many other things. They can be used, misused
or abused, but ultimately the responsibility lies within the user, and how
they have employed them to help define who they are.

> The law accepts insanity as a defense in the worst of crimes.  Some
> religions describe demons taking over people when they become insane,
> others simply say  the soul is lost.  There is a point when I will no
> longer say that is Luke's father Anakin Skywalker, but indeed evil
> Lord Vader, because Anakin is dead. 

However to use this analogy, Anakin proved that he was indeed not dead,
however different ruling factors governed his life for many years.
Ultimately, his actions reflected himself. 

					Black Adder

On Thu, 20 Mar 1997, Pengo wrote:

> Ok, try these on for size:
> 
> We associate certain behaviors and emotions with what we see, hear,
> feel, ect.  If for example, I feel extremely loved or happy and I touch
> or am touched by something and in a certain way (or hear or see), and
> this happens repeatedly, then I will associate those feelings with that
> scence. When taken into the context of a rave, this becomes very
> interesting. When you are at a rave (drugs or no) and your feeling good
> or whatever, and you see these people that you see almost exclusively at
> a rave, then you associate those good feelings with those people. Think
> about the last time you bumped into someone that you 1st met at a rave.
> Didn't seeing that person feel especially good? Something like ecstasy
> magnifies this. If you feel REALLY good, then you associate feeling
> really good with things you see, hear, or feel. Think back to the 1st
> time you went to a rave sober after you had tried ecstasy a couple of
> times at a rave. Did you feel especially good from the sensory input
> that you associated with feelings of ecstasy? The sights, sounds, ect? 
> 
> Likewise there is the factor of rapport between two people and what
> causes it. Rapport basically means that you and another person somehow
> "click" or "connect" in some way. People often refer this to being "on
> the same wavelength" with another person. All rapport comes from
> communication between people. Yet what we say to a person is only 07% of
> our total communication. The rest is through our breathing, our body
> posture, our tone of voice, ect. Well, when you think back to what kind
> of state and feeling E put you in (your breathing is usually increased,
> your pulse is up, your "awake", feeling is enhanced) and think about the
> people you are interacting with you who are having the same chemical
> infulence as you, it makes scence that you and that other person or
> group of people will feel very much "connected" with you and vice versa.
> 
> Combine both of these together now. When you think about the FEELING of
> ecstasy and how you ASSOCIATE those feelings with whats around you, and
> other people around you are FEELING the same way which causes you to
> feel CONNECTED with those people; And if youre talking about 100's or
> 1000's of people potentially, you can see what a truly exceptional
> experience one can have at a rave.
> 
> Word Up.
> 
> -=Pengo=-
> 
>

>The questions are: Did anyone go to this last year?  

yes. ben and i did. and ben managed to sprain his ankle on friday night, the
night before the parade. bummer! he was bravely limping after the trucks all
day, trying to keep up. 

>Is it only a techno
>festival, or is it more of a huge mass carnival/party? 

yes. yes. last year it was 90 % techno. german techno, which i found
incredibly monotonous. there was  some jungle, tho.
on the day (saturday) it's a huge parade with hundreds of trucks with sound
systems rolling at snail pace down from the victory column to the
brandenburg gate and back. people tend to follow their favorite trucks -
bouncing and dancing along. great fun. be prepared to be trampled to death
by the masses occassionally. it's gonna be at least a million people. and
try to stay clear of cops (there's gonna be as many of them as there are
ravers), german cops have no sense of humour. 

BTW, it is legal to carry certain small amounts of dope (the amount depends
on which part of germany you're in). it is not holland, however! 

> I can't tell
>whether it's a contained "mega-rave", or an excuse for all of Europe's
>young people to descend on Berlin for a few days and party their asses
>off, ala Brazil's Carnival.

again: yes. yes. yes. there will be a lot of non-ravers too who are just
there for....hmm...don't really know...maybe they are ravers by the time
they leave.

it would be good to arrive a few days beforehand because it really starts on
wednesday or thursday in the clubs (check out east berlin for cool
underground stuff). there will be non-stop music in berlin from wednesday to
monday night. most things are really expensive, tho, and if you go to a club
every night it quickly adds up. drugs were also slightly more expensive than
normal. we once paid DM 30 for a pill! 

don't forget to sample german chocolate!
if i remember something else useful i'll let you know.

>Nancy
>soon-to-be
>world-traveling raver!
>

yeah! me too!
iris


Iris

 (Al in Quantum Leap)

Kc, the creater of the Responisble Raving Handbook, asked me to post
this to sfraves.  If you have discussion about this, please cc
sarahtonen@eathlink.net (kc) </troy>

Forwarded message:
From sarahtonen@earthlink.net  Thu Mar 20 18:35:22 1997
Date: Thu, 20 Mar 1997 18:31:45 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <199703210231.SAA10258@spain.it.earthlink.net>
X-Sender: sarahtonen@mail.earthlink.net
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: Troy Sheets <tsheets@saturn5.com>
From: sarahtonen@earthlink.net (Kc)
Subject: Responsible raving handbook

****TROY, PLEASE POST THIS FOR ME   AND THANKS FOR MAKING ME AWARE OF THE
ISSUES*****



Hello SF Raves!  My name is Kc.  I am the author of "How Much Do You Love
Raving: a handbook for responsible raving."  It was basically solely my
project, but I had a lot of insight and perspective from long-time ravers
whose opinions I greatly respect.

I just wanted to clarify (not defend mind you) a few things about myself
and the booklet:

- I'm not a professional promoter.  I am intimately involved with the DUNE
projects as a producer and art director... I wouldn't really call any of us
in DUNE promoters and ESPECIALLY not professional promoters.  I didn't
write it for any professional reason. I have been raving/clubbing for 14
years and I just couldn't let what is such a large part of my life become
despicable.

- I wrote the booklet 1 year ago after our second chapter of DUNE when
HardCopy took something that 1800 people thought was pure and wonderful and
turned it into something totally corrupt and evil.  I know that all of the
footage wasn't of DUNE and I also understand that HardCopy makes its' money
making that sort of distortion, but I was still very hurt.

My first inclination was to lash out at HC, which I did for a while until I
realized that without a massive (read expensive) legal effort, nothing
could be changed.  I tried to discover what could have been done to prevent
such a tragedy. The answer was very clear to me.  They didn't need to
change, WE needed to change THEIR perceptions of us... and thus was born
the concept for the booklet.

- The booklet is very clear about its' intent which is simply... small
changes in individuals' attitude and behavior can make a tremendous
difference in other peoples' perception of us.

- Yes, it was intended specifically for L.A. but it is being very well
received in a great number of cities in the U.S. and abroad (even in
Bosnia!).  I believe that in the booklet are little bits of truth that
apply to everyone in every community. (This includes myself)

- Yes, the booklet is all about hard realities and could be viewed as being
"negative" BUT it is purely constructive in it's approach... which is VERY
positive.  You can preach PLUR until you are blue in the face but many
people will never make a practical application of it.  In other words,
there are many people that have to have it explained to them that "RESPECT
means 'don't spray paint the bathroom wall.'"

- Please remember that the people who spend time on lists such as SF and SC
Raves are not the biggest culprits... but you can't help but preach to the
choir when you're trying to reach those other people. It is lists such as
this which CAN make the difference, though.  We are blessed with a forum
that encourages discussions such as this.  But most are not as fortunate.
Share the wealth through communication with those who aren't online.


I don't want to take any more of your time... I've heard what a commitment
it is to read through SF Raves everyday.

I encourage those who feel the booklet is incomplete, impractical or
out-of-line to produce your own.  I warn you, though, that 1) it takes much
more time (and $) than you could possibly estimate and 2) you will be
exposing yourself for criticism as well.  NOW GET TO IT!!!


Sincerely,

Kc (of DUNE)


RESPECT+
ACCOUNTABILITY+
COMMUNICATION & EDUCATION=
RAVE ELATION FOREVER !

so my landlord tells me. It never used to happen when i lived in 
Colorado. Remember the full moon in January, the night of Gaia Mind-- It 
happened then too only it was much bigger. Yes my dear it is an 
incredible wonder. smiles! --debbie

show.  (see the SFRaves calender)

They've never head of it.

think that... well...  I just wouldn't hold my breath.
