definitely indicates a massive) would be so nonpromoted:  no flyers, no
number, no nuthin'. 

I'm thinkin' it's all about Ceridwen tonite.

Nancy Shaw wrote:
> 
> With incredible excitement, and (gulp) the liquidation of all my assets, I
> am planning a summer-long trip all over Europe!  YEA!!  I am traveling
> with a dear and wonderful person, whose only fault is that she is a
> non-raver.  Even so, I intend to submit our itinerary to any machination
> necessary to end up in Berlin July 12.  <evil laugh>
> 
> The questions are: Did anyone go to this last year?  Is it only a techno
> festival, or is it more of a huge mass carnival/party?  I can't tell
> whether it's a contained "mega-rave", or an excuse for all of Europe's
> young people to descend on Berlin for a few days and party their asses
> off, ala Brazil's Carnival.  And is anyone planning on going?
> 
> Replies appreciated,
> 
> Nancy
> soon-to-be
> world-traveling raver!


The most amazing thing about 'the love parade' is the fact that Berlin
as a city is willing to let those crazy youths come from all over and
basically take over.....its amazing to see so many people just roaming
the streets ,partying, and the polizei (sp?) just standing around with
smiles....there is no place like that here in the states.....

as for the actual parade i was glad to have experienced it but i dont
put it on the top of my ravin experiences....as someone posted the music
is well german hardcore....its great to see 3000 people surrounding just
one truck jumping all around half naked to 200bpms but its not quite my
taste.....I only saw one truck with a d&b dj.....but then again maybe a
lot has changed.

the parties that happen during the days and nights around the parade I
think are more the attraction....then you can really find a party that
will suit your taste...either parties of thousands or lil UGs.....


...the funniest was going to a party sponsored by Marlboro "friends of
energy dancers"....


The love parade isnt the only one to check out....Last summer I knew of
at least 4 other parades with attendance in the thousands....so you
could be doing this all summer if you wanted...

i'm jealous...but then again i still havent financially recovered from
that trip ;(


j

This March 1997, on Saturday the 22nd, there will be a Ward
Valley/Environmental Gathering. This will be a gathering of peaceful
protest, music, culture, dance and idea. We must all attend this gathering!
Tell everyone you know! If you need a ride, post a message! Let us spread
the electronic transmission! Please help us spread the word! This gathering
will be held at 450 Golden Gate Avenue in San Francisco. (There is public
parking at PUBLIC CENTER PARKING located 1 block south of Golden Gate @
Larkin.)

Children, Coming together and dancing with one another is one of the most
healing activities we, as members of the tribe can do. It is way past our
time to come together, what does it mean to come together? It means viewing
each one of your fellow human beings as a child of light just as you are.
We are all equally beautiful and we are all doing the best we can given the
knowledge we have. The planet we live on is screaming for help. You can see
it in the air, you can hear it in the songs of the animals, you can feel it
in the ground. There is no more time for war, for destruction. For if we
would like our children to survive we must change our ways immediately. The
answer is not easy,
but together as a group it will come. It may come from the wisdom of a
child, or from silent meditation. Now if we are focusing our energy the
collective consciousness of our souls, we will be giving earth the
necessary energy she neds to survive the constant bombarding of negative
energy from disillusioned humans.

Children, it is up to us! If not us then who will? No one! WE MUST COME
TOGETHER. Currently our brothers and sisters are gathering strong
worldwide, the negative chain that has been put on our families is
breaking! Remember your mother. Mother Earth has provided everything for
us. May the children of the planet Earth come together and dance to the
song of life.

Always maintain the vision - it cannot be done alone. There is a reason
this message was written. And there is a reason you are reading it. There
is a reason you were put on this planet at this time. And that reason has
been forgotten. Let us remember, remember why we are here.

For more information about the Kissbig Collective, the location of the
event, times, and the DJ performer lineup, checkout the site:

http://www.kissbig.moontribe.org/

Get involved, make a difference, and remember to love each other and Mother
Earth. Hope to see you there.

peace from somewhere under a rock

garrett@kissbig.moontribe.org
desertdweller@moontribe.org
http://www.moontribe.org/FMG/
http://kissbig.moontribe.org/

I suppose I can comment on this "frat boy" issue....

My progression was raver>frat boy>raver. 

You always come back to what you love, right...:)
I was a raver before I went to college, then turned 21 and spent a few
years in the disgusting depths of college life known as the greek
system....ack. (hindsight is always 20:20, right?) 
anyway, yeah..after I turned 21 I spent 2 years wrapped in a flannel
shirt drowning in the bottom of a Jack Daniels bottle..
then I recovered and got back to my raving roots...I'm so much healthier
and happier now. I had moved from SF to Boulder, CO for college...when I
first moved there the scene was whack (imho) so I ended up falling into
the folds of the geek system (not a typo...heehee) 
I dropped the geek system my sophomore year, was a total clubhead my
junior year...and got fed up with the music they played at the one or
two decent clubs in Denver...too much diva/hi-nrg/housey house..I am a
techno head thru and thru..no 303-none for me...(giggle)....so I had to
find UGs for the solid tunes, right?? Well, at the same time I was
seriously cutting down on my drinking cause I'm also a mountain biker
and was doing alot of training...suddenly I found myself back in front
of the speakers at 5am buggin' out and loving every single thump thump
tweet tweet thump  of it!! :)  
I truly felt reborn....then I went to Europe and had a wonderful
experience in London raving with my roomate (right Jeff? :) ) who hadn't
really been properly introduced to ravEing...since then I've been back
into the groove stronger than ever.... I could go on, and on... but I'll
save it.
cheers!
ari

Subject: Re: what makes us feel this way?
In-Reply-To: <199703212146.NAA06872@taz.hyperreal.com>

Just a little anecdote to go along with this thread:

When Ram Dass (formerly Richard Alpert) first travelled to India he 
brought with him a bottle of "White Lightening", a very pure batch of LSD 
he had had specially made.  When he first met his guru, Maharaji, the man 
asked for some of this 'medicine'.  Ram Dass gave him a tablet but 
Maharaji wanted more than one.  He swallowed three of the tablets, which 
was 915 micrograms (a normal dose is between 100-200 micrograms), and 
just sat there with a twinkle in his eye.  Ram Dass was with Maharaji for 
several hours and nothing happened!  Maharaji was living in a constant 
state complete clarity and understanding, so his perception was unaffected.

As Ram Dass later said of the incident, "When you're in Detroit, you 
don't need to take the bus to get to Detroit."  ;-)


love,
brett

PS.  For those who don't know, Ram Dass has recently had a stroke, but is 
recovering.  For more info check out:
http://www.geocities.com/WestHollywood/Heights/1143/ramdass.html

Kay, so it's friday afternoon at about 3:30pm
I am watching gargoyles (a good show if you have never seen it)
Now, I just wanted to say something for you all to ponder.

When you are high, do you  ever notice how stuff that is bright and fun to
play with stands out??? Yanno, playdoh, kooshballs, big squishy soft stuft
animals. Do you remember how when you were a small child, all that stuff
totally entranced you?? When you are high, can you sit and play with a piece
of playdoh for hours and hours at a time??? Do you remember being a child and
playing with a piece of playdoh for hours and hours???

Well, I guess the point I am trying to make, is that maybe when we are
children, we are in a state of being high all the time, but do not realize
it.
~~~Of course, we all could just be regressing to our childhood when we are
high.
Just a thought I thought I'd share with some other kids:)
'kay. bye bye.
smiles:)
{{hugs}}
love<3
april(4)
have you hugged yer fourth month of the year today??

Subject: NRR -- PARC Forum, 3/27/97, Mark Goldstein, Electronic instruments

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

------- Forwarded Message

Xerox PARC Forum

   Thursday, March 27, 1997
   4:00 - 5:00 PM
   George Pake Auditorium


Playing Electronic Instruments:  Technique Meets Technology

   Mark Goldstein

ABSTRACT:

The advent of electronic music changed the way composers and listeners
work with and relate to sound. Since the initial efforts in this form
were taped pieces, sonic sculptures crafted out of real time, the notion
of performer was irrelevant. Today, a wide variety of commercial
synthesizers are available and new real time synthesis techniques from
the computer music laboratories are becoming available. Most of these
synthesizers and algorithms can be controlled from arbitrary input
devices. The piano keyboard has been a ubiquitous front end for all
sorts of sounds, many of them not pianistic at all. It is also not
unusual to see a computer on stage with an electronic ensemble. Quite
often the audience cannot understand the effects of the computer
player's actions. I am interested in broadening the possibilities for
performing electronics, investigating the relationship between gesture
and sound,  and regaining a sense of instrumental virtuosity in the
electronic genre.

Music is a performing art, and part of the quality of the musical
experience comes from the relationship between the player's physical
technique and the sound that is produced. A player can feel this
intimately. A listener can appreciate this connection visually (and
viscerally) whether in a live concert or in the mind's eye while
listening to a recorded performance.

Our rich tradition of musical instruments has created a repertoire of
gestures (bowing, blowing, banging, etc.) that are closely tied to
familiar sounds. Can these gestures be appropriated to control new sorts
of sounds? Are there other forms of movement that are musically
effective? I have been exploring these questions using a MalletKAT (an
electronic marimba) and Buchla Lightning Wands (a pair of wireless
infrared wands broadcasting to a 2-D tracking sensor that also performs
gesture recognition). I will trace the development of electronic music
and its performance practices, demonstrate a variety of empty-handed and
hybrid electronic instruments, and perform a piece for Lightning solo,
"Joan is Back," by Bay Area composer Silvia Mateus.


BIOGRAPHY:
Mark Goldstein is an independent software consultant specializing in
audio and musical applications. He is also a conservatory-trained
percussionist and freelance musician. He has worked at the Center for
New Music and Audio Technologies (U.C. Berkeley), the Center for
Computer Research in Music and Acoustics (Stanford),  Gibson Guitar
G-WIZ Labs, and Studer Editech/Integrated Media Systems.


Xerox Internal:
   http://parcweb.parc.xerox.com/events/forum

External:
   http://www.parc.xerox.com/ops/projects/forum

- -------------------------------------------------------------------------
This Forum is OPEN to the public:

Host: David Jared (415) 812-4120

Requests for videotapes for XEROX EMPLOYEE ONLY should be sent to
Kim Edens (edens@parc.xerox.com)

Refreshments will be served from 3:45 to 4:00 PM

The George Pake Auditorium is located at 3333 Coyote Hill Road in Palo Alto.
We are between Page Mill Road (west of Foothill Expressway) and Hillview
Avenue, in the Stanford Research Park.  The easiest way here is to get
onto Page Mill Road, and turn onto Coyote Hill Road.  As you drive up
Coyote Hill past the horse pastures, PARC is the large building on the
left after you crest the hill.  Park in the large parking lot, and enter
the auditorium at the upper level of the building.  The auditorium entrance
is located down the stairs and to the left of the main doors.

------- End of Forwarded Message

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Mar 21 19:02:15 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id TAA05223; Fri, 21 Mar 1997 19:02:15 -0800 (PST)
Received: from dfw-ix3.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id TAA05211; Fri, 21 Mar 1997 19:02:10 -0800 (PST)
Received: (from smap@localhost)
          by dfw-ix3.ix.netcom.com (8.8.4/8.8.4)
	  id VAA23304 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 21 Mar 1997 21:01:38 -0600 (CST)
Date: Fri, 21 Mar 1997 21:01:38 -0600 (CST)
Received: from ala-ca26-13.ix.netcom.com(207.93.42.77) by dfw-ix3.ix.netcom.com via smap (V1.3)
	id sma023279; Fri Mar 21 21:01:29 1997
Message-Id: <1.5.4.16.19970321190449.0ea796fc@popd.ix.netcom.com>
X-Sender: shawna-@popd.ix.netcom.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.4 (16)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (Frisco Freaks)
From: The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: what makes us feel this way? (nrr)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>I hate to disagree, because your such a neato person.  But in my opinion the
>thing that is so wonderful about psychedelics  (E & L) is that they tap into
>a part of our minds that it is buried so deep inside of us that it is nearly
>forgotten. 
>
> It is unfortunate that our minds are programmed in such a way that this
>these feelings of love & tranquility are not immediately accessible.  It's
>also unfortunate that the tools that we use to access the buried conscience
>can also be very unpredictable.  



I am inclined to agree here.  I know a lot of people think that drugs create
feelings that are not there, cause you to behave in ways that you would not
normally behave, thus causing them to feel that drugs are causing unnatural
reactions in ourselves.  But sometimes I really think that drugs are causing
us to shed behavior that is very learned, very much taught to us by
society/parents/whatever, behavior patterns that are so ingrained in us as
to feel like normal behavior but really are not the way we were born
believing and behaving.  When the susicpicion one normally feels for
strangers suddenly falls away because we've taken e, yes maybe it's a rather
artificial way to cause that behavior, but I consider the removed behavior
in & of itself to be artificial as well.  I was not born with the fears I
live my everyday life with.  I was not born treating those around me like
shit when I can't handle my own personal issues.  I was not born with
personal issues.  I was born (I believe) curious about the world around me,
wanting to play and laugh, and love the people who were with me, I was born
loving music, I was born wanting to throw my arms around those I love, and I
was born dancing.  I remember a party I went to about a year ago (anybody
remember that Basics party they threw at the bowling alley last year? :) and
to this day I remember the feeling I got from that party.  I and several
others were on e, and it struck me how natural our behavior was, to hug and
kiss and talk and be together simply for the sake of being together.  It
felt so familiar to me, like I could tell at that moment that this behavior
for me seemed like something I'd been born with, had lost along the way from
negative experiences, societal expectations, or parents' fears being taught
to me.  It was the most natural thing in the world, and I felt like after
having lost it, I'd rediscovered it once again, come back around full circle
to the way I was meant to be from the beginning, rather than my normal
fear-based behavior of regular life.  And that discovery has carried into my
normal life.  I live my life very differently than I did two years ago.  So
much more of my behavior and the way I choose to lead my life is love-based
rather than fear-based (and I still struggle to make this change, always
will), which to me will make or break whether or not I consider myself to
have lived a worthwhile life when I die.  
And I also do not think that e makes me feel love for people I don't
normally love.  However, I do believe it encourages me to treat people with
love, and shows me more clearly often times my love for the people I really
do love.  And sometimes e creates a connection with a person that disappears
when the party's over ("just an e thing"), and even that is okay.  Sometimes
a connection happens only once, connections often happen because there is
something in common between the two of you, and sometimes that something in
common happens to be a hit of e.  Take it  for what it's worth, get
everything you can out of it.  I have had very memorable one-time
experiences with people I never saw again, but I still remember them, and
just to have remembered that experience is enough to change me just a
little.  Also bear in mind that it's possible that the "just an e thing"
connection could be very real, and would have continued into normal life,
except that once the e wears off, the normal fear-based behavior sets back
in and destroys a connection that can only exist in that non-fear-based
environment.  Ever find yourself being just a little afraid to talk to that
person you had that connection with because you're afraid it was "just an e
thing", or wonder what you could talk about while not on e?  Perhaps if you
could shed those fears for a little longer, that connection would remain
intact.  Of course that's not to say that every little e connection would
last longer every time, cuz there will always be one-time shots, drug
induced or not, but it would definitely improve on matters imo if that
artificial fear-based behavior weren't such a factor.
And one other thing for me.  Drugs always give me a new way to see old
things, always give me a different perspective than the one I'm used to
seeing.  *Anything* that gives me new perspectives with which to view the
world around me will give me a better, more complete view of the big
picture, and that is a good thing.

Anyway, enough rambling!  

Love
Shawna

>When you are high, do you  ever notice how stuff that is bright and fun to
>play with stands out??? Yanno, playdoh, kooshballs, big squishy soft stuft
>animals. Do you remember how when you were a small child, all that stuff
>totally entranced you?? When you are high, can you sit and play with a piece
>of playdoh for hours and hours at a time??? Do you remember being a child and
>playing with a piece of playdoh for hours and hours???
>
>Well, I guess the point I am trying to make, is that maybe when we are
>children, we are in a state of being high all the time, but do not realize
>it.

>~~~Of course, we all could just be regressing to our childhood when we are
>high.


I think that you are right in both situations.  I think that when 
you are a child you ARE in a different state than, let's say, adults 
are.  That is becuase kids don't have any responsibilities.  All kids
have to REALLY worry about is the rivalry that exists (The ultimate 
battle of the sexes and the ART of "PLAYING!!!!!!!").
When we get older, more responsibility are put onto our shoulders and 
the playing aspect of life begings to weaking, or even pause for some.  
Smoking pot could bring a person to many different states though.  When
I am high, I am in my own world and thinking weird and detailed thoughts.
Other times I get in deep discussions about "why the human race is here"
:):):).
And even other times, when I feel like being a dumb ass with my friends, I
just
laugh at the world around me. 
Anyways, I dont think that "pot" brings you to your inner child, but rather
the choice of the individual of what level you want to travel within
yourself.  
Take that last sentance and apply it mostly any drug. 

Drugs.....people should learn from.  I have a friend who takes drugs... for
what?
He doesn't learn anything from each time. For example,  When I took "E" for
the
first time. It was the most amazing experience of my life (that was also
the first
time I went to a rave) I had my Awsome friends around me sharing this
incredible 
experience. I saw everyone's beauty come out and onto the surface. After that 
experience, I carried that feeling with me wherever I go.  I don't rave a
lot, but
when I do, I try my hardest to enjoy the vibe and enjoy the people. MY drug
experience
has been a learning experience and the learning aspect of it all
was my decision. I CHOSE to put myself in that mind set.  

I hope this aswers you question :)!!!!

Molly

Molly (garrison@sonoma.edu) replied:

>I think that you are right in both situations.  I think that when=20
>you are a child you ARE in a different state than, let's say, adults=20
>are.  That is becuase kids don't have any responsibilities.  All kids
>have to REALLY worry about is the rivalry that exists (The ultimate=20
>battle of the sexes and the ART of "PLAYING!!!!!!!").

It is also because don't have the same limits and prejudices that=20
"grown-ups" have. We go through life, picking up what our parents say,
what our teachers say, and what we hear on TV, and this "limits" our
behavior.

>Smoking pot could bring a person to many different states though.  When
>I am high, I am in my own world and thinking weird and detailed thoughts.
>Other times I get in deep discussions about "why the human race is here"
>And even other times, when I feel like being a dumb ass with my friends, I
>just laugh at the world around me.=20

Marijuana, like so many other drugs, has different effects on different
people at different times. One day, it might make you really "stupid", and
all you do is laugh. The next day/week/month/whatever, you might do nothing
but ponder upon the great questions of life. It's all about how you go into
the high.
Take acid for example. If you have a bad day, and you're feeling down,=
 chances
are you'll have a REALLY bad trip. But if you're happy and totally looking
forward to that trip, it will most likely be a good one. =3D)

>Drugs.....people should learn from.  I have a friend who takes drugs... for
>what? He doesn't learn anything from each time.
>For example,  When I took "E" for the first time. It was the most amazing=
=20
>experience of my life (that was also the first time I went to a rave) I had
>my Awsome friends around me sharing this incredible experience. I saw=20
>everyone's beauty come out and onto the surface.

*nods his head* I can confirm that Molly had  the time of her life the first
time she bought Eggs. =3D)))
But just like she said, it's all about the situation and your attitude. A
few of my friends have gone to raves, done E, and simply expected something
marvelous to happen. Of course, sometimes it doesn't. If YOU don't give the
drug YOUR positive side, how can you expect the drug to give its positive
side to you?

Well folks, I'm off to prepare for my ELM tomorrow. If you have room, please
pray for me... ;)

*hugs*
jonas

To: Simply756@aol.com, blkadder@value.net
Subject: Re: drug induced love? Deep thoughts.
Cc: Epiglottal@aol.com, Lunatune@aol.com, bri@value.net,
        iweiss02@ccsf.cc.ca.us, laren.k@easynet.co.uk, sfraves@hyperreal.com,
        sweety@pcgame.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>  But don't you think that it reflects a facet of your personality? Sober or
>  altered, any action you take reflects something inside you ...

        Sure, but drugs can enhance one side of you while suppressing
another, effectively turning you into a different person. None of us is
entirely one thing, we all have a combination of counterbalancing traits -
and it's the total balance of all these traits that makes up our personality.

	Seeing somebody's lovey side come out is nice, but if that 
side is totally shut down by anger or inhibition when they're not on 
some drug, then the drug really is turning them into someone else.
And if it's not a drug that they can just stay on indefinitely, then
that isn't going to be who they "really" are.


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Mar 22 01:30:28 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id BAA25840; Sat, 22 Mar 1997 01:30:28 -0800 (PST)

The one thing that came to mind when I read this, is that when most 
people take LSD, they end up discovering a lot of things, about the world 
and themselves (usually whether that was the intent or not).  Babies are 
in a constant state or realization and discovery.  <shrug>  I see the 
connection. =)

--Noah

kikipopo@netmagic.net | "Without music, life would be a mistake."
midnitedub@wwcomm.com |              -Friedrich Nietzsche

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Mar 22 01:40:14 1997

Precedence: bulk

From tensent@interlog.com Fri Mar 21 23:48:37 1997
>At 09:32  97/03/21 -0800, you wrote:
>>I've heard that people have done EEG (or EKG?) studies on babies, and on
>>the brains of adults on LSD, and seen very, very similar brain traces.
>>Which makes sense on all kinds of levels to me.
>how so?
>i'm not following...

Well, LSD's commonly held to "open the doors of perception"--to make you
aware of all kinds of sensory input that you're not normally aware of--
to break down the perceptual filters that you've built up, and blow your
mind with thoughts and visions and impressions that you ordinarily
block out.  Babies don't _have_ any of those filters or doors yet.  They
process everything raw; they haven't learned to block it all out.  So
they loll their heads around and always have a totally stoned look on
their face.  The wide-eyed innocent look of a novice tripper and of a
young baby look awfully similar to me....

So it makes sense that there's some objective correlation between their
brain states.  IMHO, anyway.

Rob

So after 3 choices, and two hours of wait, I finally narrowed my night down
to Space Children.  Had to see Dutch and Surge!

I only stayed for part of the party, since I have to work in the morning,
so here's what I thought:

Surge opened it up, totally brought me back to the Surge sounds that I
remember so well, before he left about 6 months ago.  Excellent set, and
had good energy to open up the party.

Dutch played next, and took me to the "next" level with his style that I
*always* love.  Dutch has never disappointed me, ever since I first saw him
back in the Recycle days.  Great days @ The Stone & 16th * Harrison.  

Finally, I only stuck around for the live act Baktun 13 (correct?).  I give
*much* props to the guys on the conga and the drums.  Short set, but sweet.
 

So . . . missed Graeme and Union Jack.  Somebody tell me how their sets
went, since I couldn't stick around.

O.K., I'm zoned out, and need sleep, 
Peace, Bill

Sorry to post an unhappy note to this happy group, just gotta get this 
off my chest.

My freind from LA and I drove from Santa Cruz to hear the legendary 
sounds of Ron D Core, whom before I had only heard tapes of.  The whole 
scene was strrange: the woman taking my money nearly had a fit, saying 
the twenty I had gotten from the ATM was fake, because it was old and 
didn't have a magnetic strip.  Did they do this to everyone?  Was it a 
money-making scheme they started because they were empty?  Oh well.

Seconds after we walked in, we were kicked out by security who assumed 
we were part of a drug deal.  I tried to talk to him, but he had it 
fixed in his mind that my friend was selling drugs. (Which he was not)

Poop.  Someday, someday we'll see Ron.  What a was to spend the Equinox.

In response to several requests, I have set up a digest version of
SFRaves.  Using this, you'll get one large chunk of messages every 25
messages or so, which should mean about 1-2 per day.  It's all the same
content, there's no moderation going on or anything, people just sometimes
prefer it this way. 

If you want to change your subscription to that, send a message to
majordomo@hyperreal.com with the following commands:

  unsubscribe sfraves
  subscribe sfraves-digest

and all should be swell.  

	Brian

--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=--
brian@hyperreal.com     http://www.apache.org     http://www.organic.com/jobs

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

My boyfriend and I decided to go to Space Children, last night.  We got
really dressed up in glitter and candy-raver-type clothes.  I was
worried, at first, that I would hate the party, because the security
guards outside gave off a really nasty vibe.  They totally embarassed us
when we were walking in.  One of them stopped us, then turned to another
security guard and said something along the lines of, "Look at those
clothes!  Have you ever seen anything like that before in your life?" 
Then a bunch of them started laughing.  As a result, I hated that party
before I even walked in.

We finally got inside and found a place to hide our coats.  We stood up
to take a look around, and realized that we were standing right next to
some of our friends.  Immediately I felt better!  To celebrate, I took
out two big bags of assorted candy and started handing it out to all the
people sitting on the floor.  Everyone who I gave candy to was really
nice.

I'm not used to big parties, so I wasn't really sure what to expect.  I'm
really glad it turned out well, though.

I'd like to thank the promoters for being so nice to me and I'd really
like to thank all the people I met who gave me hugs (not very many people
there were into hugging) and stickers and candy.

My apologies to Space Children for thinking I wouldn't like the party.  I
was wrong--I'll make sure never to judge a party by it's security guards
again ;-)

Love and kisses to all (even those "oh-so-friendly" security guards),

                   			---Libby Rose :-)

So we got the gang together (we being that crazy Elmo guy Matt, who no longer
wants to be known as Kermit anymore... Now he's cracked-out elmo) in Matt's
nice rental Blazer... Since the poor boy CRASHED his car... It'll be back.

there... Somehow they got in anyhow... I have no idea how, but it's all good.
 We got there, and the first thing I have to say is that the parchutes were
cool, but my poor antennas kept hitting them!  That's ok thought, I had a
basket full of candy and a new dress care of my sweetheart Matt.

So the night began... Lots of fun... I got to take my little brother (& his
girlfriend) and sister. They had a blast. I got to pass out candy... Someone
called me the Little Candy Princess from Outer Space... It was great.

So, I got to dance with all the little girls... And my boyfriend (that crazy
shit) introduced me to EVERYONE he could get his hands on... hehe... Hope
 you all liked me dress...

And as for the afterparty of oh.... 60 or so people in my tiny tiny
apartment... (I said that he'd take full resposibility all Matt says is,
"oops") I apologize for the chaotic state of the apartment.  We were all in a
hurry to leave before the party, and I NEVER expected that I would have that
many people in our apartment the next morning... Maybe a couple friends...
Next time... Things will be different. If the management doesn't kick us out
first.

So... to all involved... will there be a Warmth on March 1st or so next
year... You know that will be the year anniversary that Matt and me met...
And don't worry... You'll all be invited to the wedding... hehehehe... I'll
take resposibility for  that one, baby... *wink*

Rave on! And love to all! Especially my Matthew!

   Has anyone ever seen this miraculous novelty?  They look and act just like
regular glycerin bubbles, and yet they are actually flavored candy.  These
were first introduced to me by a someone I met while away for the weekend.
 We spent much time in a group discovering uses for candy bubbles.  They were
lots of fun, and I think they'd be great to take to a party, but there's a
problem.  
     So far this weekend, I've been to numerous toy stores in search of these
edible bubbles, with no luck.  I can't find a single store that carries them.
 Does anyone know where I can purchase them, or know of a company that
manufactures them?  It would help me (and my many other friends that are
searching for them) out a tremendous bunch.  THank you so much!!

On Fri, 21 Mar 1997, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

> 
> ------- Forwarded Message
> 
> Xerox PARC Forum
> 
>    Thursday, March 27, 1997
>    4:00 - 5:00 PM
>    George Pake Auditorium
> 
> 
> Playing Electronic Instruments:  Technique Meets Technology
> 
>    Mark Goldstein
> 
> ABSTRACT:
> 
> The advent of electronic music changed the way composers and listeners
> work with and relate to sound. Since the initial efforts in this form
> were taped pieces, sonic sculptures crafted out of real time, the notion
> of performer was irrelevant. Today, a wide variety of commercial
> synthesizers are available and new real time synthesis techniques from
> the computer music laboratories are becoming available. Most of these
> synthesizers and algorithms can be controlled from arbitrary input
> devices. The piano keyboard has been a ubiquitous front end for all
> sorts of sounds, many of them not pianistic at all. It is also not
> unusual to see a computer on stage with an electronic ensemble. Quite
> often the audience cannot understand the effects of the computer
> player's actions. I am interested in broadening the possibilities for
> performing electronics, investigating the relationship between gesture
> and sound,  and regaining a sense of instrumental virtuosity in the
> electronic genre.
> 
> Music is a performing art, and part of the quality of the musical
> experience comes from the relationship between the player's physical
> technique and the sound that is produced. A player can feel this
> intimately. A listener can appreciate this connection visually (and
> viscerally) whether in a live concert or in the mind's eye while
> listening to a recorded performance.
> 
> Our rich tradition of musical instruments has created a repertoire of
> gestures (bowing, blowing, banging, etc.) that are closely tied to
> familiar sounds. Can these gestures be appropriated to control new sorts
> of sounds? Are there other forms of movement that are musically
> effective? I have been exploring these questions using a MalletKAT (an
> electronic marimba) and Buchla Lightning Wands (a pair of wireless
> infrared wands broadcasting to a 2-D tracking sensor that also performs
> gesture recognition). I will trace the development of electronic music
> and its performance practices, demonstrate a variety of empty-handed and
> hybrid electronic instruments, and perform a piece for Lightning solo,
> "Joan is Back," by Bay Area composer Silvia Mateus.
> 
> 
> BIOGRAPHY:
> Mark Goldstein is an independent software consultant specializing in
> audio and musical applications. He is also a conservatory-trained
> percussionist and freelance musician. He has worked at the Center for
> New Music and Audio Technologies (U.C. Berkeley), the Center for
> Computer Research in Music and Acoustics (Stanford),  Gibson Guitar
> G-WIZ Labs, and Studer Editech/Integrated Media Systems.
> 
> 
> Xerox Internal:
>    http://parcweb.parc.xerox.com/events/forum
> 
> External:
>    http://www.parc.xerox.com/ops/projects/forum
> 
> - -------------------------------------------------------------------------
> This Forum is OPEN to the public:
> 
> Host: David Jared (415) 812-4120
> 
> Requests for videotapes for XEROX EMPLOYEE ONLY should be sent to
> Kim Edens (edens@parc.xerox.com)
> 
> Refreshments will be served from 3:45 to 4:00 PM
> 
> The George Pake Auditorium is located at 3333 Coyote Hill Road in Palo Alto.
> We are between Page Mill Road (west of Foothill Expressway) and Hillview
> Avenue, in the Stanford Research Park.  The easiest way here is to get
> onto Page Mill Road, and turn onto Coyote Hill Road.  As you drive up
> Coyote Hill past the horse pastures, PARC is the large building on the
> left after you crest the hill.  Park in the large parking lot, and enter
> the auditorium at the upper level of the building.  The auditorium entrance
> is located down the stairs and to the left of the main doors.
> 
> ------- End of Forwarded Message
>

Subject: Simple Pleasure Review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, first of all I'll get the negative stuff out of the way. The cost was
$25 and drinks were $2.50. So already you have a good chunk of money
invested. These raves are getting expensive.

The good stuff, though, would be this is some of the best damn music I've
heard in a long time. I never left the main floor and just tripped to the
amazing spins of Jon Bishop (he was incredible), Carlos (who put on a sweet
set and some of his kick ass scratch), and Kwashi & Essence (they brought the
crowd home). I spent the whole time up front (I was in a white shirt with red
stripes on the sleeves in case you were up there). This was the release I had
been looking for since I have not raved for about three weeks. What a nice
feeling! And I met some incredibly smiley people which is sooooo nice. And
the club ... it was jacked up in lights and those figures on the ceiling are
trippy.

By the way, I just bought DJ Micro's CD Coast to Coast and can't believe how
sweet it is. Does anyone have any additional suggestions for CDs that have
this type of energy? Any help would be greatly appreciated.

peace and joy,
Carl

The party went off!

The Spacechildren's Evening with Union Jack was by far the 
fattest party I've ever been to.  Yeah the security guards
were kind of sketch on the way in... but once inside the vibe
was really there--- caesars was a great location, and the djs
and groups were incredible.  BakTun13 (sp?) were stunning...
and Union Jack was unbelieveable!  Everyone was really
into it-people were actually enjoying themselves!  The Bass
was great (thanks for the smiles hugs and energy to the
guys hanging around the bass tower stage left with me-you
were all inspring! And thanks to the guy for what he said afterwards
up on the stage-he was really right-the sound was gone but
the energy was still there-and now its up to us to take the vibe
to the rest of the world, in whatever we do..

The Spacechildren really did a great job!  Keep the vibe goin!

And I hear rumors of a Spacechildren & Seismic party being thrown down
here on May 2nd (San Luis Obispo) 4 rooms!?!  Chocolate Factory?
Sounds like a killer lineup.... Anyone know more?

Keep the vibe

Geoff

From:  MR2[SMTP:choice@ccnet.com]
Sent:  Saturday, March 22, 1997 2:47 AM
To:  sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject:  *** Space Children- A Partial Review ***

So after 3 choices, and two hours of wait, I finally narrowed my night down
to Space Children.  Had to see Dutch and Surge!

I only stayed for part of the party, since I have to work in the morning,
so here's what I thought:

Surge opened it up, totally brought me back to the Surge sounds that I
remember so well, before he left about 6 months ago.  Excellent set, and
had good energy to open up the party.

Dutch played next, and took me to the "next" level with his style that I
*always* love.  Dutch has never disappointed me, ever since I first saw him
back in the Recycle days.  Great days @ The Stone & 16th * Harrison.  

Finally, I only stuck around for the live act Baktun 13 (correct?).  I give
*much* props to the guys on the conga and the drums.  Short set, but sweet.
 

So . . . missed Graeme and Union Jack.  Somebody tell me how their sets
went, since I couldn't stick around.

O.K., I'm zoned out, and need sleep, 
Peace, Bill

Hay there SFrave Kiddies!!
the ward valley protest ROCKED!!
all the buildings in the area were bouncin and jigglin to the beats
even the cop-eroonies couldn't stand still (although they remained in
perma-frown status)
At one occasion, we were told we'd have to go away, because some of the more
daring kids were on the stairs (OH NO!!)*chuckle*, and just a few times the
music stopped... BUT when it did, the drummers kept the beat, and everyone
helped with some killer vocals, and the rave *NEVER* stopped!!!!! :) 
(except for some wonderful words for the Ward Valley Protest)
The vibe was exellent.
The dog kept trying to steal some donuts, and (HORAY) was given one to eat
all to himself...
i met ravers from LA, from Chicago, from Illinois, but i didn't meet, not
even ONE, from SFRaves... :) where were you guys?? 
It was a beautiful occasion, even the heavens approved, when they could have
cried, and rained on the *shiver* uncovered equipment, the sky just held the
rain...
What a great day... 
and the evening?? THAT is a *totally* DIFFERENT story.. :)
LoVe To AlL
--=---LunaTune---=--

I'm not usually a list whiner, but everytime I see DRC in a heading I can't
help but think of DJ DRC/Darcy.  I dig that people are forewarning of drug
discussions in their messages, but is their an alternative that doesn't
confuse people and create  unassociated associations?

Like how about use the codeword  "Jondabomb" to warn listees of sketchy topics?

Okay, that was a joke.:o) I dunno.  Maybe it's not a big deal.  Anyone have
any suggestions?

 o  DRT (drug related topics)
 o  DOPECON (dope conversation)
 o  DMT (dope mentioned therein) & for the nondopers:(Dope Mentioned,Trash.)
 o  LSD (let's suggest dope)
  
okay, I'm running low on fuel.

See you later, alligators.

I'll make this short and to the point , , ,  once again, the 1st Sunset of
the year ROCKED! 
I really enjoy the first and last Sunsets- they are the ones that bring out
the most positive vibes in everyone.  Not a frown from anyone around, and
the vibe was so thick, you couldn't cut it with a knife.  
It was really great to be back outdoors with the fresh air, smiles, and old
faces you hadn't seen in a while.
I even took a friend took his first outdoor -------> enjoyed it a lot, and
felt a lot more comfortable than being indoors.
San Francisco, California- need we say more?!

I was only there for John Howard and Galen --------> much props for
delivering such beautiful sets  :-}

Later, Bill

Subject: ward valley & Sunset!
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Oh baby what a supreme weekend!  I know it would almost be sacriligious to say 
it, but I _didn't_ have all that much fun at CLoud Factory last week.....due to 
a combo of some bad drgs and a miniquarrel with the SO that day.  Anyhoo, 
needless to say, I was doubly fired up for this weekend, to redeem it all and 
reverse the funky karma.  And, like a fat J at the end of a long day, the crews 
at Ward Valley/Moontribe and The Sunset/Pacific crew know how to satisfy!

The Ward Valley rally really went off, with some of the most tweaky music I've 
heard in awhile.  Was it the LA influence? Great builds, and the gusto to bring 
it off the top.  Getting together  for a good cause always seems to bring out a 
good vibe. Did anyone make it to the 'later event'? Review?

And Sunset... what can you say about Sunset in words?  I had mucho trabajo to 
do, so I got up xtra early to finish it all.  It was a race against the clock 
to get all the work done, and the ETD of 2 pm came and went. Finally got there 
about 6, just in time to load a b and watch the sunset.  Then the full moon 
came out, then the Hale Bopp comet was visible.  Then, went it seemed like it 
couldn't get better, we were treated to an almost-full lunar eclipse. Plus, it 
stayed pretty warm the whole time! TONS of happy folks there, a GREAT sound 
system, a little jungle towards the end of the night....was this heaven? 

Thank you, thank you, thank you. 

Nathan

Subject: Sunset...Take the trash on your way out!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

First let me say the Pacific Crew does it again, what else is new. If you
didn't have a good time it was your own fault. I had a wonder time like
always. Sunset is one of the best daytime party out there and always will
be in my book.

The only thing that bothered me was the trash people left around. This was
the worse I've ever seen. I may have not stayed after to clean up, but I
did pick up alot of trash that was left on the ground while I was there. I
spent at least a half hour cleaning up trash as I was walking around. I
could have filled 2 big garbage bags of trash and I didn't even make a dent.

People, if we want Sunsets to be as beautiful as always, we need to help
keep the space clean. It's outdoors,  the lights can't be turned on and
brooms and mops can't be brought out to clean. We need to start picking up
our trash as we go. If you trip over some trash, don't just look at it,
pick it up and throw it away. If everyone cleans up after themselves it
would make alot less of a mess.

So, please respect the space and help clean up. If you don't stay until the
end, at least pick up and take some trash on your way out.




*****************************************************************
                         Tim (knucklehead)

  BBQ & BEATS Home Page:  http://www.club.net/~knucklehead/BnB

I was kickin' in a cafe, baked outta my gourd, and I overheard this weird
couple pondering this question:

If you use Nutrasweet to make a sugar cookie, is it still a sugar cookie,
or is it a Nutracookie?


I don't know, maybe I'm crazy, but I think I just discovered a new chicken
or the egg philosopichal discussion.

High SFR!

Well, I'm pretty sure that I was one of the only SFRavers at this party. I
showed up early and the place was still pretty empty. The location was OK, even
thought there was a bar right outside the party.It was kinda hard to have 420,
but I managed. 

Jesse Martindale in the Mermaid room was RAD! I think that having somebody
spinning reggae at a party is a great idea and I hope I see this at more
parties. Some times you need a break from techno, you know? I also wanna give
phat props to Nelson Reeves and Kevin Hart for spinning some phat beats and
making me dance. Unfortunately, I went to the party with a lot of non-ravers,
so I had to leave hella early (1:00 am ={ ), but I had a good time anyways. Did
anyone else from SFR go? What happened after 1?


Ivan

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Sunset/Comet/Eclipse
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9703240949.A22289-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Three beautiful natural events... dancing with bare feet on the grass with
so many stars overhead felt like the perfect (the only!) place to be last
night.  Thanks to the fire dancer on the beach, all the people who brought
candles and glowsticks and incense and otherwise contributed to the vibe,
and of course to Pacific for a third season of giving to the scene. 

Someone said 500 people... but I'd say at least 1000 of us were there.  
I've never seen such a massive Sunset, but it was all ug, word-of-mouth 
only... and a ridiculous number of smiles and cheers.  Like I always feel 
at the first Sunset... the season is starting, and the scene is 
thriving!  Winter is over, and spring (rebirth) and summer (hedonism!) are 
in the air.

Here's to the continual rejuevenation of our scene...

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: End of DV8 -- Spundae??
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9703241043.A22633-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Just heard yesterday that DV8 is CLOSING!  Last night was IT for DV8 as a
club... it is closing starting today for remodeling and will reopen as
(gag) a restaurant downstairs, and offices on the top floors. 

Does this mean SPUNDAE is also over?  Or has it found a new home (I 
certainly hope so!)  In addition to being about the best "club" for us 
spoiled ravers, Spundae also has to be one of the all-time greatest names, 
with at least four meanings that _I_ can think of!

Also, DV8 is the largest club in SF besides 1015.  What does the closing 
of a major club mean for the mainstream scene?  Will 1015 become even 
more crowded with suburban "weekend warriors"?  Is the clubscene so 
moribound that DV8 is no longer profitable as a dance club??  DV8, though 
admittedly lame on main nights, was a home to techno... does this mean 
less venues for techno nights, now that it's gone?  Pondering...

I can be a whiner, and I have to say: why in the world do we have to 
alert people if we (gasp) dare to mention drugs in our posts??  Let's try 
to leave mainstream knee-jerk anti-drug prejudice behind and be honest 
about our experiences and our scene (thankfully open-minded, I like to 
think!).

PS I also immediately think the discussion is about DJ DRC whenever I see 
"DRC."

IMO, Trance and Jungle Factory is pretty UG!  Last time I was there it 
was all dj's and scenesters... not too many lookyloos.  The calendar is a 
service for those in the scene (not just people with email).  I wouldn't 
be too worried about the type of person who would seek out this store 
showing up at a party!  Most likely they're already spinning at it :)

BTW, Tom has done a _great_ job setting up this store!  Lotsa
love (and money, I bet!) went into decorating... check out the mini-chill
room with netting and a forest theme, complete with stuffed animals
peeking from behind trees.

I made a boo-boo in my earlier response to this (sorry Brian)
 ... so I'm resending it.

Someone asked about having SFRCalendar info posted at the Trance
and Jungle Factory.  I think that's great .... this is a list that is open to anyone
who'd like to svbscribe, and events posted on the list are there as free
information.  Real underground parties aren't posted (or are posted with
minimal information), so that's not a worry.  

Before I had email, I used to go to Ameba and ask Alan what was up, and
he'd show me his printout (and when I was really ballsy, I'd call him and
ask) ....  Matter of fact, when I lose my email, I"ll probably be asking Thomas
and Greta what's up too!

then.....  Nancy asked why we should note at all if there's Drug Related Content in
a post ....

Many of us use email accounts in our place of work .... and those work
accounts are not in any way private.  I think it's a good idea to create a way
for people to filter out posts that are on topics that would not be appropriate
for them in that environment.  Frankly, it makes me pretty nervous seeing some
of the posts that come across my mail.  Naming names in context with illegal
activities is pretty foolish as far as I'm concerned.  

My pennies worth...
Leslie

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Vienna "Raves"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9703241111.A23310-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


In preparation for continent-hopping this summer, a friend gave me a 
brochure from the Tourist Board of Vienna (Austria, for all you ignorant 
Americans ;).  It lists shopping, hotels, sightseeing tours, and bars and 
clubs!  One of which features "raves daily from 10PM".

Cute grammatical errors aside, I am not sure whether to be horrified or to
accept this as a part of European culture.  If "rave" is completely
mainstream there, does that simply mean any nightclub with techno music is
a "rave"?  Or could this event be something recognizably "rave" (by my
definition), so common in the culture that it could retain "real raveness" 
despite its inclusion in a (ack!) tourist brochure?  Or is the Tourist
Board just clueless, throwing the term "rave" in just to appear hip? 

The definition of "rave" is more than problematic, it's practically 
meaningless.  So much so that a brochure can list "rave" and I have no 
clue what to expect there.  

(Yes, my boss is out of the office today and I'm indulging in a shamefully 
delicious email orgy!)

Thank you to all who gave me suggestions for Thursday night... I'll have
to file them away for future use though, because I stumbled upon the
perfect party plan for this Thursday... <ta da>... the 20th Anniversary
screening of Saturday Night Fever at the Roxie!!!  This is a
not-to-be-missed disco event.  And for those of you who think you don't
like disco, revisit this dance music of the '70's for bells, whistles,
stomping bass and percussion.  It's the grandma of techno!  And from what 
I hear, the underground disco scene was the rave scene of the 70's.  :)

i can't actually answer your questions, but could it be that the rave
culture in germany and austria is less of an illegal / underground thing.
here in england there are parts of the rave scene that have quite a
political agenda (e.g. the travellers / new age travellers who got the whole
thing going here) and then you have the trespassing problem where hundreds
of people descend on some poor farmer's field for an all-night illegal rave,
illegal because of the criminal (in)justice act, which also makes assemblies
of more than something like 4 people and REPETITIVE BEATS illegal!!!
 i think raves are more 'acceptable' in germany (i don't know about
austria). i think germans had less problems incorporating it into the
mainstream. because, to be honest, if raves were illegal in germany, then
there wouldn't be any. did you see how the german police handled this
nuclear waste transport protest? i expect austria is fairly similar.
i'm not saying that german or austrian raves are crap, they are just not
underground.
but then...i could be completely wrong.



Iris

 (Al in Quantum Leap)

well as it has been said before,Sunset rocked!! There were alot of people and
saw a lot of old(and made some new) friends. Met Leslie and uncle noah and
ended the night by going to my first full moon.
-Full Moon was the best! It could've been 6 years ago ....Everything about it
was so perfect(cept it was cold, but that was okay) Didn't gey=t to stay very
long on account of work early the next morning. but it was definatley worth
the drive! I am wondering who was the first dj to go on-It was a woman(she
rocked!). Can anyone who was there let me know who that was? just curious-
-Missed Ron D Core!!!I can't believe it! but the party got shut down anyway.
For any and all Ron D Core fans there's always the Dr. Freeclouds
website@www.drfreeclouds.com got a big selection of ron's tapes(check out
acid test2 and for something diffrent "born in the south"(Ron's only?House
tape) The Fuck You record sounds like one of the tracks from "Clash of the
Titans" which he and excalibur put out last year on thier atomic label(if you
get the picture disk check out the backside for some psycho fun. I used to
like Ron's sets alot more but he has gotten was too fast to dance to (usally
they just mosh in LA).
-That's all for now...

till 9

Info # 510.614.7568                             @ a familiar outdoors 
East bay location.

Rebel Alliance Sound

Regarding raves in Austria, Germany and Switzerland: there are raves and
there are raves.
Especially in Germany there are big ultra commercial raves with big
corporate sponsorships (Marlboro, Pepsi and the likes), fan devotionalia,
follow-up CD compilations and videos and even the rights to broadcast from
these events are being sold to the media (see events like Mayday and Love
Parade).
This would now indicate that the whole scene is selling out. This is only
half the truth.

The techno movement is already so old and so widespread that you have loads
of different factions,
and only at the very big events like Love Parade they unite. I have heard
other people mentioning
that at events like Love Parade the music was only BUMM-BUMM GERMAN TECHNO.
Well that was probably Dutch Gabber. There were enough American DJs present
(e.g. Carl Cox) that
certainly have a more house kind of style.

Back to the original topic: So many people - read the European youth - is
infected with the techno
virus and is trying Djaying, producing tracks, putting together parties, or
opening record labels.
Among my friends I have loads of European DJs, label owners and party
promoters. Sounds impressive
right? But these guys/girls are only just getting by doing this, if at all.
Are they doing it because of their
faith in techno is all they need - no, they are just never going to make it
because there is other better
and more devoted people out there.

Translate: there is still loads of parties all over Europe that are kind of
underground, and some of them
are actually in squatted houses, at the seaside (like Sunset), at remote
mountain sites etc.
Are you likely to read about them in the press or on the internet? Not
likely. I have the good fortune
to know a lot of folks in that scene that can give me the right pointers
whenever I am in Technoland.
If you can read German: get Frontpage (their website is www.techno.de - UKs
mixmag is here too)
or Partysan (www.partysan.de). Or when in Vienna get the Prinz (a paper
like the SFBG but not free).

You will though find an ample amount of commercial to semi-commercial club
/ rave events in every
major city in Europe, which includes Vienna, Basel or Munich to stay in
that triangle.

While Vienna is perhaps beautiful to visit, if you want to rave then go to
Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands, Italy, Spain (especially Ibiza). Forget
the UK apart for some special events (Tribal Gathering) or some standard
clubbing (which is more house than techno - which is OK).

If you are an absolute party boy/girl Ibiza might be the ultimate option,
because that's where the
top Brit, German and Dutch DJs are eventually playing as well. But beware
this means party on
24h/day and  7days the week (not cheap either - but sun and fun).

I would especially look at aforementioned URLs before planning a trip to
Europe.

Enough waste of bandwidth!
Regards Jan

Date: Mon, 24 Mar 1997 20:27:17 -0500 (EST)
From: "lara at vibe.org" <lara@vibe.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: one bombass weekend with a weird LA party
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.970324201324.729M-100000@linux.announce.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Lara went to LA this weekend with some SFRavers :)
Ryan's idea of a car of partiers going to LA became a caravan, and it was 
PERFECT! Took us about 14 hours to get down to LA (11 from my house) cuz 
we stopped way too many times to get food, and get gas. BUT it was all 
good, cuz everytime we stopped, we busted out dancing in the parking lot 
-- at one point we had people staring at us from their cars and 
everything. HOW FUN though.
	The weekend was full of love and energy for us, but when we 
showed up at FULL CIRCLE, it was odd. My first LA party, I had no idea 
what to expect, i had NO expectations and thank god i didn't! Here are a 
few things I learned from this party, and from talking to various NICE LA 
ravers..
1) LA Ravers are VERY dedicated and concerned regarding what they're 
wearing. Stariana pointed out that everyone wants to be the coolest 
looking raver at the parties.
2) LA raves have ALOT OF HARDCORE and NITROUS. Hardcore is fun, but I 
could only jack my body for a half hour before i noticed that there were 
tons of people just bobbing their heads up and down (Another SFRaver 
pointed out that LA can't dance, hehe!) Plus, in the Trance tent, there 
were a couple Nitrous tanks hangin out, I was assured that Nitrous is 
very popular at parties.. I was scared to find people passing out, but 
relieved when no one did.. i THINK
3) LA raves lack the community and love SF raves do. I MISSED SF SO MUCH 
this past weekend, I am SO GRATEFUL for our scene! My friend Andy who 
lives in LA and used to throw a weekly down there said that everyone's 
out for themselves down there, and that it's so commercialized down there 
that he's given up socializing at partie4s all together, it's so 
frustrating...

Our tent was set up super phat, Ryan and Christine started bringing in 
ravers who weren't feeling well and couldnt find their friends for us to 
take care of. I sat with a cpouple of them and calmed them down hardcore, 
and it was the funnest night! 
SO OVERALL: FULL CIRCLE WAS LIKE THIS:
	The music was incredible, but Lara can only handle hardcore for a 
short while before the incessant (sp?) pounding becomes a little like a 
hammer hitting her head :) 
	The vibe SUCKED alot! I met a FEW LA Ravers who arew nice, but 
for the most part, AT THIS PARTY, the people did NOTwant to be talked to 
at ALL. Was it just THIS party? I dunno, which is why I'm determined to 
go to another LA party :) 
	The location was EXCELLENT: a desert in the middle of what seemed 
to be nowhere :) 
	The SETUP was phat, although the trance tent should have been 
bigger and if they were gonna sell Nitrous, it should have been a little 
less obvious, but then that's just me.. ;))
OK? OK!
I want to thank EVERYONE who went on this trip for sticking together, we 
all almost split up and went to 2 partie,s but without everyone, I think 
we would have had an awful time at Full Circle. THANK YOU TO HADRIAN!! 
FOR ALL THE PHAT VIBES AND HUGS :) Good Karma DOES exist, i promise! 
THanks to RYAN for the vision and seeing it through :)) THanks to the 
HAPPY KIDS for bringing me the phattest smiles and love ever, April 5th 
HERE WE GO! :) (ian where were u!) thanks to Brett (where's waldo) for 
driving down and vibin' as well :)
AND: thanks to SFRave community, for giving such love, and sticking 
together! I can't believe, how wonderful you all are!
love and hugs,
lara~~

my technics SLBD22k's...and I still couldn't match beats very well...and I

what.  I couldn't even tell when he was mixing nstuff (hi jeff!)

The Ceridwen show at Mission Rock on Friday was a-fucking-mazing. 
Beautiful night, great view of the almost-full moon, totally clear...  

The last two downstairs DJs (both with Moontribe, i understand) just
totally rocked the house, and were *so* into their set. They were both
completely and inexorably in the ZONE, plugged into the crowd, throwing
their hands in the air (and even waving 'em like they just didn't care),
obviously loving it, oozing pleasure and passion.  The crowd was throughly
infected with the trancy grooves, lotsa joyous whistling and egging the
DJs on.  

We even got the last dude to do an oncore set; people wouldn't stop
yelling and asking for more, so he complied.  Cool!

I'd love to get their names; anyone know?

--goolz

>raveness"  despite its inclusion in a (ack!) tourist brochure? 

I hear what you're saying about the confusion behind their lingo, but if you
read the Berkeley Guides (a global tourist handbook), under "San Francisco"
they urge the reader to check out the rave scene while in town.   I guess
they suggest it in the same tone that they suggest you go down to Telegraph
Ave to check out the scowling punkers sitting on newspaper boxes & hawking
lungers at pedestrians.

I think "Let's Go" has similar suggestions.,, appealing to the 20 Sumping's
with fat wallets & time to kill.

One person's lifestyle is another's vacation, I guess.

Hey Adam, it's weird how two people can be at the same party and have 
completely opposite experiences...

Ceridwen started off in a beauty way, but by 1:00 PM had turned into a 
drunken stupor,  Yes the music was amazing, the black light art hangin 
from the walls the best I have ever seen and more. Sweet gentle peole, 
lots of CCC folks and familiar faces from 7:00 PM on...

However something 
happened when the booze flowed....stumbling drunks  everywhere..and sadly
one saw fit to vomit several times on the altar I brought "Mariposa", 
some of you might remember her from the Gateway camp at Burning Man and 
some other parties since then... she came within seconds of being 
irreparably damaged..and was in fact damaged...
Had I know that Mission Rock had bars I would have never brought her...I 
accept responsibility for not doing my homework....Amazing enough, this 
is the first time I had ever been to Mission Rock...a great space, except 
for the bars...  

I had a vision, to take Mariposa to different parties and share her with 
as many tribes as possible...I was told that not all of the tribes are 
ready for her..or other altars...  myself and others spent the night 
protecting the alters from destruction....  Mariposa won't be going out 
for a while and when she does, it will be only to those parties I  already 
know and trust...

I am glad that lots of folks were unaffected by the drunkenness..

~~peace

Maureen

P.S.  As of tonight, I will no longer receive any mail via the Well..my 
new address (for some time) is mh2o@microweb.com.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 24 23:58:02 1997

Date: Mon, 24 Mar 1997 23:57:54 -0800 (PST)
From: Noah Apodaca <unclenoa@netcom.com>
Subject: WHAT a weekend! :)
To: "Ravers 'Round the Bay" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>,
        Ravers in the Southland <socal-raves@ucsd.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9703242331.A21633-0100000@netcom>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Where to start?  Okay, I have to say that my friends Annie and Andy are 
the greatest travel partners a person could ask for!

Okay so on to the parties:
Space Children:  I didn't think we had the right location at first... 
looked like a bunch of gangsters out front, but after swinging by a local 
house party, we drove back to the location and I could see inside and 
there was lots of flourescent stuff, so I figured it was all right.  
Great to see Union Jack 'live' (yes, when the 303 came unplugged, some 
sounds stopped happening, so it really was running :P).  I _really_ liked 
that they played the remix of Two Full Moons and a Trout.  One of my 
favorite tracks of all time  :)

Ward Valley Protest:  A fun gathering, but not as big as I had expected.  
Too bad, too since there was some really great music!  I heard that new 
Jedi Knights rekkid and almost fainted! (I picked up a copy at Ameba 
shortly thereafter) :)  So, all-in-all a really fun time!

Bellysomething (?) @ Cyborganic:  Didn't stay too long due mostly to 
exhaustion, but hey for $5 you really can't complain about anything, now 
can you?  The trampoline and big stuffed bear were really cool!

Sunset:  What a great party!  So many fun folks... too many to be able to 
meet everyone, but I loved being there so very much.  A lovely comet on 
one side, a beautiful eclipse on the other and loving happy people all 
around.  Wow.

Full Moon @ Panther Beach:  I had heard a lot about this location and had 
seen photos of it before and had wanted to see it in person for a long 
time.  This party was so much fun!  Too cold, yes, but fun!  If you 
wanted to boogie down, there was plenty of opportunity.  If you wanted to 
visit with frieds, there was plenty of opportunity.  If you wanted to go 
meditate on the rocks, there was plenty of opportunity.  If you wanted to 
just bug out by the fire... well, you get the picture :)

So it's been a long time since I've had a weekend quite this full of 
adventure!  I saw a lot of fun folks (including the Uncle Noah Fan Club 
who listened to the new tape I gave them twice in less than 24 hours :D) 
and had a really great time.  I only regret that now I have to go to 
sleep and go back to work in the morning :(

Okay, if there's no ODP then I'll rest this weekend and see you all at Dune

-Uncle Noah

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Mar 25 00:05:51 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id AAA12137; Tue, 25 Mar 1997 00:05:51 -0800 (PST)
Received: from melvax.sonoma.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id AAA12131; Tue, 25 Mar 1997 00:05:47 -0800 (PST)
Received: from SONOMA.EDU by SONOMA.EDU (PMDF V5.1-7 #8366)
 id <01IGWE6I8L329866LG@SONOMA.EDU> for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Tue,
 25 Mar 1997 00:05:38 PST
Date: Tue, 25 Mar 1997 00:05:38 -0800 (PST)
From: berger@SONOMA.EDU
Subject: full circle
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-id: <Pine.PMDF.3.95.970324233725.557920996F-100000@SONOMA.EDU>
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

aaaah, well, lara pretty much said everything there was to say about our
field trip to so-cal this weekend. coming from l.a. and having started
partying there, i was dissapointed with the vibethere. everybody was
concerned with being the best dresser, the most popular, etc., and noone
was willing to spread their happiness with others. us sfravers were
looking for love where all we got was intimidating stares from lots of
them. 
despite all this, there were also alot of friendly happy people that i
wanted to pack in my suitcase and take back with me to northern cal. a
girl named marisol gave me her earmuffs (blue-my favourite colour!),
something that i have been wanting for ages, a boy named scottie gave me
an fabulous hug and smile, and a girl named lawn (no clue as to how to
spell this girlie's name) had a sooper lovely smile that lit up her face.
you could see the positive energy absolutely glowing in her cheeks. one
guy, arley, gave me some pot! it wasn't so much that these people gave,
but rather that they were willing to give whatever they had, whether their
vibe or a little treat, to those around them. yay! 
i liked the music, especially in the early morning. the fliers that they
handed out were impressive, although a bit ostentatious, and now they are
making my wall pretty and colourful. the mist was kinda irritating but it
wasn't that cold and there were fires, and a yummy tent to chill in. there
was also quite a bit of drinking, something else that gives me a bad vibe
when i am around it. 
one of the highlights of this trip though was on our way to the party when
we stopped for a break to dance on the side of the road (we almost got in
trouble-oops!) and when we got to the mappoint and lara and oosha (again
spelling) started singing the "if you're happy and you know it, clap your
hands" song along with a few of the boys providing beats. so silly and so
fun! another thing was when marty was on top of the speakers in the tent
early in the morning with a happy wonderful grin on his face bumping to
the music. fun stuff. 
i believe we caused quite a stir with all of our excitement. we brought
with us such an incredibly amazing vibe with us, all, say, 20 of us, i
believe, from up north down south. if only we could have spread it
farther... if it weren't for the people i was with, i wouldn't have had
nearly as good of a time. thanks to all who went- everybody contributed
marvelous energy. it was great to meet all the happy kids (you all rock my
world) i hope everybody all had a good time.
enough of my mindless babble,
keep shining,
love and sugarkisses,
****star-E-ana****

Subject: Re: HI 8 VIDEO EDITING?
In-Reply-To: <970325015648_-1135937480@emout13.mail.aol.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.96.970325000734.28937A-100000@bass.hooked.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

well...anytime we go to VHS we start losing quality.  S-VHS it if
possible.  That's a much better format.  

or...

get it on Beta.  That's a kickin format, but basically dead because enough
people decided to go with it.  

If access is possible to a computer with video editing capabilities...then
that is the best way to do any editing.  However...the good ole linear
editing machines are still around.  Consumer grade ones don't seem to have
the accuracy that the more expensive production grades do.  

Anyway...that's a lesson in today's video editing.  But wait there's more.  

Some stereo receivers (like Moonpup's Sony) have the capability to do
video and audio edits.  They're not clean like on an editor, but it
depends upon what is needed.  

Okee?  back to my grilled tofu-cheese sandwich (that's tofu-based cheese,
not tofu and cheese, for all you cheese-heads out there nstuff (hi jeff!)

love love love

deep

Reagan Reid <raygun@value.net> wrote:
>       How was the Wicked party full moon party?! Did many people turn out
>for this?

The one I ended up at, at Panther, wasn't a Wicked affair.  I still don't
know if they did something last night or not, but I suspect that was just a
mixup on the word-of-mouth line...Garth was at Panther, and Melanie,
Carlos, Tracy, and some more.  Good crowd, maybe two hundred or so at peak
(I'm a bad judge, though), with lots of people coming down to continue
Sunset on into the night.  Bunch of people from LA, too, which was a
surprise (because of Moontribe, maybe).  The setting was truly
dazzling--Panther's pretty cool to start with, and last night's moon was
awesome.  There was a projector with various trippy vids for the cliffs,
but it was hardly necessary.  I had a damn good time, just dancing all
night...I must have told myself at least a dozen times, "OK, you *really*
have to go soon now."  I left at ten in the morning, and the music was
still rolling.

anarch@scruznet.com

is no way to squeeze Spundae into that tiny space.  V/SF though is really 
quite big in comparison to the basement of DV8, so it should be interesting 
to see how it goes off.

fact he's spending half a million dollars on renovations to do it.  But, 
they are not closing the basement, they are just remodeling it.  Spundae 
_will_ move back there when the renovations are complete...in about 3 
months...

Now I bet you never thought you'd see this response to your post, but I've
got one thing to say here: No, the bit about raves in Berkeley Guides SF
is not meant to be condescending to ravers in any way--and how do I know
this?  

BECAUSE I WROTE THE TEXT!  :-O

Berkeley Guides are revised each year, and I worked for them several
summers ago doing chapters on California and SF, and when I wrote that
bit, no, I didn't mean it the way you said at all. When I was considering
providing a comprehensive perspective of the San Francisco Bay Area, I
wanted everyone to know that raves were a vital part of the SF culture,
but I knew I had to be careful with phrasing, as this book can be bought
all over the world, and not everyone knows what a rave is or what raving
entails.  

Anyway, I'm not upset by the apparent misinterpretation at all; in fact,
as a writer I get a tremendous kick out of seeing something I wrote a long
time ago still being considered and evolving today.  Pretty cool, eh?

"The true beginning of life is writing." --Alexandrian inscription, 600
B.C.

cheers,
Timothy

It's AMAZING who's on SFRaves!!  More than once, I've written something
totally random or even a rave factoid I thought to be true, only to have
more accurate information come from the source itself (his or herself!),
another raver right here on the list!  Our numbers are huge... 

Besides networking and info and building community, this list is a great 
place to learn about all sorts of things, sometimes inadvertently! :P

It's just a major bummer that Berkeley Guides (all student written) 
folded this year.  My fantasy of touring the world on their dime will 
never be realised... you were lucky, Tim!!

pacific sound system is no joke.  everything i've heard was confirmed and
surrpassed.  when's the last time you went to a rock concert or any concert for
that matter where people helped pick up afterward?  everyone i met there was
one of us.  the natural phenomena were present: 98% moonar e-clips, comet
complete with tail, phat warm basslines, and concern for others.  why oh why
did i miss my chance to live with these guys? i'll be first in line when the
next opening happens.......

i met greta at sunset and she told me about this new store called the trance &
jungle factory which i'm sure you've all already heard of.  i went there
yesterday and was not dissappointed.  thomas was busy on the phone making
business calls so i helped myself to tasty vinyl grooves.  twelve listening
stations?  you mean i don't have to wait.....ever? that's bad ass!  when thomas
was done with his call he started to interview me.  we had a great chat as we
were nursing our hangovers from the previous sunset.  he's got great plans for
the store and he's definately committed.  please chek this store out, it's a
sure hit.  but don't forget primal. thomas made it very clear that he is doing
everything he can not to compete with primal rekkeds.  i think this a very
positive attitude.  
i will definatley make this place a regular stop on each payday.  thanks.

i think that this party on saturday afternoon is gonna be good. the R.A.S.
seems like a fun type crew so i'll just have to chek it out.

after this party and b4 sat. nite events python heads should go to the a-thon
that they are having at the uc theatre. holy grail, life o' brian, meaning all
back to back.  a big spliff is called for.  only for the headstrong strictly
for the hardcore.
..........................where oh where is the fish? a most elusive fish. and
it went wherever i do go...............dove one.

It never surprises me what we ravers do ... or what are connections to
everyone else are ... that 6 degrees of separation idea (that we are at
most 6 levels away from knowing anyone on earth, starting with everyone you
know, then everyone they know and so on) is definitely true for us ...

Nancy Shaw wrote:
>It's AMAZING who's on SFRaves!!  More than once, I've written something
>totally random or even a rave factoid I thought to be true, only to have
>more accurate information come from the source itself (his or herself!),
>another raver right here on the list!  Our numbers are huge...

As for the whole Berkeley Guides demise, there was an excellent article
about it a few weeks ago on the front page of the East Bay Express.  What's
great about books like Let's Go & the Berkeley Guides is reading between
the lines -- the people who write the stuff are generally pretty cool
students.  One of my good college friends went to Morocco & Spain for Let's
Go in the late 80's, and put information such as where in Barcelona it was
especially "wild at night with hash dealers" (deliberate misinformation --
that place compared to People's Park was a tame and safe place for hash
sales).

like gay people, Deadheads & Aliens, ravers can truly say:

WE ARE EVERYWHERE

leftjab
