From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Gay/Lesbian Ravers
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9703251016.A11234-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Although I like to think that everyone is welcome in our scene, that 
people can express themselves how and with whoever they like, I've been 
wondering just how hospitable the rave scene really is to gay and lesbian 
(etc.!) ravers.

I've seen male couples, and women together in the chill room (though 
sometimes I think a lot of this is just e-experimentation!), but going to 
a gay/lesbian club recently got me to thinking...

At this dance club, in the heart of the Castro, people were truly free.  
There was so much handholding, lapsitting, joyful embracing and sweet, 
passionate couples... As though relationships were imbued with that much 
more intensity, because here, finally, was a place couples could show how 
they felt for each other.  And I realized that I, as a (well, relatively) 
straight woman, had only _thought_ I knew what a comfortable scene was for a 
gay/lesbian person - and the rave scene suddenly looks as straight and 
uninviting as any other scene in this "hetero" world.

Yesterday my bro and me went down to greyhound rock  (a beautiful beach 
north of Santa Cruz..) indulged and lost our minds out on the beach for a 
few hours.  It got dark and cold and as we made our way back to our car 
we realized that neither of us could drive for a good long while...so 
what to do?  no problem- we chilled and watched the stars come out and 
wished we had some food...

so we figured that we would be there for about another three hours, when 
what to our eyes appears other than a rad happy group of ravers loading 
there equipment into a big orange bus.  I think they were sent from 
heaven, as one of them drove us all the way to our front door step while 
the big happy orange bus followed us.

All I've got to say- is thanks you guys, I hope you read this and I will 
always remember you!!  


jess

:)

Subject: [NRR] FUNNY!!!Advice on upgrading to Wife 1.0 (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.ULT.3.93.970325113633.27062B-100000@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is soooo funny!

Advice on upgrading to Wife 1.0

Last year a friend of mine upgraded GirlFriend 6.0 to Wife 1.0 and
found that it's a memory hog leaving very little system resources for
other applications. He is only now noticing that Wife 1.0 also is
spawning Child-Processes which are further consuming valuable
resources.

No mention of this particular phenomena was included in the
product brochure or the documentation, though other users have
informed him that this is to be expected due to the nature of the
application. Not only that, Wife 1.0 installs itself such that it is
always launched at system initialization where it can monitor all
other system activity. He's finding that some applications such as
PokerNight 10.3, BeerBash 2.5, and PubNight 7.0 are no longer able to
run, crashing the system when selected (even though they always worked
fine before). At installation, Wife 1.0 automatically installs
undesired Plug-Ins such as MotherInLaw 55.8 and BrotherInLaw Beta
release. As a consequence system performance seems to diminish with
each passing day.

Some features he'd like to see in the upcoming wife 2.0:

 - A "Don't remind me again" button
 - Minimize button
 - An install shield feature that allows Wife 2.0 to
   be installed with the option to uninstall at anytime without
   the loss of cache and other system resources.
 - An option to run the network driver in promiscuous mode which would
   allow the systems hardware probe feature to have greater use.

I myself decided to avoid all of the headaches associated with Wife
1.0 by sticking with Girlfriend 2.0. Even here, however, I found many
problems. Apparently you cannot install Girlfriend 2.0 on top of
Girlfriend 1.0. You must uninstall Girlfriend 1.0 first. Other users
say this is a long standing bug which I should have been aware of.
Apparently the versions of Girlfriend have conflicts over shared use
of the  I/O port. You think they would have fixed such a stupid bug by
now.  To make matters worse, The uninstall program for Girlfriend 1.0
doesn't work very well leaving undesirable traces of the application
in the system.

Another annoying problem -- all versions of Girlfriend continually
popup annoying messages about the advantages of upgrading to Wife 1.0

*****  BUG WARNING  ********
Wife 1.0 has an undocumented bug. If you try to install Mistress 1.1
before uninstalling Wife 1.0, Wife 1.0 will delete MSMoney files
before executing a self - uninstallation. Then Mistress 1.1 will
refuse to install, claiming insufficient system resources.

*** BUG WORK-AROUNDS ***************
To avoid the above bug, try installing Mistress 1.1 on a different
system and never run any file transfer applications such as Laplink
6.0. Also, beware of similar shareware applications that have been
known to carry viruses that may affect Wife 1.0.


Another solution would be to run Mistress 1.0 via a UseNet provider
under an anonymous name. Here again, beware of the viruses which can
accidentally be downloaded from the UseNet.



----------------- End Forwarded Message -----------------

The Many Shades of Boogie:

PLUR

That's what its all about .... And the bass room thumping hard hitting
soul shaking thump thump thump rhythm pace trance journey begins...

...Djs spinning, mixing away with their jog jog jog jog jog jog of their head
and body to the bass hits rhythm, use the fader there, bring it
in oh so slowly..here it is, got it in synch now...this is going to be phat
now here it is drop it in on em!  Yeeeaaaah!!! The crowd around
you jumps in release!  14 counts to go, fade it out, bring it back in...
red herring? Or is it amphetamine!  Feel the surgE
see the EnErgy around you.. feel the community of yeahs
and screams to the dj to go go go... do you hear it? can you
feel it coming? The bass is coming... only 4 hours left tonite
the party goes on...

...to your right, a pair of glowsticks chasing each other in the hands
of a ravechild spinning her web of glowstick wizardry and imagination
spinning twirling streaking their tracks of light and your
trance is green motion stops mesmerized at the light show
the crowd surges in energy... a steady thump thump trancelike
voice screams on 1 and 3, its Christopher Lawrence taking over
starting his set of all sets just for you..the wavEs of goosebumps rush over
your arms and your hair stands on end..and the clapping 
the clapping and the yeah yeah roar of the crowd. Smiles everywhere
people crying in joy and sensory overload.. 2,000 people its
too good to believe!  This is the 3am set-the energy is raw, electric, 
static,  gotta drink water yeah gotta drink water drink it down, 
offer it with outstretched hands to the people around you, pats on 
your back, hugs here and here and the dancing rages onward, pressing on into the
bass hits that make our night...

whistles are everywhere, someone is whistling on 2 and 4...screech
screech can you hear the voices in the corners of the room, yelling
to the rhythm thump thump thump the bass still carries you,
it will sustain you, the people will keep you going.. drink more water
drink it down, Christopher Lawrence is throwing some new vinyl on... dragging
the edge of the Technics 1200 to slow it down every so slightly...
wonder what its going to be?  The red light on the turntable is so
rad...he's bringing it in now ...wow unbelievable!  Dance harder,
dance faster, look deep into the bass focus to see what its all about... someone
grabs you, points to the sky ..its the comet! Its dancing too, streaking 
speeding across the dark universe spreading its vibe...its tail is vibrant,
its fire and beauty fired by the energy of the dancers below, motion stops,
your trance is the comet, its next set isn't going to be until 2450 AD!!
Incomprehensible....a trance song now, hugs everywhere, some 
children handing out candy oh it tastes so sweet, the energy is rising,
the bass is starting again softly, you know whats coming next... the whump
whump whump builds and it drops in as the crowd surges with screams and
arms waiving in the air you know that you've found where you belong......

See you all at DUNE III..

"May your 5 o'clock set never end"

Geoff

Date: 25 Mar 1997 11:47:00 -0800
From: Leslie Ayres <Leslie.Ayres@ncal.kaiperm.org>
To: Sfraves@hyperreal.com (Return requested)
Subject: Re: Gay/Lesbian Ravers
MIME-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Very interesting topic Nancy has brought up.  About a year ago, we had a similar
thread, but from a gay man (a very good friend of mine) who wanted to encourage 
people to invite more gay people into the scene who belong with "us" (there I go 
again!) rather than in the fairly harsh world of the gay club scene.

When I first started going out dancing, about 5 years ago (my god, how time flies).. 
I mostly went to gay clubs, because I have lots of very close gay male friends, and
I wanted to be somewhere where people treated me like a person, and didn't hit on
me (I was just coming out of a marriage).  That scene became my life in many ways
(but not in the harsh ways, which, though I hate to generalize, include too much crystal
and a lot of shallow promiscuity).

Then I discovered raving, and felt at home immediately ... but I know it wouldn't have
been that way if it weren't for spending so much time in the gay clubs (I'll admit, I still
sometimes go to Universe just for nostalgia... as do some of you, cuz I've seen you
there!  ;^)   ...............

Many of my closest friends are gay or bi ravers... but there is a definite difference in 
behavior at a party than when we're at a gay club ... there is still some self-censorship
that you have to be aware of, especially at parties with a more "thug" vibe. 

When my friends are kissing or whatever, I keep an eye out for those homophobic people
who might react to their behavior, because I've had one friend get sucker-punched
on a dance floor at Spundae's ... and his nose was broken in 8 places.   It's too bad
when you have to watch your back like that.

In chill spaces, though, and at underground parties, I don't recall ever having any
problems.  Of course, the sexuality is different at a party than a club ... it's much less
cruisy (i.e. I like you, you like me, let's go home together) at parties ... and more sensual
and caring in emphasis.   

The one thing I love about ravers is that bisexuality is so widely accepted.  I hope that
someday, in the world at large eventually, but first in our own world ... that we get to the
point that we are all free to be who we are, and we don't have to worry about other
people's acceptance of that.

I do notice, though, (and sometimes worry a little about) is that there is a feeling of
asexuality with lots of ravers.  It may have to do with age groups, it may have to do with
drug usage, or it may just be the kinds of people who are attracted to the scene.

But if that more nonsexual or asexual or omnisexual feeling is part of what makes our  
parties so comfortable, then I respect and appreciate its contribution to the vibe.

My nickel's worth on this one...
Leslie

Geez, Tony...

Here I am thinking we're making this great new society, getting rid of all the
stupid, nonproductive, limiting stereotypes of behavior based on someone's
idea of what you;re "supposed to do and be" ...... and then you post this
crazy assed middle America thing, and I feel like crying and whacking you on
the head (which I would do if you were here in person) ....

but unfortunately, I was also laughing ... geez, it's hard to be politically correct
when you're laughing like that ... (which means I couldn't have whacked you
very hard, what with ROTFLOL and all)....

but next time... can you post the Husband/Boyfriend version, and then the Gay/
Lesbian/Bisexual version as well?  How about the Mormon version? and the
Celibate version?   If you're gonna be sexist, as least be politically correct!

.... please no flames, I'm having a very weird day ... as Tony apparently is too...

Leslie    ;^)

>From what I can tell, and for myself, Raving is really an individual
experience that has little to do with sexual preference. It's about
dancing and feeling good, not about who you have sex with.

I think too many people run their lives by their sexual preference and
think that this is all they are. There is a lot more to a person then
this. 

I don't know about you, but since I got into the scene I feel more
comfortable expressing my feeling towards people of the same sex and
making physical contact (hugging, etc..). When we're raised we're taught
that it's "gay" to hung another guy or do certain things. This is all
B.S. This is why it's so much harder for people to come out. Our society
is so afraid of differences and when we should all be celebrating our
diversity.

Well, back to work.

:-)

Byroni

Where do you all work anyways? I work for Farallon in Alameda, in
Technical Support.

i have an observation:  i see a lot of girls (ahem, i mean, women) kissing
eachother at raves.  many of them consider themselves "straight".
women generally seem more inclined to be affectionate with eachother.
men seem much more homophobic-- like even a hug for a lot of non-ravers
and certainly a kiss even in the rave scene would be a negative reflection
on their sexuality.   i almost never see guys kissing eachother at raves.
it's too bad, really, 'cuz i think it's more a reflection of their hangups
than of their sexuality.


love,

brian

At 11:07 AM 3/25/97 -0800, you wrote:
>
>Although I like to think that everyone is welcome in our scene, that 
>people can express themselves how and with whoever they like, I've been 
>wondering just how hospitable the rave scene really is to gay and lesbian

I've seen a decent amount of same-sex snugglebunny romance at raves.
Certainly more than I've seen any Van Halen concert (and believe me...).  
I've never seen anyone hootin' or hollerin' about gayness at parties...but I
reckon it's a matter of where people doing the snuggling feel more
comfortable doing it...on the floor at Club Universe, or at a party where
the gay population is less than 99%.

Let's not forget where this scene originated...in the black clubs & the gay
clubs.   I'm sure there's a folk or two on the list who would supply us with
a complete archive of dance music history.  :o)

A few more thoughts...

As I was sitting eating lunch just now, I realized another
difference between our parties and clubs in general -- but 
even more specifically gay clubs.

We go to parties to see our friends and dance.  Very few people
(in their right mind anyway  ;^) go to parties to meet someone
in order to either a) start a relationship or b) find a sexual
partner.  

Ravers aren't out there looking for sexual partners as part
of the party experience.  

In gay clubs, that's different.  In the gay social world, 
cruising is a fact of life.  When you go out, you are looking
at people and being looked at.  And the standards of sexual
activity and partners are much looser then in your average 
straight world.  In a gay club, you are pretty much either 
cruising or being cruised... heck, that's one of the things
I like about gay clubs, I get to look at all the beautiful men
with my gay male friends, and people are pretty overt about it.
(of course for me, it's mostly window shopping!  but I have made
some of my greatest friends at gay clubs)

Plus, many gay people usually live some aspect of their
lives as a lie in some way, not showing the affection they want
to their lovers, not always knowing if the person they're talking
to is also gay, and therefore a possible lover ... watching what
they say at work, etc.  When you live your outside life like that,
you want to totally be free to express yourself when in safe
territory like a club that is specifically gay. 

To me, that explains the freedom of expression that you feel
when you're in that kind of place ... it's freer than cruisy
straight clubs, and sexier than parties where the music and the
dancing is what brought us together.

Frankly, I like places where there are more mixed clubs ... Seattle
is pretty good for clubs where there's a little of everything...
that's the way I like it best!

Leslie

Brian Denny wrote:

> men seem much more homophobic-- like even a hug for a lot of non-ravers
> and certainly a kiss even in the rave scene would be a negative reflection
> on their sexuality.

Actually, while I've never kissed a man, when I would be at a rave and
partaking, and if I was talking to a guy who was also partaking, I liked
to run my fingers through their hair.  It's just a warm, affectionate,
non-sexual gesture that I enjoyed and that they always seemed to enjoy. 
I'd tell them that if it bugged them I'd stop, but they never minded it,
and after a while I'd bop back out on the dance floor.

On the flip side, it was a matter of what seemed appropriate and
acceptable at the time, and the crowd and feel of raves has changed much
in the past few months.  What got me so incredibly immersed in raving
was the people and the openness that I felt, the complete lack of
barriers, the total acceptance and love (*there's* an overused word,
albeit appropo) that I felt there, and this sort of physical attention
was very in keeping with the tone of the parties I frequented.

S

Hello all,

I consider myself a human male.  I love kissing other attractive humans.  I 
personally feel that kissing is a very sensual experience, and I love to do 
it.  If the situation presents itself, and I am attracted to someone, we 
will kiss.  I have kissed a man before, and I would say that I would do it 
again if the situation was right.  It matters very little what the sex of 
the person I'm attracted to is.  I really don't care if they are 
straight/gay/male/female/transgender/etc... only the level of attraction, 
and the occasion are important.

My personal prefrences are my own, someday perhaps I will be with men, but 
for now, it seems that I'm not.  Fine, whatever, I must only keep an open 
mind to whatever situations reveal themselves to me, and handle them the 
best way I can at that time.

As far as this list goes, it seems that we are all mature about how we deal 
with others' sexuality and their preferences.  Besides, hugging and kissing 
is fun no matter who it's with right?

I agree with these posts, that although we are mostly open to new things, we 
are not entirely open to them.  I have said in the past that our scene is 
culturally, racially, (and sexually) diverse, etc... I still feel that the 
intent is there, but until _everyone_ feels comfortable at raves, I suppose 
I cannot claim that we are 100% diverse.  Compared to many other gatherings 
of people for the love of a musical genre, I strongly believe that raving 
represents some of the most positive and open minded thinking that can be 
found.  There is still more that we can do in regards to this though.

Thanks for listening.

Smiles,

Scott =)

Concerning this issue of homosexuality at the Rave scene is a bit misleading
in my opinion.  First of all, I have only been apart of the scene since
February 14 and what I have observed while attending these incredible
exhibits of PLUR is nothing but acceptance.  I have read several other
responses to the question of homosexuality and most of them seem to be
leaning toward the negative.  Well, I prefer to examine the positive aspect
of the subject at hand. 

As a gay raver and as an active participant in displaying same-sex affection,
I have discovered several things.  1)  There are certain people who no matter
what setting they are in or what chemical is present in their body, seem to
still have hang-ups about sexuality.  This is not a bad thing because it can
be changed through vicarious learning.  We have to give them a chance.  2)
 Many guys that I have offered kisses of  love have been very receptive and
even enjoyed the experience.  And 3)  Homosexual activity is not condemned at
Raves and most people seem to be able to do whatever they want to do with
whomever they want to do it with.  

Therefore, Raves seem to be a good place to display one's sexuality no matter
what that may be.  I appreciate the atmosphere and all the love I have been
able to feel during the six Raves I have attended.  Plus I love all the
people I have met but may not remember due to "brain overload."  I look
forward to seeing all of you again.  

PLUR and keep the openness available,
Derrick

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I don't know how I can possibly explain our weekend any further than Stariana 
and Lara already did!  Even the 14 hour drive down was fun, especially we 
stopped for dance breaks every 2 hours.  Star's beachouse is AMAZING!!!  I 
finally met Hadrian (Hi sweetie!), and finally threw away the icky tension that 
kept Lara & me from bonding (I love you Lara!).  We hit Venice beach before the 
rave and had tons o' fun even though it was cloudy.  And Hadrian & I ran across 
a little "rave stand" on the strip that sold glo-in-the-dark beads, neon (aka 
blacklight) nailpolish, and awesome unlabeled mixtapes for $5.  We bought a tape
called "Funky Beat Volume 1".  No track names or DJ's, but it's the best tape 
I've ever owned in my life!  Tiny bad things: Brett's van got broken into and we
cracked the cylinder heads from way too much driving way too fast (Brett:  I'll 
help you pay for the engine!  I'm sorry!), and Perry & Ryan and I had our 
conflicts (Wwhatever I did, I'm sorry boys! I still love you!)  Many 
thanks to Hadrian & Ryan for helping find to messed-up kids who needed 
love and bringing them into the tent.  Fernando: the world is filled with love! 
 Big up and much love to Marty, Usa, and Fina...Happy Kids love forever!  See 
you Saturday...

Peace & Much Love,
christine

      ~~Rave-med tent words of wisdom: 
         "If we don't take care of each other,
                   who will take care of us?"~~

I forgot!!! The people who really made the party were Marisol for drawing a big 
happy sun in my rave book, Sara for being the only person to ask if I wanted a 
bracelet (It changes color in the sun and had 'e' beads on it!), Scott for being
so happy when I said "yes, I'm giving away free hugs!", Jimmy for being so happy
we rescued him, Jesti for calling me to tell me she was okay, and John for being
the only person in Laguna Beach to talk to us and NOT think we were weird for 
dancing on the street corner.  I think that's it.  Much love to all who were 
there, all who wanted to be there, and all who were with us in spirit.  Thank 
you for making my first road trip happeee!

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Overall I would say that raves are quite accepting of same-sex
affection and sexuality.  I have noticed two drawbacks to expressing
sexual/physcial affection toward someone of my same gender at raves:
	(1)  There seems to be a group of males who have a genetically
instilled fantasy about two women being together sexually.  Whenever I'm
making out with someone who is also female, these males seem to feel
compelled to try to come over and "join in."  I have no problem with
people desiring to join the group I am part of because they find me or
someone else there an interesting and compelling human being.  I do have
a problem with feeling like that person is primarily interested in me/us
because I'm/we're "bisexual babes making it with another chick."
(Somehow this topic makes me fall into swinger lingo.  Don't ask me
why.)  Now, I'm not saying this is an attitude most men share, and
probably the proportion of raver males who act this way is even smaller
than the population in general, but nonetheless, it exists.
	(2)  My other problem is that there are a lot of people who E-xperiment
with people of their own gender at raves.  Some of them seem to have the
attitude "Well, it's okay if I make out with you as long as there's a
boy here too.  That means I'm not really gay."  That attitude really
annoys me.

Does anyone else find these to be true for them?

I haven't actually thought of labeling myself as 'Gay' in the rave scene. I
remember,
the first rave I went to, my first E, my first everything... I was all over
the place telling everyone: "Hi, I'm gay, is that ok?" now when I think
about it, I laugh. I don't think is nescesary anymore to
be asking wether is ok or not to be friends or to talk to someone even if
you are gay. I guess,
some guyz would go "hey man, I'm not gay.." or something like that if I was
to give them a hug (which happens in the non-rave world non-gay-world) but
I haven;t experienced that in the rave scene, nor have I seen it happening.

>From what I can see, the rave scene is very open minded torwards, sexual
orientation, race,
color, ethnicity, etc. The best thing to do is to be who you are and share
the best of  you with everyone. Don't separate yourself from anyone just
because you are different.

Oh well..my 3 cents :)
love and hugs
Pab

----------
> From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
> Subject: Gay/Lesbian Ravers
> Date: Tuesday, March 25, 1997 7:07 PM
> 
> 
> Although I like to think that everyone is welcome in our scene, that 
> people can express themselves how and with whoever they like, I've been 
> wondering just how hospitable the rave scene really is to gay and lesbian

> (etc.!) ravers.
> 
> I've seen male couples, and women together in the chill room (though 
> sometimes I think a lot of this is just e-experimentation!), but going to

> a gay/lesbian club recently got me to thinking...
> 
> At this dance club, in the heart of the Castro, people were truly free.  
> There was so much handholding, lapsitting, joyful embracing and sweet, 
> passionate couples... As though relationships were imbued with that much 
> more intensity, because here, finally, was a place couples could show how

> they felt for each other.  And I realized that I, as a (well, relatively)

> straight woman, had only _thought_ I knew what a comfortable scene was
for a 
> gay/lesbian person - and the rave scene suddenly looks as straight and 
> uninviting as any other scene in this "hetero" world.

Hey robin, didn't know you were on sfrave! :)

Anyway, I totally know what you're talking about, I remember being at a
party one time with this sort of a situation, only to look up to find a guy
looking greedily down at us saying "Hey, uh, can I get in on this?"  I've
encountered this more than once.  I can't stand enjoying an experience with
people, to find someone who "wants to get in on the action," like we're in
an open-invite orgy or something.  C'mon people!  I've also had the
experience of kissing a woman, only to look up (once again) to find us being
stared at intently by some male who "digs it when chicks kiss".  I am *not*
here to put on a show, it's not like I'm having sex in the chill room!  I
simply love naturally connecting with people on this level, if that's the
connection that occurs, I've taken amazing (non-sexual) journeys with them
some of those times. :)


Love
Shawna

From: bri@value.net (Brian Denny)
Subject: unwanted spectators (was Re: Gay/Lesbian Ravers
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>
><<  I've also had the
> experience of kissing a woman, only to look up (once again) to find us being
> stared at intently by some male who "digs it when chicks kiss".  I am *not*
> here to put on a show, it's not like I'm having sex in the chill room! >>
>
>first, i think it's beautiful to see any kind of love, second, if it bothers
>you to be watched, then maybe you should chose somewhere other than the chill
>room?

yes, i thing being self-conscious while in a chill room is a bit
self-defeating...

on the other hand, when someone directs a "predatory" attitude at your
loving vibe, it can make you uncomfortable.

i suppose a better question would be, "how do you deal with a situation
like that?"

you could:

a) ignore him
b) tell him to buzz off
c) invite him to join you
d) explain nicely that you are expressing your basic love for eachother as
friends, and it's not just a purely physical act to be shared with a
perfect stranger. (or however it is that you feel about it)

now, i think most of the time people choose (a), sometimes (b).  but i
think, assuming you don't want to do (c), that (d) is the way to go.  after
all, if you have a problem with the way Mr. Eyes is behaving, the only way
he's going to become aware of that and (possibly) change his behavior is if
someone explains it to him.  and if not you, who?

also:

haven't we all been in the position of feeling unloved and
affection-deprived?  a lot of guys mask underlying self-esteem issues by
acting as sexual predators.
if you at least introduce yourself, be friendly, and explain how you feel,
you are showing him a kind of respect, which he needs.  ignoring him or
being unfriendly simply feeds the problem.

finally, imagine the following scenario:

i'm sitting in a chill room, kissing a loved male friend, only to look up
and find myself being intently watched by some female who "digs it when
guys kiss".

will it ever happen?  i don't know.  but i don't imagine i'd be bothered.

we do have a lot of dysfunctional gender roles in society.  at issue here
are: (a) men are socialized to view women as the passive gender, and to be
sexually agressive with them
(b) some people react to self-esteem issues by acting with a false (and
imposing) self-assuredness
(c) women are socialized to perceive male sexuality as a potential threat
(which, unfortunately, it sometimes is)

these problems are not going to go away until we break through the
underlying issues.  until we teach men and women to think of eachother as
equals.  until people don't need to prey on others in order to feel good
about themselves.

this starts with _you_.  show respect and communicate with people, even --
no, _especially_ -- the people who are acting in ways you find bothersome.

love,

brian


ps      i speak of the "unwanted spectator" as a male in this post because
that's the way it usually is.  to all those concerned with the sexist use
of pronouns, i in no way intend to imply that the role-reversed scenario is
impossible.

From: Jonathan Dejano@SEPL on 03/26/97 10:06 AM

On 25 Mar 1997, @11:52 pm, you wrote:

>>I am interested the most in Daft Punk- Can somebody shed light on them?<<

...this is straight out of the liner notes on the WIPEOUT XL cd from
astralwerks (records)...

"Packing a kick meaty enough to put Cantona in the shade, French duo DAFT
PUNK prove Paris is ready to rock with the best of them and, no doubt, wear
a better class trousers while it does so.  Tracks like "Da Funk" and
"Musique" cause truckloads of havoc every time they blare from speakers,
those within earshot being left with few sensible options except to dance
like turbo-charged stick insects... erm, yes, we thought we'd better warn
you about that."

...the track "Musique" off the WIPEOUT cd is my first ever exposure to DAFT
PUNK and i thought it was a pretty humble track in its own right...sounds
kinda like electro-house...minimal...early Detroit techno sound...also i've
heard that their new album (i think it's called "Da Funk", but don't take
my word for it) is supposed to be pretty good...i guess you'll just have to
see them yourself and make your own judgement...i know i'll be there on
Saturday...

d0u8l3 J;)

Jondabomb@aol.com wrote:

> I think we are all Bi-sexual. Some choose not to act upon it while others do.

I beg to differ.  If there were ever a forum where one could define
one's true sexuality, this is probably it, and I can honestly say that I
am not bi-sexual.  I am 100% hetero and very comfortable that way. 
That's not to say that I'm not curious as to what it must be like, but I
have many times tested my feelings towards another man and I have never
found myself attracted sexually.

So while I'm glad for you that you are comfortable expressing your
sexuality, I don't share your particular tastes.

No offense, my friend, but I find your generalization to be similar to
men that think lesbians are women that just haven't had a good male
lover yet.

phat hugz,

S

Is it possible to be funny while still being "p.c."?  So much of American 
humor is at expense of people or utilizing stereotypes - the challenge is 
making people laugh without resorting to these "easy" laughs.  It's 
cultural - look at British humor, for example, so much physical slapstick 
and comedies of "manners."  And Americans don't get it, by and large!

Earlier this year, the dazed crew of a Japanese Trawler was plucked out of
the Sea of Japan clinging to the wreckage of their sunken ship. 

Their rescue, however, was followed by immediate imprisonment once
authorities questioned the sailors on their ship's loss.  To a man they
claimed that a cow, falling out of a clear blue sky, had struck the
trawler amidships, shattering it's hull and sinking the vessel within
minutes. 

They remained in prison for several weeks, until the Russian Air Force
reluctantly informed Japanese authorities that the crew of one of its
cargo planes had apparently stolen a cow wandering at the edge of a
Siberian airfield, forced the cow into the plane's hold and hastily taken
off for home. 

Unprepared for live cargo, the Russian crew was ill-equipped to manage a
now rampaging cow within its hold.  To save the aircraft and themselves,
they shoved the animal out of the cargo hold as they crossed the Sea of
Japan at an altitude of 30,000 feet. 


 <   giles@bowkett.com : www.bowkett.com                        \ /     >

 <                                                               (      >
 <                                                                O     >

From: Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com>

> everyone's bi.

        I disagree. Everyone certainly has the potential to engage in
        bisexual acts, but not everyone is inclined to do so under normal
        conditions (like when members both sexes are available).

        Are *you* bisexual? Find out for yourself with my patented test
        for checking your own sexual orientation! All rights reserved.

        No hands allowed! Fantasize about having sex with an attractive member
        of the opposite sex. Give it a decent 5 or 10 minutes at least. Get
        into it.

        Question 1 (boys) > Are you hard?	Yes or no?
                  (girls) > Are you wet?	Yes or no?

        No hands allowed! Fantasize about having sex with an attractive member
        of the same sex. Give it a decent 5 or 10 minutes at least. Get
        into it.

        Question 2 (boys) > Are you hard?	Yes or no?
                  (girls) > Are you wet?	Yes or no?

        If you answer yes to question 1, no to question 2, you are straight.
        If you answer no to question 1, yes to question 2, you are gay.
        If you answer yes to both, you are bi.

	If you answer no to both either you are asexual, 
	you didn't give it enough time,
	or you should go on to part 3 :

        No hands allowed! Fantasize about having sex with an attractive gray
        alien of indeterminate sexuality. Give it a decent 5 or 10 minutes at least. 
	Get into it...

[ to sfraves ]
Recently,  Rob Rayle <robertr@autodesk.com> proposed a test for sexual 
orientation:

>         Are *you* bisexual? Find out for yourself with my patented test
>         for checking your own sexual orientation! All rights reserved.
> 
>         No hands allowed! Fantasize about having sex with an attractive member
>         of the opposite sex. Give it a decent 5 or 10 minutes at least. Get
>         into it.
> 
>         Question 1 (boys) > Are you hard?	Yes or no?
>                   (girls) > Are you wet?	Yes or no?
> 
>         No hands allowed! Fantasize about having sex with an attractive member
>         of the same sex. Give it a decent 5 or 10 minutes at least. Get
>         into it.
> 
>         Question 2 (boys) > Are you hard?	Yes or no?
>                   (girls) > Are you wet?	Yes or no?
> 
>         If you answer yes to question 1, no to question 2, you are straight.
>         If you answer no to question 1, yes to question 2, you are gay.
>         If you answer yes to both, you are bi.
> 
> 	If you answer no to both either you are asexual, 
> 	you didn't give it enough time,
> 	or you should go on to part 3 :
> 
 Here's my variation on Rob's test 
   - everywhere it says "fantasize about having sex with" , replace with  
     "fantasize being married for the rest of your life to".
   - Replace "Are you hard?"/"Are you wet?" with "Are you blissed out?"

 Ten minute fantasy sex is easy ... An imagined lifetime of marriage is
harder ( and sometimes more humid as well ... :-)  ).

 Larry "Old Match Maker" Ching / larryc@netcom.com

I beg to differ w/Todd's differing with Jondabomb's statement that we
are all bisexual in some way...

SDream's paragraph was...

I beg to differ.  If there were ever a forum where one could define
one's true sexuality, this is probably it, and I can honestly say that I
am not bi-sexual.  I am 100% hetero and very comfortable that way. 
That's not to say that I'm not curious as to what it must be like, but I
have many times tested my feelings towards another man and I have never
found myself attracted sexually.


I believe that 99% of us are bisexual in some way .... to me, having curiosity and testing feelings
towards someone of the same sex, is a small percentage of bisexuality, at least it's an
openness to the possibility, and to do that you have to think about it.  

I have one friend who swears he's 100% gay ... and yet, he's had sex with women in his younger years,
and admitted that a certain kind of woman, in a certain situation, might interest him even today.

So maybe you are two examples of the people at the far end of the spectrum... that is, maybe
you're 99.9% straight, he's 99.9% gay ... and that .1% of experimentation comes in those thoughts
that go through your head occasionally.    Others might truly be 50/50 in their thoughts and
their actions, and some may be 90% one with just a 10% dabble in the other.

Remember Jimmy Carter, admitting that he lusted in his heart, even though he was married?
You don't have to act on your feelings to have them be a part of who you are.

Leslie
(can you all tell that I'm bored?  My job is coming to an end, so my days are spent tying up
loose ends and writing emails!   So write me now before i lose contact on Friday!)

One of the most amazing things about SFRaves is how we all keep _talking_. 
The thing is really just one long conversation, with posts that turn into
threads that spawn other threads and on and on into infinity.  The
conversation never stops.  There's never an awkward pause, a silence
indicating the conversation is over.  No-one ever has to say, "someone
think of something to say!" 

It's the longest dinner table conversation in history.  500 blabbermouths 
seated at the table for five years now, and we haven't shut up yet!

On Wed, 26 Mar 1997, Nancy Shaw wrote:

> 
> Is it possible to be funny while still being "p.c."?  So much of American 
> humor is at expense of people or utilizing stereotypes - the challenge is 
> making people laugh without resorting to these "easy" laughs.  It's 
> cultural - look at British humor, for example, so much physical slapstick 
> and comedies of "manners."  And Americans don't get it, by and large!
> 
> 
> 
I wasn't saying that it's not possible to be both funny and p.c. at the
same time but being in America much of the jokes/funny things I hear isn't
p.c. so I just take it for what it's worth. A long running example would
be a joke between a buddy of mine and me (PLEASE NO FLAMES ON THIS WE BOTH
SAID THIS IN JEST), regarding how it would be really screwed up if either
of us told our girlfriends that they were just a "in-the-meanwhile girl";
both of us love our girlfriends very much but we find it funny to say
something neither of us would even seriously think about doing. I also
like some british humor that I have seen on the television. I feel life is
too short so I enjoy it for what it's worth!

And Leslie I don't think you are a cranky ***** momma the post was
actually directed at people who felt offended by the humor post.

At 11:22 AM -0800 3/26/97, Leslie Ayres wrote:
>I beg to differ w/Todd's differing with Jondabomb's statement that we
>are all bisexual in some way...
>
>SDream's paragraph was...
>
>I beg to differ.  If there were ever a forum where one could define
>one's true sexuality, this is probably it, and I can honestly say that I
>am not bi-sexual.  I am 100% hetero and very comfortable that way.
>That's not to say that I'm not curious as to what it must be like, but I
>have many times tested my feelings towards another man and I have never
>found myself attracted sexually.
>
>
>I believe that 99% of us are bisexual in some way .... to me, having
>curiosity and testing feelings
>towards someone of the same sex, is a small percentage of bisexuality, at
>least it's an
>openness to the possibility, and to do that you have to think about it.
>

I differ 100% from Leslie in this regard.  I think people are what they
are.  Some people may have bi-sexual tendencies, but there are those of us
who are 100% heterosexual.  Just because one has a homosexual experience
does not mean that they are bi-sexual, IMO.  As for being open to the
possibility?  I am not, thus I do not have any inclination toward the same
sex.  I do however think that some men are handsome, but once again, I
don't think that the appreciation of beauty can ,in any way, denote one's
sexuality. The only thing it could possibly reflect is my taste or
aesthetic.

>I have one friend who swears he's 100% gay ... and yet, he's had sex with
>women in his younger years,
>and admitted that a certain kind of woman, in a certain situation, might
>interest him even today.

Then he *may be* bi-sexual.  But there are men who have had sex with other
men at some time in thier lives, and would say that the experience would
never be repeated.  Does that make them a closet bi?  I doubt it.  Same for
some women I know who became lesbians over time; after some soul-searching
of course.

I think a lot of this is hype from the non-het community, in an effort,
mostly political, to convince people they are something they are not.

I have met bi men and women, and just like thier heterosexual and
homosexual counterparts they have had these feelings from birth.  For
whatever reason, I think people know what they like and who they like it
from/to.  Yes, some may be 100% bi, some 100% homosexual, but let's not opt
out of the 100% hetero category, one which applies to me, and I'm sure
plenty of others.

>
>So maybe you are two examples of the people at the far end of the
>spectrum... that is, maybe
>you're 99.9% straight, he's 99.9% gay ... and that .1% of experimentation
>comes in those thoughts
>that go through your head occasionally.    Others might truly be 50/50 in
>their thoughts and
>their actions, and some may be 90% one with just a 10% dabble in the other.

Interesting, although I think we are more of the norm than anything (if
there is such a thing).  I think that people know what they are and we are
the 65% who know where we stand, be it straight, bi, or homosexual.

Or it could very well be that the people who think we are on the fringe
could be on the fringe themselves thinking that some memebrs of the
population are not what they say they are.  I mean, when did it become a
crime to be proud to be straight.  Sheeit, I love being straight, as much
as any homosexual man loves his sexuality, as much as anyone identifies
with thier sexuality.

This is all political to my eyes.

>
>Remember Jimmy Carter, admitting that he lusted in his heart, even though
>he was married?

Does that mean he cheated?

>You don't have to act on your feelings to have them be a part of who you are.

So he really is an adulterer because he thought it?  And people could be
murderers because they think but dont act on it?  How many real murderes
are there?  Then the question arises, are we what we think or how we act?
What are we if our actions are different than thought?  then of course the
final question arises Who are we?

See here's the problem, and I think it stems from religion to some extent.
To me, thinking something is nott the same as acting on it.  If I have
recurring fantasies about sleeping with men, that could mean many things.
If I act on it, and it is a part of who I am and I also enjoy the company
of women, that is another thing.  Thinking and acting on things, to me, are
two seperate things.

But, diff strokes for diff folx...I guess.  Since this society is so
sexually repressive, I don't think we will ever get an accurate reading as
to who's who and what's what. I think that about some % is straight, some
homosexual, some bi, and a portion of the population thinks about these
options in some form but don't act.  Actual figures will vary depending
upon factors such as politics, agenda, culture of the respondent,  openess
to ones inner truth, the statistician, bias, and a number of other factors.

The world may never know.

Your honor, I rest my case.

Peace,
John



The year 2000 approaches...have you had your wheaties?

Leslie Ayres wrote:
> 
> I beg to differ w/Todd's differing with Jondabomb's statement that we
> are all bisexual in some way...

I beg to differ with your differing with my differing...

As I stated:
> I am 100% hetero and very comfortable that way.
> That's not to say that I'm not curious as to what it must be like, but I
> have many times tested my feelings towards another man and I have never
> found myself attracted sexually.

I would be so lenient in my definition that I would allow that one's
sexual preferences can be defined by one's desires as opposed to one's
actions.  Since I would still maintain that at no time have I ever been
sexually attracted to another man, by that definition, I am still 100%
hetero.  

Like it matters.  I'd hug anyone regardless of their position in that
spectrum of degrees between full hetero- and full homosexuality, and I
would expect the same love and respect back regardless of my position.

Y'know, for those who are reading this and thinking, "Ok, this has
wandered completely outside the realm of what I was looking for when I
joined this list," my apologies.  I love Leslie to pieces and couldn't
resist that first line.

Anyway, curiosity does not define a person.  I'm curious what it would
be like to live in Japan, but that in no degree makes me Japanese.

> (can you all tell that I'm bored?  My job is coming to an end, so my days are spent tying up
> loose ends and writing emails!   So write me now before i lose contact on Friday!)

Yeah, me too, but it's because I've got too much work to do and it's all
tedious and irritating.  I needed a break.

wet smooches to you Leslie,

S

place closes at 2 (and I spin first, at 10!) ... hope to see you all
there!


Peace

Jonathan




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 26 14:04:19 1997
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) id OAA25066; Wed, 26 Mar 1997 14:04:19 -0800 (PST)
Received: from value.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id OAA25050; Wed, 26 Mar 1997 14:04:15 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [206.14.138.18] (k18.value.net [206.14.138.18]) by value.net (8.8.4/8.7.3) with SMTP id OAA13945 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 26 Mar 1997 14:04:10 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v02130501af5f49ecd2d7@[206.14.138.18]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-mailer: Eudora Pro 2.1.3
Date: Wed, 26 Mar 1997 14:07:47 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: bri@value.net (Brian Denny)
Subject: Sexual Orientations NRR (was Re: Gyas/Lesbians
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


sexual orientation is a fluid and wholly individually-defined thing which
resists strict categorization.

"gay", "straight", and "bisexual" have as much to do with social
self-identification and personal politics as they do with sexual activities
and preferences.

i, too, believe that people are not born heterosexual, homosexual, or
bisexual, just sexual.

but as far as i'm concerned, people who think of themselves as straight,
are, by definition, straight, and so on.

it's much too complicated for objective tests.  none of us has any right to
tell someone else that they are a different sexual orientation than what
they consider themselves, because self-identity is the only test that can't
be argued with.

of course, some of us don't like labels and can never figure out _how_ we
identify ourselves... the fact that i don't consider myself gay or straight
doesn't necessarily mean that i consider myself bi, either.

just some food for thought,

brian

From: Steve Simitzis <steve@saturn5.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: a request :)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Greetings. I was wondering if people posting to SFRaves (especially
party promoters) could avoid using things like colors and bold print
in their email messages. Many of us use text-only mail readers (like
on a UNIX account) or have mail programs that don't support text
layout like underlining, etc.

For example, 

<color><param>6666,3333,0000</param>********</color>
<bold><color><param>FFFF,0000,0000</param>KING</color></bold><color><param>F=
=46FF,0000,0000</param>
</color><color><param>6666,3333,0000</param> ****</color>
 
may look like bold print and colors to you, but to me, it only comes
out looking like control characters. It just makes things very very
hard to read, because sometimes the information is buried beneath all
of the control characters and stuff.

Thanks! :)

Steve

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Mar 26 15:04:37 1997

Date: Wed, 26 Mar 1997 15:07:59 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <199703262307.PAA24651@atari.saturn5.com>
From: Steve Simitzis <steve@saturn5.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: steve goes gothing
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I thought I'd take the plunge, and check out another scene last
night. My girlfriend, who is very much into the gothic scene, finally
convinced me to go with her last night to Roderick's Chamber, a small
weekly gothic/industrial event held on Tuesday nights.

She had invited me to go many times before, but I had always worried
that I wouldn't have such a good time. Well, I knew I'd like the music
(Even though I've been raving for a good 5 or 6 years now, I've always
listened to a lot of gloomy industrial)... But being a raver, I sort
of had this notion that goths go to clubs and leer at each other all
night. And I certainly knew I'd be underdressed for the event (not
owning any black PVC pants or leather boots).

But I went anyway (I found something black I could wear). And I had a
great time, so I thought I'd share my impressions of a scene that is
usually thought to be 180 degrees opposite to our rave scene.

Things I saw:
1) People greeting friends with hugs.
2) People respecting the space.
3) Friends meeting, laughing.
4) People dancing to music they love.
5) Smiles.
6) People (both men and women) looking beautiful
7) People who could dance, and make it look like an art.
8) A well tuned sound system.
9) Beautiful handmade Victorian(?) era clothing.

Things I didn't see:
1) Bad attitudes.
2) Taggers.
3) Gangstas taking way to much space with breakdancing (please, no flames).
4) Teenage kids fucked up on weird drugs.
5) Dirty dancing.
6) Flyers either shoved in my face or littered on the floor.
7) The DJ. (this was a bit weird)

I met many people I knew that night, danced a little (though, being
used to 180BPM jungle makes it hard to dance to 100BPM gothic), and
had great time. I heard some really good music spun, like Haujobb,
Dead Can Dance, Siouxsie, Sisters of Mercy, some local music, and lots
of other stuff I can't name. 

Visually, there were your typical dance club intelli-beams, but
all-in-all, fairly minimal lighting. There was also a vendor, selling
jewlery and accessories (yes, lots of silver crosses). Most people
dressed in full-on goth gear: lots of PVC, velvet dresses, and white
face powder.

So anyway, that was my gothing experience. Hopefully I'll do it again,
and get to participate rather than observe next time. 

as always, just trying to broaden my horizons. :)

Steve

--

MIME-Version: 1.0

This is so hysterical today, thank you LORD!!  

I am sitting -- smiling ear to ear -- reading about Todd's being 100% sure
he's 100% straight (dude, you're the one who knows!),
and John responding to me talking about Jimmy Carter lusting in
his heart ... and Brian kissing Ran or DeepFog at some orgy party
that people are probably  gonna save their money so they can make
sure not to miss out on advance tickets..  or everyone kissing whoever the hell
he/she wants (long as it doesn't go too far in the chill space, dudes!)
and someone I think said I'm a lesbian (which I'm not, not that
it matters to anyone!) and Mr nStuff thinking the whole world is waiting
to watch him making out in a chill room ....

And I get this picture in my head ...  of a 14-year-old newbie raver
who's just come onto the list, or a newcomer who wants to learn about
our scene, and these topics are just about as far from their reality as 
you could possibly get...

and their eyes are getting wider and wider ...  

and I'll know who they are when I meet them at a party sometime, cuz
they'll be afraid of being seen talking to me, and that wide-eyed, oh
 my god look will come back when we're introduced...

and thank you all, it's making my day!!!!

And.. best of all, I am seeing what to me is the best of SFRaves, which
is many perspectives and experiences, talking and sharing about things
that really do matter in our lives ... and no one is being mean or petty (at
least publicly!) .... and I'll miss you all so much when I lose my email
on Friday!  Oh well... 

;^)

Leslie

Steve Simitzis wrote:
> 
> I thought I'd take the plunge, and check out another scene last
> night. My girlfriend, who is very much into the gothic scene, finally
> convinced me to go with her last night to Roderick's Chamber, a small
> weekly gothic/industrial event held on Tuesday nights.
> 
> She had invited me to go many times before, but I had always worried
> that I wouldn't have such a good time. Well, I knew I'd like the music
> (Even though I've been raving for a good 5 or 6 years now, I've always
> listened to a lot of gloomy industrial)... But being a raver, I sort
> of had this notion that goths go to clubs and leer at each other all
> night. And I certainly knew I'd be underdressed for the event (not
> owning any black PVC pants or leather boots).
> 
> But I went anyway (I found something black I could wear). And I had a
> great time, so I thought I'd share my impressions of a scene that is
> usually thought to be 180 degrees opposite to our rave scene.
> 
> Things I saw:
> 1) People greeting friends with hugs.
> 2) People respecting the space.
> 3) Friends meeting, laughing.
> 4) People dancing to music they love.
> 5) Smiles.
> 6) People (both men and women) looking beautiful
> 7) People who could dance, and make it look like an art.
> 8) A well tuned sound system.
> 9) Beautiful handmade Victorian(?) era clothing.
> 
> Things I didn't see:
> 1) Bad attitudes.
> 2) Taggers.
> 3) Gangstas taking way to much space with breakdancing (please, no flames).
> 4) Teenage kids fucked up on weird drugs.
> 5) Dirty dancing.
> 6) Flyers either shoved in my face or littered on the floor.
> 7) The DJ. (this was a bit weird)
> 
> I met many people I knew that night, danced a little (though, being
> used to 180BPM jungle makes it hard to dance to 100BPM gothic), and
> had great time. I heard some really good music spun, like Haujobb,
> Dead Can Dance, Siouxsie, Sisters of Mercy, some local music, and lots
> of other stuff I can't name.
> 
> Visually, there were your typical dance club intelli-beams, but
> all-in-all, fairly minimal lighting. There was also a vendor, selling
> jewlery and accessories (yes, lots of silver crosses). Most people
> dressed in full-on goth gear: lots of PVC, velvet dresses, and white
> face powder.
> 
> So anyway, that was my gothing experience. Hopefully I'll do it again,
> and get to participate rather than observe next time.
> 
> as always, just trying to broaden my horizons. :)


ha he,

I've to Roderick's, too, about 3 or 4 times, and always had a good time.
Steve, better than Man Ray, eh?  Which is where you probably where you
got the preconcieved notion on how goths would be.  It's really
different out here than back east, isn't it?  The last time I went to
Man Ray, they moved Chris Ewen, who is still the DJ, up and away and
above the middle bar in the big room where you A. can't see him, B.
can't get up there.  Check out Labyrinth, which is Fridays at Maritime
Hall, I think.  The same smiling goths go there, too.  The best thing
about S.F. goths is that they love to make fun of the themselves and the
fact that they are gothic.  Cool crowd.  Lots of ravers used to be
goths. Like me, you remember the D.D.T. days.......

check out this URL, it would make the pastiest goth crack a huge smile!
http://www.scenario.com/eric/goth/index2.html

Sorry that I "replied to all" but I think that the list would appreciate
the fact that you are not alone.

Thank you to Steve on behalf of all us UNIX users!  Although I would like
to read these messages, I always delete because swimming through all the
font language gives me a headache. 




On Wed, 26 Mar 1997, Steve Simitzis wrote:

> 
> Greetings. I was wondering if people posting to SFRaves (especially
> party promoters) could avoid using things like colors and bold print
> in their email messages. Many of us use text-only mail readers (like
> on a UNIX account) or have mail programs that don't support text
> layout like underlining, etc.
> 
> For example, 
> 
> <color><param>6666,3333,0000</param>********</color>
> <bold><color><param>FFFF,0000,0000</param>KING</color></bold><color><param>F=
> =46FF,0000,0000</param>
> </color><color><param>6666,3333,0000</param> ****</color>
>  
> may look like bold print and colors to you, but to me, it only comes
> out looking like control characters. It just makes things very very
> hard to read, because sometimes the information is buried beneath all
> of the control characters and stuff.
> 
> Thanks! :)
> 
> Steve
> 
> --

In my previous post I talked a lot about same sex love and Rave openness, but
I failed to mention that I also believe that it is okay for gay people to
kiss and hug people of the opposite sex.  It only promotes and expresses the
complete freedom that is present during a Rave.  Yes, I am gay and I kiss
girls at Raves and I have no problem doing it.  The real issue here is not
homosexual activity at Raves but instead, all the forms of "affection through
connection" no matter who you are, what your preference, or who you are
connecting with.

PLUR,
Derrick

> <<  I've also had the
>  experience of kissing a woman, only to look up (once again) to find us being
>  stared at intently by some male who "digs it when chicks kiss".  I am *not*
>  here to put on a show, it's not like I'm having sex in the chill room! >>
> 
> first, i think it's beautiful to see any kind of love, second, if it bothers
> you to be watched, then maybe you should chose somewhere other than the chill
> room?

I wouldn't presume to speak for Shawna, but for my own part it is not so
much someone watching me as they way they are watching.  There is a look
that is admiring and benign and then there is a look that is predatory,
demanding.  I think females tend to be more sensitive to this
distinction.  When you are walking down a street there will (likely) be
people who think you are attractive.  Some of them will look at you in
an admiring and harmless way and some with look at you with a gaze that
invasive, insistent even when you have given body signals that you are
not interested.  I think some of the problem arises because some males
(some people in general) are just really bad at reading body signals and
don't know they are not wanted unless someone says it to their face.

Jondabomb@aol.com wrote:
> 
> I think we are all Bi-sexual.


We are all pansexual, omnisexual.  As Freud so elegantly put it,
polymorphously perverse.  I don't know if you know who Annie Sprinkle
is, but I was reading something where she was telling about the time she
had an orgasm from making love with the sky.  She says she makes love
with everything -- stars, wind, sun.  It is society that narrows our
sexuality -- directs it first toward solely other humans, then solely
the opposite gender (then often times only to people of your race,
nationality, religion, etc).

Amy R Starkey wrote:
> 

> Okay, so what about this sitation:  In all honesty, it is a sort of
> fanasy of mine to make out with another female as my boyfriend watches
> and maybe hers too. Of course I would be totally enjoying her attentions,
> but part of the excitement is knowing I am also turning on the man I
> love!  I think that if all parties involved know what is going on and is
> consentual about it, "watching two chicks kiss" can be quite erotic and
> sometimes it can be equally erotic to be the one putting on the show.

I don't think anyone has any problem with consensual situations.  Now,
the person who made the original complaint about this situation will
make the following confessions:  _I_ get turned on "watching two chicks
make out."  I get turned on watching two boys kiss.  I get turned on
watching most anyone who is reasonably attractive kiss. (Does that about
cover it?  Does _anything_ not turn me on?)  BUT I make it a point not
to watch people kiss in an invasive way, to not watch if they are giving
off signals that they do not want to be watched, and I certainly
wouldn't presume to try to join their scene just because I like it when
two (or three or four or. . .) chicks (or boys or whatever. . .) kiss
(or whatever :)

robin

> closet exhibitionist,

Oh dear.  Here's that bisexual discussion again.  How can you be het if
you are "enjoying her attentions"?  Yes, you mention that much of your
pleasure comes from being an exhibitionist, but not all. . .

Steve Simitzis wrote:
> 
> 
> Becoming sexually aroused by objects or concepts is a consequence of
> being overly wrapped up in one's masturbatory fantasies. I think
> nature is beautiful, but equating that with sexuality is not correct.
> 
> One cannot make love with the sky. The sky does not feel. Imagining
> that the sky is making love back to you is masturbation, plain and
> simple.
> 

I think the point is to recognize that sexual
feelings/thoughts/experiences can be generated in you by interaction
with _anything_ not just other human beings.  First, let me say that
some people might disagree with the sky not being able to make love back
with you.  I am not one of them, but some people would say that the sky
does have a spirit.  Having said that, I agree with you that the sky
(probably) can't feel.  So it is masturbation if you define masturbation
as having sex in a situation where you do not have a partner that is
also feeling sexual feelings.  Of course, calling it masturbation does
not diminish the feeling.  Unfortunately I have not reached a level of
sexual advancement :) where I can fuck the sky, but I would suspect that
people who have experienced it would say it is a vastly different
experience that applying friction to your clitoris (or whatever
equipment you got) with a hand.

Subject: Re: NRR: (sorry) bi or not??
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>well, because I could not imagine myself doing anything more than *JUST*
>kissing someone of the same gender, I consider myself fully
>heterosexual.  I think it was Brian Denny who mentioned that you could
>still be considered hetro even if you find yourself making out with
>someone of the same gender one evening.  To do anything more with a girl
>gives me the hee-bee-gee-bees. ;)

actually, my idea is that you are straight if you think of yourself as
straight, no matter who you have sex with.  so yes, you can kiss your
female friends (or whatever) and still call yourself heterosexual.

it's not a matter of _what you do_, it's a matter of _who you identify
yourself with_, or, more fundamentally, _who you are, according to you_.

i choose not to call myself straight, gay, or bi, because each of those
terms identifies me with a group of people of relatively homogeneous
preferences (in society's eyes, at least), and my feelings are often vague
and fickle.

your feelings are more clear.  you are not attracted to women, except
perhaps to a verly limited extent under very limited circumstances.  to
you, this makes you heterosexual.  and that's all that matters.

love,

brian

> 
> 
> On Wed, 26 Mar 1997, Steve Simitzis wrote:
> 
> > 
> > Greetings. I was wondering if people posting to SFRaves (especially
> > party promoters) could avoid using things like colors and bold print
> > in their email messages. Many of us use text-only mail readers (like
> > on a UNIX account) or have mail programs that don't support text
> > layout like underlining, etc.
> > 
> > For example, 
> > 
> > <color><param>6666,3333,0000</param>********</color>
> > 
<bold><color><param>FFFF,0000,0000</param>KING</color></bold><color><param>F=
> > =46FF,0000,0000</param>
> > </color><color><param>6666,3333,0000</param> ****</color>
> >  
> > may look like bold print and colors to you, but to me, it only comes
> > out looking like control characters. It just makes things very very
> > hard to read, because sometimes the information is buried beneath all
> > of the control characters and stuff.
> > 
> > Thanks! :)

Received: from 207.33.94.197 (a197.value.net [207.33.94.197]) by value.net (8.8.4/8.7.3) with SMTP id TAA16829; Wed, 26 Mar 1997 19:10:20 -0800 (PST)

MIME-Version: 1.0
To: Brian Denny <bri@value.net>
CC: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink.csus.edu>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: NRR: (sorry) bi or not??
References: <v02130501af5f8cea9004@[206.14.138.20]>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> 
> your feelings are more clear.  you are not attracted to women, except
> perhaps to a verly limited extent under very limited circumstances.  to
> you, this makes you heterosexual.  and that's all that matters.

	I'm not sure I agree that your own definintion is all that matters.  I
think it is important to consider other people's definintions of us
because it can help us see ourselves more clearly and think about
ourselves in different ways.  While I support Amy's right to label
herself in any way she chooses, I also think that it is important for
her to understand that there are people who would consider her bi under
their definitions.  Some people would say that being able to experience
any sexual/romantic feelings toward someone of your own gender makes you
at least bi.  
	Then there is another problem here: if all that matters is calling
yourself what you want by your definintion, then language loses all
meaning.  It tells me nothing.  If a girl chooses to call herself
heterosexual but has been in a long-standing relationship with a female,
it is obvious that we have radically different definitions of the word
"heterosexual."  We might as well be speaking different languages.  Now
let me make it clear that I am not necessarily against the
deconstruction of language -- it's just going to make that communication
thing a bit harder. I'm also definitely not for the Kinsey het-bi-gay
continuum, but it is currently all we have to communicate our identities
with.

konnichiwa everybody,
well, i will start with the rr stuff. i was in san francisco today and i
went into buffalo exchange and some guy asked me if a was a raver
(actually, more precisely, an l.a. raver) and he wanted to know where he
could find some good parties for tomorrow and friday night. as i know
nothing, i told him i would find out here. if anybody would care to e-mail
me back and tell me of anything interesting that would be marvelous. 
please and tank jou!!!

soooo pretty that i started to cry and i wanted to share.
okay, here ya go:

				a lover's dream
		as i sit and stare at the shimmering moon
		i also sit here and hope to see you soon
	 	then i realized i won't be able to see you tomorrow
		so i would sit here and cry in sorrow
		now i only uphold a dream which i hope comes true
		and that one dream is to be with you.

bye everyone, have a lovely wednesday evening! sweet dreams tonight!
***stariana***

Subject: Re: Sexual Orientations NRR (was Re: Gyas/Lesbians
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>sexual orientation is a fluid and wholly individually-defined thing which
>resists strict categorization.

<snip>

>of course, some of us don't like labels and can never figure out _how_ we
>identify ourselves... the fact that i don't consider myself gay or straight
>doesn't necessarily mean that i consider myself bi, either.


I definitely find this to be a fluid thing, that shifts as time moves on,
according to how I feel at the time.  I don't think I could accurately call
myself just straight, just bi, or just lesbian (I could never be that, I
dig men too much! :).  There have been time when I've felt straight-up (no
pun intended) bisexual with no difference in interest between the two
sexes, and times when I've felt totally 100% straight where like Amy, I get
no sexual rise from the thought of women at all even if I still express
affection & friendship with women by kissing them.  It all seems to ebb &
flow, and really not confine itself to any particular definition found in
the dictionary.

I also don't necessarily believe that you are born one way or another
without exception, I think now that it can certainly evolve that way (and I
dont mean a situation where you turn lesbian after being fucked over by one
too many guys) as situations present themselves to you where you can make
new discoveries.  Like "Wow, I never thought about this kind of thing
before, but now that it's happening, it's pretty damn cool!"  This has been
the case for me, and a certain portion of it has had to do with me
questioning the reasons I feel certain ways to begin with.  Like did I
consider myself 100% hetero because I truly had no sexual interest in
females, or because I assumed I was hetero because I knew most people were
(according to what we've been told) and never thought to think otherwise?
I'm finding the latter to be more true, among other things, I'm happy to
say.  And of course, I've always had an appreciation for beautiful women,
as I have an appreciation for all things beautiful, which is just not
sexual.  There's just some people I want to have gilded & hung on my wall! ;)


Love
Shawna

What follows are actual statements found on insurance forms where car drivers
attempted to summarize the details of an accident in the fewest words possible.

______

Coming home, I drove into the wrong house and collided with a tree I don't have.

The other car collided with mine without giving warning of its intentions.

I thought my window was down, but I found out it was up when I put my head
through it.

I collided with a stationary truck coming the other way.

A truck backed through my windshield into my wife's face.

A pedestrian hit me and went under my car.

The guy was all over the road and I had to swerve a number of times before I hit
him.

I pulled away from the side of the road, glanced at my mother-in-law and headed
over the embankment.

In my attempt to kill a fly I drove into a telephone pole.

I had been driving for forty years when I fell asleep at the wheel and had
an accident.

As I approached the intersection a sign suddenly appeared where no stop sign
had ever appeared before.

My car was legally parked as it backed into the other car.

An invisible car came out of nowhere, struck my car and vanished.

I told the police that I was not injured but on removing my hat, found
that I had fractured my skull.

The pedestrian had no idea which direction to run, so I ran over him.

I saw a slow moving, sad faced old gentleman as he bounced off the roof
of my car.

I was thrown from my car as it left the road.  I was later found in a ditch
by some stray cows.

On Wed, 26 Mar 1997, ivan d. weiss wrote:

> aw hell, it's funny......half the humor I hear these days isn't P.C. 
> laugh if you think it's funny, delete it if you don't like it
> 
> this message was brought to you by ME all opinions contained within this
> message are not the legal responsibility(sp??) of ME, and this public
> message in no way shape or form is or resembles a flame..........just a thought
> 
> thank you for this bandwidth now erase the message so it can go back into
> the universe =)
> 

We've gotten to this precarious position where if we complain about a joke
we are labeled P.C.  But, what if that joke really offends us?  Do we then
shut up and accept it just because someone else thinks it's funny?  It
saddens me to see any minority movement/voice being squelched by such a
backlash.  It only serves to put said movement/voice back in its place
where it belongs i.e. the minority.  So, I think it's sad when someone
says such-and-such joke offends them (and in a nice way at that), only to 
be told, "Like it or leave it."  Maybe those of us who find the joke funny
might want to try harder to understand why the other side
*doesn't* find the joke funny.  I'd certainly be willing to explain why I
didn't find the joke funny and how it relates to my life. 


Thanks,
Kirsten

Date: Wed, 26 Mar 1997 23:25:59 -0800

From: bri@value.net (Brian Denny)
Subject: Re: NRR: (sorry) bi or not??
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Robin wrote:

>        I'm not sure I agree that your own definintion is all that matters.  I
>think it is important to consider other people's definintions of us
>because it can help us see ourselves more clearly and think about
>ourselves in different ways.  While I support Amy's right to label
>herself in any way she chooses, I also think that it is important for
>her to understand that there are people who would consider her bi under
>their definitions.  Some people would say that being able to experience
>any sexual/romantic feelings toward someone of your own gender makes you
>at least bi.

i agree that it's important to understand how other people will perceive
one's labels.  many people don't understand the variety of possible sexual
preferences.  most people assume, if you call yourself "straight", that you
only have physical interactions with people of the opposite sex.  and to
some people, kissing members of the same sex makes one bisexual.  but i
think it's important that we try to make these people aware that not
everyone has the same definitions, and ultimately it's up to the individual
to decide how he/she wants to label themselves.

i personally do not call myself straight, i don't call myself gay, and i
don't usually call myself bisexual, precisely because of the preconceptions
people have about what those terms mean.  i prefer to go unlabeled.  if
someone asks me, i may say i'm bisexual, if i think the person i'm talking
to has a sufficiently broad definition of the term.  otherwise i say "i'm
go-with-the-flow", "i'm just sexual", or i try to explain how i feel about
the shortcomings of such labels.


love,

brian

hello, sorry to waste your time (again) but, oh, i simply must share with
all of you lovely people one more poem that my dear friend christina has
written.
this is called MOONSTAR:
	starlight starbright
	twinkle upon me so that i might
	grasp onto this dream that i create tonight
	may i be swallowed by the sky, a beginning with no end
	a translucent universe silent with no resistance to pretend
	let me play among the shadows, dance through the depths of peace
	swirling pools of innocence, smiling waters never cease
	a shining star i hold onto floating inside my dream
	reaching perils of vast existence to others, it might seem.


goodnight...

>considering getting out the old button maker and making up a few "Kiss Me

you need to print up buttons that say "kiss me if you're a girl...", "kiss
me if you're a guy...", "kiss me if you're an alien...", and "it doesn't

anyway, and i promise i won't try to get you into bed."  but who would
believe that one?

that's right, i'm not joking, i'm posing yet another thought-provoking
question: does "i'm on E" automatically makes a person more innocent and
trustworthy?
why is it that sober people tend to get left out of the love-puddles?  is
it because _they_ are less uninhibited and _they_ feel out of place, or is
it because other people assume that if you're sober you must have ulterior
motives?

discuss.
