From: 	Jonathan Santos[SMTP:jsantos@dnai.com]
Sent: 	Thursday, March 13, 1997 2:48 PM
To: 	sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: 	Re: The Scene Is Dead?

>Bull Shit!
>The scene is completly alive! We are all living proof. The fact that
>sfravers are so incredbily nice and lovable. SF is highly regarded on
>the west coast as being the best. LA ravers would die for an SF Rave. I
>went to OZ in LA. Everyone was saying how wonderful it was that an
>actual SF raver wnated to rave in LA. They all wanted to come up here,
>they kept telling us.

Well..  For some people, the scene dies all the time.. Then it just
comes back alive again.  It's all relative.  Everybody goes through
the typical rave stages.

1  Wow, everything is soo cool and positive.  I like the fancy lights
and popsicles.

2.  I'm starting to meet everyone... I love you all.

3.  Now its time to make hats and sell them, become a dj, or start 
promoting.

4.  Now youre sick of it.. The scene is dead..everyone is shady..  You 
start
talking shit.

5.  It's been a year and a half and you've found new light in the scene

6. You're back.

And the cycle keeps repeating itself.  Its so easy to get burnt out.. Isnt 
it?

>The scene is not dead. The scene may be falling, but that's as far as it
>will ever go. True, it is falling, but it will NEVER hit bottom. We have
>such a positive energey here in the underground portion of the rave
>scene. A lot of massives may be lost to commercialization, but the
>underground knows whats up!

What are you talking about?  Massives.. Commercialization.. same thing.
But who ever said commercialism was bad?  Every raver takes part in
their own "commercial" economy.  If you've paid money to get into a rave,
you've taken part in some form of commercialism.

I guess its just annoying to see my 'secret society' become the 11 oclock 
news,
and a new marketing scheme for Virgin.. But whatever..IT's good to see hard
working artists finally get what they deserve.  God bless em...

>I don't know about you, but I still have some faith in the scene. It may
>be total crap now to some people. It may be falling. We can look at the
>positive side of the scene falling!
>
>What's so positive about the scene falling?

Then we can just go bowling or to the movies on Saturday.

>VIBE FILTERING!
>
>Hopefully the scene will just blow up, and at the end we will see who
>the people that are left standing are,

Promoters.. With fat cash falling out of their pockets.
Dj's.. With silver shiny coats and space age sunglasses

> and we can all start anew in a
>better way. A more secret way. A even more underground way!

I don't think there is such a thing as underground anymore.
Which reminds me.. SOme one remarked about Godfather at the last
one track mind and said he was playing shit that you hear on the radio.
I said...  Oh really.

>Once the scene goes overboard where (like in England) raves are illegal,
>it will filter out all the bad vibes. Massives will be just as massive,
>yet the flyers will be smaller or it may be word of mouth. COOL WORLD
>will be forced to make smaller flyers (magazines) if they want to make
>any money. Locations will get better and promoters will really really
>really start to keep it underground.

Oh.. Cool World.  Weren't they the ones that put a commercial on the radio?
And how can locations get better?  What we need to do is get the
government to subsidize raving..  You know.. It heals cancer and all that..

>I can't wait for that to happen. It will better our scene so much.
>And I will be there in the new scene with everyone else.

New scene.. Old scene.. It's all the same scene.
You know whats scary.. WHen you start singing a Smiths song
at a rave and the person next to you finishes the next verse.

Anyway, I hope I didn't offend anyone.  If you don't know me, I'm generally 
sarcastic- but not jaded.  I still love going out when I can...

-Jon

Hi all!

On Thu, 27 Mar 1997, Brian Denny wrote:

[much snippage]


> why is it that sober people tend to get left out of the love-puddles?  is
> it because _they_ are less uninhibited and _they_ feel out of place, or is
> it because other people assume that if you're sober you must have ulterior
> motives?

 Well I had the distinct pleasure of being invited to a church party 
recently (the valentine one). I went very sober and ended up in (to no 
surprise) in the ambient room. I napped a couple hours there and woke 
about 3 AM (missed Deaks set damnit!).

 As I was sitting there waking up I was wishing there was someone there I 
knew so I could get in a people pile (oh man I love those things!) In 
about 5 minutes StarChild walks in, comes right up to me and starts 
chatting. Next comes Will Penna and pretty soon we are all just flopped 
together like one big warm friendly bean bag chair. It was wonderful! And 
I was dead sober.

hugz,

------- Blind-Carbon-Copy

To: Willard.McCarty@kcl.ac.uk
Cc: groovi-internet@netcom.com
Subject: NRR Re: BRITS: Wise to Wired and Death on Libraries (fwd)
Date: Thu, 27 Mar 97 08:21:08 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom18>


Willard -- I think you hit the nail right through the saviour's hand on
this one. I've been thinking about Wired (US) in exactly the same way
ever since they sold out to the major US media conglomerates (e.g.
Time/Warner). (This happened around the time that most of my
friends&acquaintances left Wired for other careers, so it's not like
i'm dissing my friends.) Fortunately, you were able to sum up the
problems with Wired in a much more poingnant fashion than I. I see
Wired as being the computer-wanker's version of Playboy magazine,
wowing us with the digerati's version of the silicone breast implant,
and making us long for the day when we could have the cohones and cash
to have a bit of digital perfection implanted in our own bodies, or at
least humming nearby as we plug-in to download the latest groupthink.
As if we should denigrate/ignore the results of millions of years of
evolution and heap praises on the shoddy engineering that got squeezed
in between cappucino's and marketing meetings at Intel and Microsoft. 

Actually, the comparison to Playboy is a bit unfair, since, beyond the
airbrushing, implants and exploits, that magazine has at least had some
groundgreaking reportage on issues of freedom/politics/repression in
our society. Wired, meanwhile has this sick attitude that the  benefits
of the crypto-libertarian utopia should be bestowed only upon those
Wired enough to be on the invite-list for all the cool corporate/media
parties at big national computer conferences... everyone else can rot.

That's why I'd rather be "Tired" than "Wired". It's good toilet
reading, or airplane-reading for when I'm too braindead from business
travel to read something with real content. It would be wonderful if
there was a "humanist" centered version of Wired -- an "Utne Reader"
for the digitally inclined.

I personally get a lot more out of reading the Communications of the
ACM, ACM SIGCHI, ACM SIGGRAPH,  or IEEE Computer or even Byte. This is
where the real futurism lies. At least those magazines/journals have
the substance and rigor to *TEACH* the populace about the cutting edge,
rather than just namedropping and constantly reminding us about how
lowly and falling-behind we are compared to the inner-circle of
really-cool/hip people that comprise Wired and it's wankerati
following.

- ------- Forwarded Message

>               Humanist Discussion Group, Vol. 10, No. 812.
>     Center for Electronic Texts in the Humanities (Princeton/Rutgers)
>       Centre for Computing in the Humanities, King's College London
>         Information at http://www.princeton.edu/~mccarty/humanist/
>   [1]   From:    Willard McCarty <Willard.McCarty@kcl.ac.uk>         (70)
>         Subject: demise of Wired U.K., closing of British libraries
> 
> Two interlinked news items.
> 
> Residents of N. America may not be aware that the British version of the
> high-tech monthly, <cite>Wired</cite>, has been discontinued. In the
> Guardian for 12/2/97, Douglas Rushkoff, "Beware faulty wiring", goes into
> the failure of Wired in the U.K., noting that its death "marks more than the
> rejection of a rightwing libertarian agenda. It also shows... that British
> readers would not be intimidated."
> 
> "A propaganda effort that has proved quite effective on both the business
> and the hi-tech communities of the US, Wired's Ventures' strategy of
> coercion through a combination of hype and intimidation just didn't work on
> Britain's digital enthusiasts, who were already poised to resist what they
> see as rampant cultural imperialism from American media conglomerates."
> 
> Rushkoff argues that the rejection of Wired "is a rejection of a brand of
> media more coercive than it is informative.... 'Wired used buzzwords and
> catchphrases that only insiders would understand,' one Londoner explained.
> 'The magazine made it clear that there are insiders and outsiders.' Or, as a
> young British hacker e-mailed me on hearing the news, 'They tried to tell us
> how to think, so we told them to f--- off.'
> 
> "While the British Internet community might be a more sceptical, even
> paranoid audience than America's. their perceptions of the agendas
> underlying Wired's invasion of UK media space are not entirely inaccurate.
> The increasingly common opinion in the magazine's hometown of San Francisco
> is that Wired was never more than an elaborate public-relations strategy....
> Wired might best be understood more as the outgrowth of a branch of social
> theory and control than of the techno-utopianism with which it is so often
> associated.... The loose association of editors and experts under Wired's
> masthead consisted mostly of people who were either already, or soon to
> become, associated with the Global Business Network, a first-class menu of
> futurist business and technology advisors including Kevin Kelly, John
> Barlow, [Nicholas] Negroponte, and many of the other digiterati who have
> appeared on Wired magazine's covers....
> 
> "Futurism has aleays been an act of will; those who give advice are
> naturally going to promote themselves as the exclusive purveyors of secreted
> wisdom. But when a magazine represents itself as journalism yet actually
> serves almost as the newsletter and promotional arm of a consulting firm
> with a particular agenda, something is amiss, and eventually its readers
> will catch on...."
> 
> Rushkoff does admit to liking a lot of what Wired has to offer -- the
> writings of Louis Rossetto in particular -- rather he objects to its
> manipulation of readers "into a state of suggestible anxiety, through
> cleverly exploited language and design", and its hidden cultural agenda
> "masquerading as a British effort".
> 
> I for one would be interested to know how our American colleagues have
> viewed Wired. I find myself thinking, however, that we computing humanists
> have some real work to do in the public arena. The promise that we see, the
> good that we know can be done, may quite easily be confused with darker
> purposes of those whose self-interest is anything but enlightened. 
> 
> For example, in the latest Times Literary Supplement (4903, 21/3/97, p. 16)
> Richard West, in "If in doubt, chuck out" writes about the closing of a
> number of British public libraries and the dispersal of their collections --
> e.g., the huge and valuable stock of books in the Stoke Newington Church
> Street Library's reference section, containing Daniel Defoe's books. Citing
> W. J. West's booklet, <cite>The Strange Rise of Semi-literate England: The
> dissolution of the libraries (Duckworth, 1991), Richard West notes that, "In
> the seven years since he wrote his study, W. J. West has seen the advance of
> the computer, which has become the main enemy of the public library and the
> reading habit itself." I find that a difficult sentence to swallow, but at
> the same time there's all too much idiocy, even sometimes within our
> institutions of higher learning, about the replacement of books by
> electronic media. If books are going to be replaced anyhow, why keep them?
> The British Council's plan to close its lending library in Athens has been
> stopped by a concerned group of citizens, but note that the Council figured
> on replacing it with a "high-powered information centre". Can we now read
> such promotional phrases without a shiver?
> 
> Comments?
> 
> WM
> 
> - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

> defending my heritage...  unix is a bit beleaguered right now...

i don't think Unix is -- most internet servers are Unix, and a growing
number of desktops as well (especially outside the US)... i'm happily
running Red Hat Linux 4.1 and it rocks. In fact, I have an SGI indy
sitting right next to this PC and I'm preferring Linux running on this
pentium laptop to my SGI, which cost twice as much, requires twice the
memory, and isn't much faster. The other reason why I like Linux is
because I don't have to stand-on-my-head and stick my foot in my
bunghole in order to get secure internet connectivity on the Linux box,
and everything pretty much works and isn't buggy (meanwhile, any bozo
can crack an unfirewalled SGI on the internet) ... Irix is incredibly
braindamaged in comparison to this free OS (course Irix does rule over
Solaris). 

Goes to show you -- if you want quality -- make your software free and
public. Sell support and packaging and enhancements.

I completely agree with Brian.

One or several same-sex experiences does not _make_ a straight person gay
or bi.  Who you are _primarily_ is what matters.  Many people experiment a
few times, but consider themselves straight overall.  I think it actually 
belittles other sexual orientations to equate a make-out session one 
night to a lifetime commitment and desire to be with people of the same sex.
It's primary identification that matters.

I'm straight, and I've been with women a few times.  I just think of it as
being an open-minded and sensual person!  I'm not interested in having a
girlfriend.  I'm not bi, because I can't imagine having a girlfriend for a 
while, and then maybe having a boyfriend.   I wouldn't presume to be part of 
the gay/bi community or experience just because I've enjoyed a sexual 
treat from time to time.  Because your orientation is not about a few 
sexual thrills.  It's who you are on the deepest level.

N 



On Wed, 26 Mar 1997, Brian Denny wrote:

> >well, because I could not imagine myself doing anything more than *JUST*
> >kissing someone of the same gender, I consider myself fully
> >heterosexual.  I think it was Brian Denny who mentioned that you could
> >still be considered hetro even if you find yourself making out with
> >someone of the same gender one evening.  To do anything more with a girl
> >gives me the hee-bee-gee-bees. ;)
> 
> actually, my idea is that you are straight if you think of yourself as
> straight, no matter who you have sex with.  so yes, you can kiss your
> female friends (or whatever) and still call yourself heterosexual.
> 
> it's not a matter of _what you do_, it's a matter of _who you identify
> yourself with_, or, more fundamentally, _who you are, according to you_.
> 
> i choose not to call myself straight, gay, or bi, because each of those
> terms identifies me with a group of people of relatively homogeneous
> preferences (in society's eyes, at least), and my feelings are often vague
> and fickle.
> 
> your feelings are more clear.  you are not attracted to women, except
> perhaps to a verly limited extent under very limited circumstances.  to
> you, this makes you heterosexual.  and that's all that matters.
> 
> love,
> 
> brian
> 
> 
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Mar 27 10:34:58 1997

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Epiglottal@aol.com
Date: Thu, 27 Mar 1997 02:47:24 -0500 (EST)
To: SFRaves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Long goodbyes to San Francisco.

WARNING: This is long, emotional, metaphysical (like all my posts).


"The more I get connected, the more I stand apart."

Does anyone else feel this way sometimes?

I'm about to move out of San Francisco, leave all the wonderful (and
frightful) times at the parties, clubs, and cafes of this city.  Recent
parties like Infinitely One, Ohmnisonic, Condensation, and others bring me
great joy for their warmth and vitality.  Thank you so much to their
organizers.

I've always been slow to catch on to what's popular or how I'm supposed to
act.  I just think differently and forget amazingly fast.  But I got
connected here in the San Francisco scene, fell in love quite a bit, and felt
like I was a part of things.  But I don't read Musik, wear imported shoes
with transparent soles, and no matter how much I hang out with
gays/bis/open-ended people I'm always going to be sensitive, male, and very
hetero.  Some stuff I've discovered in the "in" people of this scene really
was very "out" for me, including the blase openness to strange sex, crack
dealers, crystal and K, and closedness to all the big pop names and small
rock bands of back home.  I have the courage to say goodbye now and hello to
more fantastic fun and friends and loves even deeper.

Thank you to San Francisco, my heart and mind will always be here.  The
beautiful hills and the vibrant colors, the hundred bums I gave change to or
walked away from embrarassed or afraid, the Haight kid who offers small,
green buds on Ashbury, the DJ who made patronizing fun of me when he thought
I couldn't hear.  I say goodbye to it all.  I'll come back twice as wise,
with a heart that moves to even deeper beats.  I'll come back both more
material and more spiritual.

I want to say sorry to all the people I've hurt doing the wrong drugs at the
wrong parties.  I'm sorry for the quick goodbies, when I couldn't listen, and
to those pats, hugs, or rubs that were without heart.  But I won't wait for
forgiveness, because all that matters now is that I know that I cry inside
and that I am sincere.

All my goodbyes are really hellos in disguise.  A thousand friends and loves
in the past.  So many people from my past and future would say I am kind so I
will not hear another word about selfishness, disrespect, or the like.  I am
only growing wiser.  We all lay our own path to that eventual reunion, that
wisdom we reach when we die.

After all the Plurism and good vibes have faded, or should you ever forget
that there is astonishing warmth in this world, remember that time is
sometimes the best lover of all.  With time comes wisdom, an embrace so sweet
and mystical, that lovers' cries of ecstasy are lessened in comparison.

I believe in life.  I do.  I believe in giving.  I believe in energy with
peace.  That MDMA, I hope, has opened me up, brought me fresh joys and new
empathies.  I've stayed away from the worst addictions, perhaps out of a
wisdom, karma, or just because I haven't been initiated.  But I know that no
perversity can conquer me, no pleasure is too deep, no pain is more than a
moment when the light is not shining.  I believe in life and I will enter it
ever more the mystic, more entranced, more grounded in practicalities, more
taken with where I will go.  I will take with material greed and give with
spiritual bliss.  I pray not in churches now, but with my hands, my feet, my
music and my pen in the expanses of the city and the country.  And my prayers
are so much more expansive.  They are prayers of love now, not prayers of
guilt.

I am no child now.  My worship of the eternal is not through fear and
coercement but through the love of my body, the passion of time, and the
spirit that breathes through me from a thousand influences around me.  I
worship with something outside of me.  My tenderest soul is inspired by sweet
flutes on High, elegant drums in Nature, human failures and sorrows Within.

"I am but a broken-winged bird, and my flight is very slow."  I repeat these
childhood phrases with warm religious ecstasy, but I mumble the "ohm" that I
learned from my friends, and I curve my hands in a mathematical motion that I
taught myself.  All these things are prayers.  I will say goodbye to nothing
that is warm, but many things that are unkind.  My shameful soul had no way
to love God before.  Perhaps now that I have things to be ashamed of, my love
is deeper.

It may take an acid trip to bring the eye candy into the world, the delicate,
fractal visuals.  But that candy is no longer a thing I fear addiction to,
because I may taste it and I may leave it with little thought.  It may take a
rush of stimulants to remember one's addictions, how easy it is to become
compulsive, bound and broken.  My brain knows cravings.  My body knows waves
of pleasure.  But these pleasures are but a moment in time and I may leave
them.  I know true peace.  I know eternity.  I always have.  And I will never
settle for less than the full relief of my soul's cravings or for less than
being able to give away everything.

Why do I feel like I am just starting to understand things, only now entering
the world?




. . . I'm off to visit the animals of the zoo, and eats lots of fruits and
vegetables in San Diego.  Perhaps I'll do some surfing or get married.  Maybe
I'll write a book.  I'll see there!



Lots of love,

- Justin

Joel Gordon just posted:

>I was at a party in Santa Barbra a few weeks ago.  It was suppposed to
>be mostly an Excellent party and I had yet to partake.  I was dancing
>w/ this girl and we were hugging and having a fun time.  Then she asked
>if I was doing anything.  I said not anEthing and she got this weird
>look on her face and physically backed away.
>Jeez.
>We were having a good time and just because I was not doing anEthing
>she thought I was a creep.
>Part of the reason I do Extra sutff is for physicall contact that I
>don't think I/we get enough of in daily life.
>I would like to let go of physical inhibitions without hElp.
>I don't want to "score" with every person I hug or am affectionate (sp)
>with.

Ok, "fascism" maybe an exaggeration, but it has always bothered me to see
pEoplE say things like, "Oh, you're not on E ... I'm so sorry."  Part of it
must be a  new, everything-is-right-with-the-world that people who start
using a drug are supposed to have (the "honeymoon" period), with the wish
that EveryonE ElsE could ExperiencE it too.  This doesn't just happen to
non-E using people who are hugging.

I think that this scene does lead to more affectionate, friendly physical
contact between people, whether altErEd or not.  Americans don't often hug,
let alone kiss, friends when they meet them or say goodbye, but in other
cultures such behavior is commonplace.  But ravers do, and it feels
natural.

This coercive attitude (peer pressure at raves?) obviously grates on the
"sober" people in our midst, and IMHO is why so many straight-edged ravers
feel the need to justify or explain why they refrain from extracurricular
substances, and sometimes why others should refrain as well.

One of the most important aspects of raving for me is freedom -- freedom to
do what you want, and not to do what you don't want, without hurting
others, without fear of judgment.  (The without hurting others part is why
there is no fear of judgment, and could lead to a more complex discussion
of intent, oversensitivity, etc. which I won't start here).  It cuts all
ways, no matter what you do or don't do.

To paraphrase a catch-phrase from the pretty inane movie "Love Story":

Raving means never having to say sorry ...

(unless you bump into people repeatedly ...)

leftjab

>One of the most important aspects of raving for me is freedom -- freedom to
>do what you want, and not to do what you don't want, without hurting
>others, without fear of judgment.  (The without hurting others part is why
>there is no fear of judgment, and could lead to a more complex discussion
>of intent, oversensitivity, etc. which I won't start here).  It cuts all
>ways, no matter what you do or don't do.

This is _so_important_....  I've heard TOO MANY ravers talk down about
drugs, but I think the worst and probably more common than E-bashing or
sober-bashing (at least in my experience) are the ravers who take E but
talk down about "tweakers" and "speed freaks" that are on speed.

There is an negative attitude that many ravers share that speed has no
place in the rave scene, but E is right at home.  Frankly i think they both
fit equally as well, and can coexist without judgement, but I've seen a lot
of evidence that they don't. 

Basically we don't need straight-edge's bashing drug use, people on E
bashing the sober OR the "tweakers", or anyone saying anything negative
about anyone's drug use (or lack of) in an open, accepting environment that
ravers want the scene to be.

PLURespect

Dave

David King  <flapjack@cats.ucsc.edu>

Last year, my friend upgraded his GirlFriend3.1 to
GirlFriendPlus1.0 (marketing name: Fiancee1.0). Recently he
upgraded Fiancee1.0 to Wife1.0 and it's a memory hogger, has
taken all his space; and Wife1.0 must be running before he can
do anything. Although he didn't ask for them, Wife1.0 came
with Plug-Ins such as MotherInLaw and BrotherInLaw.

Some features I'd like to see in the upcoming GirlFriend4.0...

 - A "Don't remind me again" button

 - Minimize button

 - Shutdown feature

 - An installshield feature so that Girlfriend4.0 can be
   completely uninstalled if so desired (so you don't lose
   cache and other objects)

I tried running Girlfriend 2.0 with Girlfriend 1.0 still
installed, they tried using the same I/O port and conflicted.
Then I tried to uninstall Girlfriend 1.0 but it didn't have an
uninstall program.  I tried to uninstall it by hand, but it put
files in my system directory.  Another thing -- in all versions
of Girlfriend that I've used is that it is totally "object
orientated" and only supports hardware with gold plated contacts.

             *****  BUG WARNING  ********

Wife 1.0 has an undocumented bug. If you try to install Mistress
1.1 before uninstalling Wife 1.0, Wife 1.0 will delete MS Money
files before doing the uninstall itself. Then Mistress 1.1 will
refuse to install, claiming insufficient resources.

  <"00101333ACF4C046*/c=us/admd= /prmd=kaiperm/o=ncal/ou=notes/s=Ayres/g=Leslie/"@MHS>
Date: 27 Mar 1997 11:49:32 -0800
From: Leslie Ayres <Leslie.Ayres@ncal.kaiperm.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (Return requested)
Subject: Re: Drug/Anti-Drug Fascism at Raves
MIME-Version: 1.0
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dave King said....

>There is an negative attitude that many ravers share that speed has no
>place in the rave scene, but E is right at home.  Frankly i think they both
>fit equally as well, and can coexist without judgement, but I've seen a lot
>of evidence that they don't. 


While I appreciate the desire not to be unfairly criticized, and not be be
subjected to double standards.....  (you may have heard this lecture if you
know me!)...

Speed is NOT the same as E .... Sorry, but the reality is that speed RUINS
PEOPLE'S LIVES ON A REGULAR BASIS!!!!  I have had many friends go down to their
use of crystal, and they lied -- to their friends and themselves -- about what
was happening the whole time.  Their bodies shriveled away, they were sick,
they became paranoid and delusional, they spun down and down and down.  

The main difference with E or A or "social-use" substances .. is that they
really are occasionally used, and if used properly, they allow you to develop
into a better person.  I know few people who do E straight through the entire
weekend, but lots of people who use crystal that way.

Yes, I've had a couple of friends become hooked on E, and that scenario became
pretty much like what I've seen with speed.  So it CAN happen, but it's not nearly
as likely an outcome.

I know, I know, you say ... but I only use it sometimes, not that much, just for
this occasion, or that occasion.

*Some* people may be able to occasionally indulge in speed, and not abuse
it, and maybe you're one of those.  You're the only judge, you're the only one
to decide.  But remember.... speed will lie to you, too.  

My rule of thumb about drug decisions ... ask yourself, do people ruin their
lives because of, and through the use of, this drug?  If the answer is an easy
yes (heroin, crystal, crack), then stay away from it... is it worth taking the
risk that your life could be ruined by it too?   If it's a "maybe" (like constant
pot smoking interfering with accomplishing much of anything) then you might want
to reconsider that too.

Coming from a place of love and concern, as well as free choice,

Leslie
aka The Fairy Rave Mother


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Mar 27 12:04:02 1997

> 
> While I appreciate the desire not to be unfairly criticized, and not be be
> subjected to double standards.....  (you may have heard this lecture if you
> know me!)...
> 
> Speed is NOT the same as E .... Sorry, but the reality is that speed RUINS
> PEOPLE'S LIVES ON A REGULAR BASIS!!!!  


But rational and moderate users of the drug are lumped in with hard-core 
addicts.  If you ever do a line you are considered some sort of mangy 
slimeball by people on 4 hits of acid and e every weekend.  Hypocrisy is 
hypocrisy.  There's nothing wrong with powders, used intelligently.

N


I have had many friends go down to their
> use of crystal, and they lied -- to their friends and themselves -- about what
> was happening the whole time.  Their bodies shriveled away, they were sick,
> they became paranoid and delusional, they spun down and down and down.  
> 
> The main difference with E or A or "social-use" substances .. is that they
> really are occasionally used, and if used properly, they allow you to develop
> into a better person.  I know few people who do E straight through the entire
> weekend, but lots of people who use crystal that way.
> 
> Yes, I've had a couple of friends become hooked on E, and that scenario became
> pretty much like what I've seen with speed.  So it CAN happen, but it's not nearly
> as likely an outcome.
> 
> I know, I know, you say ... but I only use it sometimes, not that much, just for
> this occasion, or that occasion.
> 
> *Some* people may be able to occasionally indulge in speed, and not abuse
> it, and maybe you're one of those.  You're the only judge, you're the only one
> to decide.  But remember.... speed will lie to you, too.  
> 
> My rule of thumb about drug decisions ... ask yourself, do people ruin their
> lives because of, and through the use of, this drug?  If the answer is an easy
> yes (heroin, crystal, crack), then stay away from it... is it worth taking the
> risk that your life could be ruined by it too?   If it's a "maybe" (like constant
> pot smoking interfering with accomplishing much of anything) then you might want
> to reconsider that too.
> 
> Coming from a place of love and concern, as well as free choice,
> 
> Leslie
> aka The Fairy Rave Mother
> 
>

From: Andy Thomas <andy@hyperreal.com>

Subject: burning man update (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970327120842.16438A-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk

 http://www.sjmercury.com/news/breaking/docs/044069.htm:

 Change of venue sought for annual Burning Man event

 GERLACH, Nev. (AP) -- In response to opposition from Pershing
 County, organizers of the annual Burning Man event are seeking
 permission for a change of venue.

 Organizers have applied to the Bureau of Land Management to move
 the Labor Day weekend gathering from the Black Rock Desert to an
 equally remote site just to the west in Hualapai Flat.

 If approved, the bulk of the offbeat recreational and artistic
 festival would be held in Washoe County instead of Pershing County.
 But the new site would involve public and private land in both
 counties.

 The new site is located along Nevada Route 34 about 35 miles north
 of Gerlach.

 Lynn Clemons of the BLM's Winnemucca office said organizer Lee
 Harvey responded to a laundry list of complaints about last year's
 event in his application to the agency.

 Harvey ``addressed all of our concerns,'' Clemons told the Lovelock
 Review-Miner.  ``If he hadn't, he wouldn't have gotten a permit.''

 Pershing County commissioners voted to seek an end to the event
 on the Black Rock Desert after a rash of problems at last year's
 gathering, which drew more than 7,000 people, most from California.

 Three people were injured, one critically, when a drunken driver
 slammed into some tents on the desert. Another man was killed when
 his motorcycle ran head-on into a van.

 But Harvey said he intends to go to great lengths to put a new
 and more respectable face on the event.

 He said he would hire a professional security force as well as
 trained medical personnel for the event. Camping would be restricted
 to private land and vehicles would be prohibited on public land,
 he added.

 Organizers are seeking permission to erect various art figures on
 the Hualapai Flats playa and then burn them down. The event takes
 it name from the ceremonial burning of a 40-foot-high wooden
 sculpture of a man.

 Public comments voiced during a recent hearing in Lovelock will
 be used to develop a preliminary environmental assessment on the
 new site, said BLM recreational specialist Mike Bilbo.

 The assessment should be completed by late April, he said.

story detailing the mass-suicide of the web-site-building computer cult
in San Diego. Sounds like the work of PLUR-addled alien-worshipping
ravers to me... :-( ... How pathetic. How sad. Fin-du-siecle madness?

And people wonder why I feel the urge to pull out a flamethrower every
time new age group spirituality raises it's ugly head.

- ------- Forwarded Message

>quite an insane story i think. you should check out their company's web 
>page as well as their cult's webpage. the URLS are:
>
>http://www.highersource.com
>&
>http://www.heavensgate.com
>
>this is the best story i've found on the subject.
>
>March 27, 1997
>
>Mass Suicide May Have Comet Link
>
>Filed at 11:38 a.m. EST
>
>By The Associated Press
>
>RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif. (AP) -- The mysterious
>computer-cult whose members died in a mass suicide left
>videotapes announcing their plans and may have timed
>their deaths to the approach of the Hale-Bopp comet, an
>associate of a former member said today.
>
>The 39 men and women dressed in black, wore their hair
>in buzz cuts and lived -- dozens of them -- in an
>antiseptic, million-dollar mansion stocked with bulk
>food and computer hardware used to create Internet
>sites.
>
>They sent a farewell videotape to a former member and
>died in the same mansion, lying in apparent peace on
>their backs, arms at their sides, each covered across
>the face and chest with a triangular shroud of purple
>cloth.
>
>Sheriff's deputies who went to the Spanish-style mansion
>on a tip Wednesday found the victims of one of the
>biggest mass suicides in U.S. history. Other than the
>bodies, they found little but mystery.
>
>``There's no gunshot wounds, there's no knife holes in
>anybody,'' said San Diego County Sheriff's Cmdr. Alan
>Fulmer. ``Nothing to my knowledge has been found in the
>way of poison.''
>
>The home apparently was the center of a thriving
>business designing Web pages for businesses that want a
>presence on the Internet. Customers of the company
>called Higher Source described the home's occupants as
>cultlike and clannish, but businesslike and proficient.
>
>Nick Matzorkis, a Beverly Hills businessman who employs
>a former member of the Higher Source group, said today
>that members sent the employee -- whom he identified
>only as Rio -- two videotapes this week that described
>their intentions. He told NBC's ``Today'' show that it
>was his understanding that they died Monday and used
>sleeping pills to kill themselves.
>
>Members believed it was time to ``shed their
>containers,'' perhaps to rendezvous with a UFO they
>believed was traveling behind the Hale-Bopp comet,
>Matzorkis said. The comet is currently visible from
>Earth.
>
>A rumor that a UFO has trailed the comet has been
>circulating for months on the Internet; astronomers say
>the object cited by the theory's proponent, an amateur
>astronomer, is actually a star distorted by the optics
>of the amateur's telescope.
>
>Rio received the videotapes Tuesday evening, Matzorkis
>said, and Rio discussed them with Matzorkis on
>Wednesday. One video was of the group's elderly male
>leader, he said. The other contained each member's taped
>farewells.
>
>Matzorkis told ABC's ``Good Morning America'' that they
>went to the house and Rio went in and found the bodies.
>
>``When he came out he was as white as a sheet. ... At
>that point no one else in the world essentially knew
>this had taken place,'' Matzorkis told ABC. He said they
>then notified police.
>
>A Website that ``Today'' said was apparently designed by
>Higher Source described the group's desire to leave
>Earth and rendezvous with a spaceship behind the
>Hale-Bopp comet.
>
>``The joy is that our Older Member in the Evolutionary
>Level above human (the `Kingdom of Heaven') has made it
>clear to us that Hale-Bopp's approach is the `marker'
>we've been waiting for. ... Our 22 years of classroom
>here on planet Earth is finally coming to conclusion --
>`graduation' from the Human Evolutionary Level. We are
>happily prepared to leave `this world' and go with Ti's
>crew,'' the Heaven's Gate Website reads.
>
>However, there was no information on the Heaven's Gate
>Website that connected it to the Higher Source group.
>There is a separate Website under the Higher Source
>name. The Heaven's Gate Website said suicide was
>unacceptable for people who were not part of the group
>but was an acceptable way for members to ascend to a
>higher level of life.
>
>Overnight, investigators searched the house and
>refrigerated vans from the coroner's office stood by.
>One of the vans, which is capable of holding 20 bodies,
>pulled away from the home about 5:15 a.m. and arrived at
>the morgue in San Diego an hour and a half later.
>Authorities would not immediately confirm whether there
>were bodies in it.
>
>Members of the cult told the landlord, Sam
>Koutchesfahani, that they were sent to Earth as angels
>and met in ``middle America,'' Milt Silverman,
>Koutchesfahani's attorney, told San Diego radio station
>KFMB.
>
>Members also said the group has branches in Arizona and
>New Mexico, Silverman said. He didn't elaborate. In
>Santa Fe, N.M., police Sgt. Jerry Archuleta said one car
>parked outside the house was registered to a mailbox
>there, and authorities knew of no cult branch there.
>
>Silverman told CBS' ``This Morning'' that the group had
>previously rented from a couple who were doctors and
>came with good references. ``They seemed to be perfectly
>reasonable people, always paid their rent on time,'' he
>said.
>
>Tom Goodspeed, director of the San Diego Polo Club, said
>Higher Source designed a Web page for the club. He
>visited the house and described quiet men with buzz-cut
>hair and stylish, collarless black shirts.
>
>``They had that look about them that maybe they were a
>little bit strange of appearance, but that they could
>probably sit down in front of a computer and really get
>it done,'' Goodspeed told ABC's ``Nightline.'' ``They
>did a fantastic job for us.''
>
>Goodspeed was one of several visitors who thought of
>Higher Source as a cult. He and others said the group
>appeared to answer to an older man known as ``Father
>John,'' and that a ``Brother Logan'' appeared to be a
>second in command.
>
>Bill Grivas of nearby Solana Beach said he looked at the
>home as a potential buyer and heard them referring to
>themselves as monks.
>
>The Higher Source Website is adorned with pictures of
>stars and nebulae, but appears largely a straightforward
>business site, touting the company's abilities and
>listing satisfied customers.
>
>``The individuals at the core of our group have worked
>closely together for over 20 years,'' boasts one entry
>on the site. ``We try to stay positive in every
>circumstance and put the good of a project above any
>personal concerns or artistic egos.''
>
>The age of the victims and the neighborhood in which it
>took place fit the profile of modern cult activity, said
>Ronald E. Enroth, a professor at Westmont College in
>Santa Barbara, Calif., and a leading expert on new
>religious movements.
>
>The case began Wednesday with a pair of anonymous calls
>-- one to the San Diego Sheriff's Department and one
>somewhat later to Beverly Hills police. Both suggested
>checking the house in this wealthy enclave of walled
>estates and polo fields in the rolling hills 20 miles
>north of San Diego.
>
>A deputy made his way up the steep, gated drive, went in
>an open door and found 10 bodies in a room. More
>deputies arrived, wearing surgical masks against the
>putrid odor of decaying bodies.
>
>Fulmer said at first that all 39 victims were male
>between 18 and 24. He later said some were women and
>some were older, but was unable to provide further
>detail.
>
>The smell was so bad that officers at first thought it
>might be poison gas. Later, Fulmer said it was the smell
>of death, bad enough to indicate the victims had been
>dead for some time.
>
>There were no marks on the bodies and no suicide notes,
>Fulmer said. The bodies were lying on cots and bunks
>throughout the house, each with a 3-foot triangular
>purple cloth lying over the face and chest.
>
>Investigators discovered that the home had been rented
>in October. The nine-bedroom, seven-bathroom house sits
>on 3.11 acres with a swimming pool and tennis court. It
>was valued at $1.325 million in 1995.
>
>In Washington today, Attorney General Janet Reno said
>there was no immediate indication that a federal crime
>had been committed, but the FBI was monitoring the
>situation and was ready to help local authorities if
>needed.
>
>Koutchesfahani, the landlord, pleaded guilty last year
>to tax evasion and fraud after admitting he took up to
>$350,000 from Middle Eastern students between 1989 and
>1995.
>
>Prosecutors said Koutchesfahani used the money to bribe
>college instructors at three San Diego-area colleges
>into illegally enrolling students into the schools and
>certifying them as California residents.
>
>On April 19, 1993, Branch Davidian leader David Koresh
>and 80 followers -- including 18 children -- died by
>fire or gunfire, six hours after the FBI started filling
>their cult compound near Waco, Texas, with tear gas. The
>government called the deaths a mass suicide after a
>51-day armed standoff.
>
>       Copyright 1997 The New York Times Company
>
>The information contained in this AP Online news report may not be 
>republished or redistributed without the prior written authority of The 
>Associated Press.
>
>

- ------- End of Forwarded Message

The joke may of offended you but does the joke greatly affect your life??
Tollerence of certain things is a personal choice, we all have different
things that offend us and we all probobly think things are funny or
like to read things that offend other people. I ask you (and I'm not being 
patronizing) where do you draw the line, raves greatly offend my
step-parents, they really wish that I not attend them, but they don't say
I cannot go they feel it is my choice, at the same time I feel they have
no right to say raves cannot go on. 

The message was labbeled NRR which
already clues you in to the fact that the message isn't rave related i.e.
the content in the message could be anything. I am not shooting down your
comment or your opinion , all I ask is you concider these points. The
wonderful thing about the internet is it allows the minority to express
their oppinion on much the same level as the majority, I feel that stating
that the message was offending was your right, but do you feel it's your
right to say the message shouldn't have been posted in the first place??

I understand your point, and I apologize for being posting a message that
had a very "check yourself additude". We all must draw the line somewhere
but how the line is drawn is a different story.

Thank you for your time, now go 'way =)

> We've gotten to this precarious position where if we complain about a joke
> we are labeled P.C.  But, what if that joke really offends us?  Do we then
> shut up and accept it just because someone else thinks it's funny?  It
> saddens me to see any minority movement/voice being squelched by such a
> backlash.  It only serves to put said movement/voice back in its place
> where it belongs i.e. the minority.  So, I think it's sad when someone
> says such-and-such joke offends them (and in a nice way at that), only to 
> be told, "Like it or leave it."  Maybe those of us who find the joke funny
> might want to try harder to understand why the other side
> *doesn't* find the joke funny.  I'd certainly be willing to explain why I
> didn't find the joke funny and how it relates to my life.

>But rational and moderate users of the drug are lumped in with hard-core 
>addicts.  If you ever do a line you are considered some sort of mangy 
>slimeball by people on 4 hits of acid and e every weekend.  Hypocrisy is

Exactly.... I felt like I was being judged by Leslie when she said:

> *Some* people may be able to occasionally indulge in speed, and not abuse
> it, and maybe you're one of those.  You're the only judge, you're the
only one
> to decide.  But remember.... speed will lie to you, too.  

Leslie didn't really even know my motivations for posting my message.
Whether or not I use crystal, the main reason this topic was so fresh in my
mind is a conversation I had yesterday.  I was talking with a fellow raver
about last Saturday night.... I was talking about a particular DJ's set I
had heard.  I was telling this person how much I liked it, and he looked at
me suprised said, "You like him?  He's just a tweaker...."

You probably get my point.  This person judged the DJ solely on the basis
of the fact (or so he says) that the DJ uses speed.  It totally bummed me
out!!!  I loved the music, it put me in a good place, and I had a great
time.  Why should the fact that the DJ might be strung out on crystal ruin
the experience for me, or anyone else?

Nancy's words "used intelligently" are perfect... any drug can be abused.
Leslie said she knew people who abused E.  The point is just because a
certain drug may be more addictive, it doesn't make it right to judge
someone who uses that drug, especially if the do use it
intelligently/socially.  No better or worse than using E socially.

Please remember, all my thoughts on this matter are IMHO, and  they too
come from love, concern and free choice.

love,

david

On Thu, 27 Mar 1997, Mr nStuff wrote:

> Is telling someone to Shut-Up PLUR?  I am curious..
> 
> My concious is clean.. If the deal goes through.. I am "paying" for them.
> Money well spent, at that..
> Is it not polite to NOT tip a bar tender?

I don't think it's rude to not tip anyone. I think Mr. Pink was right when
he said "I don't tip because society tells me I have to".

> Is there justification in buying your daughter a barbi doll that was made
> by under payed, uneducated, starving children? Even if your daughter is
> going to be really sad if she don't get that baggy pants ravEr barbi doll
> for her birthday?

Yes. It's better to be underpaid then not paid at all. There are a lot of
things in this country that are manufacturered by underpaid people.

> Should one, NOT cut another off in traffic to avoid an accident?

To avoid an accident I would do whatever my instincts told me to do. But I
would be sure not to cause another accident if possible.

> Is it right for a General to send someone to there death, to save hundreds
> of people?

Yes. The soldier makes an oath to give his life for his country if needed.
It's an oath and it's his duty. I think it's a bunch of BS, but it's
better me then someone who's willing to make that oath.

> Is, destroying the O-zone layer ok? Aslong as you don't have a bad hair day
> right?

Fucking up the ozone layer is some pretty jacked up shit. (Sounds like
Jules Winfield from Pulp Fiction, eh?). I don't think we should allow
ourselves to create products that are not necessarily necessities that
cause permanent damage to our planet. 

> Anybody know of a good coffin for tables that comes with a third attachable
> turntable case?

Check out any DJ equipment store....

	Since I started this maybe I should say a bit about how I feel on
this issue. I posted this to the list because I wanted to share with
everyone something which made me laugh, I laugh for many reasons, but I
try really hard to never laugh AT someone or some group, but with them.
laughter can be one of the easiest ways to deal with a problem...look how
funny it is, were all in the same boat sort of thing. Stereotypes
especially can be the source of this sort of humor, I feel that the
sfraves community is one that is aware enough to know that the joke was
not intended to be hurtful, and that most people on this list will laugh
at this joke in a 'geez society is really stupid' sort a way.
	but then I read the joke again, this time from the perspective of
a woman that hed been the victim of a destructive relationship such as the
joke was describing (and then I started thinking about some of the
women I KNEW that had been in bad relationships) and realized that maybe I
should apologise because it was clear to me that I had in fact hit some
sore spots in some people on the list, and I dont want to do that to
anyone.
	Because this is a public forum, with 400? people on it you can
never be completely comfortable with your words as if you were at home
talking to your close friends...
	issues like this are very important and difficult to deal with,
alot of people give berkeley/bay area a bad rap for being too P.C. "why
dont you lighten up? ...welll, I just have to point out that P.C. is just
one approach to a VERY complex social problem, that of living and dealing
with a extremely diverse world of many differnt cultures and values and if
we are ever going to learn to respect one another it has to start with
trying to understand one another, and underastanding doesnt start with
"why dont you just chill out" phew... I'm getting a little worked up
here... so thats my rant... take it or leave it love tony

ps...would I send the joke to the list again if I could do it over? ...
hmmm hard question, depending on my mood, but if I did i would definetely
preface it with a disclaimer about the content...tr.=)

Date: Thu, 27 Mar 1997 12:19:03 -0800 (PST)
From: R. Daniel Woolman <woolman@in-search-of.com>
To: in_search_of@primenet.com
Subject: [In_Search_Of] HALE-BOPP SHIP; GROUP PLANNED RENDEZVOUS FOR MORE THAN A YEAR

We are "In Search Of . . ." answers together. Each posting must reflect
personal respect, integrity, honesty, and full disclosure of information.
----------

HALE-BOPP SHIP; GROUP PLANNED RENDEZVOUS FOR MORE THAN A YEAR

To investigators, it is becoming clearer by the hour the reasons 39 members
of the Heaven's Gate cult committed mass suicide in Rancho Santa Fe,
California sometime over the past week.  The simultaneous lunar eclipse on
Palm Sunday coupled with the passing of the Hale-Bopp comet were prophetic
signs to the group, authorities believe, signaling the arrival of a "Next
Level spacecraft" flying behind the comet.  The DRUDGE REPORT has learned
that investigators are not only in possession of video tape testimony by
each of the suicide victims but also hundreds of Internet Usenet group
postings by the group's self-confessed "Messiah" -- a chilling outline of
its suicide intentions.

Authorities are also in possession of a detailed manifesto by the group's
leader, believed to be a 25 year-old male.

"I came to Earth some 2000 years ago from another physical, biological
Evolutionary Level as the expected "Messiah," or Jesus, and for this
current mission, RETURNED to this level, this planet and entered into a
human body some 24 years ago, Earth-time," the still unidentified leader
wrote in a July 1996 manifesto.

"For the most part, I have spent these years in seclusion working with my
students/"disciples" - preparing them for membership in the "NEXT WORLD,"
the Evolutionary Level Above Human, the true physical Kingdom of Heaven.

"Now, before departure via a "Next Level" mothership, my students and I
will be assisting my Father and His other Next Level helpers...

"The human kingdom was never meant to be anything but a stepping stone - a
'realized hell' that must be evacuated WITH THE HELP OF A REPRESENTATIVE
FROM THE NEXT EVOLUTIONARY LEVEL - THE KINGDOM OF HEAVEN."

"The choices of many will find them in a 'mind set' that would view us as
'cultish,' radical, and doomsdayish, to say the least, while others have
chosen to seek mental nourishment that would have them suspect 'Truth' in
my statements," wrote the apparent leader.

The manifesto is a complicated, confusing mix of science fiction and
neo-Gnostic theory that reads like pure madness.  The DRUDGE REPORT has
also learned that authorities are now working on the theory that the
suicides had been planned for months, if not years.

The apparent leader wrote:  "There is a simple evolutionary procedure which
applies to those who might leave or graduate from the human kingdom and
enter the Evolutionary Kingdom Level Above Human (the Kingdom of Heaven or
Kingdom of God).  Periodically, the Kingdom Level Above Human sends one of
its members "down" into the human kingdom (to incarnate into a human body)
-- one who has previously been taken through that evolutionary transition
-- to offer the knowledge to those who have been 'picked' as possible
recipients of that graduation information.  This Representative of that
Next Kingdom literally takes those candidates through their weaning from
the human world -- assisting them in the actual separation or breaking of
ties to their humanness, and helping them 'graft' to Him as the
Representative of that Next Level.   Their final separation is the willful
separation from their human body, when they have changed enough to identify
as the spirit/mind/soul, ready to put on a biological body belonging to the
Kingdom of Heaven.  This entering into their 'glorified' or heavenly body
takes place aboard a Next Level spacecraft, above the Earth's surface."
--
end

Rather sick! And, I just found out the KMG radio dropped Art Bell due to
this story over 30 days ago. Looks like thing are not boding well on
Hale-Bopp.

Dan

Just wanted to clarify a couple of things......... 

I am not judging when I said ...........

> *Some* people may be able to occasionally indulge in speed, and not abuse
> it, and maybe you're one of those.  You're the only judge, you're the
only one
> to decide.  But remember.... speed will lie to you, too.  

But I am speaking from a place of experience.  

Then David explained the motivation for his post....

> I was talking about a particular DJ's set I
> had heard.  I was telling this person how much I liked it, and he looked at
> me suprised said, "You like him?  He's just a tweaker...."

I myself would never say anything like that.  Music is like a separate
entity to me, and I have huge respect for anyone who can make us dance, plus I've
long ago learned to separate my personal feelings about a dj from the music
they play -- 

some of my favorite djs are pretty obnoxious people --  (I will
however note that some djs with substance abuse problems are not very reliable
in the consistent quality of their sets.... another topic) ... and I certainly
would never say a person is "just" anything .... 

(yes, some of my favorite djs are WONDERFUL people, too of course!)

I might however shake my head with concern when I learned that someone was
deep into using speed, because I know where it goes when you pass a certain 
point with it....  

> Nancy's words "used intelligently" are perfect... 

Yes, I do know there are people who use speed cautiously (I'm not really
comfortable using the word "intelligent" in this context) ... but in my own
personal experience it's a little hard to separate the ones who really have
control over their use of the drug, and those who don't.  And the biggest thing
that I've learned is that what a person says about their use often has 
absolutely no connection to the reality.  The drug makes them lie, and this
has been freely admitted after they took control of their lives back from
the drug.

I'm talking about people who I love from the deepest depths of my heart
here... this isn't about judgments of behavior, it's about concern. When someone
tells me they use speed, I may shake my head sadly, but that's from worry, not
judgment. 


Leslie

Todd Manley@HDS
03/27/97 03:14 PM

I just wanted to throw this out for discussion, and maybe we've hashed this
one to death, but I just wanted to hear others input...


Last night I turned on my radio to Live105 and I really wasn't paying
attention while the ads were playing.  Next thing I know I hear a chord
progression from the song the radio dj is talking over, and my ears start
to perk up.  I know I had heard this song somewhere, but I couldn't place
it.  As I'm trying to think what the song is, the radio dj says "We're the
station for your dance music!"

Then it hits me what song it is, "Insomnia" by Faithless.  I was right
because just after I remembered what song it was, the dj told the listening
public the title and artist.  Now I've had this record for about a year and
a half, picking it up when I was in England in '95.  I really liked the
record when I first heard it, and i still like it when I mix it with some
other specific records.  But here is what I'm really getting at.

I know people who will hear a song at a rave and believe that the song is
great, and then when it hits the radio, the song isn't 'da bomb' (I'm
remembering the Robert Miles song 'Children') it once was.  Now I know a
song can get played out, etc., etc., and that can diminish from the appeal,
but does the fact that a song is played on the radio make it 'mainstream'.

After the song finished last night I had a weird feeling, like a part of me
being taken away.  It was such a shock to hear this song that I felt like
Big Brother was intruding on my cherished ground.

Anyway, I'm a little dazed and confused, and I wanted to know how others
felt.

-Thanks, Todd

> Nancy's words "used intelligently" are perfect... any drug can be abused.
> Leslie said she knew people who abused E.  The point is just because a
> certain drug may be more addictive, it doesn't make it right to judge
> someone who uses that drug, especially if the do use it
> intelligently/socially.  No better or worse than using E socially.
> 

Someone please explain to me exactly what it means to use E
intelligently. It has been my understanding through reading materials
from ecstacy.org that it takes approx. 6 months for your brain to fully
recover from 1 hit of E (If this simply meant that seritonin came back
or something more complex happened I'm not shure).  And even then you
have the problem of serotonergic neuron terminals potentaly growing
back to the wrong place. So far I've been able to follow this guideline
and have only taken E once in the last 10 months. But from reading this
thread I've gotten the impression that other peoples definition of
intelligent use may be different. This may explain why "casual users"
seem to be lumped in with "hard users". If indeed it is true that it
takes about a six month wait between E hits and many people who concider
themselves "casual users" are doing much more than that (say every 1-2
months) than I too would have to classify them in something other than
the responsible catagory.

-=Pengo=-

>recover from 1 hit of E (If this simply meant that seritonin came back

>back to the wrong place. So far I've been able to follow this guideline

other drug.  We are talking about the addictive nature, so maybe
intelligent isn't the "perfect" word to use, but in the context that we
were talking about, it works.

If we were talking about detrimental effects a substance has on one's
physical well-being, no use of any substance would be intelligent, then
again neither would eating burnt toast....carcinogens cause cancer you know!!!

David King wrote:
> 
> 
> Nancy's words "used intelligently" are perfect... any drug can be abused.
> Leslie said she knew people who abused E.  The point is just because a
> certain drug may be more addictive, it doesn't make it right to judge
> someone who uses that drug, especially if the do use it
> intelligently/socially.  No better or worse than using E socially.
> 

I think this can be put into perspective even more if we remember that
not only can any _drug_ be abused, but any_thing_ can be abused.  There
are many things that have "ruined people's lives":  television, sex,
food, exercise, relationships, etc.  Anything can act as an agent of
growth and enlightenment or of destruction.  Some things seem to have
more "power" -- more potential to be abused as well as to be useful. 
Drugs seem to be one of those things.

Precedence: bulk

Hi,
     This is my first post as this account isn't mine and I only get to
come round here and pick up on a few threads once every couple of weeks.
But I really felt I had to say something about this drug hypocrisy
discussion.
     First of all, I don't think it's anyone's business but their own
what drugs they do/do not do at a party or anywhere else.  Total
acceptance of who I am and what I do was the one of the biggest
attractions of the rave scene when I first got into it, and it's largely
why I'm still in it now.
     Second of all, being concerned that someone is having problems (or
will have problems) just because they use an addictive drug can cause
more harm than good.  When I was seventeen years old, I experimented with
speed and cocaine.  Then I stopped.  Several months later, rumors were
still flying around my high school that I was some kind of addict, and
"well-meaning" "friends" (who obviously believed rumor before they
believed me), went to the school administration in order to get me some
"help."  When I was called to the office to explain myself, I informed
them that I did not have a problem.  Their reaction?  "Denial is the
first sign of addiction."  Anyway, to cut a long story short (I know -
it's too late . . !), the result was that they would not believe me, they
called my parents, and they kicked me out of school until I agreed to get
"help."  And I never did go back.
     The moral of the story is BELIEVE PEOPLE.  If they tell you that
they are using speed because they enjoy it, and they are aware of the
potential downward spiral, then leave them alone.  They probably know
what they are doing.
     I always thought the rave community would be the one place on earth
that wouldn't condemn people for pursuing what they enjoy.
     Thanks for listening.

Love,
Beth

Actual Bumper Stickers:

"Change is inevitable, except from a vending machine."
"I love cats... they taste like chicken."
"Out of my mind.  Back in five minutes."
"Cover me.  I'm changing lanes."
"As long as there are tests, there will be prayer in public schools."
"Happiness is a belt-fed weapon."
"Laugh alone and the world thinks you're an idiot."
"Sometimes I wake up grumpy; Other times I let her sleep."
"I want to die in my sleep like my grandfather...Not screaming and
       yelling like the passengers in his car..."
"Montana...At least our cows are sane!"
"The gene pool could use a little chlorine."
"I didn't fight my way to the top of the food chain to be a vegetarian."
"Your kid may be an honor student but you're still an IDIOT!"
"It's as BAD as you think, and they ARE out to get you."
"When you do a good deed, get a receipt, in case heaven is like the IRS."
"Wink, I'll do the rest!"
"JESUS...protect me from your followers."
"I took an IQ test and the results were negative."
"When there's a will, I want to be in it."
"Okay, who stopped the payment on my reality check?"
"If we aren't supposed to eat animals, why are they made of meat?"
"Time is the best teacher; Unfortunately it kills all its students."
"It's lonely at the top, but you eat better."
"Reality? That's where the pizza delivery guys comes from."
"Forget about World Peace... Visualize Using Your Turning Signal!"
"Warning: Dates in Calendar are closer than they appear."
"Give me ambiguity or give me something else."
"We are born naked, wet, and hungry.  Then things get worse."
"Make it idiot proof and someone will make a better idiot."
"He who laughs last thinks slowest."
"Always remember you're unique, just like everyone else."
"Lottery: A tax on people who are bad at math."
"Very funny, Scotty.  Now beam down my clothes."
"Puritanism:  The haunting fear that someone, somewhere may be happy."
"Consciousness: That annoying time between naps."
"I souport publik edekasion"
"We are Microsoft. Resistance Is Futile.  You Will Be Assimilated."
"Be nice to your kids.  They'll choose your nursing home."
"3 kinds of people: those who can count & those who can't."
"Why is 'abbreviation' such a long word."
"Ever stop to think, and forget to start again?"
"Diplomacy is the art of saying 'Nice Doggy'!... till you can find a
  rock."
"Friends don't let friends vote Republican."
"Bad spellers of the world - UNTIE."

I had the privilege of seeing Annie perform last week, at the absolutely 
fabulous 20th anniversary party for the absolutely fabulous 
sex-positive/woman-positive sex toy store Good Vibrations.

She did a brilliant parody of a strip tease, managing to turn what is 
sometimes degrading to women into a celebration of her body, a hilarious 
send-up of traditional "femininity," a sexy and funny show, and have a 
theatrical orgasm at the same time!  She's tops in my book.  :)

both Friday and Saturday nights, and Stompy on Sunday.  Sunset came back
last week, but I don't know when it'll be weekly.  If you can keep going 
after that, there's still Mad on Monday, some new stuff like Static on
Tuesday, and Come/Unity and some new stuff on Wednesday.

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday afternoon 3pm-8pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of
       jungle, dub, breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight-3am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats,
       Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Friday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

  To all you happy ravers.
   If you're like me, than you're open to all kinds of music.  Well have I
got a treat for you!!  My band, Somethin' Grooves, is playin LIVE this Friday
night at 6:00pm at Mainstreet Music in Tracy.  We'll be done just in time for
you to take off and enjoy the evenings festivities, wherever they may be.
 Directions are as follows:  Take I-580 east to Tracy.  Take the 205 Business
exit.  go straight until you reach a Pizza Hut, then take a right.  Take your
Immediate left and go until you see a music store on the left side of the
street.  
   Call this a Pre-Party gathering or something.  And b-sides, we're a cool
band and we need the exposure.  there will be free stickers to give out
(maybe, if I get around to it) and you can get a chance to meet some of your
e-mail pals face to face.  And have I mantioned it yet, We're a really cool
band.  We've played two gigs before and we've gotten positive responces from
both
  Hope to see you all there!!!   Look for me, I'm the drummer.

        John

On Thu, 27 Mar 1997, Joe Rice wrote:

> It's my understanding that Sunset is to be every other week.

Do you know if it will ever be moved back to the marina?  I like that
location much more than the current one both in terms of travel (I can
ride my bike or bus to the marina) and locale (thicker grass, set into a
cove, etc).

Besides that, the marina is much more conducive to people getting a
positive take on raves as there is a path going right by where people
stroll, ride, etc.  The last marina Sunset I was at, curious passers-by
would stop to look and then start to groove -- even 60-70 year old
couples! :)

	Sami

 Hi everyone!

Lightseed Family invites everyone to a family gathering on Friday.

We are having a party to celebrate the arrival of the comet Hale-Bop.
It will be visible during the late after noon into the evening on
Friday.

Our party will be in a clean safe secure sf location.  Bring your love,
positive vibes, and a can of food to feed the homeless.  Our event will
benefit Food Not Bombs and The Headwaters Outreach Program.

For information check out the website @
www.intrepidnet.com/lightseed/comet/
And call 415.458.0337  &  707.329.2189

FYI: djs/music - Sean Murray, Bones, Jeff Taisch, Mystr-E, Anon, Benji,
Gamma Quadrant, Rob Rayle & Lauren

Dreams.

> After the song finished last night I had a weird feeling, like a part of me
> being taken away.  It was such a shock to hear this song that I felt like
> Big Brother was intruding on my cherished ground.

Let's say you weren't able to go to the UK in '95 and pick up Faithless.
Let's say you were busy for a long period of time working, etc. and couldn't
attend raves, clubs, what have you.
And the only music that was available was on the radio or tv or internet.
Then it would be a good thing for the radio to play faithless and introduce
you to their music.
Cause if they didn't then you wouldn't know about it.
The more people that know about and appreciate a band the better. No matter
how they were introduced to it.

Groove Radio (103.1fm) in LA has done this quite a bit... in fact, I know 
there are rekkids that are probably pretty good that I just can't stand 
because I've heard them so many times on Groove (Insomnia is one of 
them).  I always find it amusing listening to DJs from non-Groove areas 
because they almost always wind up spinning some rekkid that the 
SoCal-ers have bannished to the back of the crate due to too much airplay.

it's odd, but that station gets you motivated to really dig for the good 
rekkids.  :)

On Tue, 18 Mar 1997, ina v grubb wrote:

> both of these comments make me wonder about our music being so
> mechanistic
> that we are now resonating with the artificial sounds of machines and
> this
> concrete jungle that we have created. So much that we are becoming
> part of the machine. 

I think of it as remaking faceless, frightening technology into something

tribal, passionate, real.  Redefining inhuman sounds to resonate with the

deepest parts of our human souls.  Mechanistic bleeps are no longer the 
sound of alienation; they bring us to communalism and return us to a 
distant memory - the ecstatic dance to repetitive rhythm that humans have

done since the beginning of time.


It is important to remember to also listen to
> the beat of nature...the pulse of the earth and the whisper of the 
> wind and stars...so that we dont forget who we truely are.
> 
Exactly!

PLUR

That's what its all about .... And the bass room thumping hard hitting
soul shaking thump thump thump rhythm pace trance journey begins...

...Djs spinning, mixing away with their jog jog jog jog jog jog of their
head
and body to the bass hits rhythm, use the fader there, bring it
in oh so slowly..here it is, got it in synch now...this is going to be
phat
now here it is drop it in on em!  Yeeeaaaah!!! The crowd around
you jumps in release!  14 counts to go, fade it out, bring it back in...
red herring? Or is it amphetamine!  Feel the surgE
see the EnErgy around you.. feel the community of yeahs
and screams to the dj to go go go... do you hear it? can you
feel it coming? The bass is coming... only 4 hours left tonite
the party goes on...

...to your right, a pair of glowsticks chasing each other in the hands
of a ravechild spinning her web of glowstick wizardry and imagination
spinning twirling streaking their tracks of light and your
trance is green motion stops mesmerized at the light show
the crowd surges in energy... a steady thump thump trancelike
voice screams on 1 and 3, its Christopher Lawrence taking over
starting his set of all sets just for you..the wavEs of goosebumps rush
over
your arms and your hair stands on end..and the clapping 
the clapping and the yeah yeah roar of the crowd. Smiles everywhere
people crying in joy and sensory overload.. 2,000 people its
too good to believe!  This is the 3am set-the energy is raw, electric, 
static,  gotta drink water yeah gotta drink water drink it down, 
offer it with outstretched hands to the people around you, pats on 
your back, hugs here and here and the dancing rages onward, pressing on
into the
bass hits that make our night...

whistles are everywhere, someone is whistling on 2 and 4...screech
screech can you hear the voices in the corners of the room, yelling
to the rhythm thump thump thump the bass still carries you,
it will sustain you, the people will keep you going.. drink more water
drink it down, Christopher Lawrence is throwing some new vinyl on...
dragging
the edge of the Technics 1200 to slow it down every so slightly...
wonder what its going to be?  The red light on the turntable is so
rad...he's bringing it in now ...wow unbelievable!  Dance harder,
dance faster, look deep into the bass focus to see what its all about...
someone
grabs you, points to the sky ..its the comet! Its dancing too, streaking 
speeding across the dark universe spreading its vibe...its tail is
vibrant,
its fire and beauty fired by the energy of the dancers below, motion
stops,
your trance is the comet, its next set isn't going to be until 2450 AD!!
Incomprehensible....a trance song now, hugs everywhere, some 
children handing out candy oh it tastes so sweet, the energy is rising,
the bass is starting again softly, you know whats coming next... the
whump
whump whump builds and it drops in as the crowd surges with screams and
arms waiving in the air you know that you've found where you belong......

See you all at DUNE III..

"May your 5 o'clock set never end"

Geoff

*40th Body Found in Southern California Heavens Gate Suicides*

 Local investigators while searching for clues and information about the
Heavens Gate Cult were suprised to find a 40th body on the grounds some
ways away from the other cult members bodies. The body was found dressed
almost exactly like the other 39 members with some notable exceptions.
The individual had a pacifier in their mouth and several long depleted
glowsticks in each pocket. Glitter and some stickers were found
decorating the face as well as a multitude of laminates hanging from the
neck.

The newly discovered body had a neatly packed bag at the foot of the
bed. But instead of items similar to the other members, wich consisted
of clothes, small personal items and such, the bag contained a pair of
Technics 1200 Turntables, some carfuley selected vinyl records, 300
Blowpops, Bottled Waters, and Jonson & Jonson Hand Lotion.

"According to the neibhors reports, " said one investigating officer,
"the individual had a schedule different than the others. They were
reported to have been seen many times comming back home early in the
morning, fatuiged but wearing a big smile.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

-=Pengo=-

why are you posting this on SFR? huhhh? you don't see FMR info on the
alt.dead.cult.members.info newsgroup, do ya???  well then, MR. PENGO,
why don't we just keep all the gratuitous non-rave-related stuff off of
this mailing list so that we can get on with the SERIOUS BUSINESS of
raving! I don't have time to read the 2 - 3 (sometimes as many as 5!!!)
"NRR" posts that come across on this list each day. You figure at about
5 seconds per post (to scan and delete), that's up to 25 seconds WASTED
EACH AND EVERY DAY!  (and that's not even counting the time I spend
whining about NRR posts, which can be anywhere from 1-2 HOURS each day) 
I'm a busy guy, and I don't have that kind of time to waste!  I could be
doing better things with all that wasted time, like trying to figure out
what to do with this stick that's up my ass.
So please, no more NRR posts on SF Raves.  thanks big guy.

-philip
xoxox and peas and plur and all that shit
