a little late in the posting...but put briefly:

full moon, brisk sunday night.
foggy, ethereal glow from the moonlight.
panther beach!  bonfires! awesome, thunderous waves
melanie, carlos, garth, tracy, jason. - great music!
clean sound from two Community stacks
mind-warping computer-generated visuals - projected onto a huge cliff!
this one didn't end until well after _10 a.m._ on a most
gorgeous sunny monday morning

need i say more? 

you'd be a fool to miss the next FMR.  remember how insane they were
about 3 years ago? well, they're building up to that again.  this
summer, looks like they're gonna be fully OUT OF CONTROL.

see ya next month, kiddoes!
- pxd

Byroni wanted to get together for a bbq or something .... 

for those who don't know, we have a fairly new tradition of SFRaves
barbecues (we've done 3 now I think, all really great), which 
are now called Beats n BBQ .... currently in the plans
are an outside all-night beach party onf Saturday April 19th, 
the a daytime BBQ party on May 24th ....

and not to forget the CAMPOUT the first weekend in June, i.e. Saturday
June 7th...

Make sure to mark your calendars on that one!  

This is of course not to say we shouldn't have LOTS of excursions
into realms that may have nothing to do with dancing ..  I highly encourage
everyone to get together for dinner, hanging in the park, whatever, to get
to know your fellow SFRavers on their "non-rave" habitat!

Leslei

------- Start of forwarded message -------
From: Jackie Dove <dove@slip.net>
Subject: (event 3/29) protest for Animal Rights
Date: Thu, 27 Mar 1997 10:39:22 -0800 (PST)
Sender: craigs-list-errors@lists.best.com
To: craigs-list@lists.best.com


Easter Bunnies Around the World Take Revenge on Procter and Gamble1s
Animal Testing Policy

Please join In Defense of Animals (in partnership with Uncaged of Great
Britain) for a Global Day of Action Against Procter and Gamble, an
international day of protest. On Saturday, March 29, 1997, animal rights
supporters around the globe will demonstrate, march, sit in, and
participate in civil disobedience actions to send a clear message to P and
G that cruelty and torture are bad science and bad business.

In San Francisco, the protest will take place at the Marina Safeway at
15 Marina Boulevard (between Laguna and Buchanan) between 11:00 AM and
2:00 PM.

In addition, you can also call P and G CEO John Pepper at 1-800-543-7270
to protest the use of animals for testing cosmetics and household
products. (Public pressure really works. Gillette recently declared a
moratorium on all animal testing, after 15 years of defending the
practice.)

We need your participation to make this the biggest and loudest public
condemnation of this greedy corporate giant, who needlessly tortures
millions of animals to death each year by force-feeding them toxic
substances such as drain cleaner and laundry detergent, or forcing
shampoos, shaving preparations, and make-up into animals1 eyes and on
shaved skin. Animal testing does not make products safer!

For more information call In Defense of Animals at 415-388-9641.


__________________________________________________________________________
for info on craigs-list:  http://www.cnewmark.com

------- End of forwarded message -------

 | simitzis /sim' - i - jees/ (n) an unpronounceable string of random letters |
    | Electronic Frontier Foundation | Taos Mountain | saturn5 Productions |
            | operators are standing by : 415-626-5074 (H/VM->P) |

>supporters around the globe will demonstrate, march, sit in, and

>2:00 PM.

>to protest the use of animals for testing cosmetics and household
>products. (Public pressure really works. Gillette recently declared a
>moratorium on all animal testing, after 15 years of defending the
>practice.)
>

>condemnation of this greedy corporate giant, who needlessly tortures
>millions of animals to death each year by force-feeding them toxic

>shampoos, shaving preparations, and make-up into animals1 eyes and on
>shaved skin. Animal testing does not make products safer!

    once again, all I can say is that when you're like me spend all $$$ on 
raves, rekkids, and computers, turning on live 105 at 1pm when you need a 
house fix and Insomniac happens to be on, it makes your day!  Even if it 
is followed by a live 105 promo...
    Hmm...what's so bad about "our" music becomming "mainstream" anyway?  
It's not like live 105'ers are going to hear _a_ song and decide they want 
to spend $20-$100 a weekend to make this music their lifestyle!  So it's not 
like the few real UG's we have will be suddenly bombarded with scenesters. 
    And just in case it is, they'll probably notice that most of the rave 
"songs" they hear have no words or guitar solo's, and aren't The Prodigy, 
The Chemical Brothers w/ Noel Gallagher or a Smashing Punkins remix.  So 
if they decide they _don't_ like the music and leave, no big deal.  And 
if they decide that they _do_ like the music and stay, then we just scored 
a new member of our bomb-ass community.  

    Just my opinion...I hope I don't offend anyone!!!
   
Peace & Much Love,
christine

supposedly that last time that bagok tribe did a party there was supposed
to be barbara tucker, kot, frankie bones and a whole host of other famous
DJ's and singers. I showed up at the party at around 12:00 am. and
according to there schedule the DJ's that were supposed to be playing at
that time were not. So I wondered who did show and who did not? the reason
being I left to go to a harmony party and returned in the morning to get
some of my friends that stayed at that party. Jimmy and carlos closed but
according to there lineup some "famous" DJ's was supposed to close and not
them. So this leads me to believe that they put names on there flyers of
people that probably did not show.So I wonder who is really "confirmed" on
there lineup and who is not? I know mark B is confirmed cause my friend
talked to him as well as frankie. I will not be there so for those of you
going could you please tell me who shows and who does not. I was a little
disappointed when I did not see KOT or michelle weeks. But I can't complain
cause I did not pay for that party. Sorry to spam the list.

Just a warning to those of you to whom this might have some relevance.
The last party from Bagok Tribe (sp?), Lucky Charms, got lambasted on
sfraves.  I don't remember a single positive comment.  There was mayhem at
the map point (Your Mama's Cafe), and XLR8R blasted their flyer which
clearly and obviously made reference to drugs. Supposedly some dj's didn't
show, also.

I'm not passing judgment here, just information for you to do with what
you will.  I know little about the party, but more about the reputation.
I know what kind of party I like to go to, and this probably wouldn't be
that one.  To anyone similarly aligned with my tastes, I would not
recommend this party.  However, to those that are going and are excited
about it, I wish you the best.  Tastes differ, and if you are willing to
give this party a shot, go for it.  Hopefully the music will be good.
I'll be interested in the reviews on monday, so do take notes!! :P My
money will be spent elsewhere that evening (even a root canal being
preferable!!! :) hehehe  :)

-kirsten

Sumpin funny just happened at work.  Bossman, who's a real nice guy, asks,
"so what's up for the weekend?  heavy drugs?"  (he's just kidding - little
does he know, ha ha ha) So I laugh, noncomittal.  He goes, "hmmm!  that
wasn't a denial" (more joking) and I just laugh again (I always have
trouble lying outright).  Then he tells me there used to be an employee
here (a doctoral student in my department here at Cal!) who would
periodically call in sick Monday mornings, explaining he'd been out "at
rave parties" all weekend and just couldn't make it in.  Now there's an
honest employee! 

And I just laughed again, keeping any opinion to myself.

When I call in sick, I pretend I have the flu!

Shortly after I arrived at the DJ convention in Las Vegas, I headed into the
hotel.  After I dropped my records off in the suite, I hung my headphones
around my neck (cause that's what DJ's do), and sluffed my stinkin' butt off
to the hotel lounge.

And hanging out over at the bar, who should it be but Sandra Collins and
Keoki.  Now, I've heard that these kids like to party, but who'da thunk that
Destiny would land me so close to them?

"Boomerang,"  says  I.  "This here is your chance to make it with the big
kids.  Now you get your pink little ass over there and start hob-nobbing."

So, taking my own advice, as I sometimes do, I lit up a Camel and saddled on
up to the bar.  "Hey guys," I say.  "Next round's on me, huh?"

Sandra Collins got a sparkle in her eye, but Keoki, that techno problem
child, he says,  "Hey!  I'm a supastar!  What makes you think you can waltz
your pink little ambient room Enya-playing ass in here and just start buying
me drinks?"

"Well," says I, ever with the quick retort.  "Let's start with 25 greenbacks
that says I can drink your tattooed, nosering-wearing ass under the table."

"Oh yeah?"  says Keoki.

"Yeah!" says I.

Then Sandra Collins says, "Shoot, I'll drink both of you sucka Dj's under
the table."

"Bartender!"  I cried.  "Line 'em up and keep 'em coming."

So after Mr. Keoki realized that I was /the/ boomerang fidget, we became
fast chums.  Kindred spirits were we, sharing a comeraderie like two ships
that pass in the night.

And so the drinks were poured with careless fluidity, and we three
superstars were headed down that one-way boulevard to oblivion.

At 11 o'clock the beerjerk gave us the boot, on account of the embarrassment
we'd caused to the Women's Auxillary Knitting Club a little earlier.

Out on the boulevard, we hired a cab and set off to the closest watering
hole, which turned out to be a dirty old cowboy joint at the end of a dark
alley.  After a few rounds here, Ms. Collins and I agreed that old Keoki was
slowing us down, so for the better good, we ditched him in the can and left
to find a larger bar with stronger drinks, where we could finish the bet.

When I awoke the next morning, I was shocked and horrified to discover
that'd I'd slept in the fountain in front of Caesar's Palace.   My head was
pounding like gabbercore on crack, and the hole in my wallet suggested that
Ms. Collins had won our little wager.  Ms. Collins, however, was nowhere to
be found.   And lo and behold, I was appalled to find that my headphones
were missing!

In a panic, I rushed back to the hotel.  Once I'd changed into dry clothes,
I racked my brain for clues to the case of the missing headphones.  The
night before was a blur of lemon wedges and cocktail swords, but I had a
fleeting memory of the very last bar I'd been in the night before--a bar
that shone as if lit by angels, encased in gold and twinkling with heavenly
brilliance.  It was the most regal of meadhalls, a stately palace designed
for the elite of alcoholics.

Had it been a dream, or...?  There was a chance, a dim hope, that I had left
my precious headphones there, and perhaps they had been found by the barkeep
or the bouncer.

With phonebook between my knees, I dialed the number of every bar in town,
asking each proprietor if his tavern shone a golden glow like the chambers
of God.  For an hour I dialed and queried, with no luck.  As I was just
about to give up on my beloved headphones, there was a trace of hope.

"Sir,"  I asked the bartender.  "Does your establishment glimmer like all
the jewels of Providence?"

"It does, young man."

"Goodness gracious.  Are the stools, and the bar made of gold, and are the
napkins lined with that precious metal?"

"You are right again, young fellow."

"And your toilets, are they gold as well?"

"Ermm, can you hold on for a moment?"  the bartender asked. "Hey, Rufus!"
he shouted.  "I think I found the bastard who took a dump in your saxophone
last night!" 


Later,

b))merang

quick question Sharif why did you join SF raves, for the community or for
the information?

I feel that one thing we all have in common is that we all have had some
thing to do with rave at one time or another that is all we definately
have in common, past that we all differ in some way be it in our views,
morality, sexual preference, hair color, political standing, education
level, etc, etc,,, and we all have different things we post on this list
(which for the most part seems to be unmoderated(SP???) ) it is our choice
on if we stay part of this "community" by if we stay subscribed or not;
 
Anyway the point I'm tring to make is that this list is filled with many
differing souls that get different things from the list; if you "fight"
for not posting things like this "ufo related stuff" then you close off
part of our freedom of expression and who we are hence making an effort
towards destroying the community which I feel is the purpose of this list,
there are other ways of getting "pure" rave related info besides reading
SFraves digest/mail

One more question why not have the NRR tag it warn you that there isn't
"pure" rave content contained giving us people who like to post the other
stuff we want to express to our fellow ravers a way to do just that i.e.
letting people know about stuff we learn, hear, and /or experience outside
of raves.

Thanks for listening ( reading[ viewing{ browsing <Scrolling> } ] ) oh you
get the point

Subject: Re: Dance music on the radio (BSP)

             <333CC3AA.2ACB@entasis.com> 
Date: Sat, 29 Mar 97 08:59:05 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

> Speaking of which, I will be spinning on KALX (90.7)- the UC Berkeley
> radio station this Sunday night (Monday Morning 3.30.97-3.31.97) from
> Midnight to 1:00a.m.  

Sounds good, I'll try to give it a listen. Does anybody happen to know
the  Schedule of interesting music played on KALX? I just moved to a
different neighborhood in SF (upper noe valley) which caused me to lose
reception of my favorite station -- KFJC 89.7 -- but gain strong
reception of KALX 90.7 and  KPOO 89.5, plus weak reception of KZSU
90.1...

Unfortunately, I find KALX's music coverage and consistency to be 
extremely and annoyingly divergent, one moment they're playing  lame
70's-burnout music (Journey and REO SPeedwagon, bletch), then cutesy
rainbows-and-unicorns forgotten fluff-psychedelia from the 60's, then
gregorian chants, then keltic skin-flute jigs, then, French bistro
music, and then, if you haven't turned off the radio yet, you'll stumble
on an excellent techno/jungle/acid-jazz/reggae/dub/trance/etc.
And you never know if you're going to tune in and hear some lame
talk-show where they drone on for hours on end about issues that are
relevant to (no doubt) very few of their listening audience.

Is there some kind of method to KALX's madness? 

Is there a known schedule of kinds-of-music played? Or a list of DJ's,
kind of music they play, and timeslots?

> hunter_gatherer_

Is that the shirtless male variety, or the fur-wearing variety?

My Review

I guess it's time for me to either:

1. Grow up and face the facts

2. Bitch about how this was not a Rave, it was a freakin High School, no
make that a Junior high school dance.  What a f((((ckin  embarrasement. 
What was with the monitor Moms at the door?

How did these people ever think this was a Rave?  I don't want to get
down on someone trying to organize a party; but these people are
definately promoting the feeling that the scene is over and dead.  

Sorry but it really sucked.

An embarrassement to anyone and everyone over the age of five.

It was in the commmunity center!!//??  What the ???

Add these wanks to the list of Never Again.

Sorry, but we couldn't keep it in and the group consensus (sp?) was they
wasted our time and our minds.

Oh well, it's an insanely beautiful morning and we're going to Tangerine
Falls (an incredible 200 foot waterfall on the West Fork of Cold Springs
Trail in the Foothills of Montecito - check it out if your in SB!) then
on to the beach!!!

Thanks for the post.  This was a beautiful party.  Myster-E's set was
incredible! Lots of smiles, great vibe, nice  space and information 
exchange, e.g. the lovely flyers, holding prayers, insight, etc. as you 
walked in.. The main room was humid...and at one point it felt as if rain 
were lightly falling...one dancer ironically was wearing a T-shirt whose 
back read, "Dancing in the Rain"...  :)  Drawbacks, cig smoke and lack of 
adequate toilets per crowd size.....
Love the black lights and all the dancers wearing glowing clothing...
My friend and I had to leave early due to prior committments today...we 
danced out asses off for over three hours.  Myster-E spun a mix from my 
favorite SF film of all time... CE3K...Nebula 9:  Contact Me.  I hope 
this is out there on CD!!!!!!!!!!!  Thanks and blessings to all who put 
this one on....and toall the dances..

> quick question Sharif why did you join SF raves, for the community or for
> the information?

for information about raves, raving, music at raves, reviews of raves, busts
of raves, rave laminates, drugs at raves, live bands (daft punk, etc.), sexual
freedom or lack of at raves

not for engagement announcements, bumper sticker sayings, ufo mumbojumbo,
jokes, urban legends, virus announcements, mandela rallies

> (which for the most part seems to be unmoderated(SP???) ) it is our choice
> on if we stay part of this "community" by if we stay subscribed or not;

> Anyway the point I'm tring to make is that this list is filled with many
> differing souls that get different things from the list; if you "fight"
> for not posting things like this "ufo related stuff" then you close off
> part of our freedom of expression and who we are hence making an effort
> towards destroying the community which I feel is the purpose of this list,
> there are other ways of getting "pure" rave related info besides reading
> SFraves digest/mail

my friend, i understand exactly what u are saying and i agree wholeheartedly
but any person with half a brain and an ounce of logic can conclude that ufo
mass suicide k-rap does not belong here ... sense of community is fine ...
but let's be realistic and logical here ... do not mail to sfraves just b/c
it reaches a lot of people ... the only thread that is common to *all*
members of this list is raves/raving ... why one would assume that a majority
of subscribers would appreciate a ufo post is beyond me ... let's stick to
raving community not ufo community

> One more question why not have the NRR tag it warn you that there isn't
> "pure" rave content contained giving us people who like to post the other
> stuff we want to express to our fellow ravers a way to do just that i.e.
> letting people know about stuff we learn, hear, and /or experience outside
> of raves.

how about a separate mailing list called community@hyperreal.com ... that's
how sfraves was created ... we didn't all start sending posts posts to the ufo
list ...

> Thanks for listening ( reading[ viewing{ browsing <Scrolling> } ] ) oh you
> get the point

I appreciate your constructive response ... hopefully mine will be too

PS. I really would like to have a vote somehow of who agrees with me ... i
don't know an easy way to do that but it would be interesting

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Mar 29 13:33:18 1997

Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: re to nrr = not rave related 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Sat, 29 Mar 97 12:27:04 PST."
             <199703292027.AA04805@crl.crl.com> 
Date: Sat, 29 Mar 97 13:33:08 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> but any person with half a brain and an ounce of logic can conclude that ufo
> mass suicide k-rap does not belong here ... sense of community is fine ...
> but let's be realistic and logical here ... do not mail to sfraves just b/c
> it reaches a lot of people ... the only thread that is common to *all*
> members of this list is raves/raving ... why one would assume that a majority
> of subscribers would appreciate a ufo post is beyond me ... let's stick to
> raving community not ufo community

The UFO thing is a big part of rave culture, so a posting discussing
the untimely demise of people following this kind of social idea (or
mneme) is somewhat relevant. And then there's the cult tie-in -- many
feel the rave scene is somewhat cult like; and then there's the 
web/internet tie-in, many ravers are wired in to this scene as well.

I think the UFO thing in the rave scene started as a joke, or perhaps
out of the consensual hallucinations of people mind-expanding together.
This whole metaphor for a "beyond" of this-mortal-coil (no not the one
you left steaming in the toilet) seems to be a human need that can be
fulfilled by a wide range of bullshit-beliefs. Pick your poison. Seems
that when some have had enough of the inexplicables of traditional
judeo/christianity (like a god that could give a flying fuck about the
actions of any single ant-like human) you can go on to think that
there's aliens out there that give a fuck about you too. 

I personally think the whole alien thing is a joke, and I appreciate it
when people go into alien-babble the same way I appreciate it when
people go into church of the subgenius babble -- as pure
cynesacreligion and "mockery science." It's sometimes good to look
under your bed and realize that the only monsters hiding there is
humanity/belief/faith itself.

Unfortunately, some people feel the implicit need to replace the
outmoded bullshit that their parents  believed in (i.e. literalist
(mis)interpretations of the literature of Judaism, Christianity, 
Islam, Hinduism, etc) with new bullshit that is more relevant to our
time and our space/technology-aware culture and art (e.g. Sci-Fi
movies). So instead of book-of-revelations crap about transcending
one's physical body and rising into heaven, we can now assume that
aliens trailing a passing commet will do the job for ya... Whatever.

It's such a waste when methaphors are given literal beliefs. Next thing
you know people are killing each other over misinterpreations of
metaphors in their religious literature. And some take it so seriously
that if they beome enthralled with a charismatic leader, and kill
themselves because they're following the warped and sexually repressed
mind of said leader.

I think it's important to bring this stuff up (and discuss) because
this scene seems like a good place to cull easily-suggestible cult
members. To some extent, the rave scene  is already somewhat like a
cult, and appears this way to many outsiders.

Perhaps religion/faith/belief is the ultimate form of human population
control.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

Precedence: bulk

>People of this wonderful HOUSE NATION, What's Goin' On?!!?

same as it ever was... same as it ever was....

it goes like this: people discover something beautiful that isn't in line
with mainstream (wealth/power/dominance paradigm) values... a
counterculture/underground develops... the mainstream (thru the media,
their most poweful tool/weapon) simultaneously demonize and co-opt the
counterculture... the counterculture evolves, taking with it those who are
true to it, and leaving everyone else behind to become part of the
mainstream once again.

10 or 20 years from now the rave scene may not exist in any recognizable
form, or it may... it depends partly on us and partly on how intent the
powers-that-be are on curtailing us... but it will all evolve, and the
values that underlie raving will always be there for us to choose to live
by, with or without any specific incarnation thereof.

love,

brian

>PS. I really would like to have a vote somehow of who agrees with me

>don't know an easy way to do that but it would be interesting

 Both of you have good points. I feel that there are several subjects
that are
not directly about raves but interesting to a lot of people here...like
ufo's.
If you notice at raves there are alien stickers,pictures etc all over.
Personally
i enjoy seeing things besides pure info. These other subjects give the
list
life and gives us a chance to see what others are like and what is on
their mind.
This helps build a sense of community and the NRR tag should protect
those that just want pure info. Plus there are several good web sites
like brians where one can get "just info" if that is all you want.

when something major happens in the world like "heavens gate"  or
an earthquake or something then some people like to talk about it
and a healthy community provides a place for that. Personally i 
would prefer to hear what other ravers and people that have similar
beliefs and interest to mine have to say about these things than
the mainstream news and CNN. Ted Turnner, president of CNN
said he was happy about the mass suicide..."great way to get rid
of a few nuts" was his response. I dont know about other ppl 
but i enjoyed the posts here more than stuff like that from CNN

So my vote is to keep the aliens...even if they dont have a green card.

foolish fish

[ to SFRaves ]

 Every once and awhile, someone includes some anti-club comment in
an SFRaves post ( I probably have too ). 

 However - doesn't the San Francisco rave scene have its roots in
"after parties" ? A crowd at a dance club would be experiencing 
and sharing such a good time ( vibe !?! ) that when the legally
mandated closing time came around, some of the clubbers and DJs 
cooperated to continue the "vibe" with someone's sound system at
some other location ( a warehouse, outdoors, someone's garage ).

 Please, old school ravers, clue me in !

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

             <199703292216.OAA11176@netcom21.netcom.com>

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

>However - doesn't the San Francisco rave scene have its roots in
>"after parties" ? A crowd at a dance club would be experiencing 
>and sharing such a good time ( vibe !?! ) that when the legally
>mandated closing time came around, some of the clubbers and DJs 
>cooperated to continue the "vibe" with someone's sound system at
>some other location ( a warehouse, outdoors, someone's garage ).

in the mid-80's I used to go out clubbing in SF and lots of the clubs,
especially the underground or "invite only" ones, though clubby,
weren't all that different from the raves of today. and in a lot of
ways they were more interesting because it was a little more wild with
a better representation from the gay/transgender/dragqueen crowd than
you get in today's scene, and a lot more african americans too. i'm
thinking of places like the DV8 opening party, GLASHaus, Trocadero
Transfer, and a slew of undergrounds whose names i can't remember. I
also vaguely recall some outdoor soundsystem-parties at china cove in
88? These were ravey in the sense that it was ok to just dance -- as
opposed to dance-with-someone. And they were ravey in that people got
dressed up pretty weird too. They were clubby in that the vibe wasn't
that friendly or open.

I also went to some "clubs" in NYC in the early/mid 80's that were
pretty rave-like as well -- e.g. the Palladium back in the early 80's,
Save the Robots,  etc. Ravey in that it brought out all the freaky NY
club kids. Unravey (in theory) because it seemed very cliquish. Very
unravey if you considered you had to stand outside in some stupid
line-up and they'd only allow in the photogenically inclined and/or
club-kid-dressed. Above I said "in theory" because although people talk
about the rave scene like it isn't at all cliquish, I find it to be
more and more cliquish all the time, and then there's the fashion
police too.

Ok, i'm going to quit posting and get back to work now. I'm leaving for
a work-trip to India soon and I'm nowhere close to being done!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.970329164229.15598A-100000@value.net>

Dear All;

	I was at Lightseed lastnight, and unfortuately in a miserable
mood. I only felt like communicating with a few people last night, and the
and few people I did communicate with didn't really seem to be interested
in me, only if I was doing speed; what has happened to our scene? I also
became more aware of some awful and untrue roomers going around about
myself. 

	So I would like to take a moment to talk about OUR scene, set the
record straight about myself, and ask for help for myself from people who
say they are responsible, accountable & care. In return for your help, we
would be helping others by reducing the availability of a chemical that is
destorying the lives of so many of us, and until recently myself included.

	So first let me set the record straight about myself; I have
never, ever participated in the manufacture, and or distrubution of speed; 
however that is not to say that I don't have knowledge of such
people(other than myself), places & things.

	I'm currently recovering from P.T.S.D ( Post Traumtic Stress
Disorder ), which stems from extreme sexual & physical trauma from the
first 20 years of my life. Which means when my parents use to
say we love you, that meant violence, pain, humiliation, embrassement,
fear, inappropreiate behaviour & conduct directed at me, disrespect,
neglect, ..etc on a DAILY level for 20 years.

	Anything else you have heard about me, from persons other than
myself is just simply untrue, and is hurting me. If you don't communicate
with myself and the topic is about me, than you are living in your
imagenation. This also applies to anyone else in your life; for if your
talking about another human being, and you are drawing conclusions about
that person without getting input directly from them, then your
conclusion is unfounded.

	I don't want your pity, I however desperately need and want your
support, for what I'm asking for I can't do by myself, get in a job, or a
therapy office/hospital, I can't educate myself with books or classes, it
doesn't come from a pill or a drug, reiligion doesn't offer it, and you
won't get it in a self help 12 step program. I assure you I have tried all
of the above to varing degrees and I'm still alone and in pain. 

	What I'm asking for comes from human beings, preferablly healthly
ones that have their lives invested in the self(people who make healthy
descions about themselves), karma, and community; however it still feels
good even if your sick. Most of the time I'm terrified to ask someone for
affection. Affection being complicated like sex, or something as simply
as putting your arms around me and spending a little time. I often feel
like one of Harlow's moneys, the one who got the wire & steel effigy of a
parent. I don't feel I have the right to ask another human being to help
me with something that is clearly not their problem or responisibility.

	I feel a lot of you want to help, I feel more of you want to help
but don't know want to do. So if you see me try putting your arms around
me, I don't care what you look like, I don't care if you don't know what
to say, I don't care if you need to state your boundries and put limits on
the affection, I don't care just please do it because I don't want to be
alone anymore.

	So what do you get out of it, my promise to continue working on
all of things I mentioned above so that I continue having a healthly life
and not relapse. My promise to put the people I know who make and
distrubute speed on notice that their product is not welcome in humanity
anymore, and if they don't listen; than TOGETHER WE will put them on
notice, and continue to increase the pressure until this war machince drug
is no more. However, I will not partciapte in or condone the TORTURE of
addicted HUMAN BEINGS that I've been subjected to over the past year by
unmentioned persons. You might even be able to talk me into returning you
affection with a really nice massage, considering I am a licensed massage
therapist, go figure. But most of all you will see an immediate and
positive change in myself. For out of the 34 years I've been on this
planet the only time I can truely say I was happy was when my one and only
girlfriend was in my life for 6 months, and the 6 months I was in massage
school. I was on the right track, just not long enough 1 outta 34 is
pretty bad. 

	Sorry if this clutters your mailbox, I'm miserable, and in
terrible pain and I just don't know what else to do to help myself.

Sincerely
Brian

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Sat, 29 Mar 1997, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> Unfortunately, I find KALX's music coverage and consistency to be 
> extremely and annoyingly divergent, one moment they're playing  lame
> 70's-burnout music (Journey and REO SPeedwagon, bletch), then cutesy
> rainbows-and-unicorns forgotten fluff-psychedelia from the 60's, then
> gregorian chants, then keltic skin-flute jigs, then, French bistro
> music, and then, if you haven't turned off the radio yet, you'll stumble
> on an excellent techno/jungle/acid-jazz/reggae/dub/trance/etc.
> And you never know if you're going to tune in and hear some lame
> talk-show where they drone on for hours on end about issues that are
> relevant to (no doubt) very few of their listening audience.
> 
> Is there some kind of method to KALX's madness? 

You just described it.  When I was there it was required that you play at
least three different genres of music in a single show, and a certain
large percentage of your songs had to be pulled from a bin of "current"
music which was all over the place as well.  Since I was only let near the
control boards between 3 and 6 in the morning I used to satisfy that
requirement by playing three genres simultaneously (say, the Orb +
Lawrence Welk + the Breeders). 

> Is there a known schedule of kinds-of-music played? Or a list of DJ's,
> kind of music they play, and timeslots?

http://www-oms.berkeley.edu/kalx/schedtab.htm

Do I have to do your search engine queries for you now?  :)

	Brian

--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=--
brian@hyperreal.com     http://www.apache.org     http://www.organic.com/jobs

On Sat, 29 Mar 1997, Sharif Torpis wrote:
> how about a separate mailing list called community@hyperreal.com ...
> that's how sfraves was created ... we didn't all start sending posts
> posts to the ufo list ...

No way, not on my bandwidth!  

There is the "abducted" mailing list @ hyperreal...

  http://hyperreal.com/abducted/

for all you ufo freaks.

> PS. I really would like to have a vote somehow of who agrees with me ... i
> don't know an easy way to do that but it would be interesting

I feel that *sometimes* the NRR traffic gets so high that even people
who'd like to enjoy some off-beat-but-still-countercultural-related
discussions are prevented from doing that simply because of the volume.
Mostly these folks are not sophisticated enough to know how to use filters
either, and just throw their hands up and leave.  This list has very high
turnover.  

So, I don't have a problem with NRR posts being on the list, but anyone
who thinks they can post anything and everything so long as they label it
"NRR" is doing the community a disservice.  Just be considerate.

By the way, a digest version is now set up (as many of you probably know),
and a "best-of-sfraves" list is being considered....

	Brian

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Lightseed
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9703291941.A2134-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Another great party at Cyberorganic... I get a warm feeling whenever I go 
there, just 'cause I know the Cyber folks are cool and, being a small 
community space fitting 400, it's always a UG!

Beautiful decorations and I especially appreciated the many flyers 
holding inspirational sayings and reminders... reminders of what we're 
creating here and what we should be mindful of as we enter a sacred 
space.  The promoters taking responsibility for guiding us in this way is 
crucial, I think.  It is easy to think of it as "just a party," and if 
that's our mindset, that's what it is.  Just taking a moment to reflect 
on the phenomenon of community and freedom and the positive energy 
fomented with the input of 400 people is enough to start a beautiful ball 
of light growing.  A "lightseed," if you will.

I just wonder if the majority of people approach it that way.  I was 
dismayed to realize I didn't know 95% of the people there, and they were 
all so young.  I probably don't know them because they're all newbies 
(and I don't go to high school with them :P!)  I have tried to put 
"ageism" behind me, but I do have trouble with partying with people 10 
years younger than me.  I rave because I love the music and the 
environment, and I have to wonder why more people my own age aren't 
there.  I've hung out in the bars and clubs of the 20-something scene, 
and a lot of it sucks!  Where are my peers - more importantly, how come 
they don't have any taste?!  I worry that the youth aspect of raving will 
eventually drive me out... I look around and see some faces that are so 
babyish still and I'm finding it harder to surrender myself to the scene 
and the vibe when I'm disturbed by 14 year olds on acid...

Maybe that's why I'm not a chill room person.  But last night, the
dancefloor was the place to be!  14 or 80, I don't care when we're getting
down on the dancefloor (e-piles of children with vacant eyes are what's
most distressing to me, I suppose!).  The dancefloor went off, incredible
energy.  Whistles and yells and glowsticks and smiling dancers - but part
of me knows that the greatest enthusiasm comes from the younger,
"candyravers," and I love them for that.  Last night, though, I discovered
gold, and her name is Anna.  Can this woman rock a dance floor! 
Thickest trance and everyone was jumping, despite the heat and 
condensation.  Fantasies of cool comfortable roomy clean places to 
dance... will the underground never have a perfect location??

Thanks to the crew and dj's for all the work put into the party, it showed.
And goddamn, when is Anna spinning again?!

til next time!  :)

Yes! Exactly how I was turned on to "raving" in Chicago.  The true
clubbers would bail around 2 and hit some warehouse - and it would go
off!!!  Leaving the clubs also had to do with overcrowding by the
suburbanites who would be there to stand and stare (never could figure
out how they kept their bodies from grooving at least a little).

The Gay/Lesbian thing - it was the Berlin crew (full-on gay dance bar in
Chicago before it got over hyped in Playboy) that turned me on to the
afterhours UGs - and I am not gay - it's just that in Chi-town it is the
Gay/Les crowd that know how to dance and party to extremes.

------- Blind-Carbon-Copy

Subject: it's finally time to throw away yer fucking guitars kiddies!
Date: Sun, 30 Mar 97 15:32:40 -0800

http://www.latimes.com/HOME/NEWS/SUNCAL/t000028455.html
   
   CAN techno SAVE ROCK & ROLL? 
   
   The synthesized beats and soundscapes have transfixed
   Europeans, major rock artists and a sales-hungry music industry. But
   will America catch dance fever?
   
   By ROBERT HILBURN, STEVE HOCHMAN
   
   'No, no, no," the president of one of the biggest record labels
   in the world shouts in mock horror. "Don't say that word. All this
   talk about techno being the next big thing in pop is starting to drive
   me crazy.
    "I just had a call from one of the most respected artists in the
   world. . . . Someone who has been around for years and who has nothing
   to do with this music. But he's nervous about it and wants to know
   whether he should hire remixers to do techno versions of his new
   songs. He hasn't even written the songs yet and he's asking about
   remixes."
    The harried executive isn't alone in his frustration.
   Shaken by flat album sales over the last three years, the
   $12-billion-a-year record industry is searching desperately for
   something--anything--to help reignite consumer interest in shiny
   compact discs.
   In the four months since MTV shook up the industry by announcing
   that it was adding a techno program to its lineup, techno has emerged
   in the eyes of trend-watchers as the next big thing.
   "Trent Reznor said something smart: Music needs to be dangerous,
   needs an edge to it," says Steven Baker, president of Warner Bros.
   Records. "Techno has an element of that. The beats are kind of
   frightening. It gives its audience an identity, almost as if you are
   in a special fraternity."
   There is a revolutionary, rebellious feel to techno--and its
   accompanying all-night, drug-charged club and rave scenes--that could
   appeal to young record buyers looking for a way to separate themselves
   from the music and styles of past generations.
   Rather than traditional pop-rock elements, the emphasis in
   techno--or dance music, as supporters of the genre prefer to call
   it--is on frantic or calming soundscapes, mostly created by
   synthesizers and sampling.
   The British-led movement has been hot in Europe for years, and
   has already generated enough excitement among rock musicians for many
   of them, including U2 and David Bowie, to employ dance textures in
   their new albums. Recording under the pseudonym x-sample, guitar
   legend Eric Clapton has made a techno-influenced album as part of a
   duo billed as T.D.F.
   Not wanting to be left behind if there is a cultural and
   commercial shift to techno, many executives, artists and managers are
   trying quickly to figure out their place in this new, mysterious
   world--with its strange-sounding subgenres such as trip-hop and
   jungle--and a new collection of stars, from the Prodigy to the
   Chemical Brothers.
   The race is on to sign techno artists--just in case something
   explodes. Radio is experimenting with dance formats--notably "Groove
   Radio" (103.1 FM) in L.A.--and the music will be showcased in a
   high-profile tour this summer.
   "It's like a fever," says one label president.
   But is all this activity genuine heat that will warm up the sales
   of records, or just "Saturday Night Fever" redux, a replay of the '70s
   disco era that produced hit records but not career artists?
   "[So far] there's not only no smoke, but there's no fire," says
   Mike Shalett, chief operating officer of SoundScan, which monitors
   U.S. record sales. Together, the 10 most high-profile dance-related
   albums of the '90s have sold only 1.1 million copies here. That's less
   than half the sales of the second Hootie & the Blowfish album, which
   has been widely perceived in the industry as a disappointment, after
   the group's previous album sold 9 million copies.
   In a survey of more than a dozen U.S. record executives by
   Calendar, only one thought there was even remotely enough evidence to
   justify calling techno "the next big thing."
   "All this talk about the end of alternative rock and the birth of
   techno is just distracting," says Don Ienner, president of Columbia
   Records, summarizing the majority view. "As an industry, we tend to
   have a lemmings quality and go chasing after things. But we need to
   keep focused and search for great stars and great songs.
   "Techno is only sonically enhancing or dressing up what you have.
   You can put whatever dress or suit you want on any person. It's the
   artist and the song, not what suit you're wearing."
   Roy Lott, executive vice president and general manager of Arista
   Records, agrees: "Grunge didn't happen because record companies said
   it was the next big thing. It happened because Kurt Cobain and Eddie
   Vedder came along and wrote songs that millions of people identify
   with. You always make a mistake by signing genres rather than
   artists."
   * * * So, what's the case for techno?
   Mainstream pop-rock certainly needs help. The traditional
   textures were wearing thin by the early '80s, prompting such respected
   artists as Paul Simon, Peter Gabriel, David Byrne and Sting to look to
   world music, among other movements, for inspiration. Others, including
   Nine Inch Nails' Trent Reznor, later began focusing on techno.
   Not to be confused with mostly witless elements of disco, the
   best of techno music has substance and sophistication. These records
   are built around imaginative rhythm patterns that express all the
   emotional colors, from exhilaration to despair, that we are used to in
   pop.
   Just as with its musical cousin hip-hop, there'll continue to be
   a hard-core factor in techno that will probably appeal only to a cult.
   But some techno artists may mix and match with pop and rock the same
   way some best-selling hip-hop artists have done. Indeed, the influence
   of techno and hip-hop has already been felt in the works of such
   pop-rock bestsellers as Reznor and Beck.
   "As far as major labels investing a lot of money in this, the
   commercial potential is enormous and these investments are positive,"
   says Jason Bentley, the respected deejay who appears on both public
   station KCRW-FM (89.9) and commercial powerhouse KROQ-FM (106.7) and
   is co-head of Quango Records, a techno and dance-oriented label
   distributed by Island.
   "In a way, this is the first international pop phenomenon--this
   club culture, this techno culture, this use of technology," he says.
   "So when it's grounded in that success, there's certainly commercial
   potential here."
   And some retailers do sense some commercial smoke, even if it is
   just a wisp at this point.
   "There's really been a lack of anything new for people to get
   excited about and this really does seem to be having an effect," says
   Bob Bell, new music buyer for the Wherehouse retail chain.
   "These bands all have alternative credibility, and in terms of
   radio airplay they're doing the most important thing--making a really
   strong single that radio can support.
   "Sometimes you have these bands with great buzz and people
   talking about the album, but if you don't have one hit song, it
   doesn't happen. But when you get the combination of street-level buzz
   and a song radio can get behind, that makes hit records."
   But will radio get behind the genre as a whole, beyond just
   specific acts and songs?
   That's unlikely, says Jeff Pollack, a Los Angeles-based radio
   programming consultant with more than 100 client stations in the U.S.
   and Europe.
   "The passion level is very high for this music, and that's
   great," he says. "The problem is, how many people will be able to
   really get into it and want to be a part of it with that full
   commitment? A lot of people would find that just too fatiguing. So it
   might make sense for a radio station to be built entirely on that [to
   serve the serious fans]. But most people need something a little more
   multidimensional."
   The techno wildfire in pop began when MTV President Judy McGrath
   spoke at the Billboard Conference in November and mentioned the launch
   of the techno-ambient video showcase "Amp" and the programming of such
   techno acts as Prodigy and the Chemical Brothers as a central part of
   the channel's new agenda.
   The key was the timing.
   If the announcement had come two years earlier, when Hootie & the
   Blowfish were on a roll and Pearl Jam was selling almost a million
   copies in a week, no one would have probably paid attention. Techno
   was being dismissed at the time by much of the industry as simply
   dance music that couldn't break out of its cult audience.
   By last fall, however, record execs had been shocked to see one
   after another of their bestsellers--from Pearl Jam and Green Day to
   Hootie and R.E.M.--nose-dive commercially. Against that backdrop, the
   MTV pronouncement hit the industry hard.
   "It makes me sick to think that MTV caused all this fuss in the
   industry, but I'm sure it did," says Howie Klein, president of Reprise
   Records. "I'm not trying to dis MTV, but we should be taking our cues
   from the artist and the kid in the street, not each other."
   Even MTV, one senses, is a touch embarrassed by the commotion
   over its November announcement.
   Within the channel itself, McGrath's speech was not viewed as a
   declaration of a new direction, but merely a roundup of some new
   elements being incorporated into the programming.
   "We're not zeroing in on [techno] and we don't think it's the
   next big thing," says Andy Schuon, MTV executive vice president.
   "We're not running conventional singer-songwriters out of town on a
   rail, by any means.
   "It's just another interesting style as we're trying to widen our
   net and explore things. We're playing just as much Spice Girls and pop
   acts and singer-songwriters. There's a revolution--the Wallflowers and
   Jewel and people like that. Maybe that's the next big thing. Funny
   that people picked up on electronica, not that."
   Schuon even believes it would be a mistake to place "Amp"
   alongside such past programs as "Yo! MTV Raps," "Headbangers Ball" and
   "120 Minutes," which served in the past as launching pads for dominant
   roles on MTV--and then in pop culture--of hip-hop, heavy metal and
   alternative rock, respectively.
   In fact, Schuon says, "Amp" is designed to maintain a pure
   feeling of the style, true to the club culture from which it comes.
   And that may be hard to translate into mainstream programming.
   "Amp" producer Todd Mueller explains, "One of our prime concerns
   is to retain the deejay ethic and think about the music as beats and
   rhythms and show how they work together--approach the show as a solid
   block of entertainment as opposed to individual clips.
   "It was a conscious decision for us not to deal with this music
   in terms of personalities. We've even removed the talking head
   veejays, and we frame it by saying these beats and rhythms are the
   stars."
   And that is most definitely not the future of MTV as a whole.
   "Will we have big mainframe computers as guests on [dance music
   program] 'The Grind'?" asks Schuon facetiously. "Not while I'm captain
   of the ship."
   Until the MTV announcement, techno was looked upon by the
   recording industry as simply one of several areas of potential growth.
   There was also talk that sales could be boosted by a new wave of
   lightweight pop (the Spice Girls), sunny teen rock (No Doubt),
   traditional pop (Celine Dion) or a soul revival (Tony Rich, D'Angelo).
   
   But the MTV statement started a buzz in the record company
   corridors and in the media about techno--probably because it is the
   most cutting-edge of the alternatives--that quickly escalated it to
   the forefront of the discussion. The news that U2 and other hit rock
   acts, including Oasis and the Smashing Pumpkins, were working with
   dance textures or artists heightened the interest.
   Nothing underscores the record industry's sudden obsession with
   techno better than the turnabout in interest by major U.S. record
   labels in the Prodigy, the high-profile British dance-related band
   that was dropped three years ago by Elektra Records.
   Labels started rethinking Prodigy's commercial potential in this
   country last summer after the single "Firestarter" and its video
   caused a buzz on both sides of the Atlantic. It intensified in
   November after MTV mentioned Prodigy in its decision to put more
   emphasis on techno acts.
   Another reason so many companies--including Interscope, Columbia
   and Warner Bros.--were eager for the Prodigy is that the group looks
   like a rock band. On the whole, techno acts have tended to be a rather
   faceless bunch that places more emphasis on their sounds than on their
   public identities.
   The Prodigy fit that pattern in its Elektra days. But the band
   went through a dramatic visual transformation that made it look on
   casual glance like the Sex Pistols--complete with a spike-haired lead
   singer, Keith Flint. Even the music has something of the unruly,
   liberating energy of the Pistols.
   Maverick Records, home of Alanis Morissette, eventually won the
   multimillion-dollar competition for the Prodigy, whose new album is
   expected early this summer. The "Firestarter" single has sold an
   estimated 225,000 copies in the U.S. The band's May 28 date at the
   Mayan Theatre is sold out.
   The performance of that album--and a collection due April 8 from
   the Chemical Brothers--is likely to be widely viewed as a test of the
   commercial strength of techno music itself.
   Al Cafaro, chairman and CEO at A&M, warns against expecting
   immediate results.
   "If the Prodigy album is a bomb, you may have a lot of people who
   are saying techno is the next big thing suddenly declare techno dead
   and move on to something else," he says. "I think a purposeful
   exploration of techno music is the right thing to do, but you've got
   to look at it long term. If you think you are going to sign a techno
   band and see it blow up in two months, I think you are asking for
   trouble. . . ."
   Ironically, the dance music community is as anxious over all this
   "next big thing" talk as the record industry.
   Techno supporters are fearful that the millions being thrown at
   techno will lead to a watering down of the music and the culture.
   They say there are fundamental differences between techno and
   pop-rock that are not understood by executives, most of whom were
   raised on pop-rock. They see their music as more in the elite company
   of jazz and classical rather than something to be mass-marketed.
   In fact, many of the artists are reluctant to participate in the
   current media exposure of the scene and the big-label bidding wars.
   A prime example is Rabbit in the Moon, a Florida-based production
   combine that is among the most prized by dance music fans and
   consequently among the most coveted by the major labels.
   Rabbit member DJ Monk was reluctant to comment when contacted by
   The Times, explaining that he and his partners have strenuously
   avoided the press, especially after the spotlight was turned on techno
   in recent months.
   "We didn't get started in this for any rewards other than doing
   what we love," he says, noting that the combine has been a profitable
   enterprise via its own label, Hallucination, and by taking commissions
   to remix tracks by other artists, including one last year for Garbage.
   "We'll hear people out, but it's not really on our agenda."
   Musically, too, techno stands apart from mainstream pop. Its
   antecedents run from 20th century classical experimenters (Edgar
   Varese, Karlheinz Stockhausen) through such '70s progressive rock
   figures as Can and Faust and seminal electronic band Kraftwerk.
   The music found a home in the late '80s in England's dance clubs
   and in all-night raves that were held underground-fashion in abandoned
   warehouses. In the U.S., the rave scene caught on in such cities as
   Los Angeles and New York. More recently, that scene came aboveground,
   with promoters holding events at regular pop venues.
   "The nature of this music is it survives," says Tom Rowland, one
   half of the Chemical Brothers along with partner Ed Simons. "I'd been
   in regular bands with singers and stuff, and what I liked about
   [electronic music] is I could make it in my bedroom and Ed and I could
   press up [records and CDs] ourselves without having to deal with a
   record company and you can go to a club and see a couple of thousand
   people dancing to your record.
   "If someone in a big company office says, 'This is good this
   year,' and it's big for a while and then shifts back to not being that
   big, it doesn't matter. I can still make the music."
   Record execs aren't the only ones puzzled by techno. Mainstream
   fans are asking whether this new style, with all its synthesizers and
   intriguing soundscapes, will mean the end of rock 'n' roll and pop
   music as we know it.
   The execs see techno as being one of several styles influencing
   mainstream pop rock--as it is already felt in the work of such artists
   as Nine Inch Nails' Reznor, whose music combines marvelously
   traditional rock with techno-industrial fibers.
   Don't expect everyone to be sitting around in their rooms a year
   from now listening to 125-beat-per-minute records--the image that many
   pop fans have of techno--as their sole pop diet.
   The key, stressed again and again in interviews with executives,
   is signing great artists, whether they are in techno or alternative
   rock or soul or punk folk.
   "The same criteria always hold true: Find the great artist,
   someone who can touch you emotionally," says Gary Gersh, president and
   CEO of Capitol Records and the man who helped nurture Nirvana at
   Geffen Records.
   Like others questioned, A&M's Cafaro thinks techno will produce
   its share of exciting artists. "There is a lot of equipment being sold
   out there," he says. "Lots of gear, lots of keyboards, lots of
   computers. People are going to grow up with this technology and I do
   believe you are going to see artists coming down this pike."
   Jimmy Iovine, whose hugely profitable Interscope Records has been
   at the cutting edge of '90s music, feels the problem facing the
   industry is more than simply finding the next hot style. He thinks
   that all the corporate mergers in the '90s have put such pressure on
   executives to come up with immediate profits that the industry has
   lost its daring.
   "If kids aren't buying as many records, it's because we as an
   industry aren't inspiring them," he says. "Rather than be in bands,
   kids want to be computer whizzes or buy video games.
   "That's because Bill Gates is better than we are. I see my
   competition as Bill Gates. I have to do stuff that is more exciting
   than the video game he's creating. The issue is bigger than techno and
   alternative rock. It's all about inspiration." 
   
   - - -
   Robert Hilburn Is The Times' Pop Music Critic. Steve Hochman Writes
   About Pop Music for Calendar

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Mar 30 16:20:07 1997

Good Evening All.  Hope you all had a pleasant weekend and ate lots of
vegetarian ham at Grandma's house.

Although I didn't stay at Symbiosis the whole time...I kept coming back and
forth...I wanted to post a little props to Dave and Sam and Hope and some
of the other crew for their dedication to putting on a wonderful event.  I
didn't catch too much of the music...but it seemed like everyone enjoyed
themselves pretty well.  What I think I was most impressed about was the
amount of canned food they were able to collect!  That is truly wonderful.
Also whoever thought of bringing that big plastic drum with a spigot so we
could dispense filtered water...that was brilliant as well.  The
decorations I really liked.  They had a video projector set up
downstairs...but it turned off sometime in the middle of the night.  Too
bad.  I was gonna loan them my copy of "Star Trek :  Generations"  where
the Enterprise-D's saucer section crash-lands on a planet.  Next time.

Anyway.  I had a good time nstuff (hi jeff!)

Talk soon...Deep

Hi all!  ]=)

 Well, after a 30 hour nap I can give some of my impressions of this party.

 First off while I think the Cyborganic space is a fine place (although 
more bathrooms and more fresh air are in order) it is annoying that the 
Dance floor is downstairs and the "Ambient" room is upstairs.

 We had Lorin open up up stairs with some incredible 604! After Lorin was 
Centipede who played a more Trip Hop set. While Trip Hop is not my thang, 
Centipede was very good! He laid done some tasteful scratching and the 
music was unique and interesting (for me anyway).

 So if we have two DJ's upstairs, why not the whole main Dance floor? I 
felt sorry for the Lighting folks and the Video artist as they deserved a 
better space for their artistry.

 At this point I should say that Robin at Cyborganic was wonderful and 
very helpful throughout the entire experience!! (hugz!) Also the 
LightSeed Family were equally wonderful and supportive. This is a good 
group of people. Expect big things from them!!

 The first live group (Gamma Quadrant) was OK but I have heard the 
Psychedelic Rock Band sound so many times that it is hard to impress me 
there. Their drummer (who drove from LA for this party) WAS incredible!

 Next up was Rob Rayle who played some amazing techno! Then he had a 
bunch of dige' players jam with him. Very divine!

 I got my chance next (after being awake some 20 hours) after setting up 
decorations for eight hours and 6 hours of (sober) partying. I enjoyed 
what I was doing but was too tired to be very inspired. Especially nice 
was a surprise visit by Galena (of Galactic Dreamspell) who did some 
improv singing for us (Thank You!).

 I missed Myster-E's and Anon's sets (argh!!), but what I did hear in the 
dance floor was fine! Too bad it was too hot and wet down there.

 A very fine group of people was in attendance. Didn't see any signs of 
folks overindulging which was nice.

 Hello to Libby, Rebecca, Patrick (BA), Leslie, Jonathen (leftjab), 
Aaron, Ben, Christine, all the folks at LightSeed, Julia, Rob (of 
course), Robin, Anarch, Galena, Graham, and the many others I can't recall 
right now.

 Extra big hugz and thanks to; Rob Rayle, Martin Randall, Brendon and 
Dagny!! I couldn't have done it without you all.

much Love,

Ran D.Dreams 							408.427.1666



                                      (Namaste)

                                   -=*=-/
                                     ~

A big thank you goes out to the crew at Karam Loca for an excellent rave.
Granted, I had my doubts when the dance floor was empty at 12. By one, people
were dancing and we meet some of the nicest people ever found at a rave. It
wasn't too crowded so we actually had room to dance. The vibe was incredible.

the body, and the spirit. Thank you again to the crew!

  kiddies!
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>	If you actually read the whole article, you might have noticed a
>key point: so far the top ten techno artist put together have sold less
>than the 2d Hootie & the Blowfish record, which was considered a flop.
>I'm not going to hold my breath waiting for techno to go mainstream here.


I don't think that techno in its form as we know it now will hit
mainstream, it's just too out there, I think, for the general public.  But
"electronica", or electronically influenced music, is definitely starting
to creep into the mainstream.  I would not classify U2, David Bowie, or
even Prodigy or some of those other more techno-y groups as really being
techno in its pure form, as we know & love it.  I consider much of this to
be regular music, just as before, but with hints of electronica winding
through it.  Not true techno at all.  The general public, I think, would
not be ready for real techno, it would not appeal to them, and the
mainstream music producers know this.  Therefore, they will
alter/bastardize it to suit their needs, & to suit the appeal of the
general public.  So while yes, techno appears to be "the next big thing"
(Entertainment Magazine? C'mon on!), I agree with Rob that techno, in the
form we know of now, that which we hear at our parties, will not go
mainstream.  

-s

This was a nice party. Decorations were wonderful, and the music in the
upstairs room was a bit different than what I am used to hearing which is
a good thing. Don't seem to remember hearing the Beastie Boys at any other
party I have been to... The smoking "bubble" was really an interesting
idea, but it blocked any kind of relief from the intense heat. Going
downstairs to hear Myster-E for any length of time was out of the question
because it was sooo toasty... But when I did peek in it was indeed going
off. 

It was kinda funny, because I was sitting talking to Leslie(hi
Leslie!) saying "Geez, I don't know anyone here...." and now thinking back
on it, I did see quite a few people... Hello to Robin ;-), April(great
meeting you), Leftjab(sorry about the name thing!!!), Rob Rayle, Randy,
Amy, Wayne, Marcie and anyone else I may have forgotten in my forgetful

From: Jim Rosenfield <jnr@cinenet.net>
To: drctalk@drcnet.org
Subject: ALASKA SUPREME COURT DECISION TO ALLOW ALL U.S. CITIZENS  TO
Message-ID: <3.0.32.19970330092430.00d9564c@cinenet.net>

Cannabis Freedom Fund
12021 Wilshire Blvd #356
Los Angeles CA 90025

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

DATE: March 27, 1997
CONTACT: Richard M. Davis
TEL:  (310) 442-9073

ALASKA SUPREME COURT DECISION ON CONSTITUTIONAL RIGHT TO PRIVACY MAY ALLOW
ALL U.S. CITIZENS TO SMOKE AND GROW MARIJUANA.

The Cannabis Freedom Fund (CFF), a new California political action
committee, plans a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the
nation's cannabis (marijuana) prohibition laws. The suit will be based on
the Alaska Supreme Court decision in Ravin vs State of Alaska, 537 P2d 494,
1975. The Alaska decision gave all adults in Alaska over the age of 19 the
right to both grow and smoke marijuana in the privacy of the home, based on
each citizen's fundamental right to privacy in the home.  This means that
the United States Government has known since 1975 that the prohibition of
cannabis in the other 49 states of the nation is unconstitutional.

The CFF points out that Section 2, Article 4 of the U.S. Constitution
reads: The citizens of each state shall be entitled to all privileges and
immunities of citizens in the several states.

As the government must be held to obey the law and adhere to the
Constitution, what is not clear is whether or not all Americans already
possess the fundamental right to smoke and grow marijuana in the privacy of
their homes, without further court action. The CFF is encouraging the
public to follow this case on the World Wide Web at:
http://www.cannabisfund.org .

Alaska has also rescheduled cannabis to Schedule IVA, which allows licensed
physicians to recommend its use without interference from the federal
government.  In light of the controversy over Proposition 215 in California
and Proposition 200 in Arizona, the Alaskan Supreme Court decision takes on
new importance.

The CFF mission is to end Cannabis Prohibition and insure a speedy return
to personal freedom in all uses of Cannabis. The group was formed by
California cannabis activists who recognize the tremendous potential
benefit to the American economy and environment represented by the
industrial use of cannabis hemp for paper, fiber, fuel, plastics, food,
medicine, and building materials. These uses are presently prohibited to
farmers in the U.S., while Canadian farmers are free to grow hemp in 1997.
Non- deductible donations to the CFF will help to speed the process of
bringing this vital issue to court.

Richard M. Davis
CANNABIS FREEDOM FUND
12021 Wilshire Blvd Ste. 366
Los Angeles, CA 90025
(310) 442-9073
 FAX: (310) 442-9072

Email: edna@gte.net          http://www.cannabisfund.org
Jim Rosenfield                      jnr@cinenet.net
tel:  310-836-0926                  fax:  310-836-0592
Website -> http://mall.turnpike.net/~jnr/jnr.htm

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Mar 31 00:06:18 1997

Received: from smtp.well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.4/V2.0) with ESMTP id AAA07819; Mon, 31 Mar 1997 00:06:11 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [206.15.69.74] (sf1-ppp53.well.com [206.15.69.53])
          by smtp.well.com (8.8.5/8.8.4) with SMTP
	  id AAA04715; Mon, 31 Mar 1997 00:05:31 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: leftjab@mail.well.com
Message-Id: <v02130507af651697ddcd@[206.15.69.74]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 31 Mar 1997 00:09:21 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: Re: ELF: FWD: challenging constitutionality of cannabis prohibition (fwd)(NRR)
Cc: jnr@cinenet.net
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Randy Cone just posted on sfraves:

>The Cannabis Freedom Fund (CFF), a new California political action
>committee, plans a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the
>nation's cannabis (marijuana) prohibition laws. The suit will be based on
>the Alaska Supreme Court decision in Ravin vs State of Alaska, 537 P2d 494,
>1975. The Alaska decision gave all adults in Alaska over the age of 19 the
>right to both grow and smoke marijuana in the privacy of the home, based on
>each citizen's fundamental right to privacy in the home.  This means that
>the United States Government has known since 1975 that the prohibition of
>cannabis in the other 49 states of the nation is unconstitutional.

Um, NO, NO, NO.  Quick legal lesson:  each state's constitution is
different than the U.S. constitution, and some states, such as California
and I believe Alaska as well, have a more explicit right to privacy than is
implicitly granted by the U.S. Constitution.  More to the point, no state
court (the case cited is a state court cite from the P.2d designation) has
any binding authority to interpret the U.S. Constitution -- a state court
only has the jurisdiction to interpret its own state laws in light of the
U.S. Constitution and its own state's constitution.  Any Alaska Supreme
Court decision about the U.S. Constitution (if indeed that is what the
decision did) is not binding on any other state court, any Federal Court,
or the U.S. Supreme Court.  If I had the money to do personal legal
research at home, I'd read the case now and see what the U.S. Supreme Court
had to say about this case (they probably declined the appeal and let it
stand without comment, for the usual and unstated reason that it agreed
with the Alaska court's interpretation of the Alaska constitution).  But in
any event, no state court can determine Constitutional law as it applies to
either Federal laws or the laws of other states.  The case could be
referred to, but it has no binding effect on a Federal court.

Finally, I also believe in the last few years -- perhaps the early 90's --
the people of Alaska voted to disallow people to grow at home.   Thus that
legal decision isn't even in effect now in Alaska, even if physicians can
recommend marijuana there.

This isn't a defense of Federal policy toward marijuana, or an argument
that there is no way to challenge it.  But in no way is it true that the
"U.S. Government has known since 1975 that the prohibition of cannabis in
the other 49 states of the nation is unconstitutional" due to the case
cited -- and I can say that just by knowing that case was a state case.

>The CFF points out that Section 2, Article 4 of the U.S. Constitution
>reads: The citizens of each state shall be entitled to all privileges and
>immunities of citizens in the several states.

I didn't think this could be applied to medical marijuana, which isn't a
constitutional right (sorry), but perhaps it could be ... but even then the
California and Arizona state statutes wouldn't let everyone grow in their
homes ...

In general, of course, you cannot trust legal opinions over the net, which
includes my own as well.  I'll check out the website to see if the gist of
the case is different than described, and I'll try to read the case soon
too.

>Alaska has also rescheduled cannabis to Schedule IVA, which allows licensed
>physicians to recommend its use without interference from the federal
>government.  In light of the controversy over Proposition 215 in California
>and Proposition 200 in Arizona, the Alaskan Supreme Court decision takes on
>new importance.

It can be seen as ahead of its time, but it has no additional legal
importance due to the passage in other states of medical marijuana laws
twenty years later.

>The CFF mission is to end Cannabis Prohibition and insure a speedy return
>to personal freedom in all uses of Cannabis. The group was formed by
>California cannabis activists who recognize the tremendous potential
>benefit to the American economy and environment represented by the
>industrial use of cannabis hemp for paper, fiber, fuel, plastics, food,
>medicine, and building materials. These uses are presently prohibited to
>farmers in the U.S., while Canadian farmers are free to grow hemp in 1997.

Best of luck, of course.  Perhaps the pot leaf should replace the maple
leaf on the Canadian flag!  But remember -- industrial hemp use could be
legalized without legalizing personal use, as industrial hemp doesn't get
you high, so it doesn't necessarily follow that pointing out the manifest
benefits of legalizing industrial hemp will lead to legalized personal
usage.

>Non- deductible donations to the CFF will help to speed the process of
>bringing this vital issue to court.

Not unless the legal arguments are different than represented here (or is
that the reason you need more money) ...

leftjab

<BR>&gt;Electronica Documentary Film
<BR>&gt;
<BR>&gt;FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
<BR>&gt;
<BR>&gt;Cleopatra Pictures to Produce Independent &quot;RAVE&quot; Film
<BR>&gt;
<BR>&gt;Cleopatra Pictures, a subsidiary of the Cleopatra Label Group, is
<BR>&gt;beginning production on RAVE,&nbsp; a documentary look at the burgeoning
<BR>&gt;worldwide electronica scene.
<BR>&gt;
<BR>&gt;The film will be directed by pioneering underground filmmaker Jonathan
<BR>&gt;Reiss, whose list of credits includes several documentaries of the
San
<BR>&gt;Francisco performance art group Survival Research Laboratories.
<BR>&gt;Jonathan's filmography is highlighted further by the award winning
<BR>&gt;shorts A Bitter Message Of Hopeless Grief and The Will to Provoke both
<BR>&gt;of which have screened in festivals, theaters and cultural centers
<BR>&gt;throughout the world. Reiss has also directed a number of&nbsp; highly
<BR>&gt;stylized music videos for bands such as Nine Inch Nails, The Black
<BR>&gt;Crowes and Type O Negative to name a few.&nbsp;
<BR>&gt;
<BR>&gt;In the spirit of such landmark music documentaries as The Decline of
<BR>&gt;Western Civilization, Urgh! A Music War,Wild Style and UKDK, RAVE will
<BR>&gt;feature performance footage and interviews with both new and developing
<BR>&gt;artists as well as some of the biggest names in the world of electronic
<BR>&gt;music, tentatively including the CHEMICAL BROTHERS, PRODIGY, ORBITAL,
<BR>&gt;UNDERWORLD, and MEAT BEAT&nbsp;
<BR>&gt;MANIFESTO. The film will also provide a behind-the-scenes perspective
<BR>&gt;through interviews with industry insiders such as rave and concert
<BR>&gt;promoter Philip Blaine, Los Angeles D.J. Jason Bentley and booking
<BR>&gt;agent Gerry Gerrard among many others.
<BR>&gt;
<BR>&gt;Production of RAVE will get under way March 21 at the 1997 Winter Music
<BR>&gt;Conference in Miami.&nbsp; The film is tentatively scheduled for release
in
<BR>&gt;the fall of 1997.&nbsp;
<BR>&gt;
<BR>&gt;For more information, please contact Brian McNelis at (213) 465-5438.
<BR>&gt;
<BR>&gt;

Hello all
   We just wanted to thank everyone here who made it to the 1st Sunset party
of the year on the 23rd of March.  We couldn't have asked for a more perfect
day between the weather, the sunset, the music, the comet, the lunar eclipse,
and all the smiling faces.  It was fantastic!!
   But there is an issue we want address, because I think people should know
how fragile of a space Pt. Molate NOW is!!   Previously in the year a group
went out to Pt. Molate with a sound system thinking it was just ok to have a
party there and no one would mind.  When they got there the fence was still
locked so they took upon themselves to cut a hole in the fence.  The police
pointed it out to us and remember the group that was there.  They didn't do
anything about it at the time but are now VERY PISSED OFF by the disrespect.
 The fence is military property and they don't like there belongings messed
with.  We were able to calm them thank them for being so tolerating but now
we have to go through an even more extensive permit process involving 2
police departments with the threat it could be taken away forever.  They are
no longer going to be as nice as in the past and will not deal with
soundsystems in the same manner.
      PLEASE  PLEASE  be careful!!!   This is one of the few places left
where the permit fees are not outragously out of reach.
     You know who you are if you did this.  Please, lets not make another
example of how a few people take away something that brings so many
happiness!!

                                       Thanks Again,
                            
                                             PaCiFiC sOuNd

Not exactly a rave, but anyone interested in combining technology with
music might be interested - David Cope uses computers to generate music
"in the style of" Mozart, etc, which is then played by a real orchestra.
Sometimes it's quite convincing!

For what it's worth....

- Martin  =]

========================================================================


        **Have you ever wondered how it would feel to be the first**
           in the world to hear new music by Mozart? This weekend,

                        Santa Cruz Baroque Festival
                        and UCSC Music Department's
                          'April in Santa Cruz'
                             proudly present

                     LADY LUCK: MUSIC BY DICE AND DESIGN
                                 in the new
                        UCSC Music Center Recital Hall
                         Saturday, April 5 at 8:00 pm

        Nicole Paiement returns to Santa Cruz to conduct a 17-member
        CLASSICAL ORCHESTRA of *historic instruments* in world premieres
        of a NEW PIANO CONCERTO and NEW SYMPHONY in the style of MOZART,
        as created by the ingenious computer program of UCSC Professor
        David Cope. 'Lady Luck: Music by Dice and Design' offers a
        most intriguing musical evening, including dances composed
        as musical dice-games by Mozart and Haydn. Join us, throw the
        dice and make your own minuet or polonaise, and check out the
        'new' Mozart orchestra works. Fortepiano soloist is Linda
        Burman-Hall.

        Pre-concert talk at 7:30 by David Cope included with admission.
        Concert at 8 is followed by a Question & Answer session with
        David.

         At-Door Ticket Prices:

        * music staff and faculty get one or two tickets for $1 each
        * students who are on the music major list at the Ticket Office
          can get one ticket for $1

        The remainder of the campus and public: (walk-up sales)
        * UC student (ltd supply):  $5.00
        * senior/non-ucsc student: $12.00
        * general:                 $15.00
               [Please note: There's an additional $2/order
               handling fee if the order is called or mailed in]

Ticket Office hours are Tues-Fr, noon-6pm, Sat 10am-4pm. Phone is 459-2159.
email is tickets@cats.ucsc.edu

for further information:

     April in Santa Cruz Festival--call UCSC Public Events 459-ARTS
     Santa Cruz Baroque Festival --call Voicemail at 457-9693

Linda Burman-Hall
Professor of Music
University of California
Santa Cruz, CA. 95064. USA.

Artistic Director, Santa Cruz Baroque Festival
Visit our Web Site:     http://www.sei.com/baroque/home.html
Linda's UCSC Web Site:  http://arts.ucsc.edu/faculty/Burman-Hall/
