You know you are from the Bay Area when... 
 
You make $100,000 a year, yet still can't find a place to live. 
 
Your commute time is 45 minutes and you live 8 miles away from work. 
 
Stop asking how much things cost but, ask "How long will it take?" 
 
Two-Thirds of the people you know are from Boston or New York, but you 
are living in PST. 
 
Know vast differences difference between Thai, Vietnemese, Chinese, 
Japanese, Cantonese, and Korean food. 
 
Your home computer contains mostly hardware/software that is not on the 
consumer market yet. 
 
Go to "The City" on weekends but don't live there because you like your car. 
 
Think that "I'm going to Fry's." is an acceptable excuse to leave the 
office for a while, and your boss does too. 
 
Lost your alarm clock. You'll get to work when you get there. 
 
Go to an industrial-heavy-metal bar and see two guys get into a fightover what 
flavor of Unix is better. 
 
Own more than 10 articles of cloathing that have hardware/software 
companies printed on them. Bonus for embroidered stuff. 
 
"Your best buys..." you know the rest. 
 
You know where Woz Way, Resistor Ave, and Floppy Dr are located. 
 
You know who Woz is. 
 
You know 280 North runs west, and 680 N runs East. 
 
Even though Microsoft employs quite a few programmers in the Bay Area, 
they only work on Powerpoint, and the company is still the embodiment 
of Satan. 
 
Even if their stock IS worth more than yours. 
 
You see a billboard that says "FPGA2ASIC" and aren't phased 
 
When you need the updated Diamond Monster 3D drivers, you just walk 
across the street. 
 
You have more bandwidth in your apartment or condo than most major 
universities. 
 
You have to hire security to keep the panhandlers off your terrace 
(Oakland/Berkeley). 
 
None of the people you work with are bible thumpers. 
 
You scan yardsales for back issues of "Dr. Dobbs." 
 
Your favorite computer reseller speaks only Cantonese. 
 
Your workplace vending machines dispense "100% natural twig-bars" right 
next to Jolt cola and Instant Espresso mix. 
 
No one brings radio's into work - they just use RealAudio and listen to 
thedj.com, rebelradio.com, or other out of state stations. 
 
Regards, 
 
Lucas Ritting 
 
"The 1990's will differ from the 1970's as profoundly as the nineteenth 
century from the eighteenth." 
				-Clive Sinclair

Hi everyone, how are we all?

I had a lot of fun at Symbiosis, I must thank everyone who helped  throw
this party.
I had a great time :o).

I got there around 10:00pm, they were still setting up. There was a
disturbing
smell of PaintThiner or something like that going on, but it went away
after
a while. I spend most of the night in the 'bubble'. which was basically the

smoking room. It was soo nice in there.  It was weird that everywhere I
looked,
people had mirrors...hummm..I think people must like looking at themselves.

The vibe was..different... I noticed that the E-ers, were not very
comfortable 
and some of them left early. I dunno. I had so much fun, I got so many
gifts from
so many beautiful people...

The music was cool, It was way fast.. ;O)

Oh well..I'll say more when my mind come back :o)
Pab

Marina.

>   But there is an issue we want address, because I think people should know
>how fragile of a space Pt. Molate NOW is!!   Previously in the year a group
>went out to Pt. Molate with a sound system thinking it was just ok to have a
>party there and no one would mind.  When they got there the fence was still
>locked so they took upon themselves to cut a hole in the fence.  The police
>pointed it out to us and remember the group that was there.  They didn't do
>anything about it at the time but are now VERY PISSED OFF by the disrespect.

If I remember the explanation by people who knew what happened, there is
one person who opens the gate to the fence, who basically can forget to
open it on a weekend even if people have gone through the correct process
to use the park.  Either they tried to get him to open it, or waited for a
while, before taking matters into their own hands.  Not that this
explanation justifies this action -- if you mess up property, you have to
deal with the consequences.

We'll see soon if we are improving at all ...

Apparently they did a case study some time ago.  They took gay men,
straight men, and homophobic men and subjected them all to homoerotic
material.  The gay men and the homophobic men both got aroused, while the
straight men got no reaction.

So in this society where it's really not OK for men to show each other
physical affection (I might add that this is apparently only true in
America...in like the Middle East men are friggin all over each other from
what I hear, gay or straight)...this is what can happen.

As someone who is totally ok with flirting with, and/or having
relationships with men or women (I do swing a little further one way...but
hey => )  I must say I think this study is true, because I have caught many
a guy who doesn't at least look gay (to today's standards) checkin me out,
of all people.

And I thought I was doomed because I have hair on the back of my neck!
Eww!  Well I guess I'll never qualify for MTV's Real World.  Bummer.

Any guys out there ever had this happen to you?  It happens to me all the
time...though I admit sometimes I'm doing the same thing.  eep.

Well...if this turns into another week-lomg thread...I just want you all to
know...filters rock!  =]

deep

I hate to add to threads but, I did not see to many reviews on cap N crunch
and I was wondering how many people on the list went? and I think jimmy
mentioned something on his VM that said "bust free event" or something to
that effect. I don't recall the exact words but it was something like that.
Promoters should watch what they say about bust free events, because bottom
line is that there are no "bust free" partys unless you use home base wich
has some type of permits and some other events obtain special permits. I
think promoters have a responsibilty to make this clear to there patrions
especially when you are shelling out $20 I don't think it is so bad if you
only spend like $5 or $10 that is somewhat bearable, and a event gets
busted. I know that jimmy and his crew tried there best and did what they
could. But you should not brag about being bust free or new spaces that are
bust free and they really are not, that is deceiving to your patrons and I
feel sorry for the kids that spent there hard earned money and did not get
to enjoy a party that was supposed to be bust free. Sorry for spaming the
list, I just think promoters and people need to be a little more reponsible
in what they promise.

*hugz4all*
Macadio

 Well, ever scence about the time of "Warmth", Organic has just been
*the* spot. And it's interesting to watch how the different promoters
have learned from one another and sort of "evolved" around the site. A
good example is the smoking situation.

First at Warmth, they had the far back room the Smoking Area. Which
worked, but I still saw plenty of people smoking around the place. Then
at 3000, only the top level was Non-Smoking. Cool as well, except that
the main dance floor was exposed and all that second hand smoke made it
hard to dance long, smoker or not.

Then, well actually I took a break and missed a weekend (or two?). Don't
know but I'm shure there were parties there.

Then at Comet there was the bubble. Much better, it was easier to access
and was well ventilated by the many windows. It was pretty crowed most
of the night, though. So Symbiosis simply made it a little bigger!

I love it: The underground adapting to it's environment. :)

-=Pengo=-
http://www.gcinutri.com/Pengo

     Lightseed was the best party I've been to in a looooong time.  Actually,
that whole night was wonderful!  I almost didn't make it due to a fight with my
parents, but I lied and they let me out for a while =)   I got pulled over on
the bridge going about 80, but I cried and the cop was nice and I get away!!!  
     I was all alone =(, but I met lots of new people (hi Feross, Jeremy,
Sophie, and all the pacifier babies!) and ran into lots of old people from my
brother's parties (hi Cy and Buck!) + the EBF crew (Hi Fernando!) .  Oh yeah,
and the SFraves people! (hi April, Laura, & Randy)  I only had $12 and a can of
food with me, and my new & old friends helped me panhandle so I caould gEt somE
yummEE stuff.  Thank you Mike for hooking me up for 10 bucks! 
     It was my first time at the 654 Mission Space, AND my first time hearing
Mystr-E spin even though I have 4 mixtapes.  HE WAS PHATTT!!!  So anyway, I had
to be home by 4am so I could go to work Saturday morning.  Bummer.  But it was
lots o' fun and lots o' LOVE & dancing while it lasted!
     Thank you and much love to:
             everyone who gave me money!!!
             everyone who helped me down the stairs
             everyone who helped me when I got sick =(
             the water boy for giving me free water
             Jeremy for the toys and love
             Sophie for dancin' all night!
             Randy for talking to me outside and helping me get sober enough to 
drive!
             everyone with Lightseed, Headwaters organization, and Food not
Bombs
             the numbers 6, 5, and 4 and the letter 'e'

Peace & Much Love to all my bruthas & sistas,

Just wanted to let all of you know of a chance to get involved in non-
commercial radio that's coming up; the KZSU organizational meeting.  This
is where one can find out about the different opportunities there are in
radio.  And if you're interested in doing the radio jock thing, you can
sign up for the dj training class.

---------- Begin include message ----------


From: Sean <sean@kzsu.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: KZSU Organizational Meeting


Friends of KZSU,

Our Spring Quarter Organizational Meeting is scheduled for April 2 and 
will be held in Bishop Auditorium, located in the Graduate School of 
Business (directly across from our studios).  

We welcome anyone (students and non-students) to come join us at 7:30pm
for a brief overview of the Stanford University radio station, as well as
a chance to meet our staff and find out how you can get involved in
college radio.  We will also be giving out applications for the Spring
Quarter Broadcast Training Class, for those of you interested in getting
on the air as a DJ. 


For directions or more information, call our Business Line at 415-725-4868.  


See you there,

Sean K.
General Manager 
KZSU Radio

p.s. feel free to pass this information along to friends...

---------- End included message ----------

From: Adam Gould <goolie@construct.net>

To: SF Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Attn: promoters using the cyborganic space
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970331184843.272t-100000@skippy.construct.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970331190042.272u-100000@skippy.construct.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ah well, i might as well get this off my chest.


First, let me say that Lightseed's Comet party was awesome.  Anon and
Myster-E totally went off (y'all blew Daft Punk outta the water, imo); the
vibe was great, it was for a good cause, etc.  Easily the best party I
went to this weekend. 

BUT.

If you are going to use the Cyborganic space, YOU MUST PROVIDE ADEQUATE
VENTILATION AND WATER.   Combine these things:
  
  * The hard 'n fast shit that folks on the dance floor are going to go
    off on;
  * A complete lack of any natural ventilation in the basement area;
  * Some fraction of the dancefloor population under the influence of
    whatever drugs they happen to be on (and who may or may not be in tune
    with what their bodies are needing, ie, get me some fucking water and
    take a break, dude) 
   

and you are just begging for trouble.  To wit:  on friday, i basically had
to carry this one poor fellow off the floor; he was suffering from
heatstroke symptoms (dizziness, hot flashes), was on E, and hadn't been
drinking water.   He was fine after i hooked him up with his friends, but
it could have been worse.  

I don't feel that the Lightseed party was properly ventilated, nor do i
feel that there were enough waterstations.  At parties I've been to there
before, there were at least 3 large, industrial fans on tall stands places
strategically about the downstairs space.  And while hot, I remember
parties such as Cloud Factory's as being (just) bearable.  At lightseed, I
counted one, maybe two fans.  I'd estimate that it was probably 90-100
degrees down there, and a good 90% humidity (all surface areas were
covered with so much condensation that, as one person has already
observed, it was literally raining indoors).  Most of the other parties
have also had a water table downstairs.

If you're throwing a party here, take some basic precautions in the
downstairs area:

  * FANS!!
  * WATER!!

I would like to see parties continue at this space; it's intimate, it's
private, and it doesn't get busted.  But, if you, as the promoter, don't
make contingencies for the natural limitations of the space, you are
increasing the probability that Bad Shit Will Happen, and the liable
person in that case isn't you, it's the cool guy who's letting us party in
his space (if you're a promoter and using that space, you should know who
he is: I do.). 


I'm sorry to come down so hard, but where people's health is concerned I'm
going to be an asshole.  

And hey, party people in da house:  in the end, your health is *your*
responsibility.  Listen to your body; if you're dizzy, get off the floor
and hydrate yourself and take a break.  That's what the chill area is for,
right? 



chillin' like bob dylan,  

--goolz

On Mon, 31 Mar 1997, Adam Gould wrote:

> feel that there were enough waterstations.  At parties I've been to there
> before, there were at least 3 large, industrial fans on tall stands places
> strategically about the downstairs space. 

	As a note to people using this space, it would be good to either
push or pull air through the ventilation holes in the sidewalk through the
doors to the sink. If you can remove the dust pan it will provide more air
flow (and would be possible then to mount one of those little high powered
fans in the opening). That's if anyone can figure out how to do it wiout
breaking it.
	Then, there is the other option of removing the shitty vents in
the door that leads to the sink and put one of the much larger industrial
fans blowing air from the sidewalk out through that hole. This is a bit
more difficult because you then need fans pushing air all the way back to
stairs, and then up...
	Or someone could work on getting the big fan in there working (the
power box has a big circuit for it if I remember correctly...

	Then as a note to people going to that space:
	I have never seen anyone taking water from people at the door. 
There is a time for bitching about what promoters need to provide at
parties, but damn, don't people going to parties have some responsibility
for themselves or are raves going to be baby sitting sessions?  Granted if
someone takes your water at the door, then the promoters need to provide
it inside, but that isn't the case here.

dave

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Here Are The Facts You Requested <hatfyr@slip.net>
Subject: Most of my friends
Message-Id: <E0wBvV5-0001pm-00@ferret>
Date: Mon, 31 Mar 1997 20:48:53 -0800
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Most of my friends are horrified when they learn that before I was a
peace-suckling ravechild, I was a member of the United States Armed Forces.

To friends in the States, I was The Boomerang; the stick that won't quit.
But to my comrades in the 211th Artillery Unit stationed on the Kuwait-Iraqi
border, I was known as Lt. Col. Boomerang Fidget.  Let me tell you, my
friends: it was hell.  

We  had sandstorms, diarrhea, and viruses you can't even pronounce.  No one
knew when Sodamn Insane would launch his next attack.  We lived in endless
fear of the bomb sirens.  Human life:  so solid and defined;  yet our only
constant is that we totter on the brink of death at every moment.

On September 15, PFC Anderson MacLain came into my tent.  "Lt.Col. Fidget!
he cried.  "General Fuss wants to see you in his tent, at once!"

I rushed to the General's tent.  
"Fidget,"  the General howled.  "I have an assignment for you!"
"Please, sir,"  I begged.  "Not latrine duty again.  "Last time, the other
fellas pushed me through the hole and laughed at me."

"Shut, up, Fidget!"  he snarled.  "Stop whining like a teenager in a damn
boyscout camp.  This is the reconaissance mission you've been waiting for.
I have a frightening mission for you."

I clicked my heels and stood up straight, just like they taught me in boot
camp.   

"OK, Fidget; here's the low-down.  We've spotted a swarm of aircraft heading
toward the camp.  I want you to go onto the southwest ridge and get a look
at them.  I need to know if they're friends, or enemies."

"Yes, Sir!"  I bellowed, and rushed out of the tent.  This was my big chance
to impresss my girl back home, and I had no time to waste.  I packed my M-16
and my binoculars, then PFC Anderson MacLain drove me to the foot of the
mountain.  From there I went on foot...alone.

At the crest of the ridge, I saw a swarm of fighter jets on the horizon,
blasting through the golden heat of the desert morning.  Sure enough, there
were at least thirty jets, heading our way, and fast.

"Charlie-Echo One to Base,"  I said into the radio.  "I've spotted thirty
planes heading our way from 27 degrees southwest."

"Fidget!"  the radio squawked.   "Before we launch a string of rockets and
blow these bastards out of the sky, we need to know:  are they friends, or
enemies?"

I took one last look through my binocs.  Sweat fell from my forehead in
dizzy anticipation of my patriotic reward.  This was my one chance to make a
stand and prove myself a man worthy of the United States Marine Corps.

"Well, Sir,"  I said into the radio.  "They're all flying side-by-side...so
I guess they're friends."

On Mon, 31 Mar 1997, Dave Bayer wrote:


> 	As a note to people using this space, it would be good to either
> push or pull air through the ventilation holes in the sidewalk through the
> doors to the sink. If you can remove the dust pan it will provide more air
> flow (and would be possible then to mount one of those little high powered
> fans in the opening). That's if anyone can figure out how to do it wiout
> breaking it.
> 	Then, there is the other option of removing the shitty vents in
> the door that leads to the sink and put one of the much larger industrial
> fans blowing air from the sidewalk out through that hole. This is a bit
> more difficult because you then need fans pushing air all the way back to
> stairs, and then up...
> 	Or someone could work on getting the big fan in there working (the
> power box has a big circuit for it if I remember correctly...

 I have had experience at keeping a hot, muggy/moist enviroment cool and 
dry. The big thing to do is _remove_ the hot moist air. Just pumping cold 
air in will not do it. The hot moist air is difficult to displace. 
Provide an adequete vent/air outlet(s) (preferably near the top of the 
dance floor as hot air rises) and stick the biggest fan you can on it to 
suck the hot air out of that area. If you have additional fans _then_ 
try to pump some cold air in. Also a big thing is to keep the air on the 
dance floor circulating so that the moisture has a chance to move out 
with the hot air.

 This message brought to you by Capricorn Mountain Air.



Ran D.Dreams 							408.427.1666



                                      (Namaste)
                                         /
                                   -=*=-/
                                     ~

Hmmm, I guess I was just focusing too much on the amazing music (which I
saw no mention of in your post) that was happening to worry about all the
drunken fools and cliquish poseurs.  I don't know, the vibe was pretty
thick in the middle of the dance floor when Jeno was spinning one of the
best sets I have ever heard from him and the boys from france were laying
down the grooves.  I saw lots of cool people that all smiled back when I
smiled at them.  I am sorry you had some bad experiences, but there was
definitely fun to be had and some incredible music to be enjoyed on a
crazy sound system out by the bay on a warm spring evening.  Oh, and virgin
prob. co-sponsored the thing because Daft Punk's record happens to be on
the label (it is a really f*cking good record, btw).  Did any other 
sfravers go to this and enjoy themselves?  Just curious. 

Cheers***
Cami

this is all strictly IMHO!!!!

> 	I have never seen anyone taking water from people at the door. 
> There is a time for bitching about what promoters need to provide at
> parties, but damn, don't people going to parties have some responsibility
> for themselves or are raves going to be baby sitting sessions?  Granted if
> someone takes your water at the door, then the promoters need to provide
> it inside, but that isn't the case here.


I absolutely agree that people should take responsibility for themselves,
but unfortunately:  a) people *don't* take responsibility for themselves,
and b) we live in a litigious society that more or less holds a venue
responsible for many of the the irresponsibilities of its patrons.
Therefore, the venue should be able to make a plausible case that they
provided an environment that minimized the chances of shit happening.


No, i'm not a lawyer.  I'm just concerned about being able to use the
space in the future is all. If i went over the top about that, I
apologize.

--goolz

greetings knowers of oneness !

four frineds and i have set out a couple months back to open up a shop in 
santa crus, spreading the psychedelic trance culture and vibe outward 
from that focal point. today that dream becomes a reality, --> the _Ion 
Exchange_ is fully operational...
we are located at 765 cedar street in santa cruz, suite 102, two doors 
down from Nub Circus. our phone # is 4o8.454.9976.
we mostly carry psychedelic/ goa trance records, CDs and mixtapes plus 
jungle and ambient. 
also we have spacetribe clothing, hemp clothes and jewelry, 
black lite banners, and soon drums and didjes and other things...

we are open noon to sometime around 7pm all week except sunday, or by 
appointment...



trance out!
